323: 
324: PREFACE TO THE FIRST EDITION 1781
325: 
326: 
327: Human reason, in one sphere of its cognition, is called upon to
328: consider questions, which it cannot decline, as they are presented by
329: its own nature, but which it cannot answer, as they transcend every
330: faculty of the mind.
331: 
332: It falls into this difficulty without any fault of its own. It begins
333: with principles, which cannot be dispensed with in the field of
334: experience, and the truth and sufficiency of which are, at the same
335: time, insured by experience. With these principles it rises, in
336: obedience to the laws of its own nature, to ever higher and more remote
337: conditions. But it quickly discovers that, in this way, its labours
338: must remain ever incomplete, because new questions never cease to
339: present themselves; and thus it finds itself compelled to have recourse
340: to principles which transcend the region of experience, while they are
341: regarded by common sense without distrust. It thus falls into confusion
342: and contradictions, from which it conjectures the presence of latent
343: errors, which, however, it is unable to discover, because the
344: principles it employs, transcending the limits of experience, cannot be
345: tested by that criterion. The arena of these endless contests is called
346: _Metaphysic_.
347: 
348: Time was, when she was the _queen_ of all the sciences; and, if we take
349: the will for the deed, she certainly deserves, so far as regards the
350: high importance of her object-matter, this title of honour. Now, it is
351: the fashion of the time to heap contempt and scorn upon her; and the
352: matron mourns, forlorn and forsaken, like Hecuba:
353: 
354: Modo maxima rerum,
355: Tot generis, natisque potens...
356: Nunc trahor exul, inops.
357: —Ovid, Metamorphoses. xiii
358: 
359: 
360: At first, her government, under the administration of the _dogmatists_,
361: was an absolute _despotism_. But, as the legislative continued to show
362: traces of the ancient barbaric rule, her empire gradually broke up, and
363: intestine wars introduced the reign of _anarchy;_ while the _sceptics_,
364: like nomadic tribes, who hate a permanent habitation and settled mode
365: of living, attacked from time to time those who had organized
366: themselves into civil communities. But their number was, very happily,
367: small; and thus they could not entirely put a stop to the exertions of
368: those who persisted in raising new edifices, although on no settled or
369: uniform plan. In recent times the hope dawned upon us of seeing those
370: disputes settled, and the legitimacy of her claims established by a
371: kind of _physiology_ of the human understanding—that of the celebrated
372: Locke. But it was found that—although it was affirmed that this
373: so-called queen could not refer her descent to any higher source than
374: that of common experience, a circumstance which necessarily brought
375: suspicion on her claims—as this _genealogy_ was incorrect, she
376: persisted in the advancement of her claims to sovereignty. Thus
377: metaphysics necessarily fell back into the antiquated and rotten
378: constitution of _dogmatism_, and again became obnoxious to the contempt
379: from which efforts had been made to save it. At present, as all
380: methods, according to the general persuasion, have been tried in vain,
381: there reigns nought but weariness and complete _indifferentism_—the
382: mother of chaos and night in the scientific world, but at the same time
383: the source of, or at least the prelude to, the re-creation and
384: reinstallation of a science, when it has fallen into confusion,
385: obscurity, and disuse from ill directed effort.
386: 
387: For it is in reality vain to profess _indifference_ in regard to such
388: inquiries, the object of which cannot be indifferent to humanity.
389: Besides, these pretended _indifferentists_, however much they may try
390: to disguise themselves by the assumption of a popular style and by
391: changes on the language of the schools, unavoidably fall into
392: metaphysical declarations and propositions, which they profess to
393: regard with so much contempt. At the same time, this indifference,
394: which has arisen in the world of science, and which relates to that
395: kind of knowledge which we should wish to see destroyed the last, is a
396: phenomenon that well deserves our attention and reflection. It is
397: plainly not the effect of the levity, but of the matured _judgement_[1]
398: of the age, which refuses to be any longer entertained with illusory
399: knowledge, It is, in fact, a call to reason, again to undertake the
400: most laborious of all tasks—that of self-examination, and to establish
401: a tribunal, which may secure it in its well-grounded claims, while it
402: pronounces against all baseless assumptions and pretensions, not in an
403: arbitrary manner, but according to its own eternal and unchangeable
404: laws. This tribunal is nothing less than the _Critical Investigation of
405: Pure Reason_.
406: 
407:  [1] We very often hear complaints of the shallowness of the present
408:  age, and of the decay of profound science. But I do not think that
409:  those which rest upon a secure foundation, such as mathematics,
410:  physical science, etc., in the least deserve this reproach, but that
411:  they rather maintain their ancient fame, and in the latter case,
412:  indeed, far surpass it. The same would be the case with the other
413:  kinds of cognition, if their principles were but firmly established.
414:  In the absence of this security, indifference, doubt, and finally,
415:  severe criticism are rather signs of a profound habit of thought. Our
416:  age is the age of criticism, to which everything must be subjected.
417:  The sacredness of religion, and the authority of legislation, are by
418:  many regarded as grounds of exemption from the examination of this
419:  tribunal. But, if they are exempted, they become the subjects of just
420:  suspicion, and cannot lay claim to sincere respect, which reason
421:  accords only to that which has stood the test of a free and public
422:  examination.
423: 
424: 
425: I do not mean by this a criticism of books and systems, but a critical
426: inquiry into the faculty of reason, with reference to the cognitions to
427: which it strives to attain _without the aid of experience;_ in other
428: words, the solution of the question regarding the possibility or
429: impossibility of metaphysics, and the determination of the origin, as
430: well as of the extent and limits of this science. All this must be done
431: on the basis of principles.
432: 
433: This path—the only one now remaining—has been entered upon by me; and I
434: flatter myself that I have, in this way, discovered the cause of—and
435: consequently the mode of removing—all the errors which have hitherto
436: set reason at variance with itself, in the sphere of non-empirical
437: thought. I have not returned an evasive answer to the questions of
438: reason, by alleging the inability and limitation of the faculties of
439: the mind; I have, on the contrary, examined them completely in the
440: light of principles, and, after having discovered the cause of the
441: doubts and contradictions into which reason fell, have solved them to
442: its perfect satisfaction. It is true, these questions have not been
443: solved as dogmatism, in its vain fancies and desires, had expected; for
444: it can only be satisfied by the exercise of magical arts, and of these
445: I have no knowledge. But neither do these come within the compass of
446: our mental powers; and it was the duty of philosophy to destroy the
447: illusions which had their origin in misconceptions, whatever darling
448: hopes and valued expectations may be ruined by its explanations. My
449: chief aim in this work has been thoroughness; and I make bold to say
450: that there is not a single metaphysical problem that does not find its
451: solution, or at least the key to its solution, here. Pure reason is a
452: perfect unity; and therefore, if the principle presented by it prove to
453: be insufficient for the solution of even a single one of those
454: questions to which the very nature of reason gives birth, we must
455: reject it, as we could not be perfectly certain of its sufficiency in
456: the case of the others.
457: 
458: While I say this, I think I see upon the countenance of the reader
459: signs of dissatisfaction mingled with contempt, when he hears
460: declarations which sound so boastful and extravagant; and yet they are
461: beyond comparison more moderate than those advanced by the commonest
462: author of the commonest philosophical programme, in which the dogmatist
463: professes to demonstrate the simple nature of the soul, or the
464: necessity of a primal being. Such a dogmatist promises to extend human
465: knowledge beyond the limits of possible experience; while I humbly
466: confess that this is completely beyond my power. Instead of any such
467: attempt, I confine myself to the examination of reason alone and its
468: pure thought; and I do not need to seek far for the sum-total of its
469: cognition, because it has its seat in my own mind. Besides, common
470: logic presents me with a complete and systematic catalogue of all the
471: simple operations of reason; and it is my task to answer the question
472: how far reason can go, without the material presented and the aid
473: furnished by experience.
474: 
475: So much for the completeness and thoroughness necessary in the
476: execution of the present task. The aims set before us are not
477: arbitrarily proposed, but are imposed upon us by the nature of
478: cognition itself.
479: 
480: The above remarks relate to the _matter_ of our critical inquiry. As
481: regards the _form_, there are two indispensable conditions, which any
482: one who undertakes so difficult a task as that of a critique of pure
483: reason, is bound to fulfil. These conditions are _certitude_ and
484: _clearness_.
485: 
486: As regards _certitude_, I have fully convinced myself that, in this
487: sphere of thought, _opinion_ is perfectly inadmissible, and that
488: everything which bears the least semblance of an hypothesis must be
489: excluded, as of no value in such discussions. For it is a necessary
490: condition of every cognition that is to be established upon _à priori_
491: grounds that it shall be held to be absolutely necessary; much more is
492: this the case with an attempt to determine all pure _à priori_
493: cognition, and to furnish the standard—and consequently an example—of
494: all apodeictic (philosophical) certitude. Whether I have succeeded in
495: what I professed to do, it is for the reader to determine; it is the
496: author’s business merely to adduce grounds and reasons, without
497: determining what influence these ought to have on the mind of his
498: judges. But, lest anything he may have said may become the innocent
499: cause of doubt in their minds, or tend to weaken the effect which his
500: arguments might otherwise produce—he may be allowed to point out those
501: passages which may occasion mistrust or difficulty, although these do
502: not concern the main purpose of the present work. He does this solely
503: with the view of removing from the mind of the reader any doubts which
504: might affect his judgement of the work as a whole, and in regard to its
505: ultimate aim.
506: 
507: I know no investigations more necessary for a full insight into the
508: nature of the faculty which we call _understanding_, and at the same
509: time for the determination of the rules and limits of its use, than
510: those undertaken in the second chapter of the “Transcendental
511: Analytic,” under the title of _Deduction of the Pure Conceptions of the
512: Understanding;_ and they have also cost me by far the greatest
513: labour—labour which, I hope, will not remain uncompensated. The view
514: there taken, which goes somewhat deeply into the subject, has two
515: sides. The one relates to the objects of the pure understanding, and is
516: intended to demonstrate and to render comprehensible the objective
517: validity of its _à priori_ conceptions; and it forms for this reason an
518: essential part of the Critique. The other considers the pure
519: understanding itself, its possibility and its powers of cognition—that
520: is, from a subjective point of view; and, although this exposition is
521: of great importance, it does not belong essentially to the main purpose
522: of the work, because the grand question is what and how much can reason
523: and understanding, apart from experience, cognize, and not, how is the
524: _faculty of thought_ itself possible? As the latter is an inquiry into
525: the cause of a given effect, and has thus in it some semblance of an
526: hypothesis (although, as I shall show on another occasion, this is
527: really not the fact), it would seem that, in the present instance, I
528: had allowed myself to enounce a mere _opinion_, and that the reader
529: must therefore be at liberty to hold a different _opinion_. But I beg
530: to remind him that, if my subjective deduction does not produce in his
531: mind the conviction of its certitude at which I aimed, the objective
532: deduction, with which alone the present work is properly concerned, is
533: in every respect satisfactory.
534: 
535: As regards _clearness_, the reader has a right to demand, in the first
536: place, _discursive_ or logical clearness, that is, on the basis of
537: conceptions, and, secondly, _intuitive_ or æsthetic clearness, by means
538: of intuitions, that is, by examples or other modes of illustration _in
539: concreto_. I have done what I could for the first kind of
540: intelligibility. This was essential to my purpose; and it thus became
541: the accidental cause of my inability to do complete justice to the
542: second requirement. I have been almost always at a loss, during the
543: progress of this work, how to settle this question. Examples and
544: illustrations always appeared to me necessary, and, in the first sketch
545: of the Critique, naturally fell into their proper places. But I very
546: soon became aware of the magnitude of my task, and the numerous
547: problems with which I should be engaged; and, as I perceived that this
548: critical investigation would, even if delivered in the driest
549: _scholastic_ manner, be far from being brief, I found it unadvisable to
550: enlarge it still more with examples and explanations, which are
551: necessary only from a _popular_ point of view. I was induced to take
552: this course from the consideration also that the present work is not
553: intended for popular use, that those devoted to science do not require
554: such helps, although they are always acceptable, and that they would
555: have materially interfered with my present purpose. Abbé Terrasson
556: remarks with great justice that, if we estimate the size of a work, not
557: from the number of its pages, but from the time which we require to
558: make ourselves master of it, it may be said of many a book—_that it
559: would be much shorter, if it were not so short_. On the other hand, as
560: regards the comprehensibility of a system of speculative cognition,
561: connected under a single principle, we may say with equal justice: many
562: a book would have been much clearer, if it had not been intended to be
563: so very clear. For explanations and examples, and other helps to
564: intelligibility, aid us in the comprehension of _parts_, but they
565: distract the attention, dissipate the mental power of the reader, and
566: stand in the way of his forming a clear conception of the _whole;_ as
567: he cannot attain soon enough to a survey of the system, and the
568: colouring and embellishments bestowed upon it prevent his observing its
569: articulation or organization—which is the most important consideration
570: with him, when he comes to judge of its unity and stability.
571: 
572: The reader must naturally have a strong inducement to co-operate with
573: the present author, if he has formed the intention of erecting a
574: complete and solid edifice of metaphysical science, according to the
575: plan now laid before him. Metaphysics, as here represented, is the only
576: science which admits of completion—and with little labour, if it is
577: united, in a short time; so that nothing will be left to future
578: generations except the task of illustrating and applying it
579: _didactically_. For this science is nothing more than the inventory of
580: all that is given us by _pure reason_, systematically arranged. Nothing
581: can escape our notice; for what reason produces from itself cannot lie
582: concealed, but must be brought to the light by reason itself, so soon
583: as we have discovered the common principle of the ideas we seek. The
584: perfect unity of this kind of cognitions, which are based upon pure
585: conceptions, and uninfluenced by any empirical element, or any peculiar
586: intuition leading to determinate experience, renders this completeness
587: not only practicable, but also necessary.
588: 
589: Tecum habita, et nôris quam sit tibi curta supellex.
590: —Persius. Satirae iv. 52.
591: 
592: 
593: Such a system of pure speculative reason I hope to be able to publish
594: under the title of _Metaphysic of Nature_[2]. The content of this work
595: (which will not be half so long) will be very much richer than that of
596: the present Critique, which has to discover the sources of this
597: cognition and expose the conditions of its possibility, and at the same
598: time to clear and level a fit foundation for the scientific edifice. In
599: the present work, I look for the patient hearing and the impartiality
600: of a _judge;_ in the other, for the good-will and assistance of a
601: _co-labourer_. For, however complete the list of _principles_ for this
602: system may be in the Critique, the correctness of the system requires
603: that no _deduced_ conceptions should be absent. These cannot be
604: presented _à priori_, but must be gradually discovered; and, while the
605: _synthesis_ of conceptions has been fully exhausted in the Critique, it
606: is necessary that, in the proposed work, the same should be the case
607: with their _analysis_. But this will be rather an amusement than a
608: labour.
609: 
610:  [2] In contradistinction to the Metaphysic of Ethics. This work was
611:  never published.
612: 
613: 
614: 
615: 
616: PREFACE TO THE SECOND EDITION 1787
617: 
618: 
619: Whether the treatment of that portion of our knowledge which lies
620: within the province of pure reason advances with that undeviating
621: certainty which characterizes the progress of _science_, we shall be at
622: no loss to determine. If we find those who are engaged in metaphysical
623: pursuits, unable to come to an understanding as to the method which
624: they ought to follow; if we find them, after the most elaborate
625: preparations, invariably brought to a stand before the goal is reached,
626: and compelled to retrace their steps and strike into fresh paths, we
627: may then feel quite sure that they are far from having attained to the
628: certainty of scientific progress and may rather be said to be merely
629: groping about in the dark. In these circumstances we shall render an
630: important service to reason if we succeed in simply indicating the path
631: along which it must travel, in order to arrive at any results—even if
632: it should be found necessary to abandon many of those aims which,
633: without reflection, have been proposed for its attainment.
634: 
635: That _Logic_ has advanced in this sure course, even from the earliest
636: times, is apparent from the fact that, since Aristotle, it has been
637: unable to advance a step and, thus, to all appearance has reached its
638: completion. For, if some of the moderns have thought to enlarge its
639: domain by introducing _psychological_ discussions on the mental
640: faculties, such as imagination and wit, _metaphysical_, discussions on
641: the origin of knowledge and the different kinds of certitude, according
642: to the difference of the objects (idealism, scepticism, and so on), or
643: _anthropological_ discussions on prejudices, their causes and remedies:
644: this attempt, on the part of these authors, only shows their ignorance
645: of the peculiar nature of logical science. We do not enlarge but
646: disfigure the sciences when we lose sight of their respective limits
647: and allow them to run into one another. Now logic is enclosed within
648: limits which admit of perfectly clear definition; it is a science which
649: has for its object nothing but the exposition and proof of the _formal_
650: laws of all thought, whether it be _à priori_ or empirical, whatever be
651: its origin or its object, and whatever the difficulties—natural or
652: accidental—which it encounters in the human mind.
653: 
654: The early success of logic must be attributed exclusively to the
655: narrowness of its field, in which abstraction may, or rather must, be
656: made of all the objects of cognition with their characteristic
657: distinctions, and in which the understanding has only to deal with
658: itself and with its own forms. It is, obviously, a much more difficult
659: task for reason to strike into the sure path of science, where it has
660: to deal not simply with itself, but with objects external to itself.
661: Hence, logic is properly only a _propædeutic_—forms, as it were, the
662: vestibule of the sciences; and while it is necessary to enable us to
663: form a correct judgement with regard to the various branches of
664: knowledge, still the acquisition of real, substantive knowledge is to
665: be sought only in the sciences properly so called, that is, in the
666: objective sciences.
667: 
668: Now these sciences, if they can be termed rational at all, must contain
669: elements of _à priori_ cognition, and this cognition may stand in a
670: twofold relation to its object. Either it may have to _determine_ the
671: conception of the object—which must be supplied extraneously, or it may
672: have to _establish its reality_. The former is _theoretical_, the
673: latter _practical_, rational cognition. In both, the _pure_ or _à
674: priori_ element must be treated first, and must be carefully
675: distinguished from that which is supplied from other sources. Any other
676: method can only lead to irremediable confusion.
677: 
678: _Mathematics_ and _physics_ are the two theoretical sciences which have
679: to determine their objects _à priori_. The former is purely _à priori_,
680: the latter is partially so, but is also dependent on other sources of
681: cognition.
682: 
683: In the earliest times of which history affords us any record,
684: _mathematics_ had already entered on the sure course of science, among
685: that wonderful nation, the Greeks. Still it is not to be supposed that
686: it was as easy for this science to strike into, or rather to construct
687: for itself, that royal road, as it was for logic, in which reason has
688: only to deal with itself. On the contrary, I believe that it must have
689: remained long—chiefly among the Egyptians—in the stage of blind groping
690: after its true aims and destination, and that it was revolutionized by
691: the happy idea of one man, who struck out and determined for all time
692: the path which this science must follow, and which admits of an
693: indefinite advancement. The history of this intellectual
694: revolution—much more important in its results than the discovery of the
695: passage round the celebrated Cape of Good Hope—and of its author, has
696: not been preserved. But Diogenes Laertius, in naming the supposed
697: discoverer of some of the simplest elements of geometrical
698: demonstration—elements which, according to the ordinary opinion, do not
699: even require to be proved—makes it apparent that the change introduced
700: by the first indication of this new path, must have seemed of the
701: utmost importance to the mathematicians of that age, and it has thus
702: been secured against the chance of oblivion. A new light must have
703: flashed on the mind of the first man (_Thales_, or whatever may have
704: been his name) who demonstrated the properties of the _isosceles_
705: triangle. For he found that it was not sufficient to meditate on the
706: figure, as it lay before his eyes, or the conception of it, as it
707: existed in his mind, and thus endeavour to get at the knowledge of its
708: properties, but that it was necessary to produce these properties, as
709: it were, by a positive _à priori construction;_ and that, in order to
710: arrive with certainty at _à priori_ cognition, he must not attribute to
711: the object any other properties than those which necessarily followed
712: from that which he had himself, in accordance with his conception,
713: placed in the object.
714: 
715: A much longer period elapsed before _Physics_ entered on the highway of
716: science. For it is only about a century and a half since the wise BACON
717: gave a new direction to physical studies, or rather—as others were
718: already on the right track—imparted fresh vigour to the pursuit of this
719: new direction. Here, too, as in the case of mathematics, we find
720: evidence of a rapid intellectual revolution. In the remarks which
721: follow I shall confine myself to the _empirical_ side of natural
722: science.
723: 
724: When GALILEI experimented with balls of a definite weight on the
725: inclined plane, when TORRICELLI caused the air to sustain a weight
726: which he had calculated beforehand to be equal to that of a definite
727: column of water, or when STAHL, at a later period, converted metals
728: into lime, and reconverted lime into metal, by the addition and
729: subtraction of certain elements;[3] a light broke upon all natural
730: philosophers. They learned that reason only perceives that which it
731: produces after its own design; that it must not be content to follow,
732: as it were, in the leading-strings of nature, but must proceed in
733: advance with principles of judgement according to unvarying laws, and
734: compel nature to reply its questions. For accidental observations, made
735: according to no preconceived plan, cannot be united under a necessary
736: law. But it is this that reason seeks for and requires. It is only the
737: principles of reason which can give to concordant phenomena the
738: validity of laws, and it is only when experiment is directed by these
739: rational principles that it can have any real utility. Reason must
740: approach nature with the view, indeed, of receiving information from
741: it, not, however, in the character of a pupil, who listens to all that
742: his master chooses to tell him, but in that of a judge, who compels the
743: witnesses to reply to those questions which he himself thinks fit to
744: propose. To this single idea must the revolution be ascribed, by which,
745: after groping in the dark for so many centuries, natural science was at
746: length conducted into the path of certain progress.
747: 
748:  [3] I do not here follow with exactness the history of the
749:  experimental method, of which, indeed, the first steps are involved in
750:  some obscurity.
751: 
752: 
753: We come now to _metaphysics_, a purely speculative science, which
754: occupies a completely isolated position and is entirely independent of
755: the teachings of experience. It deals with mere conceptions—not, like
756: mathematics, with conceptions applied to intuition—and in it, reason is
757: the pupil of itself alone. It is the oldest of the sciences, and would
758: still survive, even if all the rest were swallowed up in the abyss of
759: an all-destroying barbarism. But it has not yet had the good fortune to
760: attain to the sure scientific method. This will be apparent; if we
761: apply the tests which we proposed at the outset. We find that reason
762: perpetually comes to a stand, when it attempts to gain _à priori_ the
763: perception even of those laws which the most common experience
764: confirms. We find it compelled to retrace its steps in innumerable
765: instances, and to abandon the path on which it had entered, because
766: this does not lead to the desired result. We find, too, that those who
767: are engaged in metaphysical pursuits are far from being able to agree
768: among themselves, but that, on the contrary, this science appears to
769: furnish an arena specially adapted for the display of skill or the
770: exercise of strength in mock-contests—a field in which no combatant
771: ever yet succeeded in gaining an inch of ground, in which, at least, no
772: victory was ever yet crowned with permanent possession.
773: 
774: This leads us to inquire why it is that, in metaphysics, the sure path
775: of science has not hitherto been found. Shall we suppose that it is
776: impossible to discover it? Why then should nature have visited our
777: reason with restless aspirations after it, as if it were one of our
778: weightiest concerns? Nay, more, how little cause should we have to
779: place confidence in our reason, if it abandons us in a matter about
780: which, most of all, we desire to know the truth—and not only so, but
781: even allures us to the pursuit of vain phantoms, only to betray us in
782: the end? Or, if the path has only hitherto been missed, what
783: indications do we possess to guide us in a renewed investigation, and
784: to enable us to hope for greater success than has fallen to the lot of
785: our predecessors?
786: 
787: It appears to me that the examples of mathematics and natural
788: philosophy, which, as we have seen, were brought into their present
789: condition by a sudden revolution, are sufficiently remarkable to fix
790: our attention on the essential circumstances of the change which has
791: proved so advantageous to them, and to induce us to make the experiment
792: of imitating them, so far as the analogy which, as rational sciences,
793: they bear to metaphysics may permit. It has hitherto been assumed that
794: our cognition must conform to the objects; but all attempts to
795: ascertain anything about these objects _à priori_, by means of
796: conceptions, and thus to extend the range of our knowledge, have been
797: rendered abortive by this assumption. Let us then make the experiment
798: whether we may not be more successful in metaphysics, if we assume that
799: the objects must conform to our cognition. This appears, at all events,
800: to accord better with the _possibility_ of our gaining the end we have
801: in view, that is to say, of arriving at the cognition of objects _à
802: priori_, of determining something with respect to these objects, before
803: they are given to us. We here propose to do just what COPERNICUS did in
804: attempting to explain the celestial movements. When he found that he
805: could make no progress by assuming that all the heavenly bodies
806: revolved round the spectator, he reversed the process, and tried the
807: experiment of assuming that the spectator revolved, while the stars
808: remained at rest. We may make the same experiment with regard to the
809: intuition of objects. If the intuition must conform to the nature of
810: the objects, I do not see how we can know anything of them _à priori_.
811: If, on the other hand, the object conforms to the nature of our faculty
812: of intuition, I can then easily conceive the possibility of such an _à
813: priori_ knowledge. Now as I cannot rest in the mere intuitions, but—if
814: they are to become cognitions—must refer them, as _representations_, to
815: something, as _object_, and must determine the latter by means of the
816: former, here again there are two courses open to me. _Either_, first, I
817: may assume that the conceptions, by which I effect this determination,
818: conform to the object—and in this case I am reduced to the same
819: perplexity as before; _or_ secondly, I may assume that the objects, or,
820: which is the same thing, that _experience_, in which alone as given
821: objects they are cognized, conform to my conceptions—and then I am at
822: no loss how to proceed. For experience itself is a mode of cognition
823: which requires understanding. Before objects, are given to me, that is,
824: _à priori_, I must presuppose in myself laws of the understanding which
825: are expressed in conceptions _à priori_. To these conceptions, then,
826: all the objects of experience must necessarily conform. Now there are
827: objects which reason _thinks_, and that necessarily, but which cannot
828: be given in experience, or, at least, cannot be given _so_ as reason
829: thinks them. The attempt to think these objects will hereafter furnish
830: an excellent test of the new method of thought which we have adopted,
831: and which is based on the principle that we only cognize in things _à
832: priori_ that which we ourselves place in them.[4]
833: 
834:  [4] This method, accordingly, which we have borrowed from the natural
835:  philosopher, consists in seeking for the elements of pure reason in
836:  that _which admits of confirmation or refutation by experiment_. Now
837:  the propositions of pure reason, especially when they transcend the
838:  limits of possible experience, do not admit of our making any
839:  experiment with their _objects_, as in natural science. Hence, with
840:  regard to those _conceptions_ and _principles_ which we assume _à
841:  priori_, our only course will be to view them from two different
842:  sides. We must regard one and the same conception, _on the one hand_,
843:  in relation to experience as an object of the senses and of the
844:  understanding, _on the other hand_, in relation to reason, isolated
845:  and transcending the limits of experience, as an object of mere
846:  thought. Now if we find that, when we regard things from this double
847:  point of view, the result is in harmony with the principle of pure
848:  reason, but that, when we regard them from a single point of view,
849:  reason is involved in self-contradiction, then the experiment will
850:  establish the correctness of this distinction.
851: 
852: 
853: This attempt succeeds as well as we could desire, and promises to
854: metaphysics, in its first part—that is, where it is occupied with
855: conceptions _à priori_, of which the corresponding objects may be given
856: in experience—the certain course of science. For by this new method we
857: are enabled perfectly to explain the possibility of _à priori_
858: cognition, and, what is more, to demonstrate satisfactorily the laws
859: which lie _à priori_ at the foundation of nature, as the sum of the
860: objects of experience—neither of which was possible according to the
861: procedure hitherto followed. But from this deduction of the faculty of
862: _à priori_ cognition in the first part of metaphysics, we derive a
863: surprising result, and one which, to all appearance, militates against
864: the great end of metaphysics, as treated in the second part. For we
865: come to the conclusion that our faculty of cognition is unable to
866: transcend the limits of possible experience; and yet this is precisely
867: the most essential object of this science. The estimate of our rational
868: cognition _à priori_ at which we arrive is that it has only to do with
869: phenomena, and that things in themselves, while possessing a real
870: existence, lie beyond its sphere. Here we are enabled to put the
871: justice of this estimate to the test. For that which of necessity
872: impels us to transcend the limits of experience and of all phenomena is
873: the _unconditioned_, which reason absolutely requires in things as they
874: are in themselves, in order to complete the series of conditions. Now,
875: if it appears that when, on the one hand, we assume that our cognition
876: conforms to its objects as things in themselves, _the unconditioned
877: cannot be thought without contradiction_, and that when, on the other
878: hand, we assume that our representation of things as they are given to
879: us, does not conform to these things as they are in themselves, but
880: that these objects, as phenomena, conform to our mode of
881: representation, _the contradiction disappears:_ we shall then be
882: convinced of the truth of that which we began by assuming for the sake
883: of experiment; we may look upon it as established that the
884: unconditioned does not lie in things as we know them, or as they are
885: given to us, but in things as they are in themselves, beyond the range
886: of our cognition.[5]
887: 
888:  [5] This experiment of pure reason has a great similarity to that of
889:  the _Chemists_, which they term the experiment of _reduction_, or,
890:  more usually, the _synthetic_ process. The _analysis_ of the
891:  metaphysician separates pure cognition _à priori_ into two
892:  heterogeneous elements, viz., the cognition of things as phenomena,
893:  and of things in themselves. _Dialectic_ combines these again into
894:  harmony with the necessary rational idea of the unconditioned, and
895:  finds that this harmony never results except through the above
896:  distinction, which is, therefore, concluded to be just.
897: 
898: 
899: But, after we have thus denied the power of speculative reason to make
900: any progress in the sphere of the supersensible, it still remains for
901: our consideration whether data do not exist in _practical_ cognition
902: which may enable us to determine the transcendent conception of the
903: unconditioned, to rise beyond the limits of all possible experience
904: from a _practical_ point of view, and thus to satisfy the great ends of
905: metaphysics. Speculative reason has thus, at least, made room for such
906: an extension of our knowledge: and, if it must leave this space vacant,
907: still it does not rob us of the liberty to fill it up, if we can, by
908: means of practical data—nay, it even challenges us to make the
909: attempt.[6]
910: 
911:  [6] So the central laws of the movements of the heavenly bodies
912:  established the truth of that which Copernicus, first, assumed only as
913:  a hypothesis, and, at the same time, brought to light that invisible
914:  force (Newtonian attraction) which holds the universe together. The
915:  latter would have remained forever undiscovered, if Copernicus had not
916:  ventured on the experiment—contrary to the senses but still just—of
917:  looking for the observed movements not in the heavenly bodies, but in
918:  the spectator. In this Preface I treat the new metaphysical method as
919:  a hypothesis with the view of rendering apparent the first attempts at
920:  such a change of method, which are always hypothetical. But in the
921:  Critique itself it will be demonstrated, not hypothetically, but
922:  apodeictically, from the nature of our representations of space and
923:  time, and from the elementary conceptions of the understanding.
924: 
925: 
926: This attempt to introduce a complete revolution in the procedure of
927: metaphysics, after the _example_ of the geometricians and natural
928: philosophers, constitutes the aim of the Critique of Pure Speculative
929: Reason. It is a treatise on the method to be followed, not a system of
930: the science itself. But, at the same time, it marks out and defines
931: both the external boundaries and the internal structure of this
932: science. For pure speculative reason has this peculiarity, that, in
933: choosing the various objects of thought, it is able to define the
934: limits of its own faculties, and even to give a complete enumeration of
935: the possible modes of proposing problems to itself, and thus to sketch
936: out the entire system of metaphysics. For, on the one hand, in
937: cognition _à priori_, nothing must be attributed to the objects but
938: what the thinking subject derives from itself; and, on the other hand,
939: reason is, in regard to the principles of cognition, a perfectly
940: distinct, independent unity, in which, as in an organized body, every
941: member exists for the sake of the others, and all for the sake of each,
942: so that no principle can be viewed, with safety, in one relationship,
943: unless it is, at the same time, viewed in relation to the total use of
944: pure reason. Hence, too, metaphysics has this singular advantage—an
945: advantage which falls to the lot of no other science which has to do
946: with _objects_—that, if once it is conducted into the sure path of
947: science, by means of this criticism, it can then take in the whole
948: sphere of its cognitions, and can thus complete its work, and leave it
949: for the use of posterity, as a capital which can never receive fresh
950: accessions. For metaphysics has to deal only with principles and with
951: the limitations of its own employment as determined by these
952: principles. To this perfection it is, therefore, bound, as the
953: fundamental science, to attain, and to it the maxim may justly be
954: applied:
955: 
956:  Nil actum reputans, si quid superesset agendum.
957: 
958: 
959: But, it will be asked, what kind of a treasure is this that we propose
960: to bequeath to posterity? What is the real value of this system of
961: metaphysics, purified by criticism, and thereby reduced to a permanent
962: condition? A cursory view of the present work will lead to the
963: supposition that its use is merely _negative_, that it only serves to
964: warn us against venturing, with speculative reason, beyond the limits
965: of experience. This is, in fact, its primary use. But this, at once,
966: assumes a _positive_ value, when we observe that the principles with
967: which speculative reason endeavours to transcend its limits lead
968: inevitably, not to the _extension_, but to the _contraction_ of the use
969: of reason, inasmuch as they threaten to extend the limits of
970: sensibility, which is their proper sphere, over the entire realm of
971: thought and, thus, to supplant the pure (practical) use of reason. So
972: far, then, as this criticism is occupied in confining speculative
973: reason within its proper bounds, it is only negative; but, inasmuch as
974: it thereby, at the same time, removes an obstacle which impedes and
975: even threatens to destroy the use of practical reason, it possesses a
976: positive and very important value. In order to admit this, we have only
977: to be convinced that there is an absolutely necessary use of pure
978: reason—the moral use—in which it inevitably transcends the limits of
979: sensibility, without the aid of speculation, requiring only to be
980: insured against the effects of a speculation which would involve it in
981: contradiction with itself. To deny the positive advantage of the
982: service which this criticism renders us would be as absurd as to
983: maintain that the system of police is productive of no positive
984: benefit, since its main business is to prevent the violence which
985: citizen has to apprehend from citizen, that so each may pursue his
986: vocation in peace and security. That space and time are only forms of
987: sensible intuition, and hence are only conditions of the existence of
988: things as phenomena; that, moreover, we have no conceptions of the
989: understanding, and, consequently, no elements for the cognition of
990: things, except in so far as a corresponding intuition can be given to
991: these conceptions; that, accordingly, we can have no cognition of an
992: object, as a thing in itself, but only as an object of sensible
993: intuition, that is, as phenomenon—all this is proved in the analytical
994: part of the Critique; and from this the limitation of all possible
995: speculative cognition to the mere objects of _experience_, follows as a
996: necessary result. At the same time, it must be carefully borne in mind
997: that, while we surrender the power of _cognizing_, we still reserve the
998: power of _thinking_ objects, as things in themselves.[7] For,
999: otherwise, we should require to affirm the existence of an appearance,
1000: without something that appears—which would be absurd. Now let us
1001: suppose, for a moment, that we had not undertaken this criticism and,
1002: accordingly, had not drawn the necessary distinction between things as
1003: objects of experience and things as they are in themselves. The
1004: principle of causality, and, by consequence, the mechanism of nature as
1005: determined by causality, would then have absolute validity in relation
1006: to all things as efficient causes. I should then be unable to assert,
1007: with regard to one and the same being, e.g., the human soul, that its
1008: will is _free_, and yet, at the same time, subject to natural
1009: necessity, that is, _not free_, without falling into a palpable
1010: contradiction, for in both propositions I should take the soul in _the
1011: same signification_, as a thing in general, as a thing in itself—as,
1012: without previous criticism, I could not but take it. Suppose now, on
1013: the other hand, that we _have_ undertaken this criticism, and have
1014: learnt that an object may be taken in _two senses_, first, as a
1015: phenomenon, secondly, as a thing in itself; and that, according to the
1016: deduction of the conceptions of the understanding, the principle of
1017: causality has reference only to things in the first sense. We then see
1018: how it does not involve any contradiction to assert, on the one hand,
1019: that the will, in the phenomenal sphere—in visible action—is
1020: necessarily obedient to the law of nature, and, in so far, _not free;_
1021: and, on the other hand, that, as belonging to a thing in itself, it is
1022: not subject to that law, and, accordingly, is _free_. Now, it is true
1023: that I cannot, by means of speculative reason, and still less by
1024: empirical observation, _cognize_ my soul as a thing in itself and
1025: consequently, cannot cognize liberty as the property of a being to
1026: which I ascribe effects in the world of sense. For, to do so, I must
1027: cognize this being as existing, and yet not in time, which—since I
1028: cannot support my conception by any intuition—is impossible. At the
1029: same time, while I cannot _cognize_, I can quite well _think_ freedom,
1030: that is to say, my representation of it involves at least no
1031: contradiction, if we bear in mind the critical distinction of the two
1032: modes of representation (the sensible and the intellectual) and the
1033: consequent limitation of the conceptions of the pure understanding and
1034: of the principles which flow from them. Suppose now that morality
1035: necessarily presupposed liberty, in the strictest sense, as a property
1036: of our will; suppose that reason contained certain practical, original
1037: principles _à priori_, which were absolutely impossible without this
1038: presupposition; and suppose, at the same time, that speculative reason
1039: had proved that liberty was incapable of being thought at all. It would
1040: then follow that the moral presupposition must give way to the
1041: speculative affirmation, the opposite of which involves an obvious
1042: contradiction, and that _liberty_ and, with it, morality must yield to
1043: the _mechanism of nature;_ for the negation of morality involves no
1044: contradiction, except on the presupposition of liberty. Now morality
1045: does not require the speculative cognition of liberty; it is enough
1046: that I can think it, that its conception involves no contradiction,
1047: that it does not interfere with the mechanism of nature. But even this
1048: requirement we could not satisfy, if we had not learnt the twofold
1049: sense in which things may be taken; and it is only in this way that the
1050: doctrine of morality and the doctrine of nature are confined within
1051: their proper limits. For this result, then, we are indebted to a
1052: criticism which warns us of our unavoidable ignorance with regard to
1053: things in themselves, and establishes the necessary limitation of our
1054: theoretical _cognition_ to mere phenomena.
1055: 
1056:  [7] In order to _cognize_ an object, I must be able to prove its
1057:  possibility, either from its reality as attested by experience, or _à
1058:  priori_, by means of reason. But I can _think_ what I please, provided
1059:  only I do not contradict myself; that is, provided my conception is a
1060:  possible thought, though I may be unable to answer for the existence
1061:  of a corresponding object in the sum of possibilities. But something
1062:  more is required before I can attribute to such a conception objective
1063:  validity, that is real possibility—the other possibility being merely
1064:  logical. We are not, however, confined to theoretical sources of
1065:  cognition for the means of satisfying this additional requirement, but
1066:  may derive them from practical sources.
1067: 
1068: 
1069: The positive value of the critical principles of pure reason in
1070: relation to the conception of _God_ and of the _simple nature_ of the
1071: _soul_, admits of a similar exemplification; but on this point I shall
1072: not dwell. I cannot even make the assumption—as the practical interests
1073: of morality require—of God, freedom, and immortality, if I do not
1074: deprive speculative reason of its pretensions to transcendent insight.
1075: For to arrive at these, it must make use of principles which, in fact,
1076: extend only to the objects of possible experience, and which cannot be
1077: applied to objects beyond this sphere without converting them into
1078: phenomena, and thus rendering the _practical extension_ of pure reason
1079: impossible. I must, therefore, abolish _knowledge_, to make room for
1080: _belief_. The dogmatism of metaphysics, that is, the presumption that
1081: it is possible to advance in metaphysics without previous criticism, is
1082: the true source of the unbelief (always dogmatic) which militates
1083: against morality.
1084: 
1085: Thus, while it may be no very difficult task to bequeath a legacy to
1086: posterity, in the shape of a system of metaphysics constructed in
1087: accordance with the Critique of Pure Reason, still the value of such a
1088: bequest is not to be depreciated. It will render an important service
1089: to reason, by substituting the certainty of scientific method for that
1090: random groping after results without the guidance of principles, which
1091: has hitherto characterized the pursuit of metaphysical studies. It will
1092: render an important service to the inquiring mind of youth, by leading
1093: the student to apply his powers to the cultivation of genuine science,
1094: instead of wasting them, as at present, on speculations which can never
1095: lead to any result, or on the idle attempt to invent new ideas and
1096: opinions. But, above all, it will confer an inestimable benefit on
1097: morality and religion, by showing that all the objections urged against
1098: them may be silenced for ever by the _Socratic_ method, that is to say,
1099: by proving the ignorance of the objector. For, as the world has never
1100: been, and, no doubt, never will be without a system of metaphysics of
1101: one kind or another, it is the highest and weightiest concern of
1102: philosophy to render it powerless for harm, by closing up the sources
1103: of error.
1104: 
1105: This important change in the field of the sciences, this loss of its
1106: fancied possessions, to which speculative reason must submit, does not
1107: prove in any way detrimental to the general interests of humanity. The
1108: advantages which the world has derived from the teachings of pure
1109: reason are not at all impaired. The loss falls, in its whole extent, on
1110: the _monopoly of the schools_, but does not in the slightest degree
1111: touch the _interests of mankind_. I appeal to the most obstinate
1112: dogmatist, whether the proof of the continued existence of the soul
1113: after death, derived from the simplicity of its substance; of the
1114: freedom of the will in opposition to the general mechanism of nature,
1115: drawn from the subtle but impotent distinction of subjective and
1116: objective practical necessity; or of the existence of God, deduced from
1117: the conception of an _ens realissimum_—the contingency of the
1118: changeable, and the necessity of a prime mover, has ever been able to
1119: pass beyond the limits of the schools, to penetrate the public mind, or
1120: to exercise the slightest influence on its convictions. It must be
1121: admitted that this has not been the case and that, owing to the
1122: unfitness of the common understanding for such subtle speculations, it
1123: can never be expected to take place. On the contrary, it is plain that
1124: _the hope of a future life_ arises from the feeling, which exists in
1125: the breast of every man, that the temporal is inadequate to meet and
1126: satisfy the demands of his nature. In like manner, it cannot be doubted
1127: that the clear exhibition of duties in opposition to all the claims of
1128: inclination, gives rise to the consciousness of _freedom_, and that the
1129: glorious order, beauty, and providential care, everywhere displayed in
1130: nature, give rise to the belief in a wise and great Author of the
1131: Universe. Such is the genesis of these general convictions of mankind,
1132: so far as they depend on rational grounds; and this public property not
1133: only remains undisturbed, but is even raised to greater importance, by
1134: the doctrine that the schools have no right to arrogate to themselves a
1135: more profound insight into a matter of general human concernment than
1136: that to which the great mass of men, ever held by us in the highest
1137: estimation, can without difficulty attain, and that the schools should,
1138: therefore, confine themselves to the elaboration of these universally
1139: comprehensible and, from a moral point of view, amply satisfactory
1140: proofs. The change, therefore, affects only the arrogant pretensions of
1141: the schools, which would gladly retain, in their own exclusive
1142: possession, the key to the truths which they impart to the public.
1143: 
1144:  Quod mecum nescit, solus vult scire videri.
1145: 
1146: 
1147: At the same time it does not deprive the speculative philosopher of his
1148: just title to be the sole depositor of a science which benefits the
1149: public without its knowledge—I mean, the Critique of Pure Reason. This
1150: can never become popular and, indeed, has no occasion to be so; for
1151: finespun arguments in favour of useful truths make just as little
1152: impression on the public mind as the equally subtle objections brought
1153: against these truths. On the other hand, since both inevitably force
1154: themselves on every man who rises to the height of speculation, it
1155: becomes the manifest duty of the schools to enter upon a thorough
1156: investigation of the rights of speculative reason and, thus, to prevent
1157: the scandal which metaphysical controversies are sure, sooner or later,
1158: to cause even to the masses. It is only by criticism that
1159: metaphysicians (and, as such, theologians too) can be saved from these
1160: controversies and from the consequent perversion of their doctrines.
1161: Criticism alone can strike a blow at the root of materialism, fatalism,
1162: atheism, free-thinking, fanaticism, and superstition, which are
1163: universally injurious—as well as of idealism and scepticism, which are
1164: dangerous to the schools, but can scarcely pass over to the public. If
1165: governments think proper to interfere with the affairs of the learned,
1166: it would be more consistent with a wise regard for the interests of
1167: science, as well as for those of society, to favour a criticism of this
1168: kind, by which alone the labours of reason can be established on a firm
1169: basis, than to support the ridiculous despotism of the schools, which
1170: raise a loud cry of danger to the public over the destruction of
1171: cobwebs, of which the public has never taken any notice, and the loss
1172: of which, therefore, it can never feel.
1173: 
1174: This critical science is not opposed to the _dogmatic procedure_ of
1175: reason in pure cognition; for pure cognition must always be dogmatic,
1176: that is, must rest on strict demonstration from sure principles _à
1177: priori_—but to _dogmatism_, that is, to the presumption that it is
1178: possible to make any progress with a pure cognition, derived from
1179: (philosophical) conceptions, according to the principles which reason
1180: has long been in the habit of employing—without first inquiring in what
1181: way and by what right reason has come into the possession of these
1182: principles. Dogmatism is thus the dogmatic procedure of pure reason
1183: _without previous criticism of its own powers_, and in opposing this
1184: procedure, we must not be supposed to lend any countenance to that
1185: loquacious shallowness which arrogates to itself the name of
1186: popularity, nor yet to scepticism, which makes short work with the
1187: whole science of metaphysics. On the contrary, our criticism is the
1188: necessary preparation for a thoroughly scientific system of metaphysics
1189: which must perform its task entirely _à priori_, to the complete
1190: satisfaction of speculative reason, and must, therefore, be treated,
1191: not popularly, but scholastically. In carrying out the plan which the
1192: Critique prescribes, that is, in the future system of metaphysics, we
1193: must have recourse to the strict method of the celebrated WOLF, the
1194: greatest of all dogmatic philosophers. He was the first to point out
1195: the necessity of establishing fixed principles, of clearly defining our
1196: conceptions, and of subjecting our demonstrations to the most severe
1197: scrutiny, instead of rashly jumping at conclusions. The example which
1198: he set served to awaken that spirit of profound and thorough
1199: investigation which is not yet extinct in Germany. He would have been
1200: peculiarly well fitted to give a truly scientific character to
1201: metaphysical studies, had it occurred to him to prepare the field by a
1202: criticism of the _organum_, that is, of pure reason itself. That he
1203: failed to perceive the necessity of such a procedure must be ascribed
1204: to the dogmatic mode of thought which characterized his age, and on
1205: this point the philosophers of his time, as well as of all previous
1206: times, have nothing to reproach each other with. Those who reject at
1207: once the method of Wolf, and of the Critique of Pure Reason, can have
1208: no other aim but to shake off the fetters of _science_, to change
1209: labour into sport, certainty into opinion, and philosophy into
1210: philodoxy.
1211: 
1212: In this _second edition_, I have endeavoured, as far as possible, to
1213: remove the difficulties and obscurity which, without fault of mine
1214: perhaps, have given rise to many misconceptions even among acute
1215: thinkers. In the propositions themselves, and in the demonstrations by
1216: which they are supported, as well as in the form and the entire plan of
1217: the work, I have found nothing to alter; which must be attributed
1218: partly to the long examination to which I had subjected the whole
1219: before offering it to the public and partly to the nature of the case.
1220: For pure speculative reason is an organic structure in which there is
1221: nothing isolated or independent, but every Single part is essential to
1222: all the rest; and hence, the slightest imperfection, whether defect or
1223: positive error, could not fail to betray itself in use. I venture,
1224: further, to hope, that this system will maintain the same unalterable
1225: character for the future. I am led to entertain this confidence, not by
1226: vanity, but by the evidence which the equality of the result affords,
1227: when we proceed, first, from the simplest elements up to the complete
1228: whole of pure reason and, and then, backwards from the whole to each
1229: part. We find that the attempt to make the slightest alteration, in any
1230: part, leads inevitably to contradictions, not merely in this system,
1231: but in human reason itself. At the same time, there is still much room
1232: for improvement in the _exposition_ of the doctrines contained in this
1233: work. In the present edition, I have endeavoured to remove
1234: misapprehensions of the æsthetical part, especially with regard to the
1235: conception of time; to clear away the obscurity which has been found in
1236: the deduction of the conceptions of the understanding; to supply the
1237: supposed want of sufficient evidence in the demonstration of the
1238: principles of the pure understanding; and, lastly, to obviate the
1239: misunderstanding of the paralogisms which immediately precede the
1240: Rational Psychology. Beyond this point—the end of the second main
1241: division of the “Transcendental Dialectic”—I have not extended my
1242: alterations,[8] partly from want of time, and partly because I am not
1243: aware that any portion of the remainder has given rise to
1244: misconceptions among intelligent and impartial critics, whom I do not
1245: here mention with that praise which is their due, but who will find
1246: that their suggestions have been attended to in the work itself.
1247: 
1248:  [8] The only addition, properly so called—and that only in the method
1249:  of proof—which I have made in the present edition, consists of a new
1250:  refutation of psychological _Idealism_, and a strict demonstration—the
1251:  only one possible, as I believe—of the objective reality of external
1252:  intuition. However harmless idealism may be considered—although in
1253:  reality it is not so—in regard to the essential ends of metaphysics,
1254:  it must still remain a scandal to philosophy and to the general human
1255:  reason to be obliged to assume, as an article of mere belief, the
1256:  existence of things external to ourselves (from which, yet, we derive
1257:  the whole material of cognition for the internal sense), and not to be
1258:  able to oppose a satisfactory proof to any one who may call it in
1259:  question. As there is some obscurity of expression in the
1260:  demonstration as it stands in the text, I propose to alter the passage
1261:  in question as follows: “But this permanent cannot be an intuition in
1262:  me. For all the determining grounds of my existence which can be found
1263:  in me are representations and, as such, do themselves require a
1264:  permanent, distinct from them, which may determine my existence in
1265:  relation to their changes, that is, my existence in time, wherein they
1266:  change.” It may, probably, be urged in opposition to this proof that,
1267:  after all, I am only conscious immediately of that which is in me,
1268:  that is, of my _representation_ of external things, and that,
1269:  consequently, it must always remain uncertain whether anything
1270:  corresponding to this representation does or does not exist externally
1271:  to me. But I am conscious, through internal _experience_, of my
1272:  _existence in time_ (consequently, also, of the determinability of the
1273:  former in the latter), and that is more than the simple consciousness
1274:  of my representation. It is, in fact, the same as the _empirical
1275:  consciousness of my existence_, which can only be determined in
1276:  relation to something, which, while connected with my existence, is
1277:  _external to me_. This consciousness of my existence in time is,
1278:  therefore, identical with the consciousness of a relation to something
1279:  external to me, and it is, therefore, experience, not fiction, sense,
1280:  not imagination, which inseparably connects the external with my
1281:  internal sense. For the external sense is, in itself, the relation of
1282:  intuition to something real, external to me; and the reality of this
1283:  something, as opposed to the mere imagination of it, rests solely on
1284:  its inseparable connection with internal experience as the condition
1285:  of its possibility. If with the _intellectual consciousness_ of my
1286:  existence, in the representation: _I am_, which accompanies all my
1287:  judgements, and all the operations of my understanding, I could, at
1288:  the same time, connect a determination of my existence by
1289:  _intellectual intuition_, then the consciousness of a relation to
1290:  something external to me would not be necessary. But the internal
1291:  intuition in which alone my existence can be determined, though
1292:  preceded by that purely intellectual consciousness, is itself sensible
1293:  and attached to the condition of time. Hence this determination of my
1294:  existence, and consequently my internal experience itself, must depend
1295:  on something permanent which is not in me, which can be, therefore,
1296:  only in something external to me, to which I must look upon myself as
1297:  being related. Thus the reality of the external sense is necessarily
1298:  connected with that of the internal, in order to the possibility of
1299:  experience in general; that is, I am just as certainly conscious that
1300:  there are things external to me related to my sense as I am that I
1301:  myself exist as determined in time. But in order to ascertain to what
1302:  given intuitions objects, external me, really correspond, in other
1303:  words, what intuitions belong to the external sense and not to
1304:  imagination, I must have recourse, in every particular case, to those
1305:  rules according to which experience in general (even internal
1306:  experience) is distinguished from imagination, and which are always
1307:  based on the proposition that there really is an external
1308:  experience.—We may add the remark that the representation of something
1309:  _permanent_ in existence, is not the same thing as the _permanent
1310:  representation;_ for a representation may be very variable and
1311:  changing—as all our representations, even that of matter, are—and yet
1312:  refer to something permanent, which must, therefore, be distinct from
1313:  all my representations and external to me, the existence of which is
1314:  necessarily included in the determination of my own existence, and
1315:  with it constitutes _one_ experience—an experience which would not
1316:  even be possible internally, if it were not also at the same time, in
1317:  part, external. To the question _How?_ we are no more able to reply,
1318:  than we are, in general, to think the stationary in time, the
1319:  coexistence of which with the variable, produces the conception of
1320:  change.
1321: 
1322: 
1323: In attempting to render the exposition of my views as intelligible as
1324: possible, I have been compelled to leave out or abridge various
1325: passages which were not essential to the completeness of the work, but
1326: which many readers might consider useful in other respects, and might
1327: be unwilling to miss. This trifling loss, which could not be avoided
1328: without swelling the book beyond due limits, may be supplied, at the
1329: pleasure of the reader, by a comparison with the first edition, and
1330: will, I hope, be more than compensated for by the greater clearness of
1331: the exposition as it now stands.
1332: 
1333: I have observed, with pleasure and thankfulness, in the pages of
1334: various reviews and treatises, that the spirit of profound and thorough
1335: investigation is not extinct in Germany, though it may have been
1336: overborne and silenced for a time by the fashionable tone of a licence
1337: in thinking, which gives itself the airs of genius, and that the
1338: difficulties which beset the paths of criticism have not prevented
1339: energetic and acute thinkers from making themselves masters of the
1340: science of pure reason to which these paths conduct—a science which is
1341: not popular, but scholastic in its character, and which alone can hope
1342: for a lasting existence or possess an abiding value. To these deserving
1343: men, who so happily combine profundity of view with a talent for lucid
1344: exposition—a talent which I myself am not conscious of possessing—I
1345: leave the task of removing any obscurity which may still adhere to the
1346: statement of my doctrines. For, in this case, the danger is not that of
1347: being refuted, but of being misunderstood. For my own part, I must
1348: henceforward abstain from controversy, although I shall carefully
1349: attend to all suggestions, whether from friends or adversaries, which
1350: may be of use in the future elaboration of the system of this
1351: Propædeutic. As, during these labours, I have advanced pretty far in
1352: years this month I reach my sixty-fourth year—it will be necessary for
1353: me to economize time, if I am to carry out my plan of elaborating the
1354: metaphysics of nature as well as of morals, in confirmation of the
1355: correctness of the principles established in this Critique of Pure
1356: Reason, both speculative and practical; and I must, therefore, leave
1357: the task of clearing up the obscurities of the present work—inevitable,
1358: perhaps, at the outset—as well as, the defence of the whole, to those
1359: deserving men, who have made my system their own. A philosophical
1360: system cannot come forward armed at all points like a mathematical
1361: treatise, and hence it may be quite possible to take objection to
1362: particular passages, while the organic structure of the system,
1363: considered as a unity, has no danger to apprehend. But few possess the
1364: ability, and still fewer the inclination, to take a comprehensive view
1365: of a new system. By confining the view to particular passages, taking
1366: these out of their connection and comparing them with one another, it
1367: is easy to pick out apparent contradictions, especially in a work
1368: written with any freedom of style. These contradictions place the work
1369: in an unfavourable light in the eyes of those who rely on the judgement
1370: of others, but are easily reconciled by those who have mastered the
1371: idea of the whole. If a theory possesses stability in itself, the
1372: action and reaction which seemed at first to threaten its existence
1373: serve only, in the course of time, to smooth down any superficial
1374: roughness or inequality, and—if men of insight, impartiality, and truly
1375: popular gifts, turn their attention to it—to secure to it, in a short
1376: time, the requisite elegance also.
1377: 
1378: KÖNIGSBERG, _April_ 1787.
1379: 
1380: 
1381: 
1382: 
1383: Introduction
1384: 
1385: I. Of the difference between Pure and Empirical Knowledge
1386: 
1387: 
1388: That all our knowledge begins with experience there can be no doubt.
1389: For how is it possible that the faculty of cognition should be awakened
1390: into exercise otherwise than by means of objects which affect our
1391: senses, and partly of themselves produce representations, partly rouse
1392: our powers of understanding into activity, to compare to connect, or to
1393: separate these, and so to convert the raw material of our sensuous
1394: impressions into a knowledge of objects, which is called experience? In
1395: respect of time, therefore, no knowledge of ours is antecedent to
1396: experience, but begins with it.
1397: 
1398: But, though all our knowledge begins with experience, it by no means
1399: follows that all arises out of experience. For, on the contrary, it is
1400: quite possible that our empirical knowledge is a compound of that which
1401: we receive through impressions, and that which the faculty of cognition
1402: supplies from itself (sensuous impressions giving merely the occasion),
1403: an addition which we cannot distinguish from the original element given
1404: by sense, till long practice has made us attentive to, and skilful in
1405: separating it. It is, therefore, a question which requires close
1406: investigation, and not to be answered at first sight, whether there
1407: exists a knowledge altogether independent of experience, and even of
1408: all sensuous impressions? Knowledge of this kind is called à priori, in
1409: contradistinction to empirical knowledge, which has its sources à
1410: posteriori, that is, in experience.
1411: 
1412: But the expression, “à priori,” is not as yet definite enough
1413: adequately to indicate the whole meaning of the question above started.
1414: For, in speaking of knowledge which has its sources in experience, we
1415: are wont to say, that this or that may be known à priori, because we do
1416: not derive this knowledge immediately from experience, but from a
1417: general rule, which, however, we have itself borrowed from experience.
1418: Thus, if a man undermined his house, we say, “he might know à priori
1419: that it would have fallen;” that is, he needed not to have waited for
1420: the experience that it did actually fall. But still, à priori, he could
1421: not know even this much. For, that bodies are heavy, and, consequently,
1422: that they fall when their supports are taken away, must have been known
1423: to him previously, by means of experience.
1424: 
1425: By the term “knowledge à priori,” therefore, we shall in the sequel
1426: understand, not such as is independent of this or that kind of
1427: experience, but such as is absolutely so of all experience. Opposed to
1428: this is empirical knowledge, or that which is possible only à
1429: posteriori, that is, through experience. Knowledge à priori is either
1430: pure or impure. Pure knowledge à priori is that with which no empirical
1431: element is mixed up. For example, the proposition, “Every change has a
1432: cause,” is a proposition à priori, but impure, because change is a
1433: conception which can only be derived from experience.
1434: 
1435: II. The Human Intellect, even in an Unphilosophical State, is in
1436: Possession of Certain Cognitions “à priori”.
1437: 
1438: The question now is as to a criterion, by which we may securely
1439: distinguish a pure from an empirical cognition. Experience no doubt
1440: teaches us that this or that object is constituted in such and such a
1441: manner, but not that it could not possibly exist otherwise. Now, in the
1442: first place, if we have a proposition which contains the idea of
1443: necessity in its very conception, it is priori. If, moreover, it is not
1444: derived from any other proposition, unless from one equally involving
1445: the idea of necessity, it is absolutely priori. Secondly, an empirical
1446: judgement never exhibits strict and absolute, but only assumed and
1447: comparative universality (by induction); therefore, the most we can say
1448: is—so far as we have hitherto observed, there is no exception to this
1449: or that rule. If, on the other hand, a judgement carries with it strict
1450: and absolute universality, that is, admits of no possible exception, it
1451: is not derived from experience, but is valid absolutely à priori.
1452: 
1453: Empirical universality is, therefore, only an arbitrary extension of
1454: validity, from that which may be predicated of a proposition valid in
1455: most cases, to that which is asserted of a proposition which holds good
1456: in all; as, for example, in the affirmation, “All bodies are heavy.”
1457: When, on the contrary, strict universality characterizes a judgement,
1458: it necessarily indicates another peculiar source of knowledge, namely,
1459: a faculty of cognition à priori. Necessity and strict universality,
1460: therefore, are infallible tests for distinguishing pure from empirical
1461: knowledge, and are inseparably connected with each other. But as in the
1462: use of these criteria the empirical limitation is sometimes more easily
1463: detected than the contingency of the judgement, or the unlimited
1464: universality which we attach to a judgement is often a more convincing
1465: proof than its necessity, it may be advisable to use the criteria
1466: separately, each being by itself infallible.
1467: 
1468: Now, that in the sphere of human cognition we have judgements which are
1469: necessary, and in the strictest sense universal, consequently pure à
1470: priori, it will be an easy matter to show. If we desire an example from
1471: the sciences, we need only take any proposition in mathematics. If we
1472: cast our eyes upon the commonest operations of the understanding, the
1473: proposition, “Every change must have a cause,” will amply serve our
1474: purpose. In the latter case, indeed, the conception of a cause so
1475: plainly involves the conception of a necessity of connection with an
1476: effect, and of a strict universality of the law, that the very notion
1477: of a cause would entirely disappear, were we to derive it, like Hume,
1478: from a frequent association of what happens with that which precedes;
1479: and the habit thence originating of connecting representations—the
1480: necessity inherent in the judgement being therefore merely subjective.
1481: Besides, without seeking for such examples of principles existing à
1482: priori in cognition, we might easily show that such principles are the
1483: indispensable basis of the possibility of experience itself, and
1484: consequently prove their existence à priori. For whence could our
1485: experience itself acquire certainty, if all the rules on which it
1486: depends were themselves empirical, and consequently fortuitous? No one,
1487: therefore, can admit the validity of the use of such rules as first
1488: principles. But, for the present, we may content ourselves with having
1489: established the fact, that we do possess and exercise a faculty of pure
1490: à priori cognition; and, secondly, with having pointed out the proper
1491: tests of such cognition, namely, universality and necessity.
1492: 
1493: Not only in judgements, however, but even in conceptions, is an à
