1494: priori origin manifest. For example, if we take away by degrees from
1495: our conceptions of a body all that can be referred to mere sensuous
1496: experience—colour, hardness or softness, weight, even
1497: impenetrability—the body will then vanish; but the space which it
1498: occupied still remains, and this it is utterly impossible to annihilate
1499: in thought. Again, if we take away, in like manner, from our empirical
1500: conception of any object, corporeal or incorporeal, all properties
1501: which mere experience has taught us to connect with it, still we cannot
1502: think away those through which we cogitate it as substance, or adhering
1503: to substance, although our conception of substance is more determined
1504: than that of an object. Compelled, therefore, by that necessity with
1505: which the conception of substance forces itself upon us, we must
1506: confess that it has its seat in our faculty of cognition à priori.
1507: 
1508: III. Philosophy stands in need of a Science which shall Determine the
1509: Possibility, Principles, and Extent of Human Knowledge “à priori”
1510: 
1511: Of far more importance than all that has been above said, is the
1512: consideration that certain of our cognitions rise completely above the
1513: sphere of all possible experience, and by means of conceptions, to
1514: which there exists in the whole extent of experience no corresponding
1515: object, seem to extend the range of our judgements beyond its bounds.
1516: And just in this transcendental or supersensible sphere, where
1517: experience affords us neither instruction nor guidance, lie the
1518: investigations of reason, which, on account of their importance, we
1519: consider far preferable to, and as having a far more elevated aim than,
1520: all that the understanding can achieve within the sphere of sensuous
1521: phenomena. So high a value do we set upon these investigations, that
1522: even at the risk of error, we persist in following them out, and permit
1523: neither doubt nor disregard nor indifference to restrain us from the
1524: pursuit. These unavoidable problems of mere pure reason are God,
1525: freedom (of will), and immortality. The science which, with all its
1526: preliminaries, has for its especial object the solution of these
1527: problems is named metaphysics—a science which is at the very outset
1528: dogmatical, that is, it confidently takes upon itself the execution of
1529: this task without any previous investigation of the ability or
1530: inability of reason for such an undertaking.
1531: 
1532: Now the safe ground of experience being thus abandoned, it seems
1533: nevertheless natural that we should hesitate to erect a building with
1534: the cognitions we possess, without knowing whence they come, and on the
1535: strength of principles, the origin of which is undiscovered. Instead of
1536: thus trying to build without a foundation, it is rather to be expected
1537: that we should long ago have put the question, how the understanding
1538: can arrive at these à priori cognitions, and what is the extent,
1539: validity, and worth which they may possess? We say, “This is natural
1540: enough,” meaning by the word natural, that which is consistent with a
1541: just and reasonable way of thinking; but if we understand by the term,
1542: that which usually happens, nothing indeed could be more natural and
1543: more comprehensible than that this investigation should be left long
1544: unattempted. For one part of our pure knowledge, the science of
1545: mathematics, has been long firmly established, and thus leads us to
1546: form flattering expectations with regard to others, though these may be
1547: of quite a different nature. Besides, when we get beyond the bounds of
1548: experience, we are of course safe from opposition in that quarter; and
1549: the charm of widening the range of our knowledge is so great that,
1550: unless we are brought to a standstill by some evident contradiction, we
1551: hurry on undoubtingly in our course. This, however, may be avoided, if
1552: we are sufficiently cautious in the construction of our fictions, which
1553: are not the less fictions on that account.
1554: 
1555: Mathematical science affords us a brilliant example, how far,
1556: independently of all experience, we may carry our à priori knowledge.
1557: It is true that the mathematician occupies himself with objects and
1558: cognitions only in so far as they can be represented by means of
1559: intuition. But this circumstance is easily overlooked, because the said
1560: intuition can itself be given à priori, and therefore is hardly to be
1561: distinguished from a mere pure conception. Deceived by such a proof of
1562: the power of reason, we can perceive no limits to the extension of our
1563: knowledge. The light dove cleaving in free flight the thin air, whose
1564: resistance it feels, might imagine that her movements would be far more
1565: free and rapid in airless space. Just in the same way did Plato,
1566: abandoning the world of sense because of the narrow limits it sets to
1567: the understanding, venture upon the wings of ideas beyond it, into the
1568: void space of pure intellect. He did not reflect that he made no real
1569: progress by all his efforts; for he met with no resistance which might
1570: serve him for a support, as it were, whereon to rest, and on which he
1571: might apply his powers, in order to let the intellect acquire momentum
1572: for its progress. It is, indeed, the common fate of human reason in
1573: speculation, to finish the imposing edifice of thought as rapidly as
1574: possible, and then for the first time to begin to examine whether the
1575: foundation is a solid one or no. Arrived at this point, all sorts of
1576: excuses are sought after, in order to console us for its want of
1577: stability, or rather, indeed, to enable Us to dispense altogether with
1578: so late and dangerous an investigation. But what frees us during the
1579: process of building from all apprehension or suspicion, and flatters us
1580: into the belief of its solidity, is this. A great part, perhaps the
1581: greatest part, of the business of our reason consists in the
1582: analysation of the conceptions which we already possess of objects. By
1583: this means we gain a multitude of cognitions, which although really
1584: nothing more than elucidations or explanations of that which (though in
1585: a confused manner) was already thought in our conceptions, are, at
1586: least in respect of their form, prized as new introspections; whilst,
1587: so far as regards their matter or content, we have really made no
1588: addition to our conceptions, but only disinvolved them. But as this
1589: process does furnish a real priori knowledge, which has a sure progress
1590: and useful results, reason, deceived by this, slips in, without being
1591: itself aware of it, assertions of a quite different kind; in which, to
1592: given conceptions it adds others, à priori indeed, but entirely foreign
1593: to them, without our knowing how it arrives at these, and, indeed,
1594: without such a question ever suggesting itself. I shall therefore at
1595: once proceed to examine the difference between these two modes of
1596: knowledge.
1597: 
1598: IV. Of the Difference Between Analytical and Synthetical Judgements.
1599: 
1600: In all judgements wherein the relation of a subject to the predicate is
1601: cogitated (I mention affirmative judgements only here; the application
1602: to negative will be very easy), this relation is possible in two
1603: different ways. Either the predicate B belongs to the subject A, as
1604: somewhat which is contained (though covertly) in the conception A; or
1605: the predicate B lies completely out of the conception A, although it
1606: stands in connection with it. In the first instance, I term the
1607: judgement analytical, in the second, synthetical. Analytical judgements
1608: (affirmative) are therefore those in which the connection of the
1609: predicate with the subject is cogitated through identity; those in
1610: which this connection is cogitated without identity, are called
1611: synthetical judgements. The former may be called explicative, the
1612: latter augmentative judgements; because the former add in the predicate
1613: nothing to the conception of the subject, but only analyse it into its
1614: constituent conceptions, which were thought already in the subject,
1615: although in a confused manner; the latter add to our conceptions of the
1616: subject a predicate which was not contained in it, and which no
1617: analysis could ever have discovered therein. For example, when I say,
1618: “All bodies are extended,” this is an analytical judgement. For I need
1619: not go beyond the conception of body in order to find extension
1620: connected with it, but merely analyse the conception, that is, become
1621: conscious of the manifold properties which I think in that conception,
1622: in order to discover this predicate in it: it is therefore an
1623: analytical judgement. On the other hand, when I say, “All bodies are
1624: heavy,” the predicate is something totally different from that which I
1625: think in the mere conception of a body. By the addition of such a
1626: predicate, therefore, it becomes a synthetical judgement.
1627: 
1628: Judgements of experience, as such, are always synthetical. For it would
1629: be absurd to think of grounding an analytical judgement on experience,
1630: because in forming such a judgement I need not go out of the sphere of
1631: my conceptions, and therefore recourse to the testimony of experience
1632: is quite unnecessary. That “bodies are extended” is not an empirical
1633: judgement, but a proposition which stands firm à priori. For before
1634: addressing myself to experience, I already have in my conception all
1635: the requisite conditions for the judgement, and I have only to extract
1636: the predicate from the conception, according to the principle of
1637: contradiction, and thereby at the same time become conscious of the
1638: necessity of the judgement, a necessity which I could never learn from
1639: experience. On the other hand, though at first I do not at all include
1640: the predicate of weight in my conception of body in general, that
1641: conception still indicates an object of experience, a part of the
1642: totality of experience, to which I can still add other parts; and this
1643: I do when I recognize by observation that bodies are heavy. I can
1644: cognize beforehand by analysis the conception of body through the
1645: characteristics of extension, impenetrability, shape, etc., all which
1646: are cogitated in this conception. But now I extend my knowledge, and
1647: looking back on experience from which I had derived this conception of
1648: body, I find weight at all times connected with the above
1649: characteristics, and therefore I synthetically add to my conceptions
1650: this as a predicate, and say, “All bodies are heavy.” Thus it is
1651: experience upon which rests the possibility of the synthesis of the
1652: predicate of weight with the conception of body, because both
1653: conceptions, although the one is not contained in the other, still
1654: belong to one another (only contingently, however), as parts of a
1655: whole, namely, of experience, which is itself a synthesis of
1656: intuitions.
1657: 
1658: But to synthetical judgements à priori, such aid is entirely wanting.
1659: If I go out of and beyond the conception A, in order to recognize
1660: another B as connected with it, what foundation have I to rest on,
1661: whereby to render the synthesis possible? I have here no longer the
1662: advantage of looking out in the sphere of experience for what I want.
1663: Let us take, for example, the proposition, “Everything that happens has
1664: a cause.” In the conception of “something that happens,” I indeed think
1665: an existence which a certain time antecedes, and from this I can derive
1666: analytical judgements. But the conception of a cause lies quite out of
1667: the above conception, and indicates something entirely different from
1668: “that which happens,” and is consequently not contained in that
1669: conception. How then am I able to assert concerning the general
1670: conception—“that which happens”—something entirely different from that
1671: conception, and to recognize the conception of cause although not
1672: contained in it, yet as belonging to it, and even necessarily? what is
1673: here the unknown = X, upon which the understanding rests when it
1674: believes it has found, out of the conception A a foreign predicate B,
1675: which it nevertheless considers to be connected with it? It cannot be
1676: experience, because the principle adduced annexes the two
1677: representations, cause and effect, to the representation existence, not
1678: only with universality, which experience cannot give, but also with the
1679: expression of necessity, therefore completely à priori and from pure
1680: conceptions. Upon such synthetical, that is augmentative propositions,
1681: depends the whole aim of our speculative knowledge à priori; for
1682: although analytical judgements are indeed highly important and
1683: necessary, they are so, only to arrive at that clearness of conceptions
1684: which is requisite for a sure and extended synthesis, and this alone is
1685: a real acquisition.
1686: 
1687: V. In all Theoretical Sciences of Reason, Synthetical Judgements “à
1688: priori” are contained as Principles.
1689: 
1690: 1. Mathematical judgements are always synthetical. Hitherto this fact,
1691: though incontestably true and very important in its consequences, seems
1692: to have escaped the analysts of the human mind, nay, to be in complete
1693: opposition to all their conjectures. For as it was found that
1694: mathematical conclusions all proceed according to the principle of
1695: contradiction (which the nature of every apodeictic certainty
1696: requires), people became persuaded that the fundamental principles of
1697: the science also were recognized and admitted in the same way. But the
1698: notion is fallacious; for although a synthetical proposition can
1699: certainly be discerned by means of the principle of contradiction, this
1700: is possible only when another synthetical proposition precedes, from
1701: which the latter is deduced, but never of itself.
1702: 
1703: Before all, be it observed, that proper mathematical propositions are
1704: always judgements à priori, and not empirical, because they carry along
1705: with them the conception of necessity, which cannot be given by
1706: experience. If this be demurred to, it matters not; I will then limit
1707: my assertion to pure mathematics, the very conception of which implies
1708: that it consists of knowledge altogether non-empirical and à priori.
1709: 
1710: We might, indeed at first suppose that the proposition 7 + 5 = 12 is a
1711: merely analytical proposition, following (according to the principle of
1712: contradiction) from the conception of a sum of seven and five. But if
1713: we regard it more narrowly, we find that our conception of the sum of
1714: seven and five contains nothing more than the uniting of both sums into
1715: one, whereby it cannot at all be cogitated what this single number is
1716: which embraces both. The conception of twelve is by no means obtained
1717: by merely cogitating the union of seven and five; and we may analyse
1718: our conception of such a possible sum as long as we will, still we
1719: shall never discover in it the notion of twelve. We must go beyond
1720: these conceptions, and have recourse to an intuition which corresponds
1721: to one of the two—our five fingers, for example, or like Segner in his
1722: Arithmetic five points, and so by degrees, add the units contained in
1723: the five given in the intuition, to the conception of seven. For I
1724: first take the number 7, and, for the conception of 5 calling in the
1725: aid of the fingers of my hand as objects of intuition, I add the units,
1726: which I before took together to make up the number 5, gradually now by
1727: means of the material image my hand, to the number 7, and by this
1728: process, I at length see the number 12 arise. That 7 should be added to
1729: 5, I have certainly cogitated in my conception of a sum = 7 + 5, but
1730: not that this sum was equal to 12. Arithmetical propositions are
1731: therefore always synthetical, of which we may become more clearly
1732: convinced by trying large numbers. For it will thus become quite
1733: evident that, turn and twist our conceptions as we may, it is
1734: impossible, without having recourse to intuition, to arrive at the sum
1735: total or product by means of the mere analysis of our conceptions. Just
1736: as little is any principle of pure geometry analytical. “A straight
1737: line between two points is the shortest,” is a synthetical proposition.
1738: For my conception of straight contains no notion of quantity, but is
1739: merely qualitative. The conception of the shortest is therefore fore
1740: wholly an addition, and by no analysis can it be extracted from our
1741: conception of a straight line. Intuition must therefore here lend its
1742: aid, by means of which, and thus only, our synthesis is possible.
1743: 
1744: Some few principles preposited by geometricians are, indeed, really
1745: analytical, and depend on the principle of contradiction. They serve,
1746: however, like identical propositions, as links in the chain of method,
1747: not as principles—for example, a = a, the whole is equal to itself, or
1748: (a+b) —> a, the whole is greater than its part. And yet even these
1749: principles themselves, though they derive their validity from pure
1750: conceptions, are only admitted in mathematics because they can be
1751: presented in intuition. What causes us here commonly to believe that
1752: the predicate of such apodeictic judgements is already contained in our
1753: conception, and that the judgement is therefore analytical, is merely
1754: the equivocal nature of the expression. We must join in thought a
1755: certain predicate to a given conception, and this necessity cleaves
1756: already to the conception. But the question is, not what we must join
1757: in thought to the given conception, but what we really think therein,
1758: though only obscurely, and then it becomes manifest that the predicate
1759: pertains to these conceptions, necessarily indeed, yet not as thought
1760: in the conception itself, but by virtue of an intuition, which must be
1761: added to the conception.
1762: 
1763: 2. The science of natural philosophy (physics) contains in itself
1764: synthetical judgements à priori, as principles. I shall adduce two
1765: propositions. For instance, the proposition, “In all changes of the
1766: material world, the quantity of matter remains unchanged”; or, that,
1767: “In all communication of motion, action and reaction must always be
1768: equal.” In both of these, not only is the necessity, and therefore
1769: their origin à priori clear, but also that they are synthetical
1770: propositions. For in the conception of matter, I do not cogitate its
1771: permanency, but merely its presence in space, which it fills. I
1772: therefore really go out of and beyond the conception of matter, in
1773: order to think on to it something à priori, which I did not think in
1774: it. The proposition is therefore not analytical, but synthetical, and
1775: nevertheless conceived à priori; and so it is with regard to the other
1776: propositions of the pure part of natural philosophy.
1777: 
1778: 3. As to metaphysics, even if we look upon it merely as an attempted
1779: science, yet, from the nature of human reason, an indispensable one, we
1780: find that it must contain synthetical propositions à priori. It is not
1781: merely the duty of metaphysics to dissect, and thereby analytically to
1782: illustrate the conceptions which we form à priori of things; but we
1783: seek to widen the range of our à priori knowledge. For this purpose, we
1784: must avail ourselves of such principles as add something to the
1785: original conception—something not identical with, nor contained in it,
1786: and by means of synthetical judgements à priori, leave far behind us
1787: the limits of experience; for example, in the proposition, “the world
1788: must have a beginning,” and such like. Thus metaphysics, according to
1789: the proper aim of the science, consists merely of synthetical
1790: propositions à priori.
1791: 
1792: VI. The Universal Problem of Pure Reason.
1793: 
1794: It is extremely advantageous to be able to bring a number of
1795: investigations under the formula of a single problem. For in this
1796: manner, we not only facilitate our own labour, inasmuch as we define it
1797: clearly to ourselves, but also render it more easy for others to decide
1798: whether we have done justice to our undertaking. The proper problem of
1799: pure reason, then, is contained in the question: “How are synthetical
1800: judgements à priori possible?”
1801: 
1802: That metaphysical science has hitherto remained in so vacillating a
1803: state of uncertainty and contradiction, is only to be attributed to the
1804: fact that this great problem, and perhaps even the difference between
1805: analytical and synthetical judgements, did not sooner suggest itself to
1806: philosophers. Upon the solution of this problem, or upon sufficient
1807: proof of the impossibility of synthetical knowledge à priori, depends
1808: the existence or downfall of the science of metaphysics. Among
1809: philosophers, David Hume came the nearest of all to this problem; yet
1810: it never acquired in his mind sufficient precision, nor did he regard
1811: the question in its universality. On the contrary, he stopped short at
1812: the synthetical proposition of the connection of an effect with its
1813: cause (principium causalitatis), insisting that such proposition à
1814: priori was impossible. According to his conclusions, then, all that we
1815: term metaphysical science is a mere delusion, arising from the fancied
1816: insight of reason into that which is in truth borrowed from experience,
1817: and to which habit has given the appearance of necessity. Against this
1818: assertion, destructive to all pure philosophy, he would have been
1819: guarded, had he had our problem before his eyes in its universality.
1820: For he would then have perceived that, according to his own argument,
1821: there likewise could not be any pure mathematical science, which
1822: assuredly cannot exist without synthetical propositions à priori—an
1823: absurdity from which his good understanding must have saved him.
1824: 
1825: In the solution of the above problem is at the same time comprehended
1826: the possibility of the use of pure reason in the foundation and
1827: construction of all sciences which contain theoretical knowledge à
1828: priori of objects, that is to say, the answer to the following
1829: questions:
1830: 
1831: How is pure mathematical science possible?
1832: 
1833: How is pure natural science possible?
1834: 
1835: Respecting these sciences, as they do certainly exist, it may with
1836: propriety be asked, how they are possible?—for that they must be
1837: possible is shown by the fact of their really existing.[9] But as to
1838: metaphysics, the miserable progress it has hitherto made, and the fact
1839: that of no one system yet brought forward, far as regards its true aim,
1840: can it be said that this science really exists, leaves any one at
1841: liberty to doubt with reason the very possibility of its existence.
1842: 
1843:  [9] As to the existence of pure natural science, or physics, perhaps
1844:  many may still express doubts. But we have only to look at the
1845:  different propositions which are commonly treated of at the
1846:  commencement of proper (empirical) physical science—those, for
1847:  example, relating to the permanence of the same quantity of matter,
1848:  the vis inertiae, the equality of action and reaction, etc.—to be soon
1849:  convinced that they form a science of pure physics (physica pura, or
1850:  rationalis), which well deserves to be separately exposed as a special
1851:  science, in its whole extent, whether that be great or confined.
1852: 
1853: 
1854: Yet, in a certain sense, this kind of knowledge must unquestionably be
1855: looked upon as given; in other words, metaphysics must be considered as
1856: really existing, if not as a science, nevertheless as a natural
1857: disposition of the human mind (metaphysica naturalis). For human
1858: reason, without any instigations imputable to the mere vanity of great
1859: knowledge, unceasingly progresses, urged on by its own feeling of need,
1860: towards such questions as cannot be answered by any empirical
1861: application of reason, or principles derived therefrom; and so there
1862: has ever really existed in every man some system of metaphysics. It
1863: will always exist, so soon as reason awakes to the exercise of its
1864: power of speculation. And now the question arises: “How is metaphysics,
1865: as a natural disposition, possible?” In other words, how, from the
1866: nature of universal human reason, do those questions arise which pure
1867: reason proposes to itself, and which it is impelled by its own feeling
1868: of need to answer as well as it can?
1869: 
1870: But as in all the attempts hitherto made to answer the questions which
1871: reason is prompted by its very nature to propose to itself, for
1872: example, whether the world had a beginning, or has existed from
1873: eternity, it has always met with unavoidable contradictions, we must
1874: not rest satisfied with the mere natural disposition of the mind to
1875: metaphysics, that is, with the existence of the faculty of pure reason,
1876: whence, indeed, some sort of metaphysical system always arises; but it
1877: must be possible to arrive at certainty in regard to the question
1878: whether we know or do not know the things of which metaphysics treats.
1879: We must be able to arrive at a decision on the subjects of its
1880: questions, or on the ability or inability of reason to form any
1881: judgement respecting them; and therefore either to extend with
1882: confidence the bounds of our pure reason, or to set strictly defined
1883: and safe limits to its action. This last question, which arises out of
1884: the above universal problem, would properly run thus: “How is
1885: metaphysics possible as a science?”
1886: 
1887: Thus, the critique of reason leads at last, naturally and necessarily,
1888: to science; and, on the other hand, the dogmatical use of reason
1889: without criticism leads to groundless assertions, against which others
1890: equally specious can always be set, thus ending unavoidably in
1891: scepticism.
1892: 
1893: Besides, this science cannot be of great and formidable prolixity,
1894: because it has not to do with objects of reason, the variety of which
1895: is inexhaustible, but merely with Reason herself and her problems;
1896: problems which arise out of her own bosom, and are not proposed to her
1897: by the nature of outward things, but by her own nature. And when once
1898: Reason has previously become able completely to understand her own
1899: power in regard to objects which she meets with in experience, it will
1900: be easy to determine securely the extent and limits of her attempted
1901: application to objects beyond the confines of experience.
1902: 
1903: We may and must, therefore, regard the attempts hitherto made to
1904: establish metaphysical science dogmatically as non-existent. For what
1905: of analysis, that is, mere dissection of conceptions, is contained in
1906: one or other, is not the aim of, but only a preparation for metaphysics
1907: proper, which has for its object the extension, by means of synthesis,
1908: of our à priori knowledge. And for this purpose, mere analysis is of
1909: course useless, because it only shows what is contained in these
1910: conceptions, but not how we arrive, à priori, at them; and this it is
1911: her duty to show, in order to be able afterwards to determine their
1912: valid use in regard to all objects of experience, to all knowledge in
1913: general. But little self-denial, indeed, is needed to give up these
1914: pretensions, seeing the undeniable, and in the dogmatic mode of
1915: procedure, inevitable contradictions of Reason with herself, have long
1916: since ruined the reputation of every system of metaphysics that has
1917: appeared up to this time. It will require more firmness to remain
1918: undeterred by difficulty from within, and opposition from without, from
1919: endeavouring, by a method quite opposed to all those hitherto followed,
1920: to further the growth and fruitfulness of a science indispensable to
1921: human reason—a science from which every branch it has borne may be cut
1922: away, but whose roots remain indestructible.
1923: 
1924: VII. Idea and Division of a Particular Science, under the Name of a
1925: Critique of Pure Reason.
1926: 
1927: From all that has been said, there results the idea of a particular
1928: science, which may be called the Critique of Pure Reason. For reason is
1929: the faculty which furnishes us with the principles of knowledge à
1930: priori. Hence, pure reason is the faculty which contains the principles
1931: of cognizing anything absolutely à priori. An organon of pure reason
1932: would be a compendium of those principles according to which alone all
1933: pure cognitions à priori can be obtained. The completely extended
1934: application of such an organon would afford us a system of pure reason.
1935: As this, however, is demanding a great deal, and it is yet doubtful
1936: whether any extension of our knowledge be here possible, or, if so, in
1937: what cases; we can regard a science of the mere criticism of pure
1938: reason, its sources and limits, as the propædeutic to a system of pure
1939: reason. Such a science must not be called a doctrine, but only a
1940: critique of pure reason; and its use, in regard to speculation, would
1941: be only negative, not to enlarge the bounds of, but to purify, our
1942: reason, and to shield it against error—which alone is no little gain. I
1943: apply the term transcendental to all knowledge which is not so much
1944: occupied with objects as with the mode of our cognition of these
1945: objects, so far as this mode of cognition is possible à priori. A
1946: system of such conceptions would be called transcendental philosophy.
1947: But this, again, is still beyond the bounds of our present essay. For
1948: as such a science must contain a complete exposition not only of our
1949: synthetical à priori, but of our analytical à priori knowledge, it is
1950: of too wide a range for our present purpose, because we do not require
1951: to carry our analysis any farther than is necessary to understand, in
1952: their full extent, the principles of synthesis à priori, with which
1953: alone we have to do. This investigation, which we cannot properly call
1954: a doctrine, but only a transcendental critique, because it aims not at
1955: the enlargement, but at the correction and guidance, of our knowledge,
1956: and is to serve as a touchstone of the worth or worthlessness of all
1957: knowledge à priori, is the sole object of our present essay. Such a
1958: critique is consequently, as far as possible, a preparation for an
1959: organon; and if this new organon should be found to fail, at least for
1960: a canon of pure reason, according to which the complete system of the
1961: philosophy of pure reason, whether it extend or limit the bounds of
1962: that reason, might one day be set forth both analytically and
1963: synthetically. For that this is possible, nay, that such a system is
1964: not of so great extent as to preclude the hope of its ever being
1965: completed, is evident. For we have not here to do with the nature of
1966: outward objects, which is infinite, but solely with the mind, which
1967: judges of the nature of objects, and, again, with the mind only in
1968: respect of its cognition à priori. And the object of our
1969: investigations, as it is not to be sought without, but, altogether
1970: within, ourselves, cannot remain concealed, and in all probability is
1971: limited enough to be completely surveyed and fairly estimated,
1972: according to its worth or worthlessness. Still less let the reader here
1973: expect a critique of books and systems of pure reason; our present
1974: object is exclusively a critique of the faculty of pure reason itself.
1975: Only when we make this critique our foundation, do we possess a pure
1976: touchstone for estimating the philosophical value of ancient and modern
1977: writings on this subject; and without this criterion, the incompetent
1978: historian or judge decides upon and corrects the groundless assertions
1979: of others with his own, which have themselves just as little
1980: foundation.
1981: 
1982: Transcendental philosophy is the idea of a science, for which the
1983: Critique of Pure Reason must sketch the whole plan architectonically,
1984: that is, from principles, with a full guarantee for the validity and
1985: stability of all the parts which enter into the building. It is the
1986: system of all the principles of pure reason. If this Critique itself
1987: does not assume the title of transcendental philosophy, it is only
1988: because, to be a complete system, it ought to contain a full analysis
1989: of all human knowledge à priori. Our critique must, indeed, lay before
1990: us a complete enumeration of all the radical conceptions which
1991: constitute the said pure knowledge. But from the complete analysis of
1992: these conceptions themselves, as also from a complete investigation of
1993: those derived from them, it abstains with reason; partly because it
1994: would be deviating from the end in view to occupy itself with this
1995: analysis, since this process is not attended with the difficulty and
1996: insecurity to be found in the synthesis, to which our critique is
1997: entirely devoted, and partly because it would be inconsistent with the
1998: unity of our plan to burden this essay with the vindication of the
1999: completeness of such an analysis and deduction, with which, after all,
2000: we have at present nothing to do. This completeness of the analysis of
2001: these radical conceptions, as well as of the deduction from the
2002: conceptions à priori which may be given by the analysis, we can,
2003: however, easily attain, provided only that we are in possession of all
2004: these radical conceptions, which are to serve as principles of the
2005: synthesis, and that in respect of this main purpose nothing is wanting.
2006: 
2007: To the Critique of Pure Reason, therefore, belongs all that constitutes
2008: transcendental philosophy; and it is the complete idea of
2009: transcendental philosophy, but still not the science itself; because it
2010: only proceeds so far with the analysis as is necessary to the power of
2011: judging completely of our synthetical knowledge à priori.
2012: 
2013: The principal thing we must attend to, in the division of the parts of
2014: a science like this, is that no conceptions must enter it which contain
2015: aught empirical; in other words, that the knowledge à priori must be
2016: completely pure. Hence, although the highest principles and fundamental
2017: conceptions of morality are certainly cognitions à priori, yet they do
2018: not belong to transcendental philosophy; because, though they certainly
2019: do not lay the conceptions of pain, pleasure, desires, inclinations,
2020: etc. (which are all of empirical origin), at the foundation of its
2021: precepts, yet still into the conception of duty—as an obstacle to be
2022: overcome, or as an incitement which should not be made into a
2023: motive—these empirical conceptions must necessarily enter, in the
2024: construction of a system of pure morality. Transcendental philosophy is
2025: consequently a philosophy of the pure and merely speculative reason.
2026: For all that is practical, so far as it contains motives, relates to
2027: feelings, and these belong to empirical sources of cognition.
2028: 
2029: If we wish to divide this science from the universal point of view of a
2030: science in general, it ought to comprehend, first, a Doctrine of the
2031: Elements, and, secondly, a Doctrine of the Method of pure reason. Each
2032: of these main divisions will have its subdivisions, the separate
2033: reasons for which we cannot here particularize. Only so much seems
2034: necessary, by way of introduction of premonition, that there are two
2035: sources of human knowledge (which probably spring from a common, but to
2036: us unknown root), namely, sense and understanding. By the former,
2037: objects are given to us; by the latter, thought. So far as the faculty
2038: of sense may contain representations à priori, which form the
2039: conditions under which objects are given, in so far it belongs to
2040: transcendental philosophy. The transcendental doctrine of sense must
2041: form the first part of our science of elements, because the conditions
2042: under which alone the objects of human knowledge are given must precede
2043: those under which they are thought.
2044: 
2045: 
2046: 
2047: I. TRANSCENDENTAL DOCTRINE OF ELEMENTS.
2048: 
2049: FIRST PART. TRANSCENDENTAL ÆSTHETIC.
2050: 
2051: § I. Introductory.
2052: 
2053: In whatsoever mode, or by whatsoever means, our knowledge may relate to
2054: objects, it is at least quite clear that the only manner in which it
2055: immediately relates to them is by means of an intuition. To this as the
2056: indispensable groundwork, all thought points. But an intuition can take
2057: place only in so far as the object is given to us. This, again, is only
2058: possible, to man at least, on condition that the object affect the mind
2059: in a certain manner. The capacity for receiving representations
2060: (receptivity) through the mode in which we are affected by objects,
2061: objects, is called sensibility. By means of sensibility, therefore,
2062: objects are given to us, and it alone furnishes us with intuitions; by
2063: the understanding they are thought, and from it arise conceptions. But
2064: an thought must directly, or indirectly, by means of certain signs,
2065: relate ultimately to intuitions; consequently, with us, to sensibility,
2066: because in no other way can an object be given to us.
2067: 
2068: The effect of an object upon the faculty of representation, so far as
2069: we are affected by the said object, is sensation. That sort of
2070: intuition which relates to an object by means of sensation is called an
2071: empirical intuition. The undetermined object of an empirical intuition
2072: is called phenomenon. That which in the phenomenon corresponds to the
2073: sensation, I term its matter; but that which effects that the content
2074: of the phenomenon can be arranged under certain relations, I call its
2075: form. But that in which our sensations are merely arranged, and by
2076: which they are susceptible of assuming a certain form, cannot be itself
2077: sensation. It is, then, the matter of all phenomena that is given to us
2078: à posteriori; the form must lie ready à priori for them in the mind,
2079: and consequently can be regarded separately from all sensation.
2080: 
2081: I call all representations pure, in the transcendental meaning of the
2082: word, wherein nothing is met with that belongs to sensation. And
2083: accordingly we find existing in the mind à priori, the pure form of
2084: sensuous intuitions in general, in which all the manifold content of
2085: the phenomenal world is arranged and viewed under certain relations.
2086: This pure form of sensibility I shall call pure intuition. Thus, if I
2087: take away from our representation of a body all that the understanding
2088: thinks as belonging to it, as substance, force, divisibility, etc., and
2089: also whatever belongs to sensation, as impenetrability, hardness,
2090: colour, etc.; yet there is still something left us from this empirical
2091: intuition, namely, extension and shape. These belong to pure intuition,
2092: which exists à priori in the mind, as a mere form of sensibility, and
2093: without any real object of the senses or any sensation.
2094: 
2095: The science of all the principles of sensibility à priori, I call
2096: transcendental æsthetic.[10] There must, then, be such a science
2097: forming the first part of the transcendental doctrine of elements, in
2098: contradistinction to that part which contains the principles of pure
2099: thought, and which is called transcendental logic.
2100: 
2101:  [10] The Germans are the only people who at present use this word to
2102:  indicate what others call the critique of taste. At the foundation of
2103:  this term lies the disappointed hope, which the eminent analyst,
2104:  Baumgarten, conceived, of subjecting the criticism of the beautiful to
2105:  principles of reason, and so of elevating its rules into a science.
2106:  But his endeavours were vain. For the said rules or criteria are, in
2107:  respect to their chief sources, merely empirical, consequently never
2108:  can serve as determinate laws à priori, by which our judgement in
2109:  matters of taste is to be directed. It is rather our judgement which
2110:  forms the proper test as to the correctness of the principles. On this
2111:  account it is advisable to give up the use of the term as designating
2112:  the critique of taste, and to apply it solely to that doctrine, which
2113:  is true science—the science of the laws of sensibility—and thus come
2114:  nearer to the language and the sense of the ancients in their
2115:  well-known division of the objects of cognition into aiotheta kai
2116:  noeta, or to share it with speculative philosophy, and employ it
2117:  partly in a transcendental, partly in a psychological signification.
2118: 
2119: 
2120: In the science of transcendental æsthetic accordingly, we shall first
2121: isolate sensibility or the sensuous faculty, by separating from it all
2122: that is annexed to its perceptions by the conceptions of understanding,
2123: so that nothing be left but empirical intuition. In the next place we
2124: shall take away from this intuition all that belongs to sensation, so
2125: that nothing may remain but pure intuition, and the mere form of
2126: phenomena, which is all that the sensibility can afford à priori. From
2127: this investigation it will be found that there are two pure forms of
2128: sensuous intuition, as principles of knowledge à priori, namely, space
2129: and time. To the consideration of these we shall now proceed.
2130: 
2131: SECTION I. Of Space.
2132: 
2133: § 2. Metaphysical Exposition of this Conception.
2134: 
2135: By means of the external sense (a property of the mind), we represent
2136: to ourselves objects as without us, and these all in space. Herein
2137: alone are their shape, dimensions, and relations to each other
2138: determined or determinable. The internal sense, by means of which the
2139: mind contemplates itself or its internal state, gives, indeed, no
2140: intuition of the soul as an object; yet there is nevertheless a
2141: determinate form, under which alone the contemplation of our internal
2142: state is possible, so that all which relates to the inward
2143: determinations of the mind is represented in relations of time. Of time
2144: we cannot have any external intuition, any more than we can have an
2145: internal intuition of space. What then are time and space? Are they
2146: real existences? Or, are they merely relations or determinations of
2147: things, such, however, as would equally belong to these things in
2148: themselves, though they should never become objects of intuition; or,
2149: are they such as belong only to the form of intuition, and consequently
2150: to the subjective constitution of the mind, without which these
2151: predicates of time and space could not be attached to any object? In
2152: order to become informed on these points, we shall first give an
2153: exposition of the conception of space. By exposition, I mean the clear,
2154: though not detailed, representation of that which belongs to a
2155: conception; and an exposition is metaphysical when it contains that
2156: which represents the conception as given à priori.
2157: 
2158: 1. Space is not a conception which has been derived from outward
2159: experiences. For, in order that certain sensations may relate to
2160: something without me (that is, to something which occupies a different
2161: part of space from that in which I am); in like manner, in order that I
2162: may represent them not merely as without, of, and near to each other,
2163: but also in separate places, the representation of space must already
2164: exist as a foundation. Consequently, the representation of space cannot
2165: be borrowed from the relations of external phenomena through
2166: experience; but, on the contrary, this external experience is itself
2167: only possible through the said antecedent representation.
2168: 
2169: 2. Space then is a necessary representation à priori, which serves for
2170: the foundation of all external intuitions. We never can imagine or make
2171: a representation to ourselves of the non-existence of space, though we
2172: may easily enough think that no objects are found in it. It must,
2173: therefore, be considered as the condition of the possibility of
2174: phenomena, and by no means as a determination dependent on them, and is
2175: a representation à priori, which necessarily supplies the basis for
2176: external phenomena.
2177: 
2178: 3. Space is no discursive, or as we say, general conception of the
2179: relations of things, but a pure intuition. For, in the first place, we
2180: can only represent to ourselves one space, and, when we talk of divers
2181: spaces, we mean only parts of one and the same space. Moreover, these
2182: parts cannot antecede this one all-embracing space, as the component
2183: parts from which the aggregate can be made up, but can be cogitated
2184: only as existing in it. Space is essentially one, and multiplicity in
2185: it, consequently the general notion of spaces, of this or that space,
2186: depends solely upon limitations. Hence it follows that an à priori
2187: intuition (which is not empirical) lies at the root of all our
2188: conceptions of space. Thus, moreover, the principles of geometry—for
2189: example, that “in a triangle, two sides together are greater than the
2190: third,” are never deduced from general conceptions of line and
2191: triangle, but from intuition, and this à priori, with apodeictic
2192: certainty.
2193: 
2194: 4. Space is represented as an infinite given quantity. Now every
2195: conception must indeed be considered as a representation which is
2196: contained in an infinite multitude of different possible
2197: representations, which, therefore, comprises these under itself; but no
2198: conception, as such, can be so conceived, as if it contained within
2199: itself an infinite multitude of representations. Nevertheless, space is
2200: so conceived of, for all parts of space are equally capable of being
2201: produced to infinity. Consequently, the original representation of
2202: space is an intuition à priori, and not a conception.
2203: 
2204: § 3. Transcendental Exposition of the Conception of Space.
2205: 
2206: By a transcendental exposition, I mean the explanation of a conception,
2207: as a principle, whence can be discerned the possibility of other
2208: synthetical à priori cognitions. For this purpose, it is requisite,
2209: firstly, that such cognitions do really flow from the given conception;
2210: and, secondly, that the said cognitions are only possible under the
2211: presupposition of a given mode of explaining this conception.
2212: 
2213: Geometry is a science which determines the properties of space
2214: synthetically, and yet à priori. What, then, must be our representation
2215: of space, in order that such a cognition of it may be possible? It must
2216: be originally intuition, for from a mere conception, no propositions
2217: can be deduced which go out beyond the conception, and yet this happens
2218: in geometry. (Introd. V.) But this intuition must be found in the mind
2219: à priori, that is, before any perception of objects, consequently must
2220: be pure, not empirical, intuition. For geometrical principles are
2221: always apodeictic, that is, united with the consciousness of their
2222: necessity, as: “Space has only three dimensions.” But propositions of
2223: this kind cannot be empirical judgements, nor conclusions from them.
2224: (Introd. II.) Now, how can an external intuition anterior to objects
2225: themselves, and in which our conception of objects can be determined à
2226: priori, exist in the human mind? Obviously not otherwise than in so far
2227: as it has its seat in the subject only, as the formal capacity of the
2228: subject’s being affected by objects, and thereby of obtaining immediate
2229: representation, that is, intuition; consequently, only as the form of
2230: the external sense in general.
2231: 
2232: Thus it is only by means of our explanation that the possibility of
2233: geometry, as a synthetical science à priori, becomes comprehensible.
2234: Every mode of explanation which does not show us this possibility,
2235: although in appearance it may be similar to ours, can with the utmost
2236: certainty be distinguished from it by these marks.
2237: 
2238: § 4. Conclusions from the foregoing Conceptions.
2239: 
2240: (a) Space does not represent any property of objects as things in
2241: themselves, nor does it represent them in their relations to each
2242: other; in other words, space does not represent to us any determination
2243: of objects such as attaches to the objects themselves, and would
2244: remain, even though all subjective conditions of the intuition were
2245: abstracted. For neither absolute nor relative determinations of objects
2246: can be intuited prior to the existence of the things to which they
2247: belong, and therefore not à priori.
2248: 
2249: (b) Space is nothing else than the form of all phenomena of the
2250: external sense, that is, the subjective condition of the sensibility,
2251: under which alone external intuition is possible. Now, because the
2252: receptivity or capacity of the subject to be affected by objects
2253: necessarily antecedes all intuitions of these objects, it is easily
2254: understood how the form of all phenomena can be given in the mind
2255: previous to all actual perceptions, therefore à priori, and how it, as
2256: a pure intuition, in which all objects must be determined, can contain
2257: principles of the relations of these objects prior to all experience.
2258: 
2259: It is therefore from the human point of view only that we can speak of
2260: space, extended objects, etc. If we depart from the subjective
2261: condition, under which alone we can obtain external intuition, or, in
2262: other words, by means of which we are affected by objects, the
2263: representation of space has no meaning whatsoever. This predicate is
2264: only applicable to things in so far as they appear to us, that is, are
2265: objects of sensibility. The constant form of this receptivity, which we
2266: call sensibility, is a necessary condition of all relations in which
2267: objects can be intuited as existing without us, and when abstraction of
2268: these objects is made, is a pure intuition, to which we give the name
2269: of space. It is clear that we cannot make the special conditions of
2270: sensibility into conditions of the possibility of things, but only of
2271: the possibility of their existence as far as they are phenomena. And so
2272: we may correctly say that space contains all which can appear to us
2273: externally, but not all things considered as things in themselves, be
2274: they intuited or not, or by whatsoever subject one will. As to the
2275: intuitions of other thinking beings, we cannot judge whether they are
2276: or are not bound by the same conditions which limit our own intuition,
2277: and which for us are universally valid. If we join the limitation of a
2278: judgement to the conception of the subject, then the judgement will
2279: possess unconditioned validity. For example, the proposition, “All
2280: objects are beside each other in space,” is valid only under the
2281: limitation that these things are taken as objects of our sensuous
2282: intuition. But if I join the condition to the conception and say, “All
2283: things, as external phenomena, are beside each other in space,” then
2284: the rule is valid universally, and without any limitation. Our
2285: expositions, consequently, teach the reality (i.e., the objective
2286: validity) of space in regard of all which can be presented to us
2287: externally as object, and at the same time also the ideality of space
2288: in regard to objects when they are considered by means of reason as
2289: things in themselves, that is, without reference to the constitution of
2290: our sensibility. We maintain, therefore, the empirical reality of space
2291: in regard to all possible external experience, although we must admit
2292: its transcendental ideality; in other words, that it is nothing, so
2293: soon as we withdraw the condition upon which the possibility of all
2294: experience depends and look upon space as something that belongs to
2295: things in themselves.
2296: 
2297: But, with the exception of space, there is no representation,
2298: subjective and referring to something external to us, which could be
2299: called objective à priori. For there are no other subjective
2300: representations from which we can deduce synthetical propositions à
2301: priori, as we can from the intuition of space. (See § 3.) Therefore, to
2302: speak accurately, no ideality whatever belongs to these, although they
2303: agree in this respect with the representation of space, that they
2304: belong merely to the subjective nature of the mode of sensuous
2305: perception; such a mode, for example, as that of sight, of hearing, and
2306: of feeling, by means of the sensations of colour, sound, and heat, but
2307: which, because they are only sensations and not intuitions, do not of
2308: themselves give us the cognition of any object, least of all, an à
2309: priori cognition. My purpose, in the above remark, is merely this: to
2310: guard any one against illustrating the asserted ideality of space by
2311: examples quite insufficient, for example, by colour, taste, etc.; for
2312: these must be contemplated not as properties of things, but only as
2313: changes in the subject, changes which may be different in different
2314: men. For, in such a case, that which is originally a mere phenomenon, a
2315: rose, for example, is taken by the empirical understanding for a thing
2316: in itself, though to every different eye, in respect of its colour, it
2317: may appear different. On the contrary, the transcendental conception of
2318: phenomena in space is a critical admonition, that, in general, nothing
2319: which is intuited in space is a thing in itself, and that space is not
2320: a form which belongs as a property to things; but that objects are
2321: quite unknown to us in themselves, and what we call outward objects,
2322: are nothing else but mere representations of our sensibility, whose
2323: form is space, but whose real correlate, the thing in itself, is not
2324: known by means of these representations, nor ever can be, but
2325: respecting which, in experience, no inquiry is ever made.
2326: 
2327: SECTION II. Of Time.
2328: 
2329: § 5. Metaphysical Exposition of this Conception.
2330: 
2331: 1. Time is not an empirical conception. For neither coexistence nor
2332: succession would be perceived by us, if the representation of time did
2333: not exist as a foundation à priori. Without this presupposition we
2334: could not represent to ourselves that things exist together at one and
2335: the same time, or at different times, that is, contemporaneously, or in
2336: succession.
2337: 
2338: 2. Time is a necessary representation, lying at the foundation of all
2339: our intuitions. With regard to phenomena in general, we cannot think
2340: away time from them, and represent them to ourselves as out of and
2341: unconnected with time, but we can quite well represent to ourselves
2342: time void of phenomena. Time is therefore given à priori. In it alone
2343: is all reality of phenomena possible. These may all be annihilated in
2344: thought, but time itself, as the universal condition of their
2345: possibility, cannot be so annulled.
2346: 
2347: 3. On this necessity à priori is also founded the possibility of
2348: apodeictic principles of the relations of time, or axioms of time in
2349: general, such as: “Time has only one dimension,” “Different times are
2350: not coexistent but successive” (as different spaces are not successive
2351: but coexistent). These principles cannot be derived from experience,
2352: for it would give neither strict universality, nor apodeictic
2353: certainty. We should only be able to say, “so common experience teaches
2354: us,” but not “it must be so.” They are valid as rules, through which,
2355: in general, experience is possible; and they instruct us respecting
2356: experience, and not by means of it.
2357: 
2358: 4. Time is not a discursive, or as it is called, general conception,
2359: but a pure form of the sensuous intuition. Different times are merely
2360: parts of one and the same time. But the representation which can only
2361: be given by a single object is an intuition. Besides, the proposition
2362: that different times cannot be coexistent could not be derived from a
2363: general conception. For this proposition is synthetical, and therefore
2364: cannot spring out of conceptions alone. It is therefore contained
2365: immediately in the intuition and representation of time.
2366: 
2367: 5. The infinity of time signifies nothing more than that every
2368: determined quantity of time is possible only through limitations of one
2369: time lying at the foundation. Consequently, the original
2370: representation, time, must be given as unlimited. But as the
2371: determinate representation of the parts of time and of every quantity
2372: of an object can only be obtained by limitation, the complete
2373: representation of time must not be furnished by means of conceptions,
2374: for these contain only partial representations. Conceptions, on the
2375: contrary, must have immediate intuition for their basis.
2376: 
2377: § 6 Transcendental Exposition of the Conception of Time.
2378: 
2379: I may here refer to what is said above (§ 5, 3), where, for or sake of
2380: brevity, I have placed under the head of metaphysical exposition, that
2381: which is properly transcendental. Here I shall add that the conception
2382: of change, and with it the conception of motion, as change of place, is
2383: possible only through and in the representation of time; that if this
2384: representation were not an intuition (internal) à priori, no
2385: conception, of whatever kind, could render comprehensible the
2386: possibility of change, in other words, of a conjunction of
2387: contradictorily opposed predicates in one and the same object, for
2388: example, the presence of a thing in a place and the non-presence of the
2389: same thing in the same place. It is only in time that it is possible to
2390: meet with two contradictorily opposed determinations in one thing, that
2391: is, after each other. Thus our conception of time explains the
2392: possibility of so much synthetical knowledge à priori, as is exhibited
2393: in the general doctrine of motion, which is not a little fruitful.
2394: 
2395: § 7. Conclusions from the above Conceptions.
2396: 
2397: (a) Time is not something which subsists of itself, or which inheres in
2398: things as an objective determination, and therefore remains, when
2399: abstraction is made of the subjective conditions of the intuition of
2400: things. For in the former case, it would be something real, yet without
2401: presenting to any power of perception any real object. In the latter
2402: case, as an order or determination inherent in things themselves, it
2403: could not be antecedent to things, as their condition, nor discerned or
2404: intuited by means of synthetical propositions à priori. But all this is
2405: quite possible when we regard time as merely the subjective condition
2406: under which all our intuitions take place. For in that case, this form
2407: of the inward intuition can be represented prior to the objects, and
2408: consequently à priori.
2409: 
2410: (b) Time is nothing else than the form of the internal sense, that is,
2411: of the intuitions of self and of our internal state. For time cannot be
2412: any determination of outward phenomena. It has to do neither with shape
2413: nor position; on the contrary, it determines the relation of
2414: representations in our internal state. And precisely because this
2415: internal intuition presents to us no shape or form, we endeavour to
2416: supply this want by analogies, and represent the course of time by a
2417: line progressing to infinity, the content of which constitutes a series
2418: which is only of one dimension; and we conclude from the properties of
2419: this line as to all the properties of time, with this single exception,
2420: that the parts of the line are coexistent, whilst those of time are
2421: successive. From this it is clear also that the representation of time
2422: is itself an intuition, because all its relations can be expressed in
2423: an external intuition.
2424: 
2425: (c) Time is the formal condition à priori of all phenomena whatsoever.
2426: Space, as the pure form of external intuition, is limited as a
2427: condition à priori to external phenomena alone. On the other hand,
2428: because all representations, whether they have or have not external
2429: things for their objects, still in themselves, as determinations of the
2430: mind, belong to our internal state; and because this internal state is
2431: subject to the formal condition of the internal intuition, that is, to
2432: time—time is a condition à priori of all phenomena whatsoever—the
2433: immediate condition of all internal, and thereby the mediate condition
2434: of all external phenomena. If I can say à priori, “All outward
2435: phenomena are in space, and determined à priori according to the
2436: relations of space,” I can also, from the principle of the internal
2437: sense, affirm universally, “All phenomena in general, that is, all
2438: objects of the senses, are in time and stand necessarily in relations
2439: of time.”
2440: 
2441: If we abstract our internal intuition of ourselves and all external
2442: intuitions, possible only by virtue of this internal intuition and
2443: presented to us by our faculty of representation, and consequently take
2444: objects as they are in themselves, then time is nothing. It is only of
2445: objective validity in regard to phenomena, because these are things
2446: which we regard as objects of our senses. It no longer objective we,
2447: make abstraction of the sensuousness of our intuition, in other words,
2448: of that mode of representation which is peculiar to us, and speak of
2449: things in general. Time is therefore merely a subjective condition of
2450: our (human) intuition (which is always sensuous, that is, so far as we
2451: are affected by objects), and in itself, independently of the mind or
2452: subject, is nothing. Nevertheless, in respect of all phenomena,
2453: consequently of all things which come within the sphere of our
2454: experience, it is necessarily objective. We cannot say, “All things are
2455: in time,” because in this conception of things in general, we abstract
2456: and make no mention of any sort of intuition of things. But this is the
2457: proper condition under which time belongs to our representation of
2458: objects. If we add the condition to the conception, and say, “All
2459: things, as phenomena, that is, objects of sensuous intuition, are in
2460: time,” then the proposition has its sound objective validity and
2461: universality à priori.
2462: 
2463: What we have now set forth teaches, therefore, the empirical reality of
2464: time; that is, its objective validity in reference to all objects which
2465: can ever be presented to our senses. And as our intuition is always
2466: sensuous, no object ever can be presented to us in experience, which
2467: does not come under the conditions of time. On the other hand, we deny
2468: to time all claim to absolute reality; that is, we deny that it,
2469: without having regard to the form of our sensuous intuition, absolutely
2470: inheres in things as a condition or property. Such properties as belong
2471: to objects as things in themselves never can be presented to us through
2472: the medium of the senses. Herein consists, therefore, the
2473: transcendental ideality of time, according to which, if we abstract the
2474: subjective conditions of sensuous intuition, it is nothing, and cannot
2475: be reckoned as subsisting or inhering in objects as things in
2476: themselves, independently of its relation to our intuition. This
2477: ideality, like that of space, is not to be proved or illustrated by
2478: fallacious analogies with sensations, for this reason—that in such
2479: arguments or illustrations, we make the presupposition that the
2480: phenomenon, in which such and such predicates inhere, has objective
2481: reality, while in this case we can only find such an objective reality
2482: as is itself empirical, that is, regards the object as a mere
2483: phenomenon. In reference to this subject, see the remark in Section I
2484: (§ 4)
2485: 
2486: § 8. Elucidation.
2487: 
2488: Against this theory, which grants empirical reality to time, but denies
2489: to it absolute and transcendental reality, I have heard from
2490: intelligent men an objection so unanimously urged that I conclude that
2491: it must naturally present itself to every reader to whom these
2492: considerations are novel. It runs thus: “Changes are real” (this the
2493: continual change in our own representations demonstrates, even though
2494: the existence of all external phenomena, together with their changes,
2495: is denied). Now, changes are only possible in time, and therefore time
2496: must be something real. But there is no difficulty in answering this. I
2497: grant the whole argument. Time, no doubt, is something real, that is,
2498: it is the real form of our internal intuition. It therefore has
2499: subjective reality, in reference to our internal experience, that is, I
2500: have really the representation of time and of my determinations
2501: therein. Time, therefore, is not to be regarded as an object, but as
2502: the mode of representation of myself as an object. But if I could
2503: intuite myself, or be intuited by another being, without this condition
2504: of sensibility, then those very determinations which we now represent
2505: to ourselves as changes, would present to us a knowledge in which the
2506: representation of time, and consequently of change, would not appear.
2507: The empirical reality of time, therefore, remains, as the condition of
2508: all our experience. But absolute reality, according to what has been
2509: said above, cannot be granted it. Time is nothing but the form of our
2510: internal intuition.[11] If we take away from it the special condition
2511: of our sensibility, the conception of time also vanishes; and it
2512: inheres not in the objects themselves, but solely in the subject (or
2513: mind) which intuites them.
2514: 
2515:  [11] I can indeed say “my representations follow one another, or are
2516:  successive”; but this means only that we are conscious of them as in a
2517:  succession, that is, according to the form of the internal sense.
2518:  Time, therefore, is not a thing in itself, nor is it any objective
2519:  determination pertaining to, or inherent in things.
2520: 
2521: 
2522: But the reason why this objection is so unanimously brought against our
2523: doctrine of time, and that too by disputants who cannot start any
2524: intelligible arguments against the doctrine of the ideality of space,
2525: is this—they have no hope of demonstrating apodeictically the absolute
2526: reality of space, because the doctrine of idealism is against them,
2527: according to which the reality of external objects is not capable of
2528: any strict proof. On the other hand, the reality of the object of our
2529: internal sense (that is, myself and my internal state) is clear
2530: immediately through consciousness. The former—external objects in
2531: space—might be a mere delusion, but the latter—the object of my
2532: internal perception—is undeniably real. They do not, however, reflect
2533: that both, without question of their reality as representations, belong
2534: only to the genus phenomenon, which has always two aspects, the one,
2535: the object considered as a thing in itself, without regard to the mode
2536: of intuiting it, and the nature of which remains for this very reason
2537: problematical, the other, the form of our intuition of the object,
2538: which must be sought not in the object as a thing in itself, but in the
2539: subject to which it appears—which form of intuition nevertheless
2540: belongs really and necessarily to the phenomenal object.
2541: 
2542: Time and space are, therefore, two sources of knowledge, from which, à
2543: priori, various synthetical cognitions can be drawn. Of this we find a
2544: striking example in the cognitions of space and its relations, which
2545: form the foundation of pure mathematics. They are the two pure forms of
2546: all intuitions, and thereby make synthetical propositions à priori
2547: possible. But these sources of knowledge being merely conditions of our
2548: sensibility, do therefore, and as such, strictly determine their own
2549: range and purpose, in that they do not and cannot present objects as
2550: things in themselves, but are applicable to them solely in so far as
2551: they are considered as sensuous phenomena. The sphere of phenomena is
2552: the only sphere of their validity, and if we venture out of this, no
2553: further objective use can be made of them. For the rest, this formal
2554: reality of time and space leaves the validity of our empirical
2555: knowledge unshaken; for our certainty in that respect is equally firm,
2556: whether these forms necessarily inhere in the things themselves, or
2557: only in our intuitions of them. On the other hand, those who maintain
2558: the absolute reality of time and space, whether as essentially
2559: subsisting, or only inhering, as modifications, in things, must find
2560: themselves at utter variance with the principles of experience itself.
2561: For, if they decide for the first view, and make space and time into
2562: substances, this being the side taken by mathematical natural
2563: philosophers, they must admit two self-subsisting nonentities, infinite
2564: and eternal, which exist (yet without there being anything real) for
2565: the purpose of containing in themselves everything that is real. If
2566: they adopt the second view of inherence, which is preferred by some
2567: metaphysical natural philosophers, and regard space and time as
2568: relations (contiguity in space or succession in time), abstracted from
2569: experience, though represented confusedly in this state of separation,
2570: they find themselves in that case necessitated to deny the validity of
2571: mathematical doctrines à priori in reference to real things (for
2572: example, in space)—at all events their apodeictic certainty. For such
2573: certainty cannot be found in an à posteriori proposition; and the
2574: conceptions à priori of space and time are, according to this opinion,
2575: mere creations of the imagination, having their source really in
2576: experience, inasmuch as, out of relations abstracted from experience,
2577: imagination has made up something which contains, indeed, general
2578: statements of these relations, yet of which no application can be made
2579: without the restrictions attached thereto by nature. The former of
2580: these parties gains this advantage, that they keep the sphere of
2581: phenomena free for mathematical science. On the other hand, these very
2582: conditions (space and time) embarrass them greatly, when the
2583: understanding endeavours to pass the limits of that sphere. The latter
2584: has, indeed, this advantage, that the representations of space and time
2585: do not come in their way when they wish to judge of objects, not as
2586: phenomena, but merely in their relation to the understanding. Devoid,
2587: however, of a true and objectively valid à priori intuition, they can
2588: neither furnish any basis for the possibility of mathematical
2589: cognitions à priori, nor bring the propositions of experience into
2590: necessary accordance with those of mathematics. In our theory of the
2591: true nature of these two original forms of the sensibility, both
2592: difficulties are surmounted.
2593: 
2594: In conclusion, that transcendental æsthetic cannot contain any more
2595: than these two elements—space and time, is sufficiently obvious from
2596: the fact that all other conceptions appertaining to sensibility, even
2597: that of motion, which unites in itself both elements, presuppose
2598: something empirical. Motion, for example, presupposes the perception of
2599: something movable. But space considered in itself contains nothing
2600: movable, consequently motion must be something which is found in space
2601: only through experience—in other words, an empirical datum. In like
2602: manner, transcendental æsthetic cannot number the conception of change
2603: among its data à priori; for time itself does not change, but only
2604: something which is in time. To acquire the conception of change,
2605: therefore, the perception of some existing object and of the succession
2606: of its determinations, in one word, experience, is necessary.
2607: 
2608: § 9. General Remarks on Transcendental Æsthetic.
2609: 
2610: I. In order to prevent any misunderstanding, it will be requisite, in
2611: the first place, to recapitulate, as clearly as possible, what our
2612: opinion is with respect to the fundamental nature of our sensuous
2613: cognition in general. We have intended, then, to say that all our
2614: intuition is nothing but the representation of phenomena; that the
2615: things which we intuite, are not in themselves the same as our
2616: representations of them in intuition, nor are their relations in
2617: themselves so constituted as they appear to us; and that if we take
2618: away the subject, or even only the subjective constitution of our
2619: senses in general, then not only the nature and relations of objects in
2620: space and time, but even space and time themselves disappear; and that
2621: these, as phenomena, cannot exist in themselves, but only in us. What
2622: may be the nature of objects considered as things in themselves and
2623: without reference to the receptivity of our sensibility is quite
2624: unknown to us. We know nothing more than our mode of perceiving them,
2625: which is peculiar to us, and which, though not of necessity pertaining
2626: to every animated being, is so to the whole human race. With this alone
2627: we have to do. Space and time are the pure forms thereof; sensation the
2628: matter. The former alone can we cognize à priori, that is, antecedent
2629: to all actual perception; and for this reason such cognition is called
2630: pure intuition. The latter is that in our cognition which is called
2631: cognition à posteriori, that is, empirical intuition. The former
2632: appertain absolutely and necessarily to our sensibility, of whatsoever
2633: kind our sensations may be; the latter may be of very diversified
2634: character. Supposing that we should carry our empirical intuition even
2635: to the very highest degree of clearness, we should not thereby advance
2636: one step nearer to a knowledge of the constitution of objects as things
2637: in themselves. For we could only, at best, arrive at a complete
2638: cognition of our own mode of intuition, that is of our sensibility, and
2639: this always under the conditions originally attaching to the subject,
2640: namely, the conditions of space and time; while the question: “What are
2641: objects considered as things in themselves?” remains unanswerable even
2642: after the most thorough examination of the phenomenal world.
2643: 
2644: To say, then, that all our sensibility is nothing but the confused
2645: representation of things containing exclusively that which belongs to
2646: them as things in themselves, and this under an accumulation of
2647: characteristic marks and partial representations which we cannot
2648: distinguish in consciousness, is a falsification of the conception of
2649: sensibility and phenomenization, which renders our whole doctrine
2650: thereof empty and useless. The difference between a confused and a
2651: clear representation is merely logical and has nothing to do with
2652: content. No doubt the conception of right, as employed by a sound
2653: understanding, contains all that the most subtle investigation could
2654: unfold from it, although, in the ordinary practical use of the word, we
2655: are not conscious of the manifold representations comprised in the
2656: conception. But we cannot for this reason assert that the ordinary
2657: conception is a sensuous one, containing a mere phenomenon, for right
2658: cannot appear as a phenomenon; but the conception of it lies in the
