2659: understanding, and represents a property (the moral property) of
2660: actions, which belongs to them in themselves. On the other hand, the
2661: representation in intuition of a body contains nothing which could
2662: belong to an object considered as a thing in itself, but merely the
2663: phenomenon or appearance of something, and the mode in which we are
2664: affected by that appearance; and this receptivity of our faculty of
2665: cognition is called sensibility, and remains toto caelo different from
2666: the cognition of an object in itself, even though we should examine the
2667: content of the phenomenon to the very bottom.
2668: 
2669: It must be admitted that the Leibnitz-Wolfian philosophy has assigned
2670: an entirely erroneous point of view to all investigations into the
2671: nature and origin of our cognitions, inasmuch as it regards the
2672: distinction between the sensuous and the intellectual as merely
2673: logical, whereas it is plainly transcendental, and concerns not merely
2674: the clearness or obscurity, but the content and origin of both. For the
2675: faculty of sensibility not only does not present us with an indistinct
2676: and confused cognition of objects as things in themselves, but, in
2677: fact, gives us no knowledge of these at all. On the contrary, so soon
2678: as we abstract in thought our own subjective nature, the object
2679: represented, with the properties ascribed to it by sensuous intuition,
2680: entirely disappears, because it was only this subjective nature that
2681: determined the form of the object as a phenomenon.
2682: 
2683: In phenomena, we commonly, indeed, distinguish that which essentially
2684: belongs to the intuition of them, and is valid for the sensuous faculty
2685: of every human being, from that which belongs to the same intuition
2686: accidentally, as valid not for the sensuous faculty in general, but for
2687: a particular state or organization of this or that sense. Accordingly,
2688: we are accustomed to say that the former is a cognition which
2689: represents the object itself, whilst the latter presents only a
2690: particular appearance or phenomenon thereof. This distinction, however,
2691: is only empirical. If we stop here (as is usual), and do not regard the
2692: empirical intuition as itself a mere phenomenon (as we ought to do), in
2693: which nothing that can appertain to a thing in itself is to be found,
2694: our transcendental distinction is lost, and we believe that we cognize
2695: objects as things in themselves, although in the whole range of the
2696: sensuous world, investigate the nature of its objects as profoundly as
2697: we may, we have to do with nothing but phenomena. Thus, we call the
2698: rainbow a mere appearance of phenomenon in a sunny shower, and the
2699: rain, the reality or thing in itself; and this is right enough, if we
2700: understand the latter conception in a merely physical sense, that is,
2701: as that which in universal experience, and under whatever conditions of
2702: sensuous perception, is known in intuition to be so and so determined,
2703: and not otherwise. But if we consider this empirical datum generally,
2704: and inquire, without reference to its accordance with all our senses,
2705: whether there can be discovered in it aught which represents an object
2706: as a thing in itself (the raindrops of course are not such, for they
2707: are, as phenomena, empirical objects), the question of the relation of
2708: the representation to the object is transcendental; and not only are
2709: the raindrops mere phenomena, but even their circular form, nay, the
2710: space itself through which they fall, is nothing in itself, but both
2711: are mere modifications or fundamental dispositions of our sensuous
2712: intuition, whilst the transcendental object remains for us utterly
2713: unknown.
2714: 
2715: The second important concern of our æsthetic is that it does not obtain
2716: favour merely as a plausible hypothesis, but possess as undoubted a
2717: character of certainty as can be demanded of any theory which is to
2718: serve for an organon. In order fully to convince the reader of this
2719: certainty, we shall select a case which will serve to make its validity
2720: apparent, and also to illustrate what has been said in § 3.
2721: 
2722: Suppose, then, that space and time are in themselves objective, and
2723: conditions of the—possibility of objects as things in themselves. In
2724: the first place, it is evident that both present us, with very many
2725: apodeictic and synthetic propositions à priori, but especially
2726: space—and for this reason we shall prefer it for investigation at
2727: present. As the propositions of geometry are cognized synthetically à
2728: priori, and with apodeictic certainty, I inquire: Whence do you obtain
2729: propositions of this kind, and on what basis does the understanding
2730: rest, in order to arrive at such absolutely necessary and universally
2731: valid truths?
2732: 
2733: There is no other way than through intuitions or conceptions, as such;
2734: and these are given either à priori or à posteriori. The latter,
2735: namely, empirical conceptions, together with the empirical intuition on
2736: which they are founded, cannot afford any synthetical proposition,
2737: except such as is itself also empirical, that is, a proposition of
2738: experience. But an empirical proposition cannot possess the qualities
2739: of necessity and absolute universality, which, nevertheless, are the
2740: characteristics of all geometrical propositions. As to the first and
2741: only means to arrive at such cognitions, namely, through mere
2742: conceptions or intuitions à priori, it is quite clear that from mere
2743: conceptions no synthetical cognitions, but only analytical ones, can be
2744: obtained. Take, for example, the proposition: “Two straight lines
2745: cannot enclose a space, and with these alone no figure is possible,”
2746: and try to deduce it from the conception of a straight line and the
2747: number two; or take the proposition: “It is possible to construct a
2748: figure with three straight lines,” and endeavour, in like manner, to
2749: deduce it from the mere conception of a straight line and the number
2750: three. All your endeavours are in vain, and you find yourself forced to
2751: have recourse to intuition, as, in fact, geometry always does. You
2752: therefore give yourself an object in intuition. But of what kind is
2753: this intuition? Is it a pure à priori, or is it an empirical intuition?
2754: If the latter, then neither an universally valid, much less an
2755: apodeictic proposition can arise from it, for experience never can give
2756: us any such proposition. You must, therefore, give yourself an object à
2757: priori in intuition, and upon that ground your synthetical proposition.
2758: Now if there did not exist within you a faculty of intuition à priori;
2759: if this subjective condition were not in respect to its form also the
2760: universal condition à priori under which alone the object of this
2761: external intuition is itself possible; if the object (that is, the
2762: triangle) were something in itself, without relation to you the
2763: subject; how could you affirm that that which lies necessarily in your
2764: subjective conditions in order to construct a triangle, must also
2765: necessarily belong to the triangle in itself? For to your conceptions
2766: of three lines, you could not add anything new (that is, the figure);
2767: which, therefore, must necessarily be found in the object, because the
2768: object is given before your cognition, and not by means of it. If,
2769: therefore, space (and time also) were not a mere form of your
2770: intuition, which contains conditions à priori, under which alone things
2771: can become external objects for you, and without which subjective
2772: conditions the objects are in themselves nothing, you could not
2773: construct any synthetical proposition whatsoever regarding external
2774: objects. It is therefore not merely possible or probable, but
2775: indubitably certain, that space and time, as the necessary conditions
2776: of all our external and internal experience, are merely subjective
2777: conditions of all our intuitions, in relation to which all objects are
2778: therefore mere phenomena, and not things in themselves, presented to us
2779: in this particular manner. And for this reason, in respect to the form
2780: of phenomena, much may be said à priori, whilst of the thing in itself,
2781: which may lie at the foundation of these phenomena, it is impossible to
2782: say anything.
2783: 
2784: II. In confirmation of this theory of the ideality of the external as
2785: well as internal sense, consequently of all objects of sense, as mere
2786: phenomena, we may especially remark that all in our cognition that
2787: belongs to intuition contains nothing more than mere relations. (The
2788: feelings of pain and pleasure, and the will, which are not cognitions,
2789: are excepted.) The relations, to wit, of place in an intuition
2790: (extension), change of place (motion), and laws according to which this
2791: change is determined (moving forces). That, however, which is present
2792: in this or that place, or any operation going on, or result taking
2793: place in the things themselves, with the exception of change of place,
2794: is not given to us by intuition. Now by means of mere relations, a
2795: thing cannot be known in itself; and it may therefore be fairly
2796: concluded, that, as through the external sense nothing but mere
2797: representations of relations are given us, the said external sense in
2798: its representation can contain only the relation of the object to the
2799: subject, but not the essential nature of the object as a thing in
2800: itself.
2801: 
2802: The same is the case with the internal intuition, not only because, in
2803: the internal intuition, the representation of the external senses
2804: constitutes the material with which the mind is occupied; but because
2805: time, in which we place, and which itself antecedes the consciousness
2806: of, these representations in experience, and which, as the formal
2807: condition of the mode according to which objects are placed in the
2808: mind, lies at the foundation of them, contains relations of the
2809: successive, the coexistent, and of that which always must be coexistent
2810: with succession, the permanent. Now that which, as representation, can
2811: antecede every exercise of thought (of an object), is intuition; and
2812: when it contains nothing but relations, it is the form of the
2813: intuition, which, as it presents us with no representation, except in
2814: so far as something is placed in the mind, can be nothing else than the
2815: mode in which the mind is affected by its own activity, to wit—its
2816: presenting to itself representations, consequently the mode in which
2817: the mind is affected by itself; that is, it can be nothing but an
2818: internal sense in respect to its form. Everything that is represented
2819: through the medium of sense is so far phenomenal; consequently, we must
2820: either refuse altogether to admit an internal sense, or the subject,
2821: which is the object of that sense, could only be represented by it as
2822: phenomenon, and not as it would judge of itself, if its intuition were
2823: pure spontaneous activity, that is, were intellectual. The difficulty
2824: here lies wholly in the question: How can the subject have an internal
2825: intuition of itself? But this difficulty is common to every theory. The
2826: consciousness of self (apperception) is the simple representation of
2827: the “ego”; and if by means of that representation alone, all the
2828: manifold representations in the subject were spontaneously given, then
2829: our internal intuition would be intellectual. This consciousness in man
2830: requires an internal perception of the manifold representations which
2831: are previously given in the subject; and the manner in which these
2832: representations are given in the mind without spontaneity, must, on
2833: account of this difference (the want of spontaneity), be called
2834: sensibility. If the faculty of self-consciousness is to apprehend what
2835: lies in the mind, it must all act that and can in this way alone
2836: produce an intuition of self. But the form of this intuition, which
2837: lies in the original constitution of the mind, determines, in the
2838: representation of time, the manner in which the manifold
2839: representations are to combine themselves in the mind; since the
2840: subject intuites itself, not as it would represent itself immediately
2841: and spontaneously, but according to the manner in which the mind is
2842: internally affected, consequently, as it appears, and not as it is.
2843: 
2844: III. When we say that the intuition of external objects, and also the
2845: self-intuition of the subject, represent both, objects and subject, in
2846: space and time, as they affect our senses, that is, as they appear—this
2847: is by no means equivalent to asserting that these objects are mere
2848: illusory appearances. For when we speak of things as phenomena, the
2849: objects, nay, even the properties which we ascribe to them, are looked
2850: upon as really given; only that, in so far as this or that property
2851: depends upon the mode of intuition of the subject, in the relation of
2852: the given object to the subject, the object as phenomenon is to be
2853: distinguished from the object as a thing in itself. Thus I do not say
2854: that bodies seem or appear to be external to me, or that my soul seems
2855: merely to be given in my self-consciousness, although I maintain that
2856: the properties of space and time, in conformity to which I set both, as
2857: the condition of their existence, abide in my mode of intuition, and
2858: not in the objects in themselves. It would be my own fault, if out of
2859: that which I should reckon as phenomenon, I made mere illusory
2860: appearance.[12] But this will not happen, because of our principle of
2861: the ideality of all sensuous intuitions. On the contrary, if we ascribe
2862: objective reality to these forms of representation, it becomes
2863: impossible to avoid changing everything into mere appearance. For if we
2864: regard space and time as properties, which must be found in objects as
2865: things in themselves, as sine quibus non of the possibility of their
2866: existence, and reflect on the absurdities in which we then find
2867: ourselves involved, inasmuch as we are compelled to admit the existence
2868: of two infinite things, which are nevertheless not substances, nor
2869: anything really inhering in substances, nay, to admit that they are the
2870: necessary conditions of the existence of all things, and moreover, that
2871: they must continue to exist, although all existing things were
2872: annihilated—we cannot blame the good Berkeley for degrading bodies to
2873: mere illusory appearances. Nay, even our own existence, which would in
2874: this case depend upon the self-existent reality of such a mere
2875: nonentity as time, would necessarily be changed with it into mere
2876: appearance—an absurdity which no one has as yet been guilty of.
2877: 
2878:  [12] The predicates of the phenomenon can be affixed to the object
2879:  itself in relation to our sensuous faculty; for example, the red
2880:  colour or the perfume to the rose. But (illusory) appearance never can
2881:  be attributed as a predicate to an object, for this very reason, that
2882:  it attributes to this object in itself that which belongs to it only
2883:  in relation to our sensuous faculty, or to the subject in general,
2884:  e.g., the two handles which were formerly ascribed to Saturn. That
2885:  which is never to be found in the object itself, but always in the
2886:  relation of the object to the subject, and which moreover is
2887:  inseparable from our representation of the object, we denominate
2888:  phenomenon. Thus the predicates of space and time are rightly
2889:  attributed to objects of the senses as such, and in this there is no
2890:  illusion. On the contrary, if I ascribe redness of the rose as a thing
2891:  in itself, or to Saturn his handles, or extension to all external
2892:  objects, considered as things in themselves, without regarding the
2893:  determinate relation of these objects to the subject, and without
2894:  limiting my judgement to that relation—then, and then only, arises
2895:  illusion.
2896: 
2897: 
2898: IV. In natural theology, where we think of an object—God—which never
2899: can be an object of intuition to us, and even to himself can never be
2900: an object of sensuous intuition, we carefully avoid attributing to his
2901: intuition the conditions of space and time—and intuition all his
2902: cognition must be, and not thought, which always includes limitation.
2903: But with what right can we do this if we make them forms of objects as
2904: things in themselves, and such, moreover, as would continue to exist as
2905: à priori conditions of the existence of things, even though the things
2906: themselves were annihilated? For as conditions of all existence in
2907: general, space and time must be conditions of the existence of the
2908: Supreme Being also. But if we do not thus make them objective forms of
2909: all things, there is no other way left than to make them subjective
2910: forms of our mode of intuition—external and internal; which is called
2911: sensuous, because it is not primitive, that is, is not such as gives in
2912: itself the existence of the object of the intuition (a mode of
2913: intuition which, so far as we can judge, can belong only to the
2914: Creator), but is dependent on the existence of the object, is possible,
2915: therefore, only on condition that the representative faculty of the
2916: subject is affected by the object.
2917: 
2918: It is, moreover, not necessary that we should limit the mode of
2919: intuition in space and time to the sensuous faculty of man. It may well
2920: be that all finite thinking beings must necessarily in this respect
2921: agree with man (though as to this we cannot decide), but sensibility
2922: does not on account of this universality cease to be sensibility, for
2923: this very reason, that it is a deduced (intuitus derivativus), and not
2924: an original (intuitus originarius), consequently not an intellectual
2925: intuition, and this intuition, as such, for reasons above mentioned,
2926: seems to belong solely to the Supreme Being, but never to a being
2927: dependent, quoad its existence, as well as its intuition (which its
2928: existence determines and limits relatively to given objects). This
2929: latter remark, however, must be taken only as an illustration, and not
2930: as any proof of the truth of our æsthetical theory.
2931: 
2932: § 10. Conclusion of the Transcendental Æsthetic.
2933: 
2934: We have now completely before us one part of the solution of the grand
2935: general problem of transcendental philosophy, namely, the question:
2936: “How are synthetical propositions à priori possible?” That is to say,
2937: we have shown that we are in possession of pure à priori intuitions,
2938: namely, space and time, in which we find, when in a judgement à priori
2939: we pass out beyond the given conception, something which is not
2940: discoverable in that conception, but is certainly found à priori in the
2941: intuition which corresponds to the conception, and can be united
2942: synthetically with it. But the judgements which these pure intuitions
2943: enable us to make, never reach farther than to objects of the senses,
2944: and are valid only for objects of possible experience.
2945: 
2946: Second Part—TRANSCENDENTAL LOGIC
2947: 
2948: INTRODUCTION. Idea of a Transcendental Logic.
2949: 
2950: I. Of Logic in General.
2951: 
2952: Our knowledge springs from two main sources in the mind, first of which
2953: is the faculty or power of receiving representations (receptivity for
2954: impressions); the second is the power of cognizing by means of these
2955: representations (spontaneity in the production of conceptions). Through
2956: the first an object is given to us; through the second, it is, in
2957: relation to the representation (which is a mere determination of the
2958: mind), thought. Intuition and conceptions constitute, therefore, the
2959: elements of all our knowledge, so that neither conceptions without an
2960: intuition in some way corresponding to them, nor intuition without
2961: conceptions, can afford us a cognition. Both are either pure or
2962: empirical. They are empirical, when sensation (which presupposes the
2963: actual presence of the object) is contained in them; and pure, when no
2964: sensation is mixed with the representation. Sensations we may call the
2965: matter of sensuous cognition. Pure intuition consequently contains
2966: merely the form under which something is intuited, and pure conception
2967: only the form of the thought of an object. Only pure intuitions and
2968: pure conceptions are possible à priori; the empirical only à
2969: posteriori.
2970: 
2971: We apply the term sensibility to the receptivity of the mind for
2972: impressions, in so far as it is in some way affected; and, on the other
2973: hand, we call the faculty of spontaneously producing representations,
2974: or the spontaneity of cognition, understanding. Our nature is so
2975: constituted that intuition with us never can be other than sensuous,
2976: that is, it contains only the mode in which we are affected by objects.
2977: On the other hand, the faculty of thinking the object of sensuous
2978: intuition is the understanding. Neither of these faculties has a
2979: preference over the other. Without the sensuous faculty no object would
2980: be given to us, and without the understanding no object would be
2981: thought. Thoughts without content are void; intuitions without
2982: conceptions, blind. Hence it is as necessary for the mind to make its
2983: conceptions sensuous (that is, to join to them the object in
2984: intuition), as to make its intuitions intelligible (that is, to bring
2985: them under conceptions). Neither of these faculties can exchange its
2986: proper function. Understanding cannot intuite, and the sensuous faculty
2987: cannot think. In no other way than from the united operation of both,
2988: can knowledge arise. But no one ought, on this account, to overlook the
2989: difference of the elements contributed by each; we have rather great
2990: reason carefully to separate and distinguish them. We therefore
2991: distinguish the science of the laws of sensibility, that is, æsthetic,
2992: from the science of the laws of the understanding, that is, logic.
2993: 
2994: Now, logic in its turn may be considered as twofold—namely, as logic of
2995: the general, or of the particular use of the understanding. The first
2996: contains the absolutely necessary laws of thought, without which no use
2997: whatsoever of the understanding is possible, and gives laws therefore
2998: to the understanding, without regard to the difference of objects on
2999: which it may be employed. The logic of the particular use of the
3000: understanding contains the laws of correct thinking upon a particular
3001: class of objects. The former may be called elemental logic—the latter,
3002: the organon of this or that particular science. The latter is for the
3003: most part employed in the schools, as a propædeutic to the sciences,
3004: although, indeed, according to the course of human reason, it is the
3005: last thing we arrive at, when the science has been already matured, and
3006: needs only the finishing touches towards its correction and completion;
3007: for our knowledge of the objects of our attempted science must be
3008: tolerably extensive and complete before we can indicate the laws by
3009: which a science of these objects can be established.
3010: 
3011: General logic is again either pure or applied. In the former, we
3012: abstract all the empirical conditions under which the understanding is
3013: exercised; for example, the influence of the senses, the play of the
3014: fantasy or imagination, the laws of the memory, the force of habit, of
3015: inclination, etc., consequently also, the sources of prejudice—in a
3016: word, we abstract all causes from which particular cognitions arise,
3017: because these causes regard the understanding under certain
3018: circumstances of its application, and, to the knowledge of them
3019: experience is required. Pure general logic has to do, therefore, merely
3020: with pure à priori principles, and is a canon of understanding and
3021: reason, but only in respect of the formal part of their use, be the
3022: content what it may, empirical or transcendental. General logic is
3023: called applied, when it is directed to the laws of the use of the
3024: understanding, under the subjective empirical conditions which
3025: psychology teaches us. It has therefore empirical principles, although,
3026: at the same time, it is in so far general, that it applies to the
3027: exercise of the understanding, without regard to the difference of
3028: objects. On this account, moreover, it is neither a canon of the
3029: understanding in general, nor an organon of a particular science, but
3030: merely a cathartic of the human understanding.
3031: 
3032: In general logic, therefore, that part which constitutes pure logic
3033: must be carefully distinguished from that which constitutes applied
3034: (though still general) logic. The former alone is properly science,
3035: although short and dry, as the methodical exposition of an elemental
3036: doctrine of the understanding ought to be. In this, therefore,
3037: logicians must always bear in mind two rules:
3038: 
3039: 1. As general logic, it makes abstraction of all content of the
3040: cognition of the understanding, and of the difference of objects, and
3041: has to do with nothing but the mere form of thought.
3042: 
3043: 2. As pure logic, it has no empirical principles, and consequently
3044: draws nothing (contrary to the common persuasion) from psychology,
3045: which therefore has no influence on the canon of the understanding. It
3046: is a demonstrated doctrine, and everything in it must be certain
3047: completely à priori.
3048: 
3049: What I called applied logic (contrary to the common acceptation of this
3050: term, according to which it should contain certain exercises for the
3051: scholar, for which pure logic gives the rules), is a representation of
3052: the understanding, and of the rules of its necessary employment in
3053: concreto, that is to say, under the accidental conditions of the
3054: subject, which may either hinder or promote this employment, and which
3055: are all given only empirically. Thus applied logic treats of attention,
3056: its impediments and consequences, of the origin of error, of the state
3057: of doubt, hesitation, conviction, etc., and to it is related pure
3058: general logic in the same way that pure morality, which contains only
3059: the necessary moral laws of a free will, is related to practical
3060: ethics, which considers these laws under all the impediments of
3061: feelings, inclinations, and passions to which men are more or less
3062: subjected, and which never can furnish us with a true and demonstrated
3063: science, because it, as well as applied logic, requires empirical and
3064: psychological principles.
3065: 
3066: II. Of Transcendental Logic.
3067: 
3068: General logic, as we have seen, makes abstraction of all content of
3069: cognition, that is, of all relation of cognition to its object, and
3070: regards only the logical form in the relation of cognitions to each
3071: other, that is, the form of thought in general. But as we have both
3072: pure and empirical intuitions (as transcendental æsthetic proves), in
3073: like manner a distinction might be drawn between pure and empirical
3074: thought (of objects). In this case, there would exist a kind of logic,
3075: in which we should not make abstraction of all content of cognition;
3076: for or logic which should comprise merely the laws of pure thought (of
3077: an object), would of course exclude all those cognitions which were of
3078: empirical content. This kind of logic would also examine the origin of
3079: our cognitions of objects, so far as that origin cannot be ascribed to
3080: the objects themselves; while, on the contrary, general logic has
3081: nothing to do with the origin of our cognitions, but contemplates our
3082: representations, be they given primitively à priori in ourselves, or be
3083: they only of empirical origin, solely according to the laws which the
3084: understanding observes in employing them in the process of thought, in
3085: relation to each other. Consequently, general logic treats of the form
3086: of the understanding only, which can be applied to representations,
3087: from whatever source they may have arisen.
3088: 
3089: And here I shall make a remark, which the reader must bear well in mind
3090: in the course of the following considerations, to wit, that not every
3091: cognition à priori, but only those through which we cognize that and
3092: how certain representations (intuitions or conceptions) are applied or
3093: are possible only à priori; that is to say, the à priori possibility of
3094: cognition and the à priori use of it are transcendental. Therefore
3095: neither is space, nor any à priori geometrical determination of space,
3096: a transcendental Representation, but only the knowledge that such a
3097: representation is not of empirical origin, and the possibility of its
3098: relating to objects of experience, although itself à priori, can be
3099: called transcendental. So also, the application of space to objects in
3100: general would be transcendental; but if it be limited to objects of
3101: sense it is empirical. Thus, the distinction of the transcendental and
3102: empirical belongs only to the critique of cognitions, and does not
3103: concern the relation of these to their object.
3104: 
3105: Accordingly, in the expectation that there may perhaps be conceptions
3106: which relate à priori to objects, not as pure or sensuous intuitions,
3107: but merely as acts of pure thought (which are therefore conceptions,
3108: but neither of empirical nor æsthetical origin)—in this expectation, I
3109: say, we form to ourselves, by anticipation, the idea of a science of
3110: pure understanding and rational cognition, by means of which we may
3111: cogitate objects entirely à priori. A science of this kind, which
3112: should determine the origin, the extent, and the objective validity of
3113: such cognitions, must be called transcendental logic, because it has
3114: not, like general logic, to do with the laws of understanding and
3115: reason in relation to empirical as well as pure rational cognitions
3116: without distinction, but concerns itself with these only in an à priori
3117: relation to objects.
3118: 
3119: III. Of the Division of General Logic into Analytic and Dialectic.
3120: 
3121: The old question with which people sought to push logicians into a
3122: corner, so that they must either have recourse to pitiful sophisms or
3123: confess their ignorance, and consequently the vanity of their whole
3124: art, is this: “What is truth?” The definition of the word truth, to
3125: wit, “the accordance of the cognition with its object,” is presupposed
3126: in the question; but we desire to be told, in the answer to it, what is
3127: the universal and secure criterion of the truth of every cognition.
3128: 
3129: To know what questions we may reasonably propose is in itself a strong
3130: evidence of sagacity and intelligence. For if a question be in itself
3131: absurd and unsusceptible of a rational answer, it is attended with the
3132: danger—not to mention the shame that falls upon the person who proposes
3133: it—of seducing the unguarded listener into making absurd answers, and
3134: we are presented with the ridiculous spectacle of one (as the ancients
3135: said) “milking the he-goat, and the other holding a sieve.”
3136: 
3137: If truth consists in the accordance of a cognition with its object,
3138: this object must be, ipso facto, distinguished from all others; for a
3139: cognition is false if it does not accord with the object to which it
3140: relates, although it contains something which may be affirmed of other
3141: objects. Now an universal criterion of truth would be that which is
3142: valid for all cognitions, without distinction of their objects. But it
3143: is evident that since, in the case of such a criterion, we make
3144: abstraction of all the content of a cognition (that is, of all relation
3145: to its object), and truth relates precisely to this content, it must be
3146: utterly absurd to ask for a mark of the truth of this content of
3147: cognition; and that, accordingly, a sufficient, and at the same time
3148: universal, test of truth cannot possibly be found. As we have already
3149: termed the content of a cognition its matter, we shall say: “Of the
3150: truth of our cognitions in respect of their matter, no universal test
3151: can be demanded, because such a demand is self-contradictory.”
3152: 
3153: On the other hand, with regard to our cognition in respect of its mere
3154: form (excluding all content), it is equally manifest that logic, in so
3155: far as it exhibits the universal and necessary laws of the
3156: understanding, must in these very laws present us with criteria of
3157: truth. Whatever contradicts these rules is false, because thereby the
3158: understanding is made to contradict its own universal laws of thought;
3159: that is, to contradict itself. These criteria, however, apply solely to
3160: the form of truth, that is, of thought in general, and in so far they
3161: are perfectly accurate, yet not sufficient. For although a cognition
3162: may be perfectly accurate as to logical form, that is, not
3163: self-contradictory, it is notwithstanding quite possible that it may
3164: not stand in agreement with its object. Consequently, the merely
3165: logical criterion of truth, namely, the accordance of a cognition with
3166: the universal and formal laws of understanding and reason, is nothing
3167: more than the conditio sine qua non, or negative condition of all
3168: truth. Farther than this logic cannot go, and the error which depends
3169: not on the form, but on the content of the cognition, it has no test to
3170: discover.
3171: 
3172: General logic, then, resolves the whole formal business of
3173: understanding and reason into its elements, and exhibits them as
3174: principles of all logical judging of our cognitions. This part of logic
3175: may, therefore, be called analytic, and is at least the negative test
3176: of truth, because all cognitions must first of an be estimated and
3177: tried according to these laws before we proceed to investigate them in
3178: respect of their content, in order to discover whether they contain
3179: positive truth in regard to their object. Because, however, the mere
3180: form of a cognition, accurately as it may accord with logical laws, is
3181: insufficient to supply us with material (objective) truth, no one, by
3182: means of logic alone, can venture to predicate anything of or decide
3183: concerning objects, unless he has obtained, independently of logic,
3184: well-grounded information about them, in order afterwards to examine,
3185: according to logical laws, into the use and connection, in a cohering
3186: whole, of that information, or, what is still better, merely to test it
3187: by them. Notwithstanding, there lies so seductive a charm in the
3188: possession of a specious art like this—an art which gives to all our
3189: cognitions the form of the understanding, although with respect to the
3190: content thereof we may be sadly deficient—that general logic, which is
3191: merely a canon of judgement, has been employed as an organon for the
3192: actual production, or rather for the semblance of production, of
3193: objective assertions, and has thus been grossly misapplied. Now general
3194: logic, in its assumed character of organon, is called dialectic.
3195: 
3196: Different as are the significations in which the ancients used this
3197: term for a science or an art, we may safely infer, from their actual
3198: employment of it, that with them it was nothing else than a logic of
3199: illusion—a sophistical art for giving ignorance, nay, even intentional
3200: sophistries, the colouring of truth, in which the thoroughness of
3201: procedure which logic requires was imitated, and their topic employed
3202: to cloak the empty pretensions. Now it may be taken as a safe and
3203: useful warning, that general logic, considered as an organon, must
3204: always be a logic of illusion, that is, be dialectical, for, as it
3205: teaches us nothing whatever respecting the content of our cognitions,
3206: but merely the formal conditions of their accordance with the
3207: understanding, which do not relate to and are quite indifferent in
3208: respect of objects, any attempt to employ it as an instrument (organon)
3209: in order to extend and enlarge the range of our knowledge must end in
3210: mere prating; any one being able to maintain or oppose, with some
3211: appearance of truth, any single assertion whatever.
3212: 
3213: Such instruction is quite unbecoming the dignity of philosophy. For
3214: these reasons we have chosen to denominate this part of logic
3215: dialectic, in the sense of a critique of dialectical illusion, and we
3216: wish the term to be so understood in this place.
3217: 
3218: IV. Of the Division of Transcendental Logic into Transcendental
3219: Analytic and Dialectic.
3220: 
3221: In transcendental logic we isolate the understanding (as in
3222: transcendental æsthetic the sensibility) and select from our cognition
3223: merely that part of thought which has its origin in the understanding
3224: alone. The exercise of this pure cognition, however, depends upon this
3225: as its condition, that objects to which it may be applied be given to
3226: us in intuition, for without intuition the whole of our cognition is
3227: without objects, and is therefore quite void. That part of
3228: transcendental logic, then, which treats of the elements of pure
3229: cognition of the understanding, and of the principles without which no
3230: object at all can be thought, is transcendental analytic, and at the
3231: same time a logic of truth. For no cognition can contradict it, without
3232: losing at the same time all content, that is, losing all reference to
3233: an object, and therefore all truth. But because we are very easily
3234: seduced into employing these pure cognitions and principles of the
3235: understanding by themselves, and that even beyond the boundaries of
3236: experience, which yet is the only source whence we can obtain matter
3237: (objects) on which those pure conceptions may be employed—understanding
3238: runs the risk of making, by means of empty sophisms, a material and
3239: objective use of the mere formal principles of the pure understanding,
3240: and of passing judgements on objects without distinction—objects which
3241: are not given to us, nay, perhaps cannot be given to us in any way.
3242: Now, as it ought properly to be only a canon for judging of the
3243: empirical use of the understanding, this kind of logic is misused when
3244: we seek to employ it as an organon of the universal and unlimited
3245: exercise of the understanding, and attempt with the pure understanding
3246: alone to judge synthetically, affirm, and determine respecting objects
3247: in general. In this case the exercise of the pure understanding becomes
3248: dialectical. The second part of our transcendental logic must therefore
3249: be a critique of dialectical illusion, and this critique we shall term
3250: transcendental dialectic—not meaning it as an art of producing
3251: dogmatically such illusion (an art which is unfortunately too current
3252: among the practitioners of metaphysical juggling), but as a critique of
3253: understanding and reason in regard to their hyperphysical use. This
3254: critique will expose the groundless nature of the pretensions of these
3255: two faculties, and invalidate their claims to the discovery and
3256: enlargement of our cognitions merely by means of transcendental
3257: principles, and show that the proper employment of these faculties is
3258: to test the judgements made by the pure understanding, and to guard it
3259: from sophistical delusion.
3260: 
3261: FIRST DIVISION. TRANSCENDENTAL LOGIC. TRANSCENDENTAL ANALYTIC. § 1
3262: 
3263: Transcendental analytic is the dissection of the whole of our à priori
3264: knowledge into the elements of the pure cognition of the understanding.
3265: In order to effect our purpose, it is necessary: (1) That the
3266: conceptions be pure and not empirical; (2) That they belong not to
3267: intuition and sensibility, but to thought and understanding; (3) That
3268: they be elementary conceptions, and as such, quite different from
3269: deduced or compound conceptions; (4) That our table of these elementary
3270: conceptions be complete, and fill up the whole sphere of the pure
3271: understanding. Now this completeness of a science cannot be accepted
3272: with confidence on the guarantee of a mere estimate of its existence in
3273: an aggregate formed only by means of repeated experiments and attempts.
3274: The completeness which we require is possible only by means of an idea
3275: of the totality of the à priori cognition of the understanding, and
3276: through the thereby determined division of the conceptions which form
3277: the said whole; consequently, only by means of their connection in a
3278: system. Pure understanding distinguishes itself not merely from
3279: everything empirical, but also completely from all sensibility. It is a
3280: unity self-subsistent, self-sufficient, and not to be enlarged by any
3281: additions from without. Hence the sum of its cognition constitutes a
3282: system to be determined by and comprised under an idea; and the
3283: completeness and articulation of this system can at the same time serve
3284: as a test of the correctness and genuineness of all the parts of
3285: cognition that belong to it. The whole of this part of transcendental
3286: logic consists of two books, of which the one contains the conceptions,
3287: and the other the principles of pure understanding.
3288: 
3289: BOOK I. Analytic of Conceptions. § 2
3290: 
3291: By the term Analytic of Conceptions, I do not understand the analysis
3292: of these, or the usual process in philosophical investigations of
3293: dissecting the conceptions which present themselves, according to their
3294: content, and so making them clear; but I mean the hitherto little
3295: attempted dissection of the faculty of understanding itself, in order
3296: to investigate the possibility of conceptions à priori, by looking for
3297: them in the understanding alone, as their birthplace, and analysing the
3298: pure use of this faculty. For this is the proper duty of a
3299: transcendental philosophy; what remains is the logical treatment of the
3300: conceptions in philosophy in general. We shall therefore follow up the
3301: pure conceptions even to their germs and beginnings in the human
3302: understanding, in which they lie, until they are developed on occasions
3303: presented by experience, and, freed by the same understanding from the
3304: empirical conditions attaching to them, are set forth in their
3305: unalloyed purity.
3306: 
3307: Chapter I. Of the Transcendental Clue to the Discovery of all Pure 
3308: Conceptions of the Understanding
3309: 
3310: Introductory § 3
3311: 
3312: When we call into play a faculty of cognition, different conceptions
3313: manifest themselves according to the different circumstances, and make
3314: known this faculty, and assemble themselves into a more or less
3315: extensive collection, according to the time or penetration that has
3316: been applied to the consideration of them. Where this process,
3317: conducted as it is mechanically, so to speak, will end, cannot be
3318: determined with certainty. Besides, the conceptions which we discover
3319: in this haphazard manner present themselves by no means in order and
3320: systematic unity, but are at last coupled together only according to
3321: resemblances to each other, and arranged in series, according to the
3322: quantity of their content, from the simpler to the more complex—series
3323: which are anything but systematic, though not altogether without a
3324: certain kind of method in their construction.
3325: 
3326: Transcendental philosophy has the advantage, and moreover the duty, of
3327: searching for its conceptions according to a principle; because these
3328: conceptions spring pure and unmixed out of the understanding as an
3329: absolute unity, and therefore must be connected with each other
3330: according to one conception or idea. A connection of this kind,
3331: however, furnishes us with a ready prepared rule, by which its proper
3332: place may be assigned to every pure conception of the understanding,
3333: and the completeness of the system of all be determined à priori—both
3334: which would otherwise have been dependent on mere choice or chance.
3335: 
3336: Section I. Of the Logical Use of the Understanding in General § 4
3337: 
3338: The understanding was defined above only negatively, as a non-sensuous
3339: faculty of cognition. Now, independently of sensibility, we cannot
3340: possibly have any intuition; consequently, the understanding is no
3341: faculty of intuition. But besides intuition there is no other mode of
3342: cognition, except through conceptions; consequently, the cognition of
3343: every, at least of every human, understanding is a cognition through
3344: conceptions—not intuitive, but discursive. All intuitions, as sensuous,
3345: depend on affections; conceptions, therefore, upon functions. By the
3346: word function I understand the unity of the act of arranging diverse
3347: representations under one common representation. Conceptions, then, are
3348: based on the spontaneity of thought, as sensuous intuitions are on the
3349: receptivity of impressions. Now, the understanding cannot make any
3350: other use of these conceptions than to judge by means of them. As no
3351: representation, except an intuition, relates immediately to its object,
3352: a conception never relates immediately to an object, but only to some
3353: other representation thereof, be that an intuition or itself a
3354: conception. A judgement, therefore, is the mediate cognition of an
3355: object, consequently the representation of a representation of it. In
3356: every judgement there is a conception which applies to, and is valid
3357: for many other conceptions, and which among these comprehends also a
3358: given representation, this last being immediately connected with an
3359: object. For example, in the judgement—“All bodies are divisible,” our
3360: conception of divisible applies to various other conceptions; among
3361: these, however, it is here particularly applied to the conception of
3362: body, and this conception of body relates to certain phenomena which
3363: occur to us. These objects, therefore, are mediately represented by the
3364: conception of divisibility. All judgements, accordingly, are functions
3365: of unity in our representations, inasmuch as, instead of an immediate,
3366: a higher representation, which comprises this and various others, is
3367: used for our cognition of the object, and thereby many possible
3368: cognitions are collected into one. But we can reduce all acts of the
3369: understanding to judgements, so that understanding may be represented
3370: as the faculty of judging. For it is, according to what has been said
3371: above, a faculty of thought. Now thought is cognition by means of
3372: conceptions. But conceptions, as predicates of possible judgements,
3373: relate to some representation of a yet undetermined object. Thus the
3374: conception of body indicates something—for example, metal—which can be
3375: cognized by means of that conception. It is therefore a conception, for
3376: the reason alone that other representations are contained under it, by
3377: means of which it can relate to objects. It is therefore the predicate
3378: to a possible judgement; for example: “Every metal is a body.” All the
3379: functions of the understanding therefore can be discovered, when we can
3380: completely exhibit the functions of unity in judgements. And that this
3381: may be effected very easily, the following section will show.
3382: 
3383: Section II. Of the Logical Function of the Understanding in Judgements
3384: § 5
3385: 
3386: If we abstract all the content of a judgement, and consider only the
3387: intellectual form thereof, we find that the function of thought in a
3388: judgement can be brought under four heads, of which each contains three
3389: momenta. These may be conveniently represented in the following table:
3390: 
3391:                                     1
3392:                          _Quantity of judgements_
3393:                                 Universal
3394:                                 Particular
3395:                                 Singular
3396: 
3397:                       2                           3
3398:                     _Quality                   Relation_
3399:                   Affirmative                Categorical
3400:                   Negative                   Hypothetical
3401:                   Infinite                   Disjunctive
3402: 
3403:                                     4
3404:                                  _Modality_
3405:                                Problematical
3406:                                Assertorical
3407:                                Apodeictical
3408: 
3409: As this division appears to differ in some, though not essential
3410: points, from the usual technique of logicians, the following
3411: observations, for the prevention of otherwise possible
3412: misunderstanding, will not be without their use.
3413: 
3414: 1. Logicians say, with justice, that in the use of judgements in
3415: syllogisms, singular judgements may be treated like universal ones.
3416: For, precisely because a singular judgement has no extent at all, its
3417: predicate cannot refer to a part of that which is contained in the
3418: conception of the subject and be excluded from the rest. The predicate
3419: is valid for the whole conception just as if it were a general
3420: conception, and had extent, to the whole of which the predicate
3421: applied. On the other hand, let us compare a singular with a general
3422: judgement, merely as a cognition, in regard to quantity. The singular
3423: judgement relates to the general one, as unity to infinity, and is
3424: therefore in itself essentially different. Thus, if we estimate a
3425: singular judgement (_judicium singulare_) not merely according to its
3426: intrinsic validity as a judgement, but also as a cognition generally,
3427: according to its quantity in comparison with that of other cognitions,
3428: it is then entirely different from a general judgement (_judicium
3429: commune_), and in a complete table of the momenta of thought deserves a
3430: separate place—though, indeed, this would not be necessary in a logic
3431: limited merely to the consideration of the use of judgements in
3432: reference to each other.
3433: 
3434: 2. In like manner, in transcendental logic, infinite must be
3435: distinguished from affirmative judgements, although in general logic
3436: they are rightly enough classed under affirmative. General logic
3437: abstracts all content of the predicate (though it be negative), and
3438: only considers whether the said predicate be affirmed or denied of the
3439: subject. But transcendental logic considers also the worth or content
3440: of this logical affirmation—an affirmation by means of a merely
3441: negative predicate, and inquires how much the sum total of our
3442: cognition gains by this affirmation. For example, if I say of the soul,
3443: “It is not mortal”—by this negative judgement I should at least ward
3444: off error. Now, by the proposition, “The soul is not mortal,” I have,
3445: in respect of the logical form, really affirmed, inasmuch as I thereby
3446: place the soul in the unlimited sphere of immortal beings. Now, because
3447: of the whole sphere of possible existences, the mortal occupies one
3448: part, and the immortal the other, neither more nor less is affirmed by
3449: the proposition than that the soul is one among the infinite multitude
3450: of things which remain over, when I take away the whole mortal part.
3451: But by this proceeding we accomplish only this much, that the infinite
3452: sphere of all possible existences is in so far limited that the mortal
3453: is excluded from it, and the soul is placed in the remaining part of
3454: the extent of this sphere. But this part remains, notwithstanding this
3455: exception, infinite, and more and more parts may be taken away from the
3456: whole sphere, without in the slightest degree thereby augmenting or
3457: affirmatively determining our conception of the soul. These judgements,
3458: therefore, infinite in respect of their logical extent, are, in respect
3459: of the content of their cognition, merely limitative; and are
3460: consequently entitled to a place in our transcendental table of all the
3461: momenta of thought in judgements, because the function of the
3462: understanding exercised by them may perhaps be of importance in the
3463: field of its pure à priori cognition.
3464: 
3465: 3. All relations of thought in judgements are those (a) of the
3466: predicate to the subject; (b) of the principle to its consequence; (c)
3467: of the divided cognition and all the members of the division to each
3468: other. In the first of these three classes, we consider only two
3469: conceptions; in the second, two judgements; in the third, several
3470: judgements in relation to each other. The hypothetical proposition, “If
3471: perfect justice exists, the obstinately wicked are punished,” contains
3472: properly the relation to each other of two propositions, namely,
3473: “Perfect justice exists,” and “The obstinately wicked are punished.”
3474: Whether these propositions are in themselves true is a question not
3475: here decided. Nothing is cogitated by means of this judgement except a
3476: certain consequence. Finally, the disjunctive judgement contains a
3477: relation of two or more propositions to each other—a relation not of
3478: consequence, but of logical opposition, in so far as the sphere of the
3479: one proposition excludes that of the other. But it contains at the same
3480: time a relation of community, in so far as all the propositions taken
3481: together fill up the sphere of the cognition. The disjunctive judgement
3482: contains, therefore, the relation of the parts of the whole sphere of a
3483: cognition, since the sphere of each part is a complemental part of the
3484: sphere of the other, each contributing to form the sum total of the
3485: divided cognition. Take, for example, the proposition, “The world
3486: exists either through blind chance, or through internal necessity, or
3487: through an external cause.” Each of these propositions embraces a part
3488: of the sphere of our possible cognition as to the existence of a world;
3489: all of them taken together, the whole sphere. To take the cognition out
3490: of one of these spheres, is equivalent to placing it in one of the
3491: others; and, on the other hand, to place it in one sphere is equivalent
3492: to taking it out of the rest. There is, therefore, in a disjunctive
3493: judgement a certain community of cognitions, which consists in this,
3494: that they mutually exclude each other, yet thereby determine, as a
3495: whole, the true cognition, inasmuch as, taken together, they make up
3496: the complete content of a particular given cognition. And this is all
3497: that I find necessary, for the sake of what follows, to remark in this
3498: place.
3499: 
3500: 4. The modality of judgements is a quite peculiar function, with this
3501: distinguishing characteristic, that it contributes nothing to the
3502: content of a judgement (for besides quantity, quality, and relation,
3503: there is nothing more that constitutes the content of a judgement), but
3504: concerns itself only with the value of the copula in relation to
3505: thought in general. Problematical judgements are those in which the
3506: affirmation or negation is accepted as merely possible (ad libitum). In
3507: the assertorical, we regard the proposition as real (true); in the
3508: apodeictical, we look on it as necessary.[13] Thus the two judgements
3509: (antecedens et consequens), the relation of which constitutes a
3510: hypothetical judgement, likewise those (the members of the division) in
3511: whose reciprocity the disjunctive consists, are only problematical. In
3512: the example above given the proposition, “There exists perfect
3513: justice,” is not stated assertorically, but as an ad libitum judgement,
3514: which someone may choose to adopt, and the consequence alone is
3515: assertorical. Hence such judgements may be obviously false, and yet,
3516: taken problematically, be conditions of our cognition of the truth.
3517: Thus the proposition, “The world exists only by blind chance,” is in
3518: the disjunctive judgement of problematical import only: that is to say,
3519: one may accept it for the moment, and it helps us (like the indication
3520: of the wrong road among all the roads that one can take) to find out
3521: the true proposition. The problematical proposition is, therefore, that
3522: which expresses only logical possibility (which is not objective); that
3523: is, it expresses a free choice to admit the validity of such a
3524: proposition—a merely arbitrary reception of it into the understanding.
3525: The assertorical speaks of logical reality or truth; as, for example,
3526: in a hypothetical syllogism, the antecedens presents itself in a
3527: problematical form in the major, in an assertorical form in the minor,
3528: and it shows that the proposition is in harmony with the laws of the
3529: understanding. The apodeictical proposition cogitates the assertorical
3530: as determined by these very laws of the understanding, consequently as
3531: affirming à priori, and in this manner it expresses logical necessity.
3532: Now because all is here gradually incorporated with the
3533: understanding—inasmuch as in the first place we judge problematically;
3534: then accept assertorically our judgement as true; lastly, affirm it as
3535: inseparably united with the understanding, that is, as necessary and
3536: apodeictical—we may safely reckon these three functions of modality as
3537: so many momenta of thought.
3538: 
3539:  [13] Just as if thought were in the first instance a function of the
3540:  understanding; in the second, of judgement; in the third, of reason. A
3541:  remark which will be explained in the sequel.
3542: 
3543: Section III. Of the Pure Conceptions of the Understanding, or
3544: Categories § 6
3545: 
3546: General logic, as has been repeatedly said, makes abstraction of all
3547: content of cognition, and expects to receive representations from some
3548: other quarter, in order, by means of analysis, to convert them into
3549: conceptions. On the contrary, transcendental logic has lying before it
3550: the manifold content of à priori sensibility, which transcendental
3551: æsthetic presents to it in order to give matter to the pure conceptions
3552: of the understanding, without which transcendental logic would have no
3553: content, and be therefore utterly void. Now space and time contain an
3554: infinite diversity of determinations of pure à priori intuition, but
3555: are nevertheless the condition of the mind’s receptivity, under which
3556: alone it can obtain representations of objects, and which,
3557: consequently, must always affect the conception of these objects. But
3558: the spontaneity of thought requires that this diversity be examined
3559: after a certain manner, received into the mind, and connected, in order
3560: afterwards to form a cognition out of it. This Process I call
3561: synthesis.
3562: 
3563: By the word synthesis, in its most general signification, I understand
3564: the process of joining different representations to each other and of
3565: comprehending their diversity in one cognition. This synthesis is pure
3566: when the diversity is not given empirically but à priori (as that in
3567: space and time). Our representations must be given previously to any
3568: analysis of them; and no conceptions can arise, quoad their content,
3569: analytically. But the synthesis of a diversity (be it given à priori or
3570: empirically) is the first requisite for the production of a cognition,
3571: which in its beginning, indeed, may be crude and confused, and
3572: therefore in need of analysis—still, synthesis is that by which alone
3573: the elements of our cognitions are collected and united into a certain
3574: content, consequently it is the first thing on which we must fix our
3575: attention, if we wish to investigate the origin of our knowledge.
3576: 
3577: Synthesis, generally speaking, is, as we shall afterwards see, the mere
3578: operation of the imagination—a blind but indispensable function of the
3579: soul, without which we should have no cognition whatever, but of the
3580: working of which we are seldom even conscious. But to reduce this
3581: synthesis to conceptions is a function of the understanding, by means
3582: of which we attain to cognition, in the proper meaning of the term.
3583: 
3584: Pure synthesis, represented generally, gives us the pure conception of
3585: the understanding. But by this pure synthesis, I mean that which rests
3586: upon a basis of à priori synthetical unity. Thus, our numeration (and
3587: this is more observable in large numbers) is a synthesis according to
3588: conceptions, because it takes place according to a common basis of
3589: unity (for example, the decade). By means of this conception,
3590: therefore, the unity in the synthesis of the manifold becomes
3591: necessary.
3592: 
3593: By means of analysis different representations are brought under one
3594: conception—an operation of which general logic treats. On the other
3595: hand, the duty of transcendental logic is to reduce to conceptions, not
3596: representations, but the pure synthesis of representations. The first
3597: thing which must be given to us for the sake of the à priori cognition
3598: of all objects, is the diversity of the pure intuition; the synthesis
3599: of this diversity by means of the imagination is the second; but this
3600: gives, as yet, no cognition. The conceptions which give unity to this
3601: pure synthesis, and which consist solely in the representation of this
3602: necessary synthetical unity, furnish the third requisite for the
3603: cognition of an object, and these conceptions are given by the
3604: understanding.
3605: 
3606: The same function which gives unity to the different representation in
3607: a judgement, gives also unity to the mere synthesis of different
3608: representations in an intuition; and this unity we call the pure
3609: conception of the understanding. Thus, the same understanding, and by
3610: the same operations, whereby in conceptions, by means of analytical
3611: unity, it produced the logical form of a judgement, introduces, by
3612: means of the synthetical unity of the manifold in intuition, a
3613: transcendental content into its representations, on which account they
3614: are called pure conceptions of the understanding, and they apply à
3615: priori to objects, a result not within the power of general logic.
3616: 
3617: In this manner, there arise exactly so many pure conceptions of the
3618: understanding, applying à priori to objects of intuition in general, as
3619: there are logical functions in all possible judgements. For there is no
3620: other function or faculty existing in the understanding besides those
3621: enumerated in that table. These conceptions we shall, with Aristotle,
3622: call categories, our purpose being originally identical with his,
3623: notwithstanding the great difference in the execution.
3624: 
3625:                      TABLE OF THE CATEGORIES
3626: 
3627:                     1                         2
3628: 
3629:               _Of Quantity                Of Quality_
3630:               Unity                      Reality
3631:               Plurality                  Negation
3632:               Totality                   Limitation
3633: 
3634:                            3
3635:                       _Of Relation_
3636:    Of Inherence and Subsistence (substantia et accidens)
3637:    Of Causality and Dependence (cause and effect)
3638:    Of Community (reciprocity between the agent and patient)
3639: 
3640:                            4
3641:                      _Of Modality_
3642:               Possibility&mdash;Impossibility
3643:               Existence&mdash;Non-existence
3644:               Necessity&mdash;Contingence
3645: 
3646: This, then, is a catalogue of all the originally pure conceptions of
3647: the synthesis which the understanding contains à priori, and these
3648: conceptions alone entitle it to be called a pure understanding;
3649: inasmuch as only by them it can render the manifold of intuition
3650: conceivable, in other words, think an object of intuition. This
3651: division is made systematically from a common principle, namely the
3652: faculty of judgement (which is just the same as the power of thought),
3653: and has not arisen rhapsodically from a search at haphazard after pure
3654: conceptions, respecting the full number of which we never could be
3655: certain, inasmuch as we employ induction alone in our search, without
3656: considering that in this way we can never understand wherefore
3657: precisely these conceptions, and none others, abide in the pure
3658: understanding. It was a design worthy of an acute thinker like
3659: Aristotle, to search for these fundamental conceptions. Destitute,
3660: however, of any guiding principle, he picked them up just as they
3661: occurred to him, and at first hunted out ten, which he called
3662: categories (predicaments). Afterwards be believed that he had
3663: discovered five others, which were added under the name of post
3664: predicaments. But his catalogue still remained defective. Besides,
3665: there are to be found among them some of the modes of pure sensibility
3666: (quando, ubi, situs, also prius, simul), and likewise an empirical
3667: conception (motus)—which can by no means belong to this genealogical
3668: register of the pure understanding. Moreover, there are deduced
3669: conceptions (actio, passio) enumerated among the original conceptions,
3670: and, of the latter, some are entirely wanting.
3671: 
3672: With regard to these, it is to be remarked, that the categories, as the
3673: true primitive conceptions of the pure understanding, have also their
3674: pure deduced conceptions, which, in a complete system of transcendental
3675: philosophy, must by no means be passed over; though in a merely
3676: critical essay we must be contented with the simple mention of the
3677: fact.
3678: 
3679: Let it be allowed me to call these pure, but deduced conceptions of the
3680: understanding, the predicables of the pure understanding, in
3681: contradistinction to predicaments. If we are in possession of the
3682: original and primitive, the deduced and subsidiary conceptions can
3683: easily be added, and the genealogical tree of the understanding
3684: completely delineated. As my present aim is not to set forth a complete
3685: system, but merely the principles of one, I reserve this task for
3686: another time. It may be easily executed by any one who will refer to
3687: the ontological manuals, and subordinate to the category of causality,
3688: for example, the predicables of force, action, passion; to that of
3689: community, those of presence and resistance; to the categories of
3690: modality, those of origination, extinction, change; and so with the
3691: rest. The categories combined with the modes of pure sensibility, or
3692: with one another, afford a great number of deduced à priori
3693: conceptions; a complete enumeration of which would be a useful and not
3694: unpleasant, but in this place a perfectly dispensable, occupation.
3695: 
3696: I purposely omit the definitions of the categories in this treatise. I
3697: shall analyse these conceptions only so far as is necessary for the
3698: doctrine of method, which is to form a part of this critique. In a
3699: system of pure reason, definitions of them would be with justice
3700: demanded of me, but to give them here would only bide from our view the
3701: main aim of our investigation, at the same time raising doubts and
3702: objections, the consideration of which, without injustice to our main
3703: purpose, may be very well postponed till another opportunity.
3704: Meanwhile, it ought to be sufficiently clear, from the little we have
3705: already said on this subject, that the formation of a complete
3706: vocabulary of pure conceptions, accompanied by all the requisite
3707: explanations, is not only a possible, but an easy undertaking. The
3708: compartments already exist; it is only necessary to fill them up; and a
3709: systematic topic like the present, indicates with perfect precision the
3710: proper place to which each conception belongs, while it readily points
3711: out any that have not yet been filled up.
3712: 
3713: § 7
3714: 
3715: 
3716: Our table of the categories suggests considerations of some importance,
3717: which may perhaps have significant results in regard to the scientific
3718: form of all rational cognitions. For, that this table is useful in the
3719: theoretical part of philosophy, nay, indispensable for the sketching of
3720: the complete plan of a science, so far as that science rests upon
3721: conceptions à priori, and for dividing it mathematically, according to
3722: fixed principles, is most manifest from the fact that it contains all
3723: the elementary conceptions of the understanding, nay, even the form of
3724: a system of these in the understanding itself, and consequently
3725: indicates all the momenta, and also the internal arrangement of a
3726: projected speculative science, as I have elsewhere shown.[14] Here
3727: follow some of these observations.
3728: 
3729:  [14] In the “Metaphysical Principles of Natural Science.”
3730: 
3731: 
3732: I. This table, which contains four classes of conceptions of the
3733: understanding, may, in the first instance, be divided into two classes,
3734: the first of which relates to objects of intuition—pure as well as
3735: empirical; the second, to the existence of these objects, either in
3736: relation to one another, or to the understanding.
3737: 
3738: The former of these classes of categories I would entitle the
3739: mathematical, and the latter the dynamical categories. The former, as
3740: we see, has no correlates; these are only to be found in the second
3741: class. This difference must have a ground in the nature of the human
3742: understanding.
3743: 
3744: II. The number of the categories in each class is always the same,
3745: namely, three—a fact which also demands some consideration, because in
3746: all other cases division à priori through conceptions is necessarily
3747: dichotomy. It is to be added, that the third category in each triad
3748: always arises from the combination of the second with the first.
3749: 
3750: Thus totality is nothing else but plurality contemplated as unity;
3751: limitation is merely reality conjoined with negation; community is the
3752: causality of a substance, reciprocally determining, and determined by
3753: other substances; and finally, necessity is nothing but existence,
3754: which is given through the possibility itself. Let it not be supposed,
3755: however, that the third category is merely a deduced, and not a
3756: primitive conception of the pure understanding. For the conjunction of
3757: the first and second, in order to produce the third conception,
3758: requires a particular function of the understanding, which is by no
3759: means identical with those which are exercised in the first and second.
3760: Thus, the conception of a number (which belongs to the category of
3761: totality) is not always possible, where the conceptions of multitude
3762: and unity exist (for example, in the representation of the infinite).
3763: Or, if I conjoin the conception of a cause with that of a substance, it
3764: does not follow that the conception of influence, that is, how one
3765: substance can be the cause of something in another substance, will be
3766: understood from that. Thus it is evident that a particular act of the
3767: understanding is here necessary; and so in the other instances.
3768: 
3769: III. With respect to one category, namely, that of community, which is
3770: found in the third class, it is not so easy as with the others to
3771: detect its accordance with the form of the disjunctive judgement which
3772: corresponds to it in the table of the logical functions.
3773: 
3774: In order to assure ourselves of this accordance, we must observe that
3775: in every disjunctive judgement, the sphere of the judgement (that is,
3776: the complex of all that is contained in it) is represented as a whole
3777: divided into parts; and, since one part cannot be contained in the
3778: other, they are cogitated as co-ordinated with, not subordinated to
3779: each other, so that they do not determine each other unilaterally, as
3780: in a linear series, but reciprocally, as in an aggregate—(if one member
3781: of the division is posited, all the rest are excluded; and conversely).
3782: 
3783: Now a like connection is cogitated in a whole of things; for one thing
3784: is not subordinated, as effect, to another as cause of its existence,
3785: but, on the contrary, is co-ordinated contemporaneously and
3786: reciprocally, as a cause in relation to the determination of the others
3787: (for example, in a body—the parts of which mutually attract and repel
3788: each other). And this is an entirely different kind of connection from
3789: that which we find in the mere relation of the cause to the effect (the
3790: principle to the consequence), for in such a connection the consequence
3791: does not in its turn determine the principle, and therefore does not
3792: constitute, with the latter, a whole—just as the Creator does not with
3793: the world make up a whole. The process of understanding by which it
3794: represents to itself the sphere of a divided conception, is employed
3795: also when we think of a thing as divisible; and in the same manner as
3796: the members of the division in the former exclude one another, and yet
3797: are connected in one sphere, so the understanding represents to itself
3798: the parts of the latter, as having—each of them—an existence (as
3799: substances), independently of the others, and yet as united in one
3800: whole.
3801: 
3802: § 8
3803: 
3804: 
3805: In the transcendental philosophy of the ancients there exists one more
3806: leading division, which contains pure conceptions of the understanding,
3807: and which, although not numbered among the categories, ought, according
3808: to them, as conceptions à priori, to be valid of objects. But in this
3809: case they would augment the number of the categories; which cannot be.
3810: These are set forth in the proposition, so renowned among the
3811: schoolmen—‘_Quodlibet ens est UNUM, VERUM, BONUM_.’ Now, though the
3812: inferences from this principle were mere tautological propositions, and
3813: though it is allowed only by courtesy to retain a place in modern
3814: metaphysics, yet a thought which maintained itself for such a length of
3815: time, however empty it seems to be, deserves an investigation of its
3816: origin, and justifies the conjecture that it must be grounded in some
3817: law of the understanding, which, as is often the case, has only been
3818: erroneously interpreted. These pretended transcendental predicates are,
3819: in fact, nothing but logical requisites and criteria of all cognition
3820: of objects, and they employ, as the basis for this cognition, the
3821: categories of quantity, namely, unity, plurality, and totality. But
3822: these, which must be taken as material conditions, that is, as
3823: belonging to the possibility of things themselves, they employed merely
3824: in a formal signification, as belonging to the logical requisites of
3825: all cognition, and yet most unguardedly changed these criteria of
3826: thought into properties of objects, as things in themselves. Now, in
3827: every cognition of an object, there is unity of conception, which may
3828: be called qualitative unity, so far as by this term we understand only
3829: the unity in our connection of the manifold; for example, unity of the
3830: theme in a play, an oration, or a story. Secondly, there is truth in
3831: respect of the deductions from it. The more true deductions we have
3832: from a given conception, the more criteria of its objective reality.
3833: This we might call the qualitative plurality of characteristic marks,
3834: which belong to a conception as to a common foundation, but are not
3835: cogitated as a quantity in it. Thirdly, there is perfection—which
3836: consists in this, that the plurality falls back upon the unity of the
