3837: conception, and accords completely with that conception and with no
3838: other. This we may denominate qualitative completeness. Hence it is
3839: evident that these logical criteria of the possibility of cognition are
3840: merely the three categories of quantity modified and transformed to
3841: suit an unauthorized manner of applying them. That is to say, the three
3842: categories, in which the unity in the production of the quantum must be
3843: homogeneous throughout, are transformed solely with a view to the
3844: connection of heterogeneous parts of cognition in one act of
3845: consciousness, by means of the quality of the cognition, which is the
3846: principle of that connection. Thus the criterion of the possibility of
3847: a conception (not of its object) is the definition of it, in which the
3848: unity of the conception, the truth of all that may be immediately
3849: deduced from it, and finally, the completeness of what has been thus
3850: deduced, constitute the requisites for the reproduction of the whole
3851: conception. Thus also, the criterion or test of an hypothesis is the
3852: intelligibility of the received principle of explanation, or its unity
3853: (without help from any subsidiary hypothesis)—the truth of our
3854: deductions from it (consistency with each other and with
3855: experience)—and lastly, the completeness of the principle of the
3856: explanation of these deductions, which refer to neither more nor less
3857: than what was admitted in the hypothesis, restoring analytically and à
3858: posteriori, what was cogitated synthetically and à priori. By the
3859: conceptions, therefore, of unity, truth, and perfection, we have made
3860: no addition to the transcendental table of the categories, which is
3861: complete without them. We have, on the contrary, merely employed the
3862: three categories of quantity, setting aside their application to
3863: objects of experience, as general logical laws of the consistency of
3864: cognition with itself.
3865: 
3866: Chapter II. Of the Deduction of the Pure Conceptions of the
3867: Understanding
3868: 
3869: Section I. Of the Principles of a Transcendental Deduction in general §
3870: 9
3871: 
3872: Teachers of jurisprudence, when speaking of rights and claims,
3873: distinguish in a cause the question of right (quid juris) from the
3874: question of fact (quid facti), and while they demand proof of both,
3875: they give to the proof of the former, which goes to establish right or
3876: claim in law, the name of deduction. Now we make use of a great number
3877: of empirical conceptions, without opposition from any one; and consider
3878: ourselves, even without any attempt at deduction, justified in
3879: attaching to them a sense, and a supposititious signification, because
3880: we have always experience at hand to demonstrate their objective
3881: reality. There exist also, however, usurped conceptions, such as
3882: fortune, fate, which circulate with almost universal indulgence, and
3883: yet are occasionally challenged by the question, “quid juris?” In such
3884: cases, we have great difficulty in discovering any deduction for these
3885: terms, inasmuch as we cannot produce any manifest ground of right,
3886: either from experience or from reason, on which the claim to employ
3887: them can be founded.
3888: 
3889: Among the many conceptions, which make up the very variegated web of
3890: human cognition, some are destined for pure use à priori, independent
3891: of all experience; and their title to be so employed always requires a
3892: deduction, inasmuch as, to justify such use of them, proofs from
3893: experience are not sufficient; but it is necessary to know how these
3894: conceptions can apply to objects without being derived from experience.
3895: I term, therefore, an examination of the manner in which conceptions
3896: can apply à priori to objects, the transcendental deduction of
3897: conceptions, and I distinguish it from the empirical deduction, which
3898: indicates the mode in which conception is obtained through experience
3899: and reflection thereon; consequently, does not concern itself with the
3900: right, but only with the fact of our obtaining conceptions in such and
3901: such a manner. We have already seen that we are in possession of two
3902: perfectly different kinds of conceptions, which nevertheless agree with
3903: each other in this, that they both apply to objects completely à
3904: priori. These are the conceptions of space and time as forms of
3905: sensibility, and the categories as pure conceptions of the
3906: understanding. To attempt an empirical deduction of either of these
3907: classes would be labour in vain, because the distinguishing
3908: characteristic of their nature consists in this, that they apply to
3909: their objects, without having borrowed anything from experience towards
3910: the representation of them. Consequently, if a deduction of these
3911: conceptions is necessary, it must always be transcendental.
3912: 
3913: Meanwhile, with respect to these conceptions, as with respect to all
3914: our cognition, we certainly may discover in experience, if not the
3915: principle of their possibility, yet the occasioning causes of their
3916: production. It will be found that the impressions of sense give the
3917: first occasion for bringing into action the whole faculty of cognition,
3918: and for the production of experience, which contains two very
3919: dissimilar elements, namely, a matter for cognition, given by the
3920: senses, and a certain form for the arrangement of this matter, arising
3921: out of the inner fountain of pure intuition and thought; and these, on
3922: occasion given by sensuous impressions, are called into exercise and
3923: produce conceptions. Such an investigation into the first efforts of
3924: our faculty of cognition to mount from particular perceptions to
3925: general conceptions is undoubtedly of great utility; and we have to
3926: thank the celebrated Locke for having first opened the way for this
3927: inquiry. But a deduction of the pure à priori conceptions of course
3928: never can be made in this way, seeing that, in regard to their future
3929: employment, which must be entirely independent of experience, they must
3930: have a far different certificate of birth to show from that of a
3931: descent from experience. This attempted physiological derivation, which
3932: cannot properly be called deduction, because it relates merely to a
3933: quaestio facti, I shall entitle an explanation of the possession of a
3934: pure cognition. It is therefore manifest that there can only be a
3935: transcendental deduction of these conceptions and by no means an
3936: empirical one; also, that all attempts at an empirical deduction, in
3937: regard to pure à priori conceptions, are vain, and can only be made by
3938: one who does not understand the altogether peculiar nature of these
3939: cognitions.
3940: 
3941: But although it is admitted that the only possible deduction of pure à
3942: priori cognition is a transcendental deduction, it is not, for that
3943: reason, perfectly manifest that such a deduction is absolutely
3944: necessary. We have already traced to their sources the conceptions of
3945: space and time, by means of a transcendental deduction, and we have
3946: explained and determined their objective validity à priori. Geometry,
3947: nevertheless, advances steadily and securely in the province of pure à
3948: priori cognitions, without needing to ask from philosophy any
3949: certificate as to the pure and legitimate origin of its fundamental
3950: conception of space. But the use of the conception in this science
3951: extends only to the external world of sense, the pure form of the
3952: intuition of which is space; and in this world, therefore, all
3953: geometrical cognition, because it is founded upon à priori intuition,
3954: possesses immediate evidence, and the objects of this cognition are
3955: given à priori (as regards their form) in intuition by and through the
3956: cognition itself. With the pure conceptions of understanding, on the
3957: contrary, commences the absolute necessity of seeking a transcendental
3958: deduction, not only of these conceptions themselves, but likewise of
3959: space, because, inasmuch as they make affirmations concerning objects
3960: not by means of the predicates of intuition and sensibility, but of
3961: pure thought à priori, they apply to objects without any of the
3962: conditions of sensibility. Besides, not being founded on experience,
3963: they are not presented with any object in à priori intuition upon
3964: which, antecedently to experience, they might base their synthesis.
3965: Hence results, not only doubt as to the objective validity and proper
3966: limits of their use, but that even our conception of space is rendered
3967: equivocal; inasmuch as we are very ready with the aid of the
3968: categories, to carry the use of this conception beyond the conditions
3969: of sensuous intuition—and, for this reason, we have already found a
3970: transcendental deduction of it needful. The reader, then, must be quite
3971: convinced of the absolute necessity of a transcendental deduction,
3972: before taking a single step in the field of pure reason; because
3973: otherwise he goes to work blindly, and after he has wondered about in
3974: all directions, returns to the state of utter ignorance from which he
3975: started. He ought, moreover, clearly to recognize beforehand the
3976: unavoidable difficulties in his undertaking, so that he may not
3977: afterwards complain of the obscurity in which the subject itself is
3978: deeply involved, or become too soon impatient of the obstacles in his
3979: path; because we have a choice of only two things—either at once to
3980: give up all pretensions to knowledge beyond the limits of possible
3981: experience, or to bring this critical investigation to completion.
3982: 
3983: We have been able, with very little trouble, to make it comprehensible
3984: how the conceptions of space and time, although à priori cognitions,
3985: must necessarily apply to external objects, and render a synthetical
3986: cognition of these possible, independently of all experience. For
3987: inasmuch as only by means of such pure form of sensibility an object
3988: can appear to us, that is, be an object of empirical intuition, space
3989: and time are pure intuitions, which contain à priori the condition of
3990: the possibility of objects as phenomena, and an à priori synthesis in
3991: these intuitions possesses objective validity.
3992: 
3993: On the other hand, the categories of the understanding do not represent
3994: the conditions under which objects are given to us in intuition;
3995: objects can consequently appear to us without necessarily connecting
3996: themselves with these, and consequently without any necessity binding
3997: on the understanding to contain à priori the conditions of these
3998: objects. Thus we find ourselves involved in a difficulty which did not
3999: present itself in the sphere of sensibility, that is to say, we cannot
4000: discover how the subjective conditions of thought can have objective
4001: validity, in other words, can become conditions of the possibility of
4002: all cognition of objects; for phenomena may certainly be given to us in
4003: intuition without any help from the functions of the understanding. Let
4004: us take, for example, the conception of cause, which indicates a
4005: peculiar kind of synthesis, namely, that with something, A, something
4006: entirely different, B, is connected according to a law. It is not à
4007: priori manifest why phenomena should contain anything of this kind (we
4008: are of course debarred from appealing for proof to experience, for the
4009: objective validity of this conception must be demonstrated à priori),
4010: and it hence remains doubtful à priori, whether such a conception be
4011: not quite void and without any corresponding object among phenomena.
4012: For that objects of sensuous intuition must correspond to the formal
4013: conditions of sensibility existing à priori in the mind is quite
4014: evident, from the fact that without these they could not be objects for
4015: us; but that they must also correspond to the conditions which
4016: understanding requires for the synthetical unity of thought is an
4017: assertion, the grounds for which are not so easily to be discovered.
4018: For phenomena might be so constituted as not to correspond to the
4019: conditions of the unity of thought; and all things might lie in such
4020: confusion that, for example, nothing could be met with in the sphere of
4021: phenomena to suggest a law of synthesis, and so correspond to the
4022: conception of cause and effect; so that this conception would be quite
4023: void, null, and without significance. Phenomena would nevertheless
4024: continue to present objects to our intuition; for mere intuition does
4025: not in any respect stand in need of the functions of thought.
4026: 
4027: If we thought to free ourselves from the labour of these investigations
4028: by saying: “Experience is constantly offering us examples of the
4029: relation of cause and effect in phenomena, and presents us with
4030: abundant opportunity of abstracting the conception of cause, and so at
4031: the same time of corroborating the objective validity of this
4032: conception”; we should in this case be overlooking the fact, that the
4033: conception of cause cannot arise in this way at all; that, on the
4034: contrary, it must either have an à priori basis in the understanding,
4035: or be rejected as a mere chimera. For this conception demands that
4036: something, A, should be of such a nature that something else, B, should
4037: follow from it necessarily, and according to an absolutely universal
4038: law. We may certainly collect from phenomena a law, according to which
4039: this or that usually happens, but the element of necessity is not to be
4040: found in it. Hence it is evident that to the synthesis of cause and
4041: effect belongs a dignity, which is utterly wanting in any empirical
4042: synthesis; for it is no mere mechanical synthesis, by means of
4043: addition, but a dynamical one; that is to say, the effect is not to be
4044: cogitated as merely annexed to the cause, but as posited by and through
4045: the cause, and resulting from it. The strict universality of this law
4046: never can be a characteristic of empirical laws, which obtain through
4047: induction only a comparative universality, that is, an extended range
4048: of practical application. But the pure conceptions of the understanding
4049: would entirely lose all their peculiar character, if we treated them
4050: merely as the productions of experience.
4051: 
4052: Transition to the Transcendental Deduction of the Categories § 10
4053: 
4054: There are only two possible ways in which synthetical representation
4055: and its objects can coincide with and relate necessarily to each other,
4056: and, as it were, meet together. Either the object alone makes the
4057: representation possible, or the representation alone makes the object
4058: possible. In the former case, the relation between them is only
4059: empirical, and an à priori representation is impossible. And this is
4060: the case with phenomena, as regards that in them which is referable to
4061: mere sensation. In the latter case—although representation alone (for
4062: of its causality, by means of the will, we do not here speak) does not
4063: produce the object as to its existence, it must nevertheless be à
4064: priori determinative in regard to the object, if it is only by means of
4065: the representation that we can cognize anything as an object. Now there
4066: are only two conditions of the possibility of a cognition of objects;
4067: firstly, intuition, by means of which the object, though only as
4068: phenomenon, is given; secondly, conception, by means of which the
4069: object which corresponds to this intuition is thought. But it is
4070: evident from what has been said on æsthetic that the first condition,
4071: under which alone objects can be intuited, must in fact exist, as a
4072: formal basis for them, à priori in the mind. With this formal condition
4073: of sensibility, therefore, all phenomena necessarily correspond,
4074: because it is only through it that they can be phenomena at all; that
4075: is, can be empirically intuited and given. Now the question is whether
4076: there do not exist, à priori in the mind, conceptions of understanding
4077: also, as conditions under which alone something, if not intuited, is
4078: yet thought as object. If this question be answered in the affirmative,
4079: it follows that all empirical cognition of objects is necessarily
4080: conformable to such conceptions, since, if they are not presupposed, it
4081: is impossible that anything can be an object of experience. Now all
4082: experience contains, besides the intuition of the senses through which
4083: an object is given, a conception also of an object that is given in
4084: intuition. Accordingly, conceptions of objects in general must lie as à
4085: priori conditions at the foundation of all empirical cognition; and
4086: consequently, the objective validity of the categories, as à priori
4087: conceptions, will rest upon this, that experience (as far as regards
4088: the form of thought) is possible only by their means. For in that case
4089: they apply necessarily and à priori to objects of experience, because
4090: only through them can an object of experience be thought.
4091: 
4092: The whole aim of the transcendental deduction of all à priori
4093: conceptions is to show that these conceptions are à priori conditions
4094: of the possibility of all experience. Conceptions which afford us the
4095: objective foundation of the possibility of experience are for that very
4096: reason necessary. But the analysis of the experiences in which they are
4097: met with is not deduction, but only an illustration of them, because
4098: from experience they could never derive the attribute of necessity.
4099: Without their original applicability and relation to all possible
4100: experience, in which all objects of cognition present themselves, the
4101: relation of the categories to objects, of whatever nature, would be
4102: quite incomprehensible.
4103: 
4104: The celebrated Locke, for want of due reflection on these points, and
4105: because he met with pure conceptions of the understanding in
4106: experience, sought also to deduce them from experience, and yet
4107: proceeded so inconsequently as to attempt, with their aid, to arrive it
4108: cognitions which lie far beyond the limits of all experience. David
4109: Hume perceived that, to render this possible, it was necessary that the
4110: conceptions should have an à priori origin. But as he could not explain
4111: how it was possible that conceptions which are not connected with each
4112: other in the understanding must nevertheless be thought as necessarily
4113: connected in the object—and it never occurred to him that the
4114: understanding itself might, perhaps, by means of these conceptions, be
4115: the author of the experience in which its objects were presented to
4116: it—he was forced to drive these conceptions from experience, that is,
4117: from a subjective necessity arising from repeated association of
4118: experiences erroneously considered to be objective—in one word, from
4119: habit. But he proceeded with perfect consequence and declared it to be
4120: impossible, with such conceptions and the principles arising from them,
4121: to overstep the limits of experience. The empirical derivation,
4122: however, which both of these philosophers attributed to these
4123: conceptions, cannot possibly be reconciled with the fact that we do
4124: possess scientific à priori cognitions, namely, those of pure
4125: mathematics and general physics.
4126: 
4127: The former of these two celebrated men opened a wide door to
4128: extravagance—(for if reason has once undoubted right on its side, it
4129: will not allow itself to be confined to set limits, by vague
4130: recommendations of moderation); the latter gave himself up entirely to
4131: scepticism—a natural consequence, after having discovered, as he
4132: thought, that the faculty of cognition was not trustworthy. We now
4133: intend to make a trial whether it be not possible safely to conduct
4134: reason between these two rocks, to assign her determinate limits, and
4135: yet leave open for her the entire sphere of her legitimate activity.
4136: 
4137: I shall merely premise an explanation of what the categories are. They
4138: are conceptions of an object in general, by means of which its
4139: intuition is contemplated as determined in relation to one of the
4140: logical functions of judgement. The following will make this plain. The
4141: function of the categorical judgement is that of the relation of
4142: subject to predicate; for example, in the proposition: “All bodies are
4143: divisible.” But in regard to the merely logical use of the
4144: understanding, it still remains undetermined to which Of these two
4145: conceptions belongs the function Of subject and to which that of
4146: predicate. For we could also say: “Some divisible is a body.” But the
4147: category of substance, when the conception of a body is brought under
4148: it, determines that; and its empirical intuition in experience must be
4149: contemplated always as subject and never as mere predicate. And so with
4150: all the other categories.
4151: 
4152: Section II Transcendental Deduction of the pure Conceptions of the
4153: Understanding
4154: 
4155: Of the Possibility of a Conjunction of the manifold representations
4156: given by Sense § 11.
4157: 
4158: The manifold content in our representations can be given in an
4159: intuition which is merely sensuous—in other words, is nothing but
4160: susceptibility; and the form of this intuition can exist à priori in
4161: our faculty of representation, without being anything else but the mode
4162: in which the subject is affected. But the conjunction (conjunctio) of a
4163: manifold in intuition never can be given us by the senses; it cannot
4164: therefore be contained in the pure form of sensuous intuition, for it
4165: is a spontaneous act of the faculty of representation. And as we must,
4166: to distinguish it from sensibility, entitle this faculty understanding;
4167: so all conjunction whether conscious or unconscious, be it of the
4168: manifold in intuition, sensuous or non-sensuous, or of several
4169: conceptions—is an act of the understanding. To this act we shall give
4170: the general appellation of synthesis, thereby to indicate, at the same
4171: time, that we cannot represent anything as conjoined in the object
4172: without having previously conjoined it ourselves. Of all mental
4173: notions, that of conjunction is the only one which cannot be given
4174: through objects, but can be originated only by the subject itself,
4175: because it is an act of its purely spontaneous activity. The reader
4176: will easily enough perceive that the possibility of conjunction must be
4177: grounded in the very nature of this act, and that it must be equally
4178: valid for all conjunction, and that analysis, which appears to be its
4179: contrary, must, nevertheless, always presuppose it; for where the
4180: understanding has not previously conjoined, it cannot dissect or
4181: analyse, because only as conjoined by it, must that which is to be
4182: analysed have been given to our faculty of representation.
4183: 
4184: But the conception of conjunction includes, besides the conception of
4185: the manifold and of the synthesis of it, that of the unity of it also.
4186: Conjunction is the representation of the synthetical unity of the
4187: manifold.[15] This idea of unity, therefore, cannot arise out of that
4188: of conjunction; much rather does that idea, by combining itself with
4189: the representation of the manifold, render the conception of
4190: conjunction possible. This unity, which à priori precedes all
4191: conceptions of conjunction, is not the category of unity (§ 6); for all
4192: the categories are based upon logical functions of judgement, and in
4193: these functions we already have conjunction, and consequently unity of
4194: given conceptions. It is therefore evident that the category of unity
4195: presupposes conjunction. We must therefore look still higher for this
4196: unity (as qualitative, § 8), in that, namely, which contains the ground
4197: of the unity of diverse conceptions in judgements, the ground,
4198: consequently, of the possibility of the existence of the understanding,
4199: even in regard to its logical use.
4200: 
4201:  [15] Whether the representations are in themselves identical, and
4202:  consequently whether one can be thought analytically by means of and
4203:  through the other, is a question which we need not at present
4204:  consider. Our Consciousness of the one, when we speak of the manifold,
4205:  is always distinguishable from our consciousness of the other; and it
4206:  is only respecting the synthesis of this (possible) consciousness that
4207:  we here treat.
4208: 
4209: Of the Originally Synthetical Unity of Apperception § 12
4210: 
4211: The “I think” must accompany all my representations, for otherwise
4212: something would be represented in me which could not be thought; in
4213: other words, the representation would either be impossible, or at least
4214: be, in relation to me, nothing. That representation which can be given
4215: previously to all thought is called intuition. All the diversity or
4216: manifold content of intuition, has, therefore, a necessary relation to
4217: the “I think,” in the subject in which this diversity is found. But
4218: this representation, “I think,” is an act of spontaneity; that is to
4219: say, it cannot be regarded as belonging to mere sensibility. I call it
4220: pure apperception, in order to distinguish it from empirical; or
4221: primitive apperception, because it is self-consciousness which, whilst
4222: it gives birth to the representation “I think,” must necessarily be
4223: capable of accompanying all our representations. It is in all acts of
4224: consciousness one and the same, and unaccompanied by it, no
4225: representation can exist for me. The unity of this apperception I call
4226: the transcendental unity of self-consciousness, in order to indicate
4227: the possibility of à priori cognition arising from it. For the manifold
4228: representations which are given in an intuition would not all of them
4229: be my representations, if they did not all belong to one
4230: self-consciousness, that is, as my representations (even although I am
4231: not conscious of them as such), they must conform to the condition
4232: under which alone they can exist together in a common
4233: self-consciousness, because otherwise they would not all without
4234: exception belong to me. From this primitive conjunction follow many
4235: important results.
4236: 
4237: For example, this universal identity of the apperception of the
4238: manifold given in intuition contains a synthesis of representations and
4239: is possible only by means of the consciousness of this synthesis. For
4240: the empirical consciousness which accompanies different representations
4241: is in itself fragmentary and disunited, and without relation to the
4242: identity of the subject. This relation, then, does not exist because I
4243: accompany every representation with consciousness, but because I join
4244: one representation to another, and am conscious of the synthesis of
4245: them. Consequently, only because I can connect a variety of given
4246: representations in one consciousness, is it possible that I can
4247: represent to myself the identity of consciousness in these
4248: representations; in other words, the analytical unity of apperception
4249: is possible only under the presupposition of a synthetical unity.[16]
4250: The thought, “These representations given in intuition belong all of
4251: them to me,” is accordingly just the same as, “I unite them in one
4252: self-consciousness, or can at least so unite them”; and although this
4253: thought is not itself the consciousness of the synthesis of
4254: representations, it presupposes the possibility of it; that is to say,
4255: for the reason alone that I can comprehend the variety of my
4256: representations in one consciousness, do I call them my
4257: representations, for otherwise I must have as many-coloured and various
4258: a self as are the representations of which I am conscious. Synthetical
4259: unity of the manifold in intuitions, as given à priori, is therefore
4260: the foundation of the identity of apperception itself, which antecedes
4261: à priori all determinate thought. But the conjunction of
4262: representations into a conception is not to be found in objects
4263: themselves, nor can it be, as it were, borrowed from them and taken up
4264: into the understanding by perception, but it is on the contrary an
4265: operation of the understanding itself, which is nothing more than the
4266: faculty of conjoining à priori and of bringing the variety of given
4267: representations under the unity of apperception. This principle is the
4268: highest in all human cognition.
4269: 
4270:  [16] All general conceptions—as such—depend, for their existence, on
4271:  the analytical unity of consciousness. For example, when I think of
4272:  red in general, I thereby think to myself a property which (as a
4273:  characteristic mark) can be discovered somewhere, or can be united
4274:  with other representations; consequently, it is only by means of a
4275:  forethought possible synthetical unity that I can think to myself the
4276:  analytical. A representation which is cogitated as common to different
4277:  representations, is regarded as belonging to such as, besides this
4278:  common representation, contain something different; consequently it
4279:  must be previously thought in synthetical unity with other although
4280:  only possible representations, before I can think in it the analytical
4281:  unity of consciousness which makes it a conceptas communis. And thus
4282:  the synthetical unity of apperception is the highest point with which
4283:  we must connect every operation of the understanding, even the whole
4284:  of logic, and after it our transcendental philosophy; indeed, this
4285:  faculty is the understanding itself.
4286: 
4287: 
4288: This fundamental principle of the necessary unity of apperception is
4289: indeed an identical, and therefore analytical, proposition; but it
4290: nevertheless explains the necessity for a synthesis of the manifold
4291: given in an intuition, without which the identity of self-consciousness
4292: would be incogitable. For the ego, as a simple representation, presents
4293: us with no manifold content; only in intuition, which is quite
4294: different from the representation ego, can it be given us, and by means
4295: of conjunction it is cogitated in one self-consciousness. An
4296: understanding, in which all the manifold should be given by means of
4297: consciousness itself, would be intuitive; our understanding can only
4298: think and must look for its intuition to sense. I am, therefore,
4299: conscious of my identical self, in relation to all the variety of
4300: representations given to me in an intuition, because I call all of them
4301: my representations. In other words, I am conscious myself of a
4302: necessary à priori synthesis of my representations, which is called the
4303: original synthetical unity of apperception, under which rank all the
4304: representations presented to me, but that only by means of a synthesis.
4305: 
4306: The Principle of the Synthetical Unity of Apperception is the highest
4307: Principle of all exercise of the Understanding § 13
4308: 
4309: The supreme principle of the possibility of all intuition in relation
4310: to sensibility was, according to our transcendental æsthetic, that all
4311: the manifold in intuition be subject to the formal conditions of space
4312: and time. The supreme principle of the possibility of it in relation to
4313: the understanding is that all the manifold in it be subject to
4314: conditions of the originally synthetical unity or apperception.[17] To
4315: the former of these two principles are subject all the various
4316: representations of intuition, in so far as they are given to us; to the
4317: latter, in so far as they must be capable of conjunction in one
4318: consciousness; for without this nothing can be thought or cognized,
4319: because the given representations would not have in common the act Of
4320: the apperception “I think” and therefore could not be connected in one
4321: self-consciousness.
4322: 
4323:  [17] Space and time, and all portions thereof, are intuitions;
4324:  consequently are, with a manifold for their content, single
4325:  representations. (See the Transcendental Æsthetic.) Consequently, they
4326:  are not pure conceptions, by means of which the same consciousness is
4327:  found in a great number of representations; but, on the contrary, they
4328:  are many representations contained in one, the consciousness of which
4329:  is, so to speak, compounded. The unity of consciousness is
4330:  nevertheless synthetical and, therefore, primitive. From this peculiar
4331:  character of consciousness follow many important consequences. (See §
4332:  21.)
4333: 
4334: 
4335: Understanding is, to speak generally, the faculty Of cognitions. These
4336: consist in the determined relation of given representation to an
4337: object. But an object is that, in the conception of which the manifold
4338: in a given intuition is united. Now all union of representations
4339: requires unity of consciousness in the synthesis of them. Consequently,
4340: it is the unity of consciousness alone that constitutes the possibility
4341: of representations relating to an object, and therefore of their
4342: objective validity, and of their becoming cognitions, and consequently,
4343: the possibility of the existence of the understanding itself.
4344: 
4345: The first pure cognition of understanding, then, upon which is founded
4346: all its other exercise, and which is at the same time perfectly
4347: independent of all conditions of mere sensuous intuition, is the
4348: principle of the original synthetical unity of apperception. Thus the
4349: mere form of external sensuous intuition, namely, space, affords us,
4350: per se, no cognition; it merely contributes the manifold in à priori
4351: intuition to a possible cognition. But, in order to cognize something
4352: in space (for example, a line), I must draw it, and thus produce
4353: synthetically a determined conjunction of the given manifold, so that
4354: the unity of this act is at the same time the unity of consciousness
4355: (in the conception of a line), and by this means alone is an object (a
4356: determinate space) cognized. The synthetical unity of consciousness is,
4357: therefore, an objective condition of all cognition, which I do not
4358: merely require in order to cognize an object, but to which every
4359: intuition must necessarily be subject, in order to become an object for
4360: me; because in any other way, and without this synthesis, the manifold
4361: in intuition could not be united in one consciousness.
4362: 
4363: This proposition is, as already said, itself analytical, although it
4364: constitutes the synthetical unity, the condition of all thought; for it
4365: states nothing more than that all my representations in any given
4366: intuition must be subject to the condition which alone enables me to
4367: connect them, as my representation with the identical self, and so to
4368: unite them synthetically in one apperception, by means of the general
4369: expression, “I think.”
4370: 
4371: But this principle is not to be regarded as a principle for every
4372: possible understanding, but only for the understanding by means of
4373: whose pure apperception in the thought I am, no manifold content is
4374: given. The understanding or mind which contained the manifold in
4375: intuition, in and through the act itself of its own self-consciousness,
4376: in other words, an understanding by and in the representation of which
4377: the objects of the representation should at the same time exist, would
4378: not require a special act of synthesis of the manifold as the condition
4379: of the unity of its consciousness, an act of which the human
4380: understanding, which thinks only and cannot intuite, has absolute need.
4381: But this principle is the first principle of all the operations of our
4382: understanding, so that we cannot form the least conception of any other
4383: possible understanding, either of one such as should be itself
4384: intuition, or possess a sensuous intuition, but with forms different
4385: from those of space and time.
4386: 
4387: What Objective Unity of Self-consciousness is § 14
4388: 
4389: It is by means of the transcendental unity of apperception that all the
4390: manifold, given in an intuition is united into a conception of the
4391: object. On this account it is called objective, and must be
4392: distinguished from the subjective unity of consciousness, which is a
4393: determination of the internal sense, by means of which the said
4394: manifold in intuition is given empirically to be so united. Whether I
4395: can be empirically conscious of the manifold as coexistent or as
4396: successive, depends upon circumstances, or empirical conditions. Hence
4397: the empirical unity of consciousness by means of association of
4398: representations, itself relates to a phenomenal world and is wholly
4399: contingent. On the contrary, the pure form of intuition in time, merely
4400: as an intuition, which contains a given manifold, is subject to the
4401: original unity of consciousness, and that solely by means of the
4402: necessary relation of the manifold in intuition to the “I think,”
4403: consequently by means of the pure synthesis of the understanding, which
4404: lies à priori at the foundation of all empirical synthesis. The
4405: transcendental unity of apperception is alone objectively valid; the
4406: empirical which we do not consider in this essay, and which is merely a
4407: unity deduced from the former under given conditions in concreto,
4408: possesses only subjective validity. One person connects the notion
4409: conveyed in a word with one thing, another with another thing; and the
4410: unity of consciousness in that which is empirical, is, in relation to
4411: that which is given by experience, not necessarily and universally
4412: valid.
4413: 
4414: The Logical Form of all Judgements consists in the Objective Unity of
4415: Apperception of the Conceptions contained therein § 15
4416: 
4417: I could never satisfy myself with the definition which logicians give
4418: of a judgement. It is, according to them, the representation of a
4419: relation between two conceptions. I shall not dwell here on the
4420: faultiness of this definition, in that it suits only for categorical
4421: and not for hypothetical or disjunctive judgements, these latter
4422: containing a relation not of conceptions but of judgements themselves—a
4423: blunder from which many evil results have followed.[18] It is more
4424: important for our present purpose to observe, that this definition does
4425: not determine in what the said relation consists.
4426: 
4427:  [18] The tedious doctrine of the four syllogistic figures concerns
4428:  only categorical syllogisms; and although it is nothing more than an
4429:  artifice by surreptitiously introducing immediate conclusions
4430:  (consequentiae immediatae) among the premises of a pure syllogism, to
4431:  give ism give rise to an appearance of more modes of drawing a
4432:  conclusion than that in the first figure, the artifice would not have
4433:  had much success, had not its authors succeeded in bringing
4434:  categorical judgements into exclusive respect, as those to which all
4435:  others must be referred—a doctrine, however, which, according to § 5,
4436:  is utterly false.
4437: 
4438: 
4439: But if I investigate more closely the relation of given cognitions in
4440: every judgement, and distinguish it, as belonging to the understanding,
4441: from the relation which is produced according to laws of the
4442: reproductive imagination (which has only subjective validity), I find
4443: that judgement is nothing but the mode of bringing given cognitions
4444: under the objective unit of apperception. This is plain from our use of
4445: the term of relation is in judgements, in order to distinguish the
4446: objective unity of given representations from the subjective unity. For
4447: this term indicates the relation of these representations to the
4448: original apperception, and also their necessary unity, even although
4449: the judgement is empirical, therefore contingent, as in the judgement:
4450: “All bodies are heavy.” I do not mean by this, that these
4451: representations do necessarily belong to each other in empirical
4452: intuition, but that by means of the necessary unity of appreciation
4453: they belong to each other in the synthesis of intuitions, that is to
4454: say, they belong to each other according to principles of the objective
4455: determination of all our representations, in so far as cognition can
4456: arise from them, these principles being all deduced from the main
4457: principle of the transcendental unity of apperception. In this way
4458: alone can there arise from this relation a judgement, that is, a
4459: relation which has objective validity, and is perfectly distinct from
4460: that relation of the very same representations which has only
4461: subjective validity—a relation, to wit, which is produced according to
4462: laws of association. According to these laws, I could only say: “When I
4463: hold in my hand or carry a body, I feel an impression of weight”; but I
4464: could not say: “It, the body, is heavy”; for this is tantamount to
4465: saying both these representations are conjoined in the object, that is,
4466: without distinction as to the condition of the subject, and do not
4467: merely stand together in my perception, however frequently the
4468: perceptive act may be repeated.
4469: 
4470: All Sensuous Intuitions are subject to the Categories, as Conditions
4471: under which alone the manifold Content of them can be united in one
4472: Consciousness § 16
4473: 
4474: The manifold content given in a sensuous intuition comes necessarily
4475: under the original synthetical unity of apperception, because thereby
4476: alone is the unity of intuition possible (§ 13). But that act of the
4477: understanding, by which the manifold content of given representations
4478: (whether intuitions or conceptions) is brought under one apperception,
4479: is the logical function of judgements (§ 15). All the manifold,
4480: therefore, in so far as it is given in one empirical intuition, is
4481: determined in relation to one of the logical functions of judgement, by
4482: means of which it is brought into union in one consciousness. Now the
4483: categories are nothing else than these functions of judgement so far as
4484: the manifold in a given intuition is determined in relation to them (§
4485: 9). Consequently, the manifold in a given intuition is necessarily
4486: subject to the categories of the understanding.
4487: 
4488: Observation § 17
4489: 
4490: The manifold in an intuition, which I call mine, is represented by
4491: means of the synthesis of the understanding, as belonging to the
4492: necessary unity of self-consciousness, and this takes place by means of
4493: the category.[19] The category indicates accordingly that the empirical
4494: consciousness of a given manifold in an intuition is subject to a pure
4495: self-consciousness à priori, in the same manner as an empirical
4496: intuition is subject to a pure sensuous intuition, which is also à
4497: priori. In the above proposition, then, lies the beginning of a
4498: deduction of the pure conceptions of the understanding. Now, as the
4499: categories have their origin in the understanding alone, independently
4500: of sensibility, I must in my deduction make abstraction of the mode in
4501: which the manifold of an empirical intuition is given, in order to fix
4502: my attention exclusively on the unity which is brought by the
4503: understanding into the intuition by means of the category. In what
4504: follows (§ 22), it will be shown, from the mode in which the empirical
4505: intuition is given in the faculty of sensibility, that the unity which
4506: belongs to it is no other than that which the category (according to §
4507: 16) imposes on the manifold in a given intuition, and thus, its à
4508: priori validity in regard to all objects of sense being established,
4509: the purpose of our deduction will be fully attained.
4510: 
4511:  [19] The proof of this rests on the represented unity of intuition, by
4512:  means of which an object is given, and which always includes in itself
4513:  a synthesis of the manifold to be intuited, and also the relation of
4514:  this latter to unity of apperception.
4515: 
4516: 
4517: But there is one thing in the above demonstration of which I could not
4518: make abstraction, namely, that the manifold to be intuited must be
4519: given previously to the synthesis of the understanding, and
4520: independently of it. How this takes place remains here undetermined.
4521: For if I cogitate an understanding which was itself intuitive (as, for
4522: example, a divine understanding which should not represent given
4523: objects, but by whose representation the objects themselves should be
4524: given or produced), the categories would possess no significance in
4525: relation to such a faculty of cognition. They are merely rules for an
4526: understanding, whose whole power consists in thought, that is, in the
4527: act of submitting the synthesis of the manifold which is presented to
4528: it in intuition from a very different quarter, to the unity of
4529: apperception; a faculty, therefore, which cognizes nothing per se, but
4530: only connects and arranges the material of cognition, the intuition,
4531: namely, which must be presented to it by means of the object. But to
4532: show reasons for this peculiar character of our understandings, that it
4533: produces unity of apperception à priori only by means of categories,
4534: and a certain kind and number thereof, is as impossible as to explain
4535: why we are endowed with precisely so many functions of judgement and no
4536: more, or why time and space are the only forms of our intuition.
4537: 
4538: In Cognition, its Application to Objects of Experience is the only
4539: legitimate use of the Category § 18
4540: 
4541: To think an object and to cognize an object are by no means the same
4542: thing. In cognition there are two elements: firstly, the conception,
4543: whereby an object is cogitated (the category); and, secondly, the
4544: intuition, whereby the object is given. For supposing that to the
4545: conception a corresponding intuition could not be given, it would still
4546: be a thought as regards its form, but without any object, and no
4547: cognition of anything would be possible by means of it, inasmuch as, so
4548: far as I knew, there existed and could exist nothing to which my
4549: thought could be applied. Now all intuition possible to us is sensuous;
4550: consequently, our thought of an object by means of a pure conception of
4551: the understanding, can become cognition for us only in so far as this
4552: conception is applied to objects of the senses. Sensuous intuition is
4553: either pure intuition (space and time) or empirical intuition—of that
4554: which is immediately represented in space and time by means of
4555: sensation as real. Through the determination of pure intuition we
4556: obtain à priori cognitions of objects, as in mathematics, but only as
4557: regards their form as phenomena; whether there can exist things which
4558: must be intuited in this form is not thereby established. All
4559: mathematical conceptions, therefore, are not per se cognition, except
4560: in so far as we presuppose that there exist things which can only be
4561: represented conformably to the form of our pure sensuous intuition. But
4562: things in space and time are given only in so far as they are
4563: perceptions (representations accompanied with sensation), therefore
4564: only by empirical representation. Consequently the pure conceptions of
4565: the understanding, even when they are applied to intuitions à priori
4566: (as in mathematics), produce cognition only in so far as these (and
4567: therefore the conceptions of the understanding by means of them) can be
4568: applied to empirical intuitions. Consequently the categories do not,
4569: even by means of pure intuition afford us any cognition of things; they
4570: can only do so in so far as they can be applied to empirical intuition.
4571: That is to say, the categories serve only to render empirical cognition
4572: possible. But this is what we call experience. Consequently, in
4573: cognition, their application to objects of experience is the only
4574: legitimate use of the categories.
4575: 
4576: § 19
4577: 
4578: 
4579: The foregoing proposition is of the utmost importance, for it
4580: determines the limits of the exercise of the pure conceptions of the
4581: understanding in regard to objects, just as transcendental æsthetic
4582: determined the limits of the exercise of the pure form of our sensuous
4583: intuition. Space and time, as conditions of the possibility of the
4584: presentation of objects to us, are valid no further than for objects of
4585: sense, consequently, only for experience. Beyond these limits they
4586: represent to us nothing, for they belong only to sense, and have no
4587: reality apart from it. The pure conceptions of the understanding are
4588: free from this limitation, and extend to objects of intuition in
4589: general, be the intuition like or unlike to ours, provided only it be
4590: sensuous, and not intellectual. But this extension of conceptions
4591: beyond the range of our intuition is of no advantage; for they are then
4592: mere empty conceptions of objects, as to the possibility or
4593: impossibility of the existence of which they furnish us with no means
4594: of discovery. They are mere forms of thought, without objective
4595: reality, because we have no intuition to which the synthetical unity of
4596: apperception, which alone the categories contain, could be applied, for
4597: the purpose of determining an object. Our sensuous and empirical
4598: intuition can alone give them significance and meaning.
4599: 
4600: If, then, we suppose an object of a non-sensuous intuition to be given
4601: we can in that case represent it by all those predicates which are
4602: implied in the presupposition that nothing appertaining to sensuous
4603: intuition belongs to it; for example, that it is not extended, or in
4604: space; that its duration is not time; that in it no change (the effect
4605: of the determinations in time) is to be met with, and so on. But it is
4606: no proper knowledge if I merely indicate what the intuition of the
4607: object is not, without being able to say what is contained in it, for I
4608: have not shown the possibility of an object to which my pure conception
4609: of understanding could be applicable, because I have not been able to
4610: furnish any intuition corresponding to it, but am only able to say that
4611: our intuition is not valid for it. But the most important point is
4612: this, that to a something of this kind not one category can be found
4613: applicable. Take, for example, the conception of substance, that is,
4614: something that can exist as subject, but never as mere predicate; in
4615: regard to this conception I am quite ignorant whether there can really
4616: be anything to correspond to such a determination of thought, if
4617: empirical intuition did not afford me the occasion for its application.
4618: But of this more in the sequel.
4619: 
4620: Of the Application of the Categories to Objects of the Senses in
4621: general § 20
4622: 
4623: The pure conceptions of the understanding apply to objects of intuition
4624: in general, through the understanding alone, whether the intuition be
4625: our own or some other, provided only it be sensuous, but are, for this
4626: very reason, mere forms of thought, by means of which alone no
4627: determined object can be cognized. The synthesis or conjunction of the
4628: manifold in these conceptions relates, we have said, only to the unity
4629: of apperception, and is for this reason the ground of the possibility
4630: of à priori cognition, in so far as this cognition is dependent on the
4631: understanding. This synthesis is, therefore, not merely transcendental,
4632: but also purely intellectual. But because a certain form of sensuous
4633: intuition exists in the mind à priori which rests on the receptivity of
4634: the representative faculty (sensibility), the understanding, as a
4635: spontaneity, is able to determine the internal sense by means of the
4636: diversity of given representations, conformably to the synthetical
4637: unity of apperception, and thus to cogitate the synthetical unity of
4638: the apperception of the manifold of sensuous intuition à priori, as the
4639: condition to which must necessarily be submitted all objects of human
4640: intuition. And in this manner the categories as mere forms of thought
4641: receive objective reality, that is, application to objects which are
4642: given to us in intuition, but that only as phenomena, for it is only of
4643: phenomena that we are capable of à priori intuition.
4644: 
4645: This synthesis of the manifold of sensuous intuition, which is possible
4646: and necessary à priori, may be called figurative (synthesis speciosa),
4647: in contradistinction to that which is cogitated in the mere category in
4648: regard to the manifold of an intuition in general, and is called
4649: connection or conjunction of the understanding (synthesis
4650: intellectualis). Both are transcendental, not merely because they
4651: themselves precede à priori all experience, but also because they form
4652: the basis for the possibility of other cognition à priori.
4653: 
4654: But the figurative synthesis, when it has relation only to the
4655: originally synthetical unity of apperception, that is to the
4656: transcendental unity cogitated in the categories, must, to be
4657: distinguished from the purely intellectual conjunction, be entitled the
4658: transcendental synthesis of imagination. Imagination is the faculty of
4659: representing an object even without its presence in intuition. Now, as
4660: all our intuition is sensuous, imagination, by reason of the subjective
4661: condition under which alone it can give a corresponding intuition to
4662: the conceptions of the understanding, belongs to sensibility. But in so
4663: far as the synthesis of the imagination is an act of spontaneity, which
4664: is determinative, and not, like sense, merely determinable, and which
4665: is consequently able to determine sense à priori, according to its
4666: form, conformably to the unity of apperception, in so far is the
4667: imagination a faculty of determining sensibility à priori, and its
4668: synthesis of intuitions according to the categories must be the
4669: transcendental synthesis of the imagination. It is an operation of the
4670: understanding on sensibility, and the first application of the
4671: understanding to objects of possible intuition, and at the same time
4672: the basis for the exercise of the other functions of that faculty. As
4673: figurative, it is distinguished from the merely intellectual synthesis,
4674: which is produced by the understanding alone, without the aid of
4675: imagination. Now, in so far as imagination is spontaneity, I sometimes
4676: call it also the productive imagination, and distinguish it from the
4677: reproductive, the synthesis of which is subject entirely to empirical
4678: laws, those of association, namely, and which, therefore, contributes
4679: nothing to the explanation of the possibility of à priori cognition,
4680: and for this reason belongs not to transcendental philosophy, but to
4681: psychology.
4682: 
4683: We have now arrived at the proper place for explaining the paradox
4684: which must have struck every one in our exposition of the internal
4685: sense (§ 6), namely—how this sense represents us to our own
4686: consciousness, only as we appear to ourselves, not as we are in
4687: ourselves, because, to wit, we intuite ourselves only as we are
4688: inwardly affected. Now this appears to be contradictory, inasmuch as we
4689: thus stand in a passive relation to ourselves; and therefore in the
4690: systems of psychology, the internal sense is commonly held to be one
4691: with the faculty of apperception, while we, on the contrary, carefully
4692: distinguish them.
4693: 
4694: That which determines the internal sense is the understanding, and its
4695: original power of conjoining the manifold of intuition, that is, of
4696: bringing this under an apperception (upon which rests the possibility
4697: of the understanding itself). Now, as the human understanding is not in
4698: itself a faculty of intuition, and is unable to exercise such a power,
4699: in order to conjoin, as it were, the manifold of its own intuition, the
4700: synthesis of understanding is, considered per se, nothing but the unity
4701: of action, of which, as such, it is self-conscious, even apart from
4702: sensibility, by which, moreover, it is able to determine our internal
4703: sense in respect of the manifold which may be presented to it according
4704: to the form of sensuous intuition. Thus, under the name of a
4705: transcendental synthesis of imagination, the understanding exercises an
4706: activity upon the passive subject, whose faculty it is; and so we are
4707: right in saying that the internal sense is affected thereby.
4708: Apperception and its synthetical unity are by no means one and the same
4709: with the internal sense. The former, as the source of all our
4710: synthetical conjunction, applies, under the name of the categories, to
4711: the manifold of intuition in general, prior to all sensuous intuition
4712: of objects. The internal sense, on the contrary, contains merely the
4713: form of intuition, but without any synthetical conjunction of the
4714: manifold therein, and consequently does not contain any determined
4715: intuition, which is possible only through consciousness of the
4716: determination of the manifold by the transcendental act of the
4717: imagination (synthetical influence of the understanding on the internal
4718: sense), which I have named figurative synthesis.
4719: 
4720: This we can indeed always perceive in ourselves. We cannot cogitate a
4721: geometrical line without drawing it in thought, nor a circle without
4722: describing it, nor represent the three dimensions of space without
4723: drawing three lines from the same point perpendicular to one another.
4724: We cannot even cogitate time, unless, in drawing a straight line (which
4725: is to serve as the external figurative representation of time), we fix
4726: our attention on the act of the synthesis of the manifold, whereby we
4727: determine successively the internal sense, and thus attend also to the
4728: succession of this determination. Motion as an act of the subject (not
4729: as a determination of an object),[20] consequently the synthesis of the
4730: manifold in space, if we make abstraction of space and attend merely to
4731: the act by which we determine the internal sense according to its form,
4732: is that which produces the conception of succession. The understanding,
4733: therefore, does by no means find in the internal sense any such
4734: synthesis of the manifold, but produces it, in that it affects this
4735: sense. At the same time, how “I who think” is distinct from the “i”
4736: which intuites itself (other modes of intuition being cogitable as at
4737: least possible), and yet one and the same with this latter as the same
4738: subject; how, therefore, I am able to say: “I, as an intelligence and
4739: thinking subject, cognize myself as an object thought, so far as I am,
4740: moreover, given to myself in intuition—only, like other phenomena, not
4741: as I am in myself, and as considered by the understanding, but merely
4742: as I appear”—is a question that has in it neither more nor less
4743: difficulty than the question—“How can I be an object to myself?” or
4744: this—“How I can be an object of my own intuition and internal
4745: perceptions?” But that such must be the fact, if we admit that space is
4746: merely a pure form of the phenomena of external sense, can be clearly
4747: proved by the consideration that we cannot represent time, which is not
4748: an object of external intuition, in any other way than under the image
4749: of a line, which we draw in thought, a mode of representation without
4750: which we could not cognize the unity of its dimension, and also that we
4751: are necessitated to take our determination of periods of time, or of
4752: points of time, for all our internal perceptions from the changes which
4753: we perceive in outward things. It follows that we must arrange the
4754: determinations of the internal sense, as phenomena in time, exactly in
4755: the same manner as we arrange those of the external senses in space.
4756: And consequently, if we grant, respecting this latter, that by means of
4757: them we know objects only in so far as we are affected externally, we
4758: must also confess, with regard to the internal sense, that by means of
4759: it we intuite ourselves only as we are internally affected by
4760: ourselves; in other words, as regards internal intuition, we cognize
4761: our own subject only as phenomenon, and not as it is in itself.[21]
4762: 
4763:  [20] Motion of an object in space does not belong to a pure science,
4764:  consequently not to geometry; because, that a thing is movable cannot
4765:  be known à priori, but only from experience. But motion, considered as
4766:  the description of a space, is a pure act of the successive synthesis
4767:  of the manifold in external intuition by means of productive
4768:  imagination, and belongs not only to geometry, but even to
4769:  transcendental philosophy.
4770: 
4771: 
4772:  [21] I do not see why so much difficulty should be found in admitting
4773:  that our internal sense is affected by ourselves. Every act of
4774:  attention exemplifies it. In such an act the understanding determines
4775:  the internal sense by the synthetical conjunction which it cogitates,
4776:  conformably to the internal intuition which corresponds to the
4777:  manifold in the synthesis of the understanding. How much the mind is
4778:  usually affected thereby every one will be able to perceive in
4779:  himself.
4780: 
4781: 
4782: § 21
4783: 
4784: 
4785: On the other hand, in the transcendental synthesis of the manifold
4786: content of representations, consequently in the synthetical unity of
4787: apperception, I am conscious of myself, not as I appear to myself, nor
4788: as I am in myself, but only that “I am.” This representation is a
4789: thought, not an intuition. Now, as in order to cognize ourselves, in
4790: addition to the act of thinking, which subjects the manifold of every
4791: possible intuition to the unity of apperception, there is necessary a
4792: determinate mode of intuition, whereby this manifold is given; although
4793: my own existence is certainly not mere phenomenon (much less mere
4794: illusion), the determination of my existence[22] Can only take place
4795: conformably to the form of the internal sense, according to the
4796: particular mode in which the manifold which I conjoin is given in
4797: internal intuition, and I have therefore no knowledge of myself as I
4798: am, but merely as I appear to myself. The consciousness of self is thus
4799: very far from a knowledge of self, in which I do not use the
4800: categories, whereby I cogitate an object, by means of the conjunction
4801: of the manifold in one apperception. In the same way as I require, for
4802: the sake of the cognition of an object distinct from myself, not only
4803: the thought of an object in general (in the category), but also an
4804: intuition by which to determine that general conception, in the same
4805: way do I require, in order to the cognition of myself, not only the
4806: consciousness of myself or the thought that I think myself, but in
4807: addition an intuition of the manifold in myself, by which to determine
4808: this thought. It is true that I exist as an intelligence which is
4809: conscious only of its faculty of conjunction or synthesis, but
4810: subjected in relation to the manifold which this intelligence has to
4811: conjoin to a limitative conjunction called the internal sense. My
4812: intelligence (that is, I) can render that conjunction or synthesis
4813: perceptible only according to the relations of time, which are quite
4814: beyond the proper sphere of the conceptions of the understanding and
4815: consequently cognize itself in respect to an intuition (which cannot
4816: possibly be intellectual, nor given by the understanding), only as it
4817: appears to itself, and not as it would cognize itself, if its intuition
4818: were intellectual.
4819: 
4820:  [22] The “I think” expresses the act of determining my own existence.
4821:  My existence is thus already given by the act of consciousness; but
4822:  the mode in which I must determine my existence, that is, the mode in
4823:  which I must place the manifold belonging to my existence, is not
4824:  thereby given. For this purpose intuition of self is required, and
4825:  this intuition possesses a form given à priori, namely, time, which is
4826:  sensuous, and belongs to our receptivity of the determinable. Now, as
4827:  I do not possess another intuition of self which gives the determining
4828:  in me (of the spontaneity of which I am conscious), prior to the act
4829:  of determination, in the same manner as time gives the determinable,
4830:  it is clear that I am unable to determine my own existence as that of
4831:  a spontaneous being, but I am only able to represent to myself the
4832:  spontaneity of my thought, that is, of my determination, and my
4833:  existence remains ever determinable in a purely sensuous manner, that
4834:  is to say, like the existence of a phenomenon. But it is because of
4835:  this spontaneity that I call myself an intelligence.
4836: 
4837: Transcendental Deduction of the universally possible employment in
4838: experience of the Pure Conceptions of the Understanding § 22
4839: 
4840: In the metaphysical deduction, the à priori origin of categories was
4841: proved by their complete accordance with the general logical of
4842: thought; in the transcendental deduction was exhibited the possibility
4843: of the categories as à priori cognitions of objects of an intuition in
4844: general (§ 16 and 17).At present we are about to explain the
4845: possibility of cognizing, à priori, by means of the categories, all
4846: objects which can possibly be presented to our senses, not, indeed,
4847: according to the form of their intuition, but according to the laws of
4848: their conjunction or synthesis, and thus, as it were, of prescribing
4849: laws to nature and even of rendering nature possible. For if the
4850: categories were inadequate to this task, it would not be evident to us
4851: why everything that is presented to our senses must be subject to those
4852: laws which have an à priori origin in the understanding itself.
4853: 
4854: I premise that by the term synthesis of apprehension I understand the
4855: combination of the manifold in an empirical intuition, whereby
4856: perception, that is, empirical consciousness of the intuition (as
4857: phenomenon), is possible.
4858: 
4859: We have à priori forms of the external and internal sensuous intuition
4860: in the representations of space and time, and to these must the
4861: synthesis of apprehension of the manifold in a phenomenon be always
4862: comformable, because the synthesis itself can only take place according
4863: to these forms. But space and time are not merely forms of sensuous
4864: intuition, but intuitions themselves (which contain a manifold), and
4865: therefore contain à priori the determination of the unity of this
4866: manifold.[23] (See the Transcendent Æsthetic.) Therefore is unity of
4867: the synthesis of the manifold without or within us, consequently also a
4868: conjunction to which all that is to be represented as determined in
4869: space or time must correspond, given à priori along with (not in) these
4870: intuitions, as the condition of the synthesis of all apprehension of
4871: them. But this synthetical unity can be no other than that of the
4872: conjunction of the manifold of a given intuition in general, in a
4873: primitive act of consciousness, according to the categories, but
4874: applied to our sensuous intuition. Consequently all synthesis, whereby
4875: alone is even perception possible, is subject to the categories. And,
4876: as experience is cognition by means of conjoined perceptions, the
4877: categories are conditions of the possibility of experience and are
4878: therefore valid à priori for all objects of experience.
4879: 
4880:  [23] Space represented as an object (as geometry really requires it to
4881:  be) contains more than the mere form of the intuition; namely, a
4882:  combination of the manifold given according to the form of sensibility
4883:  into a representation that can be intuited; so that the form of the
4884:  intuition gives us merely the manifold, but the formal intuition gives
4885:  unity of representation. In the æsthetic, I regarded this unity as
4886:  belonging entirely to sensibility, for the purpose of indicating that
4887:  it antecedes all conceptions, although it presupposes a synthesis
4888:  which does not belong to sense, through which alone, however, all our
4889:  conceptions of space and time are possible. For as by means of this
4890:  unity alone (the understanding determining the sensibility) space and
4891:  time are given as intuitions, it follows that the unity of this
4892:  intuition à priori belongs to space and time, and not to the
4893:  conception of the understanding (§ 20).
4894: 
4895: 
4896: When, then, for example, I make the empirical intuition of a house by
4897: apprehension of the manifold contained therein into a perception, the
4898: necessary unity of space and of my external sensuous intuition lies at
4899: the foundation of this act, and I, as it were, draw the form of the
4900: house conformably to this synthetical unity of the manifold in space.
4901: But this very synthetical unity remains, even when I abstract the form
4902: of space, and has its seat in the understanding, and is in fact the
4903: category of the synthesis of the homogeneous in an intuition; that is
4904: to say, the category of quantity, to which the aforesaid synthesis of
4905: apprehension, that is, the perception, must be completely
4906: conformable.[24]
4907: 
4908:  [24] In this manner it is proved, that the synthesis of apprehension,
4909:  which is empirical, must necessarily be conformable to the synthesis
4910:  of apperception, which is intellectual, and contained à priori in the
4911:  category. It is one and the same spontaneity which at one time, under
4912:  the name of imagination, at another under that of understanding,
4913:  produces conjunction in the manifold of intuition.
4914: 
4915: 
4916: To take another example, when I perceive the freezing of water, I
4917: apprehend two states (fluidity and solidity), which, as such, stand
4918: toward each other mutually in a relation of time. But in the time,
4919: which I place as an internal intuition, at the foundation of this
4920: phenomenon, I represent to myself synthetical unity of the manifold,
4921: without which the aforesaid relation could not be given in an intuition
4922: as determined (in regard to the succession of time). Now this
4923: synthetical unity, as the à priori condition under which I conjoin the
4924: manifold of an intuition, is, if I make abstraction of the permanent
4925: form of my internal intuition (that is to say, of time), the category
4926: of cause, by means of which, when applied to my sensibility, I
4927: determine everything that occurs according to relations of time.
4928: Consequently apprehension in such an event, and the event itself, as
4929: far as regards the possibility of its perception, stands under the
4930: conception of the relation of cause and effect: and so in all other
4931: cases.
4932: 
4933: Categories are conceptions which prescribe laws à priori to phenomena,
4934: consequently to nature as the complex of all phenomena (natura
4935: materialiter spectata). And now the question arises—inasmuch as these
4936: categories are not derived from nature, and do not regulate themselves
4937: according to her as their model (for in that case they would be
4938: empirical)—how it is conceivable that nature must regulate herself
4939: according to them, in other words, how the categories can determine à
4940: priori the synthesis of the manifold of nature, and yet not derive
4941: their origin from her. The following is the solution of this enigma.
4942: 
4943: It is not in the least more difficult to conceive how the laws of the
4944: phenomena of nature must harmonize with the understanding and with its
4945: à priori form—that is, its faculty of conjoining the manifold—than it
4946: is to understand how the phenomena themselves must correspond with the
4947: à priori form of our sensuous intuition. For laws do not exist in the
4948: phenomena any more than the phenomena exist as things in themselves.
4949: Laws do not exist except by relation to the subject in which the
4950: phenomena inhere, in so far as it possesses understanding, just as
4951: phenomena have no existence except by relation to the same existing
4952: subject in so far as it has senses. To things as things in themselves,
4953: conformability to law must necessarily belong independently of an
4954: understanding to cognize them. But phenomena are only representations
4955: of things which are utterly unknown in respect to what they are in
4956: themselves. But as mere representations, they stand under no law of
4957: conjunction except that which the conjoining faculty prescribes. Now
4958: that which conjoins the manifold of sensuous intuition is imagination,
4959: a mental act to which understanding contributes unity of intellectual
4960: synthesis, and sensibility, manifoldness of apprehension. Now as all
4961: possible perception depends on the synthesis of apprehension, and this
4962: empirical synthesis itself on the transcendental, consequently on the
4963: categories, it is evident that all possible perceptions, and therefore
4964: everything that can attain to empirical consciousness, that is, all
4965: phenomena of nature, must, as regards their conjunction, be subject to
4966: the categories. And nature (considered merely as nature in general) is
4967: dependent on them, as the original ground of her necessary
4968: conformability to law (as natura formaliter spectata). But the pure
4969: faculty (of the understanding) of prescribing laws à priori to
4970: phenomena by means of mere categories, is not competent to enounce
4971: other or more laws than those on which a nature in general, as a
4972: conformability to law of phenomena of space and time, depends.
4973: Particular laws, inasmuch as they concern empirically determined
4974: phenomena, cannot be entirely deduced from pure laws, although they all
4975: stand under them. Experience must be superadded in order to know these
4976: particular laws; but in regard to experience in general, and everything
4977: that can be cognized as an object thereof, these à priori laws are our
4978: only rule and guide.
4979: 
4980: Result of this Deduction of the Conceptions of the Understanding § 23
4981: 
4982: We cannot think any object except by means of the categories; we cannot
4983: cognize any thought except by means of intuitions corresponding to
4984: these conceptions. Now all our intuitions are sensuous, and our
4985: cognition, in so far as the object of it is given, is empirical. But
4986: empirical cognition is experience; consequently no à priori cognition
4987: is possible for us, except of objects of possible experience.[25]
4988: 
4989:  [25] Lest my readers should stumble at this assertion, and the
4990:  conclusions that may be too rashly drawn from it, I must remind them
4991:  that the categories in the act of thought are by no means limited by
4992:  the conditions of our sensuous intuition, but have an unbounded sphere
4993:  of action. It is only the cognition of the object of thought, the
4994:  determining of the object, which requires intuition. In the absence of
4995:  intuition, our thought of an object may still have true and useful
4996:  consequences in regard to the exercise of reason by the subject. But
4997:  as this exercise of reason is not always directed on the determination
4998:  of the object, in other words, on cognition thereof, but also on the
4999:  determination of the subject and its volition, I do not intend to
5000:  treat of it in this place.
5001: 
5002: 
5003: But this cognition, which is limited to objects of experience, is not
