5004: for that reason derived entirely, from, experience, but—and this is
5005: asserted of the pure intuitions and the pure conceptions of the
5006: understanding—there are, unquestionably, elements of cognition, which
5007: exist in the mind à priori. Now there are only two ways in which a
5008: necessary harmony of experience with the conceptions of its objects can
5009: be cogitated. Either experience makes these conceptions possible, or
5010: the conceptions make experience possible. The former of these
5011: statements will not hold good with respect to the categories (nor in
5012: regard to pure sensuous intuition), for they are à priori conceptions,
5013: and therefore independent of experience. The assertion of an empirical
5014: origin would attribute to them a sort of generatio aequivoca.
5015: Consequently, nothing remains but to adopt the second alternative
5016: (which presents us with a system, as it were, of the epigenesis of pure
5017: reason), namely, that on the part of the understanding the categories
5018: do contain the grounds of the possibility of all experience. But with
5019: respect to the questions how they make experience possible, and what
5020: are the principles of the possibility thereof with which they present
5021: us in their application to phenomena, the following section on the
5022: transcendental exercise of the faculty of judgement will inform the
5023: reader.
5024: 
5025: It is quite possible that someone may propose a species of
5026: preformation-system of pure reason—a middle way between the two—to wit,
5027: that the categories are neither innate and first à priori principles of
5028: cognition, nor derived from experience, but are merely subjective
5029: aptitudes for thought implanted in us contemporaneously with our
5030: existence, which were so ordered and disposed by our Creator, that
5031: their exercise perfectly harmonizes with the laws of nature which
5032: regulate experience. Now, not to mention that with such an hypothesis
5033: it is impossible to say at what point we must stop in the employment of
5034: predetermined aptitudes, the fact that the categories would in this
5035: case entirely lose that character of necessity which is essentially
5036: involved in the very conception of them, is a conclusive objection to
5037: it. The conception of cause, for example, which expresses the necessity
5038: of an effect under a presupposed condition, would be false, if it
5039: rested only upon such an arbitrary subjective necessity of uniting
5040: certain empirical representations according to such a rule of relation.
5041: I could not then say—“The effect is connected with its cause in the
5042: object (that is, necessarily),” but only, “I am so constituted that I
5043: can think this representation as so connected, and not otherwise.” Now
5044: this is just what the sceptic wants. For in this case, all our
5045: knowledge, depending on the supposed objective validity of our
5046: judgement, is nothing but mere illusion; nor would there be wanting
5047: people who would deny any such subjective necessity in respect to
5048: themselves, though they must feel it. At all events, we could not
5049: dispute with any one on that which merely depends on the manner in
5050: which his subject is organized.
5051: 
5052: Short view of the above Deduction.
5053: 
5054: The foregoing deduction is an exposition of the pure conceptions of the
5055: understanding (and with them of all theoretical à priori cognition), as
5056: principles of the possibility of experience, but of experience as the
5057: determination of all phenomena in space and time in general—of
5058: experience, finally, from the principle of the original synthetical
5059: unity of apperception, as the form of the understanding in relation to
5060: time and space as original forms of sensibility.
5061: 
5062: I consider the division by paragraphs to be necessary only up to this
5063: point, because we had to treat of the elementary conceptions. As we now
5064: proceed to the exposition of the employment of these, I shall not
5065: designate the chapters in this manner any further.
5066: 
5067: BOOK II. Analytic of Principles
5068: 
5069: General logic is constructed upon a plan which coincides exactly with
5070: the division of the higher faculties of cognition. These are,
5071: understanding, judgement, and reason. This science, accordingly, treats
5072: in its analytic of conceptions, judgements, and conclusions in exact
5073: correspondence with the functions and order of those mental powers
5074: which we include generally under the generic denomination of
5075: understanding.
5076: 
5077: As this merely formal logic makes abstraction of all content of
5078: cognition, whether pure or empirical, and occupies itself with the mere
5079: form of thought (discursive cognition), it must contain in its analytic
5080: a canon for reason. For the form of reason has its law, which, without
5081: taking into consideration the particular nature of the cognition about
5082: which it is employed, can be discovered à priori, by the simple
5083: analysis of the action of reason into its momenta.
5084: 
5085: Transcendental logic, limited as it is to a determinate content, that
5086: of pure à priori cognitions, to wit, cannot imitate general logic in
5087: this division. For it is evident that the transcendental employment of
5088: reason is not objectively valid, and therefore does not belong to the
5089: logic of truth (that is, to analytic), but as a logic of illusion,
5090: occupies a particular department in the scholastic system under the
5091: name of transcendental dialectic.
5092: 
5093: Understanding and judgement accordingly possess in transcendental logic
5094: a canon of objectively valid, and therefore true exercise, and are
5095: comprehended in the analytical department of that logic. But reason, in
5096: her endeavours to arrive by à priori means at some true statement
5097: concerning objects and to extend cognition beyond the bounds of
5098: possible experience, is altogether dialectic, and her illusory
5099: assertions cannot be constructed into a canon such as an analytic ought
5100: to contain.
5101: 
5102: Accordingly, the analytic of principles will be merely a canon for the
5103: faculty of judgement, for the instruction of this faculty in its
5104: application to phenomena of the pure conceptions of the understanding,
5105: which contain the necessary condition for the establishment of à priori
5106: laws. On this account, although the subject of the following chapters
5107: is the especial principles of understanding, I shall make use of the
5108: term Doctrine of the faculty of judgement, in order to define more
5109: particularly my present purpose.
5110: 
5111: INTRODUCTION. Of the Transcendental Faculty of judgement in General
5112: 
5113: If understanding in general be defined as the faculty of laws or rules,
5114: the faculty of judgement may be termed the faculty of subsumption under
5115: these rules; that is, of distinguishing whether this or that does or
5116: does not stand under a given rule (casus datae legis). General logic
5117: contains no directions or precepts for the faculty of judgement, nor
5118: can it contain any such. For as it makes abstraction of all content of
5119: cognition, no duty is left for it, except that of exposing analytically
5120: the mere form of cognition in conceptions, judgements, and conclusions,
5121: and of thereby establishing formal rules for all exercise of the
5122: understanding. Now if this logic wished to give some general direction
5123: how we should subsume under these rules, that is, how we should
5124: distinguish whether this or that did or did not stand under them, this
5125: again could not be done otherwise than by means of a rule. But this
5126: rule, precisely because it is a rule, requires for itself direction
5127: from the faculty of judgement. Thus, it is evident that the
5128: understanding is capable of being instructed by rules, but that the
5129: judgement is a peculiar talent, which does not, and cannot require
5130: tuition, but only exercise. This faculty is therefore the specific
5131: quality of the so-called mother wit, the want of which no scholastic
5132: discipline can compensate.
5133: 
5134: For although education may furnish, and, as it were, engraft upon a
5135: limited understanding rules borrowed from other minds, yet the power of
5136: employing these rules correctly must belong to the pupil himself; and
5137: no rule which we can prescribe to him with this purpose is, in the
5138: absence or deficiency of this gift of nature, secure from misuse.[26] A
5139: physician therefore, a judge or a statesman, may have in his head many
5140: admirable pathological, juridical, or political rules, in a degree that
5141: may enable him to be a profound teacher in his particular science, and
5142: yet in the application of these rules he may very possibly
5143: blunder—either because he is wanting in natural judgement (though not
5144: in understanding) and, whilst he can comprehend the general in
5145: abstracto, cannot distinguish whether a particular case in concreto
5146: ought to rank under the former; or because his faculty of judgement has
5147: not been sufficiently exercised by examples and real practice. Indeed,
5148: the grand and only use of examples, is to sharpen the judgement. For as
5149: regards the correctness and precision of the insight of the
5150: understanding, examples are commonly injurious rather than otherwise,
5151: because, as casus in terminis they seldom adequately fulfil the
5152: conditions of the rule. Besides, they often weaken the power of our
5153: understanding to apprehend rules or laws in their universality,
5154: independently of particular circumstances of experience; and hence,
5155: accustom us to employ them more as formulae than as principles.
5156: Examples are thus the go-cart of the judgement, which he who is
5157: naturally deficient in that faculty cannot afford to dispense with.
5158: 
5159:  [26] Deficiency in judgement is properly that which is called
5160:  stupidity; and for such a failing we know no remedy. A dull or
5161:  narrow-minded person, to whom nothing is wanting but a proper degree
5162:  of understanding, may be improved by tuition, even so far as to
5163:  deserve the epithet of learned. But as such persons frequently labour
5164:  under a deficiency in the faculty of judgement, it is not uncommon to
5165:  find men extremely learned who in the application of their science
5166:  betray a lamentable degree this irremediable want.
5167: 
5168: 
5169: But although general logic cannot give directions to the faculty of
5170: judgement, the case is very different as regards transcendental logic,
5171: insomuch that it appears to be the especial duty of the latter to
5172: secure and direct, by means of determinate rules, the faculty of
5173: judgement in the employment of the pure understanding. For, as a
5174: doctrine, that is, as an endeavour to enlarge the sphere of the
5175: understanding in regard to pure à priori cognitions, philosophy is
5176: worse than useless, since from all the attempts hitherto made, little
5177: or no ground has been gained. But, as a critique, in order to guard
5178: against the mistakes of the faculty of judgement (lapsus judicii) in
5179: the employment of the few pure conceptions of the understanding which
5180: we possess, although its use is in this case purely negative,
5181: philosophy is called upon to apply all its acuteness and penetration.
5182: 
5183: But transcendental philosophy has this peculiarity, that besides
5184: indicating the rule, or rather the general condition for rules, which
5185: is given in the pure conception of the understanding, it can, at the
5186: same time, indicate à priori the case to which the rule must be
5187: applied. The cause of the superiority which, in this respect,
5188: transcendental philosophy possesses above all other sciences except
5189: mathematics, lies in this: it treats of conceptions which must relate à
5190: priori to their objects, whose objective validity consequently cannot
5191: be demonstrated à posteriori, and is, at the same time, under the
5192: obligation of presenting in general but sufficient tests, the
5193: conditions under which objects can be given in harmony with those
5194: conceptions; otherwise they would be mere logical forms, without
5195: content, and not pure conceptions of the understanding.
5196: 
5197: Our transcendental doctrine of the faculty of judgement will contain
5198: two chapters. The first will treat of the sensuous condition under
5199: which alone pure conceptions of the understanding can be employed—that
5200: is, of the schematism of the pure understanding. The second will treat
5201: of those synthetical judgements which are derived à priori from pure
5202: conceptions of the understanding under those conditions, and which lie
5203: à priori at the foundation of all other cognitions, that is to say, it
5204: will treat of the principles of the pure understanding.
5205: 
5206: TRANSCENDENTAL DOCTRINE OF THE FACULTY OF JUDGEMENT OR, ANALYTIC OF
5207: PRINCIPLES
5208: 
5209: Chapter I. Of the Schematism at of the Pure Conceptions of the
5210: Understanding
5211: 
5212: In all subsumptions of an object under a conception, the representation
5213: of the object must be homogeneous with the conception; in other words,
5214: the conception must contain that which is represented in the object to
5215: be subsumed under it. For this is the meaning of the expression: “An
5216: object is contained under a conception.” Thus the empirical conception
5217: of a plate is homogeneous with the pure geometrical conception of a
5218: circle, inasmuch as the roundness which is cogitated in the former is
5219: intuited in the latter.
5220: 
5221: But pure conceptions of the understanding, when compared with empirical
5222: intuitions, or even with sensuous intuitions in general, are quite
5223: heterogeneous, and never can be discovered in any intuition. How then
5224: is the subsumption of the latter under the former, and consequently the
5225: application of the categories to phenomena, possible?—For it is
5226: impossible to say, for example: “Causality can be intuited through the
5227: senses and is contained in the phenomenon.”—This natural and important
5228: question forms the real cause of the necessity of a transcendental
5229: doctrine of the faculty of judgement, with the purpose, to wit, of
5230: showing how pure conceptions of the understanding can be applied to
5231: phenomena. In all other sciences, where the conceptions by which the
5232: object is thought in the general are not so different and heterogeneous
5233: from those which represent the object in concreto—as it is given, it is
5234: quite unnecessary to institute any special inquiries concerning the
5235: application of the former to the latter.
5236: 
5237: Now it is quite clear that there must be some third thing, which on the
5238: one side is homogeneous with the category, and with the phenomenon on
5239: the other, and so makes the application of the former to the latter
5240: possible. This mediating representation must be pure (without any
5241: empirical content), and yet must on the one side be intellectual, on
5242: the other sensuous. Such a representation is the transcendental schema.
5243: 
5244: The conception of the understanding contains pure synthetical unity of
5245: the manifold in general. Time, as the formal condition of the manifold
5246: of the internal sense, consequently of the conjunction of all
5247: representations, contains à priori a manifold in the pure intuition.
5248: Now a transcendental determination of time is so far homogeneous with
5249: the category, which constitutes the unity thereof, that it is universal
5250: and rests upon a rule à priori. On the other hand, it is so far
5251: homogeneous with the phenomenon, inasmuch as time is contained in every
5252: empirical representation of the manifold. Thus an application of the
5253: category to phenomena becomes possible, by means of the transcendental
5254: determination of time, which, as the schema of the conceptions of the
5255: understanding, mediates the subsumption of the latter under the former.
5256: 
5257: After what has been proved in our deduction of the categories, no one,
5258: it is to be hoped, can hesitate as to the proper decision of the
5259: question, whether the employment of these pure conceptions of the
5260: understanding ought to be merely empirical or also transcendental; in
5261: other words, whether the categories, as conditions of a possible
5262: experience, relate à priori solely to phenomena, or whether, as
5263: conditions of the possibility of things in general, their application
5264: can be extended to objects as things in themselves. For we have there
5265: seen that conceptions are quite impossible, and utterly without
5266: signification, unless either to them, or at least to the elements of
5267: which they consist, an object be given; and that, consequently, they
5268: cannot possibly apply to objects as things in themselves without regard
5269: to the question whether and how these may be given to us; and, further,
5270: that the only manner in which objects can be given to us is by means of
5271: the modification of our sensibility; and, finally, that pure à priori
5272: conceptions, in addition to the function of the understanding in the
5273: category, must contain à priori formal conditions of sensibility (of
5274: the internal sense, namely), which again contain the general condition
5275: under which alone the category can be applied to any object. This
5276: formal and pure condition of sensibility, to which the conception of
5277: the understanding is restricted in its employment, we shall name the
5278: schema of the conception of the understanding, and the procedure of the
5279: understanding with these schemata we shall call the schematism of the
5280: pure understanding.
5281: 
5282: The schema is, in itself, always a mere product of the imagination.
5283: But, as the synthesis of imagination has for its aim no single
5284: intuition, but merely unity in the determination of sensibility, the
5285: schema is clearly distinguishable from the image. Thus, if I place five
5286: points one after another.... this is an image of the number five. On
5287: the other hand, if I only think a number in general, which may be
5288: either five or a hundred, this thought is rather the representation of
5289: a method of representing in an image a sum (e.g., a thousand) in
5290: conformity with a conception, than the image itself, an image which I
5291: should find some little difficulty in reviewing, and comparing with the
5292: conception. Now this representation of a general procedure of the
5293: imagination to present its image to a conception, I call the schema of
5294: this conception.
5295: 
5296: In truth, it is not images of objects, but schemata, which lie at the
5297: foundation of our pure sensuous conceptions. No image could ever be
5298: adequate to our conception of a triangle in general. For the
5299: generalness of the conception it never could attain to, as this
5300: includes under itself all triangles, whether right-angled,
5301: acute-angled, etc., whilst the image would always be limited to a
5302: single part of this sphere. The schema of the triangle can exist
5303: nowhere else than in thought, and it indicates a rule of the synthesis
5304: of the imagination in regard to pure figures in space. Still less is an
5305: object of experience, or an image of the object, ever to the empirical
5306: conception. On the contrary, the conception always relates immediately
5307: to the schema of the imagination, as a rule for the determination of
5308: our intuition, in conformity with a certain general conception. The
5309: conception of a dog indicates a rule, according to which my imagination
5310: can delineate the figure of a four-footed animal in general, without
5311: being limited to any particular individual form which experience
5312: presents to me, or indeed to any possible image that I can represent to
5313: myself in concreto. This schematism of our understanding in regard to
5314: phenomena and their mere form, is an art, hidden in the depths of the
5315: human soul, whose true modes of action we shall only with difficulty
5316: discover and unveil. Thus much only can we say: “The image is a product
5317: of the empirical faculty of the productive imagination—the schema of
5318: sensuous conceptions (of figures in space, for example) is a product,
5319: and, as it were, a monogram of the pure imagination à priori, whereby
5320: and according to which images first become possible, which, however,
5321: can be connected with the conception only mediately by means of the
5322: schema which they indicate, and are in themselves never fully adequate
5323: to it.” On the other hand, the schema of a pure conception of the
5324: understanding is something that cannot be reduced into any image—it is
5325: nothing else than the pure synthesis expressed by the category,
5326: conformably, to a rule of unity according to conceptions. It is a
5327: transcendental product of the imagination, a product which concerns the
5328: determination of the internal sense, according to conditions of its
5329: form (time) in respect to all representations, in so far as these
5330: representations must be conjoined à priori in one conception,
5331: conformably to the unity of apperception.
5332: 
5333: Without entering upon a dry and tedious analysis of the essential
5334: requisites of transcendental schemata of the pure conceptions of the
5335: understanding, we shall rather proceed at once to give an explanation
5336: of them according to the order of the categories, and in connection
5337: therewith.
5338: 
5339: For the external sense the pure image of all quantities (quantorum) is
5340: space; the pure image of all objects of sense in general, is time. But
5341: the pure schema of quantity (quantitatis) as a conception of the
5342: understanding, is number, a representation which comprehends the
5343: successive addition of one to one (homogeneous quantities). Thus,
5344: number is nothing else than the unity of the synthesis of the manifold
5345: in a homogeneous intuition, by means of my generating time itself in my
5346: apprehension of the intuition.
5347: 
5348: Reality, in the pure conception of the understanding, is that which
5349: corresponds to a sensation in general; that, consequently, the
5350: conception of which indicates a being (in time). Negation is that the
5351: conception of which represents a not-being (in time). The opposition of
5352: these two consists therefore in the difference of one and the same
5353: time, as a time filled or a time empty. Now as time is only the form of
5354: intuition, consequently of objects as phenomena, that which in objects
5355: corresponds to sensation is the transcendental matter of all objects as
5356: things in themselves (Sachheit, reality). Now every sensation has a
5357: degree or quantity by which it can fill time, that is to say, the
5358: internal sense in respect of the representation of an object, more or
5359: less, until it vanishes into nothing (= 0 = negatio). Thus there is a
5360: relation and connection between reality and negation, or rather a
5361: transition from the former to the latter, which makes every reality
5362: representable to us as a quantum; and the schema of a reality as the
5363: quantity of something in so far as it fills time, is exactly this
5364: continuous and uniform generation of the reality in time, as we descend
5365: in time from the sensation which has a certain degree, down to the
5366: vanishing thereof, or gradually ascend from negation to the quantity
5367: thereof.
5368: 
5369: The schema of substance is the permanence of the real in time; that is,
5370: the representation of it as a substratum of the empirical determination
5371: of time; a substratum which therefore remains, whilst all else changes.
5372: (Time passes not, but in it passes the existence of the changeable. To
5373: time, therefore, which is itself unchangeable and permanent,
5374: corresponds that which in the phenomenon is unchangeable in existence,
5375: that is, substance, and it is only by it that the succession and
5376: coexistence of phenomena can be determined in regard to time.)
5377: 
5378: The schema of cause and of the causality of a thing is the real which,
5379: when posited, is always followed by something else. It consists,
5380: therefore, in the succession of the manifold, in so far as that
5381: succession is subjected to a rule.
5382: 
5383: The schema of community (reciprocity of action and reaction), or the
5384: reciprocal causality of substances in respect of their accidents, is
5385: the coexistence of the determinations of the one with those of the
5386: other, according to a general rule.
5387: 
5388: The schema of possibility is the accordance of the synthesis of
5389: different representations with the conditions of time in general (as,
5390: for example, opposites cannot exist together at the same time in the
5391: same thing, but only after each other), and is therefore the
5392: determination of the representation of a thing at any time.
5393: 
5394: The schema of reality is existence in a determined time.
5395: 
5396: The schema of necessity is the existence of an object in all time.
5397: 
5398: It is clear, from all this, that the schema of the category of quantity
5399: contains and represents the generation (synthesis) of time itself, in
5400: the successive apprehension of an object; the schema of quality the
5401: synthesis of sensation with the representation of time, or the filling
5402: up of time; the schema of relation the relation of perceptions to each
5403: other in all time (that is, according to a rule of the determination of
5404: time): and finally, the schema of modality and its categories, time
5405: itself, as the correlative of the determination of an object—whether it
5406: does belong to time, and how. The schemata, therefore, are nothing but
5407: à priori determinations of time according to rules, and these, in
5408: regard to all possible objects, following the arrangement of the
5409: categories, relate to the series in time, the content in time, the
5410: order in time, and finally, to the complex or totality in time.
5411: 
5412: Hence it is apparent that the schematism of the understanding, by means
5413: of the transcendental synthesis of the imagination, amounts to nothing
5414: else than the unity of the manifold of intuition in the internal sense,
5415: and thus indirectly to the unity of apperception, as a function
5416: corresponding to the internal sense (a receptivity). Thus, the schemata
5417: of the pure conceptions of the understanding are the true and only
5418: conditions whereby our understanding receives an application to
5419: objects, and consequently significance. Finally, therefore, the
5420: categories are only capable of empirical use, inasmuch as they serve
5421: merely to subject phenomena to the universal rules of synthesis, by
5422: means of an à priori necessary unity (on account of the necessary union
5423: of all consciousness in one original apperception); and so to render
5424: them susceptible of a complete connection in one experience. But within
5425: this whole of possible experience lie all our cognitions, and in the
5426: universal relation to this experience consists transcendental truth,
5427: which antecedes all empirical truth, and renders the latter possible.
5428: 
5429: It is, however, evident at first sight, that although the schemata of
5430: sensibility are the sole agents in realizing the categories, they do,
5431: nevertheless, also restrict them, that is, they limit the categories by
5432: conditions which lie beyond the sphere of understanding—namely, in
5433: sensibility. Hence the schema is properly only the phenomenon, or the
5434: sensuous conception of an object in harmony with the category. (Numerus
5435: est quantitas phaenomenon—sensatio realitas phaenomenon; constans et
5436: perdurabile rerum substantia phaenomenon—aeternitas, necessitas,
5437: phaenomena, etc.) Now, if we remove a restrictive condition, we thereby
5438: amplify, it appears, the formerly limited conception. In this way, the
5439: categories in their pure signification, free from all conditions of
5440: sensibility, ought to be valid of things as they are, and not, as the
5441: schemata represent them, merely as they appear; and consequently the
5442: categories must have a significance far more extended, and wholly
5443: independent of all schemata. In truth, there does always remain to the
5444: pure conceptions of the understanding, after abstracting every sensuous
5445: condition, a value and significance, which is, however, merely logical.
5446: But in this case, no object is given them, and therefore they have no
5447: meaning sufficient to afford us a conception of an object. The notion
5448: of substance, for example, if we leave out the sensuous determination
5449: of permanence, would mean nothing more than a something which can be
5450: cogitated as subject, without the possibility of becoming a predicate
5451: to anything else. Of this representation I can make nothing, inasmuch
5452: as it does not indicate to me what determinations the thing possesses
5453: which must thus be valid as premier subject. Consequently, the
5454: categories, without schemata are merely functions of the understanding
5455: for the production of conceptions, but do not represent any object.
5456: This significance they derive from sensibility, which at the same time
5457: realizes the understanding and restricts it.
5458: 
5459: Chapter II. System of all Principles of the Pure Understanding
5460: 
5461: In the foregoing chapter we have merely considered the general
5462: conditions under which alone the transcendental faculty of judgement is
5463: justified in using the pure conceptions of the understanding for
5464: synthetical judgements. Our duty at present is to exhibit in systematic
5465: connection those judgements which the understanding really produces à
5466: priori. For this purpose, our table of the categories will certainly
5467: afford us the natural and safe guidance. For it is precisely the
5468: categories whose application to possible experience must constitute all
5469: pure à priori cognition of the understanding; and the relation of which
5470: to sensibility will, on that very account, present us with a complete
5471: and systematic catalogue of all the transcendental principles of the
5472: use of the understanding.
5473: 
5474: Principles à priori are so called, not merely because they contain in
5475: themselves the grounds of other judgements, but also because they
5476: themselves are not grounded in higher and more general cognitions. This
5477: peculiarity, however, does not raise them altogether above the need of
5478: a proof. For although there could be found no higher cognition, and
5479: therefore no objective proof, and although such a principle rather
5480: serves as the foundation for all cognition of the object, this by no
5481: means hinders us from drawing a proof from the subjective sources of
5482: the possibility of the cognition of an object. Such a proof is
5483: necessary, moreover, because without it the principle might be liable
5484: to the imputation of being a mere gratuitous assertion.
5485: 
5486: In the second place, we shall limit our investigations to those
5487: principles which relate to the categories. For as to the principles of
5488: transcendental æsthetic, according to which space and time are the
5489: conditions of the possibility of things as phenomena, as also the
5490: restriction of these principles, namely, that they cannot be applied to
5491: objects as things in themselves—these, of course, do not fall within
5492: the scope of our present inquiry. In like manner, the principles of
5493: mathematical science form no part of this system, because they are all
5494: drawn from intuition, and not from the pure conception of the
5495: understanding. The possibility of these principles, however, will
5496: necessarily be considered here, inasmuch as they are synthetical
5497: judgements à priori, not indeed for the purpose of proving their
5498: accuracy and apodeictic certainty, which is unnecessary, but merely to
5499: render conceivable and deduce the possibility of such evident à priori
5500: cognitions.
5501: 
5502: But we shall have also to speak of the principle of analytical
5503: judgements, in opposition to synthetical judgements, which is the
5504: proper subject of our inquiries, because this very opposition will free
5505: the theory of the latter from all ambiguity, and place it clearly
5506: before our eyes in its true nature.
5507: 
5508: 
5509: SYSTEM OF THE PRINCIPLES OF THE PURE UNDERSTANDING
5510: 
5511: Section I. Of the Supreme Principle of all Analytical Judgements
5512: 
5513: Whatever may be the content of our cognition, and in whatever manner
5514: our cognition may be related to its object, the universal, although
5515: only negative conditions of all our judgements is that they do not
5516: contradict themselves; otherwise these judgements are in themselves
5517: (even without respect to the object) nothing. But although there may
5518: exist no contradiction in our judgement, it may nevertheless connect
5519: conceptions in such a manner that they do not correspond to the object,
5520: or without any grounds either à priori or à posteriori for arriving at
5521: such a judgement, and thus, without being self-contradictory, a
5522: judgement may nevertheless be either false or groundless.
5523: 
5524: Now, the proposition: “No subject can have a predicate that contradicts
5525: it,” is called the principle of contradiction, and is a universal but
5526: purely negative criterion of all truth. But it belongs to logic alone,
5527: because it is valid of cognitions, merely as cognitions and without
5528: respect to their content, and declares that the contradiction entirely
5529: nullifies them. We can also, however, make a positive use of this
5530: principle, that is, not merely to banish falsehood and error (in so far
5531: as it rests upon contradiction), but also for the cognition of truth.
5532: For if the judgement is analytical, be it affirmative or negative, its
5533: truth must always be recognizable by means of the principle of
5534: contradiction. For the contrary of that which lies and is cogitated as
5535: conception in the cognition of the object will be always properly
5536: negatived, but the conception itself must always be affirmed of the
5537: object, inasmuch as the contrary thereof would be in contradiction to
5538: the object.
5539: 
5540: We must therefore hold the principle of contradiction to be the
5541: universal and fully sufficient Principle of all analytical cognition.
5542: But as a sufficient criterion of truth, it has no further utility or
5543: authority. For the fact that no cognition can be at variance with this
5544: principle without nullifying itself, constitutes this principle the
5545: sine qua non, but not the determining ground of the truth of our
5546: cognition. As our business at present is properly with the synthetical
5547: part of our knowledge only, we shall always be on our guard not to
5548: transgress this inviolable principle; but at the same time not to
5549: expect from it any direct assistance in the establishment of the truth
5550: of any synthetical proposition.
5551: 
5552: There exists, however, a formula of this celebrated principle—a
5553: principle merely formal and entirely without content—which contains a
5554: synthesis that has been inadvertently and quite unnecessarily mixed up
5555: with it. It is this: “It is impossible for a thing to be and not to be
5556: at the same time.” Not to mention the superfluousness of the addition
5557: of the word impossible to indicate the apodeictic certainty, which
5558: ought to be self-evident from the proposition itself, the proposition
5559: is affected by the condition of time, and as it were says: “A thing =
5560: A, which is something = B, cannot at the same time be non-B.” But both,
5561: B as well as non-B, may quite well exist in succession. For example, a
5562: man who is young cannot at the same time be old; but the same man can
5563: very well be at one time young, and at another not young, that is, old.
5564: Now the principle of contradiction as a merely logical proposition must
5565: not by any means limit its application merely to relations of time, and
5566: consequently a formula like the preceding is quite foreign to its true
5567: purpose. The misunderstanding arises in this way. We first of all
5568: separate a predicate of a thing from the conception of the thing, and
5569: afterwards connect with this predicate its opposite, and hence do not
5570: establish any contradiction with the subject, but only with its
5571: predicate, which has been conjoined with the subject synthetically—a
5572: contradiction, moreover, which obtains only when the first and second
5573: predicate are affirmed in the same time. If I say: “A man who is
5574: ignorant is not learned,” the condition “at the same time” must be
5575: added, for he who is at one time ignorant, may at another be learned.
5576: But if I say: “No ignorant man is a learned man,” the proposition is
5577: analytical, because the characteristic ignorance is now a constituent
5578: part of the conception of the subject; and in this case the negative
5579: proposition is evident immediately from the proposition of
5580: contradiction, without the necessity of adding the condition “the same
5581: time.” This is the reason why I have altered the formula of this
5582: principle—an alteration which shows very clearly the nature of an
5583: analytical proposition.
5584: 
5585: Section II. Of the Supreme Principle of all Synthetical Judgements
5586: 
5587: The explanation of the possibility of synthetical judgements is a task
5588: with which general logic has nothing to do; indeed she needs not even
5589: be acquainted with its name. But in transcendental logic it is the most
5590: important matter to be dealt with—indeed the only one, if the question
5591: is of the possibility of synthetical judgements à priori, the
5592: conditions and extent of their validity. For when this question is
5593: fully decided, it can reach its aim with perfect ease, the
5594: determination, to wit, of the extent and limits of the pure
5595: understanding.
5596: 
5597: In an analytical judgement I do not go beyond the given conception, in
5598: order to arrive at some decision respecting it. If the judgement is
5599: affirmative, I predicate of the conception only that which was already
5600: cogitated in it; if negative, I merely exclude from the conception its
5601: contrary. But in synthetical judgements, I must go beyond the given
5602: conception, in order to cogitate, in relation with it, something quite
5603: different from that which was cogitated in it, a relation which is
5604: consequently never one either of identity or contradiction, and by
5605: means of which the truth or error of the judgement cannot be discerned
5606: merely from the judgement itself.
5607: 
5608: Granted, then, that we must go out beyond a given conception, in order
5609: to compare it synthetically with another, a third thing is necessary,
5610: in which alone the synthesis of two conceptions can originate. Now what
5611: is this tertium quid that is to be the medium of all synthetical
5612: judgements? It is only a complex in which all our representations are
5613: contained, the internal sense to wit, and its form à priori, time.
5614: 
5615: The synthesis of our representations rests upon the imagination; their
5616: synthetical unity (which is requisite to a judgement), upon the unity
5617: of apperception. In this, therefore, is to be sought the possibility of
5618: synthetical judgements, and as all three contain the sources of à
5619: priori representations, the possibility of pure synthetical judgements
5620: also; nay, they are necessary upon these grounds, if we are to possess
5621: a knowledge of objects, which rests solely upon the synthesis of
5622: representations.
5623: 
5624: If a cognition is to have objective reality, that is, to relate to an
5625: object, and possess sense and meaning in respect to it, it is necessary
5626: that the object be given in some way or another. Without this, our
5627: conceptions are empty, and we may indeed have thought by means of them,
5628: but by such thinking we have not, in fact, cognized anything, we have
5629: merely played with representation. To give an object, if this
5630: expression be understood in the sense of “to present” the object, not
5631: mediately but immediately in intuition, means nothing else than to
5632: apply the representation of it to experience, be that experience real
5633: or only possible. Space and time themselves, pure as these conceptions
5634: are from all that is empirical, and certain as it is that they are
5635: represented fully à priori in the mind, would be completely without
5636: objective validity, and without sense and significance, if their
5637: necessary use in the objects of experience were not shown. Nay, the
5638: representation of them is a mere schema, that always relates to the
5639: reproductive imagination, which calls up the objects of experience,
5640: without which they have no meaning. And so it is with all conceptions
5641: without distinction.
5642: 
5643: The possibility of experience is, then, that which gives objective
5644: reality to all our à priori cognitions. Now experience depends upon the
5645: synthetical unity of phenomena, that is, upon a synthesis according to
5646: conceptions of the object of phenomena in general, a synthesis without
5647: which experience never could become knowledge, but would be merely a
5648: rhapsody of perceptions, never fitting together into any connected
5649: text, according to rules of a thoroughly united (possible)
5650: consciousness, and therefore never subjected to the transcendental and
5651: necessary unity of apperception. Experience has therefore for a
5652: foundation, à priori principles of its form, that is to say, general
5653: rules of unity in the synthesis of phenomena, the objective reality of
5654: which rules, as necessary conditions even of the possibility of
5655: experience can which rules, as necessary conditions—even of the
5656: possibility of experience—can always be shown in experience. But apart
5657: from this relation, à priori synthetical propositions are absolutely
5658: impossible, because they have no third term, that is, no pure object,
5659: in which the synthetical unity can exhibit the objective reality of its
5660: conceptions.
5661: 
5662: Although, then, respecting space, or the forms which productive
5663: imagination describes therein, we do cognize much à priori in
5664: synthetical judgements, and are really in no need of experience for
5665: this purpose, such knowledge would nevertheless amount to nothing but a
5666: busy trifling with a mere chimera, were not space to be considered as
5667: the condition of the phenomena which constitute the material of
5668: external experience. Hence those pure synthetical judgements do relate,
5669: though but mediately, to possible experience, or rather to the
5670: possibility of experience, and upon that alone is founded the objective
5671: validity of their synthesis.
5672: 
5673: While then, on the one hand, experience, as empirical synthesis, is the
5674: only possible mode of cognition which gives reality to all other
5675: synthesis; on the other hand, this latter synthesis, as cognition à
5676: priori, possesses truth, that is, accordance with its object, only in
5677: so far as it contains nothing more than what is necessary to the
5678: synthetical unity of experience.
5679: 
5680: Accordingly, the supreme principle of all synthetical judgements is:
5681: “Every object is subject to the necessary conditions of the synthetical
5682: unity of the manifold of intuition in a possible experience.”
5683: 
5684: À priori synthetical judgements are possible when we apply the formal
5685: conditions of the à priori intuition, the synthesis of the imagination,
5686: and the necessary unity of that synthesis in a transcendental
5687: apperception, to a possible cognition of experience, and say: “The
5688: conditions of the possibility of experience in general are at the same
5689: time conditions of the possibility of the objects of experience, and
5690: have, for that reason, objective validity in an à priori synthetical
5691: judgement.”
5692: 
5693: Section III. Systematic Representation of all Synthetical Principles of
5694: the Pure Understanding
5695: 
5696: That principles exist at all is to be ascribed solely to the pure
5697: understanding, which is not only the faculty of rules in regard to that
5698: which happens, but is even the source of principles according to which
5699: everything that can be presented to us as an object is necessarily
5700: subject to rules, because without such rules we never could attain to
5701: cognition of an object. Even the laws of nature, if they are
5702: contemplated as principles of the empirical use of the understanding,
5703: possess also a characteristic of necessity, and we may therefore at
5704: least expect them to be determined upon grounds which are valid à
5705: priori and antecedent to all experience. But all laws of nature,
5706: without distinction, are subject to higher principles of the
5707: understanding, inasmuch as the former are merely applications of the
5708: latter to particular cases of experience. These higher principles alone
5709: therefore give the conception, which contains the necessary condition,
5710: and, as it were, the exponent of a rule; experience, on the other hand,
5711: gives the case which comes under the rule.
5712: 
5713: There is no danger of our mistaking merely empirical principles for
5714: principles of the pure understanding, or conversely; for the character
5715: of necessity, according to conceptions which distinguish the latter,
5716: and the absence of this in every empirical proposition, how extensively
5717: valid soever it may be, is a perfect safeguard against confounding
5718: them. There are, however, pure principles à priori, which nevertheless
5719: I should not ascribe to the pure understanding—for this reason, that
5720: they are not derived from pure conceptions, but (although by the
5721: mediation of the understanding) from pure intuitions. But understanding
5722: is the faculty of conceptions. Such principles mathematical science
5723: possesses, but their application to experience, consequently their
5724: objective validity, nay the possibility of such à priori synthetical
5725: cognitions (the deduction thereof) rests entirely upon the pure
5726: understanding.
5727: 
5728: On this account, I shall not reckon among my principles those of
5729: mathematics; though I shall include those upon the possibility and
5730: objective validity à priori, of principles of the mathematical science,
5731: which, consequently, are to be looked upon as the principle of these,
5732: and which proceed from conceptions to intuition, and not from intuition
5733: to conceptions.
5734: 
5735: In the application of the pure conceptions of the understanding to
5736: possible experience, the employment of their synthesis is either
5737: mathematical or dynamical, for it is directed partly on the intuition
5738: alone, partly on the existence of a phenomenon. But the à priori
5739: conditions of intuition are in relation to a possible experience
5740: absolutely necessary, those of the existence of objects of a possible
5741: empirical intuition are in themselves contingent. Hence the principles
5742: of the mathematical use of the categories will possess a character of
5743: absolute necessity, that is, will be apodeictic; those, on the other
5744: hand, of the dynamical use, the character of an à priori necessity
5745: indeed, but only under the condition of empirical thought in an
5746: experience, therefore only mediately and indirectly. Consequently they
5747: will not possess that immediate evidence which is peculiar to the
5748: former, although their application to experience does not, for that
5749: reason, lose its truth and certitude. But of this point we shall be
5750: better able to judge at the conclusion of this system of principles.
5751: 
5752: The table of the categories is naturally our guide to the table of
5753: principles, because these are nothing else than rules for the objective
5754: employment of the former. Accordingly, all principles of the pure
5755: understanding are:
5756: 
5757:                                 1
5758:                               Axioms
5759:                            of Intuition
5760: 
5761:                2                                    3
5762:           Anticipations                          Analogies
5763:           of Perception                        of Experience
5764:                                 4
5765:                           Postulates of
5766:                         Empirical Thought
5767:                            in general
5768: 
5769: These appellations I have chosen advisedly, in order that we might not
5770: lose sight of the distinctions in respect of the evidence and the
5771: employment of these principles. It will, however, soon appear that—a
5772: fact which concerns both the evidence of these principles, and the à
5773: priori determination of phenomena—according to the categories of
5774: quantity and quality (if we attend merely to the form of these), the
5775: principles of these categories are distinguishable from those of the
5776: two others, in as much as the former are possessed of an intuitive, but
5777: the latter of a merely discursive, though in both instances a complete,
5778: certitude. I shall therefore call the former mathematical, and the
5779: latter dynamical principles.[27] It must be observed, however, that by
5780: these terms I mean just as little in the one case the principles of
5781: mathematics as those of general (physical) dynamics in the other. I
5782: have here in view merely the principles of the pure understanding, in
5783: their application to the internal sense (without distinction of the
5784: representations given therein), by means of which the sciences of
5785: mathematics and dynamics become possible. Accordingly, I have named
5786: these principles rather with reference to their application than their
5787: content; and I shall now proceed to consider them in the order in which
5788: they stand in the table.
5789: 
5790:  [27] All combination (conjunctio) is either composition (compositio)
5791:  or connection (nexus). The former is the synthesis of a manifold, the
5792:  parts of which do not necessarily belong to each other. For example,
5793:  the two triangles into which a square is divided by a diagonal, do not
5794:  necessarily belong to each other, and of this kind is the synthesis of
5795:  the homogeneous in everything that can be mathematically considered.
5796:  This synthesis can be divided into those of aggregation and coalition,
5797:  the former of which is applied to extensive, the latter to intensive
5798:  quantities. The second sort of combination (nexus) is the synthesis of
5799:  a manifold, in so far as its parts do belong necessarily to each
5800:  other; for example, the accident to a substance, or the effect to the
5801:  cause. Consequently it is a synthesis of that which though
5802:  heterogeneous, is represented as connected à priori. This
5803:  combination—not an arbitrary one—I entitle dynamical because it
5804:  concerns the connection of the existence of the manifold. This, again,
5805:  may be divided into the physical synthesis, of the phenomena divided
5806:  among each other, and the metaphysical synthesis, or the connection of
5807:  phenomena à priori in the faculty of cognition.
5808: 
5809: 
5810: 1. AXIOMS OF INTUITION.
5811: 
5812: The principle of these is: All Intuitions are Extensive Quantities.
5813: 
5814: PROOF.
5815: 
5816: All phenomena contain, as regards their form, an intuition in space and
5817: time, which lies à priori at the foundation of all without exception.
5818: Phenomena, therefore, cannot be apprehended, that is, received into
5819: empirical consciousness otherwise than through the synthesis of a
5820: manifold, through which the representations of a determinate space or
5821: time are generated; that is to say, through the composition of the
5822: homogeneous and the consciousness of the synthetical unity of this
5823: manifold (homogeneous). Now the consciousness of a homogeneous manifold
5824: in intuition, in so far as thereby the representation of an object is
5825: rendered possible, is the conception of a quantity (quanti).
5826: Consequently, even the perception of an object as phenomenon is
5827: possible only through the same synthetical unity of the manifold of the
5828: given sensuous intuition, through which the unity of the composition of
5829: the homogeneous manifold in the conception of a quantity is cogitated;
5830: that is to say, all phenomena are quantities, and extensive quantities,
5831: because as intuitions in space or time they must be represented by
5832: means of the same synthesis through which space and time themselves are
5833: determined.
5834: 
5835: An extensive quantity I call that wherein the representation of the
5836: parts renders possible (and therefore necessarily antecedes) the
5837: representation of the whole. I cannot represent to myself any line,
5838: however small, without drawing it in thought, that is, without
5839: generating from a point all its parts one after another, and in this
5840: way alone producing this intuition. Precisely the same is the case with
5841: every, even the smallest, portion of time. I cogitate therein only the
5842: successive progress from one moment to another, and hence, by means of
5843: the different portions of time and the addition of them, a determinate
5844: quantity of time is produced. As the pure intuition in all phenomena is
5845: either time or space, so is every phenomenon in its character of
5846: intuition an extensive quantity, inasmuch as it can only be cognized in
5847: our apprehension by successive synthesis (from part to part). All
5848: phenomena are, accordingly, to be considered as aggregates, that is, as
5849: a collection of previously given parts; which is not the case with
5850: every sort of quantities, but only with those which are represented and
5851: apprehended by us as extensive.
5852: 
5853: On this successive synthesis of the productive imagination, in the
5854: generation of figures, is founded the mathematics of extension, or
5855: geometry, with its axioms, which express the conditions of sensuous
5856: intuition à priori, under which alone the schema of a pure conception
5857: of external intuition can exist; for example, “be tween two points only
5858: one straight line is possible,” “two straight lines cannot enclose a
5859: space,” etc. These are the axioms which properly relate only to
5860: quantities (quanta) as such.
5861: 
5862: But, as regards the quantity of a thing (quantitas), that is to say,
5863: the answer to the question: “How large is this or that object?”
5864: although, in respect to this question, we have various propositions
5865: synthetical and immediately certain (indemonstrabilia); we have, in the
5866: proper sense of the term, no axioms. For example, the propositions: “If
5867: equals be added to equals, the wholes are equal”; “If equals be taken
5868: from equals, the remainders are equal”; are analytical, because I am
5869: immediately conscious of the identity of the production of the one
5870: quantity with the production of the other; whereas axioms must be à
5871: priori synthetical propositions. On the other hand, the self-evident
5872: propositions as to the relation of numbers, are certainly synthetical
5873: but not universal, like those of geometry, and for this reason cannot
5874: be called axioms, but numerical formulae. That 7 + 5 = 12 is not an
5875: analytical proposition. For neither in the representation of seven, nor
5876: of five, nor of the composition of the two numbers, do I cogitate the
5877: number twelve. (Whether I cogitate the number in the addition of both,
5878: is not at present the question; for in the case of an analytical
5879: proposition, the only point is whether I really cogitate the predicate
5880: in the representation of the subject.) But although the proposition is
5881: synthetical, it is nevertheless only a singular proposition. In so far
5882: as regard is here had merely to the synthesis of the homogeneous (the
5883: units), it cannot take place except in one manner, although our use of
5884: these numbers is afterwards general. If I say: “A triangle can be
5885: constructed with three lines, any two of which taken together are
5886: greater than the third,” I exercise merely the pure function of the
5887: productive imagination, which may draw the lines longer or shorter and
5888: construct the angles at its pleasure. On the contrary, the number seven
5889: is possible only in one manner, and so is likewise the number twelve,
5890: which results from the synthesis of seven and five. Such propositions,
5891: then, cannot be termed axioms (for in that case we should have an
5892: infinity of these), but numerical formulae.
5893: 
5894: This transcendental principle of the mathematics of phenomena greatly
5895: enlarges our à priori cognition. For it is by this principle alone that
5896: pure mathematics is rendered applicable in all its precision to objects
5897: of experience, and without it the validity of this application would
5898: not be so self-evident; on the contrary, contradictions and confusions
5899: have often arisen on this very point. Phenomena are not things in
5900: themselves. Empirical intuition is possible only through pure intuition
5901: (of space and time); consequently, what geometry affirms of the latter,
5902: is indisputably valid of the former. All evasions, such as the
5903: statement that objects of sense do not conform to the rules of
5904: construction in space (for example, to the rule of the infinite
5905: divisibility of lines or angles), must fall to the ground. For, if
5906: these objections hold good, we deny to space, and with it to all
5907: mathematics, objective validity, and no longer know wherefore, and how
5908: far, mathematics can be applied to phenomena. The synthesis of spaces
5909: and times as the essential form of all intuition, is that which renders
5910: possible the apprehension of a phenomenon, and therefore every external
5911: experience, consequently all cognition of the objects of experience;
5912: and whatever mathematics in its pure use proves of the former, must
5913: necessarily hold good of the latter. All objections are but the
5914: chicaneries of an ill-instructed reason, which erroneously thinks to
5915: liberate the objects of sense from the formal conditions of our
5916: sensibility, and represents these, although mere phenomena, as things
5917: in themselves, presented as such to our understanding. But in this
5918: case, no à priori synthetical cognition of them could be possible,
5919: consequently not through pure conceptions of space and the science
5920: which determines these conceptions, that is to say, geometry, would
5921: itself be impossible.
5922: 
5923: 2. ANTICIPATIONS OF PERCEPTION.
5924: 
5925: The principle of these is: In all phenomena the Real, that which is an
5926: object of sensation, has Intensive Quantity, that is, has a Degree.
5927: 
5928: PROOF.
5929: 
5930: Perception is empirical consciousness, that is to say, a consciousness
5931: which contains an element of sensation. Phenomena as objects of
5932: perception are not pure, that is, merely formal intuitions, like space
5933: and time, for they cannot be perceived in themselves.[28] They contain,
5934: then, over and above the intuition, the materials for an object
5935: (through which is represented something existing in space or time),
5936: that is to say, they contain the real of sensation, as a representation
5937: merely subjective, which gives us merely the consciousness that the
5938: subject is affected, and which we refer to some external object. Now, a
5939: gradual transition from empirical consciousness to pure consciousness
5940: is possible, inasmuch as the real in this consciousness entirely
5941: vanishes, and there remains a merely formal consciousness (à priori) of
5942: the manifold in time and space; consequently there is possible a
5943: synthesis also of the production of the quantity of a sensation from
5944: its commencement, that is, from the pure intuition = 0 onwards up to a
5945: certain quantity of the sensation. Now as sensation in itself is not an
5946: objective representation, and in it is to be found neither the
5947: intuition of space nor of time, it cannot possess any extensive
5948: quantity, and yet there does belong to it a quantity (and that by means
5949: of its apprehension, in which empirical consciousness can within a
5950: certain time rise from nothing = 0 up to its given amount),
5951: consequently an intensive quantity. And thus we must ascribe intensive
5952: quantity, that is, a degree of influence on sense to all objects of
5953: perception, in so far as this perception contains sensation.
5954: 
5955:  [28] They can be perceived only as phenomena, and some part of them
5956:  must always belong to the non-ego; whereas pure intuitions are
5957:  entirely the products of the mind itself, and as such are cognized _in
5958:  themselves.—Tr_
5959: 
5960: 
5961: All cognition, by means of which I am enabled to cognize and determine
5962: à priori what belongs to empirical cognition, may be called an
5963: anticipation; and without doubt this is the sense in which Epicurus
5964: employed his expression prholepsis. But as there is in phenomena
5965: something which is never cognized à priori, which on this account
5966: constitutes the proper difference between pure and empirical cognition,
5967: that is to say, sensation (as the matter of perception), it follows,
5968: that sensation is just that element in cognition which cannot be at all
5969: anticipated. On the other hand, we might very well term the pure
5970: determinations in space and time, as well in regard to figure as to
5971: quantity, anticipations of phenomena, because they represent à priori
5972: that which may always be given à posteriori in experience. But suppose
5973: that in every sensation, as sensation in general, without any
5974: particular sensation being thought of, there existed something which
5975: could be cognized à priori, this would deserve to be called
5976: anticipation in a special sense—special, because it may seem surprising
5977: to forestall experience, in that which concerns the matter of
5978: experience, and which we can only derive from itself. Yet such really
5979: is the case here.
5980: 
5981: Apprehension[29], by means of sensation alone, fills only one moment,
5982: that is, if I do not take into consideration a succession of many
5983: sensations. As that in the phenomenon, the apprehension of which is not
5984: a successive synthesis advancing from parts to an entire
5985: representation, sensation has therefore no extensive quantity; the want
5986: of sensation in a moment of time would represent it as empty,
5987: consequently = 0. That which in the empirical intuition corresponds to
5988: sensation is reality (realitas phaenomenon); that which corresponds to
5989: the absence of it, negation = 0. Now every sensation is capable of a
5990: diminution, so that it can decrease, and thus gradually disappear.
5991: Therefore, between reality in a phenomenon and negation, there exists a
5992: continuous concatenation of many possible intermediate sensations, the
5993: difference of which from each other is always smaller than that between
5994: the given sensation and zero, or complete negation. That is to say, the
5995: real in a phenomenon has always a quantity, which however is not
5996: discoverable in apprehension, inasmuch as apprehension take place by
5997: means of mere sensation in one instant, and not by the successive
5998: synthesis of many sensations, and therefore does not progress from
5999: parts to the whole. Consequently, it has a quantity, but not an
6000: extensive quantity.
6001: 
6002:  [29] Apprehension is the Kantian word for preception, in the largest
6003:  sense in which we employ that term. It is the genus which includes
6004:  under i, as species, perception proper and sensation proper—Tr
6005: 
6006: 
6007: Now that quantity which is apprehended only as unity, and in which
6008: plurality can be represented only by approximation to negation = O, I
6009: term intensive quantity. Consequently, reality in a phenomenon has
6010: intensive quantity, that is, a degree. If we consider this reality as
6011: cause (be it of sensation or of another reality in the phenomenon, for
6012: example, a change), we call the degree of reality in its character of
6013: cause a momentum, for example, the momentum of weight; and for this
6014: reason, that the degree only indicates that quantity the apprehension
6015: of which is not successive, but instantaneous. This, however, I touch
6016: upon only in passing, for with causality I have at present nothing to
6017: do.
6018: 
6019: Accordingly, every sensation, consequently every reality in phenomena,
6020: however small it may be, has a degree, that is, an intensive quantity,
6021: which may always be lessened, and between reality and negation there
6022: exists a continuous connection of possible realities, and possible
6023: smaller perceptions. Every colour—for example, red—has a degree, which,
6024: be it ever so small, is never the smallest, and so is it always with
6025: heat, the momentum of weight, etc.
6026: 
6027: This property of quantities, according to which no part of them is the
6028: smallest possible (no part simple), is called their continuity. Space
6029: and time are quanta continua, because no part of them can be given,
6030: without enclosing it within boundaries (points and moments),
6031: consequently, this given part is itself a space or a time. Space,
6032: therefore, consists only of spaces, and time of times. Points and
6033: moments are only boundaries, that is, the mere places or positions of
6034: their limitation. But places always presuppose intuitions which are to
6035: limit or determine them; and we cannot conceive either space or time
6036: composed of constituent parts which are given before space or time.
6037: Such quantities may also be called flowing, because synthesis (of the
6038: productive imagination) in the production of these quantities is a
6039: progression in time, the continuity of which we are accustomed to
6040: indicate by the expression flowing.
6041: 
6042: All phenomena, then, are continuous quantities, in respect both to
6043: intuition and mere perception (sensation, and with it reality). In the
6044: former case they are extensive quantities; in the latter, intensive.
6045: When the synthesis of the manifold of a phenomenon is interrupted,
6046: there results merely an aggregate of several phenomena, and not
6047: properly a phenomenon as a quantity, which is not produced by the mere
6048: continuation of the productive synthesis of a certain kind, but by the
6049: repetition of a synthesis always ceasing. For example, if I call
6050: thirteen dollars a sum or quantity of money, I employ the term quite
6051: correctly, inasmuch as I understand by thirteen dollars the value of a
6052: mark in standard silver, which is, to be sure, a continuous quantity,
6053: in which no part is the smallest, but every part might constitute a
6054: piece of money, which would contain material for still smaller pieces.
6055: If, however, by the words thirteen dollars I understand so many coins
6056: (be their value in silver what it may), it would be quite erroneous to
6057: use the expression a quantity of dollars; on the contrary, I must call
6058: them aggregate, that is, a number of coins. And as in every number we
6059: must have unity as the foundation, so a phenomenon taken as unity is a
6060: quantity, and as such always a continuous quantity (quantum continuum).
6061: 
6062: Now, seeing all phenomena, whether considered as extensive or
6063: intensive, are continuous quantities, the proposition: “All change
6064: (transition of a thing from one state into another) is continuous,”
6065: might be proved here easily, and with mathematical evidence, were it
6066: not that the causality of a change lies, entirely beyond the bounds of
6067: a transcendental philosophy, and presupposes empirical principles. For
6068: of the possibility of a cause which changes the condition of things,
6069: that is, which determines them to the contrary to a certain given
6070: state, the understanding gives us à priori no knowledge; not merely
6071: because it has no insight into the possibility of it (for such insight
6072: is absent in several à priori cognitions), but because the notion of
6073: change concerns only certain determinations of phenomena, which
6074: experience alone can acquaint us with, while their cause lies in the
6075: unchangeable. But seeing that we have nothing which we could here
6076: employ but the pure fundamental conceptions of all possible experience,
6077: among which of course nothing empirical can be admitted, we dare not,
6078: without injuring the unity of our system, anticipate general physical
6079: science, which is built upon certain fundamental experiences.
6080: 
6081: Nevertheless, we are in no want of proofs of the great influence which
6082: the principle above developed exercises in the anticipation of
6083: perceptions, and even in supplying the want of them, so far as to
6084: shield us against the false conclusions which otherwise we might rashly
6085: draw.
6086: 
6087: If all reality in perception has a degree, between which and negation
6088: there is an endless sequence of ever smaller degrees, and if,
6089: nevertheless, every sense must have a determinate degree of receptivity
6090: for sensations; no perception, and consequently no experience is
6091: possible, which can prove, either immediately or mediately, an entire
6092: absence of all reality in a phenomenon; in other words, it is
6093: impossible ever to draw from experience a proof of the existence of
6094: empty space or of empty time. For in the first place, an entire absence
6095: of reality in a sensuous intuition cannot of course be an object of
6096: perception; secondly, such absence cannot be deduced from the
6097: contemplation of any single phenomenon, and the difference of the
6098: degrees in its reality; nor ought it ever to be admitted in explanation
6099: of any phenomenon. For if even the complete intuition of a determinate
6100: space or time is thoroughly real, that is, if no part thereof is empty,
6101: yet because every reality has its degree, which, with the extensive
6102: quantity of the phenomenon unchanged, can diminish through endless
6103: gradations down to nothing (the void), there must be infinitely
6104: graduated degrees, with which space or time is filled, and the
6105: intensive quantity in different phenomena may be smaller or greater,
6106: although the extensive quantity of the intuition remains equal and
6107: unaltered.
6108: 
6109: We shall give an example of this. Almost all natural philosophers,
6110: remarking a great difference in the quantity of the matter of different
6111: kinds in bodies with the same volume (partly on account of the momentum
6112: of gravity or weight, partly on account of the momentum of resistance
6113: to other bodies in motion), conclude unanimously that this volume
6114: (extensive quantity of the phenomenon) must be void in all bodies,
6115: although in different proportion. But who would suspect that these for
6116: the most part mathematical and mechanical inquirers into nature should
6117: ground this conclusion solely on a metaphysical hypothesis—a sort of
6118: hypothesis which they profess to disparage and avoid? Yet this they do,
6119: in assuming that the real in space (I must not here call it
6120: impenetrability or weight, because these are empirical conceptions) is
6121: always identical, and can only be distinguished according to its
6122: extensive quantity, that is, multiplicity. Now to this presupposition,
6123: for which they can have no ground in experience, and which consequently
6124: is merely metaphysical, I oppose a transcendental demonstration, which
6125: it is true will not explain the difference in the filling up of spaces,
6126: but which nevertheless completely does away with the supposed necessity
6127: of the above-mentioned presupposition that we cannot explain the said
6128: difference otherwise than by the hypothesis of empty spaces. This
6129: demonstration, moreover, has the merit of setting the understanding at
6130: liberty to conceive this distinction in a different manner, if the
6131: explanation of the fact requires any such hypothesis. For we perceive
6132: that although two equal spaces may be completely filled by matters
6133: altogether different, so that in neither of them is there left a single
6134: point wherein matter is not present, nevertheless, every reality has
6135: its degree (of resistance or of weight), which, without diminution of
6136: the extensive quantity, can become less and less ad infinitum, before
6137: it passes into nothingness and disappears. Thus an expansion which
6138: fills a space—for example, caloric, or any other reality in the
6139: phenomenal world—can decrease in its degrees to infinity, yet without
6140: leaving the smallest part of the space empty; on the contrary, filling
6141: it with those lesser degrees as completely as another phenomenon could
6142: with greater. My intention here is by no means to maintain that this is
6143: really the case with the difference of matters, in regard to their
6144: specific gravity; I wish only to prove, from a principle of the pure
6145: understanding, that the nature of our perceptions makes such a mode of
6146: explanation possible, and that it is erroneous to regard the real in a
6147: phenomenon as equal quoad its degree, and different only quoad its
6148: aggregation and extensive quantity, and this, too, on the pretended
6149: authority of an à priori principle of the understanding.
6150: 
6151: Nevertheless, this principle of the anticipation of perception must
6152: somewhat startle an inquirer whom initiation into transcendental
6153: philosophy has rendered cautious. We must naturally entertain some
6154: doubt whether or not the understanding can enounce any such synthetical
6155: proposition as that respecting the degree of all reality in phenomena,
6156: and consequently the possibility of the internal difference of
6157: sensation itself—abstraction being made of its empirical quality. Thus
6158: it is a question not unworthy of solution: “How the understanding can
6159: pronounce synthetically and à priori respecting phenomena, and thus
6160: anticipate these, even in that which is peculiarly and merely
6161: empirical, that, namely, which concerns sensation itself?”
6162: 
6163: The quality of sensation is in all cases merely empirical, and cannot
6164: be represented à priori (for example, colours, taste, etc.). But the
6165: real—that which corresponds to sensation—in opposition to negation = 0,
6166: only represents something the conception of which in itself contains a
6167: being (ein seyn), and signifies nothing but the synthesis in an
6168: empirical consciousness. That is to say, the empirical consciousness in
6169: the internal sense can be raised from 0 to every higher degree, so that
6170: the very same extensive quantity of intuition, an illuminated surface,
6171: for example, excites as great a sensation as an aggregate of many other
6172: surfaces less illuminated. We can therefore make complete abstraction
6173: of the extensive quantity of a phenomenon, and represent to ourselves
6174: in the mere sensation in a certain momentum, a synthesis of homogeneous
6175: ascension from 0 up to the given empirical consciousness, All
6176: sensations therefore as such are given only à posteriori, but this
6177: property thereof, namely, that they have a degree, can be known à
6178: priori. It is worthy of remark, that in respect to quantities in
6179: general, we can cognize à priori only a single quality, namely,
6180: continuity; but in respect to all quality (the real in phenomena), we
6181: cannot cognize à priori anything more than the intensive quantity
6182: thereof, namely, that they have a degree. All else is left to
6183: experience.
6184: 
6185: 3. ANALOGIES OF EXPERIENCE.
6186: 
6187: The principle of these is: Experience is possible only through the
6188: representation of a necessary connection of Perceptions.
6189: 
6190: PROOF.
6191: 
6192: Experience is an empirical cognition; that is to say, a cognition which
6193: determines an object by means of perceptions. It is therefore a
6194: synthesis of perceptions, a synthesis which is not itself contained in
6195: perception, but which contains the synthetical unity of the manifold of
6196: perception in a consciousness; and this unity constitutes the essential
6197: of our cognition of objects of the senses, that is, of experience (not
6198: merely of intuition or sensation). Now in experience our perceptions
6199: come together contingently, so that no character of necessity in their
