6200: connection appears, or can appear from the perceptions themselves,
6201: because apprehension is only a placing together of the manifold of
6202: empirical intuition, and no representation of a necessity in the
6203: connected existence of the phenomena which apprehension brings
6204: together, is to be discovered therein. But as experience is a cognition
6205: of objects by means of perceptions, it follows that the relation of the
6206: existence of the existence of the manifold must be represented in
6207: experience not as it is put together in time, but as it is objectively
6208: in time. And as time itself cannot be perceived, the determination of
6209: the existence of objects in time can only take place by means of their
6210: connection in time in general, consequently only by means of à priori
6211: connecting conceptions. Now as these conceptions always possess the
6212: character of necessity, experience is possible only by means of a
6213: representation of the necessary connection of perception.
6214: 
6215: The three modi of time are permanence, succession, and coexistence.
6216: Accordingly, there are three rules of all relations of time in
6217: phenomena, according to which the existence of every phenomenon is
6218: determined in respect of the unity of all time, and these antecede all
6219: experience and render it possible.
6220: 
6221: The general principle of all three analogies rests on the necessary
6222: unity of apperception in relation to all possible empirical
6223: consciousness (perception) at every time, consequently, as this unity
6224: lies à priori at the foundation of all mental operations, the principle
6225: rests on the synthetical unity of all phenomena according to their
6226: relation in time. For the original apperception relates to our internal
6227: sense (the complex of all representations), and indeed relates à priori
6228: to its form, that is to say, the relation of the manifold empirical
6229: consciousness in time. Now this manifold must be combined in original
6230: apperception according to relations of time—a necessity imposed by the
6231: à priori transcendental unity of apperception, to which is subjected
6232: all that can belong to my (i.e., my own) cognition, and therefore all
6233: that can become an object for me. This synthetical and à priori
6234: determined unity in relation of perceptions in time is therefore the
6235: rule: “All empirical determinations of time must be subject to rules of
6236: the general determination of time”; and the analogies of experience, of
6237: which we are now about to treat, must be rules of this nature.
6238: 
6239: These principles have this peculiarity, that they do not concern
6240: phenomena, and the synthesis of the empirical intuition thereof, but
6241: merely the existence of phenomena and their relation to each other in
6242: regard to this existence. Now the mode in which we apprehend a thing in
6243: a phenomenon can be determined à priori in such a manner that the rule
6244: of its synthesis can give, that is to say, can produce this à priori
6245: intuition in every empirical example. But the existence of phenomena
6246: cannot be known à priori, and although we could arrive by this path at
6247: a conclusion of the fact of some existence, we could not cognize that
6248: existence determinately, that is to say, we should be incapable of
6249: anticipating in what respect the empirical intuition of it would be
6250: distinguishable from that of others.
6251: 
6252: The two principles above mentioned, which I called mathematical, in
6253: consideration of the fact of their authorizing the application of
6254: mathematic phenomena, relate to these phenomena only in regard to their
6255: possibility, and instruct us how phenomena, as far as regards their
6256: intuition or the real in their perception, can be generated according
6257: to the rules of a mathematical synthesis. Consequently, numerical
6258: quantities, and with them the determination of a phenomenon as a
6259: quantity, can be employed in the one case as well as in the other.
6260: Thus, for example, out of 200,000 illuminations by the moon, I might
6261: compose and give à priori, that is construct, the degree of our
6262: sensations of the sun-light.[30] We may therefore entitle these two
6263: principles constitutive.
6264: 
6265:  [30] Kant’s meaning is: The two principles enunciated under the heads
6266:  of “Axioms of Intuition,” and “Anticipations of Perception,” authorize
6267:  the application to phenomena of determinations of size and number,
6268:  that is of mathematic. For example, I may compute the light of the
6269:  sun, and say that its quantity is a certain number of times greater
6270:  than that of the moon. In the same way, heat is measured by the
6271:  comparison of its different effects on water, &c., and on mercury in a
6272:  thermometer.—Tr
6273: 
6274: 
6275: The case is very different with those principles whose province it is
6276: to subject the existence of phenomena to rules à priori. For as
6277: existence does not admit of being constructed, it is clear that they
6278: must only concern the relations of existence and be merely regulative
6279: principles. In this case, therefore, neither axioms nor anticipations
6280: are to be thought of. Thus, if a perception is given us, in a certain
6281: relation of time to other (although undetermined) perceptions, we
6282: cannot then say à priori, what and how great (in quantity) the other
6283: perception necessarily connected with the former is, but only how it is
6284: connected, quoad its existence, in this given modus of time. Analogies
6285: in philosophy mean something very different from that which they
6286: represent in mathematics. In the latter they are formulae, which
6287: enounce the equality of two relations of quantity, and are always
6288: constitutive, so that if two terms of the proportion are given, the
6289: third is also given, that is, can be constructed by the aid of these
6290: formulae. But in philosophy, analogy is not the equality of two
6291: quantitative but of two qualitative relations. In this case, from three
6292: given terms, I can give à priori and cognize the relation to a fourth
6293: member, but not this fourth term itself, although I certainly possess a
6294: rule to guide me in the search for this fourth term in experience, and
6295: a mark to assist me in discovering it. An analogy of experience is
6296: therefore only a rule according to which unity of experience must arise
6297: out of perceptions in respect to objects (phenomena) not as a
6298: constitutive, but merely as a regulative principle. The same holds good
6299: also of the postulates of empirical thought in general, which relate to
6300: the synthesis of mere intuition (which concerns the form of phenomena),
6301: the synthesis of perception (which concerns the matter of phenomena),
6302: and the synthesis of experience (which concerns the relation of these
6303: perceptions). For they are only regulative principles, and clearly
6304: distinguishable from the mathematical, which are constitutive, not
6305: indeed in regard to the certainty which both possess à priori, but in
6306: the mode of evidence thereof, consequently also in the manner of
6307: demonstration.
6308: 
6309: But what has been observed of all synthetical propositions, and must be
6310: particularly remarked in this place, is this, that these analogies
6311: possess significance and validity, not as principles of the
6312: transcendental, but only as principles of the empirical use of the
6313: understanding, and their truth can therefore be proved only as such,
6314: and that consequently the phenomena must not be subjoined directly
6315: under the categories, but only under their schemata. For if the objects
6316: to which those principles must be applied were things in themselves, it
6317: would be quite impossible to cognize aught concerning them
6318: synthetically à priori. But they are nothing but phenomena; a complete
6319: knowledge of which—a knowledge to which all principles à priori must at
6320: last relate—is the only possible experience. It follows that these
6321: principles can have nothing else for their aim than the conditions of
6322: the empirical cognition in the unity of synthesis of phenomena. But
6323: this synthesis is cogitated only in the schema of the pure conception
6324: of the understanding, of whose unity, as that of a synthesis in
6325: general, the category contains the function unrestricted by any
6326: sensuous condition. These principles will therefore authorize us to
6327: connect phenomena according to an analogy, with the logical and
6328: universal unity of conceptions, and consequently to employ the
6329: categories in the principles themselves; but in the application of them
6330: to experience, we shall use only their schemata, as the key to their
6331: proper application, instead of the categories, or rather the latter as
6332: restricting conditions, under the title of “formulae” of the former.
6333: 
6334: A. FIRST ANALOGY.
6335: 
6336: Principle of the Permanence of Substance.
6337: 
6338: In all changes of phenomena, substance is permanent, and the quantum
6339: thereof in nature is neither increased nor diminished.
6340: 
6341: PROOF.
6342: 
6343: All phenomena exist in time, wherein alone as substratum, that is, as
6344: the permanent form of the internal intuition, coexistence and
6345: succession can be represented. Consequently time, in which all changes
6346: of phenomena must be cogitated, remains and changes not, because it is
6347: that in which succession and coexistence can be represented only as
6348: determinations thereof. Now, time in itself cannot be an object of
6349: perception. It follows that in objects of perception, that is, in
6350: phenomena, there must be found a substratum which represents time in
6351: general, and in which all change or coexistence can be perceived by
6352: means of the relation of phenomena to it. But the substratum of all
6353: reality, that is, of all that pertains to the existence of things, is
6354: substance; all that pertains to existence can be cogitated only as a
6355: determination of substance. Consequently, the permanent, in relation to
6356: which alone can all relations of time in phenomena be determined, is
6357: substance in the world of phenomena, that is, the real in phenomena,
6358: that which, as the substratum of all change, remains ever the same.
6359: Accordingly, as this cannot change in existence, its quantity in nature
6360: can neither be increased nor diminished.
6361: 
6362: Our apprehension of the manifold in a phenomenon is always successive,
6363: is Consequently always changing. By it alone we could, therefore, never
6364: determine whether this manifold, as an object of experience, is
6365: coexistent or successive, unless it had for a foundation something
6366: fixed and permanent, of the existence of which all succession and
6367: coexistence are nothing but so many modes (modi of time). Only in the
6368: permanent, then, are relations of time possible (for simultaneity and
6369: succession are the only relations in time); that is to say, the
6370: permanent is the substratum of our empirical representation of time
6371: itself, in which alone all determination of time is possible.
6372: Permanence is, in fact, just another expression for time, as the
6373: abiding correlate of all existence of phenomena, and of all change, and
6374: of all coexistence. For change does not affect time itself, but only
6375: the phenomena in time (just as coexistence cannot be regarded as a
6376: modus of time itself, seeing that in time no parts are coexistent, but
6377: all successive). If we were to attribute succession to time itself, we
6378: should be obliged to cogitate another time, in which this succession
6379: would be possible. It is only by means of the permanent that existence
6380: in different parts of the successive series of time receives a
6381: quantity, which we entitle duration. For in mere succession, existence
6382: is perpetually vanishing and recommencing, and therefore never has even
6383: the least quantity. Without the permanent, then, no relation in time is
6384: possible. Now, time in itself is not an object of perception;
6385: consequently the permanent in phenomena must be regarded as the
6386: substratum of all determination of time, and consequently also as the
6387: condition of the possibility of all synthetical unity of perceptions,
6388: that is, of experience; and all existence and all change in time can
6389: only be regarded as a mode in the existence of that which abides
6390: unchangeably. Therefore, in all phenomena, the permanent is the object
6391: in itself, that is, the substance (phenomenon); but all that changes or
6392: can change belongs only to the mode of the existence of this substance
6393: or substances, consequently to its determinations.
6394: 
6395: I find that in all ages not only the philosopher, but even the common
6396: understanding, has preposited this permanence as a substratum of all
6397: change in phenomena; indeed, I am compelled to believe that they will
6398: always accept this as an indubitable fact. Only the philosopher
6399: expresses himself in a more precise and definite manner, when he says:
6400: “In all changes in the world, the substance remains, and the accidents
6401: alone are changeable.” But of this decidedly synthetical proposition, I
6402: nowhere meet with even an attempt at proof; nay, it very rarely has the
6403: good fortune to stand, as it deserves to do, at the head of the pure
6404: and entirely à priori laws of nature. In truth, the statement that
6405: substance is permanent, is tautological. For this very permanence is
6406: the ground on which we apply the category of substance to the
6407: phenomenon; and we should have been obliged to prove that in all
6408: phenomena there is something permanent, of the existence of which the
6409: changeable is nothing but a determination. But because a proof of this
6410: nature cannot be dogmatical, that is, cannot be drawn from conceptions,
6411: inasmuch as it concerns a synthetical proposition à priori, and as
6412: philosophers never reflected that such propositions are valid only in
6413: relation to possible experience, and therefore cannot be proved except
6414: by means of a deduction of the possibility of experience, it is no
6415: wonder that while it has served as the foundation of all experience
6416: (for we feel the need of it in empirical cognition), it has never been
6417: supported by proof.
6418: 
6419: A philosopher was asked: “What is the weight of smoke?” He answered:
6420: “Subtract from the weight of the burnt wood the weight of the remaining
6421: ashes, and you will have the weight of the smoke.” Thus he presumed it
6422: to be incontrovertible that even in fire the matter (substance) does
6423: not perish, but that only the form of it undergoes a change. In like
6424: manner was the saying: “From nothing comes nothing,” only another
6425: inference from the principle or permanence, or rather of the
6426: ever-abiding existence of the true subject in phenomena. For if that in
6427: the phenomenon which we call substance is to be the proper substratum
6428: of all determination of time, it follows that all existence in past as
6429: well as in future time, must be determinable by means of it alone.
6430: Hence we are entitled to apply the term substance to a phenomenon, only
6431: because we suppose its existence in all time, a notion which the word
6432: permanence does not fully express, as it seems rather to be referable
6433: to future time. However, the internal necessity perpetually to be, is
6434: inseparably connected with the necessity always to have been, and so
6435: the expression may stand as it is. “Gigni de nihilo nihil; in nihilum
6436: nil posse reverti,”[31] are two propositions which the ancients never
6437: parted, and which people nowadays sometimes mistakenly disjoin, because
6438: they imagine that the propositions apply to objects as things in
6439: themselves, and that the former might be inimical to the dependence
6440: (even in respect of its substance also) of the world upon a supreme
6441: cause. But this apprehension is entirely needless, for the question in
6442: this case is only of phenomena in the sphere of experience, the unity
6443: of which never could be possible, if we admitted the possibility that
6444: new things (in respect of their substance) should arise. For in that
6445: case, we should lose altogether that which alone can represent the
6446: unity of time, to wit, the identity of the substratum, as that through
6447: which alone all change possesses complete and thorough unity. This
6448: permanence is, however, nothing but the manner in which we represent to
6449: ourselves the existence of things in the phenomenal world.
6450: 
6451:  [31] Persius, Satirae, iii.83-84.
6452: 
6453: 
6454: The determinations of a substance, which are only particular modes of
6455: its existence, are called accidents. They are always real, because they
6456: concern the existence of substance (negations are only determinations,
6457: which express the non-existence of something in the substance). Now, if
6458: to this real in the substance we ascribe a particular existence (for
6459: example, to motion as an accident of matter), this existence is called
6460: inherence, in contradistinction to the existence of substance, which we
6461: call subsistence. But hence arise many misconceptions, and it would be
6462: a more accurate and just mode of expression to designate the accident
6463: only as the mode in which the existence of a substance is positively
6464: determined. Meanwhile, by reason of the conditions of the logical
6465: exercise of our understanding, it is impossible to avoid separating, as
6466: it were, that which in the existence of a substance is subject to
6467: change, whilst the substance remains, and regarding it in relation to
6468: that which is properly permanent and radical. On this account, this
6469: category of substance stands under the title of relation, rather
6470: because it is the condition thereof than because it contains in itself
6471: any relation.
6472: 
6473: Now, upon this notion of permanence rests the proper notion of the
6474: conception change. Origin and extinction are not changes of that which
6475: originates or becomes extinct. Change is but a mode of existence, which
6476: follows on another mode of existence of the same object; hence all that
6477: changes is permanent, and only the condition thereof changes. Now since
6478: this mutation affects only determinations, which can have a beginning
6479: or an end, we may say, employing an expression which seems somewhat
6480: paradoxical: “Only the permanent (substance) is subject to change; the
6481: mutable suffers no change, but rather alternation, that is, when
6482: certain determinations cease, others begin.”
6483: 
6484: Change, when, cannot be perceived by us except in substances, and
6485: origin or extinction in an absolute sense, that does not concern merely
6486: a determination of the permanent, cannot be a possible perception, for
6487: it is this very notion of the permanent which renders possible the
6488: representation of a transition from one state into another, and from
6489: non-being to being, which, consequently, can be empirically cognized
6490: only as alternating determinations of that which is permanent. Grant
6491: that a thing absolutely begins to be; we must then have a point of time
6492: in which it was not. But how and by what can we fix and determine this
6493: point of time, unless by that which already exists? For a void
6494: time—preceding—is not an object of perception; but if we connect this
6495: beginning with objects which existed previously, and which continue to
6496: exist till the object in question in question begins to be, then the
6497: latter can only be a determination of the former as the permanent. The
6498: same holds good of the notion of extinction, for this presupposes the
6499: empirical representation of a time, in which a phenomenon no longer
6500: exists.
6501: 
6502: Substances (in the world of phenomena) are the substratum of all
6503: determinations of time. The beginning of some, and the ceasing to be of
6504: other substances, would utterly do away with the only condition of the
6505: empirical unity of time; and in that case phenomena would relate to two
6506: different times, in which, side by side, existence would pass; which is
6507: absurd. For there is only one time in which all different times must be
6508: placed, not as coexistent, but as successive.
6509: 
6510: Accordingly, permanence is a necessary condition under which alone
6511: phenomena, as things or objects, are determinable in a possible
6512: experience. But as regards the empirical criterion of this necessary
6513: permanence, and with it of the substantiality of phenomena, we shall
6514: find sufficient opportunity to speak in the sequel.
6515: 
6516: B. SECOND ANALOGY.
6517: 
6518: Principle of the Succession of Time According to the Law of Causality.
6519: All changes take place according to the law of the connection of Cause
6520: and Effect.
6521: 
6522: PROOF.
6523: 
6524: (That all phenomena in the succession of time are only changes, that
6525: is, a successive being and non-being of the determinations of
6526: substance, which is permanent; consequently that a being of substance
6527: itself which follows on the non-being thereof, or a non-being of
6528: substance which follows on the being thereof, in other words, that the
6529: origin or extinction of substance itself, is impossible—all this has
6530: been fully established in treating of the foregoing principle. This
6531: principle might have been expressed as follows: “All alteration
6532: (succession) of phenomena is merely change”; for the changes of
6533: substance are not origin or extinction, because the conception of
6534: change presupposes the same subject as existing with two opposite
6535: determinations, and consequently as permanent. After this premonition,
6536: we shall proceed to the proof.)
6537: 
6538: I perceive that phenomena succeed one another, that is to say, a state
6539: of things exists at one time, the opposite of which existed in a former
6540: state. In this case, then, I really connect together two perceptions in
6541: time. Now connection is not an operation of mere sense and intuition,
6542: but is the product of a synthetical faculty of imagination, which
6543: determines the internal sense in respect of a relation of time. But
6544: imagination can connect these two states in two ways, so that either
6545: the one or the other may antecede in time; for time in itself cannot be
6546: an object of perception, and what in an object precedes and what
6547: follows cannot be empirically determined in relation to it. I am only
6548: conscious, then, that my imagination places one state before and the
6549: other after; not that the one state antecedes the other in the object.
6550: In other words, the objective relation of the successive phenomena
6551: remains quite undetermined by means of mere perception. Now in order
6552: that this relation may be cognized as determined, the relation between
6553: the two states must be so cogitated that it is thereby determined as
6554: necessary, which of them must be placed before and which after, and not
6555: conversely. But the conception which carries with it a necessity of
6556: synthetical unity, can be none other than a pure conception of the
6557: understanding which does not lie in mere perception; and in this case
6558: it is the conception of “the relation of cause and effect,” the former
6559: of which determines the latter in time, as its necessary consequence,
6560: and not as something which might possibly antecede (or which might in
6561: some cases not be perceived to follow). It follows that it is only
6562: because we subject the sequence of phenomena, and consequently all
6563: change, to the law of causality, that experience itself, that is,
6564: empirical cognition of phenomena, becomes possible; and consequently,
6565: that phenomena themselves, as objects of experience, are possible only
6566: by virtue of this law.
6567: 
6568: Our apprehension of the manifold of phenomena is always successive. The
6569: representations of parts succeed one another. Whether they succeed one
6570: another in the object also, is a second point for reflection, which was
6571: not contained in the former. Now we may certainly give the name of
6572: object to everything, even to every representation, so far as we are
6573: conscious thereof; but what this word may mean in the case of
6574: phenomena, not merely in so far as they (as representations) are
6575: objects, but only in so far as they indicate an object, is a question
6576: requiring deeper consideration. In so far as they, regarded merely as
6577: representations, are at the same time objects of consciousness, they
6578: are not to be distinguished from apprehension, that is, reception into
6579: the synthesis of imagination, and we must therefore say: “The manifold
6580: of phenomena is always produced successively in the mind.” If phenomena
6581: were things in themselves, no man would be able to conjecture from the
6582: succession of our representations how this manifold is connected in the
6583: object; for we have to do only with our representations. How things may
6584: be in themselves, without regard to the representations through which
6585: they affect us, is utterly beyond the sphere of our cognition. Now
6586: although phenomena are not things in themselves, and are nevertheless
6587: the only thing given to us to be cognized, it is my duty to show what
6588: sort of connection in time belongs to the manifold in phenomena
6589: themselves, while the representation of this manifold in apprehension
6590: is always successive. For example, the apprehension of the manifold in
6591: the phenomenon of a house which stands before me, is successive. Now
6592: comes the question whether the manifold of this house is in itself
6593: successive—which no one will be at all willing to grant. But, so soon
6594: as I raise my conception of an object to the transcendental
6595: signification thereof, I find that the house is not a thing in itself,
6596: but only a phenomenon, that is, a representation, the transcendental
6597: object of which remains utterly unknown. What then am I to understand
6598: by the question: “How can the manifold be connected in the phenomenon
6599: itself—not considered as a thing in itself, but merely as a
6600: phenomenon?” Here that which lies in my successive apprehension is
6601: regarded as representation, whilst the phenomenon which is given me,
6602: notwithstanding that it is nothing more than a complex of these
6603: representations, is regarded as the object thereof, with which my
6604: conception, drawn from the representations of apprehension, must
6605: harmonize. It is very soon seen that, as accordance of the cognition
6606: with its object constitutes truth, the question now before us can only
6607: relate to the formal conditions of empirical truth; and that the
6608: phenomenon, in opposition to the representations of apprehension, can
6609: only be distinguished therefrom as the object of them, if it is subject
6610: to a rule which distinguishes it from every other apprehension, and
6611: which renders necessary a mode of connection of the manifold. That in
6612: the phenomenon which contains the condition of this necessary rule of
6613: apprehension, is the object.
6614: 
6615: Let us now proceed to our task. That something happens, that is to say,
6616: that something or some state exists which before was not, cannot be
6617: empirically perceived, unless a phenomenon precedes, which does not
6618: contain in itself this state. For a reality which should follow upon a
6619: void time, in other words, a beginning, which no state of things
6620: precedes, can just as little be apprehended as the void time itself.
6621: Every apprehension of an event is therefore a perception which follows
6622: upon another perception. But as this is the case with all synthesis of
6623: apprehension, as I have shown above in the example of a house, my
6624: apprehension of an event is not yet sufficiently distinguished from
6625: other apprehensions. But I remark also that if in a phenomenon which
6626: contains an occurrence, I call the antecedent state of my perception,
6627: A, and the following state, B, the perception B can only follow A in
6628: apprehension, and the perception A cannot follow B, but only precede
6629: it. For example, I see a ship float down the stream of a river. My
6630: perception of its place lower down follows upon my perception of its
6631: place higher up the course of the river, and it is impossible that, in
6632: the apprehension of this phenomenon, the vessel should be perceived
6633: first below and afterwards higher up the stream. Here, therefore, the
6634: order in the sequence of perceptions in apprehension is determined; and
6635: by this order apprehension is regulated. In the former example, my
6636: perceptions in the apprehension of a house might begin at the roof and
6637: end at the foundation, or vice versa; or I might apprehend the manifold
6638: in this empirical intuition, by going from left to right, and from
6639: right to left. Accordingly, in the series of these perceptions, there
6640: was no determined order, which necessitated my beginning at a certain
6641: point, in order empirically to connect the manifold. But this rule is
6642: always to be met with in the perception of that which happens, and it
6643: makes the order of the successive perceptions in the apprehension of
6644: such a phenomenon necessary.
6645: 
6646: I must, therefore, in the present case, deduce the subjective sequence
6647: of apprehension from the objective sequence of phenomena, for otherwise
6648: the former is quite undetermined, and one phenomenon is not
6649: distinguishable from another. The former alone proves nothing as to the
6650: connection of the manifold in an object, for it is quite arbitrary. The
6651: latter must consist in the order of the manifold in a phenomenon,
6652: according to which order the apprehension of one thing (that which
6653: happens) follows that of another thing (which precedes), in conformity
6654: with a rule. In this way alone can I be authorized to say of the
6655: phenomenon itself, and not merely of my own apprehension, that a
6656: certain order or sequence is to be found therein. That is, in other
6657: words, I cannot arrange my apprehension otherwise than in this order.
6658: 
6659: In conformity with this rule, then, it is necessary that in that which
6660: antecedes an event there be found the condition of a rule, according to
6661: which in this event follows always and necessarily; but I cannot
6662: reverse this and go back from the event, and determine (by
6663: apprehension) that which antecedes it. For no phenomenon goes back from
6664: the succeeding point of time to the preceding point, although it does
6665: certainly relate to a preceding point of time; from a given time, on
6666: the other hand, there is always a necessary progression to the
6667: determined succeeding time. Therefore, because there certainly is
6668: something that follows, I must of necessity connect it with something
6669: else, which antecedes, and upon which it follows, in conformity with a
6670: rule, that is necessarily, so that the event, as conditioned, affords
6671: certain indication of a condition, and this condition determines the
6672: event.
6673: 
6674: Let us suppose that nothing precedes an event, upon which this event
6675: must follow in conformity with a rule. All sequence of perception would
6676: then exist only in apprehension, that is to say, would be merely
6677: subjective, and it could not thereby be objectively determined what
6678: thing ought to precede, and what ought to follow in perception. In such
6679: a case, we should have nothing but a play of representations, which
6680: would possess no application to any object. That is to say, it would
6681: not be possible through perception to distinguish one phenomenon from
6682: another, as regards relations of time; because the succession in the
6683: act of apprehension would always be of the same sort, and therefore
6684: there would be nothing in the phenomenon to determine the succession,
6685: and to render a certain sequence objectively necessary. And, in this
6686: case, I cannot say that two states in a phenomenon follow one upon the
6687: other, but only that one apprehension follows upon another. But this is
6688: merely subjective, and does not determine an object, and consequently
6689: cannot be held to be cognition of an object—not even in the phenomenal
6690: world.
6691: 
6692: Accordingly, when we know in experience that something happens, we
6693: always presuppose that something precedes, whereupon it follows in
6694: conformity with a rule. For otherwise I could not say of the object
6695: that it follows; because the mere succession in my apprehension, if it
6696: be not determined by a rule in relation to something preceding, does
6697: not authorize succession in the object. Only, therefore, in reference
6698: to a rule, according to which phenomena are determined in their
6699: sequence, that is, as they happen, by the preceding state, can I make
6700: my subjective synthesis (of apprehension) objective, and it is only
6701: under this presupposition that even the experience of an event is
6702: possible.
6703: 
6704: No doubt it appears as if this were in thorough contradiction to all
6705: the notions which people have hitherto entertained in regard to the
6706: procedure of the human understanding. According to these opinions, it
6707: is by means of the perception and comparison of similar consequences
6708: following upon certain antecedent phenomena that the understanding is
6709: led to the discovery of a rule, according to which certain events
6710: always follow certain phenomena, and it is only by this process that we
6711: attain to the conception of cause. Upon such a basis, it is clear that
6712: this conception must be merely empirical, and the rule which it
6713: furnishes us with—“Everything that happens must have a cause”—would be
6714: just as contingent as experience itself. The universality and necessity
6715: of the rule or law would be perfectly spurious attributes of it.
6716: Indeed, it could not possess universal validity, inasmuch as it would
6717: not in this case be à priori, but founded on deduction. But the same is
6718: the case with this law as with other pure à priori representations
6719: (e.g., space and time), which we can draw in perfect clearness and
6720: completeness from experience, only because we had already placed them
6721: therein, and by that means, and by that alone, had rendered experience
6722: possible. Indeed, the logical clearness of this representation of a
6723: rule, determining the series of events, is possible only when we have
6724: made use thereof in experience. Nevertheless, the recognition of this
6725: rule, as a condition of the synthetical unity of phenomena in time, was
6726: the ground of experience itself and consequently preceded it à priori.
6727: 
6728: It is now our duty to show by an example that we never, even in
6729: experience, attribute to an object the notion of succession or effect
6730: (of an event—that is, the happening of something that did not exist
6731: before), and distinguish it from the subjective succession of
6732: apprehension, unless when a rule lies at the foundation, which compels
6733: us to observe this order of perception in preference to any other, and
6734: that, indeed, it is this necessity which first renders possible the
6735: representation of a succession in the object.
6736: 
6737: We have representations within us, of which also we can be conscious.
6738: But, however widely extended, however accurate and thoroughgoing this
6739: consciousness may be, these representations are still nothing more than
6740: representations, that is, internal determinations of the mind in this
6741: or that relation of time. Now how happens it that to these
6742: representations we should set an object, or that, in addition to their
6743: subjective reality, as modifications, we should still further attribute
6744: to them a certain unknown objective reality? It is clear that objective
6745: significancy cannot consist in a relation to another representation (of
6746: that which we desire to term object), for in that case the question
6747: again arises: “How does this other representation go out of itself, and
6748: obtain objective significancy over and above the subjective, which is
6749: proper to it, as a determination of a state of mind?” If we try to
6750: discover what sort of new property the relation to an object gives to
6751: our subjective representations, and what new importance they thereby
6752: receive, we shall find that this relation has no other effect than that
6753: of rendering necessary the connection of our representations in a
6754: certain manner, and of subjecting them to a rule; and that conversely,
6755: it is only because a certain order is necessary in the relations of
6756: time of our representations, that objective significancy is ascribed to
6757: them.
6758: 
6759: In the synthesis of phenomena, the manifold of our representations is
6760: always successive. Now hereby is not represented an object, for by
6761: means of this succession, which is common to all apprehension, no one
6762: thing is distinguished from another. But so soon as I perceive or
6763: assume that in this succession there is a relation to a state
6764: antecedent, from which the representation follows in accordance with a
6765: rule, so soon do I represent something as an event, or as a thing that
6766: happens; in other words, I cognize an object to which I must assign a
6767: certain determinate position in time, which cannot be altered, because
6768: of the preceding state in the object. When, therefore, I perceive that
6769: something happens, there is contained in this representation, in the
6770: first place, the fact, that something antecedes; because, it is only in
6771: relation to this that the phenomenon obtains its proper relation of
6772: time, in other words, exists after an antecedent time, in which it did
6773: not exist. But it can receive its determined place in time only by the
6774: presupposition that something existed in the foregoing state, upon
6775: which it follows inevitably and always, that is, in conformity with a
6776: rule. From all this it is evident that, in the first place, I cannot
6777: reverse the order of succession, and make that which happens precede
6778: that upon which it follows; and that, in the second place, if the
6779: antecedent state be posited, a certain determinate event inevitably and
6780: necessarily follows. Hence it follows that there exists a certain order
6781: in our representations, whereby the present gives a sure indication of
6782: some previously existing state, as a correlate, though still
6783: undetermined, of the existing event which is given—a correlate which
6784: itself relates to the event as its consequence, conditions it, and
6785: connects it necessarily with itself in the series of time.
6786: 
6787: If then it be admitted as a necessary law of sensibility, and
6788: consequently a formal condition of all perception, that the preceding
6789: necessarily determines the succeeding time (inasmuch as I cannot arrive
6790: at the succeeding except through the preceding), it must likewise be an
6791: indispensable law of empirical representation of the series of time
6792: that the phenomena of the past determine all phenomena in the
6793: succeeding time, and that the latter, as events, cannot take place,
6794: except in so far as the former determine their existence in time, that
6795: is to say, establish it according to a rule. For it is of course only
6796: in phenomena that we can empirically cognize this continuity in the
6797: connection of times.
6798: 
6799: For all experience and for the possibility of experience, understanding
6800: is indispensable, and the first step which it takes in this sphere is
6801: not to render the representation of objects clear, but to render the
6802: representation of an object in general, possible. It does this by
6803: applying the order of time to phenomena, and their existence. In other
6804: words, it assigns to each phenomenon, as a consequence, a place in
6805: relation to preceding phenomena, determined à priori in time, without
6806: which it could not harmonize with time itself, which determines a place
6807: à priori to all its parts. This determination of place cannot be
6808: derived from the relation of phenomena to absolute time (for it is not
6809: an object of perception); but, on the contrary, phenomena must
6810: reciprocally determine the places in time of one another, and render
6811: these necessary in the order of time. In other words, whatever follows
6812: or happens, must follow in conformity with a universal rule upon that
6813: which was contained in the foregoing state. Hence arises a series of
6814: phenomena, which, by means of the understanding, produces and renders
6815: necessary exactly the same order and continuous connection in the
6816: series of our possible perceptions, as is found à priori in the form of
6817: internal intuition (time), in which all our perceptions must have
6818: place.
6819: 
6820: That something happens, then, is a perception which belongs to a
6821: possible experience, which becomes real only because I look upon the
6822: phenomenon as determined in regard to its place in time, consequently
6823: as an object, which can always be found by means of a rule in the
6824: connected series of my perceptions. But this rule of the determination
6825: of a thing according to succession in time is as follows: “In what
6826: precedes may be found the condition, under which an event always (that
6827: is, necessarily) follows.” From all this it is obvious that the
6828: principle of cause and effect is the principle of possible experience,
6829: that is, of objective cognition of phenomena, in regard to their
6830: relations in the succession of time.
6831: 
6832: The proof of this fundamental proposition rests entirely on the
6833: following momenta of argument. To all empirical cognition belongs the
6834: synthesis of the manifold by the imagination, a synthesis which is
6835: always successive, that is, in which the representations therein always
6836: follow one another. But the order of succession in imagination is not
6837: determined, and the series of successive representations may be taken
6838: retrogressively as well as progressively. But if this synthesis is a
6839: synthesis of apprehension (of the manifold of a given phenomenon), then
6840: the order is determined in the object, or to speak more accurately,
6841: there is therein an order of successive synthesis which determines an
6842: object, and according to which something necessarily precedes, and when
6843: this is posited, something else necessarily follows. If, then, my
6844: perception is to contain the cognition of an event, that is, of
6845: something which really happens, it must be an empirical judgement,
6846: wherein we think that the succession is determined; that is, it
6847: presupposes another phenomenon, upon which this event follows
6848: necessarily, or in conformity with a rule. If, on the contrary, when I
6849: posited the antecedent, the event did not necessarily follow, I should
6850: be obliged to consider it merely as a subjective play of my
6851: imagination, and if in this I represented to myself anything as
6852: objective, I must look upon it as a mere dream. Thus, the relation of
6853: phenomena (as possible perceptions), according to which that which
6854: happens is, as to its existence, necessarily determined in time by
6855: something which antecedes, in conformity with a rule—in other words,
6856: the relation of cause and effect—is the condition of the objective
6857: validity of our empirical judgements in regard to the sequence of
6858: perceptions, consequently of their empirical truth, and therefore of
6859: experience. The principle of the relation of causality in the
6860: succession of phenomena is therefore valid for all objects of
6861: experience, because it is itself the ground of the possibility of
6862: experience.
6863: 
6864: Here, however, a difficulty arises, which must be resolved. The
6865: principle of the connection of causality among phenomena is limited in
6866: our formula to the succession thereof, although in practice we find
6867: that the principle applies also when the phenomena exist together in
6868: the same time, and that cause and effect may be simultaneous. For
6869: example, there is heat in a room, which does not exist in the open air.
6870: I look about for the cause, and find it to be the fire, Now the fire as
6871: the cause is simultaneous with its effect, the heat of the room. In
6872: this case, then, there is no succession as regards time, between cause
6873: and effect, but they are simultaneous; and still the law holds good.
6874: The greater part of operating causes in nature are simultaneous with
6875: their effects, and the succession in time of the latter is produced
6876: only because the cause cannot achieve the total of its effect in one
6877: moment. But at the moment when the effect first arises, it is always
6878: simultaneous with the causality of its cause, because, if the cause had
6879: but a moment before ceased to be, the effect could not have arisen.
6880: Here it must be specially remembered that we must consider the order of
6881: time and not the lapse thereof. The relation remains, even though no
6882: time has elapsed. The time between the causality of the cause and its
6883: immediate effect may entirely vanish, and the cause and effect be thus
6884: simultaneous, but the relation of the one to the other remains always
6885: determinable according to time. If, for example, I consider a leaden
6886: ball, which lies upon a cushion and makes a hollow in it, as a cause,
6887: then it is simultaneous with the effect. But I distinguish the two
6888: through the relation of time of the dynamical connection of both. For
6889: if I lay the ball upon the cushion, then the hollow follows upon the
6890: before smooth surface; but supposing the cushion has, from some cause
6891: or another, a hollow, there does not thereupon follow a leaden ball.
6892: 
6893: Thus, the law of succession of time is in all instances the only
6894: empirical criterion of effect in relation to the causality of the
6895: antecedent cause. The glass is the cause of the rising of the water
6896: above its horizontal surface, although the two phenomena are
6897: contemporaneous. For, as soon as I draw some water with the glass from
6898: a larger vessel, an effect follows thereupon, namely, the change of the
6899: horizontal state which the water had in the large vessel into a
6900: concave, which it assumes in the glass.
6901: 
6902: This conception of causality leads us to the conception of action; that
6903: of action, to the conception of force; and through it, to the
6904: conception of substance. As I do not wish this critical essay, the sole
6905: purpose of which is to treat of the sources of our synthetical
6906: cognition à priori, to be crowded with analyses which merely explain,
6907: but do not enlarge the sphere of our conceptions, I reserve the
6908: detailed explanation of the above conceptions for a future system of
6909: pure reason. Such an analysis, indeed, executed with great
6910: particularity, may already be found in well-known works on this
6911: subject. But I cannot at present refrain from making a few remarks on
6912: the empirical criterion of a substance, in so far as it seems to be
6913: more evident and more easily recognized through the conception of
6914: action than through that of the permanence of a phenomenon.
6915: 
6916: Where action (consequently activity and force) exists, substance also
6917: must exist, and in it alone must be sought the seat of that fruitful
6918: source of phenomena. Very well. But if we are called upon to explain
6919: what we mean by substance, and wish to avoid the vice of reasoning in a
6920: circle, the answer is by no means so easy. How shall we conclude
6921: immediately from the action to the permanence of that which acts, this
6922: being nevertheless an essential and peculiar criterion of substance
6923: (phenomenon)? But after what has been said above, the solution of this
6924: question becomes easy enough, although by the common mode of
6925: procedure—merely analysing our conceptions—it would be quite
6926: impossible. The conception of action indicates the relation of the
6927: subject of causality to the effect. Now because all effect consists in
6928: that which happens, therefore in the changeable, the last subject
6929: thereof is the permanent, as the substratum of all that changes, that
6930: is, substance. For according to the principle of causality, actions are
6931: always the first ground of all change in phenomena and, consequently,
6932: cannot be a property of a subject which itself changes, because if this
6933: were the case, other actions and another subject would be necessary to
6934: determine this change. From all this it results that action alone, as
6935: an empirical criterion, is a sufficient proof of the presence of
6936: substantiality, without any necessity on my part of endeavouring to
6937: discover the permanence of substance by a comparison. Besides, by this
6938: mode of induction we could not attain to the completeness which the
6939: magnitude and strict universality of the conception requires. For that
6940: the primary subject of the causality of all arising and passing away,
6941: all origin and extinction, cannot itself (in the sphere of phenomena)
6942: arise and pass away, is a sound and safe conclusion, a conclusion which
6943: leads us to the conception of empirical necessity and permanence in
6944: existence, and consequently to the conception of a substance as
6945: phenomenon.
6946: 
6947: When something happens, the mere fact of the occurrence, without regard
6948: to that which occurs, is an object requiring investigation. The
6949: transition from the non-being of a state into the existence of it,
6950: supposing that this state contains no quality which previously existed
6951: in the phenomenon, is a fact of itself demanding inquiry. Such an
6952: event, as has been shown in No. A, does not concern substance (for
6953: substance does not thus originate), but its condition or state. It is
6954: therefore only change, and not origin from nothing. If this origin be
6955: regarded as the effect of a foreign cause, it is termed creation, which
6956: cannot be admitted as an event among phenomena, because the very
6957: possibility of it would annihilate the unity of experience. If,
6958: however, I regard all things not as phenomena, but as things in
6959: themselves and objects of understanding alone, they, although
6960: substances, may be considered as dependent, in respect of their
6961: existence, on a foreign cause. But this would require a very different
6962: meaning in the words, a meaning which could not apply to phenomena as
6963: objects of possible experience.
6964: 
6965: How a thing can be changed, how it is possible that upon one state
6966: existing in one point of time, an opposite state should follow in
6967: another point of time—of this we have not the smallest conception à
6968: priori. There is requisite for this the knowledge of real powers, which
6969: can only be given empirically; for example, knowledge of moving forces,
6970: or, in other words, of certain successive phenomena (as movements)
6971: which indicate the presence of such forces. But the form of every
6972: change, the condition under which alone it can take place as the coming
6973: into existence of another state (be the content of the change, that is,
6974: the state which is changed, what it may), and consequently the
6975: succession of the states themselves can very well be considered à
6976: priori, in relation to the law of causality and the conditions of
6977: time.[32]
6978: 
6979:  [32] It must be remarked that I do not speak of the change of certain
6980:  relations, but of the change of the state. Thus, when a body moves in
6981:  a uniform manner, it does not change its state (of motion); but only
6982:  when all motion increases or decreases.
6983: 
6984: 
6985: When a substance passes from one state, a, into another state, b, the
6986: point of time in which the latter exists is different from, and
6987: subsequent to that in which the former existed. In like manner, the
6988: second state, as reality (in the phenomenon), differs from the first,
6989: in which the reality of the second did not exist, as b from zero. That
6990: is to say, if the state, b, differs from the state, a, only in respect
6991: to quantity, the change is a coming into existence of b -a, which in
6992: the former state did not exist, and in relation to which that state is
6993: = O.
6994: 
6995: Now the question arises how a thing passes from one state = a, into
6996: another state = b. Between two moments there is always a certain time,
6997: and between two states existing in these moments there is always a
6998: difference having a certain quantity (for all parts of phenomena are in
6999: their turn quantities). Consequently, every transition from one state
7000: into another is always effected in a time contained between two
7001: moments, of which the first determines the state which leaves, and the
7002: second determines the state into the thing passes. The thing leaves,
7003: and the second determines the state into which the thing Both moments,
7004: then, are limitations of the time of a change, consequently of the
7005: intermediate state between both, and as such they belong to the total
7006: of the change. Now every change has a cause, which evidences its
7007: causality in the whole time during which the charge takes place. The
7008: cause, therefore, does not produce the change all at once or in one
7009: moment, but in a time, so that, as the time gradually increases from
7010: the commencing instant, a, to its completion at b, in like manner also,
7011: the quantity of the reality (b - a) is generated through the lesser
7012: degrees which are contained between the first and last. All change is
7013: therefore possible only through a continuous action of the causality,
7014: which, in so far as it is uniform, we call a momentum. The change does
7015: not consist of these momenta, but is generated or produced by them as
7016: their effect.
7017: 
7018: Such is the law of the continuity of all change, the ground of which is
7019: that neither time itself nor any phenomenon in time consists of parts
7020: which are the smallest possible, but that, notwithstanding, the state
7021: of a thing passes in the process of a change through all these parts,
7022: as elements, to its second state. There is no smallest degree of
7023: reality in a phenomenon, just as there is no smallest degree in the
7024: quantity of time; and so the new state of reality grows up out of the
7025: former state, through all the infinite degrees thereof, the differences
7026: of which one from another, taken all together, are less than the
7027: difference between o and a.
7028: 
7029: It is not our business to inquire here into the utility of this
7030: principle in the investigation of nature. But how such a proposition,
7031: which appears so greatly to extend our knowledge of nature, is possible
7032: completely à priori, is indeed a question which deserves investigation,
7033: although the first view seems to demonstrate the truth and reality of
7034: the principle, and the question, how it is possible, may be considered
7035: superfluous. For there are so many groundless pretensions to the
7036: enlargement of our knowledge by pure reason that we must take it as a
7037: general rule to be mistrustful of all such, and without a thoroughgoing
7038: and radical deduction, to believe nothing of the sort even on the
7039: clearest dogmatical evidence.
7040: 
7041: Every addition to our empirical knowledge, and every advance made in
7042: the exercise of our perception, is nothing more than an extension of
7043: the determination of the internal sense, that is to say, a progression
7044: in time, be objects themselves what they may, phenomena, or pure
7045: intuitions. This progression in time determines everything, and is
7046: itself determined by nothing else. That is to say, the parts of the
7047: progression exist only in time, and by means of the synthesis thereof,
7048: and are not given antecedently to it. For this reason, every transition
7049: in perception to anything which follows upon another in time, is a
7050: determination of time by means of the production of this perception.
7051: And as this determination of time is, always and in all its parts, a
7052: quantity, the perception produced is to be considered as a quantity
7053: which proceeds through all its degrees—no one of which is the smallest
7054: possible—from zero up to its determined degree. From this we perceive
7055: the possibility of cognizing à priori a law of changes—a law, however,
7056: which concerns their form merely. We merely anticipate our own
7057: apprehension, the formal condition of which, inasmuch as it is itself
7058: to be found in the mind antecedently to all given phenomena, must
7059: certainly be capable of being cognized à priori.
7060: 
7061: Thus, as time contains the sensuous condition à priori of the
7062: possibility of a continuous progression of that which exists to that
7063: which follows it, the understanding, by virtue of the unity of
7064: apperception, contains the condition à priori of the possibility of a
7065: continuous determination of the position in time of all phenomena, and
7066: this by means of the series of causes and effects, the former of which
7067: necessitate the sequence of the latter, and thereby render universally
7068: and for all time, and by consequence, objectively, valid the empirical
7069: cognition of the relations of time.
7070: 
7071: C. THIRD ANALOGY.
7072: 
7073: Principle of Coexistence, According to the Law of Reciprocity or
7074: Community.
7075: 
7076: All substances, in so far as they can be perceived in space at the same
7077: time, exist in a state of complete reciprocity of action.
7078: 
7079: PROOF.
7080: 
7081: Things are coexistent, when in empirical intuition the perception of
7082: the one can follow upon the perception of the other, and vice
7083: versa—which cannot occur in the succession of phenomena, as we have
7084: shown in the explanation of the second principle. Thus I can perceive
7085: the moon and then the earth, or conversely, first the earth and then
7086: the moon; and for the reason that my perceptions of these objects can
7087: reciprocally follow each other, I say, they exist contemporaneously.
7088: Now coexistence is the existence of the manifold in the same time. But
7089: time itself is not an object of perception; and therefore we cannot
7090: conclude from the fact that things are placed in the same time, the
7091: other fact, that the perception of these things can follow each other
7092: reciprocally. The synthesis of the imagination in apprehension would
7093: only present to us each of these perceptions as present in the subject
7094: when the other is not present, and contrariwise; but would not show
7095: that the objects are coexistent, that is to say, that, if the one
7096: exists, the other also exists in the same time, and that this is
7097: necessarily so, in order that the perceptions may be capable of
7098: following each other reciprocally. It follows that a conception of the
7099: understanding or category of the reciprocal sequence of the
7100: determinations of phenomena (existing, as they do, apart from each
7101: other, and yet contemporaneously), is requisite to justify us in saying
7102: that the reciprocal succession of perceptions has its foundation in the
7103: object, and to enable us to represent coexistence as objective. But
7104: that relation of substances in which the one contains determinations
7105: the ground of which is in the other substance, is the relation of
7106: influence. And, when this influence is reciprocal, it is the relation
7107: of community or reciprocity. Consequently the coexistence of substances
7108: in space cannot be cognized in experience otherwise than under the
7109: precondition of their reciprocal action. This is therefore the
7110: condition of the possibility of things themselves as objects of
7111: experience.
7112: 
7113: Things are coexistent, in so far as they exist in one and the same
7114: time. But how can we know that they exist in one and the same time?
7115: Only by observing that the order in the synthesis of apprehension of
7116: the manifold is arbitrary and a matter of indifference, that is to say,
7117: that it can proceed from A, through B, C, D, to E, or contrariwise from
7118: E to A. For if they were successive in time (and in the order, let us
7119: suppose, which begins with A), it is quite impossible for the
7120: apprehension in perception to begin with E and go backwards to A,
7121: inasmuch as A belongs to past time and, therefore, cannot be an object
7122: of apprehension.
7123: 
7124: Let us assume that in a number of substances considered as phenomena
7125: each is completely isolated, that is, that no one acts upon another.
7126: Then I say that the coexistence of these cannot be an object of
7127: possible perception and that the existence of one cannot, by any mode
7128: of empirical synthesis, lead us to the existence of another. For we
7129: imagine them in this case to be separated by a completely void space,
7130: and thus perception, which proceeds from the one to the other in time,
7131: would indeed determine their existence by means of a following
7132: perception, but would be quite unable to distinguish whether the one
7133: phenomenon follows objectively upon the first, or is coexistent with
7134: it.
7135: 
7136: Besides the mere fact of existence, then, there must be something by
7137: means of which A determines the position of B in time and, conversely,
7138: B the position of A; because only under this condition can substances
7139: be empirically represented as existing contemporaneously. Now that
7140: alone determines the position of another thing in time which is the
7141: cause of it or of its determinations. Consequently every substance
7142: (inasmuch as it can have succession predicated of it only in respect of
7143: its determinations) must contain the causality of certain
7144: determinations in another substance, and at the same time the effects
7145: of the causality of the other in itself. That is to say, substances
7146: must stand (mediately or immediately) in dynamical community with each
7147: other, if coexistence is to be cognized in any possible experience.
7148: But, in regard to objects of experience, that is absolutely necessary
7149: without which the experience of these objects would itself be
7150: impossible. Consequently it is absolutely necessary that all substances
7151: in the world of phenomena, in so far as they are coexistent, stand in a
7152: relation of complete community of reciprocal action to each other.
7153: 
7154: The word community has in our language[33] two meanings, and contains
7155: the two notions conveyed in the Latin communio and commercium. We
7156: employ it in this place in the latter sense—that of a dynamical
7157: community, without which even the community of place (communio spatii)
7158: could not be empirically cognized. In our experiences it is easy to
7159: observe that it is only the continuous influences in all parts of space
7160: that can conduct our senses from one object to another; that the light
7161: which plays between our eyes and the heavenly bodies produces a
7162: mediating community between them and us, and thereby evidences their
7163: coexistence with us; that we cannot empirically change our position
7164: (perceive this change), unless the existence of matter throughout the
7165: whole of space rendered possible the perception of the positions we
7166: occupy; and that this perception can prove the contemporaneous
7167: existence of these places only through their reciprocal influence, and
7168: thereby also the coexistence of even the most remote objects—although
7169: in this case the proof is only mediate. Without community, every
7170: perception (of a phenomenon in space) is separated from every other and
7171: isolated, and the chain of empirical representations, that is, of
7172: experience, must, with the appearance of a new object, begin entirely
7173: de novo, without the least connection with preceding representations,
7174: and without standing towards these even in the relation of time. My
7175: intention here is by no means to combat the notion of empty space; for
7176: it may exist where our perceptions cannot exist, inasmuch as they
7177: cannot reach thereto, and where, therefore, no empirical perception of
7178: coexistence takes place. But in this case it is not an object of
7179: possible experience.
7180: 
7181:  [33] German
7182: 
7183: 
7184: The following remarks may be useful in the way of explanation. In the
7185: mind, all phenomena, as contents of a possible experience, must exist
7186: in community (communio) of apperception or consciousness, and in so far
7187: as it is requisite that objects be represented as coexistent and
7188: connected, in so far must they reciprocally determine the position in
7189: time of each other and thereby constitute a whole. If this subjective
7190: community is to rest upon an objective basis, or to be applied to
7191: substances as phenomena, the perception of one substance must render
7192: possible the perception of another, and conversely. For otherwise
7193: succession, which is always found in perceptions as apprehensions,
7194: would be predicated of external objects, and their representation of
7195: their coexistence be thus impossible. But this is a reciprocal
7196: influence, that is to say, a real community (commercium) of substances,
7197: without which therefore the empirical relation of coexistence would be
7198: a notion beyond the reach of our minds. By virtue of this commercium,
7199: phenomena, in so far as they are apart from, and nevertheless in
7200: connection with each other, constitute a compositum reale. Such
7201: composita are possible in many different ways. The three dynamical
7202: relations then, from which all others spring, are those of inherence,
7203: consequence, and composition.
7204: 
7205: These, then, are the three analogies of experience. They are nothing
7206: more than principles of the determination of the existence of phenomena
7207: in time, according to the three modi of this determination; to wit, the
7208: relation to time itself as a quantity (the quantity of existence, that
7209: is, duration), the relation in time as a series or succession, finally,
7210: the relation in time as the complex of all existence (simultaneity).
7211: This unity of determination in regard to time is thoroughly dynamical;
7212: that is to say, time is not considered as that in which experience
7213: determines immediately to every existence its position; for this is
7214: impossible, inasmuch as absolute time is not an object of perception,
7215: by means of which phenomena can be connected with each other. On the
7216: contrary, the rule of the understanding, through which alone the
7217: existence of phenomena can receive synthetical unity as regards
7218: relations of time, determines for every phenomenon its position in
7219: time, and consequently à priori, and with validity for all and every
7220: time.
7221: 
7222: By nature, in the empirical sense of the word, we understand the
7223: totality of phenomena connected, in respect of their existence,
7224: according to necessary rules, that is, laws. There are therefore
7225: certain laws (which are moreover à priori) which make nature possible;
7226: and all empirical laws can exist only by means of experience, and by
7227: virtue of those primitive laws through which experience itself becomes
7228: possible. The purpose of the analogies is therefore to represent to us
7229: the unity of nature in the connection of all phenomena under certain
7230: exponents, the only business of which is to express the relation of
7231: time (in so far as it contains all existence in itself) to the unity of
7232: apperception, which can exist in synthesis only according to rules. The
7233: combined expression of all is this: “All phenomena exist in one nature,
7234: and must so exist, inasmuch as without this à priori unity, no unity of
7235: experience, and consequently no determination of objects in experience,
7236: is possible.”
7237: 
7238: As regards the mode of proof which we have employed in treating of
7239: these transcendental laws of nature, and the peculiar character of we
7240: must make one remark, which will at the same time be important as a
7241: guide in every other attempt to demonstrate the truth of intellectual
7242: and likewise synthetical propositions à priori. Had we endeavoured to
7243: prove these analogies dogmatically, that is, from conceptions; that is
7244: to say, had we employed this method in attempting to show that
7245: everything which exists, exists only in that which is permanent—that
7246: every thing or event presupposes the existence of something in a
7247: preceding state, upon which it follows in conformity with a
7248: rule—lastly, that in the manifold, which is coexistent, the states
7249: coexist in connection with each other according to a rule, all our
7250: labour would have been utterly in vain. For more conceptions of things,
7251: analyse them as we may, cannot enable us to conclude from the existence
7252: of one object to the existence of another. What other course was left
7253: for us to pursue? This only, to demonstrate the possibility of
7254: experience as a cognition in which at last all objects must be capable
7255: of being presented to us, if the representation of them is to possess
7256: any objective reality. Now in this third, this mediating term, the
7257: essential form of which consists in the synthetical unity of the
7258: apperception of all phenomena, we found à priori conditions of the
7259: universal and necessary determination as to time of all existences in
7260: the world of phenomena, without which the empirical determination
7261: thereof as to time would itself be impossible, and we also discovered
7262: rules of synthetical unity à priori, by means of which we could
7263: anticipate experience. For want of this method, and from the fancy that
7264: it was possible to discover a dogmatical proof of the synthetical
7265: propositions which are requisite in the empirical employment of the
7266: understanding, has it happened that a proof of the principle of
7267: sufficient reason has been so often attempted, and always in vain. The
7268: other two analogies nobody has ever thought of, although they have
7269: always been silently employed by the mind,[34] because the guiding
7270: thread furnished by the categories was wanting, the guide which alone
7271: can enable us to discover every hiatus, both in the system of
7272: conceptions and of principles.
7273: 
7274:  [34] The unity of the universe, in which all phenomena to be
7275:  connected, is evidently a mere consequence of the admitted principle
7276:  of the community of all substances which are coexistent. For were
7277:  substances isolated, they could not as parts constitute a whole, and
7278:  were their connection (reciprocal action of the manifold) not
7279:  necessary from the very fact of coexistence, we could not conclude
7280:  from the fact of the latter as a merely ideal relation to the former
7281:  as a real one. We have, however, shown in its place that community is
7282:  the proper ground of the possibility of an empirical cognition of
7283:  coexistence, and that we may therefore properly reason from the latter
7284:  to the former as its condition.
7285: 
7286: 
7287: 4. THE POSTULATES OF EMPIRICAL THOUGHT.
7288: 
7289: 1. That which agrees with the formal conditions (intuition and
7290: conception) of experience, is possible.
7291: 
7292: 2. That which coheres with the material conditions of experience
7293: (sensation), is real.
7294: 
7295: 3. That whose coherence with the real is determined according to
7296: universal conditions of experience is (exists) necessary.
7297: 
7298: Explanation.
7299: 
7300: The categories of modality possess this peculiarity, that they do not
7301: in the least determine the object, or enlarge the conception to which
7302: they are annexed as predicates, but only express its relation to the
7303: faculty of cognition. Though my conception of a thing is in itself
7304: complete, I am still entitled to ask whether the object of it is merely
7305: possible, or whether it is also real, or, if the latter, whether it is
7306: also necessary. But hereby the object itself is not more definitely
7307: determined in thought, but the question is only in what relation it,
7308: including all its determinations, stands to the understanding and its
7309: employment in experience, to the empirical faculty of judgement, and to
7310: the reason of its application to experience.
7311: 
7312: For this very reason, too, the categories of modality are nothing more
7313: than explanations of the conceptions of possibility, reality, and
7314: necessity, as employed in experience, and at the same time,
7315: restrictions of all the categories to empirical use alone, not
7316: authorizing the transcendental employment of them. For if they are to
7317: have something more than a merely logical significance, and to be
7318: something more than a mere analytical expression of the form of
7319: thought, and to have a relation to things and their possibility,
7320: reality, or necessity, they must concern possible experience and its
7321: synthetical unity, in which alone objects of cognition can be given.
7322: 
7323: The postulate of the possibility of things requires also, that the
7324: conception of the things agree with the formal conditions of our
7325: experience in general. But this, that is to say, the objective form of
7326: experience, contains all the kinds of synthesis which are requisite for
7327: the cognition of objects. A conception which contains a synthesis must
7328: be regarded as empty and, without reference to an object, if its
7329: synthesis does not belong to experience—either as borrowed from it, and
7330: in this case it is called an empirical conception, or such as is the
7331: ground and à priori condition of experience (its form), and in this
7332: case it is a pure conception, a conception which nevertheless belongs
7333: to experience, inasmuch as its object can be found in this alone. For
7334: where shall we find the criterion or character of the possibility of an
7335: object which is cogitated by means of an à priori synthetical
7336: conception, if not in the synthesis which constitutes the form of
7337: empirical cognition of objects? That in such a conception no
7338: contradiction exists is indeed a necessary logical condition, but very
7339: far from being sufficient to establish the objective reality of the
7340: conception, that is, the possibility of such an object as is thought in
7341: the conception. Thus, in the conception of a figure which is contained
7342: within two straight lines, there is no contradiction, for the
7343: conceptions of two straight lines and of their junction contain no
7344: negation of a figure. The impossibility in such a case does not rest
7345: upon the conception in itself, but upon the construction of it in
7346: space, that is to say, upon the conditions of space and its
7347: determinations. But these have themselves objective reality, that is,
7348: they apply to possible things, because they contain à priori the form
7349: of experience in general.
7350: 
7351: And now we shall proceed to point out the extensive utility and
7352: influence of this postulate of possibility. When I represent to myself
7353: a thing that is permanent, so that everything in it which changes
7354: belongs merely to its state or condition, from such a conception alone
7355: I never can cognize that such a thing is possible. Or, if I represent
7356: to myself something which is so constituted that, when it is posited,
7357: something else follows always and infallibly, my thought contains no
7358: self-contradiction; but whether such a property as causality is to be
7359: found in any possible thing, my thought alone affords no means of
7360: judging. Finally, I can represent to myself different things
7361: (substances) which are so constituted that the state or condition of
7362: one causes a change in the state of the other, and reciprocally; but
7363: whether such a relation is a property of things cannot be perceived
7364: from these conceptions, which contain a merely arbitrary synthesis.
7365: Only from the fact, therefore, that these conceptions express à priori
7366: the relations of perceptions in every experience, do we know that they
7367: possess objective reality, that is, transcendental truth; and that
7368: independent of experience, though not independent of all relation to
7369: form of an experience in general and its synthetical unity, in which
