7370: alone objects can be empirically cognized.
7371: 
7372: But when we fashion to ourselves new conceptions of substances, forces,
7373: action, and reaction, from the material presented to us by perception,
7374: without following the example of experience in their connection, we
7375: create mere chimeras, of the possibility of which we cannot discover
7376: any criterion, because we have not taken experience for our
7377: instructress, though we have borrowed the conceptions from her. Such
7378: fictitious conceptions derive their character of possibility not, like
7379: the categories, à priori, as conceptions on which all experience
7380: depends, but only, à posteriori, as conceptions given by means of
7381: experience itself, and their possibility must either be cognized à
7382: posteriori and empirically, or it cannot be cognized at all. A
7383: substance which is permanently present in space, yet without filling it
7384: (like that tertium quid between matter and the thinking subject which
7385: some have tried to introduce into metaphysics), or a peculiar
7386: fundamental power of the mind of intuiting the future by anticipation
7387: (instead of merely inferring from past and present events), or,
7388: finally, a power of the mind to place itself in community of thought
7389: with other men, however distant they may be—these are conceptions the
7390: possibility of which has no ground to rest upon. For they are not based
7391: upon experience and its known laws; and, without experience, they are a
7392: merely arbitrary conjunction of thoughts, which, though containing no
7393: internal contradiction, has no claim to objective reality, neither,
7394: consequently, to the possibility of such an object as is thought in
7395: these conceptions. As far as concerns reality, it is self-evident that
7396: we cannot cogitate such a possibility in concreto without the aid of
7397: experience; because reality is concerned only with sensation, as the
7398: matter of experience, and not with the form of thought, with which we
7399: can no doubt indulge in shaping fancies.
7400: 
7401: But I pass by everything which derives its possibility from reality in
7402: experience, and I purpose treating here merely of the possibility of
7403: things by means of à priori conceptions. I maintain, then, that the
7404: possibility of things is not derived from such conceptions per se, but
7405: only when considered as formal and objective conditions of an
7406: experience in general.
7407: 
7408: It seems, indeed, as if the possibility of a triangle could be cognized
7409: from the conception of it alone (which is certainly independent of
7410: experience); for we can certainly give to the conception a
7411: corresponding object completely à priori, that is to say, we can
7412: construct it. But as a triangle is only the form of an object, it must
7413: remain a mere product of the imagination, and the possibility of the
7414: existence of an object corresponding to it must remain doubtful, unless
7415: we can discover some other ground, unless we know that the figure can
7416: be cogitated under the conditions upon which all objects of experience
7417: rest. Now, the facts that space is a formal condition à priori of
7418: external experience, that the formative synthesis, by which we
7419: construct a triangle in imagination, is the very same as that we employ
7420: in the apprehension of a phenomenon for the purpose of making an
7421: empirical conception of it, are what alone connect the notion of the
7422: possibility of such a thing, with the conception of it. In the same
7423: manner, the possibility of continuous quantities, indeed of quantities
7424: in general, for the conceptions of them are without exception
7425: synthetical, is never evident from the conceptions in themselves, but
7426: only when they are considered as the formal conditions of the
7427: determination of objects in experience. And where, indeed, should we
7428: look for objects to correspond to our conceptions, if not in
7429: experience, by which alone objects are presented to us? It is, however,
7430: true that without antecedent experience we can cognize and characterize
7431: the possibility of things, relatively to the formal conditions, under
7432: which something is determined in experience as an object, consequently,
7433: completely à priori. But still this is possible only in relation to
7434: experience and within its limits.
7435: 
7436: The postulate concerning the cognition of the reality of things
7437: requires perception, consequently conscious sensation, not indeed
7438: immediately, that is, of the object itself, whose existence is to be
7439: cognized, but still that the object have some connection with a real
7440: perception, in accordance with the analogies of experience, which
7441: exhibit all kinds of real connection in experience.
7442: 
7443: From the mere conception of a thing it is impossible to conclude its
7444: existence. For, let the conception be ever so complete, and containing
7445: a statement of all the determinations of the thing, the existence of it
7446: has nothing to do with all this, but only with thew question whether
7447: such a thing is given, so that the perception of it can in every case
7448: precede the conception. For the fact that the conception of it precedes
7449: the perception, merely indicates the possibility of its existence; it
7450: is perception which presents matter to the conception, that is the sole
7451: criterion of reality. Prior to the perception of the thing, however,
7452: and therefore comparatively à priori, we are able to cognize its
7453: existence, provided it stands in connection with some perceptions
7454: according to the principles of the empirical conjunction of these, that
7455: is, in conformity with the analogies of perception. For, in this case,
7456: the existence of the supposed thing is connected with our perception in
7457: a possible experience, and we are able, with the guidance of these
7458: analogies, to reason in the series of possible perceptions from a thing
7459: which we do really perceive to the thing we do not perceive. Thus, we
7460: cognize the existence of a magnetic matter penetrating all bodies from
7461: the perception of the attraction of the steel-filings by the magnet,
7462: although the constitution of our organs renders an immediate perception
7463: of this matter impossible for us. For, according to the laws of
7464: sensibility and the connected context of our perceptions, we should in
7465: an experience come also on an immediate empirical intuition of this
7466: matter, if our senses were more acute—but this obtuseness has no
7467: influence upon and cannot alter the form of possible experience in
7468: general. Our knowledge of the existence of things reaches as far as our
7469: perceptions, and what may be inferred from them according to empirical
7470: laws, extend. If we do not set out from experience, or do not proceed
7471: according to the laws of the empirical connection of phenomena, our
7472: pretensions to discover the existence of a thing which we do not
7473: immediately perceive are vain. Idealism, however, brings forward
7474: powerful objections to these rules for proving existence mediately.
7475: This is, therefore, the proper place for its refutation.
7476: 
7477: REFUTATION OF IDEALISM.
7478: 
7479: Idealism—I mean material idealism—is the theory which declares the
7480: existence of objects in space without us to be either () doubtful and
7481: indemonstrable, or (2) false and impossible. The first is the
7482: problematical idealism of Descartes, who admits the undoubted certainty
7483: of only one empirical assertion (assertio), to wit, “I am.” The second
7484: is the dogmatical idealism of Berkeley, who maintains that space,
7485: together with all the objects of which it is the inseparable condition,
7486: is a thing which is in itself impossible, and that consequently the
7487: objects in space are mere products of the imagination. The dogmatical
7488: theory of idealism is unavoidable, if we regard space as a property of
7489: things in themselves; for in that case it is, with all to which it
7490: serves as condition, a nonentity. But the foundation for this kind of
7491: idealism we have already destroyed in the transcendental æsthetic.
7492: Problematical idealism, which makes no such assertion, but only alleges
7493: our incapacity to prove the existence of anything besides ourselves by
7494: means of immediate experience, is a theory rational and evidencing a
7495: thorough and philosophical mode of thinking, for it observes the rule
7496: not to form a decisive judgement before sufficient proof be shown. The
7497: desired proof must therefore demonstrate that we have experience of
7498: external things, and not mere fancies. For this purpose, we must prove,
7499: that our internal and, to Descartes, indubitable experience is itself
7500: possible only under the previous assumption of external experience.
7501: 
7502: THEOREM.
7503: 
7504: The simple but empirically determined consciousness of my own existence
7505: proves the existence of external objects in space.
7506: 
7507: PROOF
7508: 
7509: I am conscious of my own existence as determined in time. All
7510: determination in regard to time presupposes the existence of something
7511: permanent in perception. But this permanent something cannot be
7512: something in me, for the very reason that my existence in time is
7513: itself determined by this permanent something. It follows that the
7514: perception of this permanent existence is possible only through a thing
7515: without me and not through the mere representation of a thing without
7516: me. Consequently, the determination of my existence in time is possible
7517: only through the existence of real things external to me. Now,
7518: consciousness in time is necessarily connected with the consciousness
7519: of the possibility of this determination in time. Hence it follows that
7520: consciousness in time is necessarily connected also with the existence
7521: of things without me, inasmuch as the existence of these things is the
7522: condition of determination in time. That is to say, the consciousness
7523: of my own existence is at the same time an immediate consciousness of
7524: the existence of other things without me.
7525: 
7526: Remark I. The reader will observe, that in the foregoing proof the game
7527: which idealism plays is retorted upon itself, and with more justice. It
7528: assumed that the only immediate experience is internal and that from
7529: this we can only infer the existence of external things. But, as always
7530: happens, when we reason from given effects to determined causes,
7531: idealism has reasoned with too much haste and uncertainty, for it is
7532: quite possible that the cause of our representations may lie in
7533: ourselves, and that we ascribe it falsely to external things. But our
7534: proof shows that external experience is properly immediate,[35] that
7535: only by virtue of it—not, indeed, the consciousness of our own
7536: existence, but certainly the determination of our existence in time,
7537: that is, internal experience—is possible. It is true, that the
7538: representation “I am,” which is the expression of the consciousness
7539: which can accompany all my thoughts, is that which immediately includes
7540: the existence of a subject. But in this representation we cannot find
7541: any knowledge of the subject, and therefore also no empirical
7542: knowledge, that is, experience. For experience contains, in addition to
7543: the thought of something existing, intuition, and in this case it must
7544: be internal intuition, that is, time, in relation to which the subject
7545: must be determined. But the existence of external things is absolutely
7546: requisite for this purpose, so that it follows that internal experience
7547: is itself possible only mediately and through external experience.
7548: 
7549:  [35] The immediate consciousness of the existence of external things
7550:  is, in the preceding theorem, not presupposed, but proved, by the
7551:  possibility of this consciousness understood by us or not. The
7552:  question as to the possibility of it would stand thus: “Have we an
7553:  internal sense, but no external sense, and is our belief in external
7554:  perception a mere delusion?” But it is evident that, in order merely
7555:  to fancy to ourselves anything as external, that is, to present it to
7556:  the sense in intuition we must already possess an external sense, and
7557:  must thereby distinguish immediately the mere receptivity of an
7558:  external intuition from the spontaneity which characterizes every act
7559:  of imagination. For merely to imagine also an external sense, would
7560:  annihilate the faculty of intuition itself which is to be determined
7561:  by the imagination.
7562: 
7563: 
7564: Remark II. Now with this view all empirical use of our faculty of
7565: cognition in the determination of time is in perfect accordance. Its
7566: truth is supported by the fact that it is possible to perceive a
7567: determination of time only by means of a change in external relations
7568: (motion) to the permanent in space (for example, we become aware of the
7569: sun’s motion by observing the changes of his relation to the objects of
7570: this earth). But this is not all. We find that we possess nothing
7571: permanent that can correspond and be submitted to the conception of a
7572: substance as intuition, except matter. This idea of permanence is not
7573: itself derived from external experience, but is an à priori necessary
7574: condition of all determination of time, consequently also of the
7575: internal sense in reference to our own existence, and that through the
7576: existence of external things. In the representation “I,” the
7577: consciousness of myself is not an intuition, but a merely intellectual
7578: representation produced by the spontaneous activity of a thinking
7579: subject. It follows, that this “i” has not any predicate of intuition,
7580: which, in its character of permanence, could serve as correlate to the
7581: determination of time in the internal sense—in the same way as
7582: impenetrability is the correlate of matter as an empirical intuition.
7583: 
7584: Remark III. From the fact that the existence of external things is a
7585: necessary condition of the possibility of a determined consciousness of
7586: ourselves, it does not follow that every intuitive representation of
7587: external things involves the existence of these things, for their
7588: representations may very well be the mere products of the imagination
7589: (in dreams as well as in madness); though, indeed, these are themselves
7590: created by the reproduction of previous external perceptions, which, as
7591: has been shown, are possible only through the reality of external
7592: objects. The sole aim of our remarks has, however, been to prove that
7593: internal experience in general is possible only through external
7594: experience in general. Whether this or that supposed experience be
7595: purely imaginary must be discovered from its particular determinations
7596: and by comparing these with the criteria of all real experience.
7597: 
7598: Finally, as regards the third postulate, it applies to material
7599: necessity in existence, and not to merely formal and logical necessity
7600: in the connection of conceptions. Now as we cannot cognize completely à
7601: priori the existence of any object of sense, though we can do so
7602: comparatively à priori, that is, relatively to some other previously
7603: given existence—a cognition, however, which can only be of such an
7604: existence as must be contained in the complex of experience, of which
7605: the previously given perception is a part—the necessity of existence
7606: can never be cognized from conceptions, but always, on the contrary,
7607: from its connection with that which is an object of perception. But the
7608: only existence cognized, under the condition of other given phenomena,
7609: as necessary, is the existence of effects from given causes in
7610: conformity with the laws of causality. It is consequently not the
7611: necessity of the existence of things (as substances), but the necessity
7612: of the state of things that we cognize, and that not immediately, but
7613: by means of the existence of other states given in perception,
7614: according to empirical laws of causality. Hence it follows that the
7615: criterion of necessity is to be found only in the law of possible
7616: experience—that everything which happens is determined à priori in the
7617: phenomenon by its cause. Thus we cognize only the necessity of effects
7618: in nature, the causes of which are given us. Moreover, the criterion of
7619: necessity in existence possesses no application beyond the field of
7620: possible experience, and even in this it is not valid of the existence
7621: of things as substances, because these can never be considered as
7622: empirical effects, or as something that happens and has a beginning.
7623: Necessity, therefore, regards only the relations of phenomena according
7624: to the dynamical law of causality, and the possibility grounded
7625: thereon, of reasoning from some given existence (of a cause) à priori
7626: to another existence (of an effect). “Everything that happens is
7627: hypothetically necessary,” is a principle which subjects the changes
7628: that take place in the world to a law, that is, to a rule of necessary
7629: existence, without which nature herself could not possibly exist. Hence
7630: the proposition, “Nothing happens by blind chance (in mundo non datur
7631: casus),” is an à priori law of nature. The case is the same with the
7632: proposition, “Necessity in nature is not blind,” that is, it is
7633: conditioned, consequently intelligible necessity (non datur fatum).
7634: Both laws subject the play of change to “a nature of things (as
7635: phenomena),” or, which is the same thing, to the unity of the
7636: understanding, and through the understanding alone can changes belong
7637: to an experience, as the synthetical unity of phenomena. Both belong to
7638: the class of dynamical principles. The former is properly a consequence
7639: of the principle of causality—one of the analogies of experience. The
7640: latter belongs to the principles of modality, which to the
7641: determination of causality adds the conception of necessity, which is
7642: itself, however, subject to a rule of the understanding. The principle
7643: of continuity forbids any leap in the series of phenomena regarded as
7644: changes (in mundo non datur saltus); and likewise, in the complex of
7645: all empirical intuitions in space, any break or hiatus between two
7646: phenomena (non datur hiatus)—for we can so express the principle, that
7647: experience can admit nothing which proves the existence of a vacuum, or
7648: which even admits it as a part of an empirical synthesis. For, as
7649: regards a vacuum or void, which we may cogitate as out and beyond the
7650: field of possible experience (the world), such a question cannot come
7651: before the tribunal of mere understanding, which decides only upon
7652: questions that concern the employment of given phenomena for the
7653: construction of empirical cognition. It is rather a problem for ideal
7654: reason, which passes beyond the sphere of a possible experience and
7655: aims at forming a judgement of that which surrounds and circumscribes
7656: it, and the proper place for the consideration of it is the
7657: transcendental dialectic. These four propositions, “In mundo non datur
7658: hiatus, non datur saltus, non datur casus, non datur fatum,” as well as
7659: all principles of transcendental origin, we could very easily exhibit
7660: in their proper order, that is, in conformity with the order of the
7661: categories, and assign to each its proper place. But the already
7662: practised reader will do this for himself, or discover the clue to such
7663: an arrangement. But the combined result of all is simply this, to admit
7664: into the empirical synthesis nothing which might cause a break in or be
7665: foreign to the understanding and the continuous connection of all
7666: phenomena, that is, the unity of the conceptions of the understanding.
7667: For in the understanding alone is the unity of experience, in which all
7668: perceptions must have their assigned place, possible.
7669: 
7670: Whether the field of possibility be greater than that of reality, and
7671: whether the field of the latter be itself greater than that of
7672: necessity, are interesting enough questions, and quite capable of
7673: synthetic solution, questions, however, which come under the
7674: jurisdiction of reason alone. For they are tantamount to asking whether
7675: all things as phenomena do without exception belong to the complex and
7676: connected whole of a single experience, of which every given perception
7677: is a part which therefore cannot be conjoined with any other
7678: phenomena—or, whether my perceptions can belong to more than one
7679: possible experience? The understanding gives to experience, according
7680: to the subjective and formal conditions, of sensibility as well as of
7681: apperception, the rules which alone make this experience possible.
7682: Other forms of intuition besides those of space and time, other forms
7683: of understanding besides the discursive forms of thought, or of
7684: cognition by means of conceptions, we can neither imagine nor make
7685: intelligible to ourselves; and even if we could, they would still not
7686: belong to experience, which is the only mode of cognition by which
7687: objects are presented to us. Whether other perceptions besides those
7688: which belong to the total of our possible experience, and consequently
7689: whether some other sphere of matter exists, the understanding has no
7690: power to decide, its proper occupation being with the synthesis of that
7691: which is given. Moreover, the poverty of the usual arguments which go
7692: to prove the existence of a vast sphere of possibility, of which all
7693: that is real (every object of experience) is but a small part, is very
7694: remarkable. “All real is possible”; from this follows naturally,
7695: according to the logical laws of conversion, the particular
7696: proposition: “Some possible is real.” Now this seems to be equivalent
7697: to: “Much is possible that is not real.” No doubt it does seem as if we
7698: ought to consider the sum of the possible to be greater than that of
7699: the real, from the fact that something must be added to the former to
7700: constitute the latter. But this notion of adding to the possible is
7701: absurd. For that which is not in the sum of the possible, and
7702: consequently requires to be added to it, is manifestly impossible. In
7703: addition to accordance with the formal conditions of experience, the
7704: understanding requires a connection with some perception; but that
7705: which is connected with this perception is real, even although it is
7706: not immediately perceived. But that another series of phenomena, in
7707: complete coherence with that which is given in perception, consequently
7708: more than one all-embracing experience is possible, is an inference
7709: which cannot be concluded from the data given us by experience, and
7710: still less without any data at all. That which is possible only under
7711: conditions which are themselves merely possible, is not possible in any
7712: respect. And yet we can find no more certain ground on which to base
7713: the discussion of the question whether the sphere of possibility is
7714: wider than that of experience.
7715: 
7716: I have merely mentioned these questions, that in treating of the
7717: conception of the understanding, there might be no omission of anything
7718: that, in the common opinion, belongs to them. In reality, however, the
7719: notion of absolute possibility (possibility which is valid in every
7720: respect) is not a mere conception of the understanding, which can be
7721: employed empirically, but belongs to reason alone, which passes the
7722: bounds of all empirical use of the understanding. We have, therefore,
7723: contented ourselves with a merely critical remark, leaving the subject
7724: to be explained in the sequel.
7725: 
7726: Before concluding this fourth section, and at the same time the system
7727: of all principles of the pure understanding, it seems proper to mention
7728: the reasons which induced me to term the principles of modality
7729: postulates. This expression I do not here use in the sense which some
7730: more recent philosophers, contrary to its meaning with mathematicians,
7731: to whom the word properly belongs, attach to it—that of a proposition,
7732: namely, immediately certain, requiring neither deduction nor proof. For
7733: if, in the case of synthetical propositions, however evident they may
7734: be, we accord to them without deduction, and merely on the strength of
7735: their own pretensions, unqualified belief, all critique of the
7736: understanding is entirely lost; and, as there is no want of bold
7737: pretensions, which the common belief (though for the philosopher this
7738: is no credential) does not reject, the understanding lies exposed to
7739: every delusion and conceit, without the power of refusing its assent to
7740: those assertions, which, though illegitimate, demand acceptance as
7741: veritable axioms. When, therefore, to the conception of a thing an à
7742: priori determination is synthetically added, such a proposition must
7743: obtain, if not a proof, at least a deduction of the legitimacy of its
7744: assertion.
7745: 
7746: The principles of modality are, however, not objectively synthetical,
7747: for the predicates of possibility, reality, and necessity do not in the
7748: least augment the conception of that of which they are affirmed,
7749: inasmuch as they contribute nothing to the representation of the
7750: object. But as they are, nevertheless, always synthetical, they are so
7751: merely subjectively. That is to say, they have a reflective power, and
7752: apply to the conception of a thing, of which, in other respects, they
7753: affirm nothing, the faculty of cognition in which the conception
7754: originates and has its seat. So that if the conception merely agree
7755: with the formal conditions of experience, its object is called
7756: possible; if it is in connection with perception, and determined
7757: thereby, the object is real; if it is determined according to
7758: conceptions by means of the connection of perceptions, the object is
7759: called necessary. The principles of modality therefore predicate of a
7760: conception nothing more than the procedure of the faculty of cognition
7761: which generated it. Now a postulate in mathematics is a practical
7762: proposition which contains nothing but the synthesis by which we
7763: present an object to ourselves, and produce the conception of it, for
7764: example—“With a given line, to describe a circle upon a plane, from a
7765: given point”; and such a proposition does not admit of proof, because
7766: the procedure, which it requires, is exactly that by which alone it is
7767: possible to generate the conception of such a figure. With the same
7768: right, accordingly, can we postulate the principles of modality,
7769: because they do not augment[36] the conception of a thing but merely
7770: indicate the manner in which it is connected with the faculty of
7771: cognition.
7772: 
7773:  [36] When I think the reality of a thing, I do really think more than
7774:  the possibility, but not in the thing; for that can never contain more
7775:  in reality than was contained in its complete possibility. But while
7776:  the notion of possibility is merely the notion of a position of thing
7777:  in relation to the understanding (its empirical use), reality is the
7778:  conjunction of the thing with perception.
7779: 
7780: 
7781: GENERAL REMARK ON THE SYSTEM OF PRINCIPLES.
7782: 
7783: It is very remarkable that we cannot perceive the possibility of a
7784: thing from the category alone, but must always have an intuition, by
7785: which to make evident the objective reality of the pure conception of
7786: the understanding. Take, for example, the categories of relation. How
7787: (1) a thing can exist only as a subject, and not as a mere
7788: determination of other things, that is, can be substance; or how (2),
7789: because something exists, some other thing must exist, consequently how
7790: a thing can be a cause; or how (3), when several things exist, from the
7791: fact that one of these things exists, some consequence to the others
7792: follows, and reciprocally, and in this way a community of substances
7793: can be possible—are questions whose solution cannot be obtained from
7794: mere conceptions. The very same is the case with the other categories;
7795: for example, how a thing can be of the same sort with many others, that
7796: is, can be a quantity, and so on. So long as we have not intuition we
7797: cannot know whether we do really think an object by the categories, and
7798: where an object can anywhere be found to cohere with them, and thus the
7799: truth is established, that the categories are not in themselves
7800: cognitions, but mere forms of thought for the construction of
7801: cognitions from given intuitions. For the same reason is it true that
7802: from categories alone no synthetical proposition can be made. For
7803: example: “In every existence there is substance,” that is, something
7804: that can exist only as a subject and not as mere predicate; or,
7805: “Everything is a quantity”—to construct propositions such as these, we
7806: require something to enable us to go out beyond the given conception
7807: and connect another with it. For the same reason the attempt to prove a
7808: synthetical proposition by means of mere conceptions, for example:
7809: “Everything that exists contingently has a cause,” has never succeeded.
7810: We could never get further than proving that, without this relation to
7811: conceptions, we could not conceive the existence of the contingent,
7812: that is, could not à priori through the understanding cognize the
7813: existence of such a thing; but it does not hence follow that this is
7814: also the condition of the possibility of the thing itself that is said
7815: to be contingent. If, accordingly; we look back to our proof of the
7816: principle of causality, we shall find that we were able to prove it as
7817: valid only of objects of possible experience, and, indeed, only as
7818: itself the principle of the possibility of experience, Consequently of
7819: the cognition of an object given in empirical intuition, and not from
7820: mere conceptions. That, however, the proposition: “Everything that is
7821: contingent must have a cause,” is evident to every one merely from
7822: conceptions, is not to be denied. But in this case the conception of
7823: the contingent is cogitated as involving not the category of modality
7824: (as that the non-existence of which can be conceived) but that of
7825: relation (as that which can exist only as the consequence of something
7826: else), and so it is really an identical proposition: “That which can
7827: exist only as a consequence, has a cause.” In fact, when we have to
7828: give examples of contingent existence, we always refer to changes, and
7829: not merely to the possibility of conceiving the opposite.[37] But
7830: change is an event, which, as such, is possible only through a cause,
7831: and considered per se its non-existence is therefore possible, and we
7832: become cognizant of its contingency from the fact that it can exist
7833: only as the effect of a cause. Hence, if a thing is assumed to be
7834: contingent, it is an analytical proposition to say, it has a cause.
7835: 
7836:  [37] We can easily conceive the non-existence of matter; but the
7837:  ancients did not thence infer its contingency. But even the
7838:  alternation of the existence and non-existence of a given state in a
7839:  thing, in which all change consists, by no means proves the
7840:  contingency of that state—the ground of proof being the reality of its
7841:  opposite. For example, a body is in a state of rest after motion, but
7842:  we cannot infer the contingency of the motion from the fact that the
7843:  former is the opposite of the latter. For this opposite is merely a
7844:  logical and not a real opposite to the other. If we wish to
7845:  demonstrate the contingency of the motion, what we ought to prove is
7846:  that, instead of the motion which took place in the preceding point of
7847:  time, it was possible for the body to have been then in rest, not,
7848:  that it is afterwards in rest; for in this case, both opposites are
7849:  perfectly consistent with each other.
7850: 
7851: 
7852: But it is still more remarkable that, to understand the possibility of
7853: things according to the categories and thus to demonstrate the
7854: objective reality of the latter, we require not merely intuitions, but
7855: external intuitions. If, for example, we take the pure conceptions of
7856: relation, we find that (1) for the purpose of presenting to the
7857: conception of substance something permanent in intuition corresponding
7858: thereto and thus of demonstrating the objective reality of this
7859: conception, we require an intuition (of matter) in space, because space
7860: alone is permanent and determines things as such, while time, and with
7861: it all that is in the internal sense, is in a state of continual flow;
7862: (2) in order to represent change as the intuition corresponding to the
7863: conception of causality, we require the representation of motion as
7864: change in space; in fact, it is through it alone that changes, the
7865: possibility of which no pure understanding can perceive, are capable of
7866: being intuited. Change is the connection of determinations
7867: contradictorily opposed to each other in the existence of one and the
7868: same thing. Now, how it is possible that out of a given state one quite
7869: opposite to it in the same thing should follow, reason without an
7870: example can not only not conceive, but cannot even make intelligible
7871: without intuition; and this intuition is the motion of a point in
7872: space; the existence of which in different spaces (as a consequence of
7873: opposite determinations) alone makes the intuition of change possible.
7874: For, in order to make even internal change cognitable, we require to
7875: represent time, as the form of the internal sense, figuratively by a
7876: line, and the internal change by the drawing of that line (motion), and
7877: consequently are obliged to employ external intuition to be able to
7878: represent the successive existence of ourselves in different states.
7879: The proper ground of this fact is that all change to be perceived as
7880: change presupposes something permanent in intuition, while in the
7881: internal sense no permanent intuition is to be found. Lastly, the
7882: objective possibility of the category of community cannot be conceived
7883: by mere reason, and consequently its objective reality cannot be
7884: demonstrated without an intuition, and that external in space. For how
7885: can we conceive the possibility of community, that is, when several
7886: substances exist, that some effect on the existence of the one follows
7887: from the existence of the other, and reciprocally, and therefore that,
7888: because something exists in the latter, something else must exist in
7889: the former, which could not be understood from its own existence alone?
7890: For this is the very essence of community—which is inconceivable as a
7891: property of things which are perfectly isolated. Hence, Leibnitz, in
7892: attributing to the substances of the world—as cogitated by the
7893: understanding alone—a community, required the mediating aid of a
7894: divinity; for, from their existence, such a property seemed to him with
7895: justice inconceivable. But we can very easily conceive the possibility
7896: of community (of substances as phenomena) if we represent them to
7897: ourselves as in space, consequently in external intuition. For external
7898: intuition contains in itself à priori formal external relations, as the
7899: conditions of the possibility of the real relations of action and
7900: reaction, and therefore of the possibility of community. With the same
7901: ease can it be demonstrated, that the possibility of things as
7902: quantities, and consequently the objective reality of the category of
7903: quantity, can be grounded only in external intuition, and that by its
7904: means alone is the notion of quantity appropriated by the internal
7905: sense. But I must avoid prolixity, and leave the task of illustrating
7906: this by examples to the reader’s own reflection.
7907: 
7908: The above remarks are of the greatest importance, not only for the
7909: confirmation of our previous confutation of idealism, but still more
7910: when the subject of self-cognition by mere internal consciousness and
7911: the determination of our own nature without the aid of external
7912: empirical intuitions is under discussion, for the indication of the
7913: grounds of the possibility of such a cognition.
7914: 
7915: The result of the whole of this part of the analytic of principles is,
7916: therefore: “All principles of the pure understanding are nothing more
7917: than à priori principles of the possibility of experience, and to
7918: experience alone do all à priori synthetical propositions apply and
7919: relate”; indeed, their possibility itself rests entirely on this
7920: relation.
7921: 
7922: Chapter III Of the Ground of the Division of all Objects into Phenomena
7923: and Noumena
7924: 
7925: We have now not only traversed the region of the pure understanding and
7926: carefully surveyed every part of it, but we have also measured it, and
7927: assigned to everything therein its proper place. But this land is an
7928: island, and enclosed by nature herself within unchangeable limits. It
7929: is the land of truth (an attractive word), surrounded by a wide and
7930: stormy ocean, the region of illusion, where many a fog-bank, many an
7931: iceberg, seems to the mariner, on his voyage of discovery, a new
7932: country, and, while constantly deluding him with vain hopes, engages
7933: him in dangerous adventures, from which he never can desist, and which
7934: yet he never can bring to a termination. But before venturing upon this
7935: sea, in order to explore it in its whole extent, and to arrive at a
7936: certainty whether anything is to be discovered there, it will not be
7937: without advantage if we cast our eyes upon the chart of the land that
7938: we are about to leave, and to ask ourselves, firstly, whether we cannot
7939: rest perfectly contented with what it contains, or whether we must not
7940: of necessity be contented with it, if we can find nowhere else a solid
7941: foundation to build upon; and, secondly, by what title we possess this
7942: land itself, and how we hold it secure against all hostile claims?
7943: Although, in the course of our analytic, we have already given
7944: sufficient answers to these questions, yet a summary recapitulation of
7945: these solutions may be useful in strengthening our conviction, by
7946: uniting in one point the momenta of the arguments.
7947: 
7948: We have seen that everything which the understanding draws from itself,
7949: without borrowing from experience, it nevertheless possesses only for
7950: the behoof and use of experience. The principles of the pure
7951: understanding, whether constitutive à priori (as the mathematical
7952: principles), or merely regulative (as the dynamical), contain nothing
7953: but the pure schema, as it were, of possible experience. For experience
7954: possesses its unity from the synthetical unity which the understanding,
7955: originally and from itself, imparts to the synthesis of the imagination
7956: in relation to apperception, and in à priori relation to and agreement
7957: with which phenomena, as data for a possible cognition, must stand. But
7958: although these rules of the understanding are not only à priori true,
7959: but the very source of all truth, that is, of the accordance of our
7960: cognition with objects, and on this ground, that they contain the basis
7961: of the possibility of experience, as the ensemble of all cognition, it
7962: seems to us not enough to propound what is true—we desire also to be
7963: told what we want to know. If, then, we learn nothing more by this
7964: critical examination than what we should have practised in the merely
7965: empirical use of the understanding, without any such subtle inquiry,
7966: the presumption is that the advantage we reap from it is not worth the
7967: labour bestowed upon it. It may certainly be answered that no rash
7968: curiosity is more prejudicial to the enlargement of our knowledge than
7969: that which must know beforehand the utility of this or that piece of
7970: information which we seek, before we have entered on the needful
7971: investigations, and before one could form the least conception of its
7972: utility, even though it were placed before our eyes. But there is one
7973: advantage in such transcendental inquiries which can be made
7974: comprehensible to the dullest and most reluctant learner—this, namely,
7975: that the understanding which is occupied merely with empirical
7976: exercise, and does not reflect on the sources of its own cognition, may
7977: exercise its functions very well and very successfully, but is quite
7978: unable to do one thing, and that of very great importance, to
7979: determine, namely, the bounds that limit its employment, and to know
7980: what lies within or without its own sphere. This purpose can be
7981: obtained only by such profound investigations as we have instituted.
7982: But if it cannot distinguish whether certain questions lie within its
7983: horizon or not, it can never be sure either as to its claims or
7984: possessions, but must lay its account with many humiliating
7985: corrections, when it transgresses, as it unavoidably will, the limits
7986: of its own territory, and loses itself in fanciful opinions and
7987: blinding illusions.
7988: 
7989: That the understanding, therefore, cannot make of its à priori
7990: principles, or even of its conceptions, other than an empirical use, is
7991: a proposition which leads to the most important results. A
7992: transcendental use is made of a conception in a fundamental proposition
7993: or principle, when it is referred to things in general and considered
7994: as things in themselves; an empirical use, when it is referred merely
7995: to phenomena, that is, to objects of a possible experience. That the
7996: latter use of a conception is the only admissible one is evident from
7997: the reasons following. For every conception are requisite, firstly, the
7998: logical form of a conception (of thought) general; and, secondly, the
7999: possibility of presenting to this an object to which it may apply.
8000: Failing this latter, it has no sense, and utterly void of content,
8001: although it may contain the logical function for constructing a
8002: conception from certain data. Now, object cannot be given to a
8003: conception otherwise than by intuition, and, even if a pure intuition
8004: antecedent to the object is à priori possible, this pure intuition can
8005: itself obtain objective validity only from empirical intuition, of
8006: which it is itself but the form. All conceptions, therefore, and with
8007: them all principles, however high the degree of their à priori
8008: possibility, relate to empirical intuitions, that is, to data towards a
8009: possible experience. Without this they possess no objective validity,
8010: but are mere play of imagination or of understanding with images or
8011: notions. Let us take, for example, the conceptions of mathematics, and
8012: first in its pure intuitions. “Space has three dimensions”—“Between two
8013: points there can be only one straight line,” etc. Although all these
8014: principles, and the representation of the object with which this
8015: science occupies itself, are generated in the mind entirely à priori,
8016: they would nevertheless have no significance if we were not always able
8017: to exhibit their significance in and by means of phenomena (empirical
8018: objects). Hence it is requisite that an abstract conception be made
8019: sensuous, that is, that an object corresponding to it in intuition be
8020: forthcoming, otherwise the conception remains, as we say, without
8021: sense, that is, without meaning. Mathematics fulfils this requirement
8022: by the construction of the figure, which is a phenomenon evident to the
8023: senses. The same science finds support and significance in number; this
8024: in its turn finds it in the fingers, or in counters, or in lines and
8025: points. The conception itself is always produced à priori, together
8026: with the synthetical principles or formulas from such conceptions; but
8027: the proper employment of them, and their application to objects, can
8028: exist nowhere but in experience, the possibility of which, as regards
8029: its form, they contain à priori.
8030: 
8031: That this is also the case with all of the categories and the
8032: principles based upon them is evident from the fact that we cannot
8033: render intelligible the possibility of an object corresponding to them
8034: without having recourse to the conditions of sensibility, consequently,
8035: to the form of phenomena, to which, as their only proper objects, their
8036: use must therefore be confined, inasmuch as, if this condition is
8037: removed, all significance, that is, all relation to an object,
8038: disappears, and no example can be found to make it comprehensible what
8039: sort of things we ought to think under such conceptions.
8040: 
8041: The conception of quantity cannot be explained except by saying that it
8042: is the determination of a thing whereby it can be cogitated how many
8043: times one is placed in it. But this “how many times” is based upon
8044: successive repetition, consequently upon time and the synthesis of the
8045: homogeneous therein. Reality, in contradistinction to negation, can be
8046: explained only by cogitating a time which is either filled therewith or
8047: is void. If I leave out the notion of permanence (which is existence in
8048: all time), there remains in the conception of substance nothing but the
8049: logical notion of subject, a notion of which I endeavour to realize by
8050: representing to myself something that can exist only as a subject. But
8051: not only am I perfectly ignorant of any conditions under which this
8052: logical prerogative can belong to a thing, I can make nothing out of
8053: the notion, and draw no inference from it, because no object to which
8054: to apply the conception is determined, and we consequently do not know
8055: whether it has any meaning at all. In like manner, if I leave out the
8056: notion of time, in which something follows upon some other thing in
8057: conformity with a rule, I can find nothing in the pure category, except
8058: that there is a something of such a sort that from it a conclusion may
8059: be drawn as to the existence of some other thing. But in this case it
8060: would not only be impossible to distinguish between a cause and an
8061: effect, but, as this power to draw conclusions requires conditions of
8062: which I am quite ignorant, the conception is not determined as to the
8063: mode in which it ought to apply to an object. The so-called principle:
8064: “Everything that is contingent has a cause,” comes with a gravity and
8065: self-assumed authority that seems to require no support from without.
8066: But, I ask, what is meant by contingent? The answer is that the
8067: non-existence of which is possible. But I should like very well to know
8068: by what means this possibility of non-existence is to be cognized, if
8069: we do not represent to ourselves a succession in the series of
8070: phenomena, and in this succession an existence which follows a
8071: non-existence, or conversely, consequently, change. For to say, that
8072: the non-existence of a thing is not self-contradictory is a lame appeal
8073: to a logical condition, which is no doubt a necessary condition of the
8074: existence of the conception, but is far from being sufficient for the
8075: real objective possibility of non-existence. I can annihilate in
8076: thought every existing substance without self-contradiction, but I
8077: cannot infer from this their objective contingency in existence, that
8078: is to say, the possibility of their non-existence in itself. As regards
8079: the category of community, it may easily be inferred that, as the pure
8080: categories of substance and causality are incapable of a definition and
8081: explanation sufficient to determine their object without the aid of
8082: intuition, the category of reciprocal causality in the relation of
8083: substances to each other (commercium) is just as little susceptible
8084: thereof. Possibility, existence, and necessity nobody has ever yet been
8085: able to explain without being guilty of manifest tautology, when the
8086: definition has been drawn entirely from the pure understanding. For the
8087: substitution of the logical possibility of the conception—the condition
8088: of which is that it be not self-contradictory, for the transcendental
8089: possibility of things—the condition of which is that there be an object
8090: corresponding to the conception, is a trick which can only deceive the
8091: inexperienced.[38]
8092: 
8093:  [38] In one word, to none of these conceptions belongs a corresponding
8094:  object, and consequently their real possibility cannot be
8095:  demonstrated, if we take away sensuous intuition—the only intuition
8096:  which we possess—and there then remains nothing but the logical
8097:  possibility, that is, the fact that the conception or thought is
8098:  possible—which, however, is not the question; what we want to know
8099:  being, whether it relates to an object and thus possesses any meaning.
8100: 
8101: 
8102: It follows incontestably, that the pure conceptions of the
8103: understanding are incapable of transcendental, and must always be of
8104: empirical use alone, and that the principles of the pure understanding
8105: relate only to the general conditions of a possible experience, to
8106: objects of the senses, and never to things in general, apart from the
8107: mode in which we intuite them.
8108: 
8109: Transcendental analytic has accordingly this important result, to wit,
8110: that the understanding is competent effect nothing à priori, except the
8111: anticipation of the form of a possible experience in general, and that,
8112: as that which is not phenomenon cannot be an object of experience, it
8113: can never overstep the limits of sensibility, within which alone
8114: objects are presented to us. Its principles are merely principles of
8115: the exposition of phenomena, and the proud name of an ontology, which
8116: professes to present synthetical cognitions à priori of things in
8117: general in a systematic doctrine, must give place to the modest title
8118: of analytic of the pure understanding.
8119: 
8120: Thought is the act of referring a given intuition to an object. If the
8121: mode of this intuition is unknown to us, the object is merely
8122: transcendental, and the conception of the understanding is employed
8123: only transcendentally, that is, to produce unity in the thought of a
8124: manifold in general. Now a pure category, in which all conditions of
8125: sensuous intuition—as the only intuition we possess—are abstracted,
8126: does not determine an object, but merely expresses the thought of an
8127: object in general, according to different modes. Now, to employ a
8128: conception, the function of judgement is required, by which an object
8129: is subsumed under the conception, consequently the at least formal
8130: condition, under which something can be given in intuition. Failing
8131: this condition of judgement (schema), subsumption is impossible; for
8132: there is in such a case nothing given, which may be subsumed under the
8133: conception. The merely transcendental use of the categories is
8134: therefore, in fact, no use at all and has no determined, or even, as
8135: regards its form, determinable object. Hence it follows that the pure
8136: category is incompetent to establish a synthetical à priori principle,
8137: and that the principles of the pure understanding are only of empirical
8138: and never of transcendental use, and that beyond the sphere of possible
8139: experience no synthetical à priori principles are possible.
8140: 
8141: It may be advisable, therefore, to express ourselves thus. The pure
8142: categories, apart from the formal conditions of sensibility, have a
8143: merely transcendental meaning, but are nevertheless not of
8144: transcendental use, because this is in itself impossible, inasmuch as
8145: all the conditions of any employment or use of them (in judgements) are
8146: absent, to wit, the formal conditions of the subsumption of an object
8147: under these conceptions. As, therefore, in the character of pure
8148: categories, they must be employed empirically, and cannot be employed
8149: transcendentally, they are of no use at all, when separated from
8150: sensibility, that is, they cannot be applied to an object. They are
8151: merely the pure form of the employment of the understanding in respect
8152: of objects in general and of thought, without its being at the same
8153: time possible to think or to determine any object by their means. But
8154: there lurks at the foundation of this subject an illusion which it is
8155: very difficult to avoid. The categories are not based, as regards their
8156: origin, upon sensibility, like the forms of intuition, space, and time;
8157: they seem, therefore, to be capable of an application beyond the sphere
8158: of sensuous objects. But this is not the case. They are nothing but
8159: mere forms of thought, which contain only the logical faculty of
8160: uniting à priori in consciousness the manifold given in intuition.
8161: Apart, then, from the only intuition possible for us, they have still
8162: less meaning than the pure sensuous forms, space and time, for through
8163: them an object is at least given, while a mode of connection of the
8164: manifold, when the intuition which alone gives the manifold is wanting,
8165: has no meaning at all. At the same time, when we designate certain
8166: objects as phenomena or sensuous existences, thus distinguishing our
8167: mode of intuiting them from their own nature as things in themselves,
8168: it is evident that by this very distinction we as it were place the
8169: latter, considered in this their own nature, although we do not so
8170: intuite them, in opposition to the former, or, on the other hand, we do
8171: so place other possible things, which are not objects of our senses,
8172: but are cogitated by the understanding alone, and call them
8173: intelligible existences (noumena). Now the question arises whether the
8174: pure conceptions of our understanding do possess significance in
8175: respect of these latter, and may possibly be a mode of cognizing them.
8176: 
8177: But we are met at the very commencement with an ambiguity, which may
8178: easily occasion great misapprehension. The understanding, when it terms
8179: an object in a certain relation phenomenon, at the same time forms out
8180: of this relation a representation or notion of an object in itself, and
8181: hence believes that it can form also conceptions of such objects. Now
8182: as the understanding possesses no other fundamental conceptions besides
8183: the categories, it takes for granted that an object considered as a
8184: thing in itself must be capable of being thought by means of these pure
8185: conceptions, and is thereby led to hold the perfectly undetermined
8186: conception of an intelligible existence, a something out of the sphere
8187: of our sensibility, for a determinate conception of an existence which
8188: we can cognize in some way or other by means of the understanding.
8189: 
8190: If, by the term noumenon, we understand a thing so far as it is not an
8191: object of our sensuous intuition, thus making abstraction of our mode
8192: of intuiting it, this is a noumenon in the negative sense of the word.
8193: But if we understand by it an object of a non-sensuous intuition, we in
8194: this case assume a peculiar mode of intuition, an intellectual
8195: intuition, to wit, which does not, however, belong to us, of the very
8196: possibility of which we have no notion—and this is a noumenon in the
8197: positive sense.
8198: 
8199: The doctrine of sensibility is also the doctrine of noumena in the
8200: negative sense, that is, of things which the understanding is obliged
8201: to cogitate apart from any relation to our mode of intuition,
8202: consequently not as mere phenomena, but as things in themselves. But
8203: the understanding at the same time comprehends that it cannot employ
8204: its categories for the consideration of things in themselves, because
8205: these possess significance only in relation to the unity of intuitions
8206: in space and time, and that they are competent to determine this unity
8207: by means of general à priori connecting conceptions only on account of
8208: the pure ideality of space and time. Where this unity of time is not to
8209: be met with, as is the case with noumena, the whole use, indeed the
8210: whole meaning of the categories is entirely lost, for even the
8211: possibility of things to correspond to the categories is in this case
8212: incomprehensible. On this point, I need only refer the reader to what I
8213: have said at the commencement of the General Remark appended to the
8214: foregoing chapter. Now, the possibility of a thing can never be proved
8215: from the fact that the conception of it is not self-contradictory, but
8216: only by means of an intuition corresponding to the conception. If,
8217: therefore, we wish to apply the categories to objects which cannot be
8218: regarded as phenomena, we must have an intuition different from the
8219: sensuous, and in this case the objects would be a noumena in the
8220: positive sense of the word. Now, as such an intuition, that is, an
8221: intellectual intuition, is no part of our faculty of cognition, it is
8222: absolutely impossible for the categories to possess any application
8223: beyond the limits of experience. It may be true that there are
8224: intelligible existences to which our faculty of sensuous intuition has
8225: no relation, and cannot be applied, but our conceptions of the
8226: understanding, as mere forms of thought for our sensuous intuition, do
8227: not extend to these. What, therefore, we call noumenon must be
8228: understood by us as such in a negative sense.
8229: 
8230: If I take away from an empirical intuition all thought (by means of the
8231: categories), there remains no cognition of any object; for by means of
8232: mere intuition nothing is cogitated, and, from the existence of such or
8233: such an affection of sensibility in me, it does not follow that this
8234: affection or representation has any relation to an object without me.
8235: But if I take away all intuition, there still remains the form of
8236: thought, that is, the mode of determining an object for the manifold of
8237: a possible intuition. Thus the categories do in some measure really
8238: extend further than sensuous intuition, inasmuch as they think objects
8239: in general, without regard to the mode (of sensibility) in which these
8240: objects are given. But they do not for this reason apply to and
8241: determine a wider sphere of objects, because we cannot assume that such
8242: can be given, without presupposing the possibility of another than the
8243: sensuous mode of intuition, a supposition we are not justified in
8244: making.
8245: 
8246: I call a conception problematical which contains in itself no
8247: contradiction, and which is connected with other cognitions as a
8248: limitation of given conceptions, but whose objective reality cannot be
8249: cognized in any manner. The conception of a noumenon, that is, of a
8250: thing which must be cogitated not as an object of sense, but as a thing
8251: in itself (solely through the pure understanding), is not
8252: self-contradictory, for we are not entitled to maintain that
8253: sensibility is the only possible mode of intuition. Nay, further, this
8254: conception is necessary to restrain sensuous intuition within the
8255: bounds of phenomena, and thus to limit the objective validity of
8256: sensuous cognition; for things in themselves, which lie beyond its
8257: province, are called noumena for the very purpose of indicating that
8258: this cognition does not extend its application to all that the
8259: understanding thinks. But, after all, the possibility of such noumena
8260: is quite incomprehensible, and beyond the sphere of phenomena, all is
8261: for us a mere void; that is to say, we possess an understanding whose
8262: province does problematically extend beyond this sphere, but we do not
8263: possess an intuition, indeed, not even the conception of a possible
8264: intuition, by means of which objects beyond the region of sensibility
8265: could be given us, and in reference to which the understanding might be
8266: employed assertorically. The conception of a noumenon is therefore
8267: merely a limitative conception and therefore only of negative use. But
8268: it is not an arbitrary or fictitious notion, but is connected with the
8269: limitation of sensibility, without, however, being capable of
8270: presenting us with any positive datum beyond this sphere.
8271: 
8272: The division of objects into phenomena and noumena, and of the world
8273: into a mundus sensibilis and intelligibilis is therefore quite
8274: inadmissible in a positive sense, although conceptions do certainly
8275: admit of such a division; for the class of noumena have no determinate
8276: object corresponding to them, and cannot therefore possess objective
8277: validity. If we abandon the senses, how can it be made conceivable that
8278: the categories (which are the only conceptions that could serve as
8279: conceptions for noumena) have any sense or meaning at all, inasmuch as
8280: something more than the mere unity of thought, namely, a possible
8281: intuition, is requisite for their application to an object? The
8282: conception of a noumenon, considered as merely problematical, is,
8283: however, not only admissible, but, as a limitative conception of
8284: sensibility, absolutely necessary. But, in this case, a noumenon is not
8285: a particular intelligible object for our understanding; on the
8286: contrary, the kind of understanding to which it could belong is itself
8287: a problem, for we cannot form the most distant conception of the
8288: possibility of an understanding which should cognize an object, not
8289: discursively by means of categories, but intuitively in a non-sensuous
8290: intuition. Our understanding attains in this way a sort of negative
8291: extension. That is to say, it is not limited by, but rather limits,
8292: sensibility, by giving the name of noumena to things, not considered as
8293: phenomena, but as things in themselves. But it at the same time
8294: prescribes limits to itself, for it confesses itself unable to cognize
8295: these by means of the categories, and hence is compelled to cogitate
8296: them merely as an unknown something.
8297: 
8298: I find, however, in the writings of modern authors, an entirely
8299: different use of the expressions, mundus sensibilis and intelligibilis,
8300: which quite departs from the meaning of the ancients—an acceptation in
8301: which, indeed, there is to be found no difficulty, but which at the
8302: same time depends on mere verbal quibbling. According to this meaning,
8303: some have chosen to call the complex of phenomena, in so far as it is
8304: intuited, mundus sensibilis, but in so far as the connection thereof is
8305: cogitated according to general laws of thought, mundus intelligibilis.
8306: Astronomy, in so far as we mean by the word the mere observation of the
8307: starry heaven, may represent the former; a system of astronomy, such as
8308: the Copernican or Newtonian, the latter. But such twisting of words is
8309: a mere sophistical subterfuge, to avoid a difficult question, by
8310: modifying its meaning to suit our own convenience. To be sure,
8311: understanding and reason are employed in the cognition of phenomena;
8312: but the question is, whether these can be applied when the object is
8313: not a phenomenon and in this sense we regard it if it is cogitated as
8314: given to the understanding alone, and not to the senses. The question
8315: therefore is whether, over and above the empirical use of the
8316: understanding, a transcendental use is possible, which applies to the
8317: noumenon as an object. This question we have answered in the negative.
8318: 
8319: When therefore we say, the senses represent objects as they appear, the
8320: understanding as they are, the latter statement must not be understood
8321: in a transcendental, but only in an empirical signification, that is,
8322: as they must be represented in the complete connection of phenomena,
8323: and not according to what they may be, apart from their relation to
8324: possible experience, consequently not as objects of the pure
8325: understanding. For this must ever remain unknown to us. Nay, it is also
8326: quite unknown to us whether any such transcendental or extraordinary
8327: cognition is possible under any circumstances, at least, whether it is
8328: possible by means of our categories. Understanding and sensibility,
8329: with us, can determine objects only in conjunction. If we separate
8330: them, we have intuitions without conceptions, or conceptions without
8331: intuitions; in both cases, representations, which we cannot apply to
8332: any determinate object.
8333: 
8334: If, after all our inquiries and explanations, any one still hesitates
8335: to abandon the mere transcendental use of the categories, let him
8336: attempt to construct with them a synthetical proposition. It would, of
8337: course, be unnecessary for this purpose to construct an analytical
8338: proposition, for that does not extend the sphere of the understanding,
8339: but, being concerned only about what is cogitated in the conception
8340: itself, it leaves it quite undecided whether the conception has any
8341: relation to objects, or merely indicates the unity of thought—complete
8342: abstraction being made of the modi in which an object may be given: in
8343: such a proposition, it is sufficient for the understanding to know what
8344: lies in the conception—to what it applies is to it indifferent. The
8345: attempt must therefore be made with a synthetical and so-called
8346: transcendental principle, for example: “Everything that exists, exists
8347: as substance,” or, “Everything that is contingent exists as an effect
8348: of some other thing, viz., of its cause.” Now I ask, whence can the
8349: understanding draw these synthetical propositions, when the conceptions
8350: contained therein do not relate to possible experience but to things in
8351: themselves (noumena)? Where is to be found the third term, which is
8352: always requisite PURE site in a synthetical proposition, which may
8353: connect in the same proposition conceptions which have no logical
8354: (analytical) connection with each other? The proposition never will be
8355: demonstrated, nay, more, the possibility of any such pure assertion
8356: never can be shown, without making reference to the empirical use of
8357: the understanding, and thus, ipso facto, completely renouncing pure and
8358: non-sensuous judgement. Thus the conception of pure and merely
8359: intelligible objects is completely void of all principles of its
8360: application, because we cannot imagine any mode in which they might be
8361: given, and the problematical thought which leaves a place open for them
8362: serves only, like a void space, to limit the use of empirical
8363: principles, without containing at the same time any other object of
8364: cognition beyond their sphere.
8365: 
8366: APPENDIX
8367: 
8368: Of the Equivocal Nature or Amphiboly of the Conceptions of Reflection
8369: from the Confusion of the Transcendental with the Empirical use of the
8370: Understanding.
8371: 
8372: Reflection (reflexio) is not occupied about objects themselves, for the
8373: purpose of directly obtaining conceptions of them, but is that state of
8374: the mind in which we set ourselves to discover the subjective
8375: conditions under which we obtain conceptions. It is the consciousness
8376: of the relation of given representations to the different sources or
8377: faculties of cognition, by which alone their relation to each other can
8378: be rightly determined. The first question which occurs in considering
8379: our representations is to what faculty of cognition do they belong? To
8380: the understanding or to the senses? Many judgements are admitted to be
8381: true from mere habit or inclination; but, because reflection neither
8382: precedes nor follows, it is held to be a judgement that has its origin
8383: in the understanding. All judgements do not require examination, that
8384: is, investigation into the grounds of their truth. For, when they are
8385: immediately certain (for example: “Between two points there can be only
8386: one straight line”), no better or less mediate test of their truth can
8387: be found than that which they themselves contain and express. But all
8388: judgement, nay, all comparisons require reflection, that is, a
8389: distinction of the faculty of cognition to which the given conceptions
8390: belong. The act whereby I compare my representations with the faculty
8391: of cognition which originates them, and whereby I distinguish whether
8392: they are compared with each other as belonging to the pure
8393: understanding or to sensuous intuition, I term transcendental
8394: reflection. Now, the relations in which conceptions can stand to each
8395: other are those of identity and difference, agreement and opposition,
8396: of the internal and external, finally, of the determinable and the
8397: determining (matter and form). The proper determination of these
8398: relations rests on the question, to what faculty of cognition they
8399: subjectively belong, whether to sensibility or understanding? For, on
8400: the manner in which we solve this question depends the manner in which
8401: we must cogitate these relations.
8402: 
8403: Before constructing any objective judgement, we compare the conceptions
8404: that are to be placed in the judgement, and observe whether there
8405: exists identity (of many representations in one conception), if a
8406: general judgement is to be constructed, or difference, if a particular;
8407: whether there is agreement when affirmative; and opposition when
8408: negative judgements are to be constructed, and so on. For this reason
8409: we ought to call these conceptions, conceptions of comparison
8410: (conceptus comparationis). But as, when the question is not as to the
8411: logical form, but as to the content of conceptions, that is to say,
8412: whether the things themselves are identical or different, in agreement
8413: or opposition, and so on, the things can have a twofold relation to our
8414: faculty of cognition, to wit, a relation either to sensibility or to
8415: the understanding, and as on this relation depends their relation to
8416: each other, transcendental reflection, that is, the relation of given
8417: representations to one or the other faculty of cognition, can alone
8418: determine this latter relation. Thus we shall not be able to discover
8419: whether the things are identical or different, in agreement or
8420: opposition, etc., from the mere conception of the things by means of
8421: comparison (comparatio), but only by distinguishing the mode of
8422: cognition to which they belong, in other words, by means of
8423: transcendental reflection. We may, therefore, with justice say, that
8424: logical reflection is mere comparison, for in it no account is taken of
8425: the faculty of cognition to which the given conceptions belong, and
8426: they are consequently, as far as regards their origin, to be treated as
8427: homogeneous; while transcendental reflection (which applies to the
8428: objects themselves) contains the ground of the possibility of objective
8429: comparison of representations with each other, and is therefore very
8430: different from the former, because the faculties of cognition to which
8431: they belong are not even the same. Transcendental reflection is a duty
8432: which no one can neglect who wishes to establish an à priori judgement
8433: upon things. We shall now proceed to fulfil this duty, and thereby
8434: throw not a little light on the question as to the determination of the
8435: proper business of the understanding.
8436: 
8437: 1. Identity and Difference. When an object is presented to us several
8438: times, but always with the same internal determinations (qualitas et
8439: quantitas), it, if an object of pure understanding, is always the same,
8440: not several things, but only one thing (numerica identitas); but if a
8441: phenomenon, we do not concern ourselves with comparing the conception
8442: of the thing with the conception of some other, but, although they may
8443: be in this respect perfectly the same, the difference of place at the
8444: same time is a sufficient ground for asserting the numerical difference
8445: of these objects (of sense). Thus, in the case of two drops of water,
8446: we may make complete abstraction of all internal difference (quality
8447: and quantity), and, the fact that they are intuited at the same time in
8448: different places, is sufficient to justify us in holding them to be
8449: numerically different. Leibnitz regarded phenomena as things in
8450: themselves, consequently as intelligibilia, that is, objects of pure
8451: understanding (although, on account of the confused nature of their
8452: representations, he gave them the name of phenomena), and in this case
8453: his principle of the indiscernible (principium identatis
8454: indiscernibilium) is not to be impugned. But, as phenomena are objects
8455: of sensibility, and, as the understanding, in respect of them, must be
8456: employed empirically and not purely or transcendentally, plurality and
8457: numerical difference are given by space itself as the condition of
8458: external phenomena. For one part of space, although it may be perfectly
8459: similar and equal to another part, is still without it, and for this
8460: reason alone is different from the latter, which is added to it in
8461: order to make up a greater space. It follows that this must hold good
8462: of all things that are in the different parts of space at the same
8463: time, however similar and equal one may be to another.
8464: 
8465: 2. Agreement and Opposition. When reality is represented by the pure
8466: understanding (realitas noumenon), opposition between realities is
8467: incogitable—such a relation, that is, that when these realities are
8468: connected in one subject, they annihilate the effects of each other and
8469: may be represented in the formula 3 -3 = 0. On the other hand, the real
8470: in a phenomenon (realitas phaenomenon) may very well be in mutual
8471: opposition, and, when united in the same subject, the one may
8472: completely or in part annihilate the effect or consequence of the
8473: other; as in the case of two moving forces in the same straight line
8474: drawing or impelling a point in opposite directions, or in the case of
8475: a pleasure counterbalancing a certain amount of pain.
8476: 
8477: 3. The Internal and External. In an object of the pure understanding,
8478: only that is internal which has no relation (as regards its existence)
8479: to anything different from itself. On the other hand, the internal
8480: determinations of a substantia phaenomenon in space are nothing but
8481: relations, and it is itself nothing more than a complex of mere
8482: relations. Substance in space we are cognizant of only through forces
8483: operative in it, either drawing others towards itself (attraction), or
8484: preventing others from forcing into itself (repulsion and
8485: impenetrability). We know no other properties that make up the
8486: conception of substance phenomenal in space, and which we term matter.
8487: On the other hand, as an object of the pure understanding, every
8488: substance must have internal determination and forces. But what other
8489: internal attributes of such an object can I think than those which my
8490: internal sense presents to me? That, to wit, which in either itself
8491: thought, or something analogous to it. Hence Leibnitz, who looked upon
8492: things as noumena, after denying them everything like external
8493: relation, and therefore also composition or combination, declared that
8494: all substances, even the component parts of matter, were simple
8495: substances with powers of representation, in one word, monads.
8496: 
8497: 4. Matter and Form. These two conceptions lie at the foundation of all
8498: other reflection, so inseparably are they connected with every mode of
8499: exercising the understanding. The former denotes the determinable in
