8500: general, the second its determination, both in a transcendental sense,
8501: abstraction being made of every difference in that which is given, and
8502: of the mode in which it is determined. Logicians formerly termed the
8503: universal, matter, the specific difference of this or that part of the
8504: universal, form. In a judgement one may call the given conceptions
8505: logical matter (for the judgement), the relation of these to each other
8506: (by means of the copula), the form of the judgement. In an object, the
8507: composite parts thereof (essentialia) are the matter; the mode in which
8508: they are connected in the object, the form. In respect to things in
8509: general, unlimited reality was regarded as the matter of all
8510: possibility, the limitation thereof (negation) as the form, by which
8511: one thing is distinguished from another according to transcendental
8512: conceptions. The understanding demands that something be given (at
8513: least in the conception), in order to be able to determine it in a
8514: certain manner. Hence, in a conception of the pure understanding, the
8515: matter precedes the form, and for this reason Leibnitz first assumed
8516: the existence of things (monads) and of an internal power of
8517: representation in them, in order to found upon this their external
8518: relation and the community their state (that is, of their
8519: representations). Hence, with him, space and time were possible—the
8520: former through the relation of substances, the latter through the
8521: connection of their determinations with each other, as causes and
8522: effects. And so would it really be, if the pure understanding were
8523: capable of an immediate application to objects, and if space and time
8524: were determinations of things in themselves. But being merely sensuous
8525: intuitions, in which we determine all objects solely as phenomena, the
8526: form of intuition (as a subjective property of sensibility) must
8527: antecede all matter (sensations), consequently space and time must
8528: antecede all phenomena and all data of experience, and rather make
8529: experience itself possible. But the intellectual philosopher could not
8530: endure that the form should precede the things themselves and determine
8531: their possibility; an objection perfectly correct, if we assume that we
8532: intuite things as they are, although with confused representation. But
8533: as sensuous intuition is a peculiar subjective condition, which is à
8534: priori at the foundation of all perception, and the form of which is
8535: primitive, the form must be given per se, and so far from matter (or
8536: the things themselves which appear) lying at the foundation of
8537: experience (as we must conclude, if we judge by mere conceptions), the
8538: very possibility of itself presupposes, on the contrary, a given formal
8539: intuition (space and time).
8540: 
8541: REMARK ON THE AMPHIBOLY OF THE CONCEPTIONS OF REFLECTION.
8542: 
8543: Let me be allowed to term the position which we assign to a conception
8544: either in the sensibility or in the pure understanding, the
8545: transcendental place. In this manner, the appointment of the position
8546: which must be taken by each conception according to the difference in
8547: its use, and the directions for determining this place to all
8548: conceptions according to rules, would be a transcendental topic, a
8549: doctrine which would thoroughly shield us from the surreptitious
8550: devices of the pure understanding and the delusions which thence arise,
8551: as it would always distinguish to what faculty of cognition each
8552: conception properly belonged. Every conception, every title, under
8553: which many cognitions rank together, may be called a logical place.
8554: Upon this is based the logical topic of Aristotle, of which teachers
8555: and rhetoricians could avail themselves, in order, under certain titles
8556: of thought, to observe what would best suit the matter they had to
8557: treat, and thus enable themselves to quibble and talk with fluency and
8558: an appearance of profundity.
8559: 
8560: Transcendental topic, on the contrary, contains nothing more than the
8561: above-mentioned four titles of all comparison and distinction, which
8562: differ from categories in this respect, that they do not represent the
8563: object according to that which constitutes its conception (quantity,
8564: reality), but set forth merely the comparison of representations, which
8565: precedes our conceptions of things. But this comparison requires a
8566: previous reflection, that is, a determination of the place to which the
8567: representations of the things which are compared belong, whether, to
8568: wit, they are cogitated by the pure understanding, or given by
8569: sensibility.
8570: 
8571: Conceptions may be logically compared without the trouble of inquiring
8572: to what faculty their objects belong, whether as noumena, to the
8573: understanding, or as phenomena, to sensibility. If, however, we wish to
8574: employ these conceptions in respect of objects, previous transcendental
8575: reflection is necessary. Without this reflection I should make a very
8576: unsafe use of these conceptions, and construct pretended synthetical
8577: propositions which critical reason cannot acknowledge and which are
8578: based solely upon a transcendental amphiboly, that is, upon a
8579: substitution of an object of pure understanding for a phenomenon.
8580: 
8581: For want of this doctrine of transcendental topic, and consequently
8582: deceived by the amphiboly of the conceptions of reflection, the
8583: celebrated Leibnitz constructed an intellectual system of the world, or
8584: rather, believed himself competent to cognize the internal nature of
8585: things, by comparing all objects merely with the understanding and the
8586: abstract formal conceptions of thought. Our table of the conceptions of
8587: reflection gives us the unexpected advantage of being able to exhibit
8588: the distinctive peculiarities of his system in all its parts, and at
8589: the same time of exposing the fundamental principle of this peculiar
8590: mode of thought, which rested upon naught but a misconception. He
8591: compared all things with each other merely by means of conceptions, and
8592: naturally found no other differences than those by which the
8593: understanding distinguishes its pure conceptions one from another. The
8594: conditions of sensuous intuition, which contain in themselves their own
8595: means of distinction, he did not look upon as primitive, because
8596: sensibility was to him but a confused mode of representation and not
8597: any particular source of representations. A phenomenon was for him the
8598: representation of the thing in itself, although distinguished from
8599: cognition by the understanding only in respect of the logical form—the
8600: former with its usual want of analysis containing, according to him, a
8601: certain mixture of collateral representations in its conception of a
8602: thing, which it is the duty of the understanding to separate and
8603: distinguish. In one word, Leibnitz intellectualized phenomena, just as
8604: Locke, in his system of noogony (if I may be allowed to make use of
8605: such expressions), sensualized the conceptions of the understanding,
8606: that is to say, declared them to be nothing more than empirical or
8607: abstract conceptions of reflection. Instead of seeking in the
8608: understanding and sensibility two different sources of representations,
8609: which, however, can present us with objective judgements of things only
8610: in conjunction, each of these great men recognized but one of these
8611: faculties, which, in their opinion, applied immediately to things in
8612: themselves, the other having no duty but that of confusing or arranging
8613: the representations of the former.
8614: 
8615: Accordingly, the objects of sense were compared by Leibnitz as things
8616: in general merely in the understanding.
8617: 
8618: 1st. He compares them in regard to their identity or difference—as
8619: judged by the understanding. As, therefore, he considered merely the
8620: conceptions of objects, and not their position in intuition, in which
8621: alone objects can be given, and left quite out of sight the
8622: transcendental locale of these conceptions—whether, that is, their
8623: object ought to be classed among phenomena, or among things in
8624: themselves, it was to be expected that he should extend the application
8625: of the principle of indiscernibles, which is valid solely of
8626: conceptions of things in general, to objects of sense (mundus
8627: phaenomenon), and that he should believe that he had thereby
8628: contributed in no small degree to extend our knowledge of nature. In
8629: truth, if I cognize in all its inner determinations a drop of water as
8630: a thing in itself, I cannot look upon one drop as different from
8631: another, if the conception of the one is completely identical with that
8632: of the other. But if it is a phenomenon in space, it has a place not
8633: merely in the understanding (among conceptions), but also in sensuous
8634: external intuition (in space), and in this case, the physical locale is
8635: a matter of indifference in regard to the internal determinations of
8636: things, and one place, B, may contain a thing which is perfectly
8637: similar and equal to another in a place, A, just as well as if the two
8638: things were in every respect different from each other. Difference of
8639: place without any other conditions, makes the plurality and distinction
8640: of objects as phenomena, not only possible in itself, but even
8641: necessary. Consequently, the above so-called law is not a law of
8642: nature. It is merely an analytical rule for the comparison of things by
8643: means of mere conceptions.
8644: 
8645: 2nd. The principle: “Realities (as simple affirmations) never logically
8646: contradict each other,” is a proposition perfectly true respecting the
8647: relation of conceptions, but, whether as regards nature, or things in
8648: themselves (of which we have not the slightest conception), is without
8649: any the least meaning. For real opposition, in which A -B is = 0,
8650: exists everywhere, an opposition, that is, in which one reality united
8651: with another in the same subject annihilates the effects of the other—a
8652: fact which is constantly brought before our eyes by the different
8653: antagonistic actions and operations in nature, which, nevertheless, as
8654: depending on real forces, must be called realitates phaenomena. General
8655: mechanics can even present us with the empirical condition of this
8656: opposition in an à priori rule, as it directs its attention to the
8657: opposition in the direction of forces—a condition of which the
8658: transcendental conception of reality can tell us nothing. Although M.
8659: Leibnitz did not announce this proposition with precisely the pomp of a
8660: new principle, he yet employed it for the establishment of new
8661: propositions, and his followers introduced it into their
8662: Leibnitzio-Wolfian system of philosophy. According to this principle,
8663: for example, all evils are but consequences of the limited nature of
8664: created beings, that is, negations, because these are the only opposite
8665: of reality. (In the mere conception of a thing in general this is
8666: really the case, but not in things as phenomena.) In like manner, the
8667: upholders of this system deem it not only possible, but natural also,
8668: to connect and unite all reality in one being, because they acknowledge
8669: no other sort of opposition than that of contradiction (by which the
8670: conception itself of a thing is annihilated), and find themselves
8671: unable to conceive an opposition of reciprocal destruction, so to
8672: speak, in which one real cause destroys the effect of another, and the
8673: conditions of whose representation we meet with only in sensibility.
8674: 
8675: 3rd. The Leibnitzian monadology has really no better foundation than on
8676: this philosopher’s mode of falsely representing the difference of the
8677: internal and external solely in relation to the understanding.
8678: Substances, in general, must have something inward, which is therefore
8679: free from external relations, consequently from that of composition
8680: also. The simple—that which can be represented by a unit—is therefore
8681: the foundation of that which is internal in things in themselves. The
8682: internal state of substances cannot therefore consist in place, shape,
8683: contact, or motion, determinations which are all external relations,
8684: and we can ascribe to them no other than that whereby we internally
8685: determine our faculty of sense itself, that is to say, the state of
8686: representation. Thus, then, were constructed the monads, which were to
8687: form the elements of the universe, the active force of which consists
8688: in representation, the effects of this force being thus entirely
8689: confined to themselves.
8690: 
8691: For the same reason, his view of the possible community of substances
8692: could not represent it but as a predetermined harmony, and by no means
8693: as a physical influence. For inasmuch as everything is occupied only
8694: internally, that is, with its own representations, the state of the
8695: representations of one substance could not stand in active and living
8696: connection with that of another, but some third cause operating on all
8697: without exception was necessary to make the different states correspond
8698: with one another. And this did not happen by means of assistance
8699: applied in each particular case (systema assistentiae), but through the
8700: unity of the idea of a cause occupied and connected with all
8701: substances, in which they necessarily receive, according to the
8702: Leibnitzian school, their existence and permanence, consequently also
8703: reciprocal correspondence, according to universal laws.
8704: 
8705: 4th. This philosopher’s celebrated doctrine of space and time, in which
8706: he intellectualized these forms of sensibility, originated in the same
8707: delusion of transcendental reflection. If I attempt to represent by the
8708: mere understanding, the external relations of things, I can do so only
8709: by employing the conception of their reciprocal action, and if I wish
8710: to connect one state of the same thing with another state, I must avail
8711: myself of the notion of the order of cause and effect. And thus
8712: Leibnitz regarded space as a certain order in the community of
8713: substances, and time as the dynamical sequence of their states. That
8714: which space and time possess proper to themselves and independent of
8715: things, he ascribed to a necessary confusion in our conceptions of
8716: them, whereby that which is a mere form of dynamical relations is held
8717: to be a self-existent intuition, antecedent even to things themselves.
8718: Thus space and time were the intelligible form of the connection of
8719: things (substances and their states) in themselves. But things were
8720: intelligible substances (substantiae noumena). At the same time, he
8721: made these conceptions valid of phenomena, because he did not allow to
8722: sensibility a peculiar mode of intuition, but sought all, even the
8723: empirical representation of objects, in the understanding, and left to
8724: sense naught but the despicable task of confusing and disarranging the
8725: representations of the former.
8726: 
8727: But even if we could frame any synthetical proposition concerning
8728: things in themselves by means of the pure understanding (which is
8729: impossible), it could not apply to phenomena, which do not represent
8730: things in themselves. In such a case I should be obliged in
8731: transcendental reflection to compare my conceptions only under the
8732: conditions of sensibility, and so space and time would not be
8733: determinations of things in themselves, but of phenomena. What things
8734: may be in themselves, I know not and need not know, because a thing is
8735: never presented to me otherwise than as a phenomenon.
8736: 
8737: I must adopt the same mode of procedure with the other conceptions of
8738: reflection. Matter is substantia phaenomenon. That in it which is
8739: internal I seek to discover in all parts of space which it occupies,
8740: and in all the functions and operations it performs, and which are
8741: indeed never anything but phenomena of the external sense. I cannot
8742: therefore find anything that is absolutely, but only what is
8743: comparatively internal, and which itself consists of external
8744: relations. The absolutely internal in matter, and as it should be
8745: according to the pure understanding, is a mere chimera, for matter is
8746: not an object for the pure understanding. But the transcendental
8747: object, which is the foundation of the phenomenon which we call matter,
8748: is a mere nescio quid, the nature of which we could not understand,
8749: even though someone were found able to tell us. For we can understand
8750: nothing that does not bring with it something in intuition
8751: corresponding to the expressions employed. If, by the complaint of
8752: being unable to perceive the internal nature of things, it is meant
8753: that we do not comprehend by the pure understanding what the things
8754: which appear to us may be in themselves, it is a silly and unreasonable
8755: complaint; for those who talk thus really desire that we should be able
8756: to cognize, consequently to intuite, things without senses, and
8757: therefore wish that we possessed a faculty of cognition perfectly
8758: different from the human faculty, not merely in degree, but even as
8759: regards intuition and the mode thereof, so that thus we should not be
8760: men, but belong to a class of beings, the possibility of whose
8761: existence, much less their nature and constitution, we have no means of
8762: cognizing. By observation and analysis of phenomena we penetrate into
8763: the interior of nature, and no one can say what progress this knowledge
8764: may make in time. But those transcendental questions which pass beyond
8765: the limits of nature, we could never answer, even although all nature
8766: were laid open to us, because we have not the power of observing our
8767: own mind with any other intuition than that of our internal sense. For
8768: herein lies the mystery of the origin and source of our faculty of
8769: sensibility. Its application to an object, and the transcendental
8770: ground of this unity of subjective and objective, lie too deeply
8771: concealed for us, who cognize ourselves only through the internal
8772: sense, consequently as phenomena, to be able to discover in our
8773: existence anything but phenomena, the non-sensuous cause of which we at
8774: the same time earnestly desire to penetrate to.
8775: 
8776: The great utility of this critique of conclusions arrived at by the
8777: processes of mere reflection consists in its clear demonstration of the
8778: nullity of all conclusions respecting objects which are compared with
8779: each other in the understanding alone, while it at the same time
8780: confirms what we particularly insisted on, namely, that, although
8781: phenomena are not included as things in themselves among the objects of
8782: the pure understanding, they are nevertheless the only things by which
8783: our cognition can possess objective reality, that is to say, which give
8784: us intuitions to correspond with our conceptions.
8785: 
8786: When we reflect in a purely logical manner, we do nothing more than
8787: compare conceptions in our understanding, to discover whether both have
8788: the same content, whether they are self-contradictory or not, whether
8789: anything is contained in either conception, which of the two is given,
8790: and which is merely a mode of thinking that given. But if I apply these
8791: conceptions to an object in general (in the transcendental sense),
8792: without first determining whether it is an object of sensuous or
8793: intellectual intuition, certain limitations present themselves, which
8794: forbid us to pass beyond the conceptions and render all empirical use
8795: of them impossible. And thus these limitations prove that the
8796: representation of an object as a thing in general is not only
8797: insufficient, but, without sensuous determination and independently of
8798: empirical conditions, self-contradictory; that we must therefore make
8799: abstraction of all objects, as in logic, or, admitting them, must think
8800: them under conditions of sensuous intuition; that, consequently, the
8801: intelligible requires an altogether peculiar intuition, which we do not
8802: possess, and in the absence of which it is for us nothing; while, on
8803: the other hand phenomena cannot be objects in themselves. For, when I
8804: merely think things in general, the difference in their external
8805: relations cannot constitute a difference in the things themselves; on
8806: the contrary, the former presupposes the latter, and if the conception
8807: of one of two things is not internally different from that of the
8808: other, I am merely thinking the same thing in different relations.
8809: Further, by the addition of one affirmation (reality) to the other, the
8810: positive therein is really augmented, and nothing is abstracted or
8811: withdrawn from it; hence the real in things cannot be in contradiction
8812: with or opposition to itself—and so on.
8813: 
8814: The true use of the conceptions of reflection in the employment of the
8815: understanding has, as we have shown, been so misconceived by Leibnitz,
8816: one of the most acute philosophers of either ancient or modern times,
8817: that he has been misled into the construction of a baseless system of
8818: intellectual cognition, which professes to determine its objects
8819: without the intervention of the senses. For this reason, the exposition
8820: of the cause of the amphiboly of these conceptions, as the origin of
8821: these false principles, is of great utility in determining with
8822: certainty the proper limits of the understanding.
8823: 
8824: It is right to say whatever is affirmed or denied of the whole of a
8825: conception can be affirmed or denied of any part of it (dictum de omni
8826: et nullo); but it would be absurd so to alter this logical proposition
8827: as to say whatever is not contained in a general conception is likewise
8828: not contained in the particular conceptions which rank under it; for
8829: the latter are particular conceptions, for the very reason that their
8830: content is greater than that which is cogitated in the general
8831: conception. And yet the whole intellectual system of Leibnitz is based
8832: upon this false principle, and with it must necessarily fall to the
8833: ground, together with all the ambiguous principles in reference to the
8834: employment of the understanding which have thence originated.
8835: 
8836: Leibnitz’s principle of the identity of indiscernibles or
8837: indistinguishables is really based on the presupposition that, if in
8838: the conception of a thing a certain distinction is not to be found, it
8839: is also not to be met with in things themselves; that, consequently,
8840: all things are completely identical (numero eadem) which are not
8841: distinguishable from each other (as to quality or quantity) in our
8842: conceptions of them. But, as in the mere conception of anything
8843: abstraction has been made of many necessary conditions of intuition,
8844: that of which abstraction has been made is rashly held to be
8845: non-existent, and nothing is attributed to the thing but what is
8846: contained in its conception.
8847: 
8848: The conception of a cubic foot of space, however I may think it, is in
8849: itself completely identical. But two cubic feet in space are
8850: nevertheless distinct from each other from the sole fact of their being
8851: in different places (they are numero diversa); and these places are
8852: conditions of intuition, wherein the object of this conception is
8853: given, and which do not belong to the conception, but to the faculty of
8854: sensibility. In like manner, there is in the conception of a thing no
8855: contradiction when a negative is not connected with an affirmative; and
8856: merely affirmative conceptions cannot, in conjunction, produce any
8857: negation. But in sensuous intuition, wherein reality (take for example,
8858: motion) is given, we find conditions (opposite directions)—of which
8859: abstraction has been made in the conception of motion in general—which
8860: render possible a contradiction or opposition (not indeed of a logical
8861: kind)—and which from pure positives produce zero = 0. We are therefore
8862: not justified in saying that all reality is in perfect agreement and
8863: harmony, because no contradiction is discoverable among its
8864: conceptions.[39] According to mere conceptions, that which is internal
8865: is the substratum of all relations or external determinations. When,
8866: therefore, I abstract all conditions of intuition, and confine myself
8867: solely to the conception of a thing in general, I can make abstraction
8868: of all external relations, and there must nevertheless remain a
8869: conception of that which indicates no relation, but merely internal
8870: determinations. Now it seems to follow that in everything (substance)
8871: there is something which is absolutely internal and which antecedes all
8872: external determinations, inasmuch as it renders them possible; and that
8873: therefore this substratum is something which does not contain any
8874: external relations and is consequently simple (for corporeal things are
8875: never anything but relations, at least of their parts external to each
8876: other); and, inasmuch as we know of no other absolutely internal
8877: determinations than those of the internal sense, this substratum is not
8878: only simple, but also, analogously with our internal sense, determined
8879: through representations, that is to say, all things are properly
8880: monads, or simple beings endowed with the power of representation. Now
8881: all this would be perfectly correct, if the conception of a thing were
8882: the only necessary condition of the presentation of objects of external
8883: intuition. It is, on the contrary, manifest that a permanent phenomenon
8884: in space (impenetrable extension) can contain mere relations, and
8885: nothing that is absolutely internal, and yet be the primary substratum
8886: of all external perception. By mere conceptions I cannot think anything
8887: external, without, at the same time, thinking something internal, for
8888: the reason that conceptions of relations presuppose given things, and
8889: without these are impossible. But, as an intuition there is something
8890: (that is, space, which, with all it contains, consists of purely
8891: formal, or, indeed, real relations) which is not found in the mere
8892: conception of a thing in general, and this presents to us the
8893: substratum which could not be cognized through conceptions alone, I
8894: cannot say: because a thing cannot be represented by mere conceptions
8895: without something absolutely internal, there is also, in the things
8896: themselves which are contained under these conceptions, and in their
8897: intuition nothing external to which something absolutely internal does
8898: not serve as the foundation. For, when we have made abstraction of all
8899: the conditions of intuition, there certainly remains in the mere
8900: conception nothing but the internal in general, through which alone the
8901: external is possible. But this necessity, which is grounded upon
8902: abstraction alone, does not obtain in the case of things themselves, in
8903: so far as they are given in intuition with such determinations as
8904: express mere relations, without having anything internal as their
8905: foundation; for they are not things of a thing of which we can neither
8906: for they are not things in themselves, but only phenomena. What we
8907: cognize in matter is nothing but relations (what we call its internal
8908: determinations are but comparatively internal). But there are some
8909: self-subsistent and permanent, through which a determined object is
8910: given. That I, when abstraction is made of these relations, have
8911: nothing more to think, does not destroy the conception of a thing as
8912: phenomenon, nor the conception of an object in abstracto, but it does
8913: away with the possibility of an object that is determinable according
8914: to mere conceptions, that is, of a noumenon. It is certainly startling
8915: to hear that a thing consists solely of relations; but this thing is
8916: simply a phenomenon, and cannot be cogitated by means of the mere
8917: categories: it does itself consist in the mere relation of something in
8918: general to the senses. In the same way, we cannot cogitate relations of
8919: things in abstracto, if we commence with conceptions alone, in any
8920: other manner than that one is the cause of determinations in the other;
8921: for that is itself the conception of the understanding or category of
8922: relation. But, as in this case we make abstraction of all intuition, we
8923: lose altogether the mode in which the manifold determines to each of
8924: its parts its place, that is, the form of sensibility (space); and yet
8925: this mode antecedes all empirical causality.
8926: 
8927:  [39] If any one wishes here to have recourse to the usual subterfuge,
8928:  and to say, that at least realitates noumena cannot be in opposition
8929:  to each other, it will be requisite for him to adduce an example of
8930:  this pure and non-sensuous reality, that it may be understood whether
8931:  the notion represents something or nothing. But an example cannot be
8932:  found except in experience, which never presents to us anything more
8933:  than phenomena; and thus the proposition means nothing more than that
8934:  the conception which contains only affirmatives does not contain
8935:  anything negative—a proposition nobody ever doubted.
8936: 
8937: 
8938: If by intelligible objects we understand things which can be thought by
8939: means of the pure categories, without the need of the schemata of
8940: sensibility, such objects are impossible. For the condition of the
8941: objective use of all our conceptions of understanding is the mode of
8942: our sensuous intuition, whereby objects are given; and, if we make
8943: abstraction of the latter, the former can have no relation to an
8944: object. And even if we should suppose a different kind of intuition
8945: from our own, still our functions of thought would have no use or
8946: signification in respect thereof. But if we understand by the term,
8947: objects of a non-sensuous intuition, in respect of which our categories
8948: are not valid, and of which we can accordingly have no knowledge
8949: (neither intuition nor conception), in this merely negative sense
8950: noumena must be admitted. For this is no more than saying that our mode
8951: of intuition is not applicable to all things, but only to objects of
8952: our senses, that consequently its objective validity is limited, and
8953: that room is therefore left for another kind of intuition, and thus
8954: also for things that may be objects of it. But in this sense the
8955: conception of a noumenon is problematical, that is to say, it is the
8956: notion of that it that it is possible, nor that it is impossible,
8957: inasmuch as we do not know of any mode of intuition besides the
8958: sensuous, or of any other sort of conceptions than the categories—a
8959: mode of intuition and a kind of conception neither of which is
8960: applicable to a non-sensuous object. We are on this account incompetent
8961: to extend the sphere of our objects of thought beyond the conditions of
8962: our sensibility, and to assume the existence of objects of pure
8963: thought, that is, of noumena, inasmuch as these have no true positive
8964: signification. For it must be confessed of the categories that they are
8965: not of themselves sufficient for the cognition of things in themselves
8966: and, without the data of sensibility, are mere subjective forms of the
8967: unity of the understanding. Thought is certainly not a product of the
8968: senses, and in so far is not limited by them, but it does not therefore
8969: follow that it may be employed purely and without the intervention of
8970: sensibility, for it would then be without reference to an object. And
8971: we cannot call a noumenon an object of pure thought; for the
8972: representation thereof is but the problematical conception of an object
8973: for a perfectly different intuition and a perfectly different
8974: understanding from ours, both of which are consequently themselves
8975: problematical. The conception of a noumenon is therefore not the
8976: conception of an object, but merely a problematical conception
8977: inseparably connected with the limitation of our sensibility. That is
8978: to say, this conception contains the answer to the question: “Are there
8979: objects quite unconnected with, and independent of, our intuition?”—a
8980: question to which only an indeterminate answer can be given. That
8981: answer is: “Inasmuch as sensuous intuition does not apply to all things
8982: without distinction, there remains room for other and different
8983: objects.” The existence of these problematical objects is therefore not
8984: absolutely denied, in the absence of a determinate conception of them,
8985: but, as no category is valid in respect of them, neither must they be
8986: admitted as objects for our understanding.
8987: 
8988: Understanding accordingly limits sensibility, without at the same time
8989: enlarging its own field. While, moreover, it forbids sensibility to
8990: apply its forms and modes to things in themselves and restricts it to
8991: the sphere of phenomena, it cogitates an object in itself, only,
8992: however, as a transcendental object, which is the cause of a phenomenon
8993: (consequently not itself a phenomenon), and which cannot be thought
8994: either as a quantity or as reality, or as substance (because these
8995: conceptions always require sensuous forms in which to determine an
8996: object)—an object, therefore, of which we are quite unable to say
8997: whether it can be met with in ourselves or out of us, whether it would
8998: be annihilated together with sensibility, or, if this were taken away,
8999: would continue to exist. If we wish to call this object a noumenon,
9000: because the representation of it is non-sensuous, we are at liberty to
9001: do so. But as we can apply to it none of the conceptions of our
9002: understanding, the representation is for us quite void, and is
9003: available only for the indication of the limits of our sensuous
9004: intuition, thereby leaving at the same time an empty space, which we
9005: are competent to fill by the aid neither of possible experience, nor of
9006: the pure understanding.
9007: 
9008: The critique of the pure understanding, accordingly, does not permit us
9009: to create for ourselves a new field of objects beyond those which are
9010: presented to us as phenomena, and to stray into intelligible worlds;
9011: nay, it does not even allow us to endeavour to form so much as a
9012: conception of them. The specious error which leads to this—and which is
9013: a perfectly excusable one—lies in the fact that the employment of the
9014: understanding, contrary to its proper purpose and destination, is made
9015: transcendental, and objects, that is, possible intuitions, are made to
9016: regulate themselves according to conceptions, instead of the
9017: conceptions arranging themselves according to the intuitions, on which
9018: alone their own objective validity rests. Now the reason of this again
9019: is that apperception, and with it thought, antecedes all possible
9020: determinate arrangement of representations. Accordingly we think
9021: something in general and determine it on the one hand sensuously, but,
9022: on the other, distinguish the general and in abstracto represented
9023: object from this particular mode of intuiting it. In this case there
9024: remains a mode of determining the object by mere thought, which is
9025: really but a logical form without content, which, however, seems to us
9026: to be a mode of the existence of the object in itself (noumenon),
9027: without regard to intuition which is limited to our senses.
9028: 
9029: Before ending this transcendental analytic, we must make an addition,
9030: which, although in itself of no particular importance, seems to be
9031: necessary to the completeness of the system. The highest conception,
9032: with which a transcendental philosophy commonly begins, is the division
9033: into possible and impossible. But as all division presupposes a divided
9034: conception, a still higher one must exist, and this is the conception
9035: of an object in general—problematically understood and without its
9036: being decided whether it is something or nothing. As the categories are
9037: the only conceptions which apply to objects in general, the
9038: distinguishing of an object, whether it is something or nothing, must
9039: proceed according to the order and direction of the categories.
9040: 
9041: 1. To the categories of quantity, that is, the conceptions of all,
9042: many, and one, the conception which annihilates all, that is, the
9043: conception of none, is opposed. And thus the object of a conception, to
9044: which no intuition can be found to correspond, is = nothing. That is,
9045: it is a conception without an object (ens rationis), like noumena,
9046: which cannot be considered possible in the sphere of reality, though
9047: they must not therefore be held to be impossible—or like certain new
9048: fundamental forces in matter, the existence of which is cogitable
9049: without contradiction, though, as examples from experience are not
9050: forthcoming, they must not be regarded as possible.
9051: 
9052: 2. Reality is something; negation is nothing, that is, a conception of
9053: the absence of an object, as cold, a shadow (nihil privativum).
9054: 
9055: 3. The mere form of intuition, without substance, is in itself no
9056: object, but the merely formal condition of an object (as phenomenon),
9057: as pure space and pure time. These are certainly something, as forms of
9058: intuition, but are not themselves objects which are intuited (ens
9059: imaginarium).
9060: 
9061: 4. The object of a conception which is self-contradictory, is nothing,
9062: because the conception is nothing—is impossible, as a figure composed
9063: of two straight lines (nihil negativum).
9064: 
9065: The table of this division of the conception of nothing (the
9066: corresponding division of the conception of something does not require
9067: special description) must therefore be arranged as follows:
9068: 
9069:                       NOTHING
9070:                         AS
9071: 
9072:                         1
9073:                 As Empty Conception
9074:                  without object,
9075:                   _ens rationis_
9076:            2                               3
9077:      Empty object of               Empty intuition
9078:       a conception,                without object,
9079:      _nihil privativum              ens imaginarium_
9080:                         4
9081:                    Empty object
9082:                  without conception,
9083:                   _nihil negativum_
9084: 
9085: We see that the ens rationis is distinguished from the nihil negativum
9086: or pure nothing by the consideration that the former must not be
9087: reckoned among possibilities, because it is a mere fiction—though not
9088: self-contradictory, while the latter is completely opposed to all
9089: possibility, inasmuch as the conception annihilates itself. Both,
9090: however, are empty conceptions. On the other hand, the nihil privativum
9091: and ens imaginarium are empty data for conceptions. If light be not
9092: given to the senses, we cannot represent to ourselves darkness, and if
9093: extended objects are not perceived, we cannot represent space. Neither
9094: the negation, nor the mere form of intuition can, without something
9095: real, be an object.
9096: 
9097: SECOND DIVISION—TRANSCENDENTAL LOGIC
9098: 
9099: TRANSCENDENTAL DIALECTIC.
9100: INTRODUCTION.
9101: 
9102: I. Of Transcendental Illusory Appearance
9103: 
9104: We termed dialectic in general a logic of appearance. This does not
9105: signify a doctrine of probability; for probability is truth, only
9106: cognized upon insufficient grounds, and though the information it gives
9107: us is imperfect, it is not therefore deceitful. Hence it must not be
9108: separated from the analytical part of logic. Still less must phenomenon
9109: and appearance be held to be identical. For truth or illusory
9110: appearance does not reside in the object, in so far as it is intuited,
9111: but in the judgement upon the object, in so far as it is thought. It
9112: is, therefore, quite correct to say that the senses do not err, not
9113: because they always judge correctly, but because they do not judge at
9114: all. Hence truth and error, consequently also, illusory appearance as
9115: the cause of error, are only to be found in a judgement, that is, in
9116: the relation of an object to our understanding. In a cognition which
9117: completely harmonizes with the laws of the understanding, no error can
9118: exist. In a representation of the senses—as not containing any
9119: judgement—there is also no error. But no power of nature can of itself
9120: deviate from its own laws. Hence neither the understanding per se
9121: (without the influence of another cause), nor the senses per se, would
9122: fall into error; the former could not, because, if it acts only
9123: according to its own laws, the effect (the judgement) must necessarily
9124: accord with these laws. But in accordance with the laws of the
9125: understanding consists the formal element in all truth. In the senses
9126: there is no judgement—neither a true nor a false one. But, as we have
9127: no source of cognition besides these two, it follows that error is
9128: caused solely by the unobserved influence of the sensibility upon the
9129: understanding. And thus it happens that the subjective grounds of a
9130: judgement and are confounded with the objective, and cause them to
9131: deviate from their proper determination,[40] just as a body in motion
9132: would always of itself proceed in a straight line, but if another
9133: impetus gives to it a different direction, it will then start off into
9134: a curvilinear line of motion. To distinguish the peculiar action of the
9135: understanding from the power which mingles with it, it is necessary to
9136: consider an erroneous judgement as the diagonal between two forces,
9137: that determine the judgement in two different directions, which, as it
9138: were, form an angle, and to resolve this composite operation into the
9139: simple ones of the understanding and the sensibility. In pure à priori
9140: judgements this must be done by means of transcendental reflection,
9141: whereby, as has been already shown, each representation has its place
9142: appointed in the corresponding faculty of cognition, and consequently
9143: the influence of the one faculty upon the other is made apparent.
9144: 
9145:  [40] Sensibility, subjected to the understanding, as the object upon
9146:  which the understanding employs its functions, is the source of real
9147:  cognitions. But, in so far as it exercises an influence upon the
9148:  action of the understanding and determines it to judgement,
9149:  sensibility is itself the cause of error.
9150: 
9151: 
9152: It is not at present our business to treat of empirical illusory
9153: appearance (for example, optical illusion), which occurs in the
9154: empirical application of otherwise correct rules of the understanding,
9155: and in which the judgement is misled by the influence of imagination.
9156: Our purpose is to speak of transcendental illusory appearance, which
9157: influences principles—that are not even applied to experience, for in
9158: this case we should possess a sure test of their correctness—but which
9159: leads us, in disregard of all the warnings of criticism, completely
9160: beyond the empirical employment of the categories and deludes us with
9161: the chimera of an extension of the sphere of the pure understanding. We
9162: shall term those principles the application of which is confined
9163: entirely within the limits of possible experience, immanent; those, on
9164: the other hand, which transgress these limits, we shall call
9165: transcendent principles. But by these latter I do not understand
9166: principles of the transcendental use or misuse of the categories, which
9167: is in reality a mere fault of the judgement when not under due
9168: restraint from criticism, and therefore not paying sufficient attention
9169: to the limits of the sphere in which the pure understanding is allowed
9170: to exercise its functions; but real principles which exhort us to break
9171: down all those barriers, and to lay claim to a perfectly new field of
9172: cognition, which recognizes no line of demarcation. Thus transcendental
9173: and transcendent are not identical terms. The principles of the pure
9174: understanding, which we have already propounded, ought to be of
9175: empirical and not of transcendental use, that is, they are not
9176: applicable to any object beyond the sphere of experience. A principle
9177: which removes these limits, nay, which authorizes us to overstep them,
9178: is called transcendent. If our criticism can succeed in exposing the
9179: illusion in these pretended principles, those which are limited in
9180: their employment to the sphere of experience may be called, in
9181: opposition to the others, immanent principles of the pure
9182: understanding.
9183: 
9184: Logical illusion, which consists merely in the imitation of the form of
9185: reason (the illusion in sophistical syllogisms), arises entirely from a
9186: want of due attention to logical rules. So soon as the attention is
9187: awakened to the case before us, this illusion totally disappears.
9188: Transcendental illusion, on the contrary, does not cease to exist, even
9189: after it has been exposed, and its nothingness clearly perceived by
9190: means of transcendental criticism. Take, for example, the illusion in
9191: the proposition: “The world must have a beginning in time.” The cause
9192: of this is as follows. In our reason, subjectively considered as a
9193: faculty of human cognition, there exist fundamental rules and maxims of
9194: its exercise, which have completely the appearance of objective
9195: principles. Now from this cause it happens that the subjective
9196: necessity of a certain connection of our conceptions, is regarded as an
9197: objective necessity of the determination of things in themselves. This
9198: illusion it is impossible to avoid, just as we cannot avoid perceiving
9199: that the sea appears to be higher at a distance than it is near the
9200: shore, because we see the former by means of higher rays than the
9201: latter, or, which is a still stronger case, as even the astronomer
9202: cannot prevent himself from seeing the moon larger at its rising than
9203: some time afterwards, although he is not deceived by this illusion.
9204: 
9205: Transcendental dialectic will therefore content itself with exposing
9206: the illusory appearance in transcendental judgements, and guarding us
9207: against it; but to make it, as in the case of logical illusion,
9208: entirely disappear and cease to be illusion is utterly beyond its
9209: power. For we have here to do with a natural and unavoidable illusion,
9210: which rests upon subjective principles and imposes these upon us as
9211: objective, while logical dialectic, in the detection of sophisms, has
9212: to do merely with an error in the logical consequence of the
9213: propositions, or with an artificially constructed illusion, in
9214: imitation of the natural error. There is, therefore, a natural and
9215: unavoidable dialectic of pure reason—not that in which the bungler,
9216: from want of the requisite knowledge, involves himself, nor that which
9217: the sophist devises for the purpose of misleading, but that which is an
9218: inseparable adjunct of human reason, and which, even after its
9219: illusions have been exposed, does not cease to deceive, and continually
9220: to lead reason into momentary errors, which it becomes necessary
9221: continually to remove.
9222: 
9223: II. Of Pure Reason as the Seat of Transcendental Illusory Appearance
9224: 
9225: A. OF REASON IN GENERAL.
9226: 
9227: All our knowledge begins with sense, proceeds thence to understanding,
9228: and ends with reason, beyond which nothing higher can be discovered in
9229: the human mind for elaborating the matter of intuition and subjecting
9230: it to the highest unity of thought. At this stage of our inquiry it is
9231: my duty to give an explanation of this, the highest faculty of
9232: cognition, and I confess I find myself here in some difficulty. Of
9233: reason, as of the understanding, there is a merely formal, that is,
9234: logical use, in which it makes abstraction of all content of cognition;
9235: but there is also a real use, inasmuch as it contains in itself the
9236: source of certain conceptions and principles, which it does not borrow
9237: either from the senses or the understanding. The former faculty has
9238: been long defined by logicians as the faculty of mediate conclusion in
9239: contradistinction to immediate conclusions (consequentiae immediatae);
9240: but the nature of the latter, which itself generates conceptions, is
9241: not to be understood from this definition. Now as a division of reason
9242: into a logical and a transcendental faculty presents itself here, it
9243: becomes necessary to seek for a higher conception of this source of
9244: cognition which shall comprehend both conceptions. In this we may
9245: expect, according to the analogy of the conceptions of the
9246: understanding, that the logical conception will give us the key to the
9247: transcendental, and that the table of the functions of the former will
9248: present us with the clue to the conceptions of reason.
9249: 
9250: In the former part of our transcendental logic, we defined the
9251: understanding to be the faculty of rules; reason may be distinguished
9252: from understanding as the faculty of principles.
9253: 
9254: The term principle is ambiguous, and commonly signifies merely a
9255: cognition that may be employed as a principle, although it is not in
9256: itself, and as regards its proper origin, entitled to the distinction.
9257: Every general proposition, even if derived from experience by the
9258: process of induction, may serve as the major in a syllogism; but it is
9259: not for that reason a principle. Mathematical axioms (for example,
9260: there can be only one straight line between two points) are general à
9261: priori cognitions, and are therefore rightly denominated principles,
9262: relatively to the cases which can be subsumed under them. But I cannot
9263: for this reason say that I cognize this property of a straight line
9264: from principles—I cognize it only in pure intuition.
9265: 
9266: Cognition from principles, then, is that cognition in which I cognize
9267: the particular in the general by means of conceptions. Thus every
9268: syllogism is a form of the deduction of a cognition from a principle.
9269: For the major always gives a conception, through which everything that
9270: is subsumed under the condition thereof is cognized according to a
9271: principle. Now as every general cognition may serve as the major in a
9272: syllogism, and the understanding presents us with such general à priori
9273: propositions, they may be termed principles, in respect of their
9274: possible use.
9275: 
9276: But if we consider these principles of the pure understanding in
9277: relation to their origin, we shall find them to be anything rather than
9278: cognitions from conceptions. For they would not even be possible à
9279: priori, if we could not rely on the assistance of pure intuition (in
9280: mathematics), or on that of the conditions of a possible experience.
9281: That everything that happens has a cause, cannot be concluded from the
9282: general conception of that which happens; on the contrary the principle
9283: of causality instructs us as to the mode of obtaining from that which
9284: happens a determinate empirical conception.
9285: 
9286: Synthetical cognitions from conceptions the understanding cannot
9287: supply, and they alone are entitled to be called principles. At the
9288: same time, all general propositions may be termed comparative
9289: principles.
9290: 
9291: It has been a long-cherished wish—that (who knows how late), may one
9292: day, be happily accomplished—that the principles of the endless variety
9293: of civil laws should be investigated and exposed; for in this way alone
9294: can we find the secret of simplifying legislation. But in this case,
9295: laws are nothing more than limitations of our freedom upon conditions
9296: under which it subsists in perfect harmony with itself; they
9297: consequently have for their object that which is completely our own
9298: work, and of which we ourselves may be the cause by means of these
9299: conceptions. But how objects as things in themselves—how the nature of
9300: things is subordinated to principles and is to be determined, according
9301: to conceptions, is a question which it seems well nigh impossible to
9302: answer. Be this, however, as it may—for on this point our investigation
9303: is yet to be made—it is at least manifest from what we have said that
9304: cognition from principles is something very different from cognition by
9305: means of the understanding, which may indeed precede other cognitions
9306: in the form of a principle, but in itself—in so far as it is
9307: synthetical—is neither based upon mere thought, nor contains a general
9308: proposition drawn from conceptions alone.
9309: 
9310: The understanding may be a faculty for the production of unity of
9311: phenomena by virtue of rules; the reason is a faculty for the
9312: production of unity of rules (of the understanding) under principles.
9313: Reason, therefore, never applies directly to experience, or to any
9314: sensuous object; its object is, on the contrary, the understanding, to
9315: the manifold cognition of which it gives a unity à priori by means of
9316: conceptions—a unity which may be called rational unity, and which is of
9317: a nature very different from that of the unity produced by the
9318: understanding.
9319: 
9320: The above is the general conception of the faculty of reason, in so far
9321: as it has been possible to make it comprehensible in the absence of
9322: examples. These will be given in the sequel.
9323: 
9324: B. OF THE LOGICAL USE OF REASON.
9325: 
9326: A distinction is commonly made between that which is immediately
9327: cognized and that which is inferred or concluded. That in a figure
9328: which is bounded by three straight lines there are three angles, is an
9329: immediate cognition; but that these angles are together equal to two
9330: right angles, is an inference or conclusion. Now, as we are constantly
9331: employing this mode of thought and have thus become quite accustomed to
9332: it, we no longer remark the above distinction, and, as in the case of
9333: the so-called deceptions of sense, consider as immediately perceived,
9334: what has really been inferred. In every reasoning or syllogism, there
9335: is a fundamental proposition, afterwards a second drawn from it, and
9336: finally the conclusion, which connects the truth in the first with the
9337: truth in the second—and that infallibly. If the judgement concluded is
9338: so contained in the first proposition that it can be deduced from it
9339: without the meditation of a third notion, the conclusion is called
9340: immediate (consequentia immediata); I prefer the term conclusion of the
9341: understanding. But if, in addition to the fundamental cognition, a
9342: second judgement is necessary for the production of the conclusion, it
9343: is called a conclusion of the reason. In the proposition: All men are
9344: mortal, are contained the propositions: Some men are mortal, Nothing
9345: that is not mortal is a man, and these are therefore immediate
9346: conclusions from the first. On the other hand, the proposition: all the
9347: learned are mortal, is not contained in the main proposition (for the
9348: conception of a learned man does not occur in it), and it can be
9349: deduced from the main proposition only by means of a mediating
9350: judgement.
9351: 
9352: In every syllogism I first cogitate a rule (the major) by means of the
9353: understanding. In the next place I subsume a cognition under the
9354: condition of the rule (and this is the minor) by means of the
9355: judgement. And finally I determine my cognition by means of the
9356: predicate of the rule (this is the conclusio), consequently, I
9357: determine it à priori by means of the reason. The relations, therefore,
9358: which the major proposition, as the rule, represents between a
9359: cognition and its condition, constitute the different kinds of
9360: syllogisms. These are just threefold—analogously with all judgements,
9361: in so far as they differ in the mode of expressing the relation of a
9362: cognition in the understanding—namely, categorical, hypothetical, and
9363: disjunctive.
9364: 
9365: When as often happens, the conclusion is a judgement which may follow
9366: from other given judgements, through which a perfectly different object
9367: is cogitated, I endeavour to discover in the understanding whether the
9368: assertion in this conclusion does not stand under certain conditions
9369: according to a general rule. If I find such a condition, and if the
9370: object mentioned in the conclusion can be subsumed under the given
9371: condition, then this conclusion follows from a rule which is also valid
9372: for other objects of cognition. From this we see that reason endeavours
9373: to subject the great variety of the cognitions of the understanding to
9374: the smallest possible number of principles (general conditions), and
9375: thus to produce in it the highest unity.
9376: 
9377: C. OF THE PURE USE OF REASON.
9378: 
9379: Can we isolate reason, and, if so, is it in this case a peculiar source
9380: of conceptions and judgements which spring from it alone, and through
9381: which it can be applied to objects; or is it merely a subordinate
9382: faculty, whose duty it is to give a certain form to given cognitions—a
9383: form which is called logical, and through which the cognitions of the
9384: understanding are subordinated to each other, and lower rules to higher
9385: (those, to wit, whose condition comprises in its sphere the condition
9386: of the others), in so far as this can be done by comparison? This is
9387: the question which we have at present to answer. Manifold variety of
9388: rules and unity of principles is a requirement of reason, for the
9389: purpose of bringing the understanding into complete accordance with
9390: itself, just as understanding subjects the manifold content of
9391: intuition to conceptions, and thereby introduces connection into it.
9392: But this principle prescribes no law to objects, and does not contain
9393: any ground of the possibility of cognizing or of determining them as
9394: such, but is merely a subjective law for the proper arrangement of the
9395: content of the understanding. The purpose of this law is, by a
9396: comparison of the conceptions of the understanding, to reduce them to
9397: the smallest possible number, although, at the same time, it does not
9398: justify us in demanding from objects themselves such a uniformity as
9399: might contribute to the convenience and the enlargement of the sphere
9400: of the understanding, or in expecting that it will itself thus receive
9401: from them objective validity. In one word, the question is: “does
9402: reason in itself, that is, does pure reason contain à priori
9403: synthetical principles and rules, and what are those principles?”
9404: 
9405: The formal and logical procedure of reason in syllogisms gives us
9406: sufficient information in regard to the ground on which the
9407: transcendental principle of reason in its pure synthetical cognition
9408: will rest.
9409: 
9410: 1. Reason, as observed in the syllogistic process, is not applicable to
9411: intuitions, for the purpose of subjecting them to rules—for this is the
9412: province of the understanding with its categories—but to conceptions
9413: and judgements. If pure reason does apply to objects and the intuition
9414: of them, it does so not immediately, but mediately—through the
9415: understanding and its judgements, which have a direct relation to the
9416: senses and their intuition, for the purpose of determining their
9417: objects. The unity of reason is therefore not the unity of a possible
9418: experience, but is essentially different from this unity, which is that
9419: of the understanding. That everything which happens has a cause, is not
9420: a principle cognized and prescribed by reason. This principle makes the
9421: unity of experience possible and borrows nothing from reason, which,
9422: without a reference to possible experience, could never have produced
9423: by means of mere conceptions any such synthetical unity.
9424: 
9425: 2. Reason, in its logical use, endeavours to discover the general
9426: condition of its judgement (the conclusion), and a syllogism is itself
9427: nothing but a judgement by means of the subsumption of its condition
9428: under a general rule (the major). Now as this rule may itself be
9429: subjected to the same process of reason, and thus the condition of the
9430: condition be sought (by means of a prosyllogism) as long as the process
9431: can be continued, it is very manifest that the peculiar principle of
9432: reason in its logical use is to find for the conditioned cognition of
9433: the understanding the unconditioned whereby the unity of the former is
9434: completed.
9435: 
9436: But this logical maxim cannot be a principle of pure reason, unless we
9437: admit that, if the conditioned is given, the whole series of conditions
9438: subordinated to one another—a series which is consequently itself
9439: unconditioned—is also given, that is, contained in the object and its
9440: connection.
9441: 
9442: But this principle of pure reason is evidently synthetical; for,
9443: analytically, the conditioned certainly relates to some condition, but
9444: not to the unconditioned. From this principle also there must originate
9445: different synthetical propositions, of which the pure understanding is
9446: perfectly ignorant, for it has to do only with objects of a possible
9447: experience, the cognition and synthesis of which is always conditioned.
9448: The unconditioned, if it does really exist, must be especially
9449: considered in regard to the determinations which distinguish it from
9450: whatever is conditioned, and will thus afford us material for many à
9451: priori synthetical propositions.
9452: 
9453: The principles resulting from this highest principle of pure reason
9454: will, however, be transcendent in relation to phenomena, that is to
9455: say, it will be impossible to make any adequate empirical use of this
9456: principle. It is therefore completely different from all principles of
9457: the understanding, the use made of which is entirely immanent, their
9458: object and purpose being merely the possibility of experience. Now our
9459: duty in the transcendental dialectic is as follows. To discover whether
9460: the principle that the series of conditions (in the synthesis of
9461: phenomena, or of thought in general) extends to the unconditioned is
9462: objectively true, or not; what consequences result therefrom affecting
9463: the empirical use of the understanding, or rather whether there exists
9464: any such objectively valid proposition of reason, and whether it is
9465: not, on the contrary, a merely logical precept which directs us to
9466: ascend perpetually to still higher conditions, to approach completeness
9467: in the series of them, and thus to introduce into our cognition the
9468: highest possible unity of reason. We must ascertain, I say, whether
9469: this requirement of reason has not been regarded, by a
9470: misunderstanding, as a transcendental principle of pure reason, which
9471: postulates a thorough completeness in the series of conditions in
9472: objects themselves. We must show, moreover, the misconceptions and
9473: illusions that intrude into syllogisms, the major proposition of which
9474: pure reason has supplied—a proposition which has perhaps more of the
9475: character of a petitio than of a postulatum—and that proceed from
9476: experience upwards to its conditions. The solution of these problems is
9477: our task in transcendental dialectic, which we are about to expose even
9478: at its source, that lies deep in human reason. We shall divide it into
9479: two parts, the first of which will treat of the transcendent
9480: conceptions of pure reason, the second of transcendent and dialectical
9481: syllogisms.
9482: 
9483: TRANSCENDENTAL DIALECTIC—BOOK I—OF THE CONCEPTIONS OF PURE REASON.
9484: 
9485: The conceptions of pure reason—we do not here speak of the possibility
9486: of them—are not obtained by reflection, but by inference or conclusion.
9487: The conceptions of understanding are also cogitated à priori
9488: antecedently to experience, and render it possible; but they contain
9489: nothing but the unity of reflection upon phenomena, in so far as these
9490: must necessarily belong to a possible empirical consciousness. Through
9491: them alone are cognition and the determination of an object possible.
9492: It is from them, accordingly, that we receive material for reasoning,
9493: and antecedently to them we possess no à priori conceptions of objects
9494: from which they might be deduced, On the other hand, the sole basis of
9495: their objective reality consists in the necessity imposed on them, as
9496: containing the intellectual form of all experience, of restricting
9497: their application and influence to the sphere of experience.
9498: 
9499: But the term, conception of reason, or rational conception, itself
9500: indicates that it does not confine itself within the limits of
9501: experience, because its object-matter is a cognition, of which every
9502: empirical cognition is but a part—nay, the whole of possible experience
9503: may be itself but a part of it—a cognition to which no actual
9504: experience ever fully attains, although it does always pertain to it.
9505: The aim of rational conceptions is the comprehension, as that of the
9506: conceptions of understanding is the understanding of perceptions. If
9507: they contain the unconditioned, they relate to that to which all
9508: experience is subordinate, but which is never itself an object of
9509: experience—that towards which reason tends in all its conclusions from
9510: experience, and by the standard of which it estimates the degree of
9511: their empirical use, but which is never itself an element in an
9512: empirical synthesis. If, notwithstanding, such conceptions possess
9513: objective validity, they may be called conceptus ratiocinati
9514: (conceptions legitimately concluded); in cases where they do not, they
9515: have been admitted on account of having the appearance of being
9516: correctly concluded, and may be called conceptus ratiocinantes
9517: (sophistical conceptions). But as this can only be sufficiently
9518: demonstrated in that part of our treatise which relates to the
9519: dialectical conclusions of reason, we shall omit any consideration of
9520: it in this place. As we called the pure conceptions of the
9521: understanding categories, we shall also distinguish those of pure
9522: reason by a new name and call them transcendental ideas. These terms,
9523: however, we must in the first place explain and justify.
9524: 
9525: Section I—Of Ideas in General
9526: 
9527: Despite the great wealth of words which European languages possess, the
9528: thinker finds himself often at a loss for an expression exactly suited
9529: to his conception, for want of which he is unable to make himself
9530: intelligible either to others or to himself. To coin new words is a
9531: pretension to legislation in language which is seldom successful; and,
9532: before recourse is taken to so desperate an expedient, it is advisable
9533: to examine the dead and learned languages, with the hope and the
9534: probability that we may there meet with some adequate expression of the
9535: notion we have in our minds. In this case, even if the original meaning
9536: of the word has become somewhat uncertain, from carelessness or want of
9537: caution on the part of the authors of it, it is always better to adhere
9538: to and confirm its proper meaning—even although it may be doubtful
9539: whether it was formerly used in exactly this sense—than to make our
9540: labour vain by want of sufficient care to render ourselves
9541: intelligible.
9542: 
9543: For this reason, when it happens that there exists only a single word
9544: to express a certain conception, and this word, in its usual
9545: acceptation, is thoroughly adequate to the conception, the accurate
9546: distinction of which from related conceptions is of great importance,
9547: we ought not to employ the expression improvidently, or, for the sake
9548: of variety and elegance of style, use it as a synonym for other cognate
9549: words. It is our duty, on the contrary, carefully to preserve its
9550: peculiar signification, as otherwise it easily happens that when the
9551: attention of the reader is no longer particularly attracted to the
9552: expression, and it is lost amid the multitude of other words of very
9553: different import, the thought which it conveyed, and which it alone
9554: conveyed, is lost with it.
9555: 
9556: Plato employed the expression idea in a way that plainly showed he
9557: meant by it something which is never derived from the senses, but which
9558: far transcends even the conceptions of the understanding (with which
9559: Aristotle occupied himself), inasmuch as in experience nothing
9560: perfectly corresponding to them could be found. Ideas are, according to
9561: him, archetypes of things themselves, and not merely keys to possible
9562: experiences, like the categories. In his view they flow from the
9563: highest reason, by which they have been imparted to human reason,
9564: which, however, exists no longer in its original state, but is obliged
9565: with great labour to recall by reminiscence—which is called
9566: philosophy—the old but now sadly obscured ideas. I will not here enter
9567: upon any literary investigation of the sense which this sublime
9568: philosopher attached to this expression. I shall content myself with
9569: remarking that it is nothing unusual, in common conversation as well as
9570: in written works, by comparing the thoughts which an author has
9571: delivered upon a subject, to understand him better than he understood
9572: himself inasmuch as he may not have sufficiently determined his
9573: conception, and thus have sometimes spoken, nay even thought, in
9574: opposition to his own opinions.
9575: 
9576: Plato perceived very clearly that our faculty of cognition has the
9577: feeling of a much higher vocation than that of merely spelling out
9578: phenomena according to synthetical unity, for the purpose of being able
9579: to read them as experience, and that our reason naturally raises itself
9580: to cognitions far too elevated to admit of the possibility of an object
9581: given by experience corresponding to them—cognitions which are
9582: nevertheless real, and are not mere phantoms of the brain.
9583: 
9584: This philosopher found his ideas especially in all that is
9585: practical,[41] that is, which rests upon freedom, which in its turn
9586: ranks under cognitions that are the peculiar product of reason. He who
9587: would derive from experience the conceptions of virtue, who would make
9588: (as many have really done) that, which at best can but serve as an
9589: imperfectly illustrative example, a model for or the formation of a
9590: perfectly adequate idea on the subject, would in fact transform virtue
9591: into a nonentity changeable according to time and circumstance and
9592: utterly incapable of being employed as a rule. On the contrary, every
9593: one is conscious that, when any one is held up to him as a model of
9594: virtue, he compares this so-called model with the true original which
9595: he possesses in his own mind and values him according to this standard.
9596: But this standard is the idea of virtue, in relation to which all
9597: possible objects of experience are indeed serviceable as
9598: examples—proofs of the practicability in a certain degree of that which
9599: the conception of virtue demands—but certainly not as archetypes. That
9600: the actions of man will never be in perfect accordance with all the
9601: requirements of the pure ideas of reason, does not prove the thought to
9602: be chimerical. For only through this idea are all judgements as to
9603: moral merit or demerit possible; it consequently lies at the foundation
9604: of every approach to moral perfection, however far removed from it the
9605: obstacles in human nature—indeterminable as to degree—may keep us.
9606: 
9607:  [41] He certainly extended the application of his conception to
9608:  speculative cognitions also, provided they were given pure and
9609:  completely à priori, nay, even to mathematics, although this science
9610:  cannot possess an object otherwhere than in Possible experience. I
9611:  cannot follow him in this, and as little can I follow him in his
9612:  mystical deduction of these ideas, or in his hypostatization of them;
9613:  although, in truth, the elevated and exaggerated language which he
9614:  employed in describing them is quite capable of an interpretation more
9615:  subdued and more in accordance with fact and the nature of things.
9616: 
9617: 
9618: The Platonic Republic has become proverbial as an example—and a
9619: striking one—of imaginary perfection, such as can exist only in the
9620: brain of the idle thinker; and Brucker ridicules the philosopher for
9621: maintaining that a prince can never govern well, unless he is
9622: participant in the ideas. But we should do better to follow up this
9623: thought and, where this admirable thinker leaves us without assistance,
9624: employ new efforts to place it in clearer light, rather than carelessly
9625: fling it aside as useless, under the very miserable and pernicious
9626: pretext of impracticability. A constitution of the greatest possible
9627: human freedom according to laws, by which the liberty of every
9628: individual can consist with the liberty of every other (not of the
9629: greatest possible happiness, for this follows necessarily from the
9630: former), is, to say the least, a necessary idea, which must be placed
9631: at the foundation not only of the first plan of the constitution of a
9632: state, but of all its laws. And, in this, it not necessary at the
9633: outset to take account of the obstacles which lie in our way—obstacles
9634: which perhaps do not necessarily arise from the character of human
9635: nature, but rather from the previous neglect of true ideas in
9636: legislation. For there is nothing more pernicious and more unworthy of
9637: a philosopher, than the vulgar appeal to a so-called adverse
9638: experience, which indeed would not have existed, if those institutions
9639: had been established at the proper time and in accordance with ideas;
9640: while, instead of this, conceptions, crude for the very reason that
9641: they have been drawn from experience, have marred and frustrated all
9642: our better views and intentions. The more legislation and government
9643: are in harmony with this idea, the more rare do punishments become and
9644: thus it is quite reasonable to maintain, as Plato did, that in a
9645: perfect state no punishments at all would be necessary. Now although a
9646: perfect state may never exist, the idea is not on that account the less
9647: just, which holds up this maximum as the archetype or standard of a
9648: constitution, in order to bring legislative government always nearer
9649: and nearer to the greatest possible perfection. For at what precise
9650: degree human nature must stop in its progress, and how wide must be the
9651: chasm which must necessarily exist between the idea and its
9652: realization, are problems which no one can or ought to determine—and
9653: for this reason, that it is the destination of freedom to overstep all
9654: assigned limits between itself and the idea.
9655: 
9656: But not only in that wherein human reason is a real causal agent and
9657: where ideas are operative causes (of actions and their objects), that
9658: is to say, in the region of ethics, but also in regard to nature
9659: herself, Plato saw clear proofs of an origin from ideas. A plant, and
9660: animal, the regular order of nature—probably also the disposition of
9661: the whole universe—give manifest evidence that they are possible only
9662: by means of and according to ideas; that, indeed, no one creature,
