9663: under the individual conditions of its existence, perfectly harmonizes
9664: with the idea of the most perfect of its kind—just as little as man
9665: with the idea of humanity, which nevertheless he bears in his soul as
9666: the archetypal standard of his actions; that, notwithstanding, these
9667: ideas are in the highest sense individually, unchangeably, and
9668: completely determined, and are the original causes of things; and that
9669: the totality of connected objects in the universe is alone fully
9670: adequate to that idea. Setting aside the exaggerations of expression in
9671: the writings of this philosopher, the mental power exhibited in this
9672: ascent from the ectypal mode of regarding the physical world to the
9673: architectonic connection thereof according to ends, that is, ideas, is
9674: an effort which deserves imitation and claims respect. But as regards
9675: the principles of ethics, of legislation, and of religion, spheres in
9676: which ideas alone render experience possible, although they never
9677: attain to full expression therein, he has vindicated for himself a
9678: position of peculiar merit, which is not appreciated only because it is
9679: judged by the very empirical rules, the validity of which as principles
9680: is destroyed by ideas. For as regards nature, experience presents us
9681: with rules and is the source of truth, but in relation to ethical laws
9682: experience is the parent of illusion, and it is in the highest degree
9683: reprehensible to limit or to deduce the laws which dictate what I ought
9684: to do, from what is done.
9685: 
9686: We must, however, omit the consideration of these important subjects,
9687: the development of which is in reality the peculiar duty and dignity of
9688: philosophy, and confine ourselves for the present to the more humble
9689: but not less useful task of preparing a firm foundation for those
9690: majestic edifices of moral science. For this foundation has been
9691: hitherto insecure from the many subterranean passages which reason in
9692: its confident but vain search for treasures has made in all directions.
9693: Our present duty is to make ourselves perfectly acquainted with the
9694: transcendental use made of pure reason, its principles and ideas, that
9695: we may be able properly to determine and value its influence and real
9696: worth. But before bringing these introductory remarks to a close, I beg
9697: those who really have philosophy at heart—and their number is but
9698: small—if they shall find themselves convinced by the considerations
9699: following as well as by those above, to exert themselves to preserve to
9700: the expression idea its original signification, and to take care that
9701: it be not lost among those other expressions by which all sorts of
9702: representations are loosely designated—that the interests of science
9703: may not thereby suffer. We are in no want of words to denominate
9704: adequately every mode of representation, without the necessity of
9705: encroaching upon terms which are proper to others. The following is a
9706: graduated list of them. The genus is representation in general
9707: (representatio). Under it stands representation with consciousness
9708: (perceptio). A perception which relates solely to the subject as a
9709: modification of its state, is a sensation (sensatio), an objective
9710: perception is a cognition (cognitio). A cognition is either an
9711: intuition or a conception (intuitus vel conceptus). The former has an
9712: immediate relation to the object and is singular and individual; the
9713: latter has but a mediate relation, by means of a characteristic mark
9714: which may be common to several things. A conception is either empirical
9715: or pure. A pure conception, in so far as it has its origin in the
9716: understanding alone, and is not the conception of a pure sensuous
9717: image, is called notio. A conception formed from notions, which
9718: transcends the possibility of experience, is an idea, or a conception
9719: of reason. To one who has accustomed himself to these distinctions, it
9720: must be quite intolerable to hear the representation of the colour red
9721: called an idea. It ought not even to be called a notion or conception
9722: of understanding.
9723: 
9724: Section II. Of Transcendental Ideas
9725: 
9726: Transcendental analytic showed us how the mere logical form of our
9727: cognition can contain the origin of pure conceptions à priori,
9728: conceptions which represent objects antecedently to all experience, or
9729: rather, indicate the synthetical unity which alone renders possible an
9730: empirical cognition of objects. The form of judgements—converted into a
9731: conception of the synthesis of intuitions—produced the categories which
9732: direct the employment of the understanding in experience. This
9733: consideration warrants us to expect that the form of syllogisms, when
9734: applied to synthetical unity of intuitions, following the rule of the
9735: categories, will contain the origin of particular à priori conceptions,
9736: which we may call pure conceptions of reason or transcendental ideas,
9737: and which will determine the use of the understanding in the totality
9738: of experience according to principles.
9739: 
9740: The function of reason in arguments consists in the universality of a
9741: cognition according to conceptions, and the syllogism itself is a
9742: judgement which is determined à priori in the whole extent of its
9743: condition. The proposition: “Caius is mortal,” is one which may be
9744: obtained from experience by the aid of the understanding alone; but my
9745: wish is to find a conception which contains the condition under which
9746: the predicate of this judgement is given—in this case, the conception
9747: of man—and after subsuming under this condition, taken in its whole
9748: extent (all men are mortal), I determine according to it the cognition
9749: of the object thought, and say: “Caius is mortal.”
9750: 
9751: Hence, in the conclusion of a syllogism we restrict a predicate to a
9752: certain object, after having thought it in the major in its whole
9753: extent under a certain condition. This complete quantity of the extent
9754: in relation to such a condition is called universality (universalitas).
9755: To this corresponds totality (universitas) of conditions in the
9756: synthesis of intuitions. The transcendental conception of reason is
9757: therefore nothing else than the conception of the totality of the
9758: conditions of a given conditioned. Now as the unconditioned alone
9759: renders possible totality of conditions, and, conversely, the totality
9760: of conditions is itself always unconditioned; a pure rational
9761: conception in general can be defined and explained by means of the
9762: conception of the unconditioned, in so far as it contains a basis for
9763: the synthesis of the conditioned.
9764: 
9765: To the number of modes of relation which the understanding cogitates by
9766: means of the categories, the number of pure rational conceptions will
9767: correspond. We must therefore seek for, first, an unconditioned of the
9768: categorical synthesis in a subject; secondly, of the hypothetical
9769: synthesis of the members of a series; thirdly, of the disjunctive
9770: synthesis of parts in a system.
9771: 
9772: There are exactly the same number of modes of syllogisms, each of which
9773: proceeds through prosyllogisms to the unconditioned—one to the subject
9774: which cannot be employed as predicate, another to the presupposition
9775: which supposes nothing higher than itself, and the third to an
9776: aggregate of the members of the complete division of a conception.
9777: Hence the pure rational conceptions of totality in the synthesis of
9778: conditions have a necessary foundation in the nature of human reason—at
9779: least as modes of elevating the unity of the understanding to the
9780: unconditioned. They may have no valid application, corresponding to
9781: their transcendental employment, in concreto, and be thus of no greater
9782: utility than to direct the understanding how, while extending them as
9783: widely as possible, to maintain its exercise and application in perfect
9784: consistence and harmony.
9785: 
9786: But, while speaking here of the totality of conditions and of the
9787: unconditioned as the common title of all conceptions of reason, we
9788: again light upon an expression which we find it impossible to dispense
9789: with, and which nevertheless, owing to the ambiguity attaching to it
9790: from long abuse, we cannot employ with safety. The word absolute is one
9791: of the few words which, in its original signification, was perfectly
9792: adequate to the conception it was intended to convey—a conception which
9793: no other word in the same language exactly suits, and the loss—or,
9794: which is the same thing, the incautious and loose employment—of which
9795: must be followed by the loss of the conception itself. And, as it is a
9796: conception which occupies much of the attention of reason, its loss
9797: would be greatly to the detriment of all transcendental philosophy. The
9798: word absolute is at present frequently used to denote that something
9799: can be predicated of a thing considered in itself and intrinsically. In
9800: this sense absolutely possible would signify that which is possible in
9801: itself (interne)—which is, in fact, the least that one can predicate of
9802: an object. On the other hand, it is sometimes employed to indicate that
9803: a thing is valid in all respects—for example, absolute sovereignty.
9804: Absolutely possible would in this sense signify that which is possible
9805: in all relations and in every respect; and this is the most that can be
9806: predicated of the possibility of a thing. Now these significations do
9807: in truth frequently coincide. Thus, for example, that which is
9808: intrinsically impossible, is also impossible in all relations, that is,
9809: absolutely impossible. But in most cases they differ from each other
9810: toto caelo, and I can by no means conclude that, because a thing is in
9811: itself possible, it is also possible in all relations, and therefore
9812: absolutely. Nay, more, I shall in the sequel show that absolute
9813: necessity does not by any means depend on internal necessity, and that,
9814: therefore, it must not be considered as synonymous with it. Of an
9815: opposite which is intrinsically impossible, we may affirm that it is in
9816: all respects impossible, and that, consequently, the thing itself, of
9817: which this is the opposite, is absolutely necessary; but I cannot
9818: reason conversely and say, the opposite of that which is absolutely
9819: necessary is intrinsically impossible, that is, that the absolute
9820: necessity of things is an internal necessity. For this internal
9821: necessity is in certain cases a mere empty word with which the least
9822: conception cannot be connected, while the conception of the necessity
9823: of a thing in all relations possesses very peculiar determinations. Now
9824: as the loss of a conception of great utility in speculative science
9825: cannot be a matter of indifference to the philosopher, I trust that the
9826: proper determination and careful preservation of the expression on
9827: which the conception depends will likewise be not indifferent to him.
9828: 
9829: In this enlarged signification, then, shall I employ the word absolute,
9830: in opposition to that which is valid only in some particular respect;
9831: for the latter is restricted by conditions, the former is valid without
9832: any restriction whatever.
9833: 
9834: Now the transcendental conception of reason has for its object nothing
9835: else than absolute totality in the synthesis of conditions and does not
9836: rest satisfied till it has attained to the absolutely, that is, in all
9837: respects and relations, unconditioned. For pure reason leaves to the
9838: understanding everything that immediately relates to the object of
9839: intuition or rather to their synthesis in imagination. The former
9840: restricts itself to the absolute totality in the employment of the
9841: conceptions of the understanding and aims at carrying out the
9842: synthetical unity which is cogitated in the category, even to the
9843: unconditioned. This unity may hence be called the rational unity of
9844: phenomena, as the other, which the category expresses, may be termed
9845: the unity of the understanding. Reason, therefore, has an immediate
9846: relation to the use of the understanding, not indeed in so far as the
9847: latter contains the ground of possible experience (for the conception
9848: of the absolute totality of conditions is not a conception that can be
9849: employed in experience, because no experience is unconditioned), but
9850: solely for the purpose of directing it to a certain unity, of which the
9851: understanding has no conception, and the aim of which is to collect
9852: into an absolute whole all acts of the understanding. Hence the
9853: objective employment of the pure conceptions of reason is always
9854: transcendent, while that of the pure conceptions of the understanding
9855: must, according to their nature, be always immanent, inasmuch as they
9856: are limited to possible experience.
9857: 
9858: I understand by idea a necessary conception of reason, to which no
9859: corresponding object can be discovered in the world of sense.
9860: Accordingly, the pure conceptions of reason at present under
9861: consideration are transcendental ideas. They are conceptions of pure
9862: reason, for they regard all empirical cognition as determined by means
9863: of an absolute totality of conditions. They are not mere fictions, but
9864: natural and necessary products of reason, and have hence a necessary
9865: relation to the whole sphere of the exercise of the understanding. And,
9866: finally, they are transcendent, and overstep the limits of all
9867: experiences, in which, consequently, no object can ever be presented
9868: that would be perfectly adequate to a transcendental idea. When we use
9869: the word idea, we say, as regards its object (an object of the pure
9870: understanding), a great deal, but as regards its subject (that is, in
9871: respect of its reality under conditions of experience), exceedingly
9872: little, because the idea, as the conception of a maximum, can never be
9873: completely and adequately presented in concreto. Now, as in the merely
9874: speculative employment of reason the latter is properly the sole aim,
9875: and as in this case the approximation to a conception, which is never
9876: attained in practice, is the same thing as if the conception were
9877: non-existent—it is commonly said of the conception of this kind, “it is
9878: only an idea.” So we might very well say, “the absolute totality of all
9879: phenomena is only an idea,” for, as we never can present an adequate
9880: representation of it, it remains for us a problem incapable of
9881: solution. On the other hand, as in the practical use of the
9882: understanding we have only to do with action and practice according to
9883: rules, an idea of pure reason can always be given really in concreto,
9884: although only partially, nay, it is the indispensable condition of all
9885: practical employment of reason. The practice or execution of the idea
9886: is always limited and defective, but nevertheless within indeterminable
9887: boundaries, consequently always under the influence of the conception
9888: of an absolute perfection. And thus the practical idea is always in the
9889: highest degree fruitful, and in relation to real actions indispensably
9890: necessary. In the idea, pure reason possesses even causality and the
9891: power of producing that which its conception contains. Hence we cannot
9892: say of wisdom, in a disparaging way, “it is only an idea.” For, for the
9893: very reason that it is the idea of the necessary unity of all possible
9894: aims, it must be for all practical exertions and endeavours the
9895: primitive condition and rule—a rule which, if not constitutive, is at
9896: least limitative.
9897: 
9898: Now, although we must say of the transcendental conceptions of reason,
9899: “they are only ideas,” we must not, on this account, look upon them as
9900: superfluous and nugatory. For, although no object can be determined by
9901: them, they can be of great utility, unobserved and at the basis of the
9902: edifice of the understanding, as the canon for its extended and
9903: self-consistent exercise—a canon which, indeed, does not enable it to
9904: cognize more in an object than it would cognize by the help of its own
9905: conceptions, but which guides it more securely in its cognition. Not to
9906: mention that they perhaps render possible a transition from our
9907: conceptions of nature and the non-ego to the practical conceptions, and
9908: thus produce for even ethical ideas keeping, so to speak, and
9909: connection with the speculative cognitions of reason. The explication
9910: of all this must be looked for in the sequel.
9911: 
9912: But setting aside, in conformity with our original purpose, the
9913: consideration of the practical ideas, we proceed to contemplate reason
9914: in its speculative use alone, nay, in a still more restricted sphere,
9915: to wit, in the transcendental use; and here must strike into the same
9916: path which we followed in our deduction of the categories. That is to
9917: say, we shall consider the logical form of the cognition of reason,
9918: that we may see whether reason may not be thereby a source of
9919: conceptions which enables us to regard objects in themselves as
9920: determined synthetically à priori, in relation to one or other of the
9921: functions of reason.
9922: 
9923: Reason, considered as the faculty of a certain logical form of
9924: cognition, is the faculty of conclusion, that is, of mediate
9925: judgement—by means of the subsumption of the condition of a possible
9926: judgement under the condition of a given judgement. The given judgement
9927: is the general rule (major). The subsumption of the condition of
9928: another possible judgement under the condition of the rule is the
9929: minor. The actual judgement, which enounces the assertion of the rule
9930: in the subsumed case, is the conclusion (conclusio). The rule
9931: predicates something generally under a certain condition. The condition
9932: of the rule is satisfied in some particular case. It follows that what
9933: was valid in general under that condition must also be considered as
9934: valid in the particular case which satisfies this condition. It is very
9935: plain that reason attains to a cognition, by means of acts of the
9936: understanding which constitute a series of conditions. When I arrive at
9937: the proposition, “All bodies are changeable,” by beginning with the
9938: more remote cognition (in which the conception of body does not appear,
9939: but which nevertheless contains the condition of that conception), “All
9940: compound is changeable,” by proceeding from this to a less remote
9941: cognition, which stands under the condition of the former, “Bodies are
9942: compound,” and hence to a third, which at length connects for me the
9943: remote cognition (changeable) with the one before me, “Consequently,
9944: bodies are changeable”—I have arrived at a cognition (conclusion)
9945: through a series of conditions (premisses). Now every series, whose
9946: exponent (of the categorical or hypothetical judgement) is given, can
9947: be continued; consequently the same procedure of reason conducts us to
9948: the ratiocinatio polysyllogistica, which is a series of syllogisms,
9949: that can be continued either on the side of the conditions (per
9950: prosyllogismos) or of the conditioned (per episyllogismos) to an
9951: indefinite extent.
9952: 
9953: But we very soon perceive that the chain or series of prosyllogisms,
9954: that is, of deduced cognitions on the side of the grounds or conditions
9955: of a given cognition, in other words, the ascending series of
9956: syllogisms must have a very different relation to the faculty of reason
9957: from that of the descending series, that is, the progressive procedure
9958: of reason on the side of the conditioned by means of episyllogisms.
9959: For, as in the former case the cognition (conclusio) is given only as
9960: conditioned, reason can attain to this cognition only under the
9961: presupposition that all the members of the series on the side of the
9962: conditions are given (totality in the series of premisses), because
9963: only under this supposition is the judgement we may be considering
9964: possible à priori; while on the side of the conditioned or the
9965: inferences, only an incomplete and becoming, and not a presupposed or
9966: given series, consequently only a potential progression, is cogitated.
9967: Hence, when a cognition is contemplated as conditioned, reason is
9968: compelled to consider the series of conditions in an ascending line as
9969: completed and given in their totality. But if the very same condition
9970: is considered at the same time as the condition of other cognitions,
9971: which together constitute a series of inferences or consequences in a
9972: descending line, reason may preserve a perfect indifference, as to how
9973: far this progression may extend _a parte posteriori_, and whether the
9974: totality of this series is possible, because it stands in no need of
9975: such a series for the purpose of arriving at the conclusion before it,
9976: inasmuch as this conclusion is sufficiently guaranteed and determined
9977: on grounds a parte priori. It may be the case, that upon the side of
9978: the conditions the series of premisses has a first or highest
9979: condition, or it may not possess this, and so be a parte priori
9980: unlimited; but it must, nevertheless, contain totality of conditions,
9981: even admitting that we never could succeed in completely apprehending
9982: it; and the whole series must be unconditionally true, if the
9983: conditioned, which is considered as an inference resulting from it, is
9984: to be held as true. This is a requirement of reason, which announces
9985: its cognition as determined à priori and as necessary, either in
9986: itself—and in this case it needs no grounds to rest upon—or, if it is
9987: deduced, as a member of a series of grounds, which is itself
9988: unconditionally true.
9989: 
9990: Section III. System of Transcendental Ideas
9991: 
9992: We are not at present engaged with a logical dialectic, which makes
9993: complete abstraction of the content of cognition and aims only at
9994: unveiling the illusory appearance in the form of syllogisms. Our
9995: subject is transcendental dialectic, which must contain, completely à
9996: priori, the origin of certain cognitions drawn from pure reason, and
9997: the origin of certain deduced conceptions, the object of which cannot
9998: be given empirically and which therefore lie beyond the sphere of the
9999: faculty of understanding. We have observed, from the natural relation
10000: which the transcendental use of our cognition, in syllogisms as well as
10001: in judgements, must have to the logical, that there are three kinds of
10002: dialectical arguments, corresponding to the three modes of conclusion,
10003: by which reason attains to cognitions on principles; and that in all it
10004: is the business of reason to ascend from the conditioned synthesis,
10005: beyond which the understanding never proceeds, to the unconditioned
10006: which the understanding never can reach.
10007: 
10008: Now the most general relations which can exist in our representations
10009: are: 1st, the relation to the subject; 2nd, the relation to objects,
10010: either as phenomena, or as objects of thought in general. If we connect
10011: this subdivision with the main division, all the relations of our
10012: representations, of which we can form either a conception or an idea,
10013: are threefold: 1. The relation to the subject; 2. The relation to the
10014: manifold of the object as a phenomenon; 3. The relation to all things
10015: in general.
10016: 
10017: Now all pure conceptions have to do in general with the synthetical
10018: unity of representations; conceptions of pure reason (transcendental
10019: ideas), on the other hand, with the unconditional synthetical unity of
10020: all conditions. It follows that all transcendental ideas arrange
10021: themselves in three classes, the first of which contains the absolute
10022: (unconditioned) unity of the thinking subject, the second the absolute
10023: unity of the series of the conditions of a phenomenon, the third the
10024: absolute unity of the condition of all objects of thought in general.
10025: 
10026: The thinking subject is the object-matter of Psychology; the sum total
10027: of all phenomena (the world) is the object-matter of Cosmology; and the
10028: thing which contains the highest condition of the possibility of all
10029: that is cogitable (the being of all beings) is the object-matter of all
10030: Theology. Thus pure reason presents us with the idea of a
10031: transcendental doctrine of the soul (psychologia rationalis), of a
10032: transcendental science of the world (cosmologia rationalis), and
10033: finally of a transcendental doctrine of God (theologia
10034: transcendentalis). Understanding cannot originate even the outline of
10035: any of these sciences, even when connected with the highest logical use
10036: of reason, that is, all cogitable syllogisms—for the purpose of
10037: proceeding from one object (phenomenon) to all others, even to the
10038: utmost limits of the empirical synthesis. They are, on the contrary,
10039: pure and genuine products, or problems, of pure reason.
10040: 
10041: What modi of the pure conceptions of reason these transcendental ideas
10042: are will be fully exposed in the following chapter. They follow the
10043: guiding thread of the categories. For pure reason never relates
10044: immediately to objects, but to the conceptions of these contained in
10045: the understanding. In like manner, it will be made manifest in the
10046: detailed explanation of these ideas—how reason, merely through the
10047: synthetical use of the same function which it employs in a categorical
10048: syllogism, necessarily attains to the conception of the absolute unity
10049: of the thinking subject—how the logical procedure in hypothetical ideas
10050: necessarily produces the idea of the absolutely unconditioned in a
10051: series of given conditions, and finally—how the mere form of the
10052: disjunctive syllogism involves the highest conception of a being of all
10053: beings: a thought which at first sight seems in the highest degree
10054: paradoxical.
10055: 
10056: An objective deduction, such as we were able to present in the case of
10057: the categories, is impossible as regards these transcendental ideas.
10058: For they have, in truth, no relation to any object, in experience, for
10059: the very reason that they are only ideas. But a subjective deduction of
10060: them from the nature of our reason is possible, and has been given in
10061: the present chapter.
10062: 
10063: It is easy to perceive that the sole aim of pure reason is the absolute
10064: totality of the synthesis on the side of the conditions, and that it
10065: does not concern itself with the absolute completeness on the Part of
10066: the conditioned. For of the former alone does she stand in need, in
10067: order to preposit the whole series of conditions, and thus present them
10068: to the understanding à priori. But if we once have a completely (and
10069: unconditionally) given condition, there is no further necessity, in
10070: proceeding with the series, for a conception of reason; for the
10071: understanding takes of itself every step downward, from the condition
10072: to the conditioned. Thus the transcendental ideas are available only
10073: for ascending in the series of conditions, till we reach the
10074: unconditioned, that is, principles. As regards descending to the
10075: conditioned, on the other hand, we find that there is a widely
10076: extensive logical use which reason makes of the laws of the
10077: understanding, but that a transcendental use thereof is impossible; and
10078: that when we form an idea of the absolute totality of such a synthesis,
10079: for example, of the whole series of all future changes in the world,
10080: this idea is a mere ens rationis, an arbitrary fiction of thought, and
10081: not a necessary presupposition of reason. For the possibility of the
10082: conditioned presupposes the totality of its conditions, but not of its
10083: consequences. Consequently, this conception is not a transcendental
10084: idea—and it is with these alone that we are at present occupied.
10085: 
10086: Finally, it is obvious that there exists among the transcendental ideas
10087: a certain connection and unity, and that pure reason, by means of them,
10088: collects all its cognitions into one system. From the cognition of self
10089: to the cognition of the world, and through these to the supreme being,
10090: the progression is so natural, that it seems to resemble the logical
10091: march of reason from the premisses to the conclusion.[42] Now whether
10092: there lies unobserved at the foundation of these ideas an analogy of
10093: the same kind as exists between the logical and transcendental
10094: procedure of reason, is another of those questions, the answer to which
10095: we must not expect till we arrive at a more advanced stage in our
10096: inquiries. In this cursory and preliminary view, we have, meanwhile,
10097: reached our aim. For we have dispelled the ambiguity which attached to
10098: the transcendental conceptions of reason, from their being commonly
10099: mixed up with other conceptions in the systems of philosophers, and not
10100: properly distinguished from the conceptions of the understanding; we
10101: have exposed their origin and, thereby, at the same time their
10102: determinate number, and presented them in a systematic connection, and
10103: have thus marked out and enclosed a definite sphere for pure reason.
10104: 
10105:  [42] The science of Metaphysics has for the proper object of its
10106:  inquiries only three grand ideas: GOD, FREEDOM, and IMMORTALITY, and
10107:  it aims at showing, that the second conception, conjoined with the
10108:  first, must lead to the third, as a necessary conclusion. All the
10109:  other subjects with which it occupies itself, are merely means for the
10110:  attainment and realization of these ideas. It does not require these
10111:  ideas for the construction of a science of nature, but, on the
10112:  contrary, for the purpose of passing beyond the sphere of nature. A
10113:  complete insight into and comprehension of them would render Theology,
10114:  Ethics, and, through the conjunction of both, Religion, solely
10115:  dependent on the speculative faculty of reason. In a systematic
10116:  representation of these ideas the above-mentioned arrangement—the
10117:  synthetical one—would be the most suitable; but in the investigation
10118:  which must necessarily precede it, the analytical, which reverses this
10119:  arrangement, would be better adapted to our purpose, as in it we
10120:  should proceed from that which experience immediately presents to
10121:  us—psychology, to cosmology, and thence to theology.
10122: 
10123: TRANSCENDENTAL DIALECTIC—BOOK II—OF THE DIALECTICAL PROCEDURE OF PURE
10124: REASON
10125: 
10126: It may be said that the object of a merely transcendental idea is
10127: something of which we have no conception, although the idea may be a
10128: necessary product of reason according to its original laws. For, in
10129: fact, a conception of an object that is adequate to the idea given by
10130: reason, is impossible. For such an object must be capable of being
10131: presented and intuited in a Possible experience. But we should express
10132: our meaning better, and with less risk of being misunderstood, if we
10133: said that we can have no knowledge of an object, which perfectly
10134: corresponds to an idea, although we may possess a problematical
10135: conception thereof.
10136: 
10137: Now the transcendental (subjective) reality at least of the pure
10138: conceptions of reason rests upon the fact that we are led to such ideas
10139: by a necessary procedure of reason. There must therefore be syllogisms
10140: which contain no empirical premisses, and by means of which we conclude
10141: from something that we do know, to something of which we do not even
10142: possess a conception, to which we, nevertheless, by an unavoidable
10143: illusion, ascribe objective reality. Such arguments are, as regards
10144: their result, rather to be termed sophisms than syllogisms, although
10145: indeed, as regards their origin, they are very well entitled to the
10146: latter name, inasmuch as they are not fictions or accidental products
10147: of reason, but are necessitated by its very nature. They are sophisms,
10148: not of men, but of pure reason herself, from which the Wisest cannot
10149: free himself. After long labour he may be able to guard against the
10150: error, but he can never be thoroughly rid of the illusion which
10151: continually mocks and misleads him.
10152: 
10153: Of these dialectical arguments there are three kinds, corresponding to
10154: the number of the ideas which their conclusions present. In the
10155: argument or syllogism of the first class, I conclude, from the
10156: transcendental conception of the subject contains no manifold, the
10157: absolute unity of the subject itself, of which I cannot in this manner
10158: attain to a conception. This dialectical argument I shall call the
10159: transcendental paralogism. The second class of sophistical arguments is
10160: occupied with the transcendental conception of the absolute totality of
10161: the series of conditions for a given phenomenon, and I conclude, from
10162: the fact that I have always a self-contradictory conception of the
10163: unconditioned synthetical unity of the series upon one side, the truth
10164: of the opposite unity, of which I have nevertheless no conception. The
10165: condition of reason in these dialectical arguments, I shall term the
10166: antinomy of pure reason. Finally, according to the third kind of
10167: sophistical argument, I conclude, from the totality of the conditions
10168: of thinking objects in general, in so far as they can be given, the
10169: absolute synthetical unity of all conditions of the possibility of
10170: things in general; that is, from things which I do not know in their
10171: mere transcendental conception, I conclude a being of all beings which
10172: I know still less by means of a transcendental conception, and of whose
10173: unconditioned necessity I can form no conception whatever. This
10174: dialectical argument I shall call the ideal of pure reason.
10175: 
10176: Chapter I. Of the Paralogisms of Pure Reason
10177: 
10178: The logical paralogism consists in the falsity of an argument in
10179: respect of its form, be the content what it may. But a transcendental
10180: paralogism has a transcendental foundation, and concludes falsely,
10181: while the form is correct and unexceptionable. In this manner the
10182: paralogism has its foundation in the nature of human reason, and is the
10183: parent of an unavoidable, though not insoluble, mental illusion.
10184: 
10185: We now come to a conception which was not inserted in the general list
10186: of transcendental conceptions, and yet must be reckoned with them, but
10187: at the same time without in the least altering, or indicating a
10188: deficiency in that table. This is the conception, or, if the term is
10189: preferred, the judgement, “I think.” But it is readily perceived that
10190: this thought is as it were the vehicle of all conceptions in general,
10191: and consequently of transcendental conceptions also, and that it is
10192: therefore regarded as a transcendental conception, although it can have
10193: no peculiar claim to be so ranked, inasmuch as its only use is to
10194: indicate that all thought is accompanied by consciousness. At the same
10195: time, pure as this conception is from empirical content (impressions of
10196: the senses), it enables us to distinguish two different kinds of
10197: objects. “I,” as thinking, am an object of the internal sense, and am
10198: called soul. That which is an object of the external senses is called
10199: body. Thus the expression, “I,” as a thinking being, designates the
10200: object-matter of psychology, which may be called “the rational doctrine
10201: of the soul,” inasmuch as in this science I desire to know nothing of
10202: the soul but what, independently of all experience (which determines me
10203: in concreto), may be concluded from this conception “I,” in so far as
10204: it appears in all thought.
10205: 
10206: Now, the rational doctrine of the soul is really an undertaking of this
10207: kind. For if the smallest empirical element of thought, if any
10208: particular perception of my internal state, were to be introduced among
10209: the grounds of cognition of this science, it would not be a rational,
10210: but an empirical doctrine of the soul. We have thus before us a
10211: pretended science, raised upon the single proposition, “I think,” whose
10212: foundation or want of foundation we may very properly, and agreeably
10213: with the nature of a transcendental philosophy, here examine. It ought
10214: not to be objected that in this proposition, which expresses the
10215: perception of one’s self, an internal experience is asserted, and that
10216: consequently the rational doctrine of the soul which is founded upon
10217: it, is not pure, but partly founded upon an empirical principle. For
10218: this internal perception is nothing more than the mere apperception, “I
10219: think,” which in fact renders all transcendental conceptions possible,
10220: in which we say, “I think substance, cause, etc.” For internal
10221: experience in general and its possibility, or perception in general,
10222: and its relation to other perceptions, unless some particular
10223: distinction or determination thereof is empirically given, cannot be
10224: regarded as empirical cognition, but as cognition of the empirical, and
10225: belongs to the investigation of the possibility of every experience,
10226: which is certainly transcendental. The smallest object of experience
10227: (for example, only pleasure or pain), that should be included in the
10228: general representation of self-consciousness, would immediately change
10229: the rational into an empirical psychology.
10230: 
10231: “I think” is therefore the only text of rational psychology, from which
10232: it must develop its whole system. It is manifest that this thought,
10233: when applied to an object (myself), can contain nothing but
10234: transcendental predicates thereof; because the least empirical
10235: predicate would destroy the purity of the science and its independence
10236: of all experience.
10237: 
10238: But we shall have to follow here the guidance of the categories—only,
10239: as in the present case a thing, “I,” as thinking being, is at first
10240: given, we shall—not indeed change the order of the categories as it
10241: stands in the table—but begin at the category of substance, by which at
10242: the a thing in itself is represented and proceeds backwards through the
10243: series. The topic of the rational doctrine of the soul, from which
10244: everything else it may contain must be deduced, is accordingly as
10245: follows:
10246: 
10247:             1                          2
10248:   The Soul is SUBSTANCE       As regards its quality
10249:                                 it is SIMPLE
10250: 
10251:                       3
10252:           As regards the different
10253:           times in which it exists,
10254:           it is numerically identical,
10255:           that is UNITY, not Plurality.
10256: 
10257:                        4
10258:   It is in relation to possible objects in space[43]
10259: 
10260:  [43] The reader, who may not so easily perceive the psychological
10261:  sense of these expressions, taken here in their transcendental
10262:  abstraction, and cannot guess why the latter attribute of the soul
10263:  belongs to the category of existence, will find the expressions
10264:  sufficiently explained and justified in the sequel. I have, moreover,
10265:  to apologize for the Latin terms which have been employed, instead of
10266:  their German synonyms, contrary to the rules of correct writing. But I
10267:  judged it better to sacrifice elegance to perspicuity.
10268: 
10269: 
10270: From these elements originate all the conceptions of pure psychology,
10271: by combination alone, without the aid of any other principle. This
10272: substance, merely as an object of the internal sense, gives the
10273: conception of Immateriality; as simple substance, that of
10274: Incorruptibility; its identity, as intellectual substance, gives the
10275: conception of Personality; all these three together, Spirituality. Its
10276: relation to objects in space gives us the conception of connection
10277: (commercium) with bodies. Thus it represents thinking substance as the
10278: principle of life in matter, that is, as a soul (anima), and as the
10279: ground of Animality; and this, limited and determined by the conception
10280: of spirituality, gives us that of Immortality.
10281: 
10282: Now to these conceptions relate four paralogisms of a transcendental
10283: psychology, which is falsely held to be a science of pure reason,
10284: touching the nature of our thinking being. We can, however, lay at the
10285: foundation of this science nothing but the simple and in itself
10286: perfectly contentless representation “i” which cannot even be called a
10287: conception, but merely a consciousness which accompanies all
10288: conceptions. By this “I,” or “He,” or “It,” who or which thinks,
10289: nothing more is represented than a transcendental subject of thought =
10290: x, which is cognized only by means of the thoughts that are its
10291: predicates, and of which, apart from these, we cannot form the least
10292: conception. Hence in a perpetual circle, inasmuch as we must always
10293: employ it, in order to frame any judgement respecting it. And this
10294: inconvenience we find it impossible to rid ourselves of, because
10295: consciousness in itself is not so much a representation distinguishing
10296: a particular object, as a form of representation in general, in so far
10297: as it may be termed cognition; for in and by cognition alone do I think
10298: anything.
10299: 
10300: It must, however, appear extraordinary at first sight that the
10301: condition under which I think, and which is consequently a property of
10302: my subject, should be held to be likewise valid for every existence
10303: which thinks, and that we can presume to base upon a seemingly
10304: empirical proposition a judgement which is apodeictic and universal, to
10305: wit, that everything which thinks is constituted as the voice of my
10306: consciousness declares it to be, that is, as a self-conscious being.
10307: The cause of this belief is to be found in the fact that we necessarily
10308: attribute to things à priori all the properties which constitute
10309: conditions under which alone we can cogitate them. Now I cannot obtain
10310: the least representation of a thinking being by means of external
10311: experience, but solely through self-consciousness. Such objects are
10312: consequently nothing more than the transference of this consciousness
10313: of mine to other things which can only thus be represented as thinking
10314: beings. The proposition, “I think,” is, in the present case, understood
10315: in a problematical sense, not in so far as it contains a perception of
10316: an existence (like the Cartesian “Cogito, ergo sum”), but in regard to
10317: its mere possibility—for the purpose of discovering what properties may
10318: be inferred from so simple a proposition and predicated of the subject
10319: of it.
10320: 
10321: If at the foundation of our pure rational cognition of thinking beings
10322: there lay more than the mere Cogito—if we could likewise call in aid
10323: observations on the play of our thoughts, and the thence derived
10324: natural laws of the thinking self, there would arise an empirical
10325: psychology which would be a kind of physiology of the internal sense
10326: and might possibly be capable of explaining the phenomena of that
10327: sense. But it could never be available for discovering those properties
10328: which do not belong to possible experience (such as the quality of
10329: simplicity), nor could it make any apodeictic enunciation on the nature
10330: of thinking beings: it would therefore not be a rational psychology.
10331: 
10332: Now, as the proposition “I think” (in the problematical sense) contains
10333: the form of every judgement in general and is the constant
10334: accompaniment of all the categories, it is manifest that conclusions
10335: are drawn from it only by a transcendental employment of the
10336: understanding. This use of the understanding excludes all empirical
10337: elements; and we cannot, as has been shown above, have any favourable
10338: conception beforehand of its procedure. We shall therefore follow with
10339: a critical eye this proposition through all the predicaments of pure
10340: psychology; but we shall, for brevity’s sake, allow this examination to
10341: proceed in an uninterrupted connection.
10342: 
10343: Before entering on this task, however, the following general remark may
10344: help to quicken our attention to this mode of argument. It is not
10345: merely through my thinking that I cognize an object, but only through
10346: my determining a given intuition in relation to the unity of
10347: consciousness in which all thinking consists. It follows that I cognize
10348: myself, not through my being conscious of myself as thinking, but only
10349: when I am conscious of the intuition of myself as determined in
10350: relation to the function of thought. All the modi of self-consciousness
10351: in thought are hence not conceptions of objects (conceptions of the
10352: understanding—categories); they are mere logical functions, which do
10353: not present to thought an object to be cognized, and cannot therefore
10354: present my Self as an object. Not the consciousness of the determining,
10355: but only that of the determinable self, that is, of my internal
10356: intuition (in so far as the manifold contained in it can be connected
10357: conformably with the general condition of the unity of apperception in
10358: thought), is the object.
10359: 
10360: 1. In all judgements I am the determining subject of that relation
10361: which constitutes a judgement. But that the I which thinks, must be
10362: considered as in thought always a subject, and as a thing which cannot
10363: be a predicate to thought, is an apodeictic and identical proposition.
10364: But this proposition does not signify that I, as an object, am, for
10365: myself, a self-subsistent being or substance. This latter statement—an
10366: ambitious one—requires to be supported by data which are not to be
10367: discovered in thought; and are perhaps (in so far as I consider the
10368: thinking self merely as such) not to be discovered in the thinking self
10369: at all.
10370: 
10371: 2. That the I or Ego of apperception, and consequently in all thought,
10372: is singular or simple, and cannot be resolved into a plurality of
10373: subjects, and therefore indicates a logically simple subject—this is
10374: self-evident from the very conception of an Ego, and is consequently an
10375: analytical proposition. But this is not tantamount to declaring that
10376: the thinking Ego is a simple substance—for this would be a synthetical
10377: proposition. The conception of substance always relates to intuitions,
10378: which with me cannot be other than sensuous, and which consequently lie
10379: completely out of the sphere of the understanding and its thought: but
10380: to this sphere belongs the affirmation that the Ego is simple in
10381: thought. It would indeed be surprising, if the conception of
10382: “substance,” which in other cases requires so much labour to
10383: distinguish from the other elements presented by intuition—so much
10384: trouble, too, to discover whether it can be simple (as in the case of
10385: the parts of matter)—should be presented immediately to me, as if by
10386: revelation, in the poorest mental representation of all.
10387: 
10388: 3. The proposition of the identity of my Self amidst all the manifold
10389: representations of which I am conscious, is likewise a proposition
10390: lying in the conceptions themselves, and is consequently analytical.
10391: But this identity of the subject, of which I am conscious in all its
10392: representations, does not relate to or concern the intuition of the
10393: subject, by which it is given as an object. This proposition cannot
10394: therefore enounce the identity of the person, by which is understood
10395: the consciousness of the identity of its own substance as a thinking
10396: being in all change and variation of circumstances. To prove this, we
10397: should require not a mere analysis of the proposition, but synthetical
10398: judgements based upon a given intuition.
10399: 
10400: 4. I distinguish my own existence, as that of a thinking being, from
10401: that of other things external to me—among which my body also is
10402: reckoned. This is also an analytical proposition, for other things are
10403: exactly those which I think as different or distinguished from myself.
10404: But whether this consciousness of myself is possible without things
10405: external to me; and whether therefore I can exist merely as a thinking
10406: being (without being man)—cannot be known or inferred from this
10407: proposition.
10408: 
10409: Thus we have gained nothing as regards the cognition of myself as
10410: object, by the analysis of the consciousness of my Self in thought. The
10411: logical exposition of thought in general is mistaken for a metaphysical
10412: determination of the object.
10413: 
10414: Our Critique would be an investigation utterly superfluous, if there
10415: existed a possibility of proving à priori, that all thinking beings are
10416: in themselves simple substances, as such, therefore, possess the
10417: inseparable attribute of personality, and are conscious of their
10418: existence apart from and unconnected with matter. For we should thus
10419: have taken a step beyond the world of sense, and have penetrated into
10420: the sphere of noumena; and in this case the right could not be denied
10421: us of extending our knowledge in this sphere, of establishing
10422: ourselves, and, under a favouring star, appropriating to ourselves
10423: possessions in it. For the proposition: “Every thinking being, as such,
10424: is simple substance,” is an à priori synthetical proposition; because
10425: in the first place it goes beyond the conception which is the subject
10426: of it, and adds to the mere notion of a thinking being the mode of its
10427: existence, and in the second place annexes a predicate (that of
10428: simplicity) to the latter conception—a predicate which it could not
10429: have discovered in the sphere of experience. It would follow that à
10430: priori synthetical propositions are possible and legitimate, not only,
10431: as we have maintained, in relation to objects of possible experience,
10432: and as principles of the possibility of this experience itself, but are
10433: applicable to things in themselves—an inference which makes an end of
10434: the whole of this Critique, and obliges us to fall back on the old mode
10435: of metaphysical procedure. But indeed the danger is not so great, if we
10436: look a little closer into the question.
10437: 
10438: There lurks in the procedure of rational Psychology a paralogism, which
10439: is represented in the following syllogism:
10440: 
10441: That which cannot be cogitated otherwise than as subject, does not
10442: exist otherwise than as subject, and is therefore substance.
10443: 
10444: A thinking being, considered merely as such, cannot be cogitated
10445: otherwise than as subject.
10446: 
10447: Therefore it exists also as such, that is, as substance.
10448: 
10449: In the major we speak of a being that can be cogitated generally and in
10450: every relation, consequently as it may be given in intuition. But in
10451: the minor we speak of the same being only in so far as it regards
10452: itself as subject, relatively to thought and the unity of
10453: consciousness, but not in relation to intuition, by which it is
10454: presented as an object to thought. Thus the conclusion is here arrived
10455: at by a Sophisma figurae dictionis.[44]
10456: 
10457:  [44] Thought is taken in the two premisses in two totally different
10458:  senses. In the major it is considered as relating and applying to
10459:  objects in general, consequently to objects of intuition also. In the
10460:  minor, we understand it as relating merely to self-consciousness. In
10461:  this sense, we do not cogitate an object, but merely the relation to
10462:  the self-consciousness of the subject, as the form of thought. In the
10463:  former premiss we speak of things which cannot be cogitated otherwise
10464:  than as subjects. In the second, we do not speak of things, but of
10465:  thought (all objects being abstracted), in which the Ego is always the
10466:  subject of consciousness. Hence the conclusion cannot be, “I cannot
10467:  exist otherwise than as subject”; but only “I can, in cogitating my
10468:  existence, employ my Ego only as the subject of the judgement.” But
10469:  this is an identical proposition, and throws no light on the mode of
10470:  my existence.
10471: 
10472: 
10473: That this famous argument is a mere paralogism, will be plain to any
10474: one who will consider the general remark which precedes our exposition
10475: of the principles of the pure understanding, and the section on
10476: noumena. For it was there proved that the conception of a thing, which
10477: can exist per se—only as a subject and never as a predicate, possesses
10478: no objective reality; that is to say, we can never know whether there
10479: exists any object to correspond to the conception; consequently, the
10480: conception is nothing more than a conception, and from it we derive no
10481: proper knowledge. If this conception is to indicate by the term
10482: substance, an object that can be given, if it is to become a cognition,
10483: we must have at the foundation of the cognition a permanent intuition,
10484: as the indispensable condition of its objective reality. For through
10485: intuition alone can an object be given. But in internal intuition there
10486: is nothing permanent, for the Ego is but the consciousness of my
10487: thought. If then, we appeal merely to thought, we cannot discover the
10488: necessary condition of the application of the conception of
10489: substance—that is, of a subject existing per se—to the subject as a
10490: thinking being. And thus the conception of the simple nature of
10491: substance, which is connected with the objective reality of this
10492: conception, is shown to be also invalid, and to be, in fact, nothing
10493: more than the logical qualitative unity of self-consciousness in
10494: thought; whilst we remain perfectly ignorant whether the subject is
10495: composite or not.
10496: 
10497: Refutation of the Argument of Mendelssohn for the Substantiality or
10498: Permanence of the Soul.
10499: 
10500: This acute philosopher easily perceived the insufficiency of the common
10501: argument which attempts to prove that the soul—it being granted that it
10502: is a simple being—cannot perish by dissolution or decomposition; he saw
10503: it is not impossible for it to cease to be by extinction, or
10504: disappearance. He endeavoured to prove in his Phaedo, that the soul
10505: cannot be annihilated, by showing that a simple being cannot cease to
10506: exist. Inasmuch as, he said, a simple existence cannot diminish, nor
10507: gradually lose portions of its being, and thus be by degrees reduced to
10508: nothing (for it possesses no parts, and therefore no multiplicity),
10509: between the moment in which it is, and the moment in which it is not,
10510: no time can be discovered—which is impossible. But this philosopher did
10511: not consider that, granting the soul to possess this simple nature,
10512: which contains no parts external to each other and consequently no
10513: extensive quantity, we cannot refuse to it any less than to any other
10514: being, intensive quantity, that is, a degree of reality in regard to
10515: all its faculties, nay, to all that constitutes its existence. But this
10516: degree of reality can become less and less through an infinite series
10517: of smaller degrees. It follows, therefore, that this supposed
10518: substance—this thing, the permanence of which is not assured in any
10519: other way, may, if not by decomposition, by gradual loss (remissio) of
10520: its powers (consequently by elanguescence, if I may employ this
10521: expression), be changed into nothing. For consciousness itself has
10522: always a degree, which may be lessened.[45] Consequently the faculty of
10523: being conscious may be diminished; and so with all other faculties. The
10524: permanence of the soul, therefore, as an object of the internal sense,
10525: remains undemonstrated, nay, even indemonstrable. Its permanence in
10526: life is evident, per se, inasmuch as the thinking being (as man) is to
10527: itself, at the same time, an object of the external senses. But this
10528: does not authorize the rational psychologist to affirm, from mere
10529: conceptions, its permanence beyond life.[46]
10530: 
10531:  [45] Clearness is not, as logicians maintain, the consciousness of a
10532:  representation. For a certain degree of consciousness, which may not,
10533:  however, be sufficient for recollection, is to be met with in many dim
10534:  representations. For without any consciousness at all, we should not
10535:  be able to recognize any difference in the obscure representations we
10536:  connect; as we really can do with many conceptions, such as those of
10537:  right and justice, and those of the musician, who strikes at once
10538:  several notes in improvising a piece of music. But a representation is
10539:  clear, in which our consciousness is sufficient for the consciousness
10540:  of the difference of this representation from others. If we are only
10541:  conscious that there is a difference, but are not conscious of the
10542:  difference—that is, what the difference is—the representation must be
10543:  termed obscure. There is, consequently, an infinite series of degrees
10544:  of consciousness down to its entire disappearance.
10545: 
10546: 
10547:  [46] There are some who think they have done enough to establish a new
10548:  possibility in the mode of the existence of souls, when they have
10549:  shown that there is no contradiction in their hypotheses on this
10550:  subject. Such are those who affirm the possibility of thought—of which
10551:  they have no other knowledge than what they derive from its use in
10552:  connecting empirical intuitions presented in this our human life—after
10553:  this life has ceased. But it is very easy to embarrass them by the
10554:  introduction of counter-possibilities, which rest upon quite as good a
10555:  foundation. Such, for example, is the possibility of the division of a
10556:  simple substance into several substances; and conversely, of the
10557:  coalition of several into one simple substance. For, although
10558:  divisibility presupposes composition, it does not necessarily require
10559:  a composition of substances, but only of the degrees (of the several
10560:  faculties) of one and the same substance. Now we can cogitate all the
10561:  powers and faculties of the soul—even that of consciousness—as
10562:  diminished by one half, the substance still remaining. In the same way
10563:  we can represent to ourselves without contradiction, this obliterated
10564:  half as preserved, not in the soul, but without it; and we can believe
10565:  that, as in this case every thing that is real in the soul, and has a
10566:  degree—consequently its entire existence—has been halved, a particular
10567:  substance would arise out of the soul. For the multiplicity, which has
10568:  been divided, formerly existed, but not as a multiplicity of
10569:  substances, but of every reality as the quantum of existence in it;
10570:  and the unity of substance was merely a mode of existence, which by
10571:  this division alone has been transformed into a plurality of
10572:  subsistence. In the same manner several simple substances might
10573:  coalesce into one, without anything being lost except the plurality of
10574:  subsistence, inasmuch as the one substance would contain the degree of
10575:  reality of all the former substances. Perhaps, indeed, the simple
10576:  substances, which appear under the form of matter, might (not indeed
10577:  by a mechanical or chemical influence upon each other, but by an
10578:  unknown influence, of which the former would be but the phenomenal
10579:  appearance), by means of such a dynamical division of the
10580:  parent-souls, as intensive quantities, produce other souls, while the
10581:  former repaired the loss thus sustained with new matter of the same
10582:  sort. I am far from allowing any value to such chimeras; and the
10583:  principles of our analytic have clearly proved that no other than an
10584:  empirical use of the categories—that of substance, for example—is
10585:  possible. But if the rationalist is bold enough to construct, on the
10586:  mere authority of the faculty of thought—without any intuition,
10587:  whereby an object is given—a self-subsistent being, merely because the
10588:  unity of apperception in thought cannot allow him to believe it a
10589:  composite being, instead of declaring, as he ought to do, that he is
10590:  unable to explain the possibility of a thinking nature; what ought to
10591:  hinder the materialist, with as complete an independence of
10592:  experience, to employ the principle of the rationalist in a directly
10593:  opposite manner—still preserving the formal unity required by his
10594:  opponent?
10595: 
10596: 
10597: If, now, we take the above propositions—as they must be accepted as
10598: valid for all thinking beings in the system of rational psychology—in
10599: synthetical connection, and proceed, from the category of relation,
10600: with the proposition: “All thinking beings are, as such, substances,”
10601: backwards through the series, till the circle is completed; we come at
10602: last to their existence, of which, in this system of rational
10603: psychology, substances are held to be conscious, independently of
10604: external things; nay, it is asserted that, in relation to the
10605: permanence which is a necessary characteristic of substance, they can
10606: of themselves determine external things. It follows that idealism—at
10607: least problematical idealism, is perfectly unavoidable in this
10608: rationalistic system. And, if the existence of outward things is not
10609: held to be requisite to the determination of the existence of a
10610: substance in time, the existence of these outward things at all, is a
10611: gratuitous assumption which remains without the possibility of a proof.
10612: 
10613: But if we proceed analytically—the “I think” as a proposition
10614: containing in itself an existence as given, consequently modality being
10615: the principle—and dissect this proposition, in order to ascertain its
10616: content, and discover whether and how this Ego determines its existence
10617: in time and space without the aid of anything external; the
10618: propositions of rationalistic psychology would not begin with the
10619: conception of a thinking being, but with a reality, and the properties
10620: of a thinking being in general would be deduced from the mode in which
10621: this reality is cogitated, after everything empirical had been
10622: abstracted; as is shown in the following table:
10623: 
10624:                         1
10625:                       I think,
10626: 
10627:             2                             3
10628:         as Subject,              as simple Subject,
10629: 
10630:                         4
10631:                as identical Subject,
10632:            in every state of my thought.
10633: 
10634: Now, inasmuch as it is not determined in this second proposition,
10635: whether I can exist and be cogitated only as subject, and not also as a
10636: predicate of another being, the conception of a subject is here taken
10637: in a merely logical sense; and it remains undetermined, whether
10638: substance is to be cogitated under the conception or not. But in the
10639: third proposition, the absolute unity of apperception—the simple Ego in
10640: the representation to which all connection and separation, which
10641: constitute thought, relate, is of itself important; even although it
10642: presents us with no information about the constitution or subsistence
10643: of the subject. Apperception is something real, and the simplicity of
10644: its nature is given in the very fact of its possibility. Now in space
10645: there is nothing real that is at the same time simple; for points,
10646: which are the only simple things in space, are merely limits, but not
10647: constituent parts of space. From this follows the impossibility of a
10648: definition on the basis of materialism of the constitution of my Ego as
10649: a merely thinking subject. But, because my existence is considered in
10650: the first proposition as given, for it does not mean, “Every thinking
10651: being exists” (for this would be predicating of them absolute
10652: necessity), but only, “I exist thinking”; the proposition is quite
10653: empirical, and contains the determinability of my existence merely in
10654: relation to my representations in time. But as I require for this
10655: purpose something that is permanent, such as is not given in internal
10656: intuition; the mode of my existence, whether as substance or as
10657: accident, cannot be determined by means of this simple
10658: self-consciousness. Thus, if materialism is inadequate to explain the
10659: mode in which I exist, spiritualism is likewise as insufficient; and
10660: the conclusion is that we are utterly unable to attain to any knowledge
10661: of the constitution of the soul, in so far as relates to the
10662: possibility of its existence apart from external objects.
10663: 
10664: And, indeed, how should it be possible, merely by the aid of the unity
10665: of consciousness—which we cognize only for the reason that it is
10666: indispensable to the possibility of experience—to pass the bounds of
10667: experience (our existence in this life); and to extend our cognition to
10668: the nature of all thinking beings by means of the empirical—but in
10669: relation to every sort of intuition, perfectly
10670: undetermined—proposition, “I think”?
10671: 
10672: There does not then exist any rational psychology as a doctrine
10673: furnishing any addition to our knowledge of ourselves. It is nothing
10674: more than a discipline, which sets impassable limits to speculative
10675: reason in this region of thought, to prevent it, on the one hand, from
10676: throwing itself into the arms of a soulless materialism, and, on the
10677: other, from losing itself in the mazes of a baseless spiritualism. It
10678: teaches us to consider this refusal of our reason to give any
10679: satisfactory answer to questions which reach beyond the limits of this
10680: our human life, as a hint to abandon fruitless speculation; and to
10681: direct, to a practical use, our knowledge of ourselves—which, although
10682: applicable only to objects of experience, receives its principles from
10683: a higher source, and regulates its procedure as if our destiny reached
10684: far beyond the boundaries of experience and life.
10685: 
10686: From all this it is evident that rational psychology has its origin in
10687: a mere misunderstanding. The unity of consciousness, which lies at the
10688: basis of the categories, is considered to be an intuition of the
10689: subject as an object; and the category of substance is applied to the
10690: intuition. But this unity is nothing more than the unity in thought, by
10691: which no object is given; to which therefore the category of
10692: substance—which always presupposes a given intuition—cannot be applied.
10693: Consequently, the subject cannot be cognized. The subject of the
10694: categories cannot, therefore, for the very reason that it cogitates
10695: these, frame any conception of itself as an object of the categories;
10696: for, to cogitate these, it must lay at the foundation its own pure
10697: self-consciousness—the very thing that it wishes to explain and
10698: describe. In like manner, the subject, in which the representation of
10699: time has its basis, cannot determine, for this very reason, its own
10700: existence in time. Now, if the latter is impossible, the former, as an
10701: attempt to determine itself by means of the categories as a thinking
10702: being in general, is no less so.[47]
10703: 
10704:  [47] The “I think” is, as has been already stated, an empirical
10705:  proposition, and contains the proposition, “I exist.” But I cannot
10706:  say, “Everything, which thinks, exists”; for in this case the property
10707:  of thought would constitute all beings possessing it, necessary
10708:  beings. Hence my existence cannot be considered as an inference from
10709:  the proposition, “I think,” as Descartes maintained—because in this
10710:  case the major premiss, “Everything, which thinks, exists,” must
10711:  precede—but the two propositions are identical. The proposition, “I
10712:  think,” expresses an undetermined empirical intuition, that perception
10713:  (proving consequently that sensation, which must belong to
10714:  sensibility, lies at the foundation of this proposition); but it
10715:  precedes experience, whose province it is to determine an object of
10716:  perception by means of the categories in relation to time; and
10717:  existence in this proposition is not a category, as it does not apply
10718:  to an undetermined given object, but only to one of which we have a
10719:  conception, and about which we wish to know whether it does or does
10720:  not exist, out of, and apart from this conception. An undetermined
10721:  perception signifies here merely something real that has been given,
10722:  only, however, to thought in general—but not as a phenomenon, nor as a
10723:  thing in itself (noumenon), but only as something that really exists,
10724:  and is designated as such in the proposition, “I think.” For it must
10725:  be remarked that, when I call the proposition, “I think,” an empirical
10726:  proposition, I do not thereby mean that the Ego in the proposition is
10727:  an empirical representation; on the contrary, it is purely
10728:  intellectual, because it belongs to thought in general. But without
10729:  some empirical representation, which presents to the mind material for
10730:  thought, the mental act, “I think,” would not take place; and the
10731:  empirical is only the condition of the application or employment of
10732:  the pure intellectual faculty.
10733: 
10734: 
10735: Thus, then, appears the vanity of the hope of establishing a cognition
10736: which is to extend its rule beyond the limits of experience—a cognition
10737: which is one of the highest interests of humanity; and thus is proved
10738: the futility of the attempt of speculative philosophy in this region of
10739: thought. But, in this interest of thought, the severity of criticism
10740: has rendered to reason a not unimportant service, by the demonstration
10741: of the impossibility of making any dogmatical affirmation concerning an
10742: object of experience beyond the boundaries of experience. She has thus
10743: fortified reason against all affirmations of the contrary. Now, this
10744: can be accomplished in only two ways. Either our proposition must be
10745: proved apodeictically; or, if this is unsuccessful, the sources of this
10746: inability must be sought for, and, if these are discovered to exist in
10747: the natural and necessary limitation of our reason, our opponents must
10748: submit to the same law of renunciation and refrain from advancing
10749: claims to dogmatic assertion.
10750: 
10751: But the right, say rather the necessity to admit a future life, upon
10752: principles of the practical conjoined with the speculative use of
10753: reason, has lost nothing by this renunciation; for the merely
10754: speculative proof has never had any influence upon the common reason of
10755: men. It stands upon the point of a hair, so that even the schools have
10756: been able to preserve it from falling only by incessantly discussing it
10757: and spinning it like a top; and even in their eyes it has never been
10758: able to present any safe foundation for the erection of a theory. The
10759: proofs which have been current among men, preserve their value
10760: undiminished; nay, rather gain in clearness and unsophisticated power,
10761: by the rejection of the dogmatical assumptions of speculative reason.
10762: For reason is thus confined within her own peculiar province—the
10763: arrangement of ends or aims, which is at the same time the arrangement
10764: of nature; and, as a practical faculty, without limiting itself to the
10765: latter, it is justified in extending the former, and with it our own
10766: existence, beyond the boundaries of experience and life. If we turn our
10767: attention to the analogy of the nature of living beings in this world,
10768: in the consideration of which reason is obliged to accept as a
10769: principle that no organ, no faculty, no appetite is useless, and that
10770: nothing is superfluous, nothing disproportionate to its use, nothing
10771: unsuited to its end; but that, on the contrary, everything is perfectly
10772: conformed to its destination in life—we shall find that man, who alone
10773: is the final end and aim of this order, is still the only animal that
10774: seems to be excepted from it. For his natural gifts—not merely as
10775: regards the talents and motives that may incite him to employ them, but
10776: especially the moral law in him—stretch so far beyond all mere earthly
10777: utility and advantage, that he feels himself bound to prize the mere
10778: consciousness of probity, apart from all advantageous consequences—even
10779: the shadowy gift of posthumous fame—above everything; and he is
10780: conscious of an inward call to constitute himself, by his conduct in
10781: this world—without regard to mere sublunary interests—the citizen of a
10782: better. This mighty, irresistible proof—accompanied by an
10783: ever-increasing knowledge of the conformability to a purpose in
10784: everything we see around us, by the conviction of the boundless
10785: immensity of creation, by the consciousness of a certain
10786: illimitableness in the possible extension of our knowledge, and by a
10787: desire commensurate therewith—remains to humanity, even after the
10788: theoretical cognition of ourselves has failed to establish the
10789: necessity of an existence after death.
10790: 
10791: Conclusion of the Solution of the Psychological Paralogism.
10792: 
10793: 
10794: The dialectical illusion in rational psychology arises from our
10795: confounding an idea of reason (of a pure intelligence) with the
10796: conception—in every respect undetermined—of a thinking being in
10797: general. I cogitate myself in behalf of a possible experience, at the
10798: same time making abstraction of all actual experience; and infer
10799: therefrom that I can be conscious of myself apart from experience and
10800: its empirical conditions. I consequently confound the possible
10801: abstraction of my empirically determined existence with the supposed
10802: consciousness of a possible separate existence of my thinking self; and
10803: I believe that I cognize what is substantial in myself as a
10804: transcendental subject, when I have nothing more in thought than the
10805: unity of consciousness, which lies at the basis of all determination of
10806: cognition.
10807: 
10808: The task of explaining the community of the soul with the body does not
10809: properly belong to the psychology of which we are here speaking;
10810: because it proposes to prove the personality of the soul apart from
10811: this communion (after death), and is therefore transcendent in the
10812: proper sense of the word, although occupying itself with an object of
10813: experience—only in so far, however, as it ceases to be an object of
10814: experience. But a sufficient answer may be found to the question in our
10815: system. The difficulty which lies in the execution of this task
10816: consists, as is well known, in the presupposed heterogeneity of the
10817: object of the internal sense (the soul) and the objects of the external
10818: senses; inasmuch as the formal condition of the intuition of the one is
10819: time, and of that of the other space also. But if we consider that both
10820: kinds of objects do not differ internally, but only in so far as the
