10821: one appears externally to the other—consequently, that what lies at the
10822: basis of phenomena, as a thing in itself, may not be heterogeneous;
10823: this difficulty disappears. There then remains no other difficulty than
10824: is to be found in the question—how a community of substances is
10825: possible; a question which lies out of the region of psychology, and
10826: which the reader, after what in our analytic has been said of primitive
10827: forces and faculties, will easily judge to be also beyond the region of
10828: human cognition.
10829: 
10830: GENERAL REMARK
10831: 
10832: On the Transition from Rational Psychology to Cosmology.
10833: 
10834: The proposition, “I think,” or, “I exist thinking,” is an empirical
10835: proposition. But such a proposition must be based on empirical
10836: intuition, and the object cogitated as a phenomenon; and thus our
10837: theory appears to maintain that the soul, even in thought, is merely a
10838: phenomenon; and in this way our consciousness itself, in fact, abuts
10839: upon nothing.
10840: 
10841: Thought, per se, is merely the purely spontaneous logical function
10842: which operates to connect the manifold of a possible intuition; and it
10843: does not represent the subject of consciousness as a phenomenon—for
10844: this reason alone, that it pays no attention to the question whether
10845: the mode of intuiting it is sensuous or intellectual. I therefore do
10846: not represent myself in thought either as I am, or as I appear to
10847: myself; I merely cogitate myself as an object in general, of the mode
10848: of intuiting which I make abstraction. When I represent myself as the
10849: subject of thought, or as the ground of thought, these modes of
10850: representation are not related to the categories of substance or of
10851: cause; for these are functions of thought applicable only to our
10852: sensuous intuition. The application of these categories to the Ego
10853: would, however, be necessary, if I wished to make myself an object of
10854: knowledge. But I wish to be conscious of myself only as thinking; in
10855: what mode my Self is given in intuition, I do not consider, and it may
10856: be that I, who think, am a phenomenon—although not in so far as I am a
10857: thinking being; but in the consciousness of myself in mere thought I am
10858: a being, though this consciousness does not present to me any property
10859: of this being as material for thought.
10860: 
10861: But the proposition, “I think,” in so far as it declares, “I exist
10862: thinking,” is not the mere representation of a logical function. It
10863: determines the subject (which is in this case an object also) in
10864: relation to existence; and it cannot be given without the aid of the
10865: internal sense, whose intuition presents to us an object, not as a
10866: thing in itself, but always as a phenomenon. In this proposition there
10867: is therefore something more to be found than the mere spontaneity of
10868: thought; there is also the receptivity of intuition, that is, my
10869: thought of myself applied to the empirical intuition of myself. Now, in
10870: this intuition the thinking self must seek the conditions of the
10871: employment of its logical functions as categories of substance, cause,
10872: and so forth; not merely for the purpose of distinguishing itself as an
10873: object in itself by means of the representation “I,” but also for the
10874: purpose of determining the mode of its existence, that is, of cognizing
10875: itself as noumenon. But this is impossible, for the internal empirical
10876: intuition is sensuous, and presents us with nothing but phenomenal
10877: data, which do not assist the object of pure consciousness in its
10878: attempt to cognize itself as a separate existence, but are useful only
10879: as contributions to experience.
10880: 
10881: But, let it be granted that we could discover, not in experience, but
10882: in certain firmly-established à priori laws of the use of pure
10883: reason—laws relating to our existence, authority to consider ourselves
10884: as legislating à priori in relation to our own existence and as
10885: determining this existence; we should, on this supposition, find
10886: ourselves possessed of a spontaneity, by which our actual existence
10887: would be determinable, without the aid of the conditions of empirical
10888: intuition. We should also become aware that in the consciousness of our
10889: existence there was an à priori content, which would serve to determine
10890: our own existence—an existence only sensuously determinable—relatively,
10891: however, to a certain internal faculty in relation to an intelligible
10892: world.
10893: 
10894: But this would not give the least help to the attempts of rational
10895: psychology. For this wonderful faculty, which the consciousness of the
10896: moral law in me reveals, would present me with a principle of the
10897: determination of my own existence which is purely intellectual—but by
10898: what predicates? By none other than those which are given in sensuous
10899: intuition. Thus I should find myself in the same position in rational
10900: psychology which I formerly occupied, that is to say, I should find
10901: myself still in need of sensuous intuitions, in order to give
10902: significance to my conceptions of substance and cause, by means of
10903: which alone I can possess a knowledge of myself: but these intuitions
10904: can never raise me above the sphere of experience. I should be
10905: justified, however, in applying these conceptions, in regard to their
10906: practical use, which is always directed to objects of experience—in
10907: conformity with their analogical significance when employed
10908: theoretically—to freedom and its subject. At the same time, I should
10909: understand by them merely the logical functions of subject and
10910: predicate, of principle and consequence, in conformity with which all
10911: actions are so determined, that they are capable of being explained
10912: along with the laws of nature, conformably to the categories of
10913: substance and cause, although they originate from a very different
10914: principle. We have made these observations for the purpose of guarding
10915: against misunderstanding, to which the doctrine of our intuition of
10916: self as a phenomenon is exposed. We shall have occasion to perceive
10917: their utility in the sequel.
10918: 
10919: Chapter II. The Antinomy of Pure Reason
10920: 
10921: We showed in the introduction to this part of our work, that all
10922: transcendental illusion of pure reason arose from dialectical
10923: arguments, the schema of which logic gives us in its three formal
10924: species of syllogisms—just as the categories find their logical schema
10925: in the four functions of all judgements. The first kind of these
10926: sophistical arguments related to the unconditioned unity of the
10927: subjective conditions of all representations in general (of the subject
10928: or soul), in correspondence with the categorical syllogisms, the major
10929: of which, as the principle, enounces the relation of a predicate to a
10930: subject. The second kind of dialectical argument will therefore be
10931: concerned, following the analogy with hypothetical syllogisms, with the
10932: unconditioned unity of the objective conditions in the phenomenon; and,
10933: in this way, the theme of the third kind to be treated of in the
10934: following chapter will be the unconditioned unity of the objective
10935: conditions of the possibility of objects in general.
10936: 
10937: But it is worthy of remark that the transcendental paralogism produced
10938: in the mind only a one-third illusion, in regard to the idea of the
10939: subject of our thought; and the conceptions of reason gave no ground to
10940: maintain the contrary proposition. The advantage is completely on the
10941: side of Pneumatism; although this theory itself passes into naught, in
10942: the crucible of pure reason.
10943: 
10944: Very different is the case when we apply reason to the objective
10945: synthesis of phenomena. Here, certainly, reason establishes, with much
10946: plausibility, its principle of unconditioned unity; but it very soon
10947: falls into such contradictions that it is compelled, in relation to
10948: cosmology, to renounce its pretensions.
10949: 
10950: For here a new phenomenon of human reason meets us—a perfectly natural
10951: antithetic, which does not require to be sought for by subtle
10952: sophistry, but into which reason of itself unavoidably falls. It is
10953: thereby preserved, to be sure, from the slumber of a fancied
10954: conviction—which a merely one-sided illusion produces; but it is at the
10955: same time compelled, either, on the one hand, to abandon itself to a
10956: despairing scepticism, or, on the other, to assume a dogmatical
10957: confidence and obstinate persistence in certain assertions, without
10958: granting a fair hearing to the other side of the question. Either is
10959: the death of a sound philosophy, although the former might perhaps
10960: deserve the title of the euthanasia of pure reason.
10961: 
10962: Before entering this region of discord and confusion, which the
10963: conflict of the laws of pure reason (antinomy) produces, we shall
10964: present the reader with some considerations, in explanation and
10965: justification of the method we intend to follow in our treatment of
10966: this subject. I term all transcendental ideas, in so far as they relate
10967: to the absolute totality in the synthesis of phenomena, cosmical
10968: conceptions; partly on account of this unconditioned totality, on which
10969: the conception of the world-whole is based—a conception, which is
10970: itself an idea—partly because they relate solely to the synthesis of
10971: phenomena—the empirical synthesis; while, on the other hand, the
10972: absolute totality in the synthesis of the conditions of all possible
10973: things gives rise to an ideal of pure reason, which is quite distinct
10974: from the cosmical conception, although it stands in relation with it.
10975: Hence, as the paralogisms of pure reason laid the foundation for a
10976: dialectical psychology, the antinomy of pure reason will present us
10977: with the transcendental principles of a pretended pure (rational)
10978: cosmology—not, however, to declare it valid and to appropriate it,
10979: but—as the very term of a conflict of reason sufficiently indicates, to
10980: present it as an idea which cannot be reconciled with phenomena and
10981: experience.
10982: 
10983: Section I. System of Cosmological Ideas
10984: 
10985: That We may be able to enumerate with systematic precision these ideas
10986: according to a principle, we must remark, in the first place, that it
10987: is from the understanding alone that pure and transcendental
10988: conceptions take their origin; that the reason does not properly give
10989: birth to any conception, but only frees the conception of the
10990: understanding from the unavoidable limitation of a possible experience,
10991: and thus endeavours to raise it above the empirical, though it must
10992: still be in connection with it. This happens from the fact that, for a
10993: given conditioned, reason demands absolute totality on the side of the
10994: conditions (to which the understanding submits all phenomena), and thus
10995: makes of the category a transcendental idea. This it does that it may
10996: be able to give absolute completeness to the empirical synthesis, by
10997: continuing it to the unconditioned (which is not to be found in
10998: experience, but only in the idea). Reason requires this according to
10999: the principle: If the conditioned is given the whole of the conditions,
11000: and consequently the absolutely unconditioned, is also given, whereby
11001: alone the former was possible. First, then, the transcendental ideas
11002: are properly nothing but categories elevated to the unconditioned; and
11003: they may be arranged in a table according to the titles of the latter.
11004: But, secondly, all the categories are not available for this purpose,
11005: but only those in which the synthesis constitutes a series—of
11006: conditions subordinated to, not co-ordinated with, each other. Absolute
11007: totality is required of reason only in so far as concerns the ascending
11008: series of the conditions of a conditioned; not, consequently, when the
11009: question relates to the descending series of consequences, or to the
11010: aggregate of the co-ordinated conditions of these consequences. For, in
11011: relation to a given conditioned, conditions are presupposed and
11012: considered to be given along with it. On the other hand, as the
11013: consequences do not render possible their conditions, but rather
11014: presuppose them—in the consideration of the procession of consequences
11015: (or in the descent from the given condition to the conditioned), we may
11016: be quite unconcerned whether the series ceases or not; and their
11017: totality is not a necessary demand of reason.
11018: 
11019: Thus we cogitate—and necessarily—a given time completely elapsed up to
11020: a given moment, although that time is not determinable by us. But as
11021: regards time future, which is not the condition of arriving at the
11022: present, in order to conceive it; it is quite indifferent whether we
11023: consider future time as ceasing at some point, or as prolonging itself
11024: to infinity. Take, for example, the series m, n, o, in which n is given
11025: as conditioned in relation to m, but at the same time as the condition
11026: of o, and let the series proceed upwards from the conditioned n to m
11027: (l, k, i, etc.), and also downwards from the condition n to the
11028: conditioned o (p, q, r, etc.)—I must presuppose the former series, to
11029: be able to consider n as given, and n is according to reason (the
11030: totality of conditions) possible only by means of that series. But its
11031: possibility does not rest on the following series o, p, q, r, which for
11032: this reason cannot be regarded as given, but only as capable of being
11033: given (dabilis).
11034: 
11035: I shall term the synthesis of the series on the side of the
11036: conditions—from that nearest to the given phenomenon up to the more
11037: remote—regressive; that which proceeds on the side of the conditioned,
11038: from the immediate consequence to the more remote, I shall call the
11039: progressive synthesis. The former proceeds in antecedentia, the latter
11040: in consequentia. The cosmological ideas are therefore occupied with the
11041: totality of the regressive synthesis, and proceed in antecedentia, not
11042: in consequentia. When the latter takes place, it is an arbitrary and
11043: not a necessary problem of pure reason; for we require, for the
11044: complete understanding of what is given in a phenomenon, not the
11045: consequences which succeed, but the grounds or principles which
11046: precede.
11047: 
11048: In order to construct the table of ideas in correspondence with the
11049: table of categories, we take first the two primitive quanta of all our
11050: intuitions, time and space. Time is in itself a series (and the formal
11051: condition of all series), and hence, in relation to a given present, we
11052: must distinguish à priori in it the antecedentia as conditions (time
11053: past) from the consequentia (time future). Consequently, the
11054: transcendental idea of the absolute totality of the series of the
11055: conditions of a given conditioned, relates merely to all past time.
11056: According to the idea of reason, the whole past time, as the condition
11057: of the given moment, is necessarily cogitated as given. But, as regards
11058: space, there exists in it no distinction between progressus and
11059: regressus; for it is an aggregate and not a series—its parts existing
11060: together at the same time. I can consider a given point of time in
11061: relation to past time only as conditioned, because this given moment
11062: comes into existence only through the past time rather through the
11063: passing of the preceding time. But as the parts of space are not
11064: subordinated, but co-ordinated to each other, one part cannot be the
11065: condition of the possibility of the other; and space is not in itself,
11066: like time, a series. But the synthesis of the manifold parts of
11067: space—(the syntheses whereby we apprehend space)—is nevertheless
11068: successive; it takes place, therefore, in time, and contains a series.
11069: And as in this series of aggregated spaces (for example, the feet in a
11070: rood), beginning with a given portion of space, those which continue to
11071: be annexed form the condition of the limits of the former—the
11072: measurement of a space must also be regarded as a synthesis of the
11073: series of the conditions of a given conditioned. It differs, however,
11074: in this respect from that of time, that the side of the conditioned is
11075: not in itself distinguishable from the side of the condition; and,
11076: consequently, regressus and progressus in space seem to be identical.
11077: But, inasmuch as one part of space is not given, but only limited, by
11078: and through another, we must also consider every limited space as
11079: conditioned, in so far as it presupposes some other space as the
11080: condition of its limitation, and so on. As regards limitation,
11081: therefore, our procedure in space is also a regressus, and the
11082: transcendental idea of the absolute totality of the synthesis in a
11083: series of conditions applies to space also; and I am entitled to demand
11084: the absolute totality of the phenomenal synthesis in space as well as
11085: in time. Whether my demand can be satisfied is a question to be
11086: answered in the sequel.
11087: 
11088: Secondly, the real in space—that is, matter—is conditioned. Its
11089: internal conditions are its parts, and the parts of parts its remote
11090: conditions; so that in this case we find a regressive synthesis, the
11091: absolute totality of which is a demand of reason. But this cannot be
11092: obtained otherwise than by a complete division of parts, whereby the
11093: real in matter becomes either nothing or that which is not matter, that
11094: is to say, the simple. Consequently we find here also a series of
11095: conditions and a progress to the unconditioned.
11096: 
11097: Thirdly, as regards the categories of a real relation between
11098: phenomena, the category of substance and its accidents is not suitable
11099: for the formation of a transcendental idea; that is to say, reason has
11100: no ground, in regard to it, to proceed regressively with conditions.
11101: For accidents (in so far as they inhere in a substance) are
11102: co-ordinated with each other, and do not constitute a series. And, in
11103: relation to substance, they are not properly subordinated to it, but
11104: are the mode of existence of the substance itself. The conception of
11105: the substantial might nevertheless seem to be an idea of the
11106: transcendental reason. But, as this signifies nothing more than the
11107: conception of an object in general, which subsists in so far as we
11108: cogitate in it merely a transcendental subject without any predicates;
11109: and as the question here is of an unconditioned in the series of
11110: phenomena—it is clear that the substantial can form no member thereof.
11111: The same holds good of substances in community, which are mere
11112: aggregates and do not form a series. For they are not subordinated to
11113: each other as conditions of the possibility of each other; which,
11114: however, may be affirmed of spaces, the limits of which are never
11115: determined in themselves, but always by some other space. It is,
11116: therefore, only in the category of causality that we can find a series
11117: of causes to a given effect, and in which we ascend from the latter, as
11118: the conditioned, to the former as the conditions, and thus answer the
11119: question of reason.
11120: 
11121: Fourthly, the conceptions of the possible, the actual, and the
11122: necessary do not conduct us to any series—excepting only in so far as
11123: the contingent in existence must always be regarded as conditioned, and
11124: as indicating, according to a law of the understanding, a condition,
11125: under which it is necessary to rise to a higher, till in the totality
11126: of the series, reason arrives at unconditioned necessity.
11127: 
11128: There are, accordingly, only four cosmological ideas, corresponding
11129: with the four titles of the categories. For we can select only such as
11130: necessarily furnish us with a series in the synthesis of the manifold.
11131: 
11132:                       1
11133:             The absolute Completeness
11134:                     of the
11135:                  COMPOSITION
11136:      of the given totality of all phenomena.
11137: 
11138:                       2
11139:             The absolute Completeness
11140:                     of the
11141:                    DIVISION
11142:      of given totality in a phenomenon.
11143: 
11144:                        3
11145:             The absolute Completeness
11146:                      of the
11147:                    ORIGINATION
11148:                   of a phenomenon.
11149: 
11150:                        4
11151:             The absolute Completeness
11152:          of the DEPENDENCE of the EXISTENCE
11153:         of what is changeable in a phenomenon.
11154: 
11155: We must here remark, in the first place, that the idea of absolute
11156: totality relates to nothing but the exposition of phenomena, and
11157: therefore not to the pure conception of a totality of things. Phenomena
11158: are here, therefore, regarded as given, and reason requires the
11159: absolute completeness of the conditions of their possibility, in so far
11160: as these conditions constitute a series—consequently an absolutely
11161: (that is, in every respect) complete synthesis, whereby a phenomenon
11162: can be explained according to the laws of the understanding.
11163: 
11164: Secondly, it is properly the unconditioned alone that reason seeks in
11165: this serially and regressively conducted synthesis of conditions. It
11166: wishes, to speak in another way, to attain to completeness in the
11167: series of premisses, so as to render it unnecessary to presuppose
11168: others. This unconditioned is always contained in the absolute totality
11169: of the series, when we endeavour to form a representation of it in
11170: thought. But this absolutely complete synthesis is itself but an idea;
11171: for it is impossible, at least before hand, to know whether any such
11172: synthesis is possible in the case of phenomena. When we represent all
11173: existence in thought by means of pure conceptions of the understanding,
11174: without any conditions of sensuous intuition, we may say with justice
11175: that for a given conditioned the whole series of conditions
11176: subordinated to each other is also given; for the former is only given
11177: through the latter. But we find in the case of phenomena a particular
11178: limitation of the mode in which conditions are given, that is, through
11179: the successive synthesis of the manifold of intuition, which must be
11180: complete in the regress. Now whether this completeness is sensuously
11181: possible, is a problem. But the idea of it lies in the reason—be it
11182: possible or impossible to connect with the idea adequate empirical
11183: conceptions. Therefore, as in the absolute totality of the regressive
11184: synthesis of the manifold in a phenomenon (following the guidance of
11185: the categories, which represent it as a series of conditions to a given
11186: conditioned) the unconditioned is necessarily contained—it being still
11187: left unascertained whether and how this totality exists; reason sets
11188: out from the idea of totality, although its proper and final aim is the
11189: unconditioned—of the whole series, or of a part thereof.
11190: 
11191: This unconditioned may be cogitated—either as existing only in the
11192: entire series, all the members of which therefore would be without
11193: exception conditioned and only the totality absolutely
11194: unconditioned—and in this case the regressus is called infinite; or the
11195: absolutely unconditioned is only a part of the series, to which the
11196: other members are subordinated, but which Is not itself submitted to
11197: any other condition.[48] In the former case the series is a parte
11198: priori unlimited (without beginning), that is, infinite, and
11199: nevertheless completely given. But the regress in it is never
11200: completed, and can only be called potentially infinite. In the second
11201: case there exists a first in the series. This first is called, in
11202: relation to past time, the beginning of the world; in relation to
11203: space, the limit of the world; in relation to the parts of a given
11204: limited whole, the simple; in relation to causes, absolute spontaneity
11205: (liberty); and in relation to the existence of changeable things,
11206: absolute physical necessity.
11207: 
11208:  [48] The absolute totality of the series of conditions to a given
11209:  conditioned is always unconditioned; because beyond it there exist no
11210:  other conditions, on which it might depend. But the absolute totality
11211:  of such a series is only an idea, or rather a problematical
11212:  conception, the possibility of which must be investigated—particularly
11213:  in relation to the mode in which the unconditioned, as the
11214:  transcendental idea which is the real subject of inquiry, may be
11215:  contained therein.
11216: 
11217: 
11218: We possess two expressions, world and nature, which are generally
11219: interchanged. The first denotes the mathematical total of all phenomena
11220: and the totality of their synthesis—in its progress by means of
11221: composition, as well as by division. And the world is termed
11222: nature,[49] when it is regarded as a dynamical whole—when our attention
11223: is not directed to the aggregation in space and time, for the purpose
11224: of cogitating it as a quantity, but to the unity in the existence of
11225: phenomena. In this case the condition of that which happens is called a
11226: cause; the unconditioned causality of the cause in a phenomenon is
11227: termed liberty; the conditioned cause is called in a more limited sense
11228: a natural cause. The conditioned in existence is termed contingent, and
11229: the unconditioned necessary. The unconditioned necessity of phenomena
11230: may be called natural necessity.
11231: 
11232:  [49] Nature, understood adjective (formaliter), signifies the complex
11233:  of the determinations of a thing, connected according to an internal
11234:  principle of causality. On the other hand, we understand by nature,
11235:  substantive (materialiter), the sum total of phenomena, in so far as
11236:  they, by virtue of an internal principle of causality, are connected
11237:  with each other throughout. In the former sense we speak of the nature
11238:  of liquid matter, of fire, etc., and employ the word only adjective;
11239:  while, if speaking of the objects of nature, we have in our minds the
11240:  idea of a subsisting whole.
11241: 
11242: 
11243: The ideas which we are at present engaged in discussing I have called
11244: cosmological ideas; partly because by the term world is understood the
11245: entire content of all phenomena, and our ideas are directed solely to
11246: the unconditioned among phenomena; partly also, because world, in the
11247: transcendental sense, signifies the absolute totality of the content of
11248: existing things, and we are directing our attention only to the
11249: completeness of the synthesis—although, properly, only in regression.
11250: In regard to the fact that these ideas are all transcendent, and,
11251: although they do not transcend phenomena as regards their mode, but are
11252: concerned solely with the world of sense (and not with noumena),
11253: nevertheless carry their synthesis to a degree far above all possible
11254: experience—it still seems to me that we can, with perfect propriety,
11255: designate them cosmical conceptions. As regards the distinction between
11256: the mathematically and the dynamically unconditioned which is the aim
11257: of the regression of the synthesis, I should call the two former, in a
11258: more limited signification, cosmical conceptions, the remaining two
11259: transcendent physical conceptions. This distinction does not at present
11260: seem to be of particular importance, but we shall afterwards find it to
11261: be of some value.
11262: 
11263: Section II. Antithetic of Pure Reason
11264: 
11265: Thetic is the term applied to every collection of dogmatical
11266: propositions. By antithetic I do not understand dogmatical assertions
11267: of the opposite, but the self-contradiction of seemingly dogmatical
11268: cognitions (thesis cum antithesis), in none of which we can discover
11269: any decided superiority. Antithetic is not, therefore, occupied with
11270: one-sided statements, but is engaged in considering the contradictory
11271: nature of the general cognitions of reason and its causes.
11272: Transcendental antithetic is an investigation into the antinomy of pure
11273: reason, its causes and result. If we employ our reason not merely in
11274: the application of the principles of the understanding to objects of
11275: experience, but venture with it beyond these boundaries, there arise
11276: certain sophistical propositions or theorems. These assertions have the
11277: following peculiarities: They can find neither confirmation nor
11278: confutation in experience; and each is in itself not only
11279: self-consistent, but possesses conditions of its necessity in the very
11280: nature of reason—only that, unluckily, there exist just as valid and
11281: necessary grounds for maintaining the contrary proposition.
11282: 
11283: The questions which naturally arise in the consideration of this
11284: dialectic of pure reason, are therefore: 1st. In what propositions is
11285: pure reason unavoidably subject to an antinomy? 2nd. What are the
11286: causes of this antinomy? 3rd. Whether and in what way can reason free
11287: itself from this self-contradiction?
11288: 
11289: A dialectical proposition or theorem of pure reason must, according to
11290: what has been said, be distinguishable from all sophistical
11291: propositions, by the fact that it is not an answer to an arbitrary
11292: question, which may be raised at the mere pleasure of any person, but
11293: to one which human reason must necessarily encounter in its progress.
11294: In the second place, a dialectical proposition, with its opposite, does
11295: not carry the appearance of a merely artificial illusion, which
11296: disappears as soon as it is investigated, but a natural and unavoidable
11297: illusion, which, even when we are no longer deceived by it, continues
11298: to mock us and, although rendered harmless, can never be completely
11299: removed.
11300: 
11301: This dialectical doctrine will not relate to the unity of understanding
11302: in empirical conceptions, but to the unity of reason in pure ideas. The
11303: conditions of this doctrine are—inasmuch as it must, as a synthesis
11304: according to rules, be conformable to the understanding, and at the
11305: same time as the absolute unity of the synthesis, to the reason—that,
11306: if it is adequate to the unity of reason, it is too great for the
11307: understanding, if according with the understanding, it is too small for
11308: the reason. Hence arises a mutual opposition, which cannot be avoided,
11309: do what we will.
11310: 
11311: These sophistical assertions of dialectic open, as it were, a
11312: battle-field, where that side obtains the victory which has been
11313: permitted to make the attack, and he is compelled to yield who has been
11314: unfortunately obliged to stand on the defensive. And hence, champions
11315: of ability, whether on the right or on the wrong side, are certain to
11316: carry away the crown of victory, if they only take care to have the
11317: right to make the last attack, and are not obliged to sustain another
11318: onset from their opponent. We can easily believe that this arena has
11319: been often trampled by the feet of combatants, that many victories have
11320: been obtained on both sides, but that the last victory, decisive of the
11321: affair between the contending parties, was won by him who fought for
11322: the right, only if his adversary was forbidden to continue the tourney.
11323: As impartial umpires, we must lay aside entirely the consideration
11324: whether the combatants are fighting for the right or for the wrong
11325: side, for the true or for the false, and allow the combat to be first
11326: decided. Perhaps, after they have wearied more than injured each other,
11327: they will discover the nothingness of their cause of quarrel and part
11328: good friends.
11329: 
11330: This method of watching, or rather of originating, a conflict of
11331: assertions, not for the purpose of finally deciding in favour of either
11332: side, but to discover whether the object of the struggle is not a mere
11333: illusion, which each strives in vain to reach, but which would be no
11334: gain even when reached—this procedure, I say, may be termed the
11335: sceptical method. It is thoroughly distinct from scepticism—the
11336: principle of a technical and scientific ignorance, which undermines the
11337: foundations of all knowledge, in order, if possible, to destroy our
11338: belief and confidence therein. For the sceptical method aims at
11339: certainty, by endeavouring to discover in a conflict of this kind,
11340: conducted honestly and intelligently on both sides, the point of
11341: misunderstanding; just as wise legislators derive, from the
11342: embarrassment of judges in lawsuits, information in regard to the
11343: defective and ill-defined parts of their statutes. The antinomy which
11344: reveals itself in the application of laws, is for our limited wisdom
11345: the best criterion of legislation. For the attention of reason, which
11346: in abstract speculation does not easily become conscious of its errors,
11347: is thus roused to the momenta in the determination of its principles.
11348: 
11349: But this sceptical method is essentially peculiar to transcendental
11350: philosophy, and can perhaps be dispensed with in every other field of
11351: investigation. In mathematics its use would be absurd; because in it no
11352: false assertions can long remain hidden, inasmuch as its demonstrations
11353: must always proceed under the guidance of pure intuition, and by means
11354: of an always evident synthesis. In experimental philosophy, doubt and
11355: delay may be very useful; but no misunderstanding is possible, which
11356: cannot be easily removed; and in experience means of solving the
11357: difficulty and putting an end to the dissension must at last be found,
11358: whether sooner or later. Moral philosophy can always exhibit its
11359: principles, with their practical consequences, in concreto—at least in
11360: possible experiences, and thus escape the mistakes and ambiguities of
11361: abstraction. But transcendental propositions, which lay claim to
11362: insight beyond the region of possible experience, cannot, on the one
11363: hand, exhibit their abstract synthesis in any à priori intuition, nor,
11364: on the other, expose a lurking error by the help of experience.
11365: Transcendental reason, therefore, presents us with no other criterion
11366: than that of an attempt to reconcile such assertions, and for this
11367: purpose to permit a free and unrestrained conflict between them. And
11368: this we now proceed to arrange.[50]
11369: 
11370:  [50] The antinomies stand in the order of the four transcendental
11371:  ideas above detailed.
11372: 
11373: 
11374: FIRST CONFLICT OF THE TRANSCENDENTAL IDEAS. THESIS.
11375: 
11376: The world has a beginning in time, and is also limited in regard to
11377: space.
11378: 
11379: PROOF.
11380: 
11381: Granted that the world has no beginning in time; up to every given
11382: moment of time, an eternity must have elapsed, and therewith passed
11383: away an infinite series of successive conditions or states of things in
11384: the world. Now the infinity of a series consists in the fact that it
11385: never can be completed by means of a successive synthesis. It follows
11386: that an infinite series already elapsed is impossible and that,
11387: consequently, a beginning of the world is a necessary condition of its
11388: existence. And this was the first thing to be proved.
11389: 
11390: As regards the second, let us take the opposite for granted. In this
11391: case, the world must be an infinite given total of coexistent things.
11392: Now we cannot cogitate the dimensions of a quantity, which is not given
11393: within certain limits of an intuition,[51] in any other way than by
11394: means of the synthesis of its parts, and the total of such a quantity
11395: only by means of a completed synthesis, or the repeated addition of
11396: unity to itself. Accordingly, to cogitate the world, which fills all
11397: spaces, as a whole, the successive synthesis of the parts of an
11398: infinite world must be looked upon as completed, that is to say, an
11399: infinite time must be regarded as having elapsed in the enumeration of
11400: all co-existing things; which is impossible. For this reason an
11401: infinite aggregate of actual things cannot be considered as a given
11402: whole, consequently, not as a contemporaneously given whole. The world
11403: is consequently, as regards extension in space, not infinite, but
11404: enclosed in limits. And this was the second thing to be proved.
11405: 
11406:  [51] We may consider an undetermined quantity as a whole, when it is
11407:  enclosed within limits, although we cannot construct or ascertain its
11408:  totality by measurement, that is, by the successive synthesis of its
11409:  parts. For its limits of themselves determine its completeness as a
11410:  whole.
11411: 
11412: 
11413: ANTITHESIS.
11414: 
11415: The world has no beginning, and no limits in space, but is, in relation
11416: both to time and space, infinite.
11417: 
11418: PROOF.
11419: 
11420: For let it be granted that it has a beginning. A beginning is an
11421: existence which is preceded by a time in which the thing does not
11422: exist. On the above supposition, it follows that there must have been a
11423: time in which the world did not exist, that is, a void time. But in a
11424: void time the origination of a thing is impossible; because no part of
11425: any such time contains a distinctive condition of being, in preference
11426: to that of non-being (whether the supposed thing originate of itself,
11427: or by means of some other cause). Consequently, many series of things
11428: may have a beginning in the world, but the world itself cannot have a
11429: beginning, and is, therefore, in relation to past time, infinite.
11430: 
11431: As regards the second statement, let us first take the opposite for
11432: granted—that the world is finite and limited in space; it follows that
11433: it must exist in a void space, which is not limited. We should
11434: therefore meet not only with a relation of things in space, but also a
11435: relation of things to space. Now, as the world is an absolute whole,
11436: out of and beyond which no object of intuition, and consequently no
11437: correlate to which can be discovered, this relation of the world to a
11438: void space is merely a relation to no object. But such a relation, and
11439: consequently the limitation of the world by void space, is nothing.
11440: Consequently, the world, as regards space, is not limited, that is, it
11441: is infinite in regard to extension.[52]
11442: 
11443:  [52] Space is merely the form of external intuition (formal
11444:  intuition), and not a real object which can be externally perceived.
11445:  Space, prior to all things which determine it (fill or limit it), or,
11446:  rather, which present an empirical intuition conformable to it, is,
11447:  under the title of absolute space, nothing but the mere possibility of
11448:  external phenomena, in so far as they either exist in themselves, or
11449:  can annex themselves to given intuitions. Empirical intuition is
11450:  therefore not a composition of phenomena and space (of perception and
11451:  empty intuition). The one is not the correlate of the other in a
11452:  synthesis, but they are vitally connected in the same empirical
11453:  intuition, as matter and form. If we wish to set one of these two
11454:  apart from the other—space from phenomena—there arise all sorts of
11455:  empty determinations of external intuition, which are very far from
11456:  being possible perceptions. For example, motion or rest of the world
11457:  in an infinite empty space, or a determination of the mutual relation
11458:  of both, cannot possibly be perceived, and is therefore merely the
11459:  predicate of a notional entity.
11460: 
11461: 
11462: OBSERVATIONS ON THE FIRST ANTINOMY. ON THE THESIS.
11463: 
11464: In bringing forward these conflicting arguments, I have not been on the
11465: search for sophisms, for the purpose of availing myself of special
11466: pleading, which takes advantage of the carelessness of the opposite
11467: party, appeals to a misunderstood statute, and erects its unrighteous
11468: claims upon an unfair interpretation. Both proofs originate fairly from
11469: the nature of the case, and the advantage presented by the mistakes of
11470: the dogmatists of both parties has been completely set aside.
11471: 
11472: The thesis might also have been unfairly demonstrated, by the
11473: introduction of an erroneous conception of the infinity of a given
11474: quantity. A quantity is infinite, if a greater than itself cannot
11475: possibly exist. The quantity is measured by the number of given
11476: units—which are taken as a standard—contained in it. Now no number can
11477: be the greatest, because one or more units can always be added. It
11478: follows that an infinite given quantity, consequently an infinite world
11479: (both as regards time and extension) is impossible. It is, therefore,
11480: limited in both respects. In this manner I might have conducted my
11481: proof; but the conception given in it does not agree with the true
11482: conception of an infinite whole. In this there is no representation of
11483: its quantity, it is not said how large it is; consequently its
11484: conception is not the conception of a maximum. We cogitate in it merely
11485: its relation to an arbitrarily assumed unit, in relation to which it is
11486: greater than any number. Now, just as the unit which is taken is
11487: greater or smaller, the infinite will be greater or smaller; but the
11488: infinity, which consists merely in the relation to this given unit,
11489: must remain always the same, although the absolute quantity of the
11490: whole is not thereby cognized.
11491: 
11492: The true (transcendental) conception of infinity is: that the
11493: successive synthesis of unity in the measurement of a given quantum can
11494: never be completed.[53] Hence it follows, without possibility of
11495: mistake, that an eternity of actual successive states up to a given
11496: (the present) moment cannot have elapsed, and that the world must
11497: therefore have a beginning.
11498: 
11499:  [53] The quantum in this sense contains a congeries of given units,
11500:  which is greater than any number—and this is the mathematical
11501:  conception of the infinite.
11502: 
11503: 
11504: In regard to the second part of the thesis, the difficulty as to an
11505: infinite and yet elapsed series disappears; for the manifold of a world
11506: infinite in extension is contemporaneously given. But, in order to
11507: cogitate the total of this manifold, as we cannot have the aid of
11508: limits constituting by themselves this total in intuition, we are
11509: obliged to give some account of our conception, which in this case
11510: cannot proceed from the whole to the determined quantity of the parts,
11511: but must demonstrate the possibility of a whole by means of a
11512: successive synthesis of the parts. But as this synthesis must
11513: constitute a series that cannot be completed, it is impossible for us
11514: to cogitate prior to it, and consequently not by means of it, a
11515: totality. For the conception of totality itself is in the present case
11516: the representation of a completed synthesis of the parts; and this
11517: completion, and consequently its conception, is impossible.
11518: 
11519: ON THE ANTITHESIS.
11520: 
11521: The proof in favour of the infinity of the cosmical succession and the
11522: cosmical content is based upon the consideration that, in the opposite
11523: case, a void time and a void space must constitute the limits of the
11524: world. Now I am not unaware, that there are some ways of escaping this
11525: conclusion. It may, for example, be alleged, that a limit to the world,
11526: as regards both space and time, is quite possible, without at the same
11527: time holding the existence of an absolute time before the beginning of
11528: the world, or an absolute space extending beyond the actual world—which
11529: is impossible. I am quite well satisfied with the latter part of this
11530: opinion of the philosophers of the Leibnitzian school. Space is merely
11531: the form of external intuition, but not a real object which can itself
11532: be externally intuited; it is not a correlate of phenomena, it is the
11533: form of phenomena itself. Space, therefore, cannot be regarded as
11534: absolutely and in itself something determinative of the existence of
11535: things, because it is not itself an object, but only the form of
11536: possible objects. Consequently, things, as phenomena, determine space;
11537: that is to say, they render it possible that, of all the possible
11538: predicates of space (size and relation), certain may belong to reality.
11539: But we cannot affirm the converse, that space, as something
11540: self-subsistent, can determine real things in regard to size or shape,
11541: for it is in itself not a real thing. Space (filled or void)[54] may
11542: therefore be limited by phenomena, but phenomena cannot be limited by
11543: an empty space without them. This is true of time also. All this being
11544: granted, it is nevertheless indisputable, that we must assume these two
11545: nonentities, void space without and void time before the world, if we
11546: assume the existence of cosmical limits, relatively to space or time.
11547: 
11548:  [54] It is evident that what is meant here is, that empty space, in so
11549:  far as it is limited by phenomena—space, that is, within the
11550:  world—does not at least contradict transcendental principles, and may
11551:  therefore, as regards them, be admitted, although its possibility
11552:  cannot on that account be affirmed.
11553: 
11554: 
11555: For, as regards the subterfuge adopted by those who endeavour to evade
11556: the consequence—that, if the world is limited as to space and time, the
11557: infinite void must determine the existence of actual things in regard
11558: to their dimensions—it arises solely from the fact that instead of a
11559: sensuous world, an intelligible world—of which nothing is known—is
11560: cogitated; instead of a real beginning (an existence, which is preceded
11561: by a period in which nothing exists), an existence which presupposes no
11562: other condition than that of time; and, instead of limits of extension,
11563: boundaries of the universe. But the question relates to the mundus
11564: phaenomenon, and its quantity; and in this case we cannot make
11565: abstraction of the conditions of sensibility, without doing away with
11566: the essential reality of this world itself. The world of sense, if it
11567: is limited, must necessarily lie in the infinite void. If this, and
11568: with it space as the à priori condition of the possibility of
11569: phenomena, is left out of view, the whole world of sense disappears. In
11570: our problem is this alone considered as given. The mundus
11571: intelligibilis is nothing but the general conception of a world, in
11572: which abstraction has been made of all conditions of intuition, and in
11573: relation to which no synthetical proposition—either affirmative or
11574: negative—is possible.
11575: 
11576: SECOND CONFLICT OF TRANSCENDENTAL IDEAS. THESIS.
11577: 
11578: Every composite substance in the world consists of simple parts; and
11579: there exists nothing that is not either itself simple, or composed of
11580: simple parts.
11581: 
11582: PROOF.
11583: 
11584: For, grant that composite substances do not consist of simple parts; in
11585: this case, if all combination or composition were annihilated in
11586: thought, no composite part, and (as, by the supposition, there do not
11587: exist simple parts) no simple part would exist. Consequently, no
11588: substance; consequently, nothing would exist. Either, then, it is
11589: impossible to annihilate composition in thought; or, after such
11590: annihilation, there must remain something that subsists without
11591: composition, that is, something that is simple. But in the former case
11592: the composite could not itself consist of substances, because with
11593: substances composition is merely a contingent relation, apart from
11594: which they must still exist as self-subsistent beings. Now, as this
11595: case contradicts the supposition, the second must contain the
11596: truth—that the substantial composite in the world consists of simple
11597: parts.
11598: 
11599: It follows, as an immediate inference, that the things in the world are
11600: all, without exception, simple beings—that composition is merely an
11601: external condition pertaining to them—and that, although we never can
11602: separate and isolate the elementary substances from the state of
11603: composition, reason must cogitate these as the primary subjects of all
11604: composition, and consequently, as prior thereto—and as simple
11605: substances.
11606: 
11607: ANTITHESIS.
11608: 
11609: No composite thing in the world consists of simple parts; and there
11610: does not exist in the world any simple substance.
11611: 
11612: PROOF.
11613: 
11614: Let it be supposed that a composite thing (as substance) consists of
11615: simple parts. Inasmuch as all external relation, consequently all
11616: composition of substances, is possible only in space; the space,
11617: occupied by that which is composite, must consist of the same number of
11618: parts as is contained in the composite. But space does not consist of
11619: simple parts, but of spaces. Therefore, every part of the composite
11620: must occupy a space. But the absolutely primary parts of what is
11621: composite are simple. It follows that what is simple occupies a space.
11622: Now, as everything real that occupies a space, contains a manifold the
11623: parts of which are external to each other, and is consequently
11624: composite—and a real composite, not of accidents (for these cannot
11625: exist external to each other apart from substance), but of
11626: substances—it follows that the simple must be a substantial composite,
11627: which is self-contradictory.
11628: 
11629: The second proposition of the antithesis—that there exists in the world
11630: nothing that is simple—is here equivalent to the following: The
11631: existence of the absolutely simple cannot be demonstrated from any
11632: experience or perception either external or internal; and the
11633: absolutely simple is a mere idea, the objective reality of which cannot
11634: be demonstrated in any possible experience; it is consequently, in the
11635: exposition of phenomena, without application and object. For, let us
11636: take for granted that an object may be found in experience for this
11637: transcendental idea; the empirical intuition of such an object must
11638: then be recognized to contain absolutely no manifold with its parts
11639: external to each other, and connected into unity. Now, as we cannot
11640: reason from the non-consciousness of such a manifold to the
11641: impossibility of its existence in the intuition of an object, and as
11642: the proof of this impossibility is necessary for the establishment and
11643: proof of absolute simplicity; it follows that this simplicity cannot be
11644: inferred from any perception whatever. As, therefore, an absolutely
11645: simple object cannot be given in any experience, and the world of sense
11646: must be considered as the sum total of all possible experiences:
11647: nothing simple exists in the world.
11648: 
11649: This second proposition in the antithesis has a more extended aim than
11650: the first. The first merely banishes the simple from the intuition of
11651: the composite; while the second drives it entirely out of nature. Hence
11652: we were unable to demonstrate it from the conception of a given object
11653: of external intuition (of the composite), but we were obliged to prove
11654: it from the relation of a given object to a possible experience in
11655: general.
11656: 
11657: OBSERVATIONS ON THE SECOND ANTINOMY. THESIS.
11658: 
11659: When I speak of a whole, which necessarily consists of simple parts, I
11660: understand thereby only a substantial whole, as the true composite;
11661: that is to say, I understand that contingent unity of the manifold
11662: which is given as perfectly isolated (at least in thought), placed in
11663: reciprocal connection, and thus constituted a unity. Space ought not to
11664: be called a compositum but a totum, for its parts are possible in the
11665: whole, and not the whole by means of the parts. It might perhaps be
11666: called a compositum ideale, but not a compositum reale. But this is of
11667: no importance. As space is not a composite of substances (and not even
11668: of real accidents), if I abstract all composition therein—nothing, not
11669: even a point, remains; for a point is possible only as the limit of a
11670: space—consequently of a composite. Space and time, therefore, do not
11671: consist of simple parts. That which belongs only to the condition or
11672: state of a substance, even although it possesses a quantity (motion or
11673: change, for example), likewise does not consist of simple parts. That
11674: is to say, a certain degree of change does not originate from the
11675: addition of many simple changes. Our inference of the simple from the
11676: composite is valid only of self-subsisting things. But the accidents of
11677: a state are not self-subsistent. The proof, then, for the necessity of
11678: the simple, as the component part of all that is substantial and
11679: composite, may prove a failure, and the whole case of this thesis be
11680: lost, if we carry the proposition too far, and wish to make it valid of
11681: everything that is composite without distinction—as indeed has really
11682: now and then happened. Besides, I am here speaking only of the simple,
11683: in so far as it is necessarily given in the composite—the latter being
11684: capable of solution into the former as its component parts. The proper
11685: signification of the word monas (as employed by Leibnitz) ought to
11686: relate to the simple, given immediately as simple substance (for
11687: example, in consciousness), and not as an element of the composite. As
11688: an clement, the term atomus would be more appropriate. And as I wish to
11689: prove the existence of simple substances, only in relation to, and as
11690: the elements of, the composite, I might term the antithesis of the
11691: second Antinomy, transcendental Atomistic. But as this word has long
11692: been employed to designate a particular theory of corporeal phenomena
11693: (moleculae), and thus presupposes a basis of empirical conceptions, I
11694: prefer calling it the dialectical principle of Monadology.
11695: 
11696: ANTITHESIS.
11697: 
11698: Against the assertion of the infinite subdivisibility of matter whose
11699: ground of proof is purely mathematical, objections have been alleged by
11700: the Monadists. These objections lay themselves open, at first sight, to
11701: suspicion, from the fact that they do not recognize the clearest
11702: mathematical proofs as propositions relating to the constitution of
11703: space, in so far as it is really the formal condition of the
11704: possibility of all matter, but regard them merely as inferences from
11705: abstract but arbitrary conceptions, which cannot have any application
11706: to real things. Just as if it were possible to imagine another mode of
11707: intuition than that given in the primitive intuition of space; and just
11708: as if its à priori determinations did not apply to everything, the
11709: existence of which is possible, from the fact alone of its filling
11710: space. If we listen to them, we shall find ourselves required to
11711: cogitate, in addition to the mathematical point, which is simple—not,
11712: however, a part, but a mere limit of space—physical points, which are
11713: indeed likewise simple, but possess the peculiar property, as parts of
11714: space, of filling it merely by their aggregation. I shall not repeat
11715: here the common and clear refutations of this absurdity, which are to
11716: be found everywhere in numbers: every one knows that it is impossible
11717: to undermine the evidence of mathematics by mere discursive
11718: conceptions; I shall only remark that, if in this case philosophy
11719: endeavours to gain an advantage over mathematics by sophistical
11720: artifices, it is because it forgets that the discussion relates solely
11721: to Phenomena and their conditions. It is not sufficient to find the
11722: conception of the simple for the pure conception of the composite, but
11723: we must discover for the intuition of the composite (matter), the
11724: intuition of the simple. Now this, according to the laws of
11725: sensibility, and consequently in the case of objects of sense, is
11726: utterly impossible. In the case of a whole composed of substances,
11727: which is cogitated solely by the pure understanding, it may be
11728: necessary to be in possession of the simple before composition is
11729: possible. But this does not hold good of the Totum substantiale
11730: phaenomenon, which, as an empirical intuition in space, possesses the
11731: necessary property of containing no simple part, for the very reason
11732: that no part of space is simple. Meanwhile, the Monadists have been
11733: subtle enough to escape from this difficulty, by presupposing intuition
11734: and the dynamical relation of substances as the condition of the
11735: possibility of space, instead of regarding space as the condition of
11736: the possibility of the objects of external intuition, that is, of
11737: bodies. Now we have a conception of bodies only as phenomena, and, as
11738: such, they necessarily presuppose space as the condition of all
11739: external phenomena. The evasion is therefore in vain; as, indeed, we
11740: have sufficiently shown in our Æsthetic. If bodies were things in
11741: themselves, the proof of the Monadists would be unexceptionable.
11742: 
11743: The second dialectical assertion possesses the peculiarity of having
11744: opposed to it a dogmatical proposition, which, among all such
11745: sophistical statements, is the only one that undertakes to prove in the
11746: case of an object of experience, that which is properly a
11747: transcendental idea—the absolute simplicity of substance. The
11748: proposition is that the object of the internal sense, the thinking Ego,
11749: is an absolute simple substance. Without at present entering upon this
11750: subject—as it has been considered at length in a former chapter—I shall
11751: merely remark that, if something is cogitated merely as an object,
11752: without the addition of any synthetical determination of its
11753: intuition—as happens in the case of the bare representation, I—it is
11754: certain that no manifold and no composition can be perceived in such a
11755: representation. As, moreover, the predicates whereby I cogitate this
11756: object are merely intuitions of the internal sense, there cannot be
11757: discovered in them anything to prove the existence of a manifold whose
11758: parts are external to each other, and, consequently, nothing to prove
11759: the existence of real composition. Consciousness, therefore, is so
11760: constituted that, inasmuch as the thinking subject is at the same time
11761: its own object, it cannot divide itself—although it can divide its
11762: inhering determinations. For every object in relation to itself is
11763: absolute unity. Nevertheless, if the subject is regarded externally, as
11764: an object of intuition, it must, in its character of phenomenon,
11765: possess the property of composition. And it must always be regarded in
11766: this manner, if we wish to know whether there is or is not contained in
11767: it a manifold whose parts are external to each other.
11768: 
11769: THIRD CONFLICT OF THE TRANSCENDENTAL IDEAS. THESIS.
11770: 
11771: Causality according to the laws of nature, is not the only causality
11772: operating to originate the phenomena of the world. A causality of
11773: freedom is also necessary to account fully for these phenomena.
11774: 
11775: PROOF.
11776: 
11777: Let it be supposed, that there is no other kind of causality than that
11778: according to the laws of nature. Consequently, everything that happens
11779: presupposes a previous condition, which it follows with absolute
11780: certainty, in conformity with a rule. But this previous condition must
11781: itself be something that has happened (that has arisen in time, as it
11782: did not exist before), for, if it has always been in existence, its
11783: consequence or effect would not thus originate for the first time, but
11784: would likewise have always existed. The causality, therefore, of a
11785: cause, whereby something happens, is itself a thing that has happened.
11786: Now this again presupposes, in conformity with the law of nature, a
11787: previous condition and its causality, and this another anterior to the
11788: former, and so on. If, then, everything happens solely in accordance
11789: with the laws of nature, there cannot be any real first beginning of
11790: things, but only a subaltern or comparative beginning. There cannot,
11791: therefore, be a completeness of series on the side of the causes which
11792: originate the one from the other. But the law of nature is that nothing
11793: can happen without a sufficient à priori determined cause. The
11794: proposition therefore—if all causality is possible only in accordance
11795: with the laws of nature—is, when stated in this unlimited and general
11796: manner, self-contradictory. It follows that this cannot be the only
11797: kind of causality.
11798: 
11799: From what has been said, it follows that a causality must be admitted,
11800: by means of which something happens, without its cause being determined
11801: according to necessary laws by some other cause preceding. That is to
11802: say, there must exist an absolute spontaneity of cause, which of itself
11803: originates a series of phenomena which proceeds according to natural
11804: laws—consequently transcendental freedom, without which even in the
11805: course of nature the succession of phenomena on the side of causes is
11806: never complete.
11807: 
11808: ANTITHESIS.
11809: 
11810: There is no such thing as freedom, but everything in the world happens
11811: solely according to the laws of nature.
11812: 
11813: PROOF.
11814: 
11815: Granted, that there does exist freedom in the transcendental sense, as
11816: a peculiar kind of causality, operating to produce events in the
11817: world—a faculty, that is to say, of originating a state, and
11818: consequently a series of consequences from that state. In this case,
11819: not only the series originated by this spontaneity, but the
11820: determination of this spontaneity itself to the production of the
11821: series, that is to say, the causality itself must have an absolute
11822: commencement, such that nothing can precede to determine this action
11823: according to unvarying laws. But every beginning of action presupposes
11824: in the acting cause a state of inaction; and a dynamically primal
11825: beginning of action presupposes a state, which has no connection—as
11826: regards causality—with the preceding state of the cause—which does not,
11827: that is, in any wise result from it. Transcendental freedom is
11828: therefore opposed to the natural law of cause and effect, and such a
11829: conjunction of successive states in effective causes is destructive of
11830: the possibility of unity in experience and for that reason not to be
11831: found in experience—is consequently a mere fiction of thought.
11832: 
11833: We have, therefore, nothing but nature to which we must look for
11834: connection and order in cosmical events. Freedom—independence of the
11835: laws of nature—is certainly a deliverance from restraint, but it is
11836: also a relinquishing of the guidance of law and rule. For it cannot be
11837: alleged that, instead of the laws of nature, laws of freedom may be
11838: introduced into the causality of the course of nature. For, if freedom
11839: were determined according to laws, it would be no longer freedom, but
11840: merely nature. Nature, therefore, and transcendental freedom are
11841: distinguishable as conformity to law and lawlessness. The former
11842: imposes upon understanding the difficulty of seeking the origin of
11843: events ever higher and higher in the series of causes, inasmuch as
11844: causality is always conditioned thereby; while it compensates this
11845: labour by the guarantee of a unity complete and in conformity with law.
11846: The latter, on the contrary, holds out to the understanding the promise
11847: of a point of rest in the chain of causes, by conducting it to an
11848: unconditioned causality, which professes to have the power of
11849: spontaneous origination, but which, in its own utter blindness,
11850: deprives it of the guidance of rules, by which alone a completely
11851: connected experience is possible.
11852: 
11853: OBSERVATIONS ON THE THIRD ANTINOMY. ON THE THESIS.
11854: 
11855: The transcendental idea of freedom is far from constituting the entire
11856: content of the psychological conception so termed, which is for the
11857: most part empirical. It merely presents us with the conception of
11858: spontaneity of action, as the proper ground for imputing freedom to the
11859: cause of a certain class of objects. It is, however, the true
11860: stumbling-stone to philosophy, which meets with unconquerable
11861: difficulties in the way of its admitting this kind of unconditioned
11862: causality. That element in the question of the freedom of the will,
11863: which has for so long a time placed speculative reason in such
11864: perplexity, is properly only transcendental, and concerns the question,
11865: whether there must be held to exist a faculty of spontaneous
11866: origination of a series of successive things or states. How such a
11867: faculty is possible is not a necessary inquiry; for in the case of
11868: natural causality itself, we are obliged to content ourselves with the
11869: à priori knowledge that such a causality must be presupposed, although
11870: we are quite incapable of comprehending how the being of one thing is
11871: possible through the being of another, but must for this information
11872: look entirely to experience. Now we have demonstrated this necessity of
11873: a free first beginning of a series of phenomena, only in so far as it
11874: is required for the comprehension of an origin of the world, all
11875: following states being regarded as a succession according to laws of
11876: nature alone. But, as there has thus been proved the existence of a
11877: faculty which can of itself originate a series in time—although we are
11878: unable to explain how it can exist—we feel ourselves authorized to
11879: admit, even in the midst of the natural course of events, a beginning,
11880: as regards causality, of different successions of phenomena, and at the
11881: same time to attribute to all substances a faculty of free action. But
11882: we ought in this case not to allow ourselves to fall into a common
11883: misunderstanding, and to suppose that, because a successive series in
11884: the world can only have a comparatively first beginning—another state
11885: or condition of things always preceding—an absolutely first beginning
11886: of a series in the course of nature is impossible. For we are not
11887: speaking here of an absolutely first beginning in relation to time, but
11888: as regards causality alone. When, for example, I, completely of my own
11889: free will, and independently of the necessarily determinative influence
11890: of natural causes, rise from my chair, there commences with this event,
11891: including its material consequences in infinitum, an absolutely new
11892: series; although, in relation to time, this event is merely the
11893: continuation of a preceding series. For this resolution and act of mine
11894: do not form part of the succession of effects in nature, and are not
11895: mere continuations of it; on the contrary, the determining causes of
11896: nature cease to operate in reference to this event, which certainly
11897: succeeds the acts of nature, but does not proceed from them. For these
11898: reasons, the action of a free agent must be termed, in regard to
11899: causality, if not in relation to time, an absolutely primal beginning
11900: of a series of phenomena.
11901: 
11902: The justification of this need of reason to rest upon a free act as the
11903: first beginning of the series of natural causes is evident from the
11904: fact, that all philosophers of antiquity (with the exception of the
11905: Epicurean school) felt themselves obliged, when constructing a theory
11906: of the motions of the universe, to accept a prime mover, that is, a
11907: freely acting cause, which spontaneously and prior to all other causes
11908: evolved this series of states. They always felt the need of going
11909: beyond mere nature, for the purpose of making a first beginning
11910: comprehensible.
11911: 
11912: ON THE ANTITHESIS.
11913: 
11914: The assertor of the all-sufficiency of nature in regard to causality
11915: (transcendental Physiocracy), in opposition to the doctrine of freedom,
11916: would defend his view of the question somewhat in the following manner.
11917: He would say, in answer to the sophistical arguments of the opposite
11918: party: If you do not accept a mathematical first, in relation to time,
11919: you have no need to seek a dynamical first, in regard to causality. Who
11920: compelled you to imagine an absolutely primal condition of the world,
11921: and therewith an absolute beginning of the gradually progressing
11922: successions of phenomena—and, as some foundation for this fancy of
11923: yours, to set bounds to unlimited nature? Inasmuch as the substances in
11924: the world have always existed—at least the unity of experience renders
11925: such a supposition quite necessary—there is no difficulty in believing
11926: also, that the changes in the conditions of these substances have
11927: always existed; and, consequently, that a first beginning, mathematical
11928: or dynamical, is by no means required. The possibility of such an
11929: infinite derivation, without any initial member from which all the
11930: others result, is certainly quite incomprehensible. But, if you are
11931: rash enough to deny the enigmatical secrets of nature for this reason,
11932: you will find yourselves obliged to deny also the existence of many
11933: fundamental properties of natural objects (such as fundamental forces),
11934: which you can just as little comprehend; and even the possibility of so
11935: simple a conception as that of change must present to you insuperable
11936: difficulties. For if experience did not teach you that it was real, you
11937: never could conceive à priori the possibility of this ceaseless
11938: sequence of being and non-being.
11939: 
11940: But if the existence of a transcendental faculty of freedom is
11941: granted—a faculty of originating changes in the world—this faculty must
11942: at least exist out of and apart from the world; although it is
11943: certainly a bold assumption, that, over and above the complete content
11944: of all possible intuitions, there still exists an object which cannot
11945: be presented in any possible perception. But, to attribute to
11946: substances in the world itself such a faculty, is quite inadmissible;
11947: for, in this case; the connection of phenomena reciprocally determining
11948: and determined according to general laws, which is termed nature, and
11949: along with it the criteria of empirical truth, which enable us to
11950: distinguish experience from mere visionary dreaming, would almost
11951: entirely disappear. In proximity with such a lawless faculty of
11952: freedom, a system of nature is hardly cogitable; for the laws of the
11953: latter would be continually subject to the intrusive influences of the
11954: former, and the course of phenomena, which would otherwise proceed
11955: regularly and uniformly, would become thereby confused and
11956: disconnected.
11957: 
11958: FOURTH CONFLICT OF THE TRANSCENDENTAL IDEAS. THESIS.
11959: 
11960: There exists either in, or in connection with the world—either as a
11961: part of it, or as the cause of it—an absolutely necessary being.
11962: 
11963: PROOF.
11964: 
11965: The world of sense, as the sum total of all phenomena, contains a
11966: series of changes. For, without such a series, the mental
11967: representation of the series of time itself, as the condition of the
11968: possibility of the sensuous world, could not be presented to us.[55]
11969: But every change stands under its condition, which precedes it in time
11970: and renders it necessary. Now the existence of a given condition
11971: presupposes a complete series of conditions up to the absolutely
11972: unconditioned, which alone is absolutely necessary. It follows that
11973: something that is absolutely necessary must exist, if change exists as
11974: its consequence. But this necessary thing itself belongs to the
11975: sensuous world. For suppose it to exist out of and apart from it, the
11976: series of cosmical changes would receive from it a beginning, and yet
11977: this necessary cause would not itself belong to the world of sense. But
11978: this is impossible. For, as the beginning of a series in time is
11979: determined only by that which precedes it in time, the supreme
11980: condition of the beginning of a series of changes must exist in the
11981: time in which this series itself did not exist; for a beginning
11982: supposes a time preceding, in which the thing that begins to be was not
11983: in existence. The causality of the necessary cause of changes, and
11984: consequently the cause itself, must for these reasons belong to
11985: time—and to phenomena, time being possible only as the form of
11986: phenomena. Consequently, it cannot be cogitated as separated from the
11987: world of sense—the sum total of all phenomena. There is, therefore,
11988: contained in the world, something that is absolutely necessary—whether
11989: it be the whole cosmical series itself, or only a part of it.
11990: 
11991:  [55] Objectively, time, as the formal condition of the possibility of
11992:  change, precedes all changes; but subjectively, and in consciousness,
11993:  the representation of time, like every other, is given solely by
11994:  occasion of perception.
11995: 
11996: 
11997: ANTITHESIS.
11998: 
11999: An absolutely necessary being does not exist, either in the world, or
12000: out of it—as its cause.
12001: 
12002: PROOF.
12003: 
12004: Grant that either the world itself is necessary, or that there is
12005: contained in it a necessary existence. Two cases are possible. First,
12006: there must either be in the series of cosmical changes a beginning,
12007: which is unconditionally necessary, and therefore uncaused—which is at
12008: variance with the dynamical law of the determination of all phenomena
12009: in time; or, secondly, the series itself is without beginning, and,
12010: although contingent and conditioned in all its parts, is nevertheless
12011: absolutely necessary and unconditioned as a whole—which is
12012: self-contradictory. For the existence of an aggregate cannot be
12013: necessary, if no single part of it possesses necessary existence.
12014: 
12015: Grant, on the other hand, that an absolutely necessary cause exists out
12016: of and apart from the world. This cause, as the highest member in the
12017: series of the causes of cosmical changes, must originate or begin[56]
12018: the existence of the latter and their series. In this case it must also
12019: begin to act, and its causality would therefore belong to time, and
12020: consequently to the sum total of phenomena, that is, to the world. It
12021: follows that the cause cannot be out of the world; which is
12022: contradictory to the hypothesis. Therefore, neither in the world, nor
12023: out of it (but in causal connection with it), does there exist any
12024: absolutely necessary being.
12025:
