12026:  [56] The word begin is taken in two senses. The first is active—the
12027:  cause being regarded as beginning a series of conditions as its effect
12028:  (infit). The second is passive—the causality in the cause itself
12029:  beginning to operate (fit). I reason here from the first to the
12030:  second.
12031: 
12032: 
12033: OBSERVATIONS ON THE FOURTH ANTINOMY. ON THE THESIS.
12034: 
12035: To demonstrate the existence of a necessary being, I cannot be
12036: permitted in this place to employ any other than the cosmological
12037: argument, which ascends from the conditioned in phenomena to the
12038: unconditioned in conception—the unconditioned being considered the
12039: necessary condition of the absolute totality of the series. The proof,
12040: from the mere idea of a supreme being, belongs to another principle of
12041: reason and requires separate discussion.
12042: 
12043: The pure cosmological proof demonstrates the existence of a necessary
12044: being, but at the same time leaves it quite unsettled, whether this
12045: being is the world itself, or quite distinct from it. To establish the
12046: truth of the latter view, principles are requisite, which are not
12047: cosmological and do not proceed in the series of phenomena. We should
12048: require to introduce into our proof conceptions of contingent
12049: beings—regarded merely as objects of the understanding, and also a
12050: principle which enables us to connect these, by means of mere
12051: conceptions, with a necessary being. But the proper place for all such
12052: arguments is a transcendent philosophy, which has unhappily not yet
12053: been established.
12054: 
12055: But, if we begin our proof cosmologically, by laying at the foundation
12056: of it the series of phenomena, and the regress in it according to
12057: empirical laws of causality, we are not at liberty to break off from
12058: this mode of demonstration and to pass over to something which is not
12059: itself a member of the series. The condition must be taken in exactly
12060: the same signification as the relation of the conditioned to its
12061: condition in the series has been taken, for the series must conduct us
12062: in an unbroken regress to this supreme condition. But if this relation
12063: is sensuous, and belongs to the possible empirical employment of
12064: understanding, the supreme condition or cause must close the regressive
12065: series according to the laws of sensibility and consequently, must
12066: belong to the series of time. It follows that this necessary existence
12067: must be regarded as the highest member of the cosmical series.
12068: 
12069: Certain philosophers have, nevertheless, allowed themselves the liberty
12070: of making such a saltus (metabasis eis allo gonos). From the changes in
12071: the world they have concluded their empirical contingency, that is,
12072: their dependence on empirically-determined causes, and they thus
12073: admitted an ascending series of empirical conditions: and in this they
12074: are quite right. But as they could not find in this series any primal
12075: beginning or any highest member, they passed suddenly from the
12076: empirical conception of contingency to the pure category, which
12077: presents us with a series—not sensuous, but intellectual—whose
12078: completeness does certainly rest upon the existence of an absolutely
12079: necessary cause. Nay, more, this intellectual series is not tied to any
12080: sensuous conditions; and is therefore free from the condition of time,
12081: which requires it spontaneously to begin its causality in time. But
12082: such a procedure is perfectly inadmissible, as will be made plain from
12083: what follows.
12084: 
12085: In the pure sense of the categories, that is contingent the
12086: contradictory opposite of which is possible. Now we cannot reason from
12087: empirical contingency to intellectual. The opposite of that which is
12088: changed—the opposite of its state—is actual at another time, and is
12089: therefore possible. Consequently, it is not the contradictory opposite
12090: of the former state. To be that, it is necessary that, in the same time
12091: in which the preceding state existed, its opposite could have existed
12092: in its place; but such a cognition is not given us in the mere
12093: phenomenon of change. A body that was in motion = A, comes into a state
12094: of rest = non-A. Now it cannot be concluded from the fact that a state
12095: opposite to the state A follows it, that the contradictory opposite of
12096: A is possible; and that A is therefore contingent. To prove this, we
12097: should require to know that the state of rest could have existed in the
12098: very same time in which the motion took place. Now we know nothing more
12099: than that the state of rest was actual in the time that followed the
12100: state of motion; consequently, that it was also possible. But motion at
12101: one time, and rest at another time, are not contradictorily opposed to
12102: each other. It follows from what has been said that the succession of
12103: opposite determinations, that is, change, does not demonstrate the fact
12104: of contingency as represented in the conceptions of the pure
12105: understanding; and that it cannot, therefore, conduct us to the fact of
12106: the existence of a necessary being. Change proves merely empirical
12107: contingency, that is to say, that the new state could not have existed
12108: without a cause, which belongs to the preceding time. This cause—even
12109: although it is regarded as absolutely necessary—must be presented to us
12110: in time, and must belong to the series of phenomena.
12111: 
12112: ON THE ANTITHESIS.
12113: 
12114: The difficulties which meet us, in our attempt to rise through the
12115: series of phenomena to the existence of an absolutely necessary supreme
12116: cause, must not originate from our inability to establish the truth of
12117: our mere conceptions of the necessary existence of a thing. That is to
12118: say, our objections not be ontological, but must be directed against
12119: the causal connection with a series of phenomena of a condition which
12120: is itself unconditioned. In one word, they must be cosmological and
12121: relate to empirical laws. We must show that the regress in the series
12122: of causes (in the world of sense) cannot conclude with an empirically
12123: unconditioned condition, and that the cosmological argument from the
12124: contingency of the cosmical state—a contingency alleged to arise from
12125: change—does not justify us in accepting a first cause, that is, a prime
12126: originator of the cosmical series.
12127: 
12128: The reader will observe in this antinomy a very remarkable contrast.
12129: The very same grounds of proof which established in the thesis the
12130: existence of a supreme being, demonstrated in the antithesis—and with
12131: equal strictness—the non-existence of such a being. We found, first,
12132: that a necessary being exists, because the whole time past contains the
12133: series of all conditions, and with it, therefore, the unconditioned
12134: (the necessary); secondly, that there does not exist any necessary
12135: being, for the same reason, that the whole time past contains the
12136: series of all conditions—which are themselves, therefore, in the
12137: aggregate, conditioned. The cause of this seeming incongruity is as
12138: follows. We attend, in the first argument, solely to the absolute
12139: totality of the series of conditions, the one of which determines the
12140: other in time, and thus arrive at a necessary unconditioned. In the
12141: second, we consider, on the contrary, the contingency of everything
12142: that is determined in the series of time—for every event is preceded by
12143: a time, in which the condition itself must be determined as
12144: conditioned—and thus everything that is unconditioned or absolutely
12145: necessary disappears. In both, the mode of proof is quite in accordance
12146: with the common procedure of human reason, which often falls into
12147: discord with itself, from considering an object from two different
12148: points of view. Herr von Mairan regarded the controversy between two
12149: celebrated astronomers, which arose from a similar difficulty as to the
12150: choice of a proper standpoint, as a phenomenon of sufficient importance
12151: to warrant a separate treatise on the subject. The one concluded: the
12152: moon revolves on its own axis, because it constantly presents the same
12153: side to the earth; the other declared that the moon does not revolve on
12154: its own axis, for the same reason. Both conclusions were perfectly
12155: correct, according to the point of view from which the motions of the
12156: moon were considered.
12157: 
12158: Section III. Of the Interest of Reason in these Self-contradictions
12159: 
12160: We have thus completely before us the dialectical procedure of the
12161: cosmological ideas. No possible experience can present us with an
12162: object adequate to them in extent. Nay, more, reason itself cannot
12163: cogitate them as according with the general laws of experience. And yet
12164: they are not arbitrary fictions of thought. On the contrary, reason, in
12165: its uninterrupted progress in the empirical synthesis, is necessarily
12166: conducted to them, when it endeavours to free from all conditions and
12167: to comprehend in its unconditioned totality that which can only be
12168: determined conditionally in accordance with the laws of experience.
12169: These dialectical propositions are so many attempts to solve four
12170: natural and unavoidable problems of reason. There are neither more, nor
12171: can there be less, than this number, because there are no other series
12172: of synthetical hypotheses, limiting à priori the empirical synthesis.
12173: 
12174: The brilliant claims of reason striving to extend its dominion beyond
12175: the limits of experience, have been represented above only in dry
12176: formulae, which contain merely the grounds of its pretensions. They
12177: have, besides, in conformity with the character of a transcendental
12178: philosophy, been freed from every empirical element; although the full
12179: splendour of the promises they hold out, and the anticipations they
12180: excite, manifests itself only when in connection with empirical
12181: cognitions. In the application of them, however, and in the advancing
12182: enlargement of the employment of reason, while struggling to rise from
12183: the region of experience and to soar to those sublime ideas, philosophy
12184: discovers a value and a dignity, which, if it could but make good its
12185: assertions, would raise it far above all other departments of human
12186: knowledge—professing, as it does, to present a sure foundation for our
12187: highest hopes and the ultimate aims of all the exertions of reason. The
12188: questions: whether the world has a beginning and a limit to its
12189: extension in space; whether there exists anywhere, or perhaps, in my
12190: own thinking Self, an indivisible and indestructible unity—or whether
12191: nothing but what is divisible and transitory exists; whether I am a
12192: free agent, or, like other beings, am bound in the chains of nature and
12193: fate; whether, finally, there is a supreme cause of the world, or all
12194: our thought and speculation must end with nature and the order of
12195: external things—are questions for the solution of which the
12196: mathematician would willingly exchange his whole science; for in it
12197: there is no satisfaction for the highest aspirations and most ardent
12198: desires of humanity. Nay, it may even be said that the true value of
12199: mathematics—that pride of human reason—consists in this: that she
12200: guides reason to the knowledge of nature—in her greater as well as in
12201: her less manifestations—in her beautiful order and regularity—guides
12202: her, moreover, to an insight into the wonderful unity of the moving
12203: forces in the operations of nature, far beyond the expectations of a
12204: philosophy building only on experience; and that she thus encourages
12205: philosophy to extend the province of reason beyond all experience, and
12206: at the same time provides it with the most excellent materials for
12207: supporting its investigations, in so far as their nature admits, by
12208: adequate and accordant intuitions.
12209: 
12210: Unfortunately for speculation—but perhaps fortunately for the practical
12211: interests of humanity—reason, in the midst of her highest
12212: anticipations, finds herself hemmed in by a press of opposite and
12213: contradictory conclusions, from which neither her honour nor her safety
12214: will permit her to draw back. Nor can she regard these conflicting
12215: trains of reasoning with indifference as mere passages at arms, still
12216: less can she command peace; for in the subject of the conflict she has
12217: a deep interest. There is no other course left open to her than to
12218: reflect with herself upon the origin of this disunion in reason—whether
12219: it may not arise from a mere misunderstanding. After such an inquiry,
12220: arrogant claims would have to be given up on both sides; but the
12221: sovereignty of reason over understanding and sense would be based upon
12222: a sure foundation.
12223: 
12224: We shall at present defer this radical inquiry and, in the meantime,
12225: consider for a little what side in the controversy we should most
12226: willingly take, if we were obliged to become partisans at all. As, in
12227: this case, we leave out of sight altogether the logical criterion of
12228: truth, and merely consult our own interest in reference to the
12229: question, these considerations, although inadequate to settle the
12230: question of right in either party, will enable us to comprehend how
12231: those who have taken part in the struggle, adopt the one view rather
12232: than the other—no special insight into the subject, however, having
12233: influenced their choice. They will, at the same time, explain to us
12234: many other things by the way—for example, the fiery zeal on the one
12235: side and the cold maintenance of their cause on the other; why the one
12236: party has met with the warmest approbations, and the other has always
12237: been repulsed by irreconcilable prejudices.
12238: 
12239: There is one thing, however, that determines the proper point of view,
12240: from which alone this preliminary inquiry can be instituted and carried
12241: on with the proper completeness—and that is the comparison of the
12242: principles from which both sides, thesis and antithesis, proceed. My
12243: readers would remark in the propositions of the antithesis a complete
12244: uniformity in the mode of thought and a perfect unity of principle. Its
12245: principle was that of pure empiricism, not only in the explication of
12246: the phenomena in the world, but also in the solution of the
12247: transcendental ideas, even of that of the universe itself. The
12248: affirmations of the thesis, on the contrary, were based, in addition to
12249: the empirical mode of explanation employed in the series of phenomena,
12250: on intellectual propositions; and its principles were in so far not
12251: simple. I shall term the thesis, in view of its essential
12252: characteristic, the dogmatism of pure reason.
12253: 
12254: On the side of Dogmatism, or of the thesis, therefore, in the
12255: determination of the cosmological ideas, we find:
12256: 
12257: 1. A practical interest, which must be very dear to every
12258: right-thinking man. That the word has a beginning—that the nature of my
12259: thinking self is simple, and therefore indestructible—that I am a free
12260: agent, and raised above the compulsion of nature and her laws—and,
12261: finally, that the entire order of things, which form the world, is
12262: dependent upon a Supreme Being, from whom the whole receives unity and
12263: connection—these are so many foundation-stones of morality and
12264: religion. The antithesis deprives us of all these supports—or, at
12265: least, seems so to deprive us.
12266: 
12267: 2. A speculative interest of reason manifests itself on this side. For,
12268: if we take the transcendental ideas and employ them in the manner which
12269: the thesis directs, we can exhibit completely à priori the entire chain
12270: of conditions, and understand the derivation of the
12271: conditioned—beginning from the unconditioned. This the antithesis does
12272: not do; and for this reason does not meet with so welcome a reception.
12273: For it can give no answer to our question respecting the conditions of
12274: its synthesis—except such as must be supplemented by another question,
12275: and so on to infinity. According to it, we must rise from a given
12276: beginning to one still higher; every part conducts us to a still
12277: smaller one; every event is preceded by another event which is its
12278: cause; and the conditions of existence rest always upon other and still
12279: higher conditions, and find neither end nor basis in some
12280: self-subsistent thing as the primal being.
12281: 
12282: 3. This side has also the advantage of popularity; and this constitutes
12283: no small part of its claim to favour. The common understanding does not
12284: find the least difficulty in the idea of the unconditioned beginning of
12285: all synthesis—accustomed, as it is, rather to follow our consequences
12286: than to seek for a proper basis for cognition. In the conception of an
12287: absolute first, moreover—the possibility of which it does not inquire
12288: into—it is highly gratified to find a firmly-established point of
12289: departure for its attempts at theory; while in the restless and
12290: continuous ascent from the conditioned to the condition, always with
12291: one foot in the air, it can find no satisfaction.
12292: 
12293: On the side of the antithesis, or Empiricism, in the determination of
12294: the cosmological ideas:
12295: 
12296: 1. We cannot discover any such practical interest arising from pure
12297: principles of reason as morality and religion present. On the contrary,
12298: pure empiricism seems to empty them of all their power and influence.
12299: If there does not exist a Supreme Being distinct from the world—if the
12300: world is without beginning, consequently without a Creator—if our wills
12301: are not free, and the soul is divisible and subject to corruption just
12302: like matter—the ideas and principles of morality lose all validity and
12303: fall with the transcendental ideas which constituted their theoretical
12304: support.
12305: 
12306: 2. But empiricism, in compensation, holds out to reason, in its
12307: speculative interests, certain important advantages, far exceeding any
12308: that the dogmatist can promise us. For, when employed by the
12309: empiricist, understanding is always upon its proper ground of
12310: investigation—the field of possible experience, the laws of which it
12311: can explore, and thus extend its cognition securely and with clear
12312: intelligence without being stopped by limits in any direction. Here can
12313: it and ought it to find and present to intuition its proper object—not
12314: only in itself, but in all its relations; or, if it employ conceptions,
12315: upon this ground it can always present the corresponding images in
12316: clear and unmistakable intuitions. It is quite unnecessary for it to
12317: renounce the guidance of nature, to attach itself to ideas, the objects
12318: of which it cannot know; because, as mere intellectual entities, they
12319: cannot be presented in any intuition. On the contrary, it is not even
12320: permitted to abandon its proper occupation, under the pretence that it
12321: has been brought to a conclusion (for it never can be), and to pass
12322: into the region of idealizing reason and transcendent conceptions,
12323: which it is not required to observe and explore the laws of nature, but
12324: merely to think and to imagine—secure from being contradicted by facts,
12325: because they have not been called as witnesses, but passed by, or
12326: perhaps subordinated to the so-called higher interests and
12327: considerations of pure reason.
12328: 
12329: Hence the empiricist will never allow himself to accept any epoch of
12330: nature for the first—the absolutely primal state; he will not believe
12331: that there can be limits to his outlook into her wide domains, nor pass
12332: from the objects of nature, which he can satisfactorily explain by
12333: means of observation and mathematical thought—which he can determine
12334: synthetically in intuition, to those which neither sense nor
12335: imagination can ever present in concreto; he will not concede the
12336: existence of a faculty in nature, operating independently of the laws
12337: of nature—a concession which would introduce uncertainty into the
12338: procedure of the understanding, which is guided by necessary laws to
12339: the observation of phenomena; nor, finally, will he permit himself to
12340: seek a cause beyond nature, inasmuch as we know nothing but it, and
12341: from it alone receive an objective basis for all our conceptions and
12342: instruction in the unvarying laws of things.
12343: 
12344: In truth, if the empirical philosopher had no other purpose in the
12345: establishment of his antithesis than to check the presumption of a
12346: reason which mistakes its true destination, which boasts of its insight
12347: and its knowledge, just where all insight and knowledge cease to exist,
12348: and regards that which is valid only in relation to a practical
12349: interest, as an advancement of the speculative interests of the mind
12350: (in order, when it is convenient for itself, to break the thread of our
12351: physical investigations, and, under pretence of extending our
12352: cognition, connect them with transcendental ideas, by means of which we
12353: really know only that we know nothing)—if, I say, the empiricist rested
12354: satisfied with this benefit, the principle advanced by him would be a
12355: maxim recommending moderation in the pretensions of reason and modesty
12356: in its affirmations, and at the same time would direct us to the right
12357: mode of extending the province of the understanding, by the help of the
12358: only true teacher, experience. In obedience to this advice,
12359: intellectual hypotheses and faith would not be called in aid of our
12360: practical interests; nor should we introduce them under the pompous
12361: titles of science and insight. For speculative cognition cannot find an
12362: objective basis any other where than in experience; and, when we
12363: overstep its limits our synthesis, which requires ever new cognitions
12364: independent of experience, has no substratum of intuition upon which to
12365: build.
12366: 
12367: But if—as often happens—empiricism, in relation to ideas, becomes
12368: itself dogmatic and boldly denies that which is above the sphere of its
12369: phenomenal cognition, it falls itself into the error of intemperance—an
12370: error which is here all the more reprehensible, as thereby the
12371: practical interest of reason receives an irreparable injury.
12372: 
12373: And this constitutes the opposition between Epicureanism[57] and
12374: Platonism.
12375: 
12376:  [57] It is, however, still a matter of doubt whether Epicurus ever
12377:  propounded these principles as directions for the objective employment
12378:  of the understanding. If, indeed, they were nothing more than maxims
12379:  for the speculative exercise of reason, he gives evidence therein a
12380:  more genuine philosophic spirit than any of the philosophers of
12381:  antiquity. That, in the explanation of phenomena, we must proceed as
12382:  if the field of inquiry had neither limits in space nor commencement
12383:  in time; that we must be satisfied with the teaching of experience in
12384:  reference to the material of which the world is posed; that we must
12385:  not look for any other mode of the origination of events than that
12386:  which is determined by the unalterable laws of nature; and finally,
12387:  that we not employ the hypothesis of a cause distinct from the world
12388:  to account for a phenomenon or for the world itself—are principles for
12389:  the extension of speculative philosophy, and the discovery of the true
12390:  sources of the principles of morals, which, however little conformed
12391:  to in the present day, are undoubtedly correct. At the same time, any
12392:  one desirous of ignoring, in mere speculation, these dogmatical
12393:  propositions, need not for that reason be accused of denying them.
12394: 
12395: 
12396: Both Epicurus and Plato assert more in their systems than they know.
12397: The former encourages and advances science—although to the prejudice of
12398: the practical; the latter presents us with excellent principles for the
12399: investigation of the practical, but, in relation to everything
12400: regarding which we can attain to speculative cognition, permits reason
12401: to append idealistic explanations of natural phenomena, to the great
12402: injury of physical investigation.
12403: 
12404: 3. In regard to the third motive for the preliminary choice of a party
12405: in this war of assertions, it seems very extraordinary that empiricism
12406: should be utterly unpopular. We should be inclined to believe that the
12407: common understanding would receive it with pleasure—promising as it
12408: does to satisfy it without passing the bounds of experience and its
12409: connected order; while transcendental dogmatism obliges it to rise to
12410: conceptions which far surpass the intelligence and ability of the most
12411: practised thinkers. But in this, in truth, is to be found its real
12412: motive. For the common understanding thus finds itself in a situation
12413: where not even the most learned can have the advantage of it. If it
12414: understands little or nothing about these transcendental conceptions,
12415: no one can boast of understanding any more; and although it may not
12416: express itself in so scholastically correct a manner as others, it can
12417: busy itself with reasoning and arguments without end, wandering among
12418: mere ideas, about which one can always be very eloquent, because we
12419: know nothing about them; while, in the observation and investigation of
12420: nature, it would be forced to remain dumb and to confess its utter
12421: ignorance. Thus indolence and vanity form of themselves strong
12422: recommendations of these principles. Besides, although it is a hard
12423: thing for a philosopher to assume a principle, of which he can give to
12424: himself no reasonable account, and still more to employ conceptions,
12425: the objective reality of which cannot be established, nothing is more
12426: usual with the common understanding. It wants something which will
12427: allow it to go to work with confidence. The difficulty of even
12428: comprehending a supposition does not disquiet it, because—not knowing
12429: what comprehending means—it never even thinks of the supposition it may
12430: be adopting as a principle; and regards as known that with which it has
12431: become familiar from constant use. And, at last, all speculative
12432: interests disappear before the practical interests which it holds dear;
12433: and it fancies that it understands and knows what its necessities and
12434: hopes incite it to assume or to believe. Thus the empiricism of
12435: transcendentally idealizing reason is robbed of all popularity; and,
12436: however prejudicial it may be to the highest practical principles,
12437: there is no fear that it will ever pass the limits of the schools, or
12438: acquire any favour or influence in society or with the multitude.
12439: 
12440: Human reason is by nature architectonic. That is to say, it regards all
12441: cognitions as parts of a possible system, and hence accepts only such
12442: principles as at least do not incapacitate a cognition to which we may
12443: have attained from being placed along with others in a general system.
12444: But the propositions of the antithesis are of a character which renders
12445: the completion of an edifice of cognitions impossible. According to
12446: these, beyond one state or epoch of the world there is always to be
12447: found one more ancient; in every part always other parts themselves
12448: divisible; preceding every event another, the origin of which must
12449: itself be sought still higher; and everything in existence is
12450: conditioned, and still not dependent on an unconditioned and primal
12451: existence. As, therefore, the antithesis will not concede the existence
12452: of a first beginning which might be available as a foundation, a
12453: complete edifice of cognition, in the presence of such hypothesis, is
12454: utterly impossible. Thus the architectonic interest of reason, which
12455: requires a unity—not empirical, but à priori and rational—forms a
12456: natural recommendation for the assertions of the thesis in our
12457: antinomy.
12458: 
12459: But if any one could free himself entirely from all considerations of
12460: interest, and weigh without partiality the assertions of reason,
12461: attending only to their content, irrespective of the consequences which
12462: follow from them; such a person, on the supposition that he knew no
12463: other way out of the confusion than to settle the truth of one or other
12464: of the conflicting doctrines, would live in a state of continual
12465: hesitation. Today, he would feel convinced that the human will is free;
12466: to-morrow, considering the indissoluble chain of nature, he would look
12467: on freedom as a mere illusion and declare nature to be all-in-all. But,
12468: if he were called to action, the play of the merely speculative reason
12469: would disappear like the shapes of a dream, and practical interest
12470: would dictate his choice of principles. But, as it well befits a
12471: reflective and inquiring being to devote certain periods of time to the
12472: examination of its own reason—to divest itself of all partiality, and
12473: frankly to communicate its observations for the judgement and opinion
12474: of others; so no one can be blamed for, much less prevented from,
12475: placing both parties on their trial, with permission to end themselves,
12476: free from intimidation, before intimidation, before a sworn jury of
12477: equal condition with themselves—the condition of weak and fallible men.
12478: 
12479: Section IV. Of the necessity imposed upon Pure Reason of presenting a
12480: Solution of its Transcendental Problems
12481: 
12482: To avow an ability to solve all problems and to answer all questions
12483: would be a profession certain to convict any philosopher of extravagant
12484: boasting and self-conceit, and at once to destroy the confidence that
12485: might otherwise have been reposed in him. There are, however, sciences
12486: so constituted that every question arising within their sphere must
12487: necessarily be capable of receiving an answer from the knowledge
12488: already possessed, for the answer must be received from the same
12489: sources whence the question arose. In such sciences it is not allowable
12490: to excuse ourselves on the plea of necessary and unavoidable ignorance;
12491: a solution is absolutely requisite. The rule of right and wrong must
12492: help us to the knowledge of what is right or wrong in all possible
12493: cases; otherwise, the idea of obligation or duty would be utterly null,
12494: for we cannot have any obligation to that which we cannot know. On the
12495: other hand, in our investigations of the phenomena of nature, much must
12496: remain uncertain, and many questions continue insoluble; because what
12497: we know of nature is far from being sufficient to explain all the
12498: phenomena that are presented to our observation. Now the question is:
12499: Whether there is in transcendental philosophy any question, relating to
12500: an object presented to pure reason, which is unanswerable by this
12501: reason; and whether we must regard the subject of the question as quite
12502: uncertain, so far as our knowledge extends, and must give it a place
12503: among those subjects, of which we have just so much conception as is
12504: sufficient to enable us to raise a question—faculty or materials
12505: failing us, however, when we attempt an answer.
12506: 
12507: Now I maintain that, among all speculative cognition, the peculiarity
12508: of transcendental philosophy is that there is no question, relating to
12509: an object presented to pure reason, which is insoluble by this reason;
12510: and that the profession of unavoidable ignorance—the problem being
12511: alleged to be beyond the reach of our faculties—cannot free us from the
12512: obligation to present a complete and satisfactory answer. For the very
12513: conception which enables us to raise the question must give us the
12514: power of answering it; inasmuch as the object, as in the case of right
12515: and wrong, is not to be discovered out of the conception.
12516: 
12517: But, in transcendental philosophy, it is only the cosmological
12518: questions to which we can demand a satisfactory answer in relation to
12519: the constitution of their object; and the philosopher is not permitted
12520: to avail himself of the pretext of necessary ignorance and impenetrable
12521: obscurity. These questions relate solely to the cosmological ideas. For
12522: the object must be given in experience, and the question relates to the
12523: adequateness of the object to an idea. If the object is transcendental
12524: and therefore itself unknown; if the question, for example, is whether
12525: the object—the something, the phenomenon of which (internal—in
12526: ourselves) is thought—that is to say, the soul, is in itself a simple
12527: being; or whether there is a cause of all things, which is absolutely
12528: necessary—in such cases we are seeking for our idea an object, of which
12529: we may confess that it is unknown to us, though we must not on that
12530: account assert that it is impossible.[58] The cosmological ideas alone
12531: posses the peculiarity that we can presuppose the object of them and
12532: the empirical synthesis requisite for the conception of that object to
12533: be given; and the question, which arises from these ideas, relates
12534: merely to the progress of this synthesis, in so far as it must contain
12535: absolute totality—which, however, is not empirical, as it cannot be
12536: given in any experience. Now, as the question here is solely in regard
12537: to a thing as the object of a possible experience and not as a thing in
12538: itself, the answer to the transcendental cosmological question need not
12539: be sought out of the idea, for the question does not regard an object
12540: in itself. The question in relation to a possible experience is not,
12541: “What can be given in an experience in concreto” but “what is contained
12542: in the idea, to which the empirical synthesis must approximate.” The
12543: question must therefore be capable of solution from the idea alone. For
12544: the idea is a creation of reason itself, which therefore cannot
12545: disclaim the obligation to answer or refer us to the unknown object.
12546: 
12547:  [58] The question, “What is the constitution of a transcendental
12548:  object?” is unanswerable—we are unable to say what it is; but we can
12549:  perceive that the question itself is nothing; because it does not
12550:  relate to any object that can be presented to us. For this reason, we
12551:  must consider all the questions raised in transcendental psychology as
12552:  answerable and as really answered; for they relate to the
12553:  transcendental subject of all internal phenomena, which is not itself
12554:  phenomenon and consequently not given as an object, in which,
12555:  moreover, none of the categories—and it is to them that the question
12556:  is properly directed—find any conditions of its application. Here,
12557:  therefore, is a case where no answer is the only proper answer. For a
12558:  question regarding the constitution of a something which cannot be
12559:  cogitated by any determined predicate, being completely beyond the
12560:  sphere of objects and experience, is perfectly null and void.
12561: 
12562: 
12563: It is not so extraordinary, as it at first sight appears, that a
12564: science should demand and expect satisfactory answers to all the
12565: questions that may arise within its own sphere (questiones domesticae),
12566: although, up to a certain time, these answers may not have been
12567: discovered. There are, in addition to transcendental philosophy, only
12568: two pure sciences of reason; the one with a speculative, the other with
12569: a practical content—pure mathematics and pure ethics. Has any one ever
12570: heard it alleged that, from our complete and necessary ignorance of the
12571: conditions, it is uncertain what exact relation the diameter of a
12572: circle bears to the circle in rational or irrational numbers? By the
12573: former the sum cannot be given exactly, by the latter only
12574: approximately; and therefore we decide that the impossibility of a
12575: solution of the question is evident. Lambert presented us with a
12576: demonstration of this. In the general principles of morals there can be
12577: nothing uncertain, for the propositions are either utterly without
12578: meaning, or must originate solely in our rational conceptions. On the
12579: other hand, there must be in physical science an infinite number of
12580: conjectures, which can never become certainties; because the phenomena
12581: of nature are not given as objects dependent on our conceptions. The
12582: key to the solution of such questions cannot, therefore, be found in
12583: our conceptions, or in pure thought, but must lie without us and for
12584: that reason is in many cases not to be discovered; and consequently a
12585: satisfactory explanation cannot be expected. The questions of
12586: transcendental analytic, which relate to the deduction of our pure
12587: cognition, are not to be regarded as of the same kind as those
12588: mentioned above; for we are not at present treating of the certainty of
12589: judgements in relation to the origin of our conceptions, but only of
12590: that certainty in relation to objects.
12591: 
12592: We cannot, therefore, escape the responsibility of at least a critical
12593: solution of the questions of reason, by complaints of the limited
12594: nature of our faculties, and the seemingly humble confession that it is
12595: beyond the power of our reason to decide, whether the world has existed
12596: from all eternity or had a beginning—whether it is infinitely extended,
12597: or enclosed within certain limits—whether anything in the world is
12598: simple, or whether everything must be capable of infinite
12599: divisibility—whether freedom can originate phenomena, or whether
12600: everything is absolutely dependent on the laws and order of nature—and,
12601: finally, whether there exists a being that is completely unconditioned
12602: and necessary, or whether the existence of everything is conditioned
12603: and consequently dependent on something external to itself, and
12604: therefore in its own nature contingent. For all these questions relate
12605: to an object, which can be given nowhere else than in thought. This
12606: object is the absolutely unconditioned totality of the synthesis of
12607: phenomena. If the conceptions in our minds do not assist us to some
12608: certain result in regard to these problems, we must not defend
12609: ourselves on the plea that the object itself remains hidden from and
12610: unknown to us. For no such thing or object can be given—it is not to be
12611: found out of the idea in our minds. We must seek the cause of our
12612: failure in our idea itself, which is an insoluble problem and in regard
12613: to which we obstinately assume that there exists a real object
12614: corresponding and adequate to it. A clear explanation of the dialectic
12615: which lies in our conception, will very soon enable us to come to a
12616: satisfactory decision in regard to such a question.
12617: 
12618: The pretext that we are unable to arrive at certainty in regard to
12619: these problems may be met with this question, which requires at least a
12620: plain answer: “From what source do the ideas originate, the solution of
12621: which involves you in such difficulties? Are you seeking for an
12622: explanation of certain phenomena; and do you expect these ideas to give
12623: you the principles or the rules of this explanation?” Let it be
12624: granted, that all nature was laid open before you; that nothing was hid
12625: from your senses and your consciousness. Still, you could not cognize
12626: in concreto the object of your ideas in any experience. For what is
12627: demanded is not only this full and complete intuition, but also a
12628: complete synthesis and the consciousness of its absolute totality; and
12629: this is not possible by means of any empirical cognition. It follows
12630: that your question—your idea—is by no means necessary for the
12631: explanation of any phenomenon; and the idea cannot have been in any
12632: sense given by the object itself. For such an object can never be
12633: presented to us, because it cannot be given by any possible experience.
12634: Whatever perceptions you may attain to, you are still surrounded by
12635: conditions—in space, or in time—and you cannot discover anything
12636: unconditioned; nor can you decide whether this unconditioned is to be
12637: placed in an absolute beginning of the synthesis, or in an absolute
12638: totality of the series without beginning. A whole, in the empirical
12639: signification of the term, is always merely comparative. The absolute
12640: whole of quantity (the universe), of division, of derivation, of the
12641: condition of existence, with the question—whether it is to be produced
12642: by finite or infinite synthesis, no possible experience can instruct us
12643: concerning. You will not, for example, be able to explain the phenomena
12644: of a body in the least degree better, whether you believe it to consist
12645: of simple, or of composite parts; for a simple phenomenon—and just as
12646: little an infinite series of composition—can never be presented to your
12647: perception. Phenomena require and admit of explanation, only in so far
12648: as the conditions of that explanation are given in perception; but the
12649: sum total of that which is given in phenomena, considered as an
12650: absolute whole, is itself a perception—and we cannot therefore seek for
12651: explanations of this whole beyond itself, in other perceptions. The
12652: explanation of this whole is the proper object of the transcendental
12653: problems of pure reason.
12654: 
12655: Although, therefore, the solution of these problems is unattainable
12656: through experience, we must not permit ourselves to say that it is
12657: uncertain how the object of our inquiries is constituted. For the
12658: object is in our own mind and cannot be discovered in experience; and
12659: we have only to take care that our thoughts are consistent with each
12660: other, and to avoid falling into the amphiboly of regarding our idea as
12661: a representation of an object empirically given, and therefore to be
12662: cognized according to the laws of experience. A dogmatical solution is
12663: therefore not only unsatisfactory but impossible. The critical
12664: solution, which may be a perfectly certain one, does not consider the
12665: question objectively, but proceeds by inquiring into the basis of the
12666: cognition upon which the question rests.
12667: 
12668: Section V. Sceptical Exposition of the Cosmological Problems presented
12669: in the four Transcendental Ideas
12670: 
12671: We should be quite willing to desist from the demand of a dogmatical
12672: answer to our questions, if we understood beforehand that, be the
12673: answer what it may, it would only serve to increase our ignorance, to
12674: throw us from one incomprehensibility into another, from one obscurity
12675: into another still greater, and perhaps lead us into irreconcilable
12676: contradictions. If a dogmatical affirmative or negative answer is
12677: demanded, is it at all prudent to set aside the probable grounds of a
12678: solution which lie before us and to take into consideration what
12679: advantage we shall gain, if the answer is to favour the one side or the
12680: other? If it happens that in both cases the answer is mere nonsense, we
12681: have in this an irresistible summons to institute a critical
12682: investigation of the question, for the purpose of discovering whether
12683: it is based on a groundless presupposition and relates to an idea, the
12684: falsity of which would be more easily exposed in its application and
12685: consequences than in the mere representation of its content. This is
12686: the great utility of the sceptical mode of treating the questions
12687: addressed by pure reason to itself. By this method we easily rid
12688: ourselves of the confusions of dogmatism, and establish in its place a
12689: temperate criticism, which, as a genuine cathartic, will successfully
12690: remove the presumptuous notions of philosophy and their consequence—the
12691: vain pretension to universal science.
12692: 
12693: If, then, I could understand the nature of a cosmological idea and
12694: perceive, before I entered on the discussion of the subject at all,
12695: that, whatever side of the question regarding the unconditioned of the
12696: regressive synthesis of phenomena it favoured—it must either be too
12697: great or too small for every conception of the understanding—I would be
12698: able to comprehend how the idea, which relates to an object of
12699: experience—an experience which must be adequate to and in accordance
12700: with a possible conception of the understanding—must be completely void
12701: and without significance, inasmuch as its object is inadequate,
12702: consider it as we may. And this is actually the case with all
12703: cosmological conceptions, which, for the reason above mentioned,
12704: involve reason, so long as it remains attached to them, in an
12705: unavoidable antinomy. For suppose:
12706: 
12707: First, that the world has no beginning—in this case it is too large for
12708: our conception; for this conception, which consists in a successive
12709: regress, cannot overtake the whole eternity that has elapsed. Grant
12710: that it has a beginning, it is then too small for the conception of the
12711: understanding. For, as a beginning presupposes a time preceding, it
12712: cannot be unconditioned; and the law of the empirical employment of the
12713: understanding imposes the necessity of looking for a higher condition
12714: of time; and the world is, therefore, evidently too small for this law.
12715: 
12716: The same is the case with the double answer to the question regarding
12717: the extent, in space, of the world. For, if it is infinite and
12718: unlimited, it must be too large for every possible empirical
12719: conception. If it is finite and limited, we have a right to ask: “What
12720: determines these limits?” Void space is not a self-subsistent correlate
12721: of things, and cannot be a final condition—and still less an empirical
12722: condition, forming a part of a possible experience. For how can we have
12723: any experience or perception of an absolute void? But the absolute
12724: totality of the empirical synthesis requires that the unconditioned be
12725: an empirical conception. Consequently, a finite world is too small for
12726: our conception.
12727: 
12728: Secondly, if every phenomenon (matter) in space consists of an infinite
12729: number of parts, the regress of the division is always too great for
12730: our conception; and if the division of space must cease with some
12731: member of the division (the simple), it is too small for the idea of
12732: the unconditioned. For the member at which we have discontinued our
12733: division still admits a regress to many more parts contained in the
12734: object.
12735: 
12736: Thirdly, suppose that every event in the world happens in accordance
12737: with the laws of nature; the causality of a cause must itself be an
12738: event and necessitates a regress to a still higher cause, and
12739: consequently the unceasing prolongation of the series of conditions a
12740: parte priori. Operative nature is therefore too large for every
12741: conception we can form in the synthesis of cosmical events.
12742: 
12743: If we admit the existence of spontaneously produced events, that is, of
12744: free agency, we are driven, in our search for sufficient reasons, on an
12745: unavoidable law of nature and are compelled to appeal to the empirical
12746: law of causality, and we find that any such totality of connection in
12747: our synthesis is too small for our necessary empirical conception.
12748: 
12749: Fourthly, if we assume the existence of an absolutely necessary
12750: being—whether it be the world or something in the world, or the cause
12751: of the world—we must place it in a time at an infinite distance from
12752: any given moment; for, otherwise, it must be dependent on some other
12753: and higher existence. Such an existence is, in this case, too large for
12754: our empirical conception, and unattainable by the continued regress of
12755: any synthesis.
12756: 
12757: But if we believe that everything in the world—be it condition or
12758: conditioned—is contingent; every given existence is too small for our
12759: conception. For in this case we are compelled to seek for some other
12760: existence upon which the former depends.
12761: 
12762: We have said that in all these cases the cosmological idea is either
12763: too great or too small for the empirical regress in a synthesis, and
12764: consequently for every possible conception of the understanding. Why
12765: did we not express ourselves in a manner exactly the reverse of this
12766: and, instead of accusing the cosmological idea of over stepping or of
12767: falling short of its true aim, possible experience, say that, in the
12768: first case, the empirical conception is always too small for the idea,
12769: and in the second too great, and thus attach the blame of these
12770: contradictions to the empirical regress? The reason is this. Possible
12771: experience can alone give reality to our conceptions; without it a
12772: conception is merely an idea, without truth or relation to an object.
12773: Hence a possible empirical conception must be the standard by which we
12774: are to judge whether an idea is anything more than an idea and fiction
12775: of thought, or whether it relates to an object in the world. If we say
12776: of a thing that in relation to some other thing it is too large or too
12777: small, the former is considered as existing for the sake of the latter,
12778: and requiring to be adapted to it. Among the trivial subjects of
12779: discussion in the old schools of dialectics was this question: “If a
12780: ball cannot pass through a hole, shall we say that the ball is too
12781: large or the hole too small?” In this case it is indifferent what
12782: expression we employ; for we do not know which exists for the sake of
12783: the other. On the other hand, we cannot say: “The man is too long for
12784: his coat”; but: “The coat is too short for the man.”
12785: 
12786: We are thus led to the well-founded suspicion that the cosmological
12787: ideas, and all the conflicting sophistical assertions connected with
12788: them, are based upon a false and fictitious conception of the mode in
12789: which the object of these ideas is presented to us; and this suspicion
12790: will probably direct us how to expose the illusion that has so long led
12791: us astray from the truth.
12792: 
12793: Section VI. Transcendental Idealism as the Key to the Solution of Pure
12794: Cosmological Dialectic
12795: 
12796: In the transcendental æsthetic we proved that everything intuited in
12797: space and time, all objects of a possible experience, are nothing but
12798: phenomena, that is, mere representations; and that these, as presented
12799: to us—as extended bodies, or as series of changes—have no
12800: self-subsistent existence apart from human thought. This doctrine I
12801: call Transcendental Idealism.[59] The realist in the transcendental
12802: sense regards these modifications of our sensibility, these mere
12803: representations, as things subsisting in themselves.
12804: 
12805:  [59] I have elsewhere termed this theory formal idealism, to
12806:  distinguish it from material idealism, which doubts or denies the
12807:  existence of external things. To avoid ambiguity, it seems advisable
12808:  in many cases to employ this term instead of that mentioned in the
12809:  text.
12810: 
12811: 
12812: It would be unjust to accuse us of holding the long-decried theory of
12813: empirical idealism, which, while admitting the reality of space,
12814: denies, or at least doubts, the existence of bodies extended in it, and
12815: thus leaves us without a sufficient criterion of reality and illusion.
12816: The supporters of this theory find no difficulty in admitting the
12817: reality of the phenomena of the internal sense in time; nay, they go
12818: the length of maintaining that this internal experience is of itself a
12819: sufficient proof of the real existence of its object as a thing in
12820: itself.
12821: 
12822: Transcendental idealism allows that the objects of external
12823: intuition—as intuited in space, and all changes in time—as represented
12824: by the internal sense, are real. For, as space is the form of that
12825: intuition which we call external, and, without objects in space, no
12826: empirical representation could be given us, we can and ought to regard
12827: extended bodies in it as real. The case is the same with
12828: representations in time. But time and space, with all phenomena
12829: therein, are not in themselves things. They are nothing but
12830: representations and cannot exist out of and apart from the mind. Nay,
12831: the sensuous internal intuition of the mind (as the object of
12832: consciousness), the determination of which is represented by the
12833: succession of different states in time, is not the real, proper self,
12834: as it exists in itself—not the transcendental subject—but only a
12835: phenomenon, which is presented to the sensibility of this, to us,
12836: unknown being. This internal phenomenon cannot be admitted to be a
12837: self-subsisting thing; for its condition is time, and time cannot be
12838: the condition of a thing in itself. But the empirical truth of
12839: phenomena in space and time is guaranteed beyond the possibility of
12840: doubt, and sufficiently distinguished from the illusion of dreams or
12841: fancy—although both have a proper and thorough connection in an
12842: experience according to empirical laws. The objects of experience then
12843: are not things in themselves, but are given only in experience, and
12844: have no existence apart from and independently of experience. That
12845: there may be inhabitants in the moon, although no one has ever observed
12846: them, must certainly be admitted; but this assertion means only, that
12847: we may in the possible progress of experience discover them at some
12848: future time. For that which stands in connection with a perception
12849: according to the laws of the progress of experience is real. They are
12850: therefore really existent, if they stand in empirical connection with
12851: my actual or real consciousness, although they are not in themselves
12852: real, that is, apart from the progress of experience.
12853: 
12854: There is nothing actually given—we can be conscious of nothing as real,
12855: except a perception and the empirical progression from it to other
12856: possible perceptions. For phenomena, as mere representations, are real
12857: only in perception; and perception is, in fact, nothing but the reality
12858: of an empirical representation, that is, a phenomenon. To call a
12859: phenomenon a real thing prior to perception means either that we must
12860: meet with this phenomenon in the progress of experience, or it means
12861: nothing at all. For I can say only of a thing in itself that it exists
12862: without relation to the senses and experience. But we are speaking here
12863: merely of phenomena in space and time, both of which are determinations
12864: of sensibility, and not of things in themselves. It follows that
12865: phenomena are not things in themselves, but are mere representations,
12866: which if not given in us—in perception—are non-existent.
12867: 
12868: The faculty of sensuous intuition is properly a receptivity—a capacity
12869: of being affected in a certain manner by representations, the relation
12870: of which to each other is a pure intuition of space and time—the pure
12871: forms of sensibility. These representations, in so far as they are
12872: connected and determinable in this relation (in space and time)
12873: according to laws of the unity of experience, are called objects. The
12874: non-sensuous cause of these representations is completely unknown to us
12875: and hence cannot be intuited as an object. For such an object could not
12876: be represented either in space or in time; and without these conditions
12877: intuition or representation is impossible. We may, at the same time,
12878: term the non-sensuous cause of phenomena the transcendental object—but
12879: merely as a mental correlate to sensibility, considered as a
12880: receptivity. To this transcendental object we may attribute the whole
12881: connection and extent of our possible perceptions, and say that it is
12882: given and exists in itself prior to all experience. But the phenomena,
12883: corresponding to it, are not given as things in themselves, but in
12884: experience alone. For they are mere representations, receiving from
12885: perceptions alone significance and relation to a real object, under the
12886: condition that this or that perception—indicating an object—is in
12887: complete connection with all others in accordance with the rules of the
12888: unity of experience. Thus we can say: “The things that really existed
12889: in past time are given in the transcendental object of experience.” But
12890: these are to me real objects, only in so far as I can represent to my
12891: own mind, that a regressive series of possible perceptions—following
12892: the indications of history, or the footsteps of cause and effect—in
12893: accordance with empirical laws—that, in one word, the course of the
12894: world conducts us to an elapsed series of time as the condition of the
12895: present time. This series in past time is represented as real, not in
12896: itself, but only in connection with a possible experience. Thus, when I
12897: say that certain events occurred in past time, I merely assert the
12898: possibility of prolonging the chain of experience, from the present
12899: perception, upwards to the conditions that determine it according to
12900: time.
12901: 
12902: If I represent to myself all objects existing in all space and time, I
12903: do not thereby place these in space and time prior to all experience;
12904: on the contrary, such a representation is nothing more than the notion
12905: of a possible experience, in its absolute completeness. In experience
12906: alone are those objects, which are nothing but representations, given.
12907: But, when I say they existed prior to my experience, this means only
12908: that I must begin with the perception present to me and follow the
12909: track indicated until I discover them in some part or region of
12910: experience. The cause of the empirical condition of this
12911: progression—and consequently at what member therein I must stop, and at
12912: what point in the regress I am to find this member—is transcendental,
12913: and hence necessarily incognizable. But with this we have not to do;
12914: our concern is only with the law of progression in experience, in which
12915: objects, that is, phenomena, are given. It is a matter of indifference,
12916: whether I say, “I may in the progress of experience discover stars, at
12917: a hundred times greater distance than the most distant of those now
12918: visible,” or, “Stars at this distance may be met in space, although no
12919: one has, or ever will discover them.” For, if they are given as things
12920: in themselves, without any relation to possible experience, they are
12921: for me non-existent, consequently, are not objects, for they are not
12922: contained in the regressive series of experience. But, if these
12923: phenomena must be employed in the construction or support of the
12924: cosmological idea of an absolute whole, and when we are discussing a
12925: question that oversteps the limits of possible experience, the proper
12926: distinction of the different theories of the reality of sensuous
12927: objects is of great importance, in order to avoid the illusion which
12928: must necessarily arise from the misinterpretation of our empirical
12929: conceptions.
12930: 
12931: Section VII. Critical Solution of the Cosmological Problem
12932: 
12933: The antinomy of pure reason is based upon the following dialectical
12934: argument: “If that which is conditioned is given, the whole series of
12935: its conditions is also given; but sensuous objects are given as
12936: conditioned; consequently...” This syllogism, the major of which seems
12937: so natural and evident, introduces as many cosmological ideas as there
12938: are different kinds of conditions in the synthesis of phenomena, in so
12939: far as these conditions constitute a series. These ideas require
12940: absolute totality in the series, and thus place reason in inextricable
12941: embarrassment. Before proceeding to expose the fallacy in this
12942: dialectical argument, it will be necessary to have a correct
12943: understanding of certain conceptions that appear in it.
12944: 
12945: In the first place, the following proposition is evident, and
12946: indubitably certain: “If the conditioned is given, a regress in the
12947: series of all its conditions is thereby imperatively required.” For the
12948: very conception of a conditioned is a conception of something related
12949: to a condition, and, if this condition is itself conditioned, to
12950: another condition—and so on through all the members of the series. This
12951: proposition is, therefore, analytical and has nothing to fear from
12952: transcendental criticism. It is a logical postulate of reason: to
12953: pursue, as far as possible, the connection of a conception with its
12954: conditions.
12955: 
12956: If, in the second place, both the conditioned and the condition are
12957: things in themselves, and if the former is given, not only is the
12958: regress to the latter requisite, but the latter is really given with
12959: the former. Now, as this is true of all the members of the series, the
12960: entire series of conditions, and with them the unconditioned, is at the
12961: same time given in the very fact of the conditioned, the existence of
12962: which is possible only in and through that series, being given. In this
12963: case, the synthesis of the conditioned with its condition, is a
12964: synthesis of the understanding merely, which represents things as they
12965: are, without regarding whether and how we can cognize them. But if I
12966: have to do with phenomena, which, in their character of mere
12967: representations, are not given, if I do not attain to a cognition of
12968: them (in other words, to themselves, for they are nothing more than
12969: empirical cognitions), I am not entitled to say: “If the conditioned is
12970: given, all its conditions (as phenomena) are also given.” I cannot,
12971: therefore, from the fact of a conditioned being given, infer the
12972: absolute totality of the series of its conditions. For phenomena are
12973: nothing but an empirical synthesis in apprehension or perception, and
12974: are therefore given only in it. Now, in speaking of phenomena it does
12975: not follow that, if the conditioned is given, the synthesis which
12976: constitutes its empirical condition is also thereby given and
12977: presupposed; such a synthesis can be established only by an actual
12978: regress in the series of conditions. But we are entitled to say in this
12979: case that a regress to the conditions of a conditioned, in other words,
12980: that a continuous empirical synthesis is enjoined; that, if the
12981: conditions are not given, they are at least required; and that we are
12982: certain to discover the conditions in this regress.
12983: 
12984: We can now see that the major, in the above cosmological syllogism,
12985: takes the conditioned in the transcendental signification which it has
12986: in the pure category, while the minor speaks of it in the empirical
12987: signification which it has in the category as applied to phenomena.
12988: There is, therefore, a dialectical fallacy in the syllogism—a sophisma
12989: figurae dictionis. But this fallacy is not a consciously devised one,
12990: but a perfectly natural illusion of the common reason of man. For, when
12991: a thing is given as conditioned, we presuppose in the major its
12992: conditions and their series, unperceived, as it were, and unseen;
12993: because this is nothing more than the logical requirement of complete
12994: and satisfactory premisses for a given conclusion. In this case, time
12995: is altogether left out in the connection of the conditioned with the
12996: condition; they are supposed to be given in themselves, and
12997: contemporaneously. It is, moreover, just as natural to regard phenomena
12998: (in the minor) as things in themselves and as objects presented to the
12999: pure understanding, as in the major, in which complete abstraction was
13000: made of all conditions of intuition. But it is under these conditions
13001: alone that objects are given. Now we overlooked a remarkable
13002: distinction between the conceptions. The synthesis of the conditioned
13003: with its condition, and the complete series of the latter (in the
13004: major) are not limited by time, and do not contain the conception of
13005: succession. On the contrary, the empirical synthesis and the series of
13006: conditions in the phenomenal world—subsumed in the minor—are
13007: necessarily successive and given in time alone. It follows that I
13008: cannot presuppose in the minor, as I did in the major, the absolute
13009: totality of the synthesis and of the series therein represented; for in
13010: the major all the members of the series are given as things in
13011: themselves—without any limitations or conditions of time, while in the
13012: minor they are possible only in and through a successive regress, which
13013: cannot exist, except it be actually carried into execution in the world
13014: of phenomena.
13015: 
13016: After this proof of the viciousness of the argument commonly employed
13017: in maintaining cosmological assertions, both parties may now be justly
13018: dismissed, as advancing claims without grounds or title. But the
13019: process has not been ended by convincing them that one or both were in
13020: the wrong and had maintained an assertion which was without valid
13021: grounds of proof. Nothing seems to be clearer than that, if one
13022: maintains: “The world has a beginning,” and another: “The world has no
13023: beginning,” one of the two must be right. But it is likewise clear
13024: that, if the evidence on both sides is equal, it is impossible to
13025: discover on what side the truth lies; and the controversy continues,
13026: although the parties have been recommended to peace before the tribunal
13027: of reason. There remains, then, no other means of settling the question
13028: than to convince the parties, who refute each other with such
13029: conclusiveness and ability, that they are disputing about nothing, and
13030: that a transcendental illusion has been mocking them with visions of
13031: reality where there is none. The mode of adjusting a dispute which
13032: cannot be decided upon its own merits, we shall now proceed to lay
13033: before our readers.
13034: 
13035: 
13036: Zeno of Elea, a subtle dialectician, was severely reprimanded by Plato
13037: as a sophist, who, merely from the base motive of exhibiting his skill
13038: in discussion, maintained and subverted the same proposition by
13039: arguments as powerful and convincing on the one side as on the other.
13040: He maintained, for example, that God (who was probably nothing more, in
13041: his view, than the world) is neither finite nor infinite, neither in
13042: motion nor in rest, neither similar nor dissimilar to any other thing.
13043: It seemed to those philosophers who criticized his mode of discussion
13044: that his purpose was to deny completely both of two self-contradictory
13045: propositions—which is absurd. But I cannot believe that there is any
13046: justice in this accusation. The first of these propositions I shall
13047: presently consider in a more detailed manner. With regard to the
13048: others, if by the word of God he understood merely the Universe, his
13049: meaning must have been—that it cannot be permanently present in one
13050: place—that is, at rest—nor be capable of changing its place—that is, of
13051: moving—because all places are in the universe, and the universe itself
13052: is, therefore, in no place. Again, if the universe contains in itself
13053: everything that exists, it cannot be similar or dissimilar to any other
13054: thing, because there is, in fact, no other thing with which it can be
13055: compared. If two opposite judgements presuppose a contingent
13056: impossible, or arbitrary condition, both—in spite of their opposition
13057: (which is, however, not properly or really a contradiction)—fall away;
13058: because the condition, which ensured the validity of both, has itself
13059: disappeared.
13060: 
13061: If we say: “Everybody has either a good or a bad smell,” we have
13062: omitted a third possible judgement—it has no smell at all; and thus
13063: both conflicting statements may be false. If we say: “It is either
13064: good-smelling or not good-smelling (vel suaveolens vel
13065: non-suaveolens),” both judgements are contradictorily opposed; and the
13066: contradictory opposite of the former judgement—some bodies are not
13067: good-smelling—embraces also those bodies which have no smell at all. In
13068: the preceding pair of opposed judgements (per disparata), the
13069: contingent condition of the conception of body (smell) attached to both
13070: conflicting statements, instead of having been omitted in the latter,
13071: which is consequently not the contradictory opposite of the former.
13072: 
13073: If, accordingly, we say: “The world is either infinite in extension, or
13074: it is not infinite (non est infinitus)”; and if the former proposition
13075: is false, its contradictory opposite—the world is not infinite—must be
13076: true. And thus I should deny the existence of an infinite, without,
13077: however affirming the existence of a finite world. But if we construct
13078: our proposition thus: “The world is either infinite or finite
13079: (non-infinite),” both statements may be false. For, in this case, we
13080: consider the world as per se determined in regard to quantity, and
13081: while, in the one judgement, we deny its infinite and consequently,
13082: perhaps, its independent existence; in the other, we append to the
13083: world, regarded as a thing in itself, a certain determination—that of
13084: finitude; and the latter may be false as well as the former, if the
13085: world is not given as a thing in itself, and thus neither as finite nor
13086: as infinite in quantity. This kind of opposition I may be allowed to
13087: term dialectical; that of contradictories may be called analytical
13088: opposition. Thus then, of two dialectically opposed judgements both may
13089: be false, from the fact, that the one is not a mere contradictory of
13090: the other, but actually enounces more than is requisite for a full and
13091: complete contradiction.
13092: 
13093: When we regard the two propositions—“The world is infinite in
13094: quantity,” and, “The world is finite in quantity,” as contradictory
13095: opposites, we are assuming that the world—the complete series of
13096: phenomena—is a thing in itself. For it remains as a permanent quantity,
13097: whether I deny the infinite or the finite regress in the series of its
13098: phenomena. But if we dismiss this assumption—this transcendental
13099: illusion—and deny that it is a thing in itself, the contradictory
13100: opposition is metamorphosed into a merely dialectical one; and the
13101: world, as not existing in itself—independently of the regressive series
13102: of my representations—exists in like manner neither as a whole which is
13103: infinite nor as a whole which is finite in itself. The universe exists
13104: for me only in the empirical regress of the series of phenomena and not
13105: per se. If, then, it is always conditioned, it is never completely or
13106: as a whole; and it is, therefore, not an unconditioned whole and does
13107: not exist as such, either with an infinite, or with a finite quantity.
13108: 
13109: What we have here said of the first cosmological idea—that of the
13110: absolute totality of quantity in phenomena—applies also to the others.
13111: The series of conditions is discoverable only in the regressive
13112: synthesis itself, and not in the phenomenon considered as a thing in
13113: itself—given prior to all regress. Hence I am compelled to say: “The
13114: aggregate of parts in a given phenomenon is in itself neither finite
13115: nor infinite; and these parts are given only in the regressive
13116: synthesis of decomposition—a synthesis which is never given in absolute
13117: completeness, either as finite, or as infinite.” The same is the case
13118: with the series of subordinated causes, or of the conditioned up to the
13119: unconditioned and necessary existence, which can never be regarded as
13120: in itself, and in its totality, either as finite or as infinite;
13121: because, as a series of subordinate representations, it subsists only
13122: in the dynamical regress and cannot be regarded as existing previously
13123: to this regress, or as a self-subsistent series of things.
13124: 
13125: Thus the antinomy of pure reason in its cosmological ideas disappears.
13126: For the above demonstration has established the fact that it is merely
13127: the product of a dialectical and illusory opposition, which arises from
13128: the application of the idea of absolute totality—admissible only as a
13129: condition of things in themselves—to phenomena, which exist only in our
13130: representations, and—when constituting a series—in a successive
13131: regress. This antinomy of reason may, however, be really profitable to
13132: our speculative interests, not in the way of contributing any
13133: dogmatical addition, but as presenting to us another material support
13134: in our critical investigations. For it furnishes us with an indirect
13135: proof of the transcendental ideality of phenomena, if our minds were
13136: not completely satisfied with the direct proof set forth in the
13137: Trancendental Æsthetic. The proof would proceed in the following
13138: dilemma. If the world is a whole existing in itself, it must be either
13139: finite or infinite. But it is neither finite nor infinite—as has been
13140: shown, on the one side, by the thesis, on the other, by the antithesis.
13141: Therefore the world—the content of all phenomena—is not a whole
13142: existing in itself. It follows that phenomena are nothing, apart from
13143: our representations. And this is what we mean by transcendental
13144: ideality.
13145: 
13146: This remark is of some importance. It enables us to see that the proofs
13147: of the fourfold antinomy are not mere sophistries—are not fallacious,
13148: but grounded on the nature of reason, and valid—under the supposition
13149: that phenomena are things in themselves. The opposition of the
13150: judgements which follow makes it evident that a fallacy lay in the
13151: initial supposition, and thus helps us to discover the true
13152: constitution of objects of sense. This transcendental dialectic does
13153: not favour scepticism, although it presents us with a triumphant
13154: demonstration of the advantages of the sceptical method, the great
13155: utility of which is apparent in the antinomy, where the arguments of
13156: reason were allowed to confront each other in undiminished force. And
13157: although the result of these conflicts of reason is not what we
13158: expected—although we have obtained no positive dogmatical addition to
13159: metaphysical science—we have still reaped a great advantage in the
13160: correction of our judgements on these subjects of thought.
13161: 
13162: Section VIII. Regulative Principle of Pure Reason in relation to the
13163: Cosmological Ideas
13164: 
13165: The cosmological principle of totality could not give us any certain
13166: knowledge in regard to the maximum in the series of conditions in the
13167: world of sense, considered as a thing in itself. The actual regress in
13168: the series is the only means of approaching this maximum. This
13169: principle of pure reason, therefore, may still be considered as
