13170: valid—not as an axiom enabling us to cogitate totality in the object as
13171: actual, but as a problem for the understanding, which requires it to
13172: institute and to continue, in conformity with the idea of totality in
13173: the mind, the regress in the series of the conditions of a given
13174: conditioned. For in the world of sense, that is, in space and time,
13175: every condition which we discover in our investigation of phenomena is
13176: itself conditioned; because sensuous objects are not things in
13177: themselves (in which case an absolutely unconditioned might be reached
13178: in the progress of cognition), but are merely empirical representations
13179: the conditions of which must always be found in intuition. The
13180: principle of reason is therefore properly a mere rule—prescribing a
13181: regress in the series of conditions for given phenomena, and
13182: prohibiting any pause or rest on an absolutely unconditioned. It is,
13183: therefore, not a principle of the possibility of experience or of the
13184: empirical cognition of sensuous objects—consequently not a principle of
13185: the understanding; for every experience is confined within certain
13186: proper limits determined by the given intuition. Still less is it a
13187: constitutive principle of reason authorizing us to extend our
13188: conception of the sensuous world beyond all possible experience. It is
13189: merely a principle for the enlargement and extension of experience as
13190: far as is possible for human faculties. It forbids us to consider any
13191: empirical limits as absolute. It is, hence, a principle of reason,
13192: which, as a rule, dictates how we ought to proceed in our empirical
13193: regress, but is unable to anticipate or indicate prior to the empirical
13194: regress what is given in the object itself. I have termed it for this
13195: reason a regulative principle of reason; while the principle of the
13196: absolute totality of the series of conditions, as existing in itself
13197: and given in the object, is a constitutive cosmological principle. This
13198: distinction will at once demonstrate the falsehood of the constitutive
13199: principle, and prevent us from attributing (by a transcendental
13200: subreptio) objective reality to an idea, which is valid only as a rule.
13201: 
13202: In order to understand the proper meaning of this rule of pure reason,
13203: we must notice first that it cannot tell us what the object is, but
13204: only how the empirical regress is to be proceeded with in order to
13205: attain to the complete conception of the object. If it gave us any
13206: information in respect to the former statement, it would be a
13207: constitutive principle—a principle impossible from the nature of pure
13208: reason. It will not therefore enable us to establish any such
13209: conclusions as: “The series of conditions for a given conditioned is in
13210: itself finite,” or, “It is infinite.” For, in this case, we should be
13211: cogitating in the mere idea of absolute totality, an object which is
13212: not and cannot be given in experience; inasmuch as we should be
13213: attributing a reality objective and independent of the empirical
13214: synthesis, to a series of phenomena. This idea of reason cannot then be
13215: regarded as valid—except as a rule for the regressive synthesis in the
13216: series of conditions, according to which we must proceed from the
13217: conditioned, through all intermediate and subordinate conditions, up to
13218: the unconditioned; although this goal is unattained and unattainable.
13219: For the absolutely unconditioned cannot be discovered in the sphere of
13220: experience.
13221: 
13222: We now proceed to determine clearly our notion of a synthesis which can
13223: never be complete. There are two terms commonly employed for this
13224: purpose. These terms are regarded as expressions of different and
13225: distinguishable notions, although the ground of the distinction has
13226: never been clearly exposed. The term employed by the mathematicians is
13227: progressus in infinitum. The philosophers prefer the expression
13228: progressus in indefinitum. Without detaining the reader with an
13229: examination of the reasons for such a distinction, or with remarks on
13230: the right or wrong use of the terms, I shall endeavour clearly to
13231: determine these conceptions, so far as is necessary for the purpose in
13232: this Critique.
13233: 
13234: We may, with propriety, say of a straight line, that it may be produced
13235: to infinity. In this case the distinction between a progressus in
13236: infinitum and a progressus in indefinitum is a mere piece of subtlety.
13237: For, although when we say, “Produce a straight line,” it is more
13238: correct to say in indefinitum than in infinitum; because the former
13239: means, “Produce it as far as you please,” the second, “You must not
13240: cease to produce it”; the expression in infinitum is, when we are
13241: speaking of the power to do it, perfectly correct, for we can always
13242: make it longer if we please—on to infinity. And this remark holds good
13243: in all cases, when we speak of a progressus, that is, an advancement
13244: from the condition to the conditioned; this possible advancement always
13245: proceeds to infinity. We may proceed from a given pair in the
13246: descending line of generation from father to son, and cogitate a
13247: never-ending line of descendants from it. For in such a case reason
13248: does not demand absolute totality in the series, because it does not
13249: presuppose it as a condition and as given (datum), but merely as
13250: conditioned, and as capable of being given (dabile).
13251: 
13252: Very different is the case with the problem: “How far the regress,
13253: which ascends from the given conditioned to the conditions, must
13254: extend”; whether I can say: “It is a regress in infinitum,” or only “in
13255: indefinitum”; and whether, for example, setting out from the human
13256: beings at present alive in the world, I may ascend in the series of
13257: their ancestors, in infinitum—or whether all that can be said is, that
13258: so far as I have proceeded, I have discovered no empirical ground for
13259: considering the series limited, so that I am justified, and indeed,
13260: compelled to search for ancestors still further back, although I am not
13261: obliged by the idea of reason to presuppose them.
13262: 
13263: My answer to this question is: “If the series is given in empirical
13264: intuition as a whole, the regress in the series of its internal
13265: conditions proceeds in infinitum; but, if only one member of the series
13266: is given, from which the regress is to proceed to absolute totality,
13267: the regress is possible only in indefinitum.” For example, the division
13268: of a portion of matter given within certain limits—of a body, that
13269: is—proceeds in infinitum. For, as the condition of this whole is its
13270: part, and the condition of the part a part of the part, and so on, and
13271: as in this regress of decomposition an unconditioned indivisible member
13272: of the series of conditions is not to be found; there are no reasons or
13273: grounds in experience for stopping in the division, but, on the
13274: contrary, the more remote members of the division are actually and
13275: empirically given prior to this division. That is to say, the division
13276: proceeds to infinity. On the other hand, the series of ancestors of any
13277: given human being is not given, in its absolute totality, in any
13278: experience, and yet the regress proceeds from every genealogical member
13279: of this series to one still higher, and does not meet with any
13280: empirical limit presenting an absolutely unconditioned member of the
13281: series. But as the members of such a series are not contained in the
13282: empirical intuition of the whole, prior to the regress, this regress
13283: does not proceed to infinity, but only in indefinitum, that is, we are
13284: called upon to discover other and higher members, which are themselves
13285: always conditioned.
13286: 
13287: In neither case—the regressus in infinitum, nor the regressus in
13288: indefinitum, is the series of conditions to be considered as actually
13289: infinite in the object itself. This might be true of things in
13290: themselves, but it cannot be asserted of phenomena, which, as
13291: conditions of each other, are only given in the empirical regress
13292: itself. Hence, the question no longer is, “What is the quantity of this
13293: series of conditions in itself—is it finite or infinite?” for it is
13294: nothing in itself; but, “How is the empirical regress to be commenced,
13295: and how far ought we to proceed with it?” And here a signal distinction
13296: in the application of this rule becomes apparent. If the whole is given
13297: empirically, it is possible to recede in the series of its internal
13298: conditions to infinity. But if the whole is not given, and can only be
13299: given by and through the empirical regress, I can only say: “It is
13300: possible to infinity, to proceed to still higher conditions in the
13301: series.” In the first case, I am justified in asserting that more
13302: members are empirically given in the object than I attain to in the
13303: regress (of decomposition). In the second case, I am justified only in
13304: saying, that I can always proceed further in the regress, because no
13305: member of the series is given as absolutely conditioned, and thus a
13306: higher member is possible, and an inquiry with regard to it is
13307: necessary. In the one case it is necessary to find other members of the
13308: series, in the other it is necessary to inquire for others, inasmuch as
13309: experience presents no absolute limitation of the regress. For, either
13310: you do not possess a perception which absolutely limits your empirical
13311: regress, and in this case the regress cannot be regarded as complete;
13312: or, you do possess such a limitative perception, in which case it is
13313: not a part of your series (for that which limits must be distinct from
13314: that which is limited by it), and it is incumbent you to continue your
13315: regress up to this condition, and so on.
13316: 
13317: These remarks will be placed in their proper light by their application
13318: in the following section.
13319: 
13320: Section IX. Of the Empirical Use of the Regulative Principle of Reason
13321: with regard to the Cosmological Ideas
13322: 
13323: We have shown that no transcendental use can be made either of the
13324: conceptions of reason or of understanding. We have shown, likewise,
13325: that the demand of absolute totality in the series of conditions in the
13326: world of sense arises from a transcendental employment of reason,
13327: resting on the opinion that phenomena are to be regarded as things in
13328: themselves. It follows that we are not required to answer the question
13329: respecting the absolute quantity of a series—whether it is in itself
13330: limited or unlimited. We are only called upon to determine how far we
13331: must proceed in the empirical regress from condition to condition, in
13332: order to discover, in conformity with the rule of reason, a full and
13333: correct answer to the questions proposed by reason itself.
13334: 
13335: This principle of reason is hence valid only as a rule for the
13336: extension of a possible experience—its invalidity as a principle
13337: constitutive of phenomena in themselves having been sufficiently
13338: demonstrated. And thus, too, the antinomial conflict of reason with
13339: itself is completely put an end to; inasmuch as we have not only
13340: presented a critical solution of the fallacy lurking in the opposite
13341: statements of reason, but have shown the true meaning of the ideas
13342: which gave rise to these statements. The dialectical principle of
13343: reason has, therefore, been changed into a doctrinal principle. But in
13344: fact, if this principle, in the subjective signification which we have
13345: shown to be its only true sense, may be guaranteed as a principle of
13346: the unceasing extension of the employment of our understanding, its
13347: influence and value are just as great as if it were an axiom for the à
13348: priori determination of objects. For such an axiom could not exert a
13349: stronger influence on the extension and rectification of our knowledge,
13350: otherwise than by procuring for the principles of the understanding the
13351: most widely expanded employment in the field of experience.
13352: 
13353: I. Solution of the Cosmological Idea of the Totality of the Composition
13354: of Phenomena in the Universe
13355: 
13356: Here, as well as in the case of the other cosmological problems, the
13357: ground of the regulative principle of reason is the proposition that in
13358: our empirical regress no experience of an absolute limit, and
13359: consequently no experience of a condition, which is itself absolutely
13360: unconditioned, is discoverable. And the truth of this proposition
13361: itself rests upon the consideration that such an experience must
13362: represent to us phenomena as limited by nothing or the mere void, on
13363: which our continued regress by means of perception must abut—which is
13364: impossible.
13365: 
13366: Now this proposition, which declares that every condition attained in
13367: the empirical regress must itself be considered empirically
13368: conditioned, contains the rule in terminis, which requires me, to
13369: whatever extent I may have proceeded in the ascending series, always to
13370: look for some higher member in the series—whether this member is to
13371: become known to me through experience, or not.
13372: 
13373: Nothing further is necessary, then, for the solution of the first
13374: cosmological problem, than to decide, whether, in the regress to the
13375: unconditioned quantity of the universe (as regards space and time),
13376: this never limited ascent ought to be called a regressus in infinitum
13377: or indefinitum.
13378: 
13379: The general representation which we form in our minds of the series of
13380: all past states or conditions of the world, or of all the things which
13381: at present exist in it, is itself nothing more than a possible
13382: empirical regress, which is cogitated—although in an undetermined
13383: manner—in the mind, and which gives rise to the conception of a series
13384: of conditions for a given object.[60] Now I have a conception of the
13385: universe, but not an intuition—that is, not an intuition of it as a
13386: whole. Thus I cannot infer the magnitude of the regress from the
13387: quantity or magnitude of the world, and determine the former by means
13388: of the latter; on the contrary, I must first of all form a conception
13389: of the quantity or magnitude of the world from the magnitude of the
13390: empirical regress. But of this regress I know nothing more than that I
13391: ought to proceed from every given member of the series of conditions to
13392: one still higher. But the quantity of the universe is not thereby
13393: determined, and we cannot affirm that this regress proceeds in
13394: infinitum. Such an affirmation would anticipate the members of the
13395: series which have not yet been reached, and represent the number of
13396: them as beyond the grasp of any empirical synthesis; it would
13397: consequently determine the cosmical quantity prior to the regress
13398: (although only in a negative manner)—which is impossible. For the world
13399: is not given in its totality in any intuition: consequently, its
13400: quantity cannot be given prior to the regress. It follows that we are
13401: unable to make any declaration respecting the cosmical quantity in
13402: itself—not even that the regress in it is a regress in infinitum; we
13403: must only endeavour to attain to a conception of the quantity of the
13404: universe, in conformity with the rule which determines the empirical
13405: regress in it. But this rule merely requires us never to admit an
13406: absolute limit to our series—how far soever we may have proceeded in
13407: it, but always, on the contrary, to subordinate every phenomenon to
13408: some other as its condition, and consequently to proceed to this higher
13409: phenomenon. Such a regress is, therefore, the regressus in indefinitum,
13410: which, as not determining a quantity in the object, is clearly
13411: distinguishable from the regressus in infinitum.
13412: 
13413:  [60] The cosmical series can neither be greater nor smaller than the
13414:  possible empirical regress, upon which its conception is based. And as
13415:  this regress cannot be a determinate infinite regress, still less a
13416:  determinate finite (absolutely limited), it is evident that we cannot
13417:  regard the world as either finite or infinite, because the regress,
13418:  which gives us the representation of the world, is neither finite nor
13419:  infinite.
13420: 
13421: 
13422: It follows from what we have said that we are not justified in
13423: declaring the world to be infinite in space, or as regards past time.
13424: For this conception of an infinite given quantity is empirical; but we
13425: cannot apply the conception of an infinite quantity to the world as an
13426: object of the senses. I cannot say, “The regress from a given
13427: perception to everything limited either in space or time, proceeds in
13428: infinitum,” for this presupposes an infinite cosmical quantity; neither
13429: can I say, “It is finite,” for an absolute limit is likewise impossible
13430: in experience. It follows that I am not entitled to make any assertion
13431: at all respecting the whole object of experience—the world of sense; I
13432: must limit my declarations to the rule according to which experience or
13433: empirical knowledge is to be attained.
13434: 
13435: To the question, therefore, respecting the cosmical quantity, the first
13436: and negative answer is: “The world has no beginning in time, and no
13437: absolute limit in space.”
13438: 
13439: For, in the contrary case, it would be limited by a void time on the
13440: one hand, and by a void space on the other. Now, since the world, as a
13441: phenomenon, cannot be thus limited in itself for a phenomenon is not a
13442: thing in itself; it must be possible for us to have a perception of
13443: this limitation by a void time and a void space. But such a
13444: perception—such an experience is impossible; because it has no content.
13445: Consequently, an absolute cosmical limit is empirically, and therefore
13446: absolutely, impossible.[61]
13447: 
13448:  [61] The reader will remark that the proof presented above is very
13449:  different from the dogmatical demonstration given in the antithesis of
13450:  the first antinomy. In that demonstration, it was taken for granted
13451:  that the world is a thing in itself—given in its totality prior to all
13452:  regress, and a determined position in space and time was denied to
13453:  it—if it was not considered as occupying all time and all space. Hence
13454:  our conclusion differed from that given above; for we inferred in the
13455:  antithesis the actual infinity of the world.
13456: 
13457: 
13458: From this follows the affirmative answer: “The regress in the series of
13459: phenomena—as a determination of the cosmical quantity, proceeds in
13460: indefinitum.” This is equivalent to saying: “The world of sense has no
13461: absolute quantity, but the empirical regress (through which alone the
13462: world of sense is presented to us on the side of its conditions) rests
13463: upon a rule, which requires it to proceed from every member of the
13464: series, as conditioned, to one still more remote (whether through
13465: personal experience, or by means of history, or the chain of cause and
13466: effect), and not to cease at any point in this extension of the
13467: possible empirical employment of the understanding.” And this is the
13468: proper and only use which reason can make of its principles.
13469: 
13470: The above rule does not prescribe an unceasing regress in one kind of
13471: phenomena. It does not, for example, forbid us, in our ascent from an
13472: individual human being through the line of his ancestors, to expect
13473: that we shall discover at some point of the regress a primeval pair, or
13474: to admit, in the series of heavenly bodies, a sun at the farthest
13475: possible distance from some centre. All that it demands is a perpetual
13476: progress from phenomena to phenomena, even although an actual
13477: perception is not presented by them (as in the case of our perceptions
13478: being so weak as that we are unable to become conscious of them), since
13479: they, nevertheless, belong to possible experience.
13480: 
13481: Every beginning is in time, and all limits to extension are in space.
13482: But space and time are in the world of sense. Consequently phenomena in
13483: the world are conditionally limited, but the world itself is not
13484: limited, either conditionally or unconditionally.
13485: 
13486: For this reason, and because neither the world nor the cosmical series
13487: of conditions to a given conditioned can be completely given, our
13488: conception of the cosmical quantity is given only in and through the
13489: regress and not prior to it—in a collective intuition. But the regress
13490: itself is really nothing more than the determining of the cosmical
13491: quantity, and cannot therefore give us any determined conception of
13492: it—still less a conception of a quantity which is, in relation to a
13493: certain standard, infinite. The regress does not, therefore, proceed to
13494: infinity (an infinity given), but only to an indefinite extent, for or
13495: the of presenting to us a quantity—realized only in and through the
13496: regress itself.
13497: 
13498: II. Solution of the Cosmological Idea of the Totality of the Division
13499: of a Whole given in Intuition
13500: 
13501: When I divide a whole which is given in intuition, I proceed from a
13502: conditioned to its conditions. The division of the parts of the whole
13503: (subdivisio or decompositio) is a regress in the series of these
13504: conditions. The absolute totality of this series would be actually
13505: attained and given to the mind, if the regress could arrive at simple
13506: parts. But if all the parts in a continuous decomposition are
13507: themselves divisible, the division, that is to say, the regress,
13508: proceeds from the conditioned to its conditions in infinitum; because
13509: the conditions (the parts) are themselves contained in the conditioned,
13510: and, as the latter is given in a limited intuition, the former are all
13511: given along with it. This regress cannot, therefore, be called a
13512: regressus in indefinitum, as happened in the case of the preceding
13513: cosmological idea, the regress in which proceeded from the conditioned
13514: to the conditions not given contemporaneously and along with it, but
13515: discoverable only through the empirical regress. We are not, however,
13516: entitled to affirm of a whole of this kind, which is divisible in
13517: infinitum, that it consists of an infinite number of parts. For,
13518: although all the parts are contained in the intuition of the whole, the
13519: whole division is not contained therein. The division is contained only
13520: in the progressing decomposition—in the regress itself, which is the
13521: condition of the possibility and actuality of the series. Now, as this
13522: regress is infinite, all the members (parts) to which it attains must
13523: be contained in the given whole as an aggregate. But the complete
13524: series of division is not contained therein. For this series, being
13525: infinite in succession and always incomplete, cannot represent an
13526: infinite number of members, and still less a composition of these
13527: members into a whole.
13528: 
13529: To apply this remark to space. Every limited part of space presented to
13530: intuition is a whole, the parts of which are always spaces—to whatever
13531: extent subdivided. Every limited space is hence divisible to infinity.
13532: 
13533: Let us again apply the remark to an external phenomenon enclosed in
13534: limits, that is, a body. The divisibility of a body rests upon the
13535: divisibility of space, which is the condition of the possibility of the
13536: body as an extended whole. A body is consequently divisible to
13537: infinity, though it does not, for that reason, consist of an infinite
13538: number of parts.
13539: 
13540: It certainly seems that, as a body must be cogitated as substance in
13541: space, the law of divisibility would not be applicable to it as
13542: substance. For we may and ought to grant, in the case of space, that
13543: division or decomposition, to any extent, never can utterly annihilate
13544: composition (that is to say, the smallest part of space must still
13545: consist of spaces); otherwise space would entirely cease to exist—which
13546: is impossible. But, the assertion on the other hand that when all
13547: composition in matter is annihilated in thought, nothing remains, does
13548: not seem to harmonize with the conception of substance, which must be
13549: properly the subject of all composition and must remain, even after the
13550: conjunction of its attributes in space—which constituted a body—is
13551: annihilated in thought. But this is not the case with substance in the
13552: phenomenal world, which is not a thing in itself cogitated by the pure
13553: category. Phenomenal substance is not an absolute subject; it is merely
13554: a permanent sensuous image, and nothing more than an intuition, in
13555: which the unconditioned is not to be found.
13556: 
13557: But, although this rule of progress to infinity is legitimate and
13558: applicable to the subdivision of a phenomenon, as a mere occupation or
13559: filling of space, it is not applicable to a whole consisting of a
13560: number of distinct parts and constituting a quantum discretum—that is
13561: to say, an organized body. It cannot be admitted that every part in an
13562: organized whole is itself organized, and that, in analysing it to
13563: infinity, we must always meet with organized parts; although we may
13564: allow that the parts of the matter which we decompose in infinitum, may
13565: be organized. For the infinity of the division of a phenomenon in space
13566: rests altogether on the fact that the divisibility of a phenomenon is
13567: given only in and through this infinity, that is, an undetermined
13568: number of parts is given, while the parts themselves are given and
13569: determined only in and through the subdivision; in a word, the infinity
13570: of the division necessarily presupposes that the whole is not already
13571: divided in se. Hence our division determines a number of parts in the
13572: whole—a number which extends just as far as the actual regress in the
13573: division; while, on the other hand, the very notion of a body organized
13574: to infinity represents the whole as already and in itself divided. We
13575: expect, therefore, to find in it a determinate, but at the same time,
13576: infinite, number of parts—which is self-contradictory. For we should
13577: thus have a whole containing a series of members which could not be
13578: completed in any regress—which is infinite, and at the same time
13579: complete in an organized composite. Infinite divisibility is applicable
13580: only to a quantum continuum, and is based entirely on the infinite
13581: divisibility of space, But in a quantum discretum the multitude of
13582: parts or units is always determined, and hence always equal to some
13583: number. To what extent a body may be organized, experience alone can
13584: inform us; and although, so far as our experience of this or that body
13585: has extended, we may not have discovered any inorganic part, such parts
13586: must exist in possible experience. But how far the transcendental
13587: division of a phenomenon must extend, we cannot know from experience—it
13588: is a question which experience cannot answer; it is answered only by
13589: the principle of reason which forbids us to consider the empirical
13590: regress, in the analysis of extended body, as ever absolutely complete.
13591: 
13592: Concluding Remark on the Solution of the Transcendental Mathematical
13593: Ideas—and Introductory to the Solution of the Dynamical Ideas.
13594: 
13595: We presented the antinomy of pure reason in a tabular form, and we
13596: endeavoured to show the ground of this self-contradiction on the part
13597: of reason, and the only means of bringing it to a conclusion—namely, by
13598: declaring both contradictory statements to be false. We represented in
13599: these antinomies the conditions of phenomena as belonging to the
13600: conditioned according to relations of space and time—which is the usual
13601: supposition of the common understanding. In this respect, all
13602: dialectical representations of totality, in the series of conditions to
13603: a given conditioned, were perfectly homogeneous. The condition was
13604: always a member of the series along with the conditioned, and thus the
13605: homogeneity of the whole series was assured. In this case the regress
13606: could never be cogitated as complete; or, if this was the case, a
13607: member really conditioned was falsely regarded as a primal member,
13608: consequently as unconditioned. In such an antinomy, therefore, we did
13609: not consider the object, that is, the conditioned, but the series of
13610: conditions belonging to the object, and the magnitude of that series.
13611: And thus arose the difficulty—a difficulty not to be settled by any
13612: decision regarding the claims of the two parties, but simply by cutting
13613: the knot—by declaring the series proposed by reason to be either too
13614: long or too short for the understanding, which could in neither case
13615: make its conceptions adequate with the ideas.
13616: 
13617: But we have overlooked, up to this point, an essential difference
13618: existing between the conceptions of the understanding which reason
13619: endeavours to raise to the rank of ideas—two of these indicating a
13620: mathematical, and two a dynamical synthesis of phenomena. Hitherto, it
13621: was necessary to signalize this distinction; for, just as in our
13622: general representation of all transcendental ideas, we considered them
13623: under phenomenal conditions, so, in the two mathematical ideas, our
13624: discussion is concerned solely with an object in the world of
13625: phenomena. But as we are now about to proceed to the consideration of
13626: the dynamical conceptions of the understanding, and their adequateness
13627: with ideas, we must not lose sight of this distinction. We shall find
13628: that it opens up to us an entirely new view of the conflict in which
13629: reason is involved. For, while in the first two antinomies, both
13630: parties were dismissed, on the ground of having advanced statements
13631: based upon false hypothesis; in the present case the hope appears of
13632: discovering a hypothesis which may be consistent with the demands of
13633: reason, and, the judge completing the statement of the grounds of
13634: claim, which both parties had left in an unsatisfactory state, the
13635: question may be settled on its own merits, not by dismissing the
13636: claimants, but by a comparison of the arguments on both sides. If we
13637: consider merely their extension, and whether they are adequate with
13638: ideas, the series of conditions may be regarded as all homogeneous. But
13639: the conception of the understanding which lies at the basis of these
13640: ideas, contains either a synthesis of the homogeneous (presupposed in
13641: every quantity—in its composition as well as in its division) or of the
13642: heterogeneous, which is the case in the dynamical synthesis of cause
13643: and effect, as well as of the necessary and the contingent.
13644: 
13645: Thus it happens that in the mathematical series of phenomena no other
13646: than a sensuous condition is admissible—a condition which is itself a
13647: member of the series; while the dynamical series of sensuous conditions
13648: admits a heterogeneous condition, which is not a member of the series,
13649: but, as purely intelligible, lies out of and beyond it. And thus reason
13650: is satisfied, and an unconditioned placed at the head of the series of
13651: phenomena, without introducing confusion into or discontinuing it,
13652: contrary to the principles of the understanding.
13653: 
13654: Now, from the fact that the dynamical ideas admit a condition of
13655: phenomena which does not form a part of the series of phenomena, arises
13656: a result which we should not have expected from an antinomy. In former
13657: cases, the result was that both contradictory dialectical statements
13658: were declared to be false. In the present case, we find the conditioned
13659: in the dynamical series connected with an empirically unconditioned,
13660: but non-sensuous condition; and thus satisfaction is done to the
13661: understanding on the one hand and to the reason on the other.[62]
13662: While, moreover, the dialectical arguments for unconditioned totality
13663: in mere phenomena fall to the ground, both propositions of reason may
13664: be shown to be true in their proper signification. This could not
13665: happen in the case of the cosmological ideas which demanded a
13666: mathematically unconditioned unity; for no condition could be placed at
13667: the head of the series of phenomena, except one which was itself a
13668: phenomenon and consequently a member of the series.
13669: 
13670:  [62] For the understanding cannot admit among phenomena a condition
13671:  which is itself empirically unconditioned. But if it is possible to
13672:  cogitate an intelligible condition—one which is not a member of the
13673:  series of phenomena—for a conditioned phenomenon, without breaking the
13674:  series of empirical conditions, such a condition may be admissible as
13675:  empirically unconditioned, and the empirical regress continue regular,
13676:  unceasing, and intact.
13677: 
13678: III. Solution of the Cosmological Idea of the Totality of the Deduction
13679: of Cosmical Events from their Causes
13680: 
13681: There are only two modes of causality cogitable—the causality of nature
13682: or of freedom. The first is the conjunction of a particular state with
13683: another preceding it in the world of sense, the former following the
13684: latter by virtue of a law. Now, as the causality of phenomena is
13685: subject to conditions of time, and the preceding state, if it had
13686: always existed, could not have produced an effect which would make its
13687: first appearance at a particular time, the causality of a cause must
13688: itself be an effect—must itself have begun to be, and therefore,
13689: according to the principle of the understanding, itself requires a
13690: cause.
13691: 
13692: We must understand, on the contrary, by the term freedom, in the
13693: cosmological sense, a faculty of the spontaneous origination of a
13694: state; the causality of which, therefore, is not subordinated to
13695: another cause determining it in time. Freedom is in this sense a pure
13696: transcendental idea, which, in the first place, contains no empirical
13697: element; the object of which, in the second place, cannot be given or
13698: determined in any experience, because it is a universal law of the very
13699: possibility of experience, that everything which happens must have a
13700: cause, that consequently the causality of a cause, being itself
13701: something that has happened, must also have a cause. In this view of
13702: the case, the whole field of experience, how far soever it may extend,
13703: contains nothing that is not subject to the laws of nature. But, as we
13704: cannot by this means attain to an absolute totality of conditions in
13705: reference to the series of causes and effects, reason creates the idea
13706: of a spontaneity, which can begin to act of itself, and without any
13707: external cause determining it to action, according to the natural law
13708: of causality.
13709: 
13710: It is especially remarkable that the practical conception of freedom is
13711: based upon the transcendental idea, and that the question of the
13712: possibility of the former is difficult only as it involves the
13713: consideration of the truth of the latter. Freedom, in the practical
13714: sense, is the independence of the will of coercion by sensuous
13715: impulses. A will is sensuous, in so far as it is pathologically
13716: affected (by sensuous impulses); it is termed animal (arbitrium
13717: brutum), when it is pathologically necessitated. The human will is
13718: certainly an arbitrium sensitivum, not brutum, but liberum; because
13719: sensuousness does not necessitate its action, a faculty existing in man
13720: of self-determination, independently of all sensuous coercion.
13721: 
13722: It is plain that, if all causality in the world of sense were
13723: natural—and natural only—every event would be determined by another
13724: according to necessary laws, and that, consequently, phenomena, in so
13725: far as they determine the will, must necessitate every action as a
13726: natural effect from themselves; and thus all practical freedom would
13727: fall to the ground with the transcendental idea. For the latter
13728: presupposes that although a certain thing has not happened, it ought to
13729: have happened, and that, consequently, its phenomenal cause was not so
13730: powerful and determinative as to exclude the causality of our will—a
13731: causality capable of producing effects independently of and even in
13732: opposition to the power of natural causes, and capable, consequently,
13733: of spontaneously originating a series of events.
13734: 
13735: Here, too, we find it to be the case, as we generally found in the
13736: self-contradictions and perplexities of a reason which strives to pass
13737: the bounds of possible experience, that the problem is properly not
13738: physiological, but transcendental. The question of the possibility of
13739: freedom does indeed concern psychology; but, as it rests upon
13740: dialectical arguments of pure reason, its solution must engage the
13741: attention of transcendental philosophy. Before attempting this
13742: solution, a task which transcendental philosophy cannot decline, it
13743: will be advisable to make a remark with regard to its procedure in the
13744: settlement of the question.
13745: 
13746: If phenomena were things in themselves, and time and space forms of the
13747: existence of things, condition and conditioned would always be members
13748: of the same series; and thus would arise in the present case the
13749: antinomy common to all transcendental ideas—that their series is either
13750: too great or too small for the understanding. The dynamical ideas,
13751: which we are about to discuss in this and the following section,
13752: possess the peculiarity of relating to an object, not considered as a
13753: quantity, but as an existence; and thus, in the discussion of the
13754: present question, we may make abstraction of the quantity of the series
13755: of conditions, and consider merely the dynamical relation of the
13756: condition to the conditioned. The question, then, suggests itself,
13757: whether freedom is possible; and, if it is, whether it can consist with
13758: the universality of the natural law of causality; and, consequently,
13759: whether we enounce a proper disjunctive proposition when we say: “Every
13760: effect must have its origin either in nature or in freedom,” or whether
13761: both cannot exist together in the same event in different relations.
13762: The principle of an unbroken connection between all events in the
13763: phenomenal world, in accordance with the unchangeable laws of nature,
13764: is a well-established principle of transcendental analytic which admits
13765: of no exception. The question, therefore, is: “Whether an effect,
13766: determined according to the laws of nature, can at the same time be
13767: produced by a free agent, or whether freedom and nature mutually
13768: exclude each other?” And here, the common but fallacious hypothesis of
13769: the absolute reality of phenomena manifests its injurious influence in
13770: embarrassing the procedure of reason. For if phenomena are things in
13771: themselves, freedom is impossible. In this case, nature is the complete
13772: and all-sufficient cause of every event; and condition and conditioned,
13773: cause and effect are contained in the same series, and necessitated by
13774: the same law. If, on the contrary, phenomena are held to be, as they
13775: are in fact, nothing more than mere representations, connected with
13776: each other in accordance with empirical laws, they must have a ground
13777: which is not phenomenal. But the causality of such an intelligible
13778: cause is not determined or determinable by phenomena; although its
13779: effects, as phenomena, must be determined by other phenomenal
13780: existences. This cause and its causality exist therefore out of and
13781: apart from the series of phenomena; while its effects do exist and are
13782: discoverable in the series of empirical conditions. Such an effect may
13783: therefore be considered to be free in relation to its intelligible
13784: cause, and necessary in relation to the phenomena from which it is a
13785: necessary consequence—a distinction which, stated in this perfectly
13786: general and abstract manner, must appear in the highest degree subtle
13787: and obscure. The sequel will explain. It is sufficient, at present, to
13788: remark that, as the complete and unbroken connection of phenomena is an
13789: unalterable law of nature, freedom is impossible—on the supposition
13790: that phenomena are absolutely real. Hence those philosophers who adhere
13791: to the common opinion on this subject can never succeed in reconciling
13792: the ideas of nature and freedom.
13793: 
13794: _Possibility of Freedom in Harmony with the Universal Law of Natural
13795: Necessity._
13796: 
13797: That element in a sensuous object which is not itself sensuous, I may
13798: be allowed to term intelligible. If, accordingly, an object which must
13799: be regarded as a sensuous phenomenon possesses a faculty which is not
13800: an object of sensuous intuition, but by means of which it is capable of
13801: being the cause of phenomena, the causality of an object or existence
13802: of this kind may be regarded from two different points of view. It may
13803: be considered to be intelligible, as regards its action—the action of a
13804: thing which is a thing in itself, and sensuous, as regards its
13805: effects—the effects of a phenomenon belonging to the sensuous world. We
13806: should accordingly, have to form both an empirical and an intellectual
13807: conception of the causality of such a faculty or power—both, however,
13808: having reference to the same effect. This twofold manner of cogitating
13809: a power residing in a sensuous object does not run counter to any of
13810: the conceptions which we ought to form of the world of phenomena or of
13811: a possible experience. Phenomena—not being things in themselves—must
13812: have a transcendental object as a foundation, which determines them as
13813: mere representations; and there seems to be no reason why we should not
13814: ascribe to this transcendental object, in addition to the property of
13815: self-phenomenization, a causality whose effects are to be met with in
13816: the world of phenomena, although it is not itself a phenomenon. But
13817: every effective cause must possess a character, that is to say, a law
13818: of its causality, without which it would cease to be a cause. In the
13819: above case, then, every sensuous object would possess an empirical
13820: character, which guaranteed that its actions, as phenomena, stand in
13821: complete and harmonious connection, conformably to unvarying natural
13822: laws, with all other phenomena, and can be deduced from these, as
13823: conditions, and that they do thus, in connection with these, constitute
13824: a series in the order of nature. This sensuous object must, in the
13825: second place, possess an intelligible character, which guarantees it to
13826: be the cause of those actions, as phenomena, although it is not itself
13827: a phenomenon nor subordinate to the conditions of the world of sense.
13828: The former may be termed the character of the thing as a phenomenon,
13829: the latter the character of the thing as a thing in itself.
13830: 
13831: Now this active subject would, in its character of intelligible
13832: subject, be subordinate to no conditions of time, for time is only a
13833: condition of phenomena, and not of things in themselves. No action
13834: would begin or cease to be in this subject; it would consequently be
13835: free from the law of all determination of time—the law of change,
13836: namely, that everything which happens must have a cause in the
13837: phenomena of a preceding state. In one word, the causality of the
13838: subject, in so far as it is intelligible, would not form part of the
13839: series of empirical conditions which determine and necessitate an event
13840: in the world of sense. Again, this intelligible character of a thing
13841: cannot be immediately cognized, because we can perceive nothing but
13842: phenomena, but it must be capable of being cogitated in harmony with
13843: the empirical character; for we always find ourselves compelled to
13844: place, in thought, a transcendental object at the basis of phenomena
13845: although we can never know what this object is in itself.
13846: 
13847: In virtue of its empirical character, this subject would at the same
13848: time be subordinate to all the empirical laws of causality, and, as a
13849: phenomenon and member of the sensuous world, its effects would have to
13850: be accounted for by a reference to preceding phenomena. Eternal
13851: phenomena must be capable of influencing it; and its actions, in
13852: accordance with natural laws, must explain to us how its empirical
13853: character, that is, the law of its causality, is to be cognized in and
13854: by means of experience. In a word, all requisites for a complete and
13855: necessary determination of these actions must be presented to us by
13856: experience.
13857: 
13858: In virtue of its intelligible character, on the other hand (although we
13859: possess only a general conception of this character), the subject must
13860: be regarded as free from all sensuous influences, and from all
13861: phenomenal determination. Moreover, as nothing happens in this
13862: subject—for it is a noumenon, and there does not consequently exist in
13863: it any change, demanding the dynamical determination of time, and for
13864: the same reason no connection with phenomena as causes—this active
13865: existence must in its actions be free from and independent of natural
13866: necessity, for this necessity exists only in the world of phenomena. It
13867: would be quite correct to say that it originates or begins its effects
13868: in the world of sense from itself, although the action productive of
13869: these effects does not begin in itself. We should not be in this case
13870: affirming that these sensuous effects began to exist of themselves,
13871: because they are always determined by prior empirical conditions—by
13872: virtue of the empirical character, which is the phenomenon of the
13873: intelligible character—and are possible only as constituting a
13874: continuation of the series of natural causes. And thus nature and
13875: freedom, each in the complete and absolute signification of these
13876: terms, can exist, without contradiction or disagreement, in the same
13877: action.
13878: 
13879: _Exposition of the Cosmological Idea of Freedom in Harmony with the
13880: Universal Law of Natural Necessity._
13881: 
13882: I have thought it advisable to lay before the reader at first merely a
13883: sketch of the solution of this transcendental problem, in order to
13884: enable him to form with greater ease a clear conception of the course
13885: which reason must adopt in the solution. I shall now proceed to exhibit
13886: the several momenta of this solution, and to consider them in their
13887: order.
13888: 
13889: The natural law that everything which happens must have a cause, that
13890: the causality of this cause, that is, the action of the cause (which
13891: cannot always have existed, but must be itself an event, for it
13892: precedes in time some effect which it has originated), must have itself
13893: a phenomenal cause, by which it is determined and, and, consequently,
13894: all events are empirically determined in an order of nature—this law, I
13895: say, which lies at the foundation of the possibility of experience, and
13896: of a connected system of phenomena or nature is a law of the
13897: understanding, from which no departure, and to which no exception, can
13898: be admitted. For to except even a single phenomenon from its operation
13899: is to exclude it from the sphere of possible experience and thus to
13900: admit it to be a mere fiction of thought or phantom of the brain.
13901: 
13902: Thus we are obliged to acknowledge the existence of a chain of causes,
13903: in which, however, absolute totality cannot be found. But we need not
13904: detain ourselves with this question, for it has already been
13905: sufficiently answered in our discussion of the antinomies into which
13906: reason falls, when it attempts to reach the unconditioned in the series
13907: of phenomena. If we permit ourselves to be deceived by the illusion of
13908: transcendental idealism, we shall find that neither nature nor freedom
13909: exists. Now the question is: “Whether, admitting the existence of
13910: natural necessity in the world of phenomena, it is possible to consider
13911: an effect as at the same time an effect of nature and an effect of
13912: freedom—or, whether these two modes of causality are contradictory and
13913: incompatible?”
13914: 
13915: No phenomenal cause can absolutely and of itself begin a series. Every
13916: action, in so far as it is productive of an event, is itself an event
13917: or occurrence, and presupposes another preceding state, in which its
13918: cause existed. Thus everything that happens is but a continuation of a
13919: series, and an absolute beginning is impossible in the sensuous world.
13920: The actions of natural causes are, accordingly, themselves effects, and
13921: presuppose causes preceding them in time. A primal action which forms
13922: an absolute beginning, is beyond the causal power of phenomena.
13923: 
13924: Now, is it absolutely necessary that, granting that all effects are
13925: phenomena, the causality of the cause of these effects must also be a
13926: phenomenon and belong to the empirical world? Is it not rather possible
13927: that, although every effect in the phenomenal world must be connected
13928: with an empirical cause, according to the universal law of nature, this
13929: empirical causality may be itself the effect of a non-empirical and
13930: intelligible causality—its connection with natural causes remaining
13931: nevertheless intact? Such a causality would be considered, in reference
13932: to phenomena, as the primal action of a cause, which is in so far,
13933: therefore, not phenomenal, but, by reason of this faculty or power,
13934: intelligible; although it must, at the same time, as a link in the
13935: chain of nature, be regarded as belonging to the sensuous world.
13936: 
13937: A belief in the reciprocal causality of phenomena is necessary, if we
13938: are required to look for and to present the natural conditions of
13939: natural events, that is to say, their causes. This being admitted as
13940: unexceptionably valid, the requirements of the understanding, which
13941: recognizes nothing but nature in the region of phenomena, are
13942: satisfied, and our physical explanations of physical phenomena may
13943: proceed in their regular course, without hindrance and without
13944: opposition. But it is no stumbling-block in the way, even assuming the
13945: idea to be a pure fiction, to admit that there are some natural causes
13946: in the possession of a faculty which is not empirical, but
13947: intelligible, inasmuch as it is not determined to action by empirical
13948: conditions, but purely and solely upon grounds brought forward by the
13949: understanding—this action being still, when the cause is phenomenized,
13950: in perfect accordance with the laws of empirical causality. Thus the
13951: acting subject, as a causal phenomenon, would continue to preserve a
13952: complete connection with nature and natural conditions; and the
13953: phenomenon only of the subject (with all its phenomenal causality)
13954: would contain certain conditions, which, if we ascend from the
13955: empirical to the transcendental object, must necessarily be regarded as
13956: intelligible. For, if we attend, in our inquiries with regard to causes
13957: in the world of phenomena, to the directions of nature alone, we need
13958: not trouble ourselves about the relation in which the transcendental
13959: subject, which is completely unknown to us, stands to these phenomena
13960: and their connection in nature. The intelligible ground of phenomena in
13961: this subject does not concern empirical questions. It has to do only
13962: with pure thought; and, although the effects of this thought and action
13963: of the pure understanding are discoverable in phenomena, these
13964: phenomena must nevertheless be capable of a full and complete
13965: explanation, upon purely physical grounds and in accordance with
13966: natural laws. And in this case we attend solely to their empirical and
13967: omit all consideration of their intelligible character (which is the
13968: transcendental cause of the former) as completely unknown, except in so
13969: far as it is exhibited by the latter as its empirical symbol. Now let
13970: us apply this to experience. Man is a phenomenon of the sensuous world
13971: and, at the same time, therefore, a natural cause, the causality of
13972: which must be regulated by empirical laws. As such, he must possess an
13973: empirical character, like all other natural phenomena. We remark this
13974: empirical character in his actions, which reveal the presence of
13975: certain powers and faculties. If we consider inanimate or merely animal
13976: nature, we can discover no reason for ascribing to ourselves any other
13977: than a faculty which is determined in a purely sensuous manner. But
13978: man, to whom nature reveals herself only through sense, cognizes
13979: himself not only by his senses, but also through pure apperception; and
13980: this in actions and internal determinations, which he cannot regard as
13981: sensuous impressions. He is thus to himself, on the one hand, a
13982: phenomenon, but on the other hand, in respect of certain faculties, a
13983: purely intelligible object—intelligible, because its action cannot be
13984: ascribed to sensuous receptivity. These faculties are understanding and
13985: reason. The latter, especially, is in a peculiar manner distinct from
13986: all empirically-conditioned faculties, for it employs ideas alone in
13987: the consideration of its objects, and by means of these determines the
13988: understanding, which then proceeds to make an empirical use of its own
13989: conceptions, which, like the ideas of reason, are pure and
13990: non-empirical.
13991: 
13992: That reason possesses the faculty of causality, or that at least we are
13993: compelled so to represent it, is evident from the imperatives, which in
13994: the sphere of the practical we impose on many of our executive powers.
13995: The words I ought express a species of necessity, and imply a
13996: connection with grounds which nature does not and cannot present to the
13997: mind of man. Understanding knows nothing in nature but that which is,
13998: or has been, or will be. It would be absurd to say that anything in
13999: nature ought to be other than it is in the relations of time in which
14000: it stands; indeed, the ought, when we consider merely the course of
14001: nature, has neither application nor meaning. The question, “What ought
14002: to happen in the sphere of nature?” is just as absurd as the question,
14003: “What ought to be the properties of a circle?” All that we are entitled
14004: to ask is, “What takes place in nature?” or, in the latter case, “What
14005: are the properties of a circle?”
14006: 
14007: But the idea of an ought or of duty indicates a possible action, the
14008: ground of which is a pure conception; while the ground of a merely
14009: natural action is, on the contrary, always a phenomenon. This action
14010: must certainly be possible under physical conditions, if it is
14011: prescribed by the moral imperative ought; but these physical or natural
14012: conditions do not concern the determination of the will itself, they
14013: relate to its effects alone, and the consequences of the effect in the
14014: world of phenomena. Whatever number of motives nature may present to my
14015: will, whatever sensuous impulses—the moral ought it is beyond their
14016: power to produce. They may produce a volition, which, so far from being
14017: necessary, is always conditioned—a volition to which the ought
14018: enunciated by reason, sets an aim and a standard, gives permission or
14019: prohibition. Be the object what it may, purely sensuous—as pleasure, or
14020: presented by pure reason—as good, reason will not yield to grounds
14021: which have an empirical origin. Reason will not follow the order of
14022: things presented by experience, but, with perfect spontaneity,
14023: rearranges them according to ideas, with which it compels empirical
14024: conditions to agree. It declares, in the name of these ideas, certain
14025: actions to be necessary which nevertheless have not taken place and
14026: which perhaps never will take place; and yet presupposes that it
14027: possesses the faculty of causality in relation to these actions. For,
14028: in the absence of this supposition, it could not expect its ideas to
14029: produce certain effects in the world of experience.
14030: 
14031: Now, let us stop here and admit it to be at least possible that reason
14032: does stand in a really causal relation to phenomena. In this case it
14033: must—pure reason as it is—exhibit an empirical character. For every
14034: cause supposes a rule, according to which certain phenomena follow as
14035: effects from the cause, and every rule requires uniformity in these
14036: effects; and this is the proper ground of the conception of a cause—as
14037: a faculty or power. Now this conception (of a cause) may be termed the
14038: empirical character of reason; and this character is a permanent one,
14039: while the effects produced appear, in conformity with the various
14040: conditions which accompany and partly limit them, in various forms.
14041: 
14042: Thus the volition of every man has an empirical character, which is
14043: nothing more than the causality of his reason, in so far as its effects
14044: in the phenomenal world manifest the presence of a rule, according to
14045: which we are enabled to examine, in their several kinds and degrees,
14046: the actions of this causality and the rational grounds for these
14047: actions, and in this way to decide upon the subjective principles of
14048: the volition. Now we learn what this empirical character is only from
14049: phenomenal effects, and from the rule of these which is presented by
14050: experience; and for this reason all the actions of man in the world of
14051: phenomena are determined by his empirical character, and the
14052: co-operative causes of nature. If, then, we could investigate all the
14053: phenomena of human volition to their lowest foundation in the mind,
14054: there would be no action which we could not anticipate with certainty,
14055: and recognize to be absolutely necessary from its preceding conditions.
14056: So far as relates to this empirical character, therefore, there can be
14057: no freedom; and it is only in the light of this character that we can
14058: consider the human will, when we confine ourselves to simple
14059: observation and, as is the case in anthropology, institute a
14060: physiological investigation of the motive causes of human actions.
14061: 
14062: But when we consider the same actions in relation to reason—not for the
14063: purpose of explaining their origin, that is, in relation to speculative
14064: reason, but to practical reason, as the producing cause of these
14065: actions—we shall discover a rule and an order very different from those
14066: of nature and experience. For the declaration of this mental faculty
14067: may be that what has and could not but take place in the course of
14068: nature, ought not to have taken place. Sometimes, too, we discover, or
14069: believe that we discover, that the ideas of reason did actually stand
14070: in a causal relation to certain actions of man; and that these actions
14071: have taken place because they were determined, not by empirical causes,
14072: but by the act of the will upon grounds of reason.
14073: 
14074: Now, granting that reason stands in a causal relation to phenomena; can
14075: an action of reason be called free, when we know that, sensuously, in
14076: its empirical character, it is completely determined and absolutely
14077: necessary? But this empirical character is itself determined by the
14078: intelligible character. The latter we cannot cognize; we can only
14079: indicate it by means of phenomena, which enable us to have an immediate
14080: cognition only of the empirical character.[63] An action, then, in so
14081: far as it is to be ascribed to an intelligible cause, does not result
14082: from it in accordance with empirical laws. That is to say, not the
14083: conditions of pure reason, but only their effects in the internal
14084: sense, precede the act. Pure reason, as a purely intelligible faculty,
14085: is not subject to the conditions of time. The causality of reason in
14086: its intelligible character does not begin to be; it does not make its
14087: appearance at a certain time, for the purpose of producing an effect.
14088: If this were not the case, the causality of reason would be subservient
14089: to the natural law of phenomena, which determines them according to
14090: time, and as a series of causes and effects in time; it would
14091: consequently cease to be freedom and become a part of nature. We are
14092: therefore justified in saying: “If reason stands in a causal relation
14093: to phenomena, it is a faculty which originates the sensuous condition
14094: of an empirical series of effects.” For the condition, which resides in
14095: the reason, is non-sensuous, and therefore cannot be originated, or
14096: begin to be. And thus we find—what we could not discover in any
14097: empirical series—a condition of a successive series of events itself
14098: empirically unconditioned. For, in the present case, the condition
14099: stands out of and beyond the series of phenomena—it is intelligible,
14100: and it consequently cannot be subjected to any sensuous condition, or
14101: to any time-determination by a preceding cause.
14102: 
14103:  [63] The real morality of actions—their merit or demerit, and even
14104:  that of our own conduct, is completely unknown to us. Our estimates
14105:  can relate only to their empirical character. How much is the result
14106:  of the action of free will, how much is to be ascribed to nature and
14107:  to blameless error, or to a happy constitution of temperament (merito
14108:  fortunae), no one can discover, nor, for this reason, determine with
14109:  perfect justice.
14110: 
14111: 
14112: But, in another respect, the same cause belongs also to the series of
14113: phenomena. Man is himself a phenomenon. His will has an empirical
14114: character, which is the empirical cause of all his actions. There is no
14115: condition—determining man and his volition in conformity with this
14116: character—which does not itself form part of the series of effects in
14117: nature, and is subject to their law—the law according to which an
14118: empirically undetermined cause of an event in time cannot exist. For
14119: this reason no given action can have an absolute and spontaneous
14120: origination, all actions being phenomena, and belonging to the world of
14121: experience. But it cannot be said of reason, that the state in which it
14122: determines the will is always preceded by some other state determining
14123: it. For reason is not a phenomenon, and therefore not subject to
14124: sensuous conditions; and, consequently, even in relation to its
14125: causality, the sequence or conditions of time do not influence reason,
14126: nor can the dynamical law of nature, which determines the sequence of
14127: time according to certain rules, be applied to it.
14128: 
14129: Reason is consequently the permanent condition of all actions of the
14130: human will. Each of these is determined in the empirical character of
14131: the man, even before it has taken place. The intelligible character, of
14132: which the former is but the sensuous schema, knows no before or after;
14133: and every action, irrespective of the time-relation in which it stands
14134: with other phenomena, is the immediate effect of the intelligible
14135: character of pure reason, which, consequently, enjoys freedom of
14136: action, and is not dynamically determined either by internal or
14137: external preceding conditions. This freedom must not be described, in a
14138: merely negative manner, as independence of empirical conditions, for in
14139: this case the faculty of reason would cease to be a cause of phenomena;
14140: but it must be regarded, positively, as a faculty which can
14141: spontaneously originate a series of events. At the same time, it must
14142: not be supposed that any beginning can take place in reason; on the
14143: contrary, reason, as the unconditioned condition of all action of the
14144: will, admits of no time-conditions, although its effect does really
14145: begin in a series of phenomena—a beginning which is not, however,
14146: absolutely primal.
14147: 
14148: I shall illustrate this regulative principle of reason by an example,
14149: from its employment in the world of experience; proved it cannot be by
14150: any amount of experience, or by any number of facts, for such arguments
14151: cannot establish the truth of transcendental propositions. Let us take
14152: a voluntary action—for example, a falsehood—by means of which a man has
14153: introduced a certain degree of confusion into the social life of
14154: humanity, which is judged according to the motives from which it
14155: originated, and the blame of which and of the evil consequences arising
14156: from it, is imputed to the offender. We at first proceed to examine the
14157: empirical character of the offence, and for this purpose we endeavour
14158: to penetrate to the sources of that character, such as a defective
14159: education, bad company, a shameless and wicked disposition, frivolity,
14160: and want of reflection—not forgetting also the occasioning causes which
14161: prevailed at the moment of the transgression. In this the procedure is
14162: exactly the same as that pursued in the investigation of the series of
14163: causes which determine a given physical effect. Now, although we
14164: believe the action to have been determined by all these circumstances,
14165: we do not the less blame the offender. We do not blame him for his
14166: unhappy disposition, nor for the circumstances which influenced him,
14167: nay, not even for his former course of life; for we presuppose that all
14168: these considerations may be set aside, that the series of preceding
14169: conditions may be regarded as having never existed, and that the action
14170: may be considered as completely unconditioned in relation to any state
14171: preceding, just as if the agent commenced with it an entirely new
14172: series of effects. Our blame of the offender is grounded upon a law of
14173: reason, which requires us to regard this faculty as a cause, which
14174: could have and ought to have otherwise determined the behaviour of the
14175: culprit, independently of all empirical conditions. This causality of
14176: reason we do not regard as a co-operating agency, but as complete in
14177: itself. It matters not whether the sensuous impulses favoured or
14178: opposed the action of this causality, the offence is estimated
14179: according to its intelligible character—the offender is decidedly
14180: worthy of blame, the moment he utters a falsehood. It follows that we
14181: regard reason, in spite of the empirical conditions of the act, as
14182: completely free, and therefore, as in the present case,
14183: culpable.
14184: 
14185: The above judgement is complete evidence that we are accustomed to
14186: think that reason is not affected by sensuous conditions, that in it no
14187: change takes place—although its phenomena, in other words, the mode in
14188: which it appears in its effects, are subject to change—that in it no
14189: preceding state determines the following, and, consequently, that it
14190: does not form a member of the series of sensuous conditions which
14191: necessitate phenomena according to natural laws. Reason is present and
14192: the same in all human actions and at all times; but it does not itself
14193: exist in time, and therefore does not enter upon any state in which it
14194: did not formerly exist. It is, relatively to new states or conditions,
14195: determining, but not determinable. Hence we cannot ask: “Why did not
14196: reason determine itself in a different manner?” The question ought to
14197: be thus stated: “Why did not reason employ its power of causality to
14198: determine certain phenomena in a different manner?” But this is a
14199: question which admits of no answer. For a different intelligible
14200: character would have exhibited a different empirical character; and,
14201: when we say that, in spite of the course which his whole former life
14202: has taken, the offender could have refrained from uttering the
14203: falsehood, this means merely that the act was subject to the power and
14204: authority—permissive or prohibitive—of reason. Now, reason is not
14205: subject in its causality to any conditions of phenomena or of time; and
14206: a difference in time may produce a difference in the relation of
14207: phenomena to each other—for these are not things and therefore not
14208: causes in themselves—but it cannot produce any difference in the
14209: relation in which the action stands to the faculty of reason.
14210: 
14211: Thus, then, in our investigation into free actions and the causal power
14212: which produced them, we arrive at an intelligible cause, beyond which,
14213: however, we cannot go; although we can recognize that it is free, that
14214: is, independent of all sensuous conditions, and that, in this way, it
14215: may be the sensuously unconditioned condition of phenomena. But for
14216: what reason the intelligible character generates such and such
14217: phenomena and exhibits such and such an empirical character under
14218: certain circumstances, it is beyond the power of our reason to decide.
14219: The question is as much above the power and the sphere of reason as the
14220: following would be: “Why does the transcendental object of our external
14221: sensuous intuition allow of no other form than that of intuition in
14222: space?” But the problem, which we were called upon to solve, does not
14223: require us to entertain any such questions. The problem was merely
14224: this—whether freedom and natural necessity can exist without opposition
14225: in the same action. To this question we have given a sufficient answer;
14226: for we have shown that, as the former stands in a relation to a
14227: different kind of condition from those of the latter, the law of the
14228: one does not affect the law of the other and that, consequently, both
14229: can exist together in independence of and without interference with
14230: each other.
14231: 
14232: The reader must be careful to remark that my intention in the above
14233: remarks has not been to prove the actual existence of freedom, as a
14234: faculty in which resides the cause of certain sensuous phenomena. For,
14235: not to mention that such an argument would not have a transcendental
14236: character, nor have been limited to the discussion of pure
14237: conceptions—all attempts at inferring from experience what cannot be
14238: cogitated in accordance with its laws, must ever be unsuccessful. Nay,
14239: more, I have not even aimed at demonstrating the possibility of
14240: freedom; for this too would have been a vain endeavour, inasmuch as it
14241: is beyond the power of the mind to cognize the possibility of a reality
14242: or of a causal power by the aid of mere à priori conceptions. Freedom
14243: has been considered in the foregoing remarks only as a transcendental
14244: idea, by means of which reason aims at originating a series of
14245: conditions in the world of phenomena with the help of that which is
14246: sensuously unconditioned, involving itself, however, in an antinomy
14247: with the laws which itself prescribes for the conduct of the
14248: understanding. That this antinomy is based upon a mere illusion, and
14249: that nature and freedom are at least not opposed—this was the only
14250: thing in our power to prove, and the question which it was our task to
14251: solve.
14252: 
14253: IV. Solution of the Cosmological Idea of the Totality of the Dependence
14254: of Phenomenal Existences
14255: 
14256: In the preceding remarks, we considered the changes in the world of
14257: sense as constituting a dynamical series, in which each member is
14258: subordinated to another—as its cause. Our present purpose is to avail
14259: ourselves of this series of states or conditions as a guide to an
14260: existence which may be the highest condition of all changeable
14261: phenomena, that is, to a necessary being. Our endeavour to reach, not
14262: the unconditioned causality, but the unconditioned existence, of
14263: substance. The series before us is therefore a series of conceptions,
14264: and not of intuitions (in which the one intuition is the condition of
14265: the other).
14266: 
14267: But it is evident that, as all phenomena are subject to change and
14268: conditioned in their existence, the series of dependent existences
14269: cannot embrace an unconditioned member, the existence of which would be
14270: absolutely necessary. It follows that, if phenomena were things in
14271: themselves, and—as an immediate consequence from this
14272: supposition—condition and conditioned belonged to the same series of
14273: phenomena, the existence of a necessary being, as the condition of the
14274: existence of sensuous phenomena, would be perfectly impossible.
14275: 
14276: An important distinction, however, exists between the dynamical and the
14277: mathematical regress. The latter is engaged solely with the combination
14278: of parts into a whole, or with the division of a whole into its parts;
14279: and therefore are the conditions of its series parts of the series, and
14280: to be consequently regarded as homogeneous, and for this reason, as
14281: consisting, without exception, of phenomena. If the former regress, on
14282: the contrary, the aim of which is not to establish the possibility of
14283: an unconditioned whole consisting of given parts, or of an
14284: unconditioned part of a given whole, but to demonstrate the possibility
14285: of the deduction of a certain state from its cause, or of the
14286: contingent existence of substance from that which exists necessarily,
14287: it is not requisite that the condition should form part of an empirical
14288: series along with the conditioned.
14289: 
14290: In the case of the apparent antinomy with which we are at present
14291: dealing, there exists a way of escape from the difficulty; for it is
14292: not impossible that both of the contradictory statements may be true in
14293: different relations. All sensuous phenomena may be contingent, and
14294: consequently possess only an empirically conditioned existence, and yet
14295: there may also exist a non-empirical condition of the whole series, or,
14296: in other words, a necessary being. For this necessary being, as an
14297: intelligible condition, would not form a member—not even the highest
14298: member—of the series; the whole world of sense would be left in its
14299: empirically determined existence uninterfered with and uninfluenced.
14300: This would also form a ground of distinction between the modes of
14301: solution employed for the third and fourth antinomies. For, while in
14302: the consideration of freedom in the former antinomy, the thing
14303: itself—the cause (substantia phaenomenon)—was regarded as belonging to
14304: the series of conditions, and only its causality to the intelligible
14305: world—we are obliged in the present case to cogitate this necessary
14306: being as purely intelligible and as existing entirely apart from the
14307: world of sense (as an ens extramundanum); for otherwise it would be
14308: subject to the phenomenal law of contingency and dependence.
14309:
