14310: In relation to the present problem, therefore, the regulative principle
14311: of reason is that everything in the sensuous world possesses an
14312: empirically conditioned existence—that no property of the sensuous
14313: world possesses unconditioned necessity—that we are bound to expect,
14314: and, so far as is possible, to seek for the empirical condition of
14315: every member in the series of conditions—and that there is no
14316: sufficient reason to justify us in deducing any existence from a
14317: condition which lies out of and beyond the empirical series, or in
14318: regarding any existence as independent and self-subsistent; although
14319: this should not prevent us from recognizing the possibility of the
14320: whole series being based upon a being which is intelligible, and for
14321: this reason free from all empirical conditions.
14322: 
14323: But it has been far from my intention, in these remarks, to prove the
14324: existence of this unconditioned and necessary being, or even to
14325: evidence the possibility of a purely intelligible condition of the
14326: existence of all sensuous phenomena. As bounds were set to reason, to
14327: prevent it from leaving the guiding thread of empirical conditions and
14328: losing itself in transcendent theories which are incapable of concrete
14329: presentation; so it was my purpose, on the other hand, to set bounds to
14330: the law of the purely empirical understanding, and to protest against
14331: any attempts on its part at deciding on the possibility of things, or
14332: declaring the existence of the intelligible to be impossible, merely on
14333: the ground that it is not available for the explanation and exposition
14334: of phenomena. It has been shown, at the same time, that the contingency
14335: of all the phenomena of nature and their empirical conditions is quite
14336: consistent with the arbitrary hypothesis of a necessary, although
14337: purely intelligible condition, that no real contradiction exists
14338: between them and that, consequently, both may be true. The existence of
14339: such an absolutely necessary being may be impossible; but this can
14340: never be demonstrated from the universal contingency and dependence of
14341: sensuous phenomena, nor from the principle which forbids us to
14342: discontinue the series at some member of it, or to seek for its cause
14343: in some sphere of existence beyond the world of nature. Reason goes its
14344: way in the empirical world, and follows, too, its peculiar path in the
14345: sphere of the transcendental.
14346: 
14347: The sensuous world contains nothing but phenomena, which are mere
14348: representations, and always sensuously conditioned; things in
14349: themselves are not, and cannot be, objects to us. It is not to be
14350: wondered at, therefore, that we are not justified in leaping from some
14351: member of an empirical series beyond the world of sense, as if
14352: empirical representations were things in themselves, existing apart
14353: from their transcendental ground in the human mind, and the cause of
14354: whose existence may be sought out of the empirical series. This would
14355: certainly be the case with contingent things; but it cannot be with
14356: mere representations of things, the contingency of which is itself
14357: merely a phenomenon and can relate to no other regress than that which
14358: determines phenomena, that is, the empirical. But to cogitate an
14359: intelligible ground of phenomena, as free, moreover, from the
14360: contingency of the latter, conflicts neither with the unlimited nature
14361: of the empirical regress, nor with the complete contingency of
14362: phenomena. And the demonstration of this was the only thing necessary
14363: for the solution of this apparent antinomy. For if the condition of
14364: every conditioned—as regards its existence—is sensuous, and for this
14365: reason a part of the same series, it must be itself conditioned, as was
14366: shown in the antithesis of the fourth antinomy. The embarrassments into
14367: which a reason, which postulates the unconditioned, necessarily falls,
14368: must, therefore, continue to exist; or the unconditioned must be placed
14369: in the sphere of the intelligible. In this way, its necessity does not
14370: require, nor does it even permit, the presence of an empirical
14371: condition: and it is, consequently, unconditionally necessary.
14372: 
14373: The empirical employment of reason is not affected by the assumption of
14374: a purely intelligible being; it continues its operations on the
14375: principle of the contingency of all phenomena, proceeding from
14376: empirical conditions to still higher and higher conditions, themselves
14377: empirical. Just as little does this regulative principle exclude the
14378: assumption of an intelligible cause, when the question regards merely
14379: the pure employment of reason—in relation to ends or aims. For, in this
14380: case, an intelligible cause signifies merely the transcendental and to
14381: us unknown ground of the possibility of sensuous phenomena, and its
14382: existence, necessary and independent of all sensuous conditions, is not
14383: inconsistent with the contingency of phenomena, or with the unlimited
14384: possibility of regress which exists in the series of empirical
14385: conditions.
14386: 
14387: Concluding Remarks on the Antinomy of Pure Reason.
14388: 
14389: So long as the object of our rational conceptions is the totality of
14390: conditions in the world of phenomena, and the satisfaction, from this
14391: source, of the requirements of reason, so long are our ideas
14392: transcendental and cosmological. But when we set the
14393: unconditioned—which is the aim of all our inquiries—in a sphere which
14394: lies out of the world of sense and possible experience, our ideas
14395: become transcendent. They are then not merely serviceable towards the
14396: completion of the exercise of reason (which remains an idea, never
14397: executed, but always to be pursued); they detach themselves completely
14398: from experience and construct for themselves objects, the material of
14399: which has not been presented by experience, and the objective reality
14400: of which is not based upon the completion of the empirical series, but
14401: upon pure à priori conceptions. The intelligible object of these
14402: transcendent ideas may be conceded, as a transcendental object. But we
14403: cannot cogitate it as a thing determinable by certain distinct
14404: predicates relating to its internal nature, for it has no connection
14405: with empirical conceptions; nor are we justified in affirming the
14406: existence of any such object. It is, consequently, a mere product of
14407: the mind alone. Of all the cosmological ideas, however, it is that
14408: occasioning the fourth antinomy which compels us to venture upon this
14409: step. For the existence of phenomena, always conditioned and never
14410: self-subsistent, requires us to look for an object different from
14411: phenomena—an intelligible object, with which all contingency must
14412: cease. But, as we have allowed ourselves to assume the existence of a
14413: self-subsistent reality out of the field of experience, and are
14414: therefore obliged to regard phenomena as merely a contingent mode of
14415: representing intelligible objects employed by beings which are
14416: themselves intelligences—no other course remains for us than to follow
14417: analogy and employ the same mode in forming some conception of
14418: intelligible things, of which we have not the least knowledge, which
14419: nature taught us to use in the formation of empirical conceptions.
14420: Experience made us acquainted with the contingent. But we are at
14421: present engaged in the discussion of things which are not objects of
14422: experience; and must, therefore, deduce our knowledge of them from that
14423: which is necessary absolutely and in itself, that is, from pure
14424: conceptions. Hence the first step which we take out of the world of
14425: sense obliges us to begin our system of new cognition with the
14426: investigation of a necessary being, and to deduce from our conceptions
14427: of it all our conceptions of intelligible things. This we propose to
14428: attempt in the following chapter.
14429: 
14430: Chapter III. The Ideal of Pure Reason
14431: 
14432: Section I. Of the Ideal in General
14433: 
14434: We have seen that pure conceptions do not present objects to the mind,
14435: except under sensuous conditions; because the conditions of objective
14436: reality do not exist in these conceptions, which contain, in fact,
14437: nothing but the mere form of thought. They may, however, when applied
14438: to phenomena, be presented in concreto; for it is phenomena that
14439: present to them the materials for the formation of empirical
14440: conceptions, which are nothing more than concrete forms of the
14441: conceptions of the understanding. But ideas are still further removed
14442: from objective reality than categories; for no phenomenon can ever
14443: present them to the human mind in concreto. They contain a certain
14444: perfection, attainable by no possible empirical cognition; and they
14445: give to reason a systematic unity, to which the unity of experience
14446: attempts to approximate, but can never completely attain.
14447: 
14448: But still further removed than the idea from objective reality is the
14449: Ideal, by which term I understand the idea, not in concreto, but in
14450: individuo—as an individual thing, determinable or determined by the
14451: idea alone. The idea of humanity in its complete perfection supposes
14452: not only the advancement of all the powers and faculties, which
14453: constitute our conception of human nature, to a complete attainment of
14454: their final aims, but also everything which is requisite for the
14455: complete determination of the idea; for of all contradictory
14456: predicates, only one can conform with the idea of the perfect man. What
14457: I have termed an ideal was in Plato’s philosophy an idea of the divine
14458: mind—an individual object present to its pure intuition, the most
14459: perfect of every kind of possible beings, and the archetype of all
14460: phenomenal existences.
14461: 
14462: Without rising to these speculative heights, we are bound to confess
14463: that human reason contains not only ideas, but ideals, which possess,
14464: not, like those of Plato, creative, but certainly practical power—as
14465: regulative principles, and form the basis of the perfectibility of
14466: certain actions. Moral conceptions are not perfectly pure conceptions
14467: of reason, because an empirical element—of pleasure or pain—lies at the
14468: foundation of them. In relation, however, to the principle, whereby
14469: reason sets bounds to a freedom which is in itself without law, and
14470: consequently when we attend merely to their form, they may be
14471: considered as pure conceptions of reason. Virtue and wisdom in their
14472: perfect purity are ideas. But the wise man of the Stoics is an ideal,
14473: that is to say, a human being existing only in thought and in complete
14474: conformity with the idea of wisdom. As the idea provides a rule, so the
14475: ideal serves as an archetype for the perfect and complete determination
14476: of the copy. Thus the conduct of this wise and divine man serves us as
14477: a standard of action, with which we may compare and judge ourselves,
14478: which may help us to reform ourselves, although the perfection it
14479: demands can never be attained by us. Although we cannot concede
14480: objective reality to these ideals, they are not to be considered as
14481: chimeras; on the contrary, they provide reason with a standard, which
14482: enables it to estimate, by comparison, the degree of incompleteness in
14483: the objects presented to it. But to aim at realizing the ideal in an
14484: example in the world of experience—to describe, for instance, the
14485: character of the perfectly wise man in a romance—is impracticable. Nay
14486: more, there is something absurd in the attempt; and the result must be
14487: little edifying, as the natural limitations, which are continually
14488: breaking in upon the perfection and completeness of the idea, destroy
14489: the illusion in the story and throw an air of suspicion even on what is
14490: good in the idea, which hence appears fictitious and unreal.
14491: 
14492: Such is the constitution of the ideal of reason, which is always based
14493: upon determinate conceptions, and serves as a rule and a model for
14494: limitation or of criticism. Very different is the nature of the ideals
14495: of the imagination. Of these it is impossible to present an
14496: intelligible conception; they are a kind of monogram, drawn according
14497: to no determinate rule, and forming rather a vague picture—the
14498: production of many diverse experiences—than a determinate image. Such
14499: are the ideals which painters and physiognomists profess to have in
14500: their minds, and which can serve neither as a model for production nor
14501: as a standard for appreciation. They may be termed, though improperly,
14502: sensuous ideals, as they are declared to be models of certain possible
14503: empirical intuitions. They cannot, however, furnish rules or standards
14504: for explanation or examination.
14505: 
14506: In its ideals, reason aims at complete and perfect determination
14507: according to à priori rules; and hence it cogitates an object, which
14508: must be completely determinable in conformity with principles, although
14509: all empirical conditions are absent, and the conception of the object
14510: is on this account transcendent.
14511: 
14512: Section II. Of the Transcendental Ideal (Prototypon Trancendentale)
14513: 
14514: Every conception is, in relation to that which is not contained in it,
14515: undetermined and subject to the principle of determinability. This
14516: principle is that, of every two contradictorily opposed predicates,
14517: only one can belong to a conception. It is a purely logical principle,
14518: itself based upon the principle of contradiction; inasmuch as it makes
14519: complete abstraction of the content and attends merely to the logical
14520: form of the cognition.
14521: 
14522: But again, everything, as regards its possibility, is also subject to
14523: the principle of complete determination, according to which one of all
14524: the possible contradictory predicates of things must belong to it. This
14525: principle is not based merely upon that of contradiction; for, in
14526: addition to the relation between two contradictory predicates, it
14527: regards everything as standing in a relation to the sum of
14528: possibilities, as the sum total of all predicates of things, and, while
14529: presupposing this sum as an à priori condition, presents to the mind
14530: everything as receiving the possibility of its individual existence
14531: from the relation it bears to, and the share it possesses in, the
14532: aforesaid sum of possibilities.[64] The principle of complete
14533: determination relates the content and not to the logical form. It is
14534: the principle of the synthesis of all the predicates which are required
14535: to constitute the complete conception of a thing, and not a mere
14536: principle analytical representation, which enounces that one of two
14537: contradictory predicates must belong to a conception. It contains,
14538: moreover, a transcendental presupposition—that, namely, of the material
14539: for all possibility, which must contain à priori the data for this or
14540: that particular possibility.
14541: 
14542:  [64] Thus this principle declares everything to possess a relation to
14543:  a common correlate—the sum-total of possibility, which, if discovered
14544:  to exist in the idea of one individual thing, would establish the
14545:  affinity of all possible things, from the identity of the ground of
14546:  their complete determination. The determinability of every conception
14547:  is subordinate to the universality (Allgemeinheit, universalitas) of
14548:  the principle of excluded middle; the determination of a thing to the
14549:  totality (Allheit, universitas) of all possible predicates.
14550: 
14551: 
14552: The proposition, everything which exists is completely determined,
14553: means not only that one of every pair of given contradictory
14554: attributes, but that one of all possible attributes, is always
14555: predicable of the thing; in it the predicates are not merely compared
14556: logically with each other, but the thing itself is transcendentally
14557: compared with the sum-total of all possible predicates. The proposition
14558: is equivalent to saying: “To attain to a complete knowledge of a thing,
14559: it is necessary to possess a knowledge of everything that is possible,
14560: and to determine it thereby in a positive or negative manner.” The
14561: conception of complete determination is consequently a conception which
14562: cannot be presented in its totality in concreto, and is therefore based
14563: upon an idea, which has its seat in the reason—the faculty which
14564: prescribes to the understanding the laws of its harmonious and perfect
14565: exercise.
14566: 
14567: Now, although this idea of the sum-total of all possibility, in so far
14568: as it forms the condition of the complete determination of everything,
14569: is itself undetermined in relation to the predicates which may
14570: constitute this sum-total, and we cogitate in it merely the sum-total
14571: of all possible predicates—we nevertheless find, upon closer
14572: examination, that this idea, as a primitive conception of the mind,
14573: excludes a large number of predicates—those deduced and those
14574: irreconcilable with others, and that it is evolved as a conception
14575: completely determined à priori. Thus it becomes the conception of an
14576: individual object, which is completely determined by and through the
14577: mere idea, and must consequently be termed an ideal of pure reason.
14578: 
14579: When we consider all possible predicates, not merely logically, but
14580: transcendentally, that is to say, with reference to the content which
14581: may be cogitated as existing in them à priori, we shall find that some
14582: indicate a being, others merely a non-being. The logical negation
14583: expressed in the word not does not properly belong to a conception, but
14584: only to the relation of one conception to another in a judgement, and
14585: is consequently quite insufficient to present to the mind the content
14586: of a conception. The expression not mortal does not indicate that a
14587: non-being is cogitated in the object; it does not concern the content
14588: at all. A transcendental negation, on the contrary, indicates non-being
14589: in itself, and is opposed to transcendental affirmation, the conception
14590: of which of itself expresses a being. Hence this affirmation indicates
14591: a reality, because in and through it objects are considered to be
14592: something—to be things; while the opposite negation, on the other hand,
14593: indicates a mere want, or privation, or absence, and, where such
14594: negations alone are attached to a representation, the non-existence of
14595: anything corresponding to the representation.
14596: 
14597: Now a negation cannot be cogitated as determined, without cogitating at
14598: the same time the opposite affirmation. The man born blind has not the
14599: least notion of darkness, because he has none of light; the vagabond
14600: knows nothing of poverty, because he has never known what it is to be
14601: in comfort;[65] the ignorant man has no conception of his ignorance,
14602: because he has no conception of knowledge. All conceptions of negatives
14603: are accordingly derived or deduced conceptions; and realities contain
14604: the data, and, so to speak, the material or transcendental content of
14605: the possibility and complete determination of all things.
14606: 
14607:  [65] The investigations and calculations of astronomers have taught us
14608:  much that is wonderful; but the most important lesson we have received
14609:  from them is the discovery of the abyss of our ignorance in relation
14610:  to the universe—an ignorance the magnitude of which reason, without
14611:  the information thus derived, could never have conceived. This
14612:  discovery of our deficiencies must produce a great change in the
14613:  determination of the aims of human reason.
14614: 
14615: 
14616: If, therefore, a transcendental substratum lies at the foundation of
14617: the complete determination of things—a substratum which is to form the
14618: fund from which all possible predicates of things are to be supplied,
14619: this substratum cannot be anything else than the idea of a sum-total of
14620: reality (omnitudo realitatis). In this view, negations are nothing but
14621: limitations—a term which could not, with propriety, be applied to them,
14622: if the unlimited (the all) did not form the true basis of our
14623: conception.
14624: 
14625: This conception of a sum-total of reality is the conception of a thing
14626: in itself, regarded as completely determined; and the conception of an
14627: ens realissimum is the conception of an individual being, inasmuch as
14628: it is determined by that predicate of all possible contradictory
14629: predicates, which indicates and belongs to being. It is, therefore, a
14630: transcendental ideal which forms the basis of the complete
14631: determination of everything that exists, and is the highest material
14632: condition of its possibility—a condition on which must rest the
14633: cogitation of all objects with respect to their content. Nay, more,
14634: this ideal is the only proper ideal of which the human mind is capable;
14635: because in this case alone a general conception of a thing is
14636: completely determined by and through itself, and cognized as the
14637: representation of an individuum.
14638: 
14639: The logical determination of a conception is based upon a disjunctive
14640: syllogism, the major of which contains the logical division of the
14641: extent of a general conception, the minor limits this extent to a
14642: certain part, while the conclusion determines the conception by this
14643: part. The general conception of a reality cannot be divided à priori,
14644: because, without the aid of experience, we cannot know any determinate
14645: kinds of reality, standing under the former as the genus. The
14646: transcendental principle of the complete determination of all things is
14647: therefore merely the representation of the sum-total of all reality; it
14648: is not a conception which is the genus of all predicates under itself,
14649: but one which comprehends them all within itself. The complete
14650: determination of a thing is consequently based upon the limitation of
14651: this total of reality, so much being predicated of the thing, while all
14652: that remains over is excluded—a procedure which is in exact agreement
14653: with that of the disjunctive syllogism and the determination of the
14654: objects in the conclusion by one of the members of the division. It
14655: follows that reason, in laying the transcendental ideal at the
14656: foundation of its determination of all possible things, takes a course
14657: in exact analogy with that which it pursues in disjunctive syllogisms—a
14658: proposition which formed the basis of the systematic division of all
14659: transcendental ideas, according to which they are produced in complete
14660: parallelism with the three modes of syllogistic reasoning employed by
14661: the human mind.
14662: 
14663: It is self-evident that reason, in cogitating the necessary complete
14664: determination of things, does not presuppose the existence of a being
14665: corresponding to its ideal, but merely the idea of the ideal—for the
14666: purpose of deducing from the unconditional totality of complete
14667: determination, The ideal is therefore the prototype of all things,
14668: which, as defective copies (ectypa), receive from it the material of
14669: their possibility, and approximate to it more or less, though it is
14670: impossible that they can ever attain to its perfection.
14671: 
14672: The possibility of things must therefore be regarded as derived—except
14673: that of the thing which contains in itself all reality, which must be
14674: considered to be primitive and original. For all negations—and they are
14675: the only predicates by means of which all other things can be
14676: distinguished from the ens realissimum—are mere limitations of a
14677: greater and a higher—nay, the highest reality; and they consequently
14678: presuppose this reality, and are, as regards their content, derived
14679: from it. The manifold nature of things is only an infinitely various
14680: mode of limiting the conception of the highest reality, which is their
14681: common substratum; just as all figures are possible only as different
14682: modes of limiting infinite space. The object of the ideal of reason—an
14683: object existing only in reason itself—is also termed the primal being
14684: (ens originarium); as having no existence superior to him, the supreme
14685: being (ens summum); and as being the condition of all other beings,
14686: which rank under it, the being of all beings (ens entium). But none of
14687: these terms indicate the objective relation of an actually existing
14688: object to other things, but merely that of an idea to conceptions; and
14689: all our investigations into this subject still leave us in perfect
14690: uncertainty with regard to the existence of this being.
14691: 
14692: A primal being cannot be said to consist of many other beings with an
14693: existence which is derivative, for the latter presuppose the former,
14694: and therefore cannot be constitutive parts of it. It follows that the
14695: ideal of the primal being must be cogitated as simple.
14696: 
14697: The deduction of the possibility of all other things from this primal
14698: being cannot, strictly speaking, be considered as a limitation, or as a
14699: kind of division of its reality; for this would be regarding the primal
14700: being as a mere aggregate—which has been shown to be impossible,
14701: although it was so represented in our first rough sketch. The highest
14702: reality must be regarded rather as the ground than as the sum-total of
14703: the possibility of all things, and the manifold nature of things be
14704: based, not upon the limitation of the primal being itself, but upon the
14705: complete series of effects which flow from it. And thus all our powers
14706: of sense, as well as all phenomenal reality, may be with propriety
14707: regarded as belonging to this series of effects, while they could not
14708: have formed parts of the idea, considered as an aggregate. Pursuing
14709: this track, and hypostatizing this idea, we shall find ourselves
14710: authorized to determine our notion of the Supreme Being by means of the
14711: mere conception of a highest reality, as one, simple, all-sufficient,
14712: eternal, and so on—in one word, to determine it in its unconditioned
14713: completeness by the aid of every possible predicate. The conception of
14714: such a being is the conception of God in its transcendental sense, and
14715: thus the ideal of pure reason is the object-matter of a transcendental
14716: theology.
14717: 
14718: But, by such an employment of the transcendental idea, we should be
14719: over stepping the limits of its validity and purpose. For reason placed
14720: it, as the conception of all reality, at the basis of the complete
14721: determination of things, without requiring that this conception be
14722: regarded as the conception of an objective existence. Such an existence
14723: would be purely fictitious, and the hypostatizing of the content of the
14724: idea into an ideal, as an individual being, is a step perfectly
14725: unauthorized. Nay, more, we are not even called upon to assume the
14726: possibility of such an hypothesis, as none of the deductions drawn from
14727: such an ideal would affect the complete determination of things in
14728: general—for the sake of which alone is the idea necessary.
14729: 
14730: It is not sufficient to circumscribe the procedure and the dialectic of
14731: reason; we must also endeavour to discover the sources of this
14732: dialectic, that we may have it in our power to give a rational
14733: explanation of this illusion, as a phenomenon of the human mind. For
14734: the ideal, of which we are at present speaking, is based, not upon an
14735: arbitrary, but upon a natural, idea. The question hence arises: How
14736: happens it that reason regards the possibility of all things as deduced
14737: from a single possibility, that, to wit, of the highest reality, and
14738: presupposes this as existing in an individual and primal being?
14739: 
14740: The answer is ready; it is at once presented by the procedure of
14741: transcendental analytic. The possibility of sensuous objects is a
14742: relation of these objects to thought, in which something (the empirical
14743: form) may be cogitated à priori; while that which constitutes the
14744: matter—the reality of the phenomenon (that element which corresponds to
14745: sensation)—must be given from without, as otherwise it could not even
14746: be cogitated by, nor could its possibility be presentable to the mind.
14747: Now, a sensuous object is completely determined, when it has been
14748: compared with all phenomenal predicates, and represented by means of
14749: these either positively or negatively. But, as that which constitutes
14750: the thing itself—the real in a phenomenon, must be given, and that, in
14751: which the real of all phenomena is given, is experience, one, sole, and
14752: all-embracing—the material of the possibility of all sensuous objects
14753: must be presupposed as given in a whole, and it is upon the limitation
14754: of this whole that the possibility of all empirical objects, their
14755: distinction from each other and their complete determination, are
14756: based. Now, no other objects are presented to us besides sensuous
14757: objects, and these can be given only in connection with a possible
14758: experience; it follows that a thing is not an object to us, unless it
14759: presupposes the whole or sum-total of empirical reality as the
14760: condition of its possibility. Now, a natural illusion leads us to
14761: consider this principle, which is valid only of sensuous objects, as
14762: valid with regard to things in general. And thus we are induced to hold
14763: the empirical principle of our conceptions of the possibility of
14764: things, as phenomena, by leaving out this limitative condition, to be a
14765: transcendental principle of the possibility of things in general.
14766: 
14767: We proceed afterwards to hypostatize this idea of the sum-total of all
14768: reality, by changing the distributive unity of the empirical exercise
14769: of the understanding into the collective unity of an empirical whole—a
14770: dialectical illusion, and by cogitating this whole or sum of experience
14771: as an individual thing, containing in itself all empirical reality.
14772: This individual thing or being is then, by means of the above-mentioned
14773: transcendental subreption, substituted for our notion of a thing which
14774: stands at the head of the possibility of all things, the real
14775: conditions of whose complete determination it presents.[66]
14776: 
14777:  [66] This ideal of the ens realissimum—although merely a mental
14778:  representation—is first objectivized, that is, has an objective
14779:  existence attributed to it, then hypostatized, and finally, by the
14780:  natural progress of reason to the completion of unity, personified, as
14781:  we shall show presently. For the regulative unity of experience is not
14782:  based upon phenomena themselves, but upon the connection of the
14783:  variety of phenomena by the understanding in a consciousness, and thus
14784:  the unity of the supreme reality and the complete determinability of
14785:  all things, seem to reside in a supreme understanding, and,
14786:  consequently, in a conscious intelligence.
14787: 
14788: Section III. Of the Arguments employed by Speculative Reason in Proof
14789: of the Existence of a Supreme Being
14790: 
14791: Notwithstanding the pressing necessity which reason feels, to form some
14792: presupposition that shall serve the understanding as a proper basis for
14793: the complete determination of its conceptions, the idealistic and
14794: factitious nature of such a presupposition is too evident to allow
14795: reason for a moment to persuade itself into a belief of the objective
14796: existence of a mere creation of its own thought. But there are other
14797: considerations which compel reason to seek out some resting place in
14798: the regress from the conditioned to the unconditioned, which is not
14799: given as an actual existence from the mere conception of it, although
14800: it alone can give completeness to the series of conditions. And this is
14801: the natural course of every human reason, even of the most uneducated,
14802: although the path at first entered it does not always continue to
14803: follow. It does not begin from conceptions, but from common experience,
14804: and requires a basis in actual existence. But this basis is insecure,
14805: unless it rests upon the immovable rock of the absolutely necessary.
14806: And this foundation is itself unworthy of trust, if it leave under and
14807: above it empty space, if it do not fill all, and leave no room for a
14808: why or a wherefore, if it be not, in one word, infinite in its reality.
14809: 
14810: If we admit the existence of some one thing, whatever it may be, we
14811: must also admit that there is something which exists necessarily. For
14812: what is contingent exists only under the condition of some other thing,
14813: which is its cause; and from this we must go on to conclude the
14814: existence of a cause which is not contingent, and which consequently
14815: exists necessarily and unconditionally. Such is the argument by which
14816: reason justifies its advances towards a primal being.
14817: 
14818: Now reason looks round for the conception of a being that may be
14819: admitted, without inconsistency, to be worthy of the attribute of
14820: absolute necessity, not for the purpose of inferring à priori, from the
14821: conception of such a being, its objective existence (for if reason
14822: allowed itself to take this course, it would not require a basis in
14823: given and actual existence, but merely the support of pure
14824: conceptions), but for the purpose of discovering, among all our
14825: conceptions of possible things, that conception which possesses no
14826: element inconsistent with the idea of absolute necessity. For that
14827: there must be some absolutely necessary existence, it regards as a
14828: truth already established. Now, if it can remove every existence
14829: incapable of supporting the attribute of absolute necessity, excepting
14830: one—this must be the absolutely necessary being, whether its necessity
14831: is comprehensible by us, that is, deducible from the conception of it
14832: alone, or not.
14833: 
14834: Now that, the conception of which contains a therefore to every
14835: wherefore, which is not defective in any respect whatever, which is
14836: all-sufficient as a condition, seems to be the being of which we can
14837: justly predicate absolute necessity—for this reason, that, possessing
14838: the conditions of all that is possible, it does not and cannot itself
14839: require any condition. And thus it satisfies, in one respect at least,
14840: the requirements of the conception of absolute necessity. In this view,
14841: it is superior to all other conceptions, which, as deficient and
14842: incomplete, do not possess the characteristic of independence of all
14843: higher conditions. It is true that we cannot infer from this that what
14844: does not contain in itself the supreme and complete condition—the
14845: condition of all other things—must possess only a conditioned
14846: existence; but as little can we assert the contrary, for this supposed
14847: being does not possess the only characteristic which can enable reason
14848: to cognize by means of an à priori conception the unconditioned and
14849: necessary nature of its existence.
14850: 
14851: The conception of an ens realissimum is that which best agrees with the
14852: conception of an unconditioned and necessary being. The former
14853: conception does not satisfy all the requirements of the latter; but we
14854: have no choice, we are obliged to adhere to it, for we find that we
14855: cannot do without the existence of a necessary being; and even although
14856: we admit it, we find it out of our power to discover in the whole
14857: sphere of possibility any being that can advance well-grounded claims
14858: to such a distinction.
14859: 
14860: The following is, therefore, the natural course of human reason. It
14861: begins by persuading itself of the existence of some necessary being.
14862: In this being it recognizes the characteristics of unconditioned
14863: existence. It then seeks the conception of that which is independent of
14864: all conditions, and finds it in that which is itself the sufficient
14865: condition of all other things—in other words, in that which contains
14866: all reality. But the unlimited all is an absolute unity, and is
14867: conceived by the mind as a being one and supreme; and thus reason
14868: concludes that the Supreme Being, as the primal basis of all things,
14869: possesses an existence which is absolutely necessary.
14870: 
14871: This conception must be regarded as in some degree satisfactory, if we
14872: admit the existence of a necessary being, and consider that there
14873: exists a necessity for a definite and final answer to these questions.
14874: In such a case, we cannot make a better choice, or rather we have no
14875: choice at all, but feel ourselves obliged to declare in favour of the
14876: absolute unity of complete reality, as the highest source of the
14877: possibility of things. But if there exists no motive for coming to a
14878: definite conclusion, and we may leave the question unanswered till we
14879: have fully weighed both sides—in other words, when we are merely called
14880: upon to decide how much we happen to know about the question, and how
14881: much we merely flatter ourselves that we know—the above conclusion does
14882: not appear to be so great advantage, but, on the contrary, seems
14883: defective in the grounds upon which it is supported.
14884: 
14885: For, admitting the truth of all that has been said, that, namely, the
14886: inference from a given existence (my own, for example) to the existence
14887: of an unconditioned and necessary being is valid and unassailable;
14888: that, in the second place, we must consider a being which contains all
14889: reality, and consequently all the conditions of other things, to be
14890: absolutely unconditioned; and admitting too, that we have thus
14891: discovered the conception of a thing to which may be attributed,
14892: without inconsistency, absolute necessity—it does not follow from all
14893: this that the conception of a limited being, in which the supreme
14894: reality does not reside, is therefore incompatible with the idea of
14895: absolute necessity. For, although I do not discover the element of the
14896: unconditioned in the conception of such a being—an element which is
14897: manifestly existent in the sum-total of all conditions—I am not
14898: entitled to conclude that its existence is therefore conditioned; just
14899: as I am not entitled to affirm, in a hypothetical syllogism, that where
14900: a certain condition does not exist (in the present, completeness, as
14901: far as pure conceptions are concerned), the conditioned does not exist
14902: either. On the contrary, we are free to consider all limited beings as
14903: likewise unconditionally necessary, although we are unable to infer
14904: this from the general conception which we have of them. Thus conducted,
14905: this argument is incapable of giving us the least notion of the
14906: properties of a necessary being, and must be in every respect without
14907: result.
14908: 
14909: This argument continues, however, to possess a weight and an authority,
14910: which, in spite of its objective insufficiency, it has never been
14911: divested of. For, granting that certain responsibilities lie upon us,
14912: which, as based on the ideas of reason, deserve to be respected and
14913: submitted to, although they are incapable of a real or practical
14914: application to our nature, or, in other words, would be
14915: responsibilities without motives, except upon the supposition of a
14916: Supreme Being to give effect and influence to the practical laws: in
14917: such a case we should be bound to obey our conceptions, which, although
14918: objectively insufficient, do, according to the standard of reason,
14919: preponderate over and are superior to any claims that may be advanced
14920: from any other quarter. The equilibrium of doubt would in this case be
14921: destroyed by a practical addition; indeed, Reason would be compelled to
14922: condemn herself, if she refused to comply with the demands of the
14923: judgement, no superior to which we know—however defective her
14924: understanding of the grounds of these demands might be.
14925: 
14926: This argument, although in fact transcendental, inasmuch as it rests
14927: upon the intrinsic insufficiency of the contingent, is so simple and
14928: natural, that the commonest understanding can appreciate its value. We
14929: see things around us change, arise, and pass away; they, or their
14930: condition, must therefore have a cause. The same demand must again be
14931: made of the cause itself—as a datum of experience. Now it is natural
14932: that we should place the highest causality just where we place supreme
14933: causality, in that being, which contains the conditions of all possible
14934: effects, and the conception of which is so simple as that of an
14935: all-embracing reality. This highest cause, then, we regard as
14936: absolutely necessary, because we find it absolutely necessary to rise
14937: to it, and do not discover any reason for proceeding beyond it. Thus,
14938: among all nations, through the darkest polytheism glimmer some faint
14939: sparks of monotheism, to which these idolaters have been led, not from
14940: reflection and profound thought, but by the study and natural progress
14941: of the common understanding.
14942: 
14943: There are only three modes of proving the existence of a Deity, on the
14944: grounds of speculative reason.
14945: 
14946: All the paths conducting to this end begin either from determinate
14947: experience and the peculiar constitution of the world of sense, and
14948: rise, according to the laws of causality, from it to the highest cause
14949: existing apart from the world—or from a purely indeterminate
14950: experience, that is, some empirical existence—or abstraction is made of
14951: all experience, and the existence of a supreme cause is concluded from
14952: à priori conceptions alone. The first is the physico-theological
14953: argument, the second the cosmological, the third the ontological. More
14954: there are not, and more there cannot be.
14955: 
14956: I shall show it is as unsuccessful on the one path—the empirical—as on
14957: the other—the transcendental, and that it stretches its wings in vain,
14958: to soar beyond the world of sense by the mere might of speculative
14959: thought. As regards the order in which we must discuss those arguments,
14960: it will be exactly the reverse of that in which reason, in the progress
14961: of its development, attains to them—the order in which they are placed
14962: above. For it will be made manifest to the reader that, although
14963: experience presents the occasion and the starting-point, it is the
14964: transcendental idea of reason which guides it in its pilgrimage and is
14965: the goal of all its struggles. I shall therefore begin with an
14966: examination of the transcendental argument, and afterwards inquire what
14967: additional strength has accrued to this mode of proof from the addition
14968: of the empirical element.
14969: 
14970: Section IV. Of the Impossibility of an Ontological Proof of the
14971: Existence of God
14972: 
14973: It is evident from what has been said that the conception of an
14974: absolutely necessary being is a mere idea, the objective reality of
14975: which is far from being established by the mere fact that it is a need
14976: of reason. On the contrary, this idea serves merely to indicate a
14977: certain unattainable perfection, and rather limits the operations than,
14978: by the presentation of new objects, extends the sphere of the
14979: understanding. But a strange anomaly meets us at the very threshold;
14980: for the inference from a given existence in general to an absolutely
14981: necessary existence seems to be correct and unavoidable, while the
14982: conditions of the understanding refuse to aid us in forming any
14983: conception of such a being.
14984: 
14985: Philosophers have always talked of an absolutely necessary being, and
14986: have nevertheless declined to take the trouble of conceiving
14987: whether—and how—a being of this nature is even cogitable, not to
14988: mention that its existence is actually demonstrable. A verbal
14989: definition of the conception is certainly easy enough: it is something
14990: the non-existence of which is impossible. But does this definition
14991: throw any light upon the conditions which render it impossible to
14992: cogitate the non-existence of a thing—conditions which we wish to
14993: ascertain, that we may discover whether we think anything in the
14994: conception of such a being or not? For the mere fact that I throw away,
14995: by means of the word unconditioned, all the conditions which the
14996: understanding habitually requires in order to regard anything as
14997: necessary, is very far from making clear whether by means of the
14998: conception of the unconditionally necessary I think of something, or
14999: really of nothing at all.
15000: 
15001: Nay, more, this chance-conception, now become so current, many have
15002: endeavoured to explain by examples which seemed to render any inquiries
15003: regarding its intelligibility quite needless. Every geometrical
15004: proposition—a triangle has three angles—it was said, is absolutely
15005: necessary; and thus people talked of an object which lay out of the
15006: sphere of our understanding as if it were perfectly plain what the
15007: conception of such a being meant.
15008: 
15009: All the examples adduced have been drawn, without exception, from
15010: judgements, and not from things. But the unconditioned necessity of a
15011: judgement does not form the absolute necessity of a thing. On the
15012: contrary, the absolute necessity of a judgement is only a conditioned
15013: necessity of a thing, or of the predicate in a judgement. The
15014: proposition above-mentioned does not enounce that three angles
15015: necessarily exist, but, upon condition that a triangle exists, three
15016: angles must necessarily exist—in it. And thus this logical necessity
15017: has been the source of the greatest delusions. Having formed an à
15018: priori conception of a thing, the content of which was made to embrace
15019: existence, we believed ourselves safe in concluding that, because
15020: existence belongs necessarily to the object of the conception (that is,
15021: under the condition of my positing this thing as given), the existence
15022: of the thing is also posited necessarily, and that it is therefore
15023: absolutely necessary—merely because its existence has been cogitated in
15024: the conception.
15025: 
15026: If, in an identical judgement, I annihilate the predicate in thought,
15027: and retain the subject, a contradiction is the result; and hence I say,
15028: the former belongs necessarily to the latter. But if I suppress both
15029: subject and predicate in thought, no contradiction arises; for there is
15030: nothing at all, and therefore no means of forming a contradiction. To
15031: suppose the existence of a triangle and not that of its three angles,
15032: is self-contradictory; but to suppose the non-existence of both
15033: triangle and angles is perfectly admissible. And so is it with the
15034: conception of an absolutely necessary being. Annihilate its existence
15035: in thought, and you annihilate the thing itself with all its
15036: predicates; how then can there be any room for contradiction?
15037: Externally, there is nothing to give rise to a contradiction, for a
15038: thing cannot be necessary externally; nor internally, for, by the
15039: annihilation or suppression of the thing itself, its internal
15040: properties are also annihilated. God is omnipotent—that is a necessary
15041: judgement. His omnipotence cannot be denied, if the existence of a
15042: Deity is posited—the existence, that is, of an infinite being, the two
15043: conceptions being identical. But when you say, God does not exist,
15044: neither omnipotence nor any other predicate is affirmed; they must all
15045: disappear with the subject, and in this judgement there cannot exist
15046: the least self-contradiction.
15047: 
15048: You have thus seen that when the predicate of a judgement is
15049: annihilated in thought along with the subject, no internal
15050: contradiction can arise, be the predicate what it may. There is no
15051: possibility of evading the conclusion—you find yourselves compelled to
15052: declare: There are certain subjects which cannot be annihilated in
15053: thought. But this is nothing more than saying: There exist subjects
15054: which are absolutely necessary—the very hypothesis which you are called
15055: upon to establish. For I find myself unable to form the slightest
15056: conception of a thing which when annihilated in thought with all its
15057: predicates, leaves behind a contradiction; and contradiction is the
15058: only criterion of impossibility in the sphere of pure à priori
15059: conceptions.
15060: 
15061: Against these general considerations, the justice of which no one can
15062: dispute, one argument is adduced, which is regarded as furnishing a
15063: satisfactory demonstration from the fact. It is affirmed that there is
15064: one and only one conception, in which the non-being or annihilation of
15065: the object is self-contradictory, and this is the conception of an ens
15066: realissimum. It possesses, you say, all reality, and you feel
15067: yourselves justified in admitting the possibility of such a being.
15068: (This I am willing to grant for the present, although the existence of
15069: a conception which is not self-contradictory is far from being
15070: sufficient to prove the possibility of an object.)[67] Now the notion
15071: of all reality embraces in it that of existence; the notion of
15072: existence lies, therefore, in the conception of this possible thing. If
15073: this thing is annihilated in thought, the internal possibility of the
15074: thing is also annihilated, which is self-contradictory.
15075: 
15076:  [67] A conception is always possible, if it is not self-contradictory.
15077:  This is the logical criterion of possibility, distinguishing the
15078:  object of such a conception from the nihil negativum. But it may be,
15079:  notwithstanding, an empty conception, unless the objective reality of
15080:  this synthesis, but which it is generated, is demonstrated; and a
15081:  proof of this kind must be based upon principles of possible
15082:  experience, and not upon the principle of analysis or contradiction.
15083:  This remark may be serviceable as a warning against concluding, from
15084:  the possibility of a conception—which is logical—the possibility of a
15085:  thing—which is real.
15086: 
15087: 
15088: I answer: It is absurd to introduce—under whatever term disguised—into
15089: the conception of a thing, which is to be cogitated solely in reference
15090: to its possibility, the conception of its existence. If this is
15091: admitted, you will have apparently gained the day, but in reality have
15092: enounced nothing but a mere tautology. I ask, is the proposition, this
15093: or that thing (which I am admitting to be possible) exists, an
15094: analytical or a synthetical proposition? If the former, there is no
15095: addition made to the subject of your thought by the affirmation of its
15096: existence; but then the conception in your minds is identical with the
15097: thing itself, or you have supposed the existence of a thing to be
15098: possible, and then inferred its existence from its internal
15099: possibility—which is but a miserable tautology. The word reality in the
15100: conception of the thing, and the word existence in the conception of
15101: the predicate, will not help you out of the difficulty. For, supposing
15102: you were to term all positing of a thing reality, you have thereby
15103: posited the thing with all its predicates in the conception of the
15104: subject and assumed its actual existence, and this you merely repeat in
15105: the predicate. But if you confess, as every reasonable person must,
15106: that every existential proposition is synthetical, how can it be
15107: maintained that the predicate of existence cannot be denied without
15108: contradiction?—a property which is the characteristic of analytical
15109: propositions, alone.
15110: 
15111: I should have a reasonable hope of putting an end for ever to this
15112: sophistical mode of argumentation, by a strict definition of the
15113: conception of existence, did not my own experience teach me that the
15114: illusion arising from our confounding a logical with a real predicate
15115: (a predicate which aids in the determination of a thing) resists almost
15116: all the endeavours of explanation and illustration. A logical predicate
15117: may be what you please, even the subject may be predicated of itself;
15118: for logic pays no regard to the content of a judgement. But the
15119: determination of a conception is a predicate, which adds to and
15120: enlarges the conception. It must not, therefore, be contained in the
15121: conception.
15122: 
15123: Being is evidently not a real predicate, that is, a conception of
15124: something which is added to the conception of some other thing. It is
15125: merely the positing of a thing, or of certain determinations in it.
15126: Logically, it is merely the copula of a judgement. The proposition, God
15127: is omnipotent, contains two conceptions, which have a certain object or
15128: content; the word is, is no additional predicate—it merely indicates
15129: the relation of the predicate to the subject. Now, if I take the
15130: subject (God) with all its predicates (omnipotence being one), and say:
15131: God is, or, There is a God, I add no new predicate to the conception of
15132: God, I merely posit or affirm the existence of the subject with all its
15133: predicates—I posit the object in relation to my conception. The content
15134: of both is the same; and there is no addition made to the conception,
15135: which expresses merely the possibility of the object, by my cogitating
15136: the object—in the expression, it is—as absolutely given or existing.
15137: Thus the real contains no more than the possible. A hundred real
15138: dollars contain no more than a hundred possible dollars. For, as the
15139: latter indicate the conception, and the former the object, on the
15140: supposition that the content of the former was greater than that of the
15141: latter, my conception would not be an expression of the whole object,
15142: and would consequently be an inadequate conception of it. But in
15143: reckoning my wealth there may be said to be more in a hundred real
15144: dollars than in a hundred possible dollars—that is, in the mere
15145: conception of them. For the real object—the dollars—is not analytically
15146: contained in my conception, but forms a synthetical addition to my
15147: conception (which is merely a determination of my mental state),
15148: although this objective reality—this existence—apart from my
15149: conceptions, does not in the least degree increase the aforesaid
15150: hundred dollars.
15151: 
15152: By whatever and by whatever number of predicates—even to the complete
15153: determination of it—I may cogitate a thing, I do not in the least
15154: augment the object of my conception by the addition of the statement:
15155: This thing exists. Otherwise, not exactly the same, but something more
15156: than what was cogitated in my conception, would exist, and I could not
15157: affirm that the exact object of my conception had real existence. If I
15158: cogitate a thing as containing all modes of reality except one, the
15159: mode of reality which is absent is not added to the conception of the
15160: thing by the affirmation that the thing exists; on the contrary, the
15161: thing exists—if it exist at all—with the same defect as that cogitated
15162: in its conception; otherwise not that which was cogitated, but
15163: something different, exists. Now, if I cogitate a being as the highest
15164: reality, without defect or imperfection, the question still
15165: remains—whether this being exists or not? For, although no element is
15166: wanting in the possible real content of my conception, there is a
15167: defect in its relation to my mental state, that is, I am ignorant
15168: whether the cognition of the object indicated by the conception is
15169: possible à posteriori. And here the cause of the present difficulty
15170: becomes apparent. If the question regarded an object of sense merely,
15171: it would be impossible for me to confound the conception with the
15172: existence of a thing. For the conception merely enables me to cogitate
15173: an object as according with the general conditions of experience; while
15174: the existence of the object permits me to cogitate it as contained in
15175: the sphere of actual experience. At the same time, this connection with
15176: the world of experience does not in the least augment the conception,
15177: although a possible perception has been added to the experience of the
15178: mind. But if we cogitate existence by the pure category alone, it is
15179: not to be wondered at, that we should find ourselves unable to present
15180: any criterion sufficient to distinguish it from mere possibility.
15181: 
15182: Whatever be the content of our conception of an object, it is necessary
15183: to go beyond it, if we wish to predicate existence of the object. In
15184: the case of sensuous objects, this is attained by their connection
15185: according to empirical laws with some one of my perceptions; but there
15186: is no means of cognizing the existence of objects of pure thought,
15187: because it must be cognized completely à priori. But all our knowledge
15188: of existence (be it immediately by perception, or by inferences
15189: connecting some object with a perception) belongs entirely to the
15190: sphere of experience—which is in perfect unity with itself; and
15191: although an existence out of this sphere cannot be absolutely declared
15192: to be impossible, it is a hypothesis the truth of which we have no
15193: means of ascertaining.
15194: 
15195: The notion of a Supreme Being is in many respects a highly useful idea;
15196: but for the very reason that it is an idea, it is incapable of
15197: enlarging our cognition with regard to the existence of things. It is
15198: not even sufficient to instruct us as to the possibility of a being
15199: which we do not know to exist. The analytical criterion of possibility,
15200: which consists in the absence of contradiction in propositions, cannot
15201: be denied it. But the connection of real properties in a thing is a
15202: synthesis of the possibility of which an à priori judgement cannot be
15203: formed, because these realities are not presented to us specifically;
15204: and even if this were to happen, a judgement would still be impossible,
15205: because the criterion of the possibility of synthetical cognitions must
15206: be sought for in the world of experience, to which the object of an
15207: idea cannot belong. And thus the celebrated Leibnitz has utterly failed
15208: in his attempt to establish upon à priori grounds the possibility of
15209: this sublime ideal being.
15210: 
15211: The celebrated ontological or Cartesian argument for the existence of a
15212: Supreme Being is therefore insufficient; and we may as well hope to
15213: increase our stock of knowledge by the aid of mere ideas, as the
15214: merchant to augment his wealth by the addition of noughts to his cash
15215: account.
15216: 
15217: Section V. Of the Impossibility of a Cosmological Proof of the
15218: Existence of God
15219: 
15220: It was by no means a natural course of proceeding, but, on the
15221: contrary, an invention entirely due to the subtlety of the schools, to
15222: attempt to draw from a mere idea a proof of the existence of an object
15223: corresponding to it. Such a course would never have been pursued, were
15224: it not for that need of reason which requires it to suppose the
15225: existence of a necessary being as a basis for the empirical regress,
15226: and that, as this necessity must be unconditioned and à priori, reason
15227: is bound to discover a conception which shall satisfy, if possible,
15228: this requirement, and enable us to attain to the à priori cognition of
15229: such a being. This conception was thought to be found in the idea of an
15230: ens realissimum, and thus this idea was employed for the attainment of
15231: a better defined knowledge of a necessary being, of the existence of
15232: which we were convinced, or persuaded, on other grounds. Thus reason
15233: was seduced from her natural courage; and, instead of concluding with
15234: the conception of an ens realissimum, an attempt was made to begin with
15235: it, for the purpose of inferring from it that idea of a necessary
15236: existence which it was in fact called in to complete. Thus arose that
15237: unfortunate ontological argument, which neither satisfies the healthy
15238: common sense of humanity, nor sustains the scientific examination of
15239: the philosopher.
15240: 
15241: The cosmological proof, which we are about to examine, retains the
15242: connection between absolute necessity and the highest reality; but,
15243: instead of reasoning from this highest reality to a necessary
15244: existence, like the preceding argument, it concludes from the given
15245: unconditioned necessity of some being its unlimited reality. The track
15246: it pursues, whether rational or sophistical, is at least natural, and
15247: not only goes far to persuade the common understanding, but shows
15248: itself deserving of respect from the speculative intellect; while it
15249: contains, at the same time, the outlines of all the arguments employed
15250: in natural theology—arguments which always have been, and still will
15251: be, in use and authority. These, however adorned, and hid under
15252: whatever embellishments of rhetoric and sentiment, are at bottom
15253: identical with the arguments we are at present to discuss. This proof,
15254: termed by Leibnitz the argumentum a contingentia mundi, I shall now lay
15255: before the reader, and subject to a strict examination.
15256: 
15257: It is framed in the following manner: If something exists, an
15258: absolutely necessary being must likewise exist. Now I, at least, exist.
15259: Consequently, there exists an absolutely necessary being. The minor
15260: contains an experience, the major reasons from a general experience to
15261: the existence of a necessary being.[68] Thus this argument really
15262: begins at experience, and is not completely à priori, or ontological.
15263: The object of all possible experience being the world, it is called the
15264: cosmological proof. It contains no reference to any peculiar property
15265: of sensuous objects, by which this world of sense might be
15266: distinguished from other possible worlds; and in this respect it
15267: differs from the physico-theological proof, which is based upon the
15268: consideration of the peculiar constitution of our sensuous world.
15269: 
15270:  [68] This inference is too well known to require more detailed
15271:  discussion. It is based upon the spurious transcendental law of
15272:  causality, that everything which is contingent has a cause, which, if
15273:  itself contingent, must also have a cause; and so on, till the series
15274:  of subordinated causes must end with an absolutely necessary cause,
15275:  without which it would not possess completeness.
15276: 
15277: 
15278: The proof proceeds thus: A necessary being can be determined only in
15279: one way, that is, it can be determined by only one of all possible
15280: opposed predicates; consequently, it must be completely determined in
15281: and by its conception. But there is only a single conception of a thing
15282: possible, which completely determines the thing à priori: that is, the
15283: conception of the ens realissimum. It follows that the conception of
15284: the ens realissimum is the only conception by and in which we can
15285: cogitate a necessary being. Consequently, a Supreme Being necessarily
15286: exists.
15287: 
15288: In this cosmological argument are assembled so many sophistical
15289: propositions that speculative reason seems to have exerted in it all
15290: her dialectical skill to produce a transcendental illusion of the most
15291: extreme character. We shall postpone an investigation of this argument
15292: for the present, and confine ourselves to exposing the stratagem by
15293: which it imposes upon us an old argument in a new dress, and appeals to
15294: the agreement of two witnesses, the one with the credentials of pure
15295: reason, and the other with those of empiricism; while, in fact, it is
15296: only the former who has changed his dress and voice, for the purpose of
15297: passing himself off for an additional witness. That it may possess a
15298: secure foundation, it bases its conclusions upon experience, and thus
15299: appears to be completely distinct from the ontological argument, which
15300: places its confidence entirely in pure à priori conceptions. But this
15301: experience merely aids reason in making one step—to the existence of a
15302: necessary being. What the properties of this being are cannot be
15303: learned from experience; and therefore reason abandons it altogether,
15304: and pursues its inquiries in the sphere of pure conception, for the
15305: purpose of discovering what the properties of an absolutely necessary
15306: being ought to be, that is, what among all possible things contain the
15307: conditions (requisita) of absolute necessity. Reason believes that it
15308: has discovered these requisites in the conception of an ens
15309: realissimum—and in it alone, and hence concludes: The ens realissimum
15310: is an absolutely necessary being. But it is evident that reason has
15311: here presupposed that the conception of an ens realissimum is perfectly
15312: adequate to the conception of a being of absolute necessity, that is,
15313: that we may infer the existence of the latter from that of the former—a
15314: proposition which formed the basis of the ontological argument, and
15315: which is now employed in the support of the cosmological argument,
15316: contrary to the wish and professions of its inventors. For the
15317: existence of an absolutely necessary being is given in conceptions
15318: alone. But if I say: “The conception of the ens realissimum is a
15319: conception of this kind, and in fact the only conception which is
15320: adequate to our idea of a necessary being,” I am obliged to admit, that
15321: the latter may be inferred from the former. Thus it is properly the
15322: ontological argument which figures in the cosmological, and constitutes
15323: the whole strength of the latter; while the spurious basis of
15324: experience has been of no further use than to conduct us to the
15325: conception of absolute necessity, being utterly insufficient to
15326: demonstrate the presence of this attribute in any determinate existence
15327: or thing. For when we propose to ourselves an aim of this character, we
15328: must abandon the sphere of experience, and rise to that of pure
15329: conceptions, which we examine with the purpose of discovering whether
15330: any one contains the conditions of the possibility of an absolutely
15331: necessary being. But if the possibility of such a being is thus
15332: demonstrated, its existence is also proved; for we may then assert
15333: that, of all possible beings there is one which possesses the attribute
15334: of necessity—in other words, this being possesses an absolutely
15335: necessary existence.
15336: 
15337: All illusions in an argument are more easily detected when they are
15338: presented in the formal manner employed by the schools, which we now
15339: proceed to do.
15340: 
15341: If the proposition: “Every absolutely necessary being is likewise an
15342: ens realissimum,” is correct (and it is this which constitutes the
15343: nervus probandi of the cosmological argument), it must, like all
15344: affirmative judgements, be capable of conversion—the conversio per
15345: accidens, at least. It follows, then, that some entia realissima are
15346: absolutely necessary beings. But no ens realissimum is in any respect
15347: different from another, and what is valid of some is valid of all. In
15348: this present case, therefore, I may employ simple conversion, and say:
15349: “Every ens realissimum is a necessary being.” But as this proposition
15350: is determined à priori by the conceptions contained in it, the mere
15351: conception of an ens realissimum must possess the additional attribute
15352: of absolute necessity. But this is exactly what was maintained in the
15353: ontological argument, and not recognized by the cosmological, although
15354: it formed the real ground of its disguised and illusory reasoning.
15355: 
15356: Thus the second mode employed by speculative reason of demonstrating
15357: the existence of a Supreme Being, is not only, like the first, illusory
15358: and inadequate, but possesses the additional blemish of an ignoratio
15359: elenchi—professing to conduct us by a new road to the desired goal, but
15360: bringing us back, after a short circuit, to the old path which we had
15361: deserted at its call.
15362: 
15363: I mentioned above that this cosmological argument contains a perfect
15364: nest of dialectical assumptions, which transcendental criticism does
15365: not find it difficult to expose and to dissipate. I shall merely
15366: enumerate these, leaving it to the reader, who must by this time be
15367: well practised in such matters, to investigate the fallacies residing
15368: therein.
15369: 
15370: The following fallacies, for example, are discoverable in this mode of
15371: proof: 1. The transcendental principle: “Everything that is contingent
15372: must have a cause”—a principle without significance, except in the
15373: sensuous world. For the purely intellectual conception of the
15374: contingent cannot produce any synthetical proposition, like that of
15375: causality, which is itself without significance or distinguishing
15376: characteristic except in the phenomenal world. But in the present case
15377: it is employed to help us beyond the limits of its sphere. 2. “From the
15378: impossibility of an infinite ascending series of causes in the world of
15379: sense a first cause is inferred”; a conclusion which the principles of
15380: the employment of reason do not justify even in the sphere of
15381: experience, and still less when an attempt is made to pass the limits
15382: of this sphere. 3. Reason allows itself to be satisfied upon
15383: insufficient grounds, with regard to the completion of this series. It
15384: removes all conditions (without which, however, no conception of
15385: Necessity can take place); and, as after this it is beyond our power to
15386: form any other conceptions, it accepts this as a completion of the
15387: conception it wishes to form of the series. 4. The logical possibility
15388: of a conception of the total of reality (the criterion of this
15389: possibility being the absence of contradiction) is confounded with the
15390: transcendental, which requires a principle of the practicability of
15391: such a synthesis—a principle which again refers us to the world of
15392: experience. And so on.
15393: 
15394: The aim of the cosmological argument is to avoid the necessity of
15395: proving the existence of a necessary being priori from mere
15396: conceptions—a proof which must be ontological, and of which we feel
15397: ourselves quite incapable. With this purpose, we reason from an actual
15398: existence—an experience in general, to an absolutely necessary
15399: condition of that existence. It is in this case unnecessary to
15400: demonstrate its possibility. For after having proved that it exists,
15401: the question regarding its possibility is superfluous. Now, when we
15402: wish to define more strictly the nature of this necessary being, we do
15403: not look out for some being the conception of which would enable us to
15404: comprehend the necessity of its being—for if we could do this, an
15405: empirical presupposition would be unnecessary; no, we try to discover
15406: merely the negative condition (conditio sine qua non), without which a
15407: being would not be absolutely necessary. Now this would be perfectly
15408: admissible in every sort of reasoning, from a consequence to its
15409: principle; but in the present case it unfortunately happens that the
15410: condition of absolute necessity can be discovered in but a single
15411: being, the conception of which must consequently contain all that is
15412: requisite for demonstrating the presence of absolute necessity, and
15413: thus entitle me to infer this absolute necessity à priori. That is, it
15414: must be possible to reason conversely, and say: The thing, to which the
15415: conception of the highest reality belongs, is absolutely necessary. But
15416: if I cannot reason thus—and I cannot, unless I believe in the
15417: sufficiency of the ontological argument—I find insurmountable obstacles
15418: in my new path, and am really no farther than the point from which I
15419: set out. The conception of a Supreme Being satisfies all questions à
15420: priori regarding the internal determinations of a thing, and is for
15421: this reason an ideal without equal or parallel, the general conception
15422: of it indicating it as at the same time an ens individuum among all
15423: possible things. But the conception does not satisfy the question
15424: regarding its existence—which was the purpose of all our inquiries;
15425: and, although the existence of a necessary being were admitted, we
15426: should find it impossible to answer the question: What of all things in
15427: the world must be regarded as such?
15428: 
15429: It is certainly allowable to admit the existence of an all-sufficient
15430: being—a cause of all possible effects—for the purpose of enabling
15431: reason to introduce unity into its mode and grounds of explanation with
15432: regard to phenomena. But to assert that such a being necessarily
15433: exists, is no longer the modest enunciation of an admissible
15434: hypothesis, but the boldest declaration of an apodeictic certainty; for
15435: the cognition of that which is absolutely necessary must itself possess
15436: that character.
15437: 
15438: The aim of the transcendental ideal formed by the mind is either to
15439: discover a conception which shall harmonize with the idea of absolute
15440: necessity, or a conception which shall contain that idea. If the one is
15441: possible, so is the other; for reason recognizes that alone as
15442: absolutely necessary which is necessary from its conception. But both
15443: attempts are equally beyond our power—we find it impossible to satisfy
15444: the understanding upon this point, and as impossible to induce it to
15445: remain at rest in relation to this incapacity.
15446: 
15447: Unconditioned necessity, which, as the ultimate support and stay of all
15448: existing things, is an indispensable requirement of the mind, is an
15449: abyss on the verge of which human reason trembles in dismay. Even the
15450: idea of eternity, terrible and sublime as it is, as depicted by Haller,
15451: does not produce upon the mental vision such a feeling of awe and
15452: terror; for, although it measures the duration of things, it does not
15453: support them. We cannot bear, nor can we rid ourselves of the thought
15454: that a being, which we regard as the greatest of all possible
15455: existences, should say to himself: I am from eternity to eternity;
15456: beside me there is nothing, except that which exists by my will; whence
15457: then am I? Here all sinks away from under us; and the greatest, as the
15458: smallest, perfection, hovers without stay or footing in presence of the
15459: speculative reason, which finds it as easy to part with the one as with
15460: the other.
15461: 
15462: Many physical powers, which evidence their existence by their effects,
15463: are perfectly inscrutable in their nature; they elude all our powers of
