15464: observation. The transcendental object which forms the basis of
15465: phenomena, and, in connection with it, the reason why our sensibility
15466: possesses this rather than that particular kind of conditions, are and
15467: must ever remain hidden from our mental vision; the fact is there, the
15468: reason of the fact we cannot see. But an ideal of pure reason cannot be
15469: termed mysterious or inscrutable, because the only credential of its
15470: reality is the need of it felt by reason, for the purpose of giving
15471: completeness to the world of synthetical unity. An ideal is not even
15472: given as a cogitable object, and therefore cannot be inscrutable; on
15473: the contrary, it must, as a mere idea, be based on the constitution of
15474: reason itself, and on this account must be capable of explanation and
15475: solution. For the very essence of reason consists in its ability to
15476: give an account, of all our conceptions, opinions, and assertions—upon
15477: objective, or, when they happen to be illusory and fallacious, upon
15478: subjective grounds.
15479: 
15480: Detection and Explanation of the Dialectical Illusion in all
15481: Transcendental Arguments for the Existence of a Necessary Being.
15482: 
15483: Both of the above arguments are transcendental; in other words, they do
15484: not proceed upon empirical principles. For, although the cosmological
15485: argument professed to lay a basis of experience for its edifice of
15486: reasoning, it did not ground its procedure upon the peculiar
15487: constitution of experience, but upon pure principles of reason—in
15488: relation to an existence given by empirical consciousness; utterly
15489: abandoning its guidance, however, for the purpose of supporting its
15490: assertions entirely upon pure conceptions. Now what is the cause, in
15491: these transcendental arguments, of the dialectical, but natural,
15492: illusion, which connects the conceptions of necessity and supreme
15493: reality, and hypostatizes that which cannot be anything but an idea?
15494: What is the cause of this unavoidable step on the part of reason, of
15495: admitting that some one among all existing things must be necessary,
15496: while it falls back from the assertion of the existence of such a being
15497: as from an abyss? And how does reason proceed to explain this anomaly
15498: to itself, and from the wavering condition of a timid and reluctant
15499: approbation—always again withdrawn—arrive at a calm and settled insight
15500: into its cause?
15501: 
15502: It is something very remarkable that, on the supposition that something
15503: exists, I cannot avoid the inference that something exists necessarily.
15504: Upon this perfectly natural—but not on that account reliable—inference
15505: does the cosmological argument rest. But, let me form any conception
15506: whatever of a thing, I find that I cannot cogitate the existence of the
15507: thing as absolutely necessary, and that nothing prevents me—be the
15508: thing or being what it may—from cogitating its non-existence. I may
15509: thus be obliged to admit that all existing things have a necessary
15510: basis, while I cannot cogitate any single or individual thing as
15511: necessary. In other words, I can never complete the regress through the
15512: conditions of existence, without admitting the existence of a necessary
15513: being; but, on the other hand, I cannot make a commencement from this
15514: being.
15515: 
15516: If I must cogitate something as existing necessarily as the basis of
15517: existing things, and yet am not permitted to cogitate any individual
15518: thing as in itself necessary, the inevitable inference is that
15519: necessity and contingency are not properties of things
15520: themselves—otherwise an internal contradiction would result; that
15521: consequently neither of these principles are objective, but merely
15522: subjective principles of reason—the one requiring us to seek for a
15523: necessary ground for everything that exists, that is, to be satisfied
15524: with no other explanation than that which is complete à priori, the
15525: other forbidding us ever to hope for the attainment of this
15526: completeness, that is, to regard no member of the empirical world as
15527: unconditioned. In this mode of viewing them, both principles, in their
15528: purely heuristic and regulative character, and as concerning merely the
15529: formal interest of reason, are quite consistent with each other. The
15530: one says: “You must philosophize upon nature,” as if there existed a
15531: necessary primal basis of all existing things, solely for the purpose
15532: of introducing systematic unity into your knowledge, by pursuing an
15533: idea of this character—a foundation which is arbitrarily admitted to be
15534: ultimate; while the other warns you to consider no individual
15535: determination, concerning the existence of things, as such an ultimate
15536: foundation, that is, as absolutely necessary, but to keep the way
15537: always open for further progress in the deduction, and to treat every
15538: determination as determined by some other. But if all that we perceive
15539: must be regarded as conditionally necessary, it is impossible that
15540: anything which is empirically given should be absolutely necessary.
15541: 
15542: It follows from this that you must accept the absolutely necessary as
15543: out of and beyond the world, inasmuch as it is useful only as a
15544: principle of the highest possible unity in experience, and you cannot
15545: discover any such necessary existence in the would, the second rule
15546: requiring you to regard all empirical causes of unity as themselves
15547: deduced.
15548: 
15549: The philosophers of antiquity regarded all the forms of nature as
15550: contingent; while matter was considered by them, in accordance with the
15551: judgement of the common reason of mankind, as primal and necessary. But
15552: if they had regarded matter, not relatively—as the substratum of
15553: phenomena, but absolutely and in itself—as an independent existence,
15554: this idea of absolute necessity would have immediately disappeared. For
15555: there is nothing absolutely connecting reason with such an existence;
15556: on the contrary, it can annihilate it in thought, always and without
15557: self-contradiction. But in thought alone lay the idea of absolute
15558: necessity. A regulative principle must, therefore, have been at the
15559: foundation of this opinion. In fact, extension and
15560: impenetrability—which together constitute our conception of matter—form
15561: the supreme empirical principle of the unity of phenomena, and this
15562: principle, in so far as it is empirically unconditioned, possesses the
15563: property of a regulative principle. But, as every determination of
15564: matter which constitutes what is real in it—and consequently
15565: impenetrability—is an effect, which must have a cause, and is for this
15566: reason always derived, the notion of matter cannot harmonize with the
15567: idea of a necessary being, in its character of the principle of all
15568: derived unity. For every one of its real properties, being derived,
15569: must be only conditionally necessary, and can therefore be annihilated
15570: in thought; and thus the whole existence of matter can be so
15571: annihilated or suppressed. If this were not the case, we should have
15572: found in the world of phenomena the highest ground or condition of
15573: unity—which is impossible, according to the second regulative
15574: principle. It follows that matter, and, in general, all that forms part
15575: of the world of sense, cannot be a necessary primal being, nor even a
15576: principle of empirical unity, but that this being or principle must
15577: have its place assigned without the world. And, in this way, we can
15578: proceed in perfect confidence to deduce the phenomena of the world and
15579: their existence from other phenomena, just as if there existed no
15580: necessary being; and we can at the same time, strive without ceasing
15581: towards the attainment of completeness for our deduction, just as if
15582: such a being—the supreme condition of all existences—were presupposed
15583: by the mind.
15584: 
15585: These remarks will have made it evident to the reader that the ideal of
15586: the Supreme Being, far from being an enouncement of the existence of a
15587: being in itself necessary, is nothing more than a regulative principle
15588: of reason, requiring us to regard all connection existing between
15589: phenomena as if it had its origin from an all-sufficient necessary
15590: cause, and basing upon this the rule of a systematic and necessary
15591: unity in the explanation of phenomena. We cannot, at the same time,
15592: avoid regarding, by a transcendental subreptio, this formal principle
15593: as constitutive, and hypostatizing this unity. Precisely similar is the
15594: case with our notion of space. Space is the primal condition of all
15595: forms, which are properly just so many different limitations of it; and
15596: thus, although it is merely a principle of sensibility, we cannot help
15597: regarding it as an absolutely necessary and self-subsistent thing—as an
15598: object given à priori in itself. In the same way, it is quite natural
15599: that, as the systematic unity of nature cannot be established as a
15600: principle for the empirical employment of reason, unless it is based
15601: upon the idea of an ens realissimum, as the supreme cause, we should
15602: regard this idea as a real object, and this object, in its character of
15603: supreme condition, as absolutely necessary, and that in this way a
15604: regulative should be transformed into a constitutive principle. This
15605: interchange becomes evident when I regard this supreme being, which,
15606: relatively to the world, was absolutely (unconditionally) necessary, as
15607: a thing per se. In this case, I find it impossible to represent this
15608: necessity in or by any conception, and it exists merely in my own mind,
15609: as the formal condition of thought, but not as a material and
15610: hypostatic condition of existence.
15611: 
15612: Section VI. Of the Impossibility of a Physico-Theological Proof
15613: 
15614: If, then, neither a pure conception nor the general experience of an
15615: existing being can provide a sufficient basis for the proof of the
15616: existence of the Deity, we can make the attempt by the only other
15617: mode—that of grounding our argument upon a determinate experience of
15618: the phenomena of the present world, their constitution and disposition,
15619: and discover whether we can thus attain to a sound conviction of the
15620: existence of a Supreme Being. This argument we shall term the
15621: physico-theological argument. If it is shown to be insufficient,
15622: speculative reason cannot present us with any satisfactory proof of the
15623: existence of a being corresponding to our transcendental idea.
15624: 
15625: It is evident from the remarks that have been made in the preceding
15626: sections, that an answer to this question will be far from being
15627: difficult or unconvincing. For how can any experience be adequate with
15628: an idea? The very essence of an idea consists in the fact that no
15629: experience can ever be discovered congruent or adequate with it. The
15630: transcendental idea of a necessary and all-sufficient being is so
15631: immeasurably great, so high above all that is empirical, which is
15632: always conditioned, that we hope in vain to find materials in the
15633: sphere of experience sufficiently ample for our conception, and in vain
15634: seek the unconditioned among things that are conditioned, while
15635: examples, nay, even guidance is denied us by the laws of empirical
15636: synthesis.
15637: 
15638: If the Supreme Being forms a link in the chain of empirical conditions,
15639: it must be a member of the empirical series, and, like the lower
15640: members which it precedes, have its origin in some higher member of the
15641: series. If, on the other hand, we disengage it from the chain, and
15642: cogitate it as an intelligible being, apart from the series of natural
15643: causes—how shall reason bridge the abyss that separates the latter from
15644: the former? All laws respecting the regress from effects to causes, all
15645: synthetical additions to our knowledge relate solely to possible
15646: experience and the objects of the sensuous world, and, apart from them,
15647: are without significance.
15648: 
15649: The world around us opens before our view so magnificent a spectacle of
15650: order, variety, beauty, and conformity to ends, that whether we pursue
15651: our observations into the infinity of space in the one direction, or
15652: into its illimitable divisions in the other, whether we regard the
15653: world in its greatest or its least manifestations—even after we have
15654: attained to the highest summit of knowledge which our weak minds can
15655: reach, we find that language in the presence of wonders so
15656: inconceivable has lost its force, and number its power to reckon, nay,
15657: even thought fails to conceive adequately, and our conception of the
15658: whole dissolves into an astonishment without power of expression—all
15659: the more eloquent that it is dumb. Everywhere around us we observe a
15660: chain of causes and effects, of means and ends, of death and birth;
15661: and, as nothing has entered of itself into the condition in which we
15662: find it, we are constantly referred to some other thing, which itself
15663: suggests the same inquiry regarding its cause, and thus the universe
15664: must sink into the abyss of nothingness, unless we admit that, besides
15665: this infinite chain of contingencies, there exists something that is
15666: primal and self-subsistent—something which, as the cause of this
15667: phenomenal world, secures its continuance and preservation.
15668: 
15669: This highest cause—what magnitude shall we attribute to it? Of the
15670: content of the world we are ignorant; still less can we estimate its
15671: magnitude by comparison with the sphere of the possible. But this
15672: supreme cause being a necessity of the human mind, what is there to
15673: prevent us from attributing to it such a degree of perfection as to
15674: place it above the sphere of all that is possible? This we can easily
15675: do, although only by the aid of the faint outline of an abstract
15676: conception, by representing this being to ourselves as containing in
15677: itself, as an individual substance, all possible perfection—a
15678: conception which satisfies that requirement of reason which demands
15679: parsimony in principles, which is free from self-contradiction, which
15680: even contributes to the extension of the employment of reason in
15681: experience, by means of the guidance afforded by this idea to order and
15682: system, and which in no respect conflicts with any law of experience.
15683: 
15684: This argument always deserves to be mentioned with respect. It is the
15685: oldest, the clearest, and that most in conformity with the common
15686: reason of humanity. It animates the study of nature, as it itself
15687: derives its existence and draws ever new strength from that source. It
15688: introduces aims and ends into a sphere in which our observation could
15689: not of itself have discovered them, and extends our knowledge of
15690: nature, by directing our attention to a unity, the principle of which
15691: lies beyond nature. This knowledge of nature again reacts upon this
15692: idea—its cause; and thus our belief in a divine author of the universe
15693: rises to the power of an irresistible conviction.
15694: 
15695: For these reasons it would be utterly hopeless to attempt to rob this
15696: argument of the authority it has always enjoyed. The mind, unceasingly
15697: elevated by these considerations, which, although empirical, are so
15698: remarkably powerful, and continually adding to their force, will not
15699: suffer itself to be depressed by the doubts suggested by subtle
15700: speculation; it tears itself out of this state of uncertainty, the
15701: moment it casts a look upon the wondrous forms of nature and the
15702: majesty of the universe, and rises from height to height, from
15703: condition to condition, till it has elevated itself to the supreme and
15704: unconditioned author of all.
15705: 
15706: But although we have nothing to object to the reasonableness and
15707: utility of this procedure, but have rather to commend and encourage it,
15708: we cannot approve of the claims which this argument advances to
15709: demonstrative certainty and to a reception upon its own merits, apart
15710: from favour or support by other arguments. Nor can it injure the cause
15711: of morality to endeavour to lower the tone of the arrogant sophist, and
15712: to teach him that modesty and moderation which are the properties of a
15713: belief that brings calm and content into the mind, without prescribing
15714: to it an unworthy subjection. I maintain, then, that the
15715: physico-theological argument is insufficient of itself to prove the
15716: existence of a Supreme Being, that it must entrust this to the
15717: ontological argument—to which it serves merely as an introduction, and
15718: that, consequently, this argument contains the only possible ground of
15719: proof (possessed by speculative reason) for the existence of this
15720: being.
15721: 
15722: The chief momenta in the physico-theological argument are as follow: 1.
15723: We observe in the world manifest signs of an arrangement full of
15724: purpose, executed with great wisdom, and argument in whole of a content
15725: indescribably various, and of an extent without limits. 2. This
15726: arrangement of means and ends is entirely foreign to the things
15727: existing in the world—it belongs to them merely as a contingent
15728: attribute; in other words, the nature of different things could not of
15729: itself, whatever means were employed, harmoniously tend towards certain
15730: purposes, were they not chosen and directed for these purposes by a
15731: rational and disposing principle, in accordance with certain
15732: fundamental ideas. 3. There exists, therefore, a sublime and wise cause
15733: (or several), which is not merely a blind, all-powerful nature,
15734: producing the beings and events which fill the world in unconscious
15735: fecundity, but a free and intelligent cause of the world. 4. The unity
15736: of this cause may be inferred from the unity of the reciprocal relation
15737: existing between the parts of the world, as portions of an artistic
15738: edifice—an inference which all our observation favours, and all
15739: principles of analogy support.
15740: 
15741: In the above argument, it is inferred from the analogy of certain
15742: products of nature with those of human art, when it compels Nature to
15743: bend herself to its purposes, as in the case of a house, a ship, or a
15744: watch, that the same kind of causality—namely, understanding and
15745: will—resides in nature. It is also declared that the internal
15746: possibility of this freely-acting nature (which is the source of all
15747: art, and perhaps also of human reason) is derivable from another and
15748: superhuman art—a conclusion which would perhaps be found incapable of
15749: standing the test of subtle transcendental criticism. But to neither of
15750: these opinions shall we at present object. We shall only remark that it
15751: must be confessed that, if we are to discuss the subject of cause at
15752: all, we cannot proceed more securely than with the guidance of the
15753: analogy subsisting between nature and such products of design—these
15754: being the only products whose causes and modes of organization are
15755: completely known to us. Reason would be unable to satisfy her own
15756: requirements, if she passed from a causality which she does know, to
15757: obscure and indemonstrable principles of explanation which she does not
15758: know.
15759: 
15760: According to the physico-theological argument, the connection and
15761: harmony existing in the world evidence the contingency of the form
15762: merely, but not of the matter, that is, of the substance of the world.
15763: To establish the truth of the latter opinion, it would be necessary to
15764: prove that all things would be in themselves incapable of this harmony
15765: and order, unless they were, even as regards their substance, the
15766: product of a supreme wisdom. But this would require very different
15767: grounds of proof from those presented by the analogy with human art.
15768: This proof can at most, therefore, demonstrate the existence of an
15769: architect of the world, whose efforts are limited by the capabilities
15770: of the material with which he works, but not of a creator of the world,
15771: to whom all things are subject. Thus this argument is utterly
15772: insufficient for the task before us—a demonstration of the existence of
15773: an all-sufficient being. If we wish to prove the contingency of matter,
15774: we must have recourse to a transcendental argument, which the
15775: physico-theological was constructed expressly to avoid.
15776: 
15777: We infer, from the order and design visible in the universe, as a
15778: disposition of a thoroughly contingent character, the existence of a
15779: cause proportionate thereto. The conception of this cause must contain
15780: certain determinate qualities, and it must therefore be regarded as the
15781: conception of a being which possesses all power, wisdom, and so on, in
15782: one word, all perfection—the conception, that is, of an all-sufficient
15783: being. For the predicates of very great, astonishing, or immeasurable
15784: power and excellence, give us no determinate conception of the thing,
15785: nor do they inform us what the thing may be in itself. They merely
15786: indicate the relation existing between the magnitude of the object and
15787: the observer, who compares it with himself and with his own power of
15788: comprehension, and are mere expressions of praise and reverence, by
15789: which the object is either magnified, or the observing subject
15790: depreciated in relation to the object. Where we have to do with the
15791: magnitude (of the perfection) of a thing, we can discover no
15792: determinate conception, except that which comprehends all possible
15793: perfection or completeness, and it is only the total (omnitudo) of
15794: reality which is completely determined in and through its conception
15795: alone.
15796: 
15797: Now it cannot be expected that any one will be bold enough to declare
15798: that he has a perfect insight into the relation which the magnitude of
15799: the world he contemplates bears (in its extent as well as in its
15800: content) to omnipotence, into that of the order and design in the world
15801: to the highest wisdom, and that of the unity of the world to the
15802: absolute unity of a Supreme Being. Physico-theology is therefore
15803: incapable of presenting a determinate conception of a supreme cause of
15804: the world, and is therefore insufficient as a principle of theology—a
15805: theology which is itself to be the basis of religion.
15806: 
15807: The attainment of absolute totality is completely impossible on the
15808: path of empiricism. And yet this is the path pursued in the
15809: physico-theological argument. What means shall we employ to bridge the
15810: abyss?
15811: 
15812: After elevating ourselves to admiration of the magnitude of the power,
15813: wisdom, and other attributes of the author of the world, and finding we
15814: can advance no further, we leave the argument on empirical grounds, and
15815: proceed to infer the contingency of the world from the order and
15816: conformity to aims that are observable in it. From this contingency we
15817: infer, by the help of transcendental conceptions alone, the existence
15818: of something absolutely necessary; and, still advancing, proceed from
15819: the conception of the absolute necessity of the first cause to the
15820: completely determined or determining conception thereof—the conception
15821: of an all-embracing reality. Thus the physico-theological, failing in
15822: its undertaking, recurs in its embarrassment to the cosmological
15823: argument; and, as this is merely the ontological argument in disguise,
15824: it executes its design solely by the aid of pure reason, although it at
15825: first professed to have no connection with this faculty and to base its
15826: entire procedure upon experience alone.
15827: 
15828: The physico-theologians have therefore no reason to regard with such
15829: contempt the transcendental mode of argument, and to look down upon it,
15830: with the conceit of clear-sighted observers of nature, as the
15831: brain-cobweb of obscure speculatists. For, if they reflect upon and
15832: examine their own arguments, they will find that, after following for
15833: some time the path of nature and experience, and discovering themselves
15834: no nearer their object, they suddenly leave this path and pass into the
15835: region of pure possibility, where they hope to reach upon the wings of
15836: ideas what had eluded all their empirical investigations. Gaining, as
15837: they think, a firm footing after this immense leap, they extend their
15838: determinate conception—into the possession of which they have come,
15839: they know not how—over the whole sphere of creation, and explain their
15840: ideal, which is entirely a product of pure reason, by illustrations
15841: drawn from experience—though in a degree miserably unworthy of the
15842: grandeur of the object, while they refuse to acknowledge that they have
15843: arrived at this cognition or hypothesis by a very different road from
15844: that of experience.
15845: 
15846: Thus the physico-theological is based upon the cosmological, and this
15847: upon the ontological proof of the existence of a Supreme Being; and as
15848: besides these three there is no other path open to speculative reason,
15849: the ontological proof, on the ground of pure conceptions of reason, is
15850: the only possible one, if any proof of a proposition so far
15851: transcending the empirical exercise of the understanding is possible at
15852: all.
15853: 
15854: Section VII. Critique of all Theology based upon Speculative Principles
15855: of Reason
15856: 
15857: If by the term theology I understand the cognition of a primal being,
15858: that cognition is based either upon reason alone (theologia rationalis)
15859: or upon revelation (theologia revelata). The former cogitates its
15860: object either by means of pure transcendental conceptions, as an ens
15861: originarium, realissimum, ens entium, and is termed transcendental
15862: theology; or, by means of a conception derived from the nature of our
15863: own mind, as a supreme intelligence, and must then be entitled natural
15864: theology. The person who believes in a transcendental theology alone,
15865: is termed a deist; he who acknowledges the possibility of a natural
15866: theology also, a theist. The former admits that we can cognize by pure
15867: reason alone the existence of a Supreme Being, but at the same time
15868: maintains that our conception of this being is purely transcendental,
15869: and that all we can say of it is that it possesses all reality, without
15870: being able to define it more closely. The second asserts that reason is
15871: capable of presenting us, from the analogy with nature, with a more
15872: definite conception of this being, and that its operations, as the
15873: cause of all things, are the results of intelligence and free will. The
15874: former regards the Supreme Being as the cause of the world—whether by
15875: the necessity of his nature, or as a free agent, is left undetermined;
15876: the latter considers this being as the author of the world.
15877: 
15878: Transcendental theology aims either at inferring the existence of a
15879: Supreme Being from a general experience, without any closer reference
15880: to the world to which this experience belongs, and in this case it is
15881: called cosmotheology; or it endeavours to cognize the existence of such
15882: a being, through mere conceptions, without the aid of experience, and
15883: is then termed ontotheology.
15884: 
15885: Natural theology infers the attributes and the existence of an author
15886: of the world, from the constitution of, the order and unity observable
15887: in, the world, in which two modes of causality must be admitted to
15888: exist—those of nature and freedom. Thus it rises from this world to a
15889: supreme intelligence, either as the principle of all natural, or of all
15890: moral order and perfection. In the former case it is termed
15891: physico-theology, in the latter, ethical or moral-theology.[69]
15892: 
15893:  [69] Not theological ethics; for this science contains ethical laws,
15894:  which presuppose the existence of a Supreme Governor of the world;
15895:  while moral-theology, on the contrary, is the expression of a
15896:  conviction of the existence of a Supreme Being, founded upon ethical
15897:  laws.
15898: 
15899: 
15900: As we are wont to understand by the term God not merely an eternal
15901: nature, the operations of which are insensate and blind, but a Supreme
15902: Being, who is the free and intelligent author of all things, and as it
15903: is this latter view alone that can be of interest to humanity, we
15904: might, in strict rigour, deny to the deist any belief in God at all,
15905: and regard him merely as a maintainer of the existence of a primal
15906: being or thing—the supreme cause of all other things. But, as no one
15907: ought to be blamed, merely because he does not feel himself justified
15908: in maintaining a certain opinion, as if he altogether denied its truth
15909: and asserted the opposite, it is more correct—as it is less harsh—to
15910: say, the deist believes in a God, the theist in a living God (summa
15911: intelligentia). We shall now proceed to investigate the sources of all
15912: these attempts of reason to establish the existence of a Supreme Being.
15913: 
15914: It may be sufficient in this place to define theoretical knowledge or
15915: cognition as knowledge of that which is, and practical knowledge as
15916: knowledge of that which ought to be. In this view, the theoretical
15917: employment of reason is that by which I cognize à priori (as necessary)
15918: that something is, while the practical is that by which I cognize à
15919: priori what ought to happen. Now, if it is an indubitably certain,
15920: though at the same time an entirely conditioned truth, that something
15921: is, or ought to happen, either a certain determinate condition of this
15922: truth is absolutely necessary, or such a condition may be arbitrarily
15923: presupposed. In the former case the condition is postulated (per
15924: thesin), in the latter supposed (per hypothesin). There are certain
15925: practical laws—those of morality—which are absolutely necessary. Now,
15926: if these laws necessarily presuppose the existence of some being, as
15927: the condition of the possibility of their obligatory power, this being
15928: must be postulated, because the conditioned, from which we reason to
15929: this determinate condition, is itself cognized à priori as absolutely
15930: necessary. We shall at some future time show that the moral laws not
15931: merely presuppose the existence of a Supreme Being, but also, as
15932: themselves absolutely necessary in a different relation, demand or
15933: postulate it—although only from a practical point of view. The
15934: discussion of this argument we postpone for the present.
15935: 
15936: When the question relates merely to that which is, not to that which
15937: ought to be, the conditioned which is presented in experience is always
15938: cogitated as contingent. For this reason its condition cannot be
15939: regarded as absolutely necessary, but merely as relatively necessary,
15940: or rather as needful; the condition is in itself and à priori a mere
15941: arbitrary presupposition in aid of the cognition, by reason, of the
15942: conditioned. If, then, we are to possess a theoretical cognition of the
15943: absolute necessity of a thing, we cannot attain to this cognition
15944: otherwise than à priori by means of conceptions; while it is impossible
15945: in this way to cognize the existence of a cause which bears any
15946: relation to an existence given in experience.
15947: 
15948: Theoretical cognition is speculative when it relates to an object or
15949: certain conceptions of an object which is not given and cannot be
15950: discovered by means of experience. It is opposed to the cognition of
15951: nature, which concerns only those objects or predicates which can be
15952: presented in a possible experience.
15953: 
15954: The principle that everything which happens (the empirically
15955: contingent) must have a cause, is a principle of the cognition of
15956: nature, but not of speculative cognition. For, if we change it into an
15957: abstract principle, and deprive it of its reference to experience and
15958: the empirical, we shall find that it cannot with justice be regarded
15959: any longer as a synthetical proposition, and that it is impossible to
15960: discover any mode of transition from that which exists to something
15961: entirely different—termed cause. Nay, more, the conception of a cause
15962: likewise that of the contingent—loses, in this speculative mode of
15963: employing it, all significance, for its objective reality and meaning
15964: are comprehensible from experience alone.
15965: 
15966: When from the existence of the universe and the things in it the
15967: existence of a cause of the universe is inferred, reason is proceeding
15968: not in the natural, but in the speculative method. For the principle of
15969: the former enounces, not that things themselves or substances, but only
15970: that which happens or their states—as empirically contingent, have a
15971: cause: the assertion that the existence of substance itself is
15972: contingent is not justified by experience, it is the assertion of a
15973: reason employing its principles in a speculative manner. If, again, I
15974: infer from the form of the universe, from the way in which all things
15975: are connected and act and react upon each other, the existence of a
15976: cause entirely distinct from the universe—this would again be a
15977: judgement of purely speculative reason; because the object in this
15978: case—the cause—can never be an object of possible experience. In both
15979: these cases the principle of causality, which is valid only in the
15980: field of experience—useless and even meaningless beyond this region,
15981: would be diverted from its proper destination.
15982: 
15983: Now I maintain that all attempts of reason to establish a theology by
15984: the aid of speculation alone are fruitless, that the principles of
15985: reason as applied to nature do not conduct us to any theological
15986: truths, and, consequently, that a rational theology can have no
15987: existence, unless it is founded upon the laws of morality. For all
15988: synthetical principles of the understanding are valid only as immanent
15989: in experience; while the cognition of a Supreme Being necessitates
15990: their being employed transcendentally, and of this the understanding is
15991: quite incapable. If the empirical law of causality is to conduct us to
15992: a Supreme Being, this being must belong to the chain of empirical
15993: objects—in which case it would be, like all phenomena, itself
15994: conditioned. If the possibility of passing the limits of experience be
15995: admitted, by means of the dynamical law of the relation of an effect to
15996: its cause, what kind of conception shall we obtain by this procedure?
15997: Certainly not the conception of a Supreme Being, because experience
15998: never presents us with the greatest of all possible effects, and it is
15999: only an effect of this character that could witness to the existence of
16000: a corresponding cause. If, for the purpose of fully satisfying the
16001: requirements of Reason, we recognize her right to assert the existence
16002: of a perfect and absolutely necessary being, this can be admitted only
16003: from favour, and cannot be regarded as the result of irresistible
16004: demonstration. The physico-theological proof may add weight to
16005: others—if other proofs there are—by connecting speculation with
16006: experience; but in itself it rather prepares the mind for theological
16007: cognition, and gives it a right and natural direction, than establishes
16008: a sure foundation for theology.
16009: 
16010: It is now perfectly evident that transcendental questions admit only of
16011: transcendental answers—those presented à priori by pure conceptions
16012: without the least empirical admixture. But the question in the present
16013: case is evidently synthetical—it aims at the extension of our cognition
16014: beyond the bounds of experience—it requires an assurance respecting the
16015: existence of a being corresponding with the idea in our minds, to which
16016: no experience can ever be adequate. Now it has been abundantly proved
16017: that all à priori synthetical cognition is possible only as the
16018: expression of the formal conditions of a possible experience; and that
16019: the validity of all principles depends upon their immanence in the
16020: field of experience, that is, their relation to objects of empirical
16021: cognition or phenomena. Thus all transcendental procedure in reference
16022: to speculative theology is without result.
16023: 
16024: If any one prefers doubting the conclusiveness of the proofs of our
16025: analytic to losing the persuasion of the validity of these old and time
16026: honoured arguments, he at least cannot decline answering the
16027: question—how he can pass the limits of all possible experience by the
16028: help of mere ideas. If he talks of new arguments, or of improvements
16029: upon old arguments, I request him to spare me. There is certainly no
16030: great choice in this sphere of discussion, as all speculative arguments
16031: must at last look for support to the ontological, and I have,
16032: therefore, very little to fear from the argumentative fecundity of the
16033: dogmatical defenders of a non-sensuous reason. Without looking upon
16034: myself as a remarkably combative person, I shall not decline the
16035: challenge to detect the fallacy and destroy the pretensions of every
16036: attempt of speculative theology. And yet the hope of better fortune
16037: never deserts those who are accustomed to the dogmatical mode of
16038: procedure. I shall, therefore, restrict myself to the simple and
16039: equitable demand that such reasoners will demonstrate, from the nature
16040: of the human mind as well as from that of the other sources of
16041: knowledge, how we are to proceed to extend our cognition completely à
16042: priori, and to carry it to that point where experience abandons us, and
16043: no means exist of guaranteeing the objective reality of our
16044: conceptions. In whatever way the understanding may have attained to a
16045: conception, the existence of the object of the conception cannot be
16046: discovered in it by analysis, because the cognition of the existence of
16047: the object depends upon the object’s being posited and given in itself
16048: apart from the conception. But it is utterly impossible to go beyond
16049: our conception, without the aid of experience—which presents to the
16050: mind nothing but phenomena, or to attain by the help of mere
16051: conceptions to a conviction of the existence of new kinds of objects or
16052: supernatural beings.
16053: 
16054: But although pure speculative reason is far from sufficient to
16055: demonstrate the existence of a Supreme Being, it is of the highest
16056: utility in correcting our conception of this being—on the supposition
16057: that we can attain to the cognition of it by some other means—in making
16058: it consistent with itself and with all other conceptions of
16059: intelligible objects, clearing it from all that is incompatible with
16060: the conception of an ens summun, and eliminating from it all
16061: limitations or admixtures of empirical elements.
16062: 
16063: Transcendental theology is still therefore, notwithstanding its
16064: objective insufficiency, of importance in a negative respect; it is
16065: useful as a test of the procedure of reason when engaged with pure
16066: ideas, no other than a transcendental standard being in this case
16067: admissible. For if, from a practical point of view, the hypothesis of a
16068: Supreme and All-sufficient Being is to maintain its validity without
16069: opposition, it must be of the highest importance to define this
16070: conception in a correct and rigorous manner—as the transcendental
16071: conception of a necessary being, to eliminate all phenomenal elements
16072: (anthropomorphism in its most extended signification), and at the same
16073: time to overflow all contradictory assertions—be they atheistic,
16074: deistic, or anthropomorphic. This is of course very easy; as the same
16075: arguments which demonstrated the inability of human reason to affirm
16076: the existence of a Supreme Being must be alike sufficient to prove the
16077: invalidity of its denial. For it is impossible to gain from the pure
16078: speculation of reason demonstration that there exists no Supreme Being,
16079: as the ground of all that exists, or that this being possesses none of
16080: those properties which we regard as analogical with the dynamical
16081: qualities of a thinking being, or that, as the anthropomorphists would
16082: have us believe, it is subject to all the limitations which sensibility
16083: imposes upon those intelligences which exist in the world of
16084: experience.
16085: 
16086: A Supreme Being is, therefore, for the speculative reason, a mere
16087: ideal, though a faultless one—a conception which perfects and crowns
16088: the system of human cognition, but the objective reality of which can
16089: neither be proved nor disproved by pure reason. If this defect is ever
16090: supplied by a moral theology, the problematic transcendental theology
16091: which has preceded, will have been at least serviceable as
16092: demonstrating the mental necessity existing for the conception, by the
16093: complete determination of it which it has furnished, and the ceaseless
16094: testing of the conclusions of a reason often deceived by sense, and not
16095: always in harmony with its own ideas. The attributes of necessity,
16096: infinitude, unity, existence apart from the world (and not as a world
16097: soul), eternity (free from conditions of time), omnipresence (free from
16098: conditions of space), omnipotence, and others, are pure transcendental
16099: predicates; and thus the accurate conception of a Supreme Being, which
16100: every theology requires, is furnished by transcendental theology alone.
16101: 
16102: APPENDIX. Of the Regulative Employment of the Ideas of Pure Reason
16103: 
16104: The result of all the dialectical attempts of pure reason not only
16105: confirms the truth of what we have already proved in our Transcendental
16106: Analytic, namely, that all inferences which would lead us beyond the
16107: limits of experience are fallacious and groundless, but it at the same
16108: time teaches us this important lesson, that human reason has a natural
16109: inclination to overstep these limits, and that transcendental ideas are
16110: as much the natural property of the reason as categories are of the
16111: understanding. There exists this difference, however, that while the
16112: categories never mislead us, outward objects being always in perfect
16113: harmony therewith, ideas are the parents of irresistible illusions, the
16114: severest and most subtle criticism being required to save us from the
16115: fallacies which they induce.
16116: 
16117: Whatever is grounded in the nature of our powers will be found to be in
16118: harmony with the final purpose and proper employment of these powers,
16119: when once we have discovered their true direction and aim. We are
16120: entitled to suppose, therefore, that there exists a mode of employing
16121: transcendental ideas which is proper and immanent; although, when we
16122: mistake their meaning, and regard them as conceptions of actual things,
16123: their mode of application is transcendent and delusive. For it is not
16124: the idea itself, but only the employment of the idea in relation to
16125: possible experience, that is transcendent or immanent. An idea is
16126: employed transcendently, when it is applied to an object falsely
16127: believed to be adequate with and to correspond to it; imminently, when
16128: it is applied solely to the employment of the understanding in the
16129: sphere of experience. Thus all errors of subreptio—of misapplication,
16130: are to be ascribed to defects of judgement, and not to understanding or
16131: reason.
16132: 
16133: Reason never has an immediate relation to an object; it relates
16134: immediately to the understanding alone. It is only through the
16135: understanding that it can be employed in the field of experience. It
16136: does not form conceptions of objects, it merely arranges them and gives
16137: to them that unity which they are capable of possessing when the sphere
16138: of their application has been extended as widely as possible. Reason
16139: avails itself of the conception of the understanding for the sole
16140: purpose of producing totality in the different series. This totality
16141: the understanding does not concern itself with; its only occupation is
16142: the connection of experiences, by which series of conditions in
16143: accordance with conceptions are established. The object of reason is,
16144: therefore, the understanding and its proper destination. As the latter
16145: brings unity into the diversity of objects by means of its conceptions,
16146: so the former brings unity into the diversity of conceptions by means
16147: of ideas; as it sets the final aim of a collective unity to the
16148: operations of the understanding, which without this occupies itself
16149: with a distributive unity alone.
16150: 
16151: I accordingly maintain that transcendental ideas can never be employed
16152: as constitutive ideas, that they cannot be conceptions of objects, and
16153: that, when thus considered, they assume a fallacious and dialectical
16154: character. But, on the other hand, they are capable of an admirable and
16155: indispensably necessary application to objects—as regulative ideas,
16156: directing the understanding to a certain aim, the guiding lines towards
16157: which all its laws follow, and in which they all meet in one point.
16158: This point—though a mere idea (focus imaginarius), that is, not a point
16159: from which the conceptions of the understanding do really proceed, for
16160: it lies beyond the sphere of possible experience—serves,
16161: notwithstanding, to give to these conceptions the greatest possible
16162: unity combined with the greatest possible extension. Hence arises the
16163: natural illusion which induces us to believe that these lines proceed
16164: from an object which lies out of the sphere of empirical cognition,
16165: just as objects reflected in a mirror appear to be behind it. But this
16166: illusion—which we may hinder from imposing upon us—is necessary and
16167: unavoidable, if we desire to see, not only those objects which lie
16168: before us, but those which are at a great distance behind us; that is
16169: to say, when, in the present case, we direct the aims of the
16170: understanding, beyond every given experience, towards an extension as
16171: great as can possibly be attained.
16172: 
16173: If we review our cognitions in their entire extent, we shall find that
16174: the peculiar business of reason is to arrange them into a system, that
16175: is to say, to give them connection according to a principle. This unity
16176: presupposes an idea—the idea of the form of a whole (of cognition),
16177: preceding the determinate cognition of the parts, and containing the
16178: conditions which determine à priori to every part its place and
16179: relation to the other parts of the whole system. This idea,
16180: accordingly, demands complete unity in the cognition of the
16181: understanding—not the unity of a contingent aggregate, but that of a
16182: system connected according to necessary laws. It cannot be affirmed
16183: with propriety that this idea is a conception of an object; it is
16184: merely a conception of the complete unity of the conceptions of
16185: objects, in so far as this unity is available to the understanding as a
16186: rule. Such conceptions of reason are not derived from nature; on the
16187: contrary, we employ them for the interrogation and investigation of
16188: nature, and regard our cognition as defective so long as it is not
16189: adequate to them. We admit that such a thing as pure earth, pure water,
16190: or pure air, is not to be discovered. And yet we require these
16191: conceptions (which have their origin in the reason, so far as regards
16192: their absolute purity and completeness) for the purpose of determining
16193: the share which each of these natural causes has in every phenomenon.
16194: Thus the different kinds of matter are all referred to earths, as mere
16195: weight; to salts and inflammable bodies, as pure force; and finally, to
16196: water and air, as the vehicula of the former, or the machines employed
16197: by them in their operations—for the purpose of explaining the chemical
16198: action and reaction of bodies in accordance with the idea of a
16199: mechanism. For, although not actually so expressed, the influence of
16200: such ideas of reason is very observable in the procedure of natural
16201: philosophers.
16202: 
16203: If reason is the faculty of deducing the particular from the general,
16204: and if the general be certain in se and given, it is only necessary
16205: that the judgement should subsume the particular under the general, the
16206: particular being thus necessarily determined. I shall term this the
16207: demonstrative or apodeictic employment of reason. If, however, the
16208: general is admitted as problematical only, and is a mere idea, the
16209: particular case is certain, but the universality of the rule which
16210: applies to this particular case remains a problem. Several particular
16211: cases, the certainty of which is beyond doubt, are then taken and
16212: examined, for the purpose of discovering whether the rule is applicable
16213: to them; and if it appears that all the particular cases which can be
16214: collected follow from the rule, its universality is inferred, and at
16215: the same time, all the causes which have not, or cannot be presented to
16216: our observation, are concluded to be of the same character with those
16217: which we have observed. This I shall term the hypothetical employment
16218: of the reason.
16219: 
16220: The hypothetical exercise of reason by the aid of ideas employed as
16221: problematical conceptions is properly not constitutive. That is to say,
16222: if we consider the subject strictly, the truth of the rule, which has
16223: been employed as an hypothesis, does not follow from the use that is
16224: made of it by reason. For how can we know all the possible cases that
16225: may arise? some of which may, however, prove exceptions to the
16226: universality of the rule. This employment of reason is merely
16227: regulative, and its sole aim is the introduction of unity into the
16228: aggregate of our particular cognitions, and thereby the approximating
16229: of the rule to universality.
16230: 
16231: The object of the hypothetical employment of reason is therefore the
16232: systematic unity of cognitions; and this unity is the criterion of the
16233: truth of a rule. On the other hand, this systematic unity—as a mere
16234: idea—is in fact merely a unity projected, not to be regarded as given,
16235: but only in the light of a problem—a problem which serves, however, as
16236: a principle for the various and particular exercise of the
16237: understanding in experience, directs it with regard to those cases
16238: which are not presented to our observation, and introduces harmony and
16239: consistency into all its operations.
16240: 
16241: All that we can be certain of from the above considerations is that
16242: this systematic unity is a logical principle, whose aim is to assist
16243: the understanding, where it cannot of itself attain to rules, by means
16244: of ideas, to bring all these various rules under one principle, and
16245: thus to ensure the most complete consistency and connection that can be
16246: attained. But the assertion that objects and the understanding by which
16247: they are cognized are so constituted as to be determined to systematic
16248: unity, that this may be postulated à priori, without any reference to
16249: the interest of reason, and that we are justified in declaring all
16250: possible cognitions—empirical and others—to possess systematic unity,
16251: and to be subject to general principles from which, notwithstanding
16252: their various character, they are all derivable such an assertion can
16253: be founded only upon a transcendental principle of reason, which would
16254: render this systematic unity not subjectively and logically—in its
16255: character of a method, but objectively necessary.
16256: 
16257: We shall illustrate this by an example. The conceptions of the
16258: understanding make us acquainted, among many other kinds of unity, with
16259: that of the causality of a substance, which is termed power. The
16260: different phenomenal manifestations of the same substance appear at
16261: first view to be so very dissimilar that we are inclined to assume the
16262: existence of just as many different powers as there are different
16263: effects—as, in the case of the human mind, we have feeling,
16264: consciousness, imagination, memory, wit, analysis, pleasure, desire and
16265: so on. Now we are required by a logical maxim to reduce these
16266: differences to as small a number as possible, by comparing them and
16267: discovering the hidden identity which exists. We must inquire, for
16268: example, whether or not imagination (connected with consciousness),
16269: memory, wit, and analysis are not merely different forms of
16270: understanding and reason. The idea of a fundamental power, the
16271: existence of which no effort of logic can assure us of, is the problem
16272: to be solved, for the systematic representation of the existing variety
16273: of powers. The logical principle of reason requires us to produce as
16274: great a unity as is possible in the system of our cognitions; and the
16275: more the phenomena of this and the other power are found to be
16276: identical, the more probable does it become, that they are nothing but
16277: different manifestations of one and the same power, which may be
16278: called, relatively speaking, a fundamental power. And so with other
16279: cases.
16280: 
16281: These relatively fundamental powers must again be compared with each
16282: other, to discover, if possible, the one radical and absolutely
16283: fundamental power of which they are but the manifestations. But this
16284: unity is purely hypothetical. It is not maintained, that this unity
16285: does really exist, but that we must, in the interest of reason, that
16286: is, for the establishment of principles for the various rules presented
16287: by experience, try to discover and introduce it, so far as is
16288: practicable, into the sphere of our cognitions.
16289: 
16290: But the transcendental employment of the understanding would lead us to
16291: believe that this idea of a fundamental power is not problematical, but
16292: that it possesses objective reality, and thus the systematic unity of
16293: the various powers or forces in a substance is demanded by the
16294: understanding and erected into an apodeictic or necessary principle.
16295: For, without having attempted to discover the unity of the various
16296: powers existing in nature, nay, even after all our attempts have
16297: failed, we notwithstanding presuppose that it does exist, and may be,
16298: sooner or later, discovered. And this reason does, not only, as in the
16299: case above adduced, with regard to the unity of substance, but where
16300: many substances, although all to a certain extent homogeneous, are
16301: discoverable, as in the case of matter in general. Here also does
16302: reason presuppose the existence of the systematic unity of various
16303: powers—inasmuch as particular laws of nature are subordinate to general
16304: laws; and parsimony in principles is not merely an economical principle
16305: of reason, but an essential law of nature.
16306: 
16307: We cannot understand, in fact, how a logical principle of unity can of
16308: right exist, unless we presuppose a transcendental principle, by which
16309: such a systematic unit—as a property of objects themselves—is regarded
16310: as necessary à priori. For with what right can reason, in its logical
16311: exercise, require us to regard the variety of forces which nature
16312: displays, as in effect a disguised unity, and to deduce them from one
16313: fundamental force or power, when she is free to admit that it is just
16314: as possible that all forces should be different in kind, and that a
16315: systematic unity is not conformable to the design of nature? In this
16316: view of the case, reason would be proceeding in direct opposition to
16317: her own destination, by setting as an aim an idea which entirely
16318: conflicts with the procedure and arrangement of nature. Neither can we
16319: assert that reason has previously inferred this unity from the
16320: contingent nature of phenomena. For the law of reason which requires us
16321: to seek for this unity is a necessary law, inasmuch as without it we
16322: should not possess a faculty of reason, nor without reason a consistent
16323: and self-accordant mode of employing the understanding, nor, in the
16324: absence of this, any proper and sufficient criterion of empirical
16325: truth. In relation to this criterion, therefore, we must suppose the
16326: idea of the systematic unity of nature to possess objective validity
16327: and necessity.
16328: 
16329: We find this transcendental presupposition lurking in different forms
16330: in the principles of philosophers, although they have neither
16331: recognized it nor confessed to themselves its presence. That the
16332: diversities of individual things do not exclude identity of species,
16333: that the various species must be considered as merely different
16334: determinations of a few genera, and these again as divisions of still
16335: higher races, and so on—that, accordingly, a certain systematic unity
16336: of all possible empirical conceptions, in so far as they can be deduced
16337: from higher and more general conceptions, must be sought for, is a
16338: scholastic maxim or logical principle, without which reason could not
16339: be employed by us. For we can infer the particular from the general,
16340: only in so far as general properties of things constitute the
16341: foundation upon which the particular rest.
16342: 
16343: That the same unity exists in nature is presupposed by philosophers in
16344: the well-known scholastic maxim, which forbids us unnecessarily to
16345: augment the number of entities or principles (entia praeter
16346: necessitatem non esse multiplicanda). This maxim asserts that nature
16347: herself assists in the establishment of this unity of reason, and that
16348: the seemingly infinite diversity of phenomena should not deter us from
16349: the expectation of discovering beneath this diversity a unity of
16350: fundamental properties, of which the aforesaid variety is but a more or
16351: less determined form. This unity, although a mere idea, thinkers have
16352: found it necessary rather to moderate the desire than to encourage it.
16353: It was considered a great step when chemists were able to reduce all
16354: salts to two main genera—acids and alkalis; and they regard this
16355: difference as itself a mere variety, or different manifestation of one
16356: and the same fundamental material. The different kinds of earths
16357: (stones and even metals) chemists have endeavoured to reduce to three,
16358: and afterwards to two; but still, not content with this advance, they
16359: cannot but think that behind these diversities there lurks but one
16360: genus—nay, that even salts and earths have a common principle. It might
16361: be conjectured that this is merely an economical plan of reason, for
16362: the purpose of sparing itself trouble, and an attempt of a purely
16363: hypothetical character, which, when successful, gives an appearance of
16364: probability to the principle of explanation employed by the reason. But
16365: a selfish purpose of this kind is easily to be distinguished from the
16366: idea, according to which every one presupposes that this unity is in
16367: accordance with the laws of nature, and that reason does not in this
16368: case request, but requires, although we are quite unable to determine
16369: the proper limits of this unity.
16370: 
16371: If the diversity existing in phenomena—a diversity not of form (for in
16372: this they may be similar) but of content—were so great that the
16373: subtlest human reason could never by comparison discover in them the
16374: least similarity (which is not impossible), in this case the logical
16375: law of genera would be without foundation, the conception of a genus,
16376: nay, all general conceptions would be impossible, and the faculty of
16377: the understanding, the exercise of which is restricted to the world of
16378: conceptions, could not exist. The logical principle of genera,
16379: accordingly, if it is to be applied to nature (by which I mean objects
16380: presented to our senses), presupposes a transcendental principle. In
16381: accordance with this principle, homogeneity is necessarily presupposed
16382: in the variety of phenomena (although we are unable to determine à
16383: priori the degree of this homogeneity), because without it no empirical
16384: conceptions, and consequently no experience, would be possible.
16385: 
16386: The logical principle of genera, which demands identity in phenomena,
16387: is balanced by another principle—that of species, which requires
16388: variety and diversity in things, notwithstanding their accordance in
16389: the same genus, and directs the understanding to attend to the one no
16390: less than to the other. This principle (of the faculty of distinction)
16391: acts as a check upon the reason and reason exhibits in this respect a
16392: double and conflicting interest—on the one hand, the interest in the
16393: extent (the interest of generality) in relation to genera; on the
16394: other, that of the content (the interest of individuality) in relation
16395: to the variety of species. In the former case, the understanding
16396: cogitates more under its conceptions, in the latter it cogitates more
16397: in them. This distinction manifests itself likewise in the habits of
16398: thought peculiar to natural philosophers, some of whom—the remarkably
16399: speculative heads—may be said to be hostile to heterogeneity in
16400: phenomena, and have their eyes always fixed on the unity of genera,
16401: while others—with a strong empirical tendency—aim unceasingly at the
16402: analysis of phenomena, and almost destroy in us the hope of ever being
16403: able to estimate the character of these according to general
16404: principles.
16405: 
16406: The latter mode of thought is evidently based upon a logical principle,
16407: the aim of which is the systematic completeness of all cognitions. This
16408: principle authorizes me, beginning at the genus, to descend to the
16409: various and diverse contained under it; and in this way extension, as
16410: in the former case unity, is assured to the system. For if we merely
16411: examine the sphere of the conception which indicates a genus, we cannot
16412: discover how far it is possible to proceed in the division of that
16413: sphere; just as it is impossible, from the consideration of the space
16414: occupied by matter, to determine how far we can proceed in the division
16415: of it. Hence every genus must contain different species, and these
16416: again different subspecies; and as each of the latter must itself
16417: contain a sphere (must be of a certain extent, as a conceptus
16418: communis), reason demands that no species or sub-species is to be
16419: considered as the lowest possible. For a species or sub-species, being
16420: always a conception, which contains only what is common to a number of
16421: different things, does not completely determine any individual thing,
16422: or relate immediately to it, and must consequently contain other
16423: conceptions, that is, other sub-species under it. This law of
16424: specification may be thus expressed: entium varietates non temere sunt
16425: minuendae.
16426: 
16427: But it is easy to see that this logical law would likewise be without
16428: sense or application, were it not based upon a transcendental law of
16429: specification, which certainly does not require that the differences
16430: existing phenomena should be infinite in number, for the logical
16431: principle, which merely maintains the indeterminateness of the logical
16432: sphere of a conception, in relation to its possible division, does not
16433: authorize this statement; while it does impose upon the understanding
16434: the duty of searching for subspecies to every species, and minor
16435: differences in every difference. For, were there no lower conceptions,
16436: neither could there be any higher. Now the understanding cognizes only
16437: by means of conceptions; consequently, how far soever it may proceed in
16438: division, never by mere intuition, but always by lower and lower
16439: conceptions. The cognition of phenomena in their complete determination
16440: (which is possible only by means of the understanding) requires an
16441: unceasingly continued specification of conceptions, and a progression
16442: to ever smaller differences, of which abstraction had been made in the
16443: conception of the species, and still more in that of the genus.
16444: 
16445: This law of specification cannot be deduced from experience; it can
16446: never present us with a principle of so universal an application.
16447: Empirical specification very soon stops in its distinction of
16448: diversities, and requires the guidance of the transcendental law, as a
16449: principle of the reason—a law which imposes on us the necessity of
16450: never ceasing in our search for differences, even although these may
16451: not present themselves to the senses. That absorbent earths are of
16452: different kinds could only be discovered by obeying the anticipatory
16453: law of reason, which imposes upon the understanding the task of
16454: discovering the differences existing between these earths, and supposes
16455: that nature is richer in substances than our senses would indicate. The
16456: faculty of the understanding belongs to us just as much under the
16457: presupposition of differences in the objects of nature, as under the
16458: condition that these objects are homogeneous, because we could not
16459: possess conceptions, nor make any use of our understanding, were not
16460: the phenomena included under these conceptions in some respects
16461: dissimilar, as well as similar, in their character.
16462: 
16463: Reason thus prepares the sphere of the understanding for the operations
16464: of this faculty: 1. By the principle of the homogeneity of the diverse
16465: in higher genera; 2. By the principle of the variety of the homogeneous
16466: in lower species; and, to complete the systematic unity, it adds, 3. A
16467: law of the affinity of all conceptions which prescribes a continuous
16468: transition from one species to every other by the gradual increase of
16469: diversity. We may term these the principles of the homogeneity, the
16470: specification, and the continuity of forms. The latter results from the
16471: union of the two former, inasmuch as we regard the systematic
16472: connection as complete in thought, in the ascent to higher genera, as
16473: well as in the descent to lower species. For all diversities must be
16474: related to each other, as they all spring from one highest genus,
16475: descending through the different gradations of a more and more extended
16476: determination.
16477: 
16478: We may illustrate the systematic unity produced by the three logical
16479: principles in the following manner. Every conception may be regarded as
16480: a point, which, as the standpoint of a spectator, has a certain
16481: horizon, which may be said to enclose a number of things that may be
16482: viewed, so to speak, from that centre. Within this horizon there must
16483: be an infinite number of other points, each of which has its own
16484: horizon, smaller and more circumscribed; in other words, every species
16485: contains sub-species, according to the principle of specification, and
16486: the logical horizon consists of smaller horizons (subspecies), but not
16487: of points (individuals), which possess no extent. But different
16488: horizons or genera, which include under them so many conceptions, may
16489: have one common horizon, from which, as from a mid-point, they may be
16490: surveyed; and we may proceed thus, till we arrive at the highest genus,
16491: or universal and true horizon, which is determined by the highest
16492: conception, and which contains under itself all differences and
16493: varieties, as genera, species, and subspecies.
16494: 
16495: To this highest standpoint I am conducted by the law of homogeneity, as
16496: to all lower and more variously-determined conceptions by the law of
16497: specification. Now as in this way there exists no void in the whole
16498: extent of all possible conceptions, and as out of the sphere of these
16499: the mind can discover nothing, there arises from the presupposition of
16500: the universal horizon above mentioned, and its complete division, the
16501: principle: Non datur vacuum formarum. This principle asserts that there
16502: are not different primitive and highest genera, which stand isolated,
16503: so to speak, from each other, but all the various genera are mere
16504: divisions and limitations of one highest and universal genus; and hence
16505: follows immediately the principle: Datur continuum formarum. This
16506: principle indicates that all differences of species limit each other,
16507: and do not admit of transition from one to another by a saltus, but
16508: only through smaller degrees of the difference between the one species
16509: and the other. In one word, there are no species or sub-species which
16510: (in the view of reason) are the nearest possible to each other;
16511: intermediate species or sub-species being always possible, the
16512: difference of which from each of the former is always smaller than the
16513: difference existing between these.
16514: 
16515: The first law, therefore, directs us to avoid the notion that there
16516: exist different primal genera, and enounces the fact of perfect
16517: homogeneity; the second imposes a check upon this tendency to unity and
16518: prescribes the distinction of sub-species, before proceeding to apply
16519: our general conceptions to individuals. The third unites both the
16520: former, by enouncing the fact of homogeneity as existing even in the
16521: most various diversity, by means of the gradual transition from one
16522: species to another. Thus it indicates a relationship between the
16523: different branches or species, in so far as they all spring from the
16524: same stem.
16525: 
16526: But this logical law of the continuum specierum (formarum logicarum)
16527: presupposes a transcendental principle (lex continui in natura),
16528: without which the understanding might be led into error, by following
16529: the guidance of the former, and thus perhaps pursuing a path contrary
16530: to that prescribed by nature. This law must, consequently, be based
16531: upon pure transcendental, and not upon empirical, considerations. For,
16532: in the latter case, it would come later than the system; whereas it is
16533: really itself the parent of all that is systematic in our cognition of
16534: nature. These principles are not mere hypotheses employed for the
16535: purpose of experimenting upon nature; although when any such connection
16536: is discovered, it forms a solid ground for regarding the hypothetical
16537: unity as valid in the sphere of nature—and thus they are in this
16538: respect not without their use. But we go farther, and maintain that it
16539: is manifest that these principles of parsimony in fundamental causes,
16540: variety in effects, and affinity in phenomena, are in accordance both
16541: with reason and nature, and that they are not mere methods or plans
16542: devised for the purpose of assisting us in our observation of the
16543: external world.
16544: 
16545: But it is plain that this continuity of forms is a mere idea, to which
16546: no adequate object can be discovered in experience. And this for two
16547: reasons. First, because the species in nature are really divided, and
16548: hence form quanta discreta; and, if the gradual progression through
16549: their affinity were continuous, the intermediate members lying between
16550: two given species must be infinite in number, which is impossible.
16551: Secondly, because we cannot make any determinate empirical use of this
16552: law, inasmuch as it does not present us with any criterion of affinity
16553: which could aid us in determining how far we ought to pursue the
16554: graduation of differences: it merely contains a general indication that
16555: it is our duty to seek for and, if possible, to discover them.
16556: 
16557: When we arrange these principles of systematic unity in the order
16558: conformable to their employment in experience, they will stand thus:
16559: Variety, Affinity, Unity, each of them, as ideas, being taken in the
16560: highest degree of their completeness. Reason presupposes the existence
16561: of cognitions of the understanding, which have a direct relation to
16562: experience, and aims at the ideal unity of these cognitions—a unity
16563: which far transcends all experience or empirical notions. The affinity
16564: of the diverse, notwithstanding the differences existing between its
16565: parts, has a relation to things, but a still closer one to the mere
16566: properties and powers of things. For example, imperfect experience may
16567: represent the orbits of the planets as circular. But we discover
16568: variations from this course, and we proceed to suppose that the planets
16569: revolve in a path which, if not a circle, is of a character very
16570: similar to it. That is to say, the movements of those planets which do
16571: not form a circle will approximate more or less to the properties of a
16572: circle, and probably form an ellipse. The paths of comets exhibit still
16573: greater variations, for, so far as our observation extends, they do not
16574: return upon their own course in a circle or ellipse. But we proceed to
16575: the conjecture that comets describe a parabola, a figure which is
16576: closely allied to the ellipse. In fact, a parabola is merely an
16577: ellipse, with its longer axis produced to an indefinite extent. Thus
16578: these principles conduct us to a unity in the genera of the forms of
16579: these orbits, and, proceeding farther, to a unity as regards the cause
16580: of the motions of the heavenly bodies—that is, gravitation. But we go
16581: on extending our conquests over nature, and endeavour to explain all
16582: seeming deviations from these rules, and even make additions to our
16583: system which no experience can ever substantiate—for example, the
16584: theory, in affinity with that of ellipses, of hyperbolic paths of
16585: comets, pursuing which, these bodies leave our solar system and,
16586: passing from sun to sun, unite the most distant parts of the infinite
16587: universe, which is held together by the same moving power.
16588: 
16589: The most remarkable circumstance connected with these principles is
16590: that they seem to be transcendental, and, although only containing
16591: ideas for the guidance of the empirical exercise of reason, and
16592: although this empirical employment stands to these ideas in an
16593: asymptotic relation alone (to use a mathematical term), that is,
16594: continually approximate, without ever being able to attain to them,
16595: they possess, notwithstanding, as à priori synthetical propositions,
16596: objective though undetermined validity, and are available as rules for
16597: possible experience. In the elaboration of our experience, they may
16598: also be employed with great advantage, as heuristic[70] principles. A
16599: transcendental deduction of them cannot be made; such a deduction being
16600: always impossible in the case of ideas, as has been already shown.
16601: 
16602:  [70] From the Greek, eurhioko.
16603: 
16604: 
16605: We distinguished, in the Transcendental Analytic, the dynamical
