16606: principles of the understanding, which are regulative principles of
16607: intuition, from the mathematical, which are constitutive principles of
16608: intuition. These dynamical laws are, however, constitutive in relation
16609: to experience, inasmuch as they render the conceptions without which
16610: experience could not exist possible à priori. But the principles of
16611: pure reason cannot be constitutive even in regard to empirical
16612: conceptions, because no sensuous schema corresponding to them can be
16613: discovered, and they cannot therefore have an object in concreto. Now,
16614: if I grant that they cannot be employed in the sphere of experience, as
16615: constitutive principles, how shall I secure for them employment and
16616: objective validity as regulative principles, and in what way can they
16617: be so employed?
16618: 
16619: The understanding is the object of reason, as sensibility is the object
16620: of the understanding. The production of systematic unity in all the
16621: empirical operations of the understanding is the proper occupation of
16622: reason; just as it is the business of the understanding to connect the
16623: various content of phenomena by means of conceptions, and subject them
16624: to empirical laws. But the operations of the understanding are, without
16625: the schemata of sensibility, undetermined; and, in the same manner, the
16626: unity of reason is perfectly undetermined as regards the conditions
16627: under which, and the extent to which, the understanding ought to carry
16628: the systematic connection of its conceptions. But, although it is
16629: impossible to discover in intuition a schema for the complete
16630: systematic unity of all the conceptions of the understanding, there
16631: must be some analogon of this schema. This analogon is the idea of the
16632: maximum of the division and the connection of our cognition in one
16633: principle. For we may have a determinate notion of a maximum and an
16634: absolutely perfect, all the restrictive conditions which are connected
16635: with an indeterminate and various content having been abstracted. Thus
16636: the idea of reason is analogous with a sensuous schema, with this
16637: difference, that the application of the categories to the schema of
16638: reason does not present a cognition of any object (as is the case with
16639: the application of the categories to sensuous schemata), but merely
16640: provides us with a rule or principle for the systematic unity of the
16641: exercise of the understanding. Now, as every principle which imposes
16642: upon the exercise of the understanding à priori compliance with the
16643: rule of systematic unity also relates, although only in an indirect
16644: manner, to an object of experience, the principles of pure reason will
16645: also possess objective reality and validity in relation to experience.
16646: But they will not aim at determining our knowledge in regard to any
16647: empirical object; they will merely indicate the procedure, following
16648: which the empirical and determinate exercise of the understanding may
16649: be in complete harmony and connection with itself—a result which is
16650: produced by its being brought into harmony with the principle of
16651: systematic unity, so far as that is possible, and deduced from it.
16652: 
16653: I term all subjective principles, which are not derived from
16654: observation of the constitution of an object, but from the interest
16655: which Reason has in producing a certain completeness in her cognition
16656: of that object, maxims of reason. Thus there are maxims of speculative
16657: reason, which are based solely upon its speculative interest, although
16658: they appear to be objective principles.
16659: 
16660: When principles which are really regulative are regarded as
16661: constitutive, and employed as objective principles, contradictions must
16662: arise; but if they are considered as mere maxims, there is no room for
16663: contradictions of any kind, as they then merely indicate the different
16664: interests of reason, which occasion differences in the mode of thought.
16665: In effect, Reason has only one single interest, and the seeming
16666: contradiction existing between her maxims merely indicates a difference
16667: in, and a reciprocal limitation of, the methods by which this interest
16668: is satisfied.
16669: 
16670: This reasoner has at heart the interest of diversity—in accordance with
16671: the principle of specification; another, the interest of unity—in
16672: accordance with the principle of aggregation. Each believes that his
16673: judgement rests upon a thorough insight into the subject he is
16674: examining, and yet it has been influenced solely by a greater or less
16675: degree of adherence to some one of the two principles, neither of which
16676: are objective, but originate solely from the interest of reason, and on
16677: this account to be termed maxims rather than principles. When I observe
16678: intelligent men disputing about the distinctive characteristics of men,
16679: animals, or plants, and even of minerals, those on the one side
16680: assuming the existence of certain national characteristics, certain
16681: well-defined and hereditary distinctions of family, race, and so on,
16682: while the other side maintain that nature has endowed all races of men
16683: with the same faculties and dispositions, and that all differences are
16684: but the result of external and accidental circumstances—I have only to
16685: consider for a moment the real nature of the subject of discussion, to
16686: arrive at the conclusion that it is a subject far too deep for us to
16687: judge of, and that there is little probability of either party being
16688: able to speak from a perfect insight into and understanding of the
16689: nature of the subject itself. Both have, in reality, been struggling
16690: for the twofold interest of reason; the one maintaining the one
16691: interest, the other the other. But this difference between the maxims
16692: of diversity and unity may easily be reconciled and adjusted; although,
16693: so long as they are regarded as objective principles, they must
16694: occasion not only contradictions and polemic, but place hinderances in
16695: the way of the advancement of truth, until some means is discovered of
16696: reconciling these conflicting interests, and bringing reason into union
16697: and harmony with itself.
16698: 
16699: The same is the case with the so-called law discovered by Leibnitz, and
16700: supported with remarkable ability by Bonnet—the law of the continuous
16701: gradation of created beings, which is nothing more than an inference
16702: from the principle of affinity; for observation and study of the order
16703: of nature could never present it to the mind as an objective truth. The
16704: steps of this ladder, as they appear in experience, are too far apart
16705: from each other, and the so-called petty differences between different
16706: kinds of animals are in nature commonly so wide separations that no
16707: confidence can be placed in such views (particularly when we reflect on
16708: the great variety of things, and the ease with which we can discover
16709: resemblances), and no faith in the laws which are said to express the
16710: aims and purposes of nature. On the other hand, the method of
16711: investigating the order of nature in the light of this principle, and
16712: the maxim which requires us to regard this order—it being still
16713: undetermined how far it extends—as really existing in nature, is beyond
16714: doubt a legitimate and excellent principle of reason—a principle which
16715: extends farther than any experience or observation of ours and which,
16716: without giving us any positive knowledge of anything in the region of
16717: experience, guides us to the goal of systematic unity.
16718: 
16719: _Of the Ultimate End of the Natural Dialectic of Human Reason._
16720: 
16721: The ideas of pure reason cannot be, of themselves and in their own
16722: nature, dialectical; it is from their misemployment alone that
16723: fallacies and illusions arise. For they originate in the nature of
16724: reason itself, and it is impossible that this supreme tribunal for all
16725: the rights and claims of speculation should be itself undeserving of
16726: confidence and promotive of error. It is to be expected, therefore,
16727: that these ideas have a genuine and legitimate aim. It is true, the mob
16728: of sophists raise against reason the cry of inconsistency and
16729: contradiction, and affect to despise the government of that faculty,
16730: because they cannot understand its constitution, while it is to its
16731: beneficial influences alone that they owe the position and the
16732: intelligence which enable them to criticize and to blame its procedure.
16733: 
16734: We cannot employ an à priori conception with certainty, until we have
16735: made a transcendental deduction therefore. The ideas of pure reason do
16736: not admit of the same kind of deduction as the categories. But if they
16737: are to possess the least objective validity, and to represent anything
16738: but mere creations of thought (entia rationis ratiocinantis), a
16739: deduction of them must be possible. This deduction will complete the
16740: critical task imposed upon pure reason; and it is to this part Of our
16741: labours that we now proceed.
16742: 
16743: There is a great difference between a thing’s being presented to the
16744: mind as an object in an absolute sense, or merely as an ideal object.
16745: In the former case I employ my conceptions to determine the object; in
16746: the latter case nothing is present to the mind but a mere schema, which
16747: does not relate directly to an object, not even in a hypothetical
16748: sense, but which is useful only for the purpose of representing other
16749: objects to the mind, in a mediate and indirect manner, by means of
16750: their relation to the idea in the intellect. Thus I say the conception
16751: of a supreme intelligence is a mere idea; that is to say, its objective
16752: reality does not consist in the fact that it has an immediate relation
16753: to an object (for in this sense we have no means of establishing its
16754: objective validity), it is merely a schema constructed according to the
16755: necessary conditions of the unity of reason—the schema of a thing in
16756: general, which is useful towards the production of the highest degree
16757: of systematic unity in the empirical exercise of reason, in which we
16758: deduce this or that object of experience from the imaginary object of
16759: this idea, as the ground or cause of the said object of experience. In
16760: this way, the idea is properly a heuristic, and not an ostensive,
16761: conception; it does not give us any information respecting the
16762: constitution of an object, it merely indicates how, under the guidance
16763: of the idea, we ought to investigate the constitution and the relations
16764: of objects in the world of experience. Now, if it can be shown that the
16765: three kinds of transcendental ideas (psychological, cosmological, and
16766: theological), although not relating directly to any object nor
16767: determining it, do nevertheless, on the supposition of the existence of
16768: an ideal object, produce systematic unity in the laws of the empirical
16769: employment of the reason, and extend our empirical cognition, without
16770: ever being inconsistent or in opposition with it—it must be a necessary
16771: maxim of reason to regulate its procedure according to these ideas. And
16772: this forms the transcendental deduction of all speculative ideas, not
16773: as constitutive principles of the extension of our cognition beyond the
16774: limits of our experience, but as regulative principles of the
16775: systematic unity of empirical cognition, which is by the aid of these
16776: ideas arranged and emended within its own proper limits, to an extent
16777: unattainable by the operation of the principles of the understanding
16778: alone.
16779: 
16780: I shall make this plainer. Guided by the principles involved in these
16781: ideas, we must, in the first place, so connect all the phenomena,
16782: actions, and feelings of the mind, as if it were a simple substance,
16783: which, endowed with personal identity, possesses a permanent existence
16784: (in this life at least), while its states, among which those of the
16785: body are to be included as external conditions, are in continual
16786: change. Secondly, in cosmology, we must investigate the conditions of
16787: all natural phenomena, internal as well as external, as if they
16788: belonged to a chain infinite and without any prime or supreme member,
16789: while we do not, on this account, deny the existence of intelligible
16790: grounds of these phenomena, although we never employ them to explain
16791: phenomena, for the simple reason that they are not objects of our
16792: cognition. Thirdly, in the sphere of theology, we must regard the whole
16793: system of possible experience as forming an absolute, but dependent and
16794: sensuously-conditioned unity, and at the same time as based upon a
16795: sole, supreme, and all-sufficient ground existing apart from the world
16796: itself—a ground which is a self-subsistent, primeval and creative
16797: reason, in relation to which we so employ our reason in the field of
16798: experience, as if all objects drew their origin from that archetype of
16799: all reason. In other words, we ought not to deduce the internal
16800: phenomena of the mind from a simple thinking substance, but deduce them
16801: from each other under the guidance of the regulative idea of a simple
16802: being; we ought not to deduce the phenomena, order, and unity of the
16803: universe from a supreme intelligence, but merely draw from this idea of
16804: a supremely wise cause the rules which must guide reason in its
16805: connection of causes and effects.
16806: 
16807: Now there is nothing to hinder us from admitting these ideas to possess
16808: an objective and hyperbolic existence, except the cosmological ideas,
16809: which lead reason into an antinomy: the psychological and theological
16810: ideas are not antinomial. They contain no contradiction; and how, then,
16811: can any one dispute their objective reality, since he who denies it
16812: knows as little about their possibility as we who affirm? And yet, when
16813: we wish to admit the existence of a thing, it is not sufficient to
16814: convince ourselves that there is no positive obstacle in the way; for
16815: it cannot be allowable to regard mere creations of thought, which
16816: transcend, though they do not contradict, all our conceptions, as real
16817: and determinate objects, solely upon the authority of a speculative
16818: reason striving to compass its own aims. They cannot, therefore, be
16819: admitted to be real in themselves; they can only possess a comparative
16820: reality—that of a schema of the regulative principle of the systematic
16821: unity of all cognition. They are to be regarded not as actual things,
16822: but as in some measure analogous to them. We abstract from the object
16823: of the idea all the conditions which limit the exercise of our
16824: understanding, but which, on the other hand, are the sole conditions of
16825: our possessing a determinate conception of any given thing. And thus we
16826: cogitate a something, of the real nature of which we have not the least
16827: conception, but which we represent to ourselves as standing in a
16828: relation to the whole system of phenomena, analogous to that in which
16829: phenomena stand to each other.
16830: 
16831: By admitting these ideal beings, we do not really extend our cognitions
16832: beyond the objects of possible experience; we extend merely the
16833: empirical unity of our experience, by the aid of systematic unity, the
16834: schema of which is furnished by the idea, which is therefore valid—not
16835: as a constitutive, but as a regulative principle. For although we posit
16836: a thing corresponding to the idea—a something, an actual existence—we
16837: do not on that account aim at the extension of our cognition by means
16838: of transcendent conceptions. This existence is purely ideal, and not
16839: objective; it is the mere expression of the systematic unity which is
16840: to be the guide of reason in the field of experience. There are no
16841: attempts made at deciding what the ground of this unity may be, or what
16842: the real nature of this imaginary being.
16843: 
16844: Thus the transcendental and only determinate conception of God, which
16845: is presented to us by speculative reason, is in the strictest sense
16846: deistic. In other words, reason does not assure us of the objective
16847: validity of the conception; it merely gives us the idea of something,
16848: on which the supreme and necessary unity of all experience is based.
16849: This something we cannot, following the analogy of a real substance,
16850: cogitate otherwise than as the cause of all things operating in
16851: accordance with rational laws, if we regard it as an individual object;
16852: although we should rest contented with the idea alone as a regulative
16853: principle of reason, and make no attempt at completing the sum of the
16854: conditions imposed by thought. This attempt is, indeed, inconsistent
16855: with the grand aim of complete systematic unity in the sphere of
16856: cognition—a unity to which no bounds are set by reason.
16857: 
16858: Hence it happens that, admitting a divine being, I can have no
16859: conception of the internal possibility of its perfection, or of the
16860: necessity of its existence. The only advantage of this admission is
16861: that it enables me to answer all other questions relating to the
16862: contingent, and to give reason the most complete satisfaction as
16863: regards the unity which it aims at attaining in the world of
16864: experience. But I cannot satisfy reason with regard to this hypothesis
16865: itself; and this proves that it is not its intelligence and insight
16866: into the subject, but its speculative interest alone which induces it
16867: to proceed from a point lying far beyond the sphere of our cognition,
16868: for the purpose of being able to consider all objects as parts of a
16869: systematic whole.
16870: 
16871: Here a distinction presents itself, in regard to the way in which we
16872: may cogitate a presupposition—a distinction which is somewhat subtle,
16873: but of great importance in transcendental philosophy. I may have
16874: sufficient grounds to admit something, or the existence of something,
16875: in a relative point of view (suppositio relativa), without being
16876: justified in admitting it in an absolute sense (suppositio absoluta).
16877: This distinction is undoubtedly requisite, in the case of a regulative
16878: principle, the necessity of which we recognize, though we are ignorant
16879: of the source and cause of that necessity, and which we assume to be
16880: based upon some ultimate ground, for the purpose of being able to
16881: cogitate the universality of the principle in a more determinate way.
16882: For example, I cogitate the existence of a being corresponding to a
16883: pure transcendental idea. But I cannot admit that this being exists
16884: absolutely and in itself, because all of the conceptions by which I can
16885: cogitate an object in a determinate manner fall short of assuring me of
16886: its existence; nay, the conditions of the objective validity of my
16887: conceptions are excluded by the idea—by the very fact of its being an
16888: idea. The conceptions of reality, substance, causality, nay, even that
16889: of necessity in existence, have no significance out of the sphere of
16890: empirical cognition, and cannot, beyond that sphere, determine any
16891: object. They may, accordingly, be employed to explain the possibility
16892: of things in the world of sense, but they are utterly inadequate to
16893: explain the possibility of the universe itself considered as a whole;
16894: because in this case the ground of explanation must lie out of and
16895: beyond the world, and cannot, therefore, be an object of possible
16896: experience. Now, I may admit the existence of an incomprehensible being
16897: of this nature—the object of a mere idea, relatively to the world of
16898: sense; although I have no ground to admit its existence absolutely and
16899: in itself. For if an idea (that of a systematic and complete unity, of
16900: which I shall presently speak more particularly) lies at the foundation
16901: of the most extended empirical employment of reason, and if this idea
16902: cannot be adequately represented in concreto, although it is
16903: indispensably necessary for the approximation of empirical unity to the
16904: highest possible degree—I am not only authorized, but compelled, to
16905: realize this idea, that is, to posit a real object corresponding
16906: thereto. But I cannot profess to know this object; it is to me merely a
16907: something, to which, as the ground of systematic unity in cognition, I
16908: attribute such properties as are analogous to the conceptions employed
16909: by the understanding in the sphere of experience. Following the analogy
16910: of the notions of reality, substance, causality, and necessity, I
16911: cogitate a being, which possesses all these attributes in the highest
16912: degree; and, as this idea is the offspring of my reason alone, I
16913: cogitate this being as self-subsistent reason, and as the cause of the
16914: universe operating by means of ideas of the greatest possible harmony
16915: and unity. Thus I abstract all conditions that would limit my idea,
16916: solely for the purpose of rendering systematic unity possible in the
16917: world of empirical diversity, and thus securing the widest possible
16918: extension for the exercise of reason in that sphere. This I am enabled
16919: to do, by regarding all connections and relations in the world of
16920: sense, as if they were the dispositions of a supreme reason, of which
16921: our reason is but a faint image. I then proceed to cogitate this
16922: Supreme Being by conceptions which have, properly, no meaning or
16923: application, except in the world of sense. But as I am authorized to
16924: employ the transcendental hypothesis of such a being in a relative
16925: respect alone, that is, as the substratum of the greatest possible
16926: unity in experience—I may attribute to a being which I regard as
16927: distinct from the world, such properties as belong solely to the sphere
16928: of sense and experience. For I do not desire, and am not justified in
16929: desiring, to cognize this object of my idea, as it exists in itself;
16930: for I possess no conceptions sufficient for this task, those of
16931: reality, substance, causality, nay, even that of necessity in
16932: existence, losing all significance, and becoming merely the signs of
16933: conceptions, without content and without applicability, when I attempt
16934: to carry them beyond the limits of the world of sense. I cogitate
16935: merely the relation of a perfectly unknown being to the greatest
16936: possible systematic unity of experience, solely for the purpose of
16937: employing it as the schema of the regulative principle which directs
16938: reason in its empirical exercise.
16939: 
16940: It is evident, at the first view, that we cannot presuppose the reality
16941: of this transcendental object, by means of the conceptions of reality,
16942: substance, causality, and so on, because these conceptions cannot be
16943: applied to anything that is distinct from the world of sense. Thus the
16944: supposition of a Supreme Being or cause is purely relative; it is
16945: cogitated only in behalf of the systematic unity of experience; such a
16946: being is but a something, of whose existence in itself we have not the
16947: least conception. Thus, too, it becomes sufficiently manifest why we
16948: required the idea of a necessary being in relation to objects given by
16949: sense, although we can never have the least conception of this being,
16950: or of its absolute necessity.
16951: 
16952: And now we can clearly perceive the result of our transcendental
16953: dialectic, and the proper aim of the ideas of pure reason—which become
16954: dialectical solely from misunderstanding and inconsiderateness. Pure
16955: reason is, in fact, occupied with itself, and not with any object.
16956: Objects are not presented to it to be embraced in the unity of an
16957: empirical conception; it is only the cognitions of the understanding
16958: that are presented to it, for the purpose of receiving the unity of a
16959: rational conception, that is, of being connected according to a
16960: principle. The unity of reason is the unity of system; and this
16961: systematic unity is not an objective principle, extending its dominion
16962: over objects, but a subjective maxim, extending its authority over the
16963: empirical cognition of objects. The systematic connection which reason
16964: gives to the empirical employment of the understanding not only
16965: advances the extension of that employment, but ensures its correctness,
16966: and thus the principle of a systematic unity of this nature is also
16967: objective, although only in an indefinite respect (principium vagum).
16968: It is not, however, a constitutive principle, determining an object to
16969: which it directly relates; it is merely a regulative principle or
16970: maxim, advancing and strengthening the empirical exercise of reason, by
16971: the opening up of new paths of which the understanding is ignorant,
16972: while it never conflicts with the laws of its exercise in the sphere of
16973: experience.
16974: 
16975: But reason cannot cogitate this systematic unity, without at the same
16976: time cogitating an object of the idea—an object that cannot be
16977: presented in any experience, which contains no concrete example of a
16978: complete systematic unity. This being (ens rationis ratiocinatae) is
16979: therefore a mere idea and is not assumed to be a thing which is real
16980: absolutely and in itself. On the contrary, it forms merely the
16981: problematical foundation of the connection which the mind introduces
16982: among the phenomena of the sensuous world. We look upon this
16983: connection, in the light of the above-mentioned idea, as if it drew its
16984: origin from the supposed being which corresponds to the idea. And yet
16985: all we aim at is the possession of this idea as a secure foundation for
16986: the systematic unity of experience—a unity indispensable to reason,
16987: advantageous to the understanding, and promotive of the interests of
16988: empirical cognition.
16989: 
16990: We mistake the true meaning of this idea when we regard it as an
16991: enouncement, or even as a hypothetical declaration of the existence of
16992: a real thing, which we are to regard as the origin or ground of a
16993: systematic constitution of the universe. On the contrary, it is left
16994: completely undetermined what the nature or properties of this so-called
16995: ground may be. The idea is merely to be adopted as a point of view,
16996: from which this unity, so essential to reason and so beneficial to the
16997: understanding, may be regarded as radiating. In one word, this
16998: transcendental thing is merely the schema of a regulative principle, by
16999: means of which Reason, so far as in her lies, extends the dominion of
17000: systematic unity over the whole sphere of experience.
17001: 
17002: The first object of an idea of this kind is the ego, considered merely
17003: as a thinking nature or soul. If I wish to investigate the properties
17004: of a thinking being, I must interrogate experience. But I find that I
17005: can apply none of the categories to this object, the schema of these
17006: categories, which is the condition of their application, being given
17007: only in sensuous intuition. But I cannot thus attain to the cognition
17008: of a systematic unity of all the phenomena of the internal sense.
17009: Instead, therefore, of an empirical conception of what the soul really
17010: is, reason takes the conception of the empirical unity of all thought,
17011: and, by cogitating this unity as unconditioned and primitive,
17012: constructs the rational conception or idea of a simple substance which
17013: is in itself unchangeable, possessing personal identity, and in
17014: connection with other real things external to it; in one word, it
17015: constructs the idea of a simple self-subsistent intelligence. But the
17016: real aim of reason in this procedure is the attainment of principles of
17017: systematic unity for the explanation of the phenomena of the soul. That
17018: is, reason desires to be able to represent all the determinations of
17019: the internal sense as existing in one subject, all powers as deduced
17020: from one fundamental power, all changes as mere varieties in the
17021: condition of a being which is permanent and always the same, and all
17022: phenomena in space as entirely different in their nature from the
17023: procedure of thought. Essential simplicity (with the other attributes
17024: predicated of the ego) is regarded as the mere schema of this
17025: regulative principle; it is not assumed that it is the actual ground of
17026: the properties of the soul. For these properties may rest upon quite
17027: different grounds, of which we are completely ignorant; just as the
17028: above predicates could not give us any knowledge of the soul as it is
17029: in itself, even if we regarded them as valid in respect of it, inasmuch
17030: as they constitute a mere idea, which cannot be represented in
17031: concreto. Nothing but good can result from a psychological idea of this
17032: kind, if we only take proper care not to consider it as more than an
17033: idea; that is, if we regard it as valid merely in relation to the
17034: employment of reason, in the sphere of the phenomena of the soul. Under
17035: the guidance of this idea, or principle, no empirical laws of corporeal
17036: phenomena are called in to explain that which is a phenomenon of the
17037: internal sense alone; no windy hypotheses of the generation,
17038: annihilation, and palingenesis of souls are admitted. Thus the
17039: consideration of this object of the internal sense is kept pure, and
17040: unmixed with heterogeneous elements; while the investigation of reason
17041: aims at reducing all the grounds of explanation employed in this sphere
17042: of knowledge to a single principle. All this is best effected, nay,
17043: cannot be effected otherwise than by means of such a schema, which
17044: requires us to regard this ideal thing as an actual existence. The
17045: psychological idea is, therefore, meaningless and inapplicable, except
17046: as the schema of a regulative conception. For, if I ask whether the
17047: soul is not really of a spiritual nature—it is a question which has no
17048: meaning. From such a conception has been abstracted, not merely all
17049: corporeal nature, but all nature, that is, all the predicates of a
17050: possible experience; and consequently, all the conditions which enable
17051: us to cogitate an object to this conception have disappeared. But, if
17052: these conditions are absent, it is evident that the conception is
17053: meaningless.
17054: 
17055: The second regulative idea of speculative reason is the conception of
17056: the universe. For nature is properly the only object presented to us,
17057: in regard to which reason requires regulative principles. Nature is
17058: twofold—thinking and corporeal nature. To cogitate the latter in regard
17059: to its internal possibility, that is, to determine the application of
17060: the categories to it, no idea is required—no representation which
17061: transcends experience. In this sphere, therefore, an idea is
17062: impossible, sensuous intuition being our only guide; while, in the
17063: sphere of psychology, we require the fundamental idea (I), which
17064: contains à priori a certain form of thought namely, the unity of the
17065: ego. Pure reason has, therefore, nothing left but nature in general,
17066: and the completeness of conditions in nature in accordance with some
17067: principle. The absolute totality of the series of these conditions is
17068: an idea, which can never be fully realized in the empirical exercise of
17069: reason, while it is serviceable as a rule for the procedure of reason
17070: in relation to that totality. It requires us, in the explanation of
17071: given phenomena (in the regress or ascent in the series), to proceed as
17072: if the series were infinite in itself, that is, were prolonged in
17073: indefinitum; while on the other hand, where reason is regarded as
17074: itself the determining cause (in the region of freedom), we are
17075: required to proceed as if we had not before us an object of sense, but
17076: of the pure understanding. In this latter case, the conditions do not
17077: exist in the series of phenomena, but may be placed quite out of and
17078: beyond it, and the series of conditions may be regarded as if it had an
17079: absolute beginning from an intelligible cause. All this proves that the
17080: cosmological ideas are nothing but regulative principles, and not
17081: constitutive; and that their aim is not to realize an actual totality
17082: in such series. The full discussion of this subject will be found in
17083: its proper place in the chapter on the antinomy of pure reason.
17084: 
17085: The third idea of pure reason, containing the hypothesis of a being
17086: which is valid merely as a relative hypothesis, is that of the one and
17087: all-sufficient cause of all cosmological series, in other words, the
17088: idea of God. We have not the slightest ground absolutely to admit the
17089: existence of an object corresponding to this idea; for what can empower
17090: or authorize us to affirm the existence of a being of the highest
17091: perfection—a being whose existence is absolutely necessary—merely
17092: because we possess the conception of such a being? The answer is: It is
17093: the existence of the world which renders this hypothesis necessary. But
17094: this answer makes it perfectly evident that the idea of this being,
17095: like all other speculative ideas, is essentially nothing more than a
17096: demand upon reason that it shall regulate the connection which it and
17097: its subordinate faculties introduce into the phenomena of the world by
17098: principles of systematic unity and, consequently, that it shall regard
17099: all phenomena as originating from one all-embracing being, as the
17100: supreme and all-sufficient cause. From this it is plain that the only
17101: aim of reason in this procedure is the establishment of its own formal
17102: rule for the extension of its dominion in the world of experience; that
17103: it does not aim at an extension of its cognition beyond the limits of
17104: experience; and that, consequently, this idea does not contain any
17105: constitutive principle.
17106: 
17107: The highest formal unity, which is based upon ideas alone, is the unity
17108: of all things—a unity in accordance with an aim or purpose; and the
17109: speculative interest of reason renders it necessary to regard all order
17110: in the world as if it originated from the intention and design of a
17111: supreme reason. This principle unfolds to the view of reason in the
17112: sphere of experience new and enlarged prospects, and invites it to
17113: connect the phenomena of the world according to teleological laws, and
17114: in this way to attain to the highest possible degree of systematic
17115: unity. The hypothesis of a supreme intelligence, as the sole cause of
17116: the universe—an intelligence which has for us no more than an ideal
17117: existence—is accordingly always of the greatest service to reason.
17118: Thus, if we presuppose, in relation to the figure of the earth (which
17119: is round, but somewhat flattened at the poles),[71] or that of
17120: mountains or seas, wise designs on the part of an author of the
17121: universe, we cannot fail to make, by the light of this supposition, a
17122: great number of interesting discoveries. If we keep to this hypothesis,
17123: as a principle which is purely regulative, even error cannot be very
17124: detrimental. For, in this case, error can have no more serious
17125: consequences than that, where we expected to discover a teleological
17126: connection (nexus finalis), only a mechanical or physical connection
17127: appears. In such a case, we merely fail to find the additional form of
17128: unity we expected, but we do not lose the rational unity which the mind
17129: requires in its procedure in experience. But even a miscarriage of this
17130: sort cannot affect the law in its general and teleological relations.
17131: For although we may convict an anatomist of an error, when he connects
17132: the limb of some animal with a certain purpose, it is quite impossible
17133: to prove in a single case that any arrangement of nature, be it what it
17134: may, is entirely without aim or design. And thus medical physiology, by
17135: the aid of a principle presented to it by pure reason, extends its very
17136: limited empirical knowledge of the purposes of the different parts of
17137: an organized body so far that it may be asserted with the utmost
17138: confidence, and with the approbation of all reflecting men, that every
17139: organ or bodily part of an animal has its use and answers a certain
17140: design. Now, this is a supposition which, if regarded as of a
17141: constitutive character, goes much farther than any experience or
17142: observation of ours can justify. Hence it is evident that it is nothing
17143: more than a regulative principle of reason, which aims at the highest
17144: degree of systematic unity, by the aid of the idea of a causality
17145: according to design in a supreme cause—a cause which it regards as the
17146: highest intelligence.
17147: 
17148:  [71] The advantages which a circular form, in the case of the earth,
17149:  has over every other, are well known. But few are aware that the
17150:  slight flattening at the poles, which gives it the figure of a
17151:  spheroid, is the only cause which prevents the elevations of
17152:  continents or even of mountains, perhaps thrown up by some internal
17153:  convulsion, from continually altering the position of the axis of the
17154:  earth—and that to some considerable degree in a short time. The great
17155:  protuberance of the earth under the Equator serves to overbalance the
17156:  impetus of all other masses of earth, and thus to preserve the axis of
17157:  the earth, so far as we can observe, in its present position. And yet
17158:  this wise arrangement has been unthinkingly explained from the
17159:  equilibrium of the formerly fluid mass.
17160: 
17161: 
17162: If, however, we neglect this restriction of the idea to a purely
17163: regulative influence, reason is betrayed into numerous errors. For it
17164: has then left the ground of experience, in which alone are to be found
17165: the criteria of truth, and has ventured into the region of the
17166: incomprehensible and unsearchable, on the heights of which it loses its
17167: power and collectedness, because it has completely severed its
17168: connection with experience.
17169: 
17170: The first error which arises from our employing the idea of a Supreme
17171: Being as a constitutive (in repugnance to the very nature of an idea),
17172: and not as a regulative principle, is the error of inactive reason
17173: (ignava ratio).[72] We may so term every principle which requires us to
17174: regard our investigations of nature as absolutely complete, and allows
17175: reason to cease its inquiries, as if it had fully executed its task.
17176: Thus the psychological idea of the ego, when employed as a constitutive
17177: principle for the explanation of the phenomena of the soul, and for the
17178: extension of our knowledge regarding this subject beyond the limits of
17179: experience—even to the condition of the soul after death—is convenient
17180: enough for the purposes of pure reason, but detrimental and even
17181: ruinous to its interests in the sphere of nature and experience. The
17182: dogmatizing spiritualist explains the unchanging unity of our
17183: personality through all changes of condition from the unity of a
17184: thinking substance, the interest which we take in things and events
17185: that can happen only after our death, from a consciousness of the
17186: immaterial nature of our thinking subject, and so on. Thus he dispenses
17187: with all empirical investigations into the cause of these internal
17188: phenomena, and with all possible explanations of them upon purely
17189: natural grounds; while, at the dictation of a transcendent reason, he
17190: passes by the immanent sources of cognition in experience, greatly to
17191: his own ease and convenience, but to the sacrifice of all, genuine
17192: insight and intelligence. These prejudicial consequences become still
17193: more evident, in the case of the dogmatical treatment of our idea of a
17194: Supreme Intelligence, and the theological system of nature
17195: (physico-theology) which is falsely based upon it. For, in this case,
17196: the aims which we observe in nature, and often those which we merely
17197: fancy to exist, make the investigation of causes a very easy task, by
17198: directing us to refer such and such phenomena immediately to the
17199: unsearchable will and counsel of the Supreme Wisdom, while we ought to
17200: investigate their causes in the general laws of the mechanism of
17201: matter. We are thus recommended to consider the labour of reason as
17202: ended, when we have merely dispensed with its employment, which is
17203: guided surely and safely only by the order of nature and the series of
17204: changes in the world—which are arranged according to immanent and
17205: general laws. This error may be avoided, if we do not merely consider
17206: from the view-point of final aims certain parts of nature, such as the
17207: division and structure of a continent, the constitution and direction
17208: of certain mountain-chains, or even the organization existing in the
17209: vegetable and animal kingdoms, but look upon this systematic unity of
17210: nature in a perfectly general way, in relation to the idea of a Supreme
17211: Intelligence. If we pursue this advice, we lay as a foundation for all
17212: investigation the conformity to aims of all phenomena of nature in
17213: accordance with universal laws, for which no particular arrangement of
17214: nature is exempt, but only cognized by us with more or less difficulty;
17215: and we possess a regulative principle of the systematic unity of a
17216: teleological connection, which we do not attempt to anticipate or
17217: predetermine. All that we do, and ought to do, is to follow out the
17218: physico-mechanical connection in nature according to general laws, with
17219: the hope of discovering, sooner or later, the teleological connection
17220: also. Thus, and thus only, can the principle of final unity aid in the
17221: extension of the employment of reason in the sphere of experience,
17222: without being in any case detrimental to its interests.
17223: 
17224:  [72] This was the term applied by the old dialecticians to a
17225:  sophistical argument, which ran thus: If it is your fate to die of
17226:  this disease, you will die, whether you employ a physician or not.
17227:  Cicero says that this mode of reasoning has received this appellation,
17228:  because, if followed, it puts an end to the employment of reason in
17229:  the affairs of life. For a similar reason, I have applied this
17230:  designation to the sophistical argument of pure reason.
17231: 
17232: 
17233: The second error which arises from the misconception of the principle
17234: of systematic unity is that of perverted reason (perversa ratio,
17235: usteron roteron rationis). The idea of systematic unity is available as
17236: a regulative principle in the connection of phenomena according to
17237: general natural laws; and, how far soever we have to travel upon the
17238: path of experience to discover some fact or event, this idea requires
17239: us to believe that we have approached all the more nearly to the
17240: completion of its use in the sphere of nature, although that completion
17241: can never be attained. But this error reverses the procedure of reason.
17242: We begin by hypostatizing the principle of systematic unity, and by
17243: giving an anthropomorphic determination to the conception of a Supreme
17244: Intelligence, and then proceed forcibly to impose aims upon nature.
17245: Thus not only does teleology, which ought to aid in the completion of
17246: unity in accordance with general laws, operate to the destruction of
17247: its influence, but it hinders reason from attaining its proper aim,
17248: that is, the proof, upon natural grounds, of the existence of a supreme
17249: intelligent cause. For, if we cannot presuppose supreme finality in
17250: nature à priori, that is, as essentially belonging to nature, how can
17251: we be directed to endeavour to discover this unity and, rising
17252: gradually through its different degrees, to approach the supreme
17253: perfection of an author of all—a perfection which is absolutely
17254: necessary, and therefore cognizable à priori? The regulative principle
17255: directs us to presuppose systematic unity absolutely and, consequently,
17256: as following from the essential nature of things—but only as a unity of
17257: nature, not merely cognized empirically, but presupposed à priori,
17258: although only in an indeterminate manner. But if I insist on basing
17259: nature upon the foundation of a supreme ordaining Being, the unity of
17260: nature is in effect lost. For, in this case, it is quite foreign and
17261: unessential to the nature of things, and cannot be cognized from the
17262: general laws of nature. And thus arises a vicious circular argument,
17263: what ought to have been proved having been presupposed.
17264: 
17265: To take the regulative principle of systematic unity in nature for a
17266: constitutive principle, and to hypostatize and make a cause out of that
17267: which is properly the ideal ground of the consistent and harmonious
17268: exercise of reason, involves reason in inextricable embarrassments. The
17269: investigation of nature pursues its own path under the guidance of the
17270: chain of natural causes, in accordance with the general laws of nature,
17271: and ever follows the light of the idea of an author of the universe—not
17272: for the purpose of deducing the finality, which it constantly pursues,
17273: from this Supreme Being, but to attain to the cognition of his
17274: existence from the finality which it seeks in the existence of the
17275: phenomena of nature, and, if possible, in that of all things to cognize
17276: this being, consequently, as absolutely necessary. Whether this latter
17277: purpose succeed or not, the idea is and must always be a true one, and
17278: its employment, when merely regulative, must always be accompanied by
17279: truthful and beneficial results.
17280: 
17281: Complete unity, in conformity with aims, constitutes absolute
17282: perfection. But if we do not find this unity in the nature of the
17283: things which go to constitute the world of experience, that is, of
17284: objective cognition, consequently in the universal and necessary laws
17285: of nature, how can we infer from this unity the idea of the supreme and
17286: absolutely necessary perfection of a primal being, which is the origin
17287: of all causality? The greatest systematic unity, and consequently
17288: teleological unity, constitutes the very foundation of the possibility
17289: of the most extended employment of human reason. The idea of unity is
17290: therefore essentially and indissolubly connected with the nature of our
17291: reason. This idea is a legislative one; and hence it is very natural
17292: that we should assume the existence of a legislative reason
17293: corresponding to it, from which the systematic unity of nature—the
17294: object of the operations of reason—must be derived.
17295: 
17296: In the course of our discussion of the antinomies, we stated that it is
17297: always possible to answer all the questions which pure reason may
17298: raise; and that the plea of the limited nature of our cognition, which
17299: is unavoidable and proper in many questions regarding natural
17300: phenomena, cannot in this case be admitted, because the questions
17301: raised do not relate to the nature of things, but are necessarily
17302: originated by the nature of reason itself, and relate to its own
17303: internal constitution. We can now establish this assertion, which at
17304: first sight appeared so rash, in relation to the two questions in which
17305: reason takes the greatest interest, and thus complete our discussion of
17306: the dialectic of pure reason.
17307: 
17308: If, then, the question is asked, in relation to transcendental
17309: theology,[73] first, whether there is anything distinct from the world,
17310: which contains the ground of cosmical order and connection according to
17311: general laws? The answer is: Certainly. For the world is a sum of
17312: phenomena; there must, therefore, be some transcendental basis of these
17313: phenomena, that is, a basis cogitable by the pure understanding alone.
17314: If, secondly, the question is asked whether this being is substance,
17315: whether it is of the greatest reality, whether it is necessary, and so
17316: forth? I answer that this question is utterly without meaning. For all
17317: the categories which aid me in forming a conception of an object cannot
17318: be employed except in the world of sense, and are without meaning when
17319: not applied to objects of actual or possible experience. Out of this
17320: sphere, they are not properly conceptions, but the mere marks or
17321: indices of conceptions, which we may admit, although they cannot,
17322: without the help of experience, help us to understand any subject or
17323: thing. If, thirdly, the question is whether we may not cogitate this
17324: being, which is distinct from the world, in analogy with the objects of
17325: experience? The answer is: Undoubtedly, but only as an ideal, and not
17326: as a real object. That is, we must cogitate it only as an unknown
17327: substratum of the systematic unity, order, and finality of the world—a
17328: unity which reason must employ as the regulative principle of its
17329: investigation of nature. Nay, more, we may admit into the idea certain
17330: anthropomorphic elements, which are promotive of the interests of this
17331: regulative principle. For it is no more than an idea, which does not
17332: relate directly to a being distinct from the world, but to the
17333: regulative principle of the systematic unity of the world, by means,
17334: however, of a schema of this unity—the schema of a Supreme
17335: Intelligence, who is the wisely-designing author of the universe. What
17336: this basis of cosmical unity may be in itself, we know not—we cannot
17337: discover from the idea; we merely know how we ought to employ the idea
17338: of this unity, in relation to the systematic operation of reason in the
17339: sphere of experience.
17340: 
17341:  [73] After what has been said of the psychological idea of the ego and
17342:  its proper employment as a regulative principle of the operations of
17343:  reason, I need not enter into details regarding the transcendental
17344:  illusion by which the systematic unity of all the various phenomena of
17345:  the internal sense is hypostatized. The procedure is in this case very
17346:  similar to that which has been discussed in our remarks on the
17347:  theological ideal.
17348: 
17349: 
17350: But, it will be asked again, can we on these grounds, admit the
17351: existence of a wise and omnipotent author of the world? Without doubt;
17352: and not only so, but we must assume the existence of such a being. But
17353: do we thus extend the limits of our knowledge beyond the field of
17354: possible experience? By no means. For we have merely presupposed a
17355: something, of which we have no conception, which we do not know as it
17356: is in itself; but, in relation to the systematic disposition of the
17357: universe, which we must presuppose in all our observation of nature, we
17358: have cogitated this unknown being in analogy with an intelligent
17359: existence (an empirical conception), that is to say, we have endowed it
17360: with those attributes, which, judging from the nature of our own
17361: reason, may contain the ground of such a systematic unity. This idea is
17362: therefore valid only relatively to the employment in experience of our
17363: reason. But if we attribute to it absolute and objective validity, we
17364: overlook the fact that it is merely an ideal being that we cogitate;
17365: and, by setting out from a basis which is not determinable by
17366: considerations drawn from experience, we place ourselves in a position
17367: which incapacitates us from applying this principle to the empirical
17368: employment of reason.
17369: 
17370: But, it will be asked further, can I make any use of this conception
17371: and hypothesis in my investigations into the world and nature? Yes, for
17372: this very purpose was the idea established by reason as a fundamental
17373: basis. But may I regard certain arrangements, which seemed to have been
17374: made in conformity with some fixed aim, as the arrangements of design,
17375: and look upon them as proceeding from the divine will, with the
17376: intervention, however, of certain other particular arrangements
17377: disposed to that end? Yes, you may do so; but at the same time you must
17378: regard it as indifferent, whether it is asserted that divine wisdom has
17379: disposed all things in conformity with his highest aims, or that the
17380: idea of supreme wisdom is a regulative principle in the investigation
17381: of nature, and at the same time a principle of the systematic unity of
17382: nature according to general laws, even in those cases where we are
17383: unable to discover that unity. In other words, it must be perfectly
17384: indifferent to you whether you say, when you have discovered this
17385: unity: God has wisely willed it so; or: Nature has wisely arranged
17386: this. For it was nothing but the systematic unity, which reason
17387: requires as a basis for the investigation of nature, that justified you
17388: in accepting the idea of a supreme intelligence as a schema for a
17389: regulative principle; and, the farther you advance in the discovery of
17390: design and finality, the more certain the validity of your idea. But,
17391: as the whole aim of this regulative principle was the discovery of a
17392: necessary and systematic unity in nature, we have, in so far as we
17393: attain this, to attribute our success to the idea of a Supreme Being;
17394: while, at the same time, we cannot, without involving ourselves in
17395: contradictions, overlook the general laws of nature, as it was in
17396: reference to them alone that this idea was employed. We cannot, I say,
17397: overlook the general laws of nature, and regard this conformity to aims
17398: observable in nature as contingent or hyperphysical in its origin;
17399: inasmuch as there is no ground which can justify us in the admission of
17400: a being with such properties distinct from and above nature. All that
17401: we are authorized to assert is that this idea may be employed as a
17402: principle, and that the properties of the being which is assumed to
17403: correspond to it may be regarded as systematically connected in analogy
17404: with the causal determination of phenomena.
17405: 
17406: For the same reasons we are justified in introducing into the idea of
17407: the supreme cause other anthropomorphic elements (for without these we
17408: could not predicate anything of it); we may regard it as allowable to
17409: cogitate this cause as a being with understanding, the feelings of
17410: pleasure and displeasure, and faculties of desire and will
17411: corresponding to these. At the same time, we may attribute to this
17412: being infinite perfection—a perfection which necessarily transcends
17413: that which our knowledge of the order and design in the world authorize
17414: us to predicate of it. For the regulative law of systematic unity
17415: requires us to study nature on the supposition that systematic and
17416: final unity in infinitum is everywhere discoverable, even in the
17417: highest diversity. For, although we may discover little of this
17418: cosmical perfection, it belongs to the legislative prerogative of
17419: reason to require us always to seek for and to expect it; while it must
17420: always be beneficial to institute all inquiries into nature in
17421: accordance with this principle. But it is evident that, by this idea of
17422: a supreme author of all, which I place as the foundation of all
17423: inquiries into nature, I do not mean to assert the existence of such a
17424: being, or that I have any knowledge of its existence; and,
17425: consequently, I do not really deduce anything from the existence of
17426: this being, but merely from its idea, that is to say, from the nature
17427: of things in this world, in accordance with this idea. A certain dim
17428: consciousness of the true use of this idea seems to have dictated to
17429: the philosophers of all times the moderate language used by them
17430: regarding the cause of the world. We find them employing the
17431: expressions wisdom and care of nature, and divine wisdom, as
17432: synonymous—nay, in purely speculative discussions, preferring the
17433: former, because it does not carry the appearance of greater pretensions
17434: than such as we are entitled to make, and at the same time directs
17435: reason to its proper field of action—nature and her phenomena.
17436: 
17437: Thus, pure reason, which at first seemed to promise us nothing less
17438: than the extension of our cognition beyond the limits of experience, is
17439: found, when thoroughly examined, to contain nothing but regulative
17440: principles, the virtue and function of which is to introduce into our
17441: cognition a higher degree of unity than the understanding could of
17442: itself. These principles, by placing the goal of all our struggles at
17443: so great a distance, realize for us the most thorough connection
17444: between the different parts of our cognition, and the highest degree of
17445: systematic unity. But, on the other hand, if misunderstood and employed
17446: as constitutive principles of transcendent cognition, they become the
17447: parents of illusions and contradictions, while pretending to introduce
17448: us to new regions of knowledge.
17449: 
17450: Thus all human cognition begins with intuitions, proceeds from thence
17451: to conceptions, and ends with ideas. Although it possesses, in relation
17452: to all three elements, à priori sources of cognition, which seemed to
17453: transcend the limits of all experience, a thoroughgoing criticism
17454: demonstrates that speculative reason can never, by the aid of these
17455: elements, pass the bounds of possible experience, and that the proper
17456: destination of this highest faculty of cognition is to employ all
17457: methods, and all the principles of these methods, for the purpose of
17458: penetrating into the innermost secrets of nature, by the aid of the
17459: principles of unity (among all kinds of which teleological unity is the
17460: highest), while it ought not to attempt to soar above the sphere of
17461: experience, beyond which there lies nought for us but the void inane.
17462: The critical examination, in our Transcendental Analytic, of all the
17463: propositions which professed to extend cognition beyond the sphere of
17464: experience, completely demonstrated that they can only conduct us to a
17465: possible experience. If we were not distrustful even of the clearest
17466: abstract theorems, if we were not allured by specious and inviting
17467: prospects to escape from the constraining power of their evidence, we
17468: might spare ourselves the laborious examination of all the dialectical
17469: arguments which a transcendent reason adduces in support of its
17470: pretensions; for we should know with the most complete certainty that,
17471: however honest such professions might be, they are null and valueless,
17472: because they relate to a kind of knowledge to which no man can by any
17473: possibility attain. But, as there is no end to discussion, if we cannot
17474: discover the true cause of the illusions by which even the wisest are
17475: deceived, and as the analysis of all our transcendent cognition into
17476: its elements is of itself of no slight value as a psychological study,
17477: while it is a duty incumbent on every philosopher—it was found
17478: necessary to investigate the dialectical procedure of reason in its
17479: primary sources. And as the inferences of which this dialectic is the
17480: parent are not only deceitful, but naturally possess a profound
17481: interest for humanity, it was advisable at the same time, to give a
17482: full account of the momenta of this dialectical procedure, and to
17483: deposit it in the archives of human reason, as a warning to all future
17484: metaphysicians to avoid these causes of speculative error.
17485: 
17486: 
17487: 
17488: II. Transcendental Doctrine of Method
17489: 
17490: 
17491: If we regard the sum of the cognition of pure speculative reason as an
17492: edifice, the idea of which, at least, exists in the human mind, it may
17493: be said that we have in the Transcendental Doctrine of Elements
17494: examined the materials and determined to what edifice these belong, and
17495: what its height and stability. We have found, indeed, that, although we
17496: had purposed to build for ourselves a tower which should reach to
17497: Heaven, the supply of materials sufficed merely for a habitation, which
17498: was spacious enough for all terrestrial purposes, and high enough to
17499: enable us to survey the level plain of experience, but that the bold
17500: undertaking designed necessarily failed for want of materials—not to
17501: mention the confusion of tongues, which gave rise to endless disputes
17502: among the labourers on the plan of the edifice, and at last scattered
17503: them over all the world, each to erect a separate building for himself,
17504: according to his own plans and his own inclinations. Our present task
17505: relates not to the materials, but to the plan of an edifice; and, as we
17506: have had sufficient warning not to venture blindly upon a design which
17507: may be found to transcend our natural powers, while, at the same time,
17508: we cannot give up the intention of erecting a secure abode for the
17509: mind, we must proportion our design to the material which is presented
17510: to us, and which is, at the same time, sufficient for all our wants.
17511: 
17512: I understand, then, by the transcendental doctrine of method, the
17513: determination of the formal conditions of a complete system of pure
17514: reason. We shall accordingly have to treat of the discipline, the
17515: canon, the architectonic, and, finally, the history of pure reason.
17516: This part of our Critique will accomplish, from the transcendental
17517: point of view, what has been usually attempted, but miserably executed,
17518: under the name of practical logic. It has been badly executed, I say,
17519: because general logic, not being limited to any particular kind of
17520: cognition (not even to the pure cognition of the understanding) nor to
17521: any particular objects, it cannot, without borrowing from other
17522: sciences, do more than present merely the titles or signs of possible
17523: methods and the technical expressions, which are employed in the
17524: systematic parts of all sciences; and thus the pupil is made acquainted
17525: with names, the meaning and application of which he is to learn only at
17526: some future time.
17527: 
17528: Chapter I. The Discipline of Pure Reason
17529: 
17530: Negative judgements—those which are so not merely as regards their
17531: logical form, but in respect of their content—are not commonly held in
17532: especial respect. They are, on the contrary, regarded as jealous
17533: enemies of our insatiable desire for knowledge; and it almost requires
17534: an apology to induce us to tolerate, much less to prize and to respect
17535: them.
17536: 
17537: All propositions, indeed, may be logically expressed in a negative
17538: form; but, in relation to the content of our cognition, the peculiar
17539: province of negative judgements is solely to prevent error. For this
17540: reason, too, negative propositions, which are framed for the purpose of
17541: correcting false cognitions where error is absolutely impossible, are
17542: undoubtedly true, but inane and senseless; that is, they are in reality
17543: purposeless and, for this reason, often very ridiculous. Such is the
17544: proposition of the schoolman that Alexander could not have subdued any
17545: countries without an army.
17546: 
17547: But where the limits of our possible cognition are very much
17548: contracted, the attraction to new fields of knowledge great, the
17549: illusions to which the mind is subject of the most deceptive character,
17550: and the evil consequences of error of no inconsiderable magnitude—the
17551: negative element in knowledge, which is useful only to guard us against
17552: error, is of far more importance than much of that positive instruction
17553: which makes additions to the sum of our knowledge. The restraint which
17554: is employed to repress, and finally to extirpate the constant
17555: inclination to depart from certain rules, is termed discipline. It is
17556: distinguished from culture, which aims at the formation of a certain
17557: degree of skill, without attempting to repress or to destroy any other
17558: mental power, already existing. In the cultivation of a talent, which
17559: has given evidence of an impulse towards self-development, discipline
17560: takes a negative,[74] culture and doctrine a positive, part.
17561: 
17562:  [74] I am well aware that, in the language of the schools, the term
17563:  discipline is usually employed as synonymous with instruction. But
17564:  there are so many cases in which it is necessary to distinguish the
17565:  notion of the former, as a course of corrective training, from that of
17566:  the latter, as the communication of knowledge, and the nature of
17567:  things itself demands the appropriation of the most suitable
17568:  expressions for this distinction, that it is my desire that the former
17569:  terms should never be employed in any other than a negative
17570:  signification.
17571: 
17572: 
17573: That natural dispositions and talents (such as imagination and wit),
17574: which ask a free and unlimited development, require in many respects
17575: the corrective influence of discipline, every one will readily grant.
17576: But it may well appear strange that reason, whose proper duty it is to
17577: prescribe rules of discipline to all the other powers of the mind,
17578: should itself require this corrective. It has, in fact, hitherto
17579: escaped this humiliation, only because, in presence of its magnificent
17580: pretensions and high position, no one could readily suspect it to be
17581: capable of substituting fancies for conceptions, and words for things.
17582: 
17583: Reason, when employed in the field of experience, does not stand in
17584: need of criticism, because its principles are subjected to the
17585: continual test of empirical observations. Nor is criticism requisite in
17586: the sphere of mathematics, where the conceptions of reason must always
17587: be presented in concreto in pure intuition, and baseless or arbitrary
17588: assertions are discovered without difficulty. But where reason is not
17589: held in a plain track by the influence of empirical or of pure
17590: intuition, that is, when it is employed in the transcendental sphere of
17591: pure conceptions, it stands in great need of discipline, to restrain
17592: its propensity to overstep the limits of possible experience and to
17593: keep it from wandering into error. In fact, the utility of the
17594: philosophy of pure reason is entirely of this negative character.
17595: Particular errors may be corrected by particular animadversions, and
17596: the causes of these errors may be eradicated by criticism. But where we
17597: find, as in the case of pure reason, a complete system of illusions and
17598: fallacies, closely connected with each other and depending upon grand
17599: general principles, there seems to be required a peculiar and negative
17600: code of mental legislation, which, under the denomination of a
17601: discipline, and founded upon the nature of reason and the objects of
17602: its exercise, shall constitute a system of thorough examination and
17603: testing, which no fallacy will be able to withstand or escape from,
17604: under whatever disguise or concealment it may lurk.
17605: 
17606: But the reader must remark that, in this the second division of our
17607: transcendental Critique the discipline of pure reason is not directed
17608: to the content, but to the method of the cognition of pure reason. The
17609: former task has been completed in the doctrine of elements. But there
17610: is so much similarity in the mode of employing the faculty of reason,
17611: whatever be the object to which it is applied, while, at the same time,
17612: its employment in the transcendental sphere is so essentially different
17613: in kind from every other, that, without the warning negative influence
17614: of a discipline specially directed to that end, the errors are
17615: unavoidable which spring from the unskillful employment of the methods
17616: which are originated by reason but which are out of place in this
17617: sphere.
17618: 
17619: Section I. The Discipline of Pure Reason in the Sphere of Dogmatism
17620: 
17621: The science of mathematics presents the most brilliant example of the
17622: extension of the sphere of pure reason without the aid of experience.
17623: Examples are always contagious; and they exert an especial influence on
17624: the same faculty, which naturally flatters itself that it will have the
17625: same good fortune in other case as fell to its lot in one fortunate
17626: instance. Hence pure reason hopes to be able to extend its empire in
17627: the transcendental sphere with equal success and security, especially
17628: when it applies the same method which was attended with such brilliant
17629: results in the science of mathematics. It is, therefore, of the highest
17630: importance for us to know whether the method of arriving at
17631: demonstrative certainty, which is termed mathematical, be identical
17632: with that by which we endeavour to attain the same degree of certainty
17633: in philosophy, and which is termed in that science dogmatical.
17634: 
17635: Philosophical cognition is the cognition of reason by means of
17636: conceptions; mathematical cognition is cognition by means of the
17637: construction of conceptions. The construction of a conception is the
17638: presentation à priori of the intuition which corresponds to the
17639: conception. For this purpose a non-empirical intuition is requisite,
17640: which, as an intuition, is an individual object; while, as the
17641: construction of a conception (a general representation), it must be
17642: seen to be universally valid for all the possible intuitions which rank
17643: under that conception. Thus I construct a triangle, by the presentation
17644: of the object which corresponds to this conception, either by mere
17645: imagination, in pure intuition, or upon paper, in empirical intuition,
17646: in both cases completely à priori, without borrowing the type of that
17647: figure from any experience. The individual figure drawn upon paper is
17648: empirical; but it serves, notwithstanding, to indicate the conception,
17649: even in its universality, because in this empirical intuition we keep
17650: our eye merely on the act of the construction of the conception, and
17651: pay no attention to the various modes of determining it, for example,
17652: its size, the length of its sides, the size of its angles, these not in
17653: the least affecting the essential character of the conception.
17654: 
17655: Philosophical cognition, accordingly, regards the particular only in
17656: the general; mathematical the general in the particular, nay, in the
17657: individual. This is done, however, entirely à priori and by means of
17658: pure reason, so that, as this individual figure is determined under
17659: certain universal conditions of construction, the object of the
17660: conception, to which this individual figure corresponds as its schema,
17661: must be cogitated as universally determined.
17662: 
17663: The essential difference of these two modes of cognition consists,
17664: therefore, in this formal quality; it does not regard the difference of
17665: the matter or objects of both. Those thinkers who aim at distinguishing
17666: philosophy from mathematics by asserting that the former has to do with
17667: quality merely, and the latter with quantity, have mistaken the effect
17668: for the cause. The reason why mathematical cognition can relate only to
17669: quantity is to be found in its form alone. For it is the conception of
17670: quantities only that is capable of being constructed, that is,
17671: presented à priori in intuition; while qualities cannot be given in any
17672: other than an empirical intuition. Hence the cognition of qualities by
17673: reason is possible only through conceptions. No one can find an
17674: intuition which shall correspond to the conception of reality, except
17675: in experience; it cannot be presented to the mind à priori and
17676: antecedently to the empirical consciousness of a reality. We can form
17677: an intuition, by means of the mere conception of it, of a cone, without
17678: the aid of experience; but the colour of the cone we cannot know except
17679: from experience. I cannot present an intuition of a cause, except in an
17680: example which experience offers to me. Besides, philosophy, as well as
17681: mathematics, treats of quantities; as, for example, of totality,
17682: infinity, and so on. Mathematics, too, treats of the difference of
17683: lines and surfaces—as spaces of different quality, of the continuity of
17684: extension—as a quality thereof. But, although in such cases they have a
17685: common object, the mode in which reason considers that object is very
17686: different in philosophy from what it is in mathematics. The former
17687: confines itself to the general conceptions; the latter can do nothing
17688: with a mere conception, it hastens to intuition. In this intuition it
17689: regards the conception in concreto, not empirically, but in an à priori
17690: intuition, which it has constructed; and in which, all the results
17691: which follow from the general conditions of the construction of the
17692: conception are in all cases valid for the object of the constructed
17693: conception.
17694: 
17695: Suppose that the conception of a triangle is given to a philosopher and
17696: that he is required to discover, by the philosophical method, what
17697: relation the sum of its angles bears to a right angle. He has nothing
17698: before him but the conception of a figure enclosed within three right
17699: lines, and, consequently, with the same number of angles. He may
17700: analyse the conception of a right line, of an angle, or of the number
17701: three as long as he pleases, but he will not discover any properties
17702: not contained in these conceptions. But, if this question is proposed
17703: to a geometrician, he at once begins by constructing a triangle. He
17704: knows that two right angles are equal to the sum of all the contiguous
17705: angles which proceed from one point in a straight line; and he goes on
17706: to produce one side of his triangle, thus forming two adjacent angles
17707: which are together equal to two right angles. He then divides the
17708: exterior of these angles, by drawing a line parallel with the opposite
17709: side of the triangle, and immediately perceives that he has thus got an
17710: exterior adjacent angle which is equal to the interior. Proceeding in
17711: this way, through a chain of inferences, and always on the ground of
17712: intuition, he arrives at a clear and universally valid solution of the
17713: question.
17714: 
17715: But mathematics does not confine itself to the construction of
17716: quantities (quanta), as in the case of geometry; it occupies itself
17717: with pure quantity also (quantitas), as in the case of algebra, where
17718: complete abstraction is made of the properties of the object indicated
17719: by the conception of quantity. In algebra, a certain method of notation
17720: by signs is adopted, and these indicate the different possible
17721: constructions of quantities, the extraction of roots, and so on. After
17722: having thus denoted the general conception of quantities, according to
17723: their different relations, the different operations by which quantity
17724: or number is increased or diminished are presented in intuition in
