17725: accordance with general rules. Thus, when one quantity is to be divided
17726: by another, the signs which denote both are placed in the form peculiar
17727: to the operation of division; and thus algebra, by means of a
17728: symbolical construction of quantity, just as geometry, with its
17729: ostensive or geometrical construction (a construction of the objects
17730: themselves), arrives at results which discursive cognition cannot hope
17731: to reach by the aid of mere conceptions.
17732: 
17733: Now, what is the cause of this difference in the fortune of the
17734: philosopher and the mathematician, the former of whom follows the path
17735: of conceptions, while the latter pursues that of intuitions, which he
17736: represents, à priori, in correspondence with his conceptions? The cause
17737: is evident from what has been already demonstrated in the introduction
17738: to this Critique. We do not, in the present case, want to discover
17739: analytical propositions, which may be produced merely by analysing our
17740: conceptions—for in this the philosopher would have the advantage over
17741: his rival; we aim at the discovery of synthetical propositions—such
17742: synthetical propositions, moreover, as can be cognized à priori. I must
17743: not confine myself to that which I actually cogitate in my conception
17744: of a triangle, for this is nothing more than the mere definition; I
17745: must try to go beyond that, and to arrive at properties which are not
17746: contained in, although they belong to, the conception. Now, this is
17747: impossible, unless I determine the object present to my mind according
17748: to the conditions, either of empirical, or of pure, intuition. In the
17749: former case, I should have an empirical proposition (arrived at by
17750: actual measurement of the angles of the triangle), which would possess
17751: neither universality nor necessity; but that would be of no value. In
17752: the latter, I proceed by geometrical construction, by means of which I
17753: collect, in a pure intuition, just as I would in an empirical
17754: intuition, all the various properties which belong to the schema of a
17755: triangle in general, and consequently to its conception, and thus
17756: construct synthetical propositions which possess the attribute of
17757: universality.
17758: 
17759: It would be vain to philosophize upon the triangle, that is, to reflect
17760: on it discursively; I should get no further than the definition with
17761: which I had been obliged to set out. There are certainly transcendental
17762: synthetical propositions which are framed by means of pure conceptions,
17763: and which form the peculiar distinction of philosophy; but these do not
17764: relate to any particular thing, but to a thing in general, and enounce
17765: the conditions under which the perception of it may become a part of
17766: possible experience. But the science of mathematics has nothing to do
17767: with such questions, nor with the question of existence in any fashion;
17768: it is concerned merely with the properties of objects in themselves,
17769: only in so far as these are connected with the conception of the
17770: objects.
17771: 
17772: In the above example, we merely attempted to show the great difference
17773: which exists between the discursive employment of reason in the sphere
17774: of conceptions, and its intuitive exercise by means of the construction
17775: of conceptions. The question naturally arises: What is the cause which
17776: necessitates this twofold exercise of reason, and how are we to
17777: discover whether it is the philosophical or the mathematical method
17778: which reason is pursuing in an argument?
17779: 
17780: All our knowledge relates, finally, to possible intuitions, for it is
17781: these alone that present objects to the mind. An à priori or
17782: non-empirical conception contains either a pure intuition—and in this
17783: case it can be constructed; or it contains nothing but the synthesis of
17784: possible intuitions, which are not given à priori. In this latter case,
17785: it may help us to form synthetical à priori judgements, but only in the
17786: discursive method, by conceptions, not in the intuitive, by means of
17787: the construction of conceptions.
17788: 
17789: The only à priori intuition is that of the pure form of phenomena—space
17790: and time. A conception of space and time as quanta may be presented à
17791: priori in intuition, that is, constructed, either alone with their
17792: quality (figure), or as pure quantity (the mere synthesis of the
17793: homogeneous), by means of number. But the matter of phenomena, by which
17794: things are given in space and time, can be presented only in
17795: perception, à posteriori. The only conception which represents à priori
17796: this empirical content of phenomena is the conception of a thing in
17797: general; and the à priori synthetical cognition of this conception can
17798: give us nothing more than the rule for the synthesis of that which may
17799: be contained in the corresponding à posteriori perception; it is
17800: utterly inadequate to present an à priori intuition of the real object,
17801: which must necessarily be empirical.
17802: 
17803: Synthetical propositions, which relate to things in general, an à
17804: priori intuition of which is impossible, are transcendental. For this
17805: reason transcendental propositions cannot be framed by means of the
17806: construction of conceptions; they are à priori, and based entirely on
17807: conceptions themselves. They contain merely the rule, by which we are
17808: to seek in the world of perception or experience the synthetical unity
17809: of that which cannot be intuited à priori. But they are incompetent to
17810: present any of the conceptions which appear in them in an à priori
17811: intuition; these can be given only à posteriori, in experience, which,
17812: however, is itself possible only through these synthetical principles.
17813: 
17814: If we are to form a synthetical judgement regarding a conception, we
17815: must go beyond it, to the intuition in which it is given. If we keep to
17816: what is contained in the conception, the judgement is merely
17817: analytical—it is merely an explanation of what we have cogitated in the
17818: conception. But I can pass from the conception to the pure or empirical
17819: intuition which corresponds to it. I can proceed to examine my
17820: conception in concreto, and to cognize, either à priori or a posterio,
17821: what I find in the object of the conception. The former—à priori
17822: cognition—is rational-mathematical cognition by means of the
17823: construction of the conception; the latter—à posteriori cognition—is
17824: purely empirical cognition, which does not possess the attributes of
17825: necessity and universality. Thus I may analyse the conception I have of
17826: gold; but I gain no new information from this analysis, I merely
17827: enumerate the different properties which I had connected with the
17828: notion indicated by the word. My knowledge has gained in logical
17829: clearness and arrangement, but no addition has been made to it. But if
17830: I take the matter which is indicated by this name, and submit it to the
17831: examination of my senses, I am enabled to form several
17832: synthetical—although still empirical—propositions. The mathematical
17833: conception of a triangle I should construct, that is, present à priori
17834: in intuition, and in this way attain to rational-synthetical cognition.
17835: But when the transcendental conception of reality, or substance, or
17836: power is presented to my mind, I find that it does not relate to or
17837: indicate either an empirical or pure intuition, but that it indicates
17838: merely the synthesis of empirical intuitions, which cannot of course be
17839: given à priori. The synthesis in such a conception cannot proceed à
17840: priori—without the aid of experience—to the intuition which corresponds
17841: to the conception; and, for this reason, none of these conceptions can
17842: produce a determinative synthetical proposition, they can never present
17843: more than a principle of the synthesis[75] of possible empirical
17844: intuitions. A transcendental proposition is, therefore, a synthetical
17845: cognition of reason by means of pure conceptions and the discursive
17846: method, and it renders possible all synthetical unity in empirical
17847: cognition, though it cannot present us with any intuition à priori.
17848: 
17849:  [75] In the case of the conception of cause, I do really go beyond the
17850:  empirical conception of an event—but not to the intuition which
17851:  presents this conception in concreto, but only to the time-conditions,
17852:  which may be found in experience to correspond to the conception. My
17853:  procedure is, therefore, strictly according to conceptions; I cannot
17854:  in a case of this kind employ the construction of conceptions, because
17855:  the conception is merely a rule for the synthesis of perceptions,
17856:  which are not pure intuitions, and which, therefore, cannot be given à
17857:  priori.
17858: 
17859: 
17860: There is thus a twofold exercise of reason. Both modes have the
17861: properties of universality and an à priori origin in common, but are,
17862: in their procedure, of widely different character. The reason of this
17863: is that in the world of phenomena, in which alone objects are presented
17864: to our minds, there are two main elements—the form of intuition (space
17865: and time), which can be cognized and determined completely à priori,
17866: and the matter or content—that which is presented in space and time,
17867: and which, consequently, contains a something—an existence
17868: corresponding to our powers of sensation. As regards the latter, which
17869: can never be given in a determinate mode except by experience, there
17870: are no à priori notions which relate to it, except the undetermined
17871: conceptions of the synthesis of possible sensations, in so far as these
17872: belong (in a possible experience) to the unity of consciousness. As
17873: regards the former, we can determine our conceptions à priori in
17874: intuition, inasmuch as we are ourselves the creators of the objects of
17875: the conceptions in space and time—these objects being regarded simply
17876: as quanta. In the one case, reason proceeds according to conceptions
17877: and can do nothing more than subject phenomena to these—which can only
17878: be determined empirically, that is, à posteriori—in conformity,
17879: however, with those conceptions as the rules of all empirical
17880: synthesis. In the other case, reason proceeds by the construction of
17881: conceptions; and, as these conceptions relate to an à priori intuition,
17882: they may be given and determined in pure intuition à priori, and
17883: without the aid of empirical data. The examination and consideration of
17884: everything that exists in space or time—whether it is a quantum or not,
17885: in how far the particular something (which fills space or time) is a
17886: primary substratum, or a mere determination of some other existence,
17887: whether it relates to anything else—either as cause or effect, whether
17888: its existence is isolated or in reciprocal connection with and
17889: dependence upon others, the possibility of this existence, its reality
17890: and necessity or opposites—all these form part of the cognition of
17891: reason on the ground of conceptions, and this cognition is termed
17892: philosophical. But to determine à priori an intuition in space (its
17893: figure), to divide time into periods, or merely to cognize the quantity
17894: of an intuition in space and time, and to determine it by number—all
17895: this is an operation of reason by means of the construction of
17896: conceptions, and is called mathematical.
17897: 
17898: The success which attends the efforts of reason in the sphere of
17899: mathematics naturally fosters the expectation that the same good
17900: fortune will be its lot, if it applies the mathematical method in other
17901: regions of mental endeavour besides that of quantities. Its success is
17902: thus great, because it can support all its conceptions by à priori
17903: intuitions and, in this way, make itself a master, as it were, over
17904: nature; while pure philosophy, with its à priori discursive
17905: conceptions, bungles about in the world of nature, and cannot accredit
17906: or show any à priori evidence of the reality of these conceptions.
17907: Masters in the science of mathematics are confident of the success of
17908: this method; indeed, it is a common persuasion that it is capable of
17909: being applied to any subject of human thought. They have hardly ever
17910: reflected or philosophized on their favourite science—a task of great
17911: difficulty; and the specific difference between the two modes of
17912: employing the faculty of reason has never entered their thoughts. Rules
17913: current in the field of common experience, and which common sense
17914: stamps everywhere with its approval, are regarded by them as axiomatic.
17915: From what source the conceptions of space and time, with which (as the
17916: only primitive quanta) they have to deal, enter their minds, is a
17917: question which they do not trouble themselves to answer; and they think
17918: it just as unnecessary to examine into the origin of the pure
17919: conceptions of the understanding and the extent of their validity. All
17920: they have to do with them is to employ them. In all this they are
17921: perfectly right, if they do not overstep the limits of the sphere of
17922: nature. But they pass, unconsciously, from the world of sense to the
17923: insecure ground of pure transcendental conceptions (instabilis tellus,
17924: innabilis unda), where they can neither stand nor swim, and where the
17925: tracks of their footsteps are obliterated by time; while the march of
17926: mathematics is pursued on a broad and magnificent highway, which the
17927: latest posterity shall frequent without fear of danger or impediment.
17928: 
17929: As we have taken upon us the task of determining, clearly and
17930: certainly, the limits of pure reason in the sphere of
17931: transcendentalism, and as the efforts of reason in this direction are
17932: persisted in, even after the plainest and most expressive warnings,
17933: hope still beckoning us past the limits of experience into the
17934: splendours of the intellectual world—it becomes necessary to cut away
17935: the last anchor of this fallacious and fantastic hope. We shall,
17936: accordingly, show that the mathematical method is unattended in the
17937: sphere of philosophy by the least advantage—except, perhaps, that it
17938: more plainly exhibits its own inadequacy—that geometry and philosophy
17939: are two quite different things, although they go hand in hand in the
17940: field of natural science, and, consequently, that the procedure of the
17941: one can never be imitated by the other.
17942: 
17943: The evidence of mathematics rests upon definitions, axioms, and
17944: demonstrations. I shall be satisfied with showing that none of these
17945: forms can be employed or imitated in philosophy in the sense in which
17946: they are understood by mathematicians; and that the geometrician, if he
17947: employs his method in philosophy, will succeed only in building
17948: card-castles, while the employment of the philosophical method in
17949: mathematics can result in nothing but mere verbiage. The essential
17950: business of philosophy, indeed, is to mark out the limits of the
17951: science; and even the mathematician, unless his talent is naturally
17952: circumscribed and limited to this particular department of knowledge,
17953: cannot turn a deaf ear to the warnings of philosophy, or set himself
17954: above its direction.
17955: 
17956: I. Of Definitions. A definition is, as the term itself indicates, the
17957: representation, upon primary grounds, of the complete conception of a
17958: thing within its own limits.[76] Accordingly, an empirical conception
17959: cannot be defined, it can only be explained. For, as there are in such
17960: a conception only a certain number of marks or signs, which denote a
17961: certain class of sensuous objects, we can never be sure that we do not
17962: cogitate under the word which indicates the same object, at one time a
17963: greater, at another a smaller number of signs. Thus, one person may
17964: cogitate in his conception of gold, in addition to its properties of
17965: weight, colour, malleability, that of resisting rust, while another
17966: person may be ignorant of this quality. We employ certain signs only so
17967: long as we require them for the sake of distinction; new observations
17968: abstract some and add new ones, so that an empirical conception never
17969: remains within permanent limits. It is, in fact, useless to define a
17970: conception of this kind. If, for example, we are speaking of water and
17971: its properties, we do not stop at what we actually think by the word
17972: water, but proceed to observation and experiment; and the word, with
17973: the few signs attached to it, is more properly a designation than a
17974: conception of the thing. A definition in this case would evidently be
17975: nothing more than a determination of the word. In the second place, no
17976: à priori conception, such as those of substance, cause, right, fitness,
17977: and so on, can be defined. For I can never be sure, that the clear
17978: representation of a given conception (which is given in a confused
17979: state) has been fully developed, until I know that the representation
17980: is adequate with its object. But, inasmuch as the conception, as it is
17981: presented to the mind, may contain a number of obscure representations,
17982: which we do not observe in our analysis, although we employ them in our
17983: application of the conception, I can never be sure that my analysis is
17984: complete, while examples may make this probable, although they can
17985: never demonstrate the fact. Instead of the word definition, I should
17986: rather employ the term exposition—a more modest expression, which the
17987: critic may accept without surrendering his doubts as to the
17988: completeness of the analysis of any such conception. As, therefore,
17989: neither empirical nor à priori conceptions are capable of definition,
17990: we have to see whether the only other kind of conceptions—arbitrary
17991: conceptions—can be subjected to this mental operation. Such a
17992: conception can always be defined; for I must know thoroughly what I
17993: wished to cogitate in it, as it was I who created it, and it was not
17994: given to my mind either by the nature of my understanding or by
17995: experience. At the same time, I cannot say that, by such a definition,
17996: I have defined a real object. If the conception is based upon empirical
17997: conditions, if, for example, I have a conception of a clock for a ship,
17998: this arbitrary conception does not assure me of the existence or even
17999: of the possibility of the object. My definition of such a conception
18000: would with more propriety be termed a declaration of a project than a
18001: definition of an object. There are no other conceptions which can bear
18002: definition, except those which contain an arbitrary synthesis, which
18003: can be constructed à priori. Consequently, the science of mathematics
18004: alone possesses definitions. For the object here thought is presented à
18005: priori in intuition; and thus it can never contain more or less than
18006: the conception, because the conception of the object has been given by
18007: the definition—and primarily, that is, without deriving the definition
18008: from any other source. Philosophical definitions are, therefore, merely
18009: expositions of given conceptions, while mathematical definitions are
18010: constructions of conceptions originally formed by the mind itself; the
18011: former are produced by analysis, the completeness of which is never
18012: demonstratively certain, the latter by a synthesis. In a mathematical
18013: definition the conception is formed, in a philosophical definition it
18014: is only explained. From this it follows:
18015: 
18016:  [76] The definition must describe the conception completely that is,
18017:  omit none of the marks or signs of which it composed; within its own
18018:  limits, that is, it must be precise, and enumerate no more signs than
18019:  belong to the conception; and on primary grounds, that is to say, the
18020:  limitations of the bounds of the conception must not be deduced from
18021:  other conceptions, as in this case a proof would be necessary, and the
18022:  so-called definition would be incapable of taking its place at the
18023:  head of all the judgements we have to form regarding an object.
18024: 
18025: 
18026: (a) That we must not imitate, in philosophy, the mathematical usage of
18027: commencing with definitions—except by way of hypothesis or experiment.
18028: For, as all so-called philosophical definitions are merely analyses of
18029: given conceptions, these conceptions, although only in a confused form,
18030: must precede the analysis; and the incomplete exposition must precede
18031: the complete, so that we may be able to draw certain inferences from
18032: the characteristics which an incomplete analysis has enabled us to
18033: discover, before we attain to the complete exposition or definition of
18034: the conception. In one word, a full and clear definition ought, in
18035: philosophy, rather to form the conclusion than the commencement of our
18036: labours.[77] In mathematics, on the contrary, we cannot have a
18037: conception prior to the definition; it is the definition which gives us
18038: the conception, and it must for this reason form the commencement of
18039: every chain of mathematical reasoning.
18040: 
18041:  [77] Philosophy abounds in faulty definitions, especially such as
18042:  contain some of the elements requisite to form a complete definition.
18043:  If a conception could not be employed in reasoning before it had been
18044:  defined, it would fare ill with all philosophical thought. But, as
18045:  incompletely defined conceptions may always be employed without
18046:  detriment to truth, so far as our analysis of the elements contained
18047:  in them proceeds, imperfect definitions, that is, propositions which
18048:  are properly not definitions, but merely approximations thereto, may
18049:  be used with great advantage. In mathematics, definition belongs ad
18050:  esse, in philosophy ad melius esse. It is a difficult task to
18051:  construct a proper definition. Jurists are still without a complete
18052:  definition of the idea of right.
18053: 
18054: 
18055: (b) Mathematical definitions cannot be erroneous. For the conception is
18056: given only in and through the definition, and thus it contains only
18057: what has been cogitated in the definition. But although a definition
18058: cannot be incorrect, as regards its content, an error may sometimes,
18059: although seldom, creep into the form. This error consists in a want of
18060: precision. Thus the common definition of a circle—that it is a curved
18061: line, every point in which is equally distant from another point called
18062: the centre—is faulty, from the fact that the determination indicated by
18063: the word curved is superfluous. For there ought to be a particular
18064: theorem, which may be easily proved from the definition, to the effect
18065: that every line, which has all its points at equal distances from
18066: another point, must be a curved line—that is, that not even the
18067: smallest part of it can be straight. Analytical definitions, on the
18068: other hand, may be erroneous in many respects, either by the
18069: introduction of signs which do not actually exist in the conception, or
18070: by wanting in that completeness which forms the essential of a
18071: definition. In the latter case, the definition is necessarily
18072: defective, because we can never be fully certain of the completeness of
18073: our analysis. For these reasons, the method of definition employed in
18074: mathematics cannot be imitated in philosophy.
18075: 
18076: 2. Of Axioms. These, in so far as they are immediately certain, are à
18077: priori synthetical principles. Now, one conception cannot be connected
18078: synthetically and yet immediately with another; because, if we wish to
18079: proceed out of and beyond a conception, a third mediating cognition is
18080: necessary. And, as philosophy is a cognition of reason by the aid of
18081: conceptions alone, there is to be found in it no principle which
18082: deserves to be called an axiom. Mathematics, on the other hand, may
18083: possess axioms, because it can always connect the predicates of an
18084: object à priori, and without any mediating term, by means of the
18085: construction of conceptions in intuition. Such is the case with the
18086: proposition: Three points can always lie in a plane. On the other hand,
18087: no synthetical principle which is based upon conceptions, can ever be
18088: immediately certain (for example, the proposition: Everything that
18089: happens has a cause), because I require a mediating term to connect the
18090: two conceptions of event and cause—namely, the condition of
18091: time-determination in an experience, and I cannot cognize any such
18092: principle immediately and from conceptions alone. Discursive principles
18093: are, accordingly, very different from intuitive principles or axioms.
18094: The former always require deduction, which in the case of the latter
18095: may be altogether dispensed with. Axioms are, for this reason, always
18096: self-evident, while philosophical principles, whatever may be the
18097: degree of certainty they possess, cannot lay any claim to such a
18098: distinction. No synthetical proposition of pure transcendental reason
18099: can be so evident, as is often rashly enough declared, as the
18100: statement, twice two are four. It is true that in the Analytic I
18101: introduced into the list of principles of the pure understanding,
18102: certain axioms of intuition; but the principle there discussed was not
18103: itself an axiom, but served merely to present the principle of the
18104: possibility of axioms in general, while it was really nothing more than
18105: a principle based upon conceptions. For it is one part of the duty of
18106: transcendental philosophy to establish the possibility of mathematics
18107: itself. Philosophy possesses, then, no axioms, and has no right to
18108: impose its à priori principles upon thought, until it has established
18109: their authority and validity by a thoroughgoing deduction.
18110: 
18111: 3. Of Demonstrations. Only an apodeictic proof, based upon intuition,
18112: can be termed a demonstration. Experience teaches us what is, but it
18113: cannot convince us that it might not have been otherwise. Hence a proof
18114: upon empirical grounds cannot be apodeictic. À priori conceptions, in
18115: discursive cognition, can never produce intuitive certainty or
18116: evidence, however certain the judgement they present may be.
18117: Mathematics alone, therefore, contains demonstrations, because it does
18118: not deduce its cognition from conceptions, but from the construction of
18119: conceptions, that is, from intuition, which can be given à priori in
18120: accordance with conceptions. The method of algebra, in equations, from
18121: which the correct answer is deduced by reduction, is a kind of
18122: construction—not geometrical, but by symbols—in which all conceptions,
18123: especially those of the relations of quantities, are represented in
18124: intuition by signs; and thus the conclusions in that science are
18125: secured from errors by the fact that every proof is submitted to ocular
18126: evidence. Philosophical cognition does not possess this advantage, it
18127: being required to consider the general always in abstracto (by means of
18128: conceptions), while mathematics can always consider it in concreto (in
18129: an individual intuition), and at the same time by means of à priori
18130: representation, whereby all errors are rendered manifest to the senses.
18131: The former—discursive proofs—ought to be termed acroamatic proofs,
18132: rather than demonstrations, as only words are employed in them, while
18133: demonstrations proper, as the term itself indicates, always require a
18134: reference to the intuition of the object.
18135: 
18136: It follows from all these considerations that it is not consonant with
18137: the nature of philosophy, especially in the sphere of pure reason, to
18138: employ the dogmatical method, and to adorn itself with the titles and
18139: insignia of mathematical science. It does not belong to that order, and
18140: can only hope for a fraternal union with that science. Its attempts at
18141: mathematical evidence are vain pretensions, which can only keep it back
18142: from its true aim, which is to detect the illusory procedure of reason
18143: when transgressing its proper limits, and by fully explaining and
18144: analysing our conceptions, to conduct us from the dim regions of
18145: speculation to the clear region of modest self-knowledge. Reason must
18146: not, therefore, in its transcendental endeavours, look forward with
18147: such confidence, as if the path it is pursuing led straight to its aim,
18148: nor reckon with such security upon its premisses, as to consider it
18149: unnecessary to take a step back, or to keep a strict watch for errors,
18150: which, overlooked in the principles, may be detected in the arguments
18151: themselves—in which case it may be requisite either to determine these
18152: principles with greater strictness, or to change them entirely.
18153: 
18154: I divide all apodeictic propositions, whether demonstrable or
18155: immediately certain, into dogmata and mathemata. A direct synthetical
18156: proposition, based on conceptions, is a dogma; a proposition of the
18157: same kind, based on the construction of conceptions, is a mathema.
18158: Analytical judgements do not teach us any more about an object than
18159: what was contained in the conception we had of it; because they do not
18160: extend our cognition beyond our conception of an object, they merely
18161: elucidate the conception. They cannot therefore be with propriety
18162: termed dogmas. Of the two kinds of à priori synthetical propositions
18163: above mentioned, only those which are employed in philosophy can,
18164: according to the general mode of speech, bear this name; those of
18165: arithmetic or geometry would not be rightly so denominated. Thus the
18166: customary mode of speaking confirms the explanation given above, and
18167: the conclusion arrived at, that only those judgements which are based
18168: upon conceptions, not on the construction of conceptions, can be termed
18169: dogmatical.
18170: 
18171: Thus, pure reason, in the sphere of speculation, does not contain a
18172: single direct synthetical judgement based upon conceptions. By means of
18173: ideas, it is, as we have shown, incapable of producing synthetical
18174: judgements, which are objectively valid; by means of the conceptions of
18175: the understanding, it establishes certain indubitable principles, not,
18176: however, directly on the basis of conceptions, but only indirectly by
18177: means of the relation of these conceptions to something of a purely
18178: contingent nature, namely, possible experience. When experience is
18179: presupposed, these principles are apodeictically certain, but in
18180: themselves, and directly, they cannot even be cognized à priori. Thus
18181: the given conceptions of cause and event will not be sufficient for the
18182: demonstration of the proposition: Every event has a cause. For this
18183: reason, it is not a dogma; although from another point of view, that of
18184: experience, it is capable of being proved to demonstration. The proper
18185: term for such a proposition is principle, and not theorem (although it
18186: does require to be proved), because it possesses the remarkable
18187: peculiarity of being the condition of the possibility of its own ground
18188: of proof, that is, experience, and of forming a necessary
18189: presupposition in all empirical observation.
18190: 
18191: If then, in the speculative sphere of pure reason, no dogmata are to be
18192: found; all dogmatical methods, whether borrowed from mathematics, or
18193: invented by philosophical thinkers, are alike inappropriate and
18194: inefficient. They only serve to conceal errors and fallacies, and to
18195: deceive philosophy, whose duty it is to see that reason pursues a safe
18196: and straight path. A philosophical method may, however, be
18197: systematical. For our reason is, subjectively considered, itself a
18198: system, and, in the sphere of mere conceptions, a system of
18199: investigation according to principles of unity, the material being
18200: supplied by experience alone. But this is not the proper place for
18201: discussing the peculiar method of transcendental philosophy, as our
18202: present task is simply to examine whether our faculties are capable of
18203: erecting an edifice on the basis of pure reason, and how far they may
18204: proceed with the materials at their command.
18205: 
18206: Section II. The Discipline of Pure Reason in Polemics
18207: 
18208: Reason must be subject, in all its operations, to criticism, which must
18209: always be permitted to exercise its functions without restraint;
18210: otherwise its interests are imperilled and its influence obnoxious to
18211: suspicion. There is nothing, however useful, however sacred it may be,
18212: that can claim exemption from the searching examination of this supreme
18213: tribunal, which has no respect of persons. The very existence of reason
18214: depends upon this freedom; for the voice of reason is not that of a
18215: dictatorial and despotic power, it is rather like the vote of the
18216: citizens of a free state, every member of which must have the privilege
18217: of giving free expression to his doubts, and possess even the right of
18218: veto.
18219: 
18220: But while reason can never decline to submit itself to the tribunal of
18221: criticism, it has not always cause to dread the judgement of this
18222: court. Pure reason, however, when engaged in the sphere of dogmatism,
18223: is not so thoroughly conscious of a strict observance of its highest
18224: laws, as to appear before a higher judicial reason with perfect
18225: confidence. On the contrary, it must renounce its magnificent
18226: dogmatical pretensions in philosophy.
18227: 
18228: Very different is the case when it has to defend itself, not before a
18229: judge, but against an equal. If dogmatical assertions are advanced on
18230: the negative side, in opposition to those made by reason on the
18231: positive side, its justification kat authrhopon is complete, although
18232: the proof of its propositions is kat aletheian unsatisfactory.
18233: 
18234: By the polemic of pure reason I mean the defence of its propositions
18235: made by reason, in opposition to the dogmatical counter-propositions
18236: advanced by other parties. The question here is not whether its own
18237: statements may not also be false; it merely regards the fact that
18238: reason proves that the opposite cannot be established with
18239: demonstrative certainty, nor even asserted with a higher degree of
18240: probability. Reason does not hold her possessions upon sufferance; for,
18241: although she cannot show a perfectly satisfactory title to them, no one
18242: can prove that she is not the rightful possessor.
18243: 
18244: It is a melancholy reflection that reason, in its highest exercise,
18245: falls into an antithetic; and that the supreme tribunal for the
18246: settlement of differences should not be at union with itself. It is
18247: true that we had to discuss the question of an apparent antithetic, but
18248: we found that it was based upon a misconception. In conformity with the
18249: common prejudice, phenomena were regarded as things in themselves, and
18250: thus an absolute completeness in their synthesis was required in the
18251: one mode or in the other (it was shown to be impossible in both); a
18252: demand entirely out of place in regard to phenomena. There was, then,
18253: no real self-contradiction of reason in the propositions: The series of
18254: phenomena given in themselves has an absolutely first beginning; and:
18255: This series is absolutely and in itself without beginning. The two
18256: propositions are perfectly consistent with each other, because
18257: phenomena as phenomena are in themselves nothing, and consequently the
18258: hypothesis that they are things in themselves must lead to
18259: self-contradictory inferences.
18260: 
18261: But there are cases in which a similar misunderstanding cannot be
18262: provided against, and the dispute must remain unsettled. Take, for
18263: example, the theistic proposition: There is a Supreme Being; and on the
18264: other hand, the atheistic counter-statement: There exists no Supreme
18265: Being; or, in psychology: Everything that thinks possesses the
18266: attribute of absolute and permanent unity, which is utterly different
18267: from the transitory unity of material phenomena; and the
18268: counter-proposition: The soul is not an immaterial unity, and its
18269: nature is transitory, like that of phenomena. The objects of these
18270: questions contain no heterogeneous or contradictory elements, for they
18271: relate to things in themselves, and not to phenomena. There would
18272: arise, indeed, a real contradiction, if reason came forward with a
18273: statement on the negative side of these questions alone. As regards the
18274: criticism to which the grounds of proof on the affirmative side must be
18275: subjected, it may be freely admitted, without necessitating the
18276: surrender of the affirmative propositions, which have, at least, the
18277: interest of reason in their favour—an advantage which the opposite
18278: party cannot lay claim to.
18279: 
18280: I cannot agree with the opinion of several admirable thinkers—Sulzer
18281: among the rest—that, in spite of the weakness of the arguments hitherto
18282: in use, we may hope, one day, to see sufficient demonstrations of the
18283: two cardinal propositions of pure reason—the existence of a Supreme
18284: Being, and the immortality of the soul. I am certain, on the contrary,
18285: that this will never be the case. For on what ground can reason base
18286: such synthetical propositions, which do not relate to the objects of
18287: experience and their internal possibility? But it is also
18288: demonstratively certain that no one will ever be able to maintain the
18289: contrary with the least show of probability. For, as he can attempt
18290: such a proof solely upon the basis of pure reason, he is bound to prove
18291: that a Supreme Being, and a thinking subject in the character of a pure
18292: intelligence, are impossible. But where will he find the knowledge
18293: which can enable him to enounce synthetical judgements in regard to
18294: things which transcend the region of experience? We may, therefore,
18295: rest assured that the opposite never will be demonstrated. We need not,
18296: then, have recourse to scholastic arguments; we may always admit the
18297: truth of those propositions which are consistent with the speculative
18298: interests of reason in the sphere of experience, and form, moreover,
18299: the only means of uniting the speculative with the practical interest.
18300: Our opponent, who must not be considered here as a critic solely, we
18301: can be ready to meet with a non liquet which cannot fail to disconcert
18302: him; while we cannot deny his right to a similar retort, as we have on
18303: our side the advantage of the support of the subjective maxim of
18304: reason, and can therefore look upon all his sophistical arguments with
18305: calm indifference.
18306: 
18307: From this point of view, there is properly no antithetic of pure
18308: reason. For the only arena for such a struggle would be upon the field
18309: of pure theology and psychology; but on this ground there can appear no
18310: combatant whom we need to fear. Ridicule and boasting can be his only
18311: weapons; and these may be laughed at, as mere child’s play. This
18312: consideration restores to Reason her courage; for what source of
18313: confidence could be found, if she, whose vocation it is to destroy
18314: error, were at variance with herself and without any reasonable hope of
18315: ever reaching a state of permanent repose?
18316: 
18317: Everything in nature is good for some purpose. Even poisons are
18318: serviceable; they destroy the evil effects of other poisons generated
18319: in our system, and must always find a place in every complete
18320: pharmacopoeia. The objections raised against the fallacies and
18321: sophistries of speculative reason, are objections given by the nature
18322: of this reason itself, and must therefore have a destination and
18323: purpose which can only be for the good of humanity. For what purpose
18324: has Providence raised many objects, in which we have the deepest
18325: interest, so far above us, that we vainly try to cognize them with
18326: certainty, and our powers of mental vision are rather excited than
18327: satisfied by the glimpses we may chance to seize? It is very doubtful
18328: whether it is for our benefit to advance bold affirmations regarding
18329: subjects involved in such obscurity; perhaps it would even be
18330: detrimental to our best interests. But it is undoubtedly always
18331: beneficial to leave the investigating, as well as the critical reason,
18332: in perfect freedom, and permit it to take charge of its own interests,
18333: which are advanced as much by its limitation, as by its extension of
18334: its views, and which always suffer by the interference of foreign
18335: powers forcing it, against its natural tendencies, to bend to certain
18336: preconceived designs.
18337: 
18338: Allow your opponent to say what he thinks reasonable, and combat him
18339: only with the weapons of reason. Have no anxiety for the practical
18340: interests of humanity—these are never imperilled in a purely
18341: speculative dispute. Such a dispute serves merely to disclose the
18342: antinomy of reason, which, as it has its source in the nature of
18343: reason, ought to be thoroughly investigated. Reason is benefited by the
18344: examination of a subject on both sides, and its judgements are
18345: corrected by being limited. It is not the matter that may give occasion
18346: to dispute, but the manner. For it is perfectly permissible to employ,
18347: in the presence of reason, the language of a firmly rooted faith, even
18348: after we have been obliged to renounce all pretensions to knowledge.
18349: 
18350: If we were to ask the dispassionate David Hume—a philosopher endowed,
18351: in a degree that few are, with a well-balanced judgement: What motive
18352: induced you to spend so much labour and thought in undermining the
18353: consoling and beneficial persuasion that reason is capable of assuring
18354: us of the existence, and presenting us with a determinate conception of
18355: a Supreme Being?—his answer would be: Nothing but the desire of
18356: teaching reason to know its own powers better, and, at the same time, a
18357: dislike of the procedure by which that faculty was compelled to support
18358: foregone conclusions, and prevented from confessing the internal
18359: weaknesses which it cannot but feel when it enters upon a rigid
18360: self-examination. If, on the other hand, we were to ask Priestley—a
18361: philosopher who had no taste for transcendental speculation, but was
18362: entirely devoted to the principles of empiricism—what his motives were
18363: for overturning those two main pillars of religion—the doctrines of the
18364: freedom of the will and the immortality of the soul (in his view the
18365: hope of a future life is but the expectation of the miracle of
18366: resurrection)—this philosopher, himself a zealous and pious teacher of
18367: religion, could give no other answer than this: I acted in the interest
18368: of reason, which always suffers, when certain objects are explained and
18369: judged by a reference to other supposed laws than those of material
18370: nature—the only laws which we know in a determinate manner. It would be
18371: unfair to decry the latter philosopher, who endeavoured to harmonize
18372: his paradoxical opinions with the interests of religion, and to
18373: undervalue an honest and reflecting man, because he finds himself at a
18374: loss the moment he has left the field of natural science. The same
18375: grace must be accorded to Hume, a man not less well-disposed, and quite
18376: as blameless in his moral character, and who pushed his abstract
18377: speculations to an extreme length, because, as he rightly believed, the
18378: object of them lies entirely beyond the bounds of natural science, and
18379: within the sphere of pure ideas.
18380: 
18381: What is to be done to provide against the danger which seems in the
18382: present case to menace the best interests of humanity? The course to be
18383: pursued in reference to this subject is a perfectly plain and natural
18384: one. Let each thinker pursue his own path; if he shows talent, if he
18385: gives evidence of profound thought, in one word, if he shows that he
18386: possesses the power of reasoning—reason is always the gainer. If you
18387: have recourse to other means, if you attempt to coerce reason, if you
18388: raise the cry of treason to humanity, if you excite the feelings of the
18389: crowd, which can neither understand nor sympathize with such subtle
18390: speculations—you will only make yourselves ridiculous. For the question
18391: does not concern the advantage or disadvantage which we are expected to
18392: reap from such inquiries; the question is merely how far reason can
18393: advance in the field of speculation, apart from all kinds of interest,
18394: and whether we may depend upon the exertions of speculative reason, or
18395: must renounce all reliance on it. Instead of joining the combatants, it
18396: is your part to be a tranquil spectator of the struggle—a laborious
18397: struggle for the parties engaged, but attended, in its progress as well
18398: as in its result, with the most advantageous consequences for the
18399: interests of thought and knowledge. It is absurd to expect to be
18400: enlightened by Reason, and at the same time to prescribe to her what
18401: side of the question she must adopt. Moreover, reason is sufficiently
18402: held in check by its own power, the limits imposed on it by its own
18403: nature are sufficient; it is unnecessary for you to place over it
18404: additional guards, as if its power were dangerous to the constitution
18405: of the intellectual state. In the dialectic of reason there is no
18406: victory gained which need in the least disturb your tranquility.
18407: 
18408: The strife of dialectic is a necessity of reason, and we cannot but
18409: wish that it had been conducted long ere this with that perfect freedom
18410: which ought to be its essential condition. In this case, we should have
18411: had at an earlier period a matured and profound criticism, which must
18412: have put an end to all dialectical disputes, by exposing the illusions
18413: and prejudices in which they originated.
18414: 
18415: There is in human nature an unworthy propensity—a propensity which,
18416: like everything that springs from nature, must in its final purpose be
18417: conducive to the good of humanity—to conceal our real sentiments, and
18418: to give expression only to certain received opinions, which are
18419: regarded as at once safe and promotive of the common good. It is true,
18420: this tendency, not only to conceal our real sentiments, but to profess
18421: those which may gain us favour in the eyes of society, has not only
18422: civilized, but, in a certain measure, moralized us; as no one can break
18423: through the outward covering of respectability, honour, and morality,
18424: and thus the seemingly-good examples which we see around us form an
18425: excellent school for moral improvement, so long as our belief in their
18426: genuineness remains unshaken. But this disposition to represent
18427: ourselves as better than we are, and to utter opinions which are not
18428: our own, can be nothing more than a kind of provisionary arrangement of
18429: nature to lead us from the rudeness of an uncivilized state, and to
18430: teach us how to assume at least the appearance and manner of the good
18431: we see. But when true principles have been developed, and have obtained
18432: a sure foundation in our habit of thought, this conventionalism must be
18433: attacked with earnest vigour, otherwise it corrupts the heart, and
18434: checks the growth of good dispositions with the mischievous weed of
18435: fair appearances.
18436: 
18437: I am sorry to remark the same tendency to misrepresentation and
18438: hypocrisy in the sphere of speculative discussion, where there is less
18439: temptation to restrain the free expression of thought. For what can be
18440: more prejudicial to the interests of intelligence than to falsify our
18441: real sentiments, to conceal the doubts which we feel in regard to our
18442: statements, or to maintain the validity of grounds of proof which we
18443: well know to be insufficient? So long as mere personal vanity is the
18444: source of these unworthy artifices—and this is generally the case in
18445: speculative discussions, which are mostly destitute of practical
18446: interest, and are incapable of complete demonstration—the vanity of the
18447: opposite party exaggerates as much on the other side; and thus the
18448: result is the same, although it is not brought about so soon as if the
18449: dispute had been conducted in a sincere and upright spirit. But where
18450: the mass entertains the notion that the aim of certain subtle
18451: speculators is nothing less than to shake the very foundations of
18452: public welfare and morality—it seems not only prudent, but even praise
18453: worthy, to maintain the good cause by illusory arguments, rather than
18454: to give to our supposed opponents the advantage of lowering our
18455: declarations to the moderate tone of a merely practical conviction, and
18456: of compelling us to confess our inability to attain to apodeictic
18457: certainty in speculative subjects. But we ought to reflect that there
18458: is nothing, in the world more fatal to the maintenance of a good cause
18459: than deceit, misrepresentation, and falsehood. That the strictest laws
18460: of honesty should be observed in the discussion of a purely speculative
18461: subject is the least requirement that can be made. If we could reckon
18462: with security even upon so little, the conflict of speculative reason
18463: regarding the important questions of God, immortality, and freedom,
18464: would have been either decided long ago, or would very soon be brought
18465: to a conclusion. But, in general, the uprightness of the defence stands
18466: in an inverse ratio to the goodness of the cause; and perhaps more
18467: honesty and fairness are shown by those who deny than by those who
18468: uphold these doctrines.
18469: 
18470: I shall persuade myself, then, that I have readers who do not wish to
18471: see a righteous cause defended by unfair arguments. Such will now
18472: recognize the fact that, according to the principles of this Critique,
18473: if we consider not what is, but what ought to be the case, there can be
18474: really no polemic of pure reason. For how can two persons dispute about
18475: a thing, the reality of which neither can present in actual or even in
18476: possible experience? Each adopts the plan of meditating on his idea for
18477: the purpose of drawing from the idea, if he can, what is more than the
18478: idea, that is, the reality of the object which it indicates. How shall
18479: they settle the dispute, since neither is able to make his assertions
18480: directly comprehensible and certain, but must restrict himself to
18481: attacking and confuting those of his opponent? All statements enounced
18482: by pure reason transcend the conditions of possible experience, beyond
18483: the sphere of which we can discover no criterion of truth, while they
18484: are at the same time framed in accordance with the laws of the
18485: understanding, which are applicable only to experience; and thus it is
18486: the fate of all such speculative discussions that while the one party
18487: attacks the weaker side of his opponent, he infallibly lays open his
18488: own weaknesses.
18489: 
18490: The critique of pure reason may be regarded as the highest tribunal for
18491: all speculative disputes; for it is not involved in these disputes,
18492: which have an immediate relation to certain objects and not to the laws
18493: of the mind, but is instituted for the purpose of determining the
18494: rights and limits of reason.
18495: 
18496: Without the control of criticism, reason is, as it were, in a state of
18497: nature, and can only establish its claims and assertions by war.
18498: Criticism, on the contrary, deciding all questions according to the
18499: fundamental laws of its own institution, secures to us the peace of law
18500: and order, and enables us to discuss all differences in the more
18501: tranquil manner of a legal process. In the former case, disputes are
18502: ended by victory, which both sides may claim and which is followed by a
18503: hollow armistice; in the latter, by a sentence, which, as it strikes at
18504: the root of all speculative differences, ensures to all concerned a
18505: lasting peace. The endless disputes of a dogmatizing reason compel us
18506: to look for some mode of arriving at a settled decision by a critical
18507: investigation of reason itself; just as Hobbes maintains that the state
18508: of nature is a state of injustice and violence, and that we must leave
18509: it and submit ourselves to the constraint of law, which indeed limits
18510: individual freedom, but only that it may consist with the freedom of
18511: others and with the common good of all.
18512: 
18513: This freedom will, among other things, permit of our openly stating the
18514: difficulties and doubts which we are ourselves unable to solve, without
18515: being decried on that account as turbulent and dangerous citizens. This
18516: privilege forms part of the native rights of human reason, which
18517: recognizes no other judge than the universal reason of humanity; and as
18518: this reason is the source of all progress and improvement, such a
18519: privilege is to be held sacred and inviolable. It is unwise, moreover,
18520: to denounce as dangerous any bold assertions against, or rash attacks
18521: upon, an opinion which is held by the largest and most moral class of
18522: the community; for that would be giving them an importance which they
18523: do not deserve. When I hear that the freedom of the will, the hope of a
18524: future life, and the existence of God have been overthrown by the
18525: arguments of some able writer, I feel a strong desire to read his book;
18526: for I expect that he will add to my knowledge and impart greater
18527: clearness and distinctness to my views by the argumentative power shown
18528: in his writings. But I am perfectly certain, even before I have opened
18529: the book, that he has not succeeded in a single point, not because I
18530: believe I am in possession of irrefutable demonstrations of these
18531: important propositions, but because this transcendental critique, which
18532: has disclosed to me the power and the limits of pure reason, has fully
18533: convinced me that, as it is insufficient to establish the affirmative,
18534: it is as powerless, and even more so, to assure us of the truth of the
18535: negative answer to these questions. From what source does this
18536: free-thinker derive his knowledge that there is, for example, no
18537: Supreme Being? This proposition lies out of the field of possible
18538: experience, and, therefore, beyond the limits of human cognition. But I
18539: would not read at, all the answer which the dogmatical maintainer of
18540: the good cause makes to his opponent, because I know well beforehand,
18541: that he will merely attack the fallacious grounds of his adversary,
18542: without being able to establish his own assertions. Besides, a new
18543: illusory argument, in the construction of which talent and acuteness
18544: are shown, is suggestive of new ideas and new trains of reasoning, and
18545: in this respect the old and everyday sophistries are quite useless.
18546: Again, the dogmatical opponent of religion gives employment to
18547: criticism, and enables us to test and correct its principles, while
18548: there is no occasion for anxiety in regard to the influence and results
18549: of his reasoning.
18550: 
18551: But, it will be said, must we not warn the youth entrusted to
18552: academical care against such writings, must we not preserve them from
18553: the knowledge of these dangerous assertions, until their judgement is
18554: ripened, or rather until the doctrines which we wish to inculcate are
18555: so firmly rooted in their minds as to withstand all attempts at
18556: instilling the contrary dogmas, from whatever quarter they may come?
18557: 
18558: If we are to confine ourselves to the dogmatical procedure in the
18559: sphere of pure reason, and find ourselves unable to settle such
18560: disputes otherwise than by becoming a party in them, and setting
18561: counter-assertions against the statements advanced by our opponents,
18562: there is certainly no plan more advisable for the moment, but, at the
18563: same time, none more absurd and inefficient for the future, than this
18564: retaining of the youthful mind under guardianship for a time, and thus
18565: preserving it—for so long at least—from seduction into error. But when,
18566: at a later period, either curiosity, or the prevalent fashion of
18567: thought places such writings in their hands, will the so-called
18568: convictions of their youth stand firm? The young thinker, who has in
18569: his armoury none but dogmatical weapons with which to resist the
18570: attacks of his opponent, and who cannot detect the latent dialectic
18571: which lies in his own opinions as well as in those of the opposite
18572: party, sees the advance of illusory arguments and grounds of proof
18573: which have the advantage of novelty, against as illusory grounds of
18574: proof destitute of this advantage, and which, perhaps, excite the
18575: suspicion that the natural credulity of his youth has been abused by
18576: his instructors. He thinks he can find no better means of showing that
18577: he has out grown the discipline of his minority than by despising those
18578: well-meant warnings, and, knowing no system of thought but that of
18579: dogmatism, he drinks deep draughts of the poison that is to sap the
18580: principles in which his early years were trained.
18581: 
18582: Exactly the opposite of the system here recommended ought to be pursued
18583: in academical instruction. This can only be effected, however, by a
18584: thorough training in the critical investigation of pure reason. For, in
18585: order to bring the principles of this critique into exercise as soon as
18586: possible, and to demonstrate their perfect even in the presence of the
18587: highest degree of dialectical illusion, the student ought to examine
18588: the assertions made on both sides of speculative questions step by
18589: step, and to test them by these principles. It cannot be a difficult
18590: task for him to show the fallacies inherent in these propositions, and
18591: thus he begins early to feel his own power of securing himself against
18592: the influence of such sophistical arguments, which must finally lose,
18593: for him, all their illusory power. And, although the same blows which
18594: overturn the edifice of his opponent are as fatal to his own
18595: speculative structures, if such he has wished to rear; he need not feel
18596: any sorrow in regard to this seeming misfortune, as he has now before
18597: him a fair prospect into the practical region in which he may
18598: reasonably hope to find a more secure foundation for a rational system.
18599: 
18600: There is, accordingly, no proper polemic in the sphere of pure reason.
18601: Both parties beat the air and fight with their own shadows, as they
18602: pass beyond the limits of nature, and can find no tangible point of
18603: attack—no firm footing for their dogmatical conflict. Fight as
18604: vigorously as they may, the shadows which they hew down, immediately
18605: start up again, like the heroes in Walhalla, and renew the bloodless
18606: and unceasing contest.
18607: 
18608: But neither can we admit that there is any proper sceptical employment
18609: of pure reason, such as might be based upon the principle of neutrality
18610: in all speculative disputes. To excite reason against itself, to place
18611: weapons in the hands of the party on the one side as well as in those
18612: of the other, and to remain an undisturbed and sarcastic spectator of
18613: the fierce struggle that ensues, seems, from the dogmatical point of
18614: view, to be a part fitting only a malevolent disposition. But, when the
18615: sophist evidences an invincible obstinacy and blindness, and a pride
18616: which no criticism can moderate, there is no other practicable course
18617: than to oppose to this pride and obstinacy similar feelings and
18618: pretensions on the other side, equally well or ill founded, so that
18619: reason, staggered by the reflections thus forced upon it, finds it
18620: necessary to moderate its confidence in such pretensions and to listen
18621: to the advice of criticism. But we cannot stop at these doubts, much
18622: less regard the conviction of our ignorance, not only as a cure for the
18623: conceit natural to dogmatism, but as the settlement of the disputes in
18624: which reason is involved with itself. On the contrary, scepticism is
18625: merely a means of awakening reason from its dogmatic dreams and
18626: exciting it to a more careful investigation into its own powers and
18627: pretensions. But, as scepticism appears to be the shortest road to a
18628: permanent peace in the domain of philosophy, and as it is the track
18629: pursued by the many who aim at giving a philosophical colouring to
18630: their contemptuous dislike of all inquiries of this kind, I think it
18631: necessary to present to my readers this mode of thought in its true
18632: light.
18633: 
18634: _Scepticism not a Permanent State for Human Reason._
18635: 
18636: The consciousness of ignorance—unless this ignorance is recognized to
18637: be absolutely necessary ought, instead of forming the conclusion of my
18638: inquiries, to be the strongest motive to the pursuit of them. All
18639: ignorance is either ignorance of things or of the limits of knowledge.
18640: If my ignorance is accidental and not necessary, it must incite me, in
18641: the first case, to a dogmatical inquiry regarding the objects of which
18642: I am ignorant; in the second, to a critical investigation into the
18643: bounds of all possible knowledge. But that my ignorance is absolutely
18644: necessary and unavoidable, and that it consequently absolves from the
18645: duty of all further investigation, is a fact which cannot be made out
18646: upon empirical grounds—from observation—but upon critical grounds
18647: alone, that is, by a thoroughgoing investigation into the primary
18648: sources of cognition. It follows that the determination of the bounds
18649: of reason can be made only on à priori grounds; while the empirical
18650: limitation of reason, which is merely an indeterminate cognition of an
18651: ignorance that can never be completely removed, can take place only à
18652: posteriori. In other words, our empirical knowledge is limited by that
18653: which yet remains for us to know. The former cognition of our
18654: ignorance, which is possible only on a rational basis, is a science;
18655: the latter is merely a perception, and we cannot say how far the
18656: inferences drawn from it may extend. If I regard the earth, as it
18657: really appears to my senses, as a flat surface, I am ignorant how far
18658: this surface extends. But experience teaches me that, how far soever I
18659: go, I always see before me a space in which I can proceed farther; and
18660: thus I know the limits—merely visual—of my actual knowledge of the
18661: earth, although I am ignorant of the limits of the earth itself. But if
18662: I have got so far as to know that the earth is a sphere, and that its
18663: surface is spherical, I can cognize à priori and determine upon
18664: principles, from my knowledge of a small part of this surface—say to
18665: the extent of a degree—the diameter and circumference of the earth; and
18666: although I am ignorant of the objects which this surface contains, I
18667: have a perfect knowledge of its limits and extent.
18668: 
18669: The sum of all the possible objects of our cognition seems to us to be
18670: a level surface, with an apparent horizon—that which forms the limit of
18671: its extent, and which has been termed by us the idea of unconditioned
18672: totality. To reach this limit by empirical means is impossible, and all
18673: attempts to determine it à priori according to a principle, are alike
18674: in vain. But all the questions raised by pure reason relate to that
18675: which lies beyond this horizon, or, at least, in its boundary line.
18676: 
18677: The celebrated David Hume was one of those geographers of human reason
18678: who believe that they have given a sufficient answer to all such
18679: questions by declaring them to lie beyond the horizon of our
18680: knowledge—a horizon which, however, Hume was unable to determine. His
18681: attention especially was directed to the principle of causality; and he
18682: remarked with perfect justice that the truth of this principle, and
18683: even the objective validity of the conception of a cause, was not
18684: commonly based upon clear insight, that is, upon à priori cognition.
18685: Hence he concluded that this law does not derive its authority from its
18686: universality and necessity, but merely from its general applicability
18687: in the course of experience, and a kind of subjective necessity thence
18688: arising, which he termed habit. From the inability of reason to
18689: establish this principle as a necessary law for the acquisition of all
18690: experience, he inferred the nullity of all the attempts of reason to
18691: pass the region of the empirical.
18692: 
18693: This procedure of subjecting the facta of reason to examination, and,
18694: if necessary, to disapproval, may be termed the censura of reason. This
18695: censura must inevitably lead us to doubts regarding all transcendent
18696: employment of principles. But this is only the second step in our
18697: inquiry. The first step in regard to the subjects of pure reason, and
18698: which marks the infancy of that faculty, is that of dogmatism. The
18699: second, which we have just mentioned, is that of scepticism, and it
18700: gives evidence that our judgement has been improved by experience. But
18701: a third step is necessary—indicative of the maturity and manhood of the
18702: judgement, which now lays a firm foundation upon universal and
18703: necessary principles. This is the period of criticism, in which we do
18704: not examine the facta of reason, but reason itself, in the whole extent
18705: of its powers, and in regard to its capability of à priori cognition;
18706: and thus we determine not merely the empirical and ever-shifting bounds
18707: of our knowledge, but its necessary and eternal limits. We demonstrate
18708: from indubitable principles, not merely our ignorance in respect to
18709: this or that subject, but in regard to all possible questions of a
18710: certain class. Thus scepticism is a resting place for reason, in which
18711: it may reflect on its dogmatical wanderings and gain some knowledge of
18712: the region in which it happens to be, that it may pursue its way with
18713: greater certainty; but it cannot be its permanent dwelling-place. It
18714: must take up its abode only in the region of complete certitude,
18715: whether this relates to the cognition of objects themselves, or to the
18716: limits which bound all our cognition.
18717: 
18718: Reason is not to be considered as an indefinitely extended plane, of
18719: the bounds of which we have only a general knowledge; it ought rather
18720: to be compared to a sphere, the radius of which may be found from the
18721: curvature of its surface—that is, the nature of à priori synthetical
18722: propositions—and, consequently, its circumference and extent. Beyond
18723: the sphere of experience there are no objects which it can cognize;
18724: nay, even questions regarding such supposititious objects relate only
18725: to the subjective principles of a complete determination of the
18726: relations which exist between the understanding-conceptions which lie
18727: within this sphere.
18728: 
18729: We are actually in possession of à priori synthetical cognitions, as is
18730: proved by the existence of the principles of the understanding, which
18731: anticipate experience. If any one cannot comprehend the possibility of
18732: these principles, he may have some reason to doubt whether they are
18733: really à priori; but he cannot on this account declare them to be
18734: impossible, and affirm the nullity of the steps which reason may have
18735: taken under their guidance. He can only say: If we perceived their
18736: origin and their authenticity, we should be able to determine the
18737: extent and limits of reason; but, till we can do this, all propositions
18738: regarding the latter are mere random assertions. In this view, the
18739: doubt respecting all dogmatical philosophy, which proceeds without the
18740: guidance of criticism, is well grounded; but we cannot therefore deny
18741: to reason the ability to construct a sound philosophy, when the way has
18742: been prepared by a thorough critical investigation. All the conceptions
18743: produced, and all the questions raised, by pure reason, do not lie in
18744: the sphere of experience, but in that of reason itself, and hence they
18745: must be solved, and shown to be either valid or inadmissible, by that
18746: faculty. We have no right to decline the solution of such problems, on
18747: the ground that the solution can be discovered only from the nature of
18748: things, and under pretence of the limitation of human faculties, for
18749: reason is the sole creator of all these ideas, and is therefore bound
18750: either to establish their validity or to expose their illusory nature.
18751: 
18752: The polemic of scepticism is properly directed against the dogmatist,
18753: who erects a system of philosophy without having examined the
18754: fundamental objective principles on which it is based, for the purpose
18755: of evidencing the futility of his designs, and thus bringing him to a
18756: knowledge of his own powers. But, in itself, scepticism does not give
18757: us any certain information in regard to the bounds of our knowledge.
18758: All unsuccessful dogmatical attempts of reason are facia, which it is
18759: always useful to submit to the censure of the sceptic. But this cannot
18760: help us to any decision regarding the expectations which reason
18761: cherishes of better success in future endeavours; the investigations of
18762: scepticism cannot, therefore, settle the dispute regarding the rights
18763: and powers of human reason.
18764: 
18765: Hume is perhaps the ablest and most ingenious of all sceptical
18766: philosophers, and his writings have, undoubtedly, exerted the most
18767: powerful influence in awakening reason to a thorough investigation into
18768: its own powers. It will, therefore, well repay our labours to consider
18769: for a little the course of reasoning which he followed and the errors
18770: into which he strayed, although setting out on the path of truth and
18771: certitude.
18772: 
18773: Hume was probably aware, although he never clearly developed the
18774: notion, that we proceed in judgements of a certain class beyond our
18775: conception of the object. I have termed this kind of judgement
18776: synthetical. As regard the manner in which I pass beyond my conception
18777: by the aid of experience, no doubts can be entertained. Experience is
18778: itself a synthesis of perceptions; and it employs perceptions to
18779: increment the conception, which I obtain by means of another
18780: perception. But we feel persuaded that we are able to proceed beyond a
18781: conception, and to extend our cognition à priori. We attempt this in
18782: two ways—either, through the pure understanding, in relation to that
18783: which may become an object of experience, or, through pure reason, in
18784: relation to such properties of things, or of the existence of things,
18785: as can never be presented in any experience. This sceptical philosopher
18786: did not distinguish these two kinds of judgements, as he ought to have
18787: done, but regarded this augmentation of conceptions, and, if we may so
18788: express ourselves, the spontaneous generation of understanding and
18789: reason, independently of the impregnation of experience, as altogether
18790: impossible. The so-called à priori principles of these faculties he
18791: consequently held to be invalid and imaginary, and regarded them as
18792: nothing but subjective habits of thought originating in experience, and
18793: therefore purely empirical and contingent rules, to which we attribute
18794: a spurious necessity and universality. In support of this strange
18795: assertion, he referred us to the generally acknowledged principle of
18796: the relation between cause and effect. No faculty of the mind can
18797: conduct us from the conception of a thing to the existence of something
18798: else; and hence he believed he could infer that, without experience, we
18799: possess no source from which we can augment a conception, and no ground
18800: sufficient to justify us in framing a judgement that is to extend our
18801: cognition à priori. That the light of the sun, which shines upon a
18802: piece of wax, at the same time melts it, while it hardens clay, no
18803: power of the understanding could infer from the conceptions which we
18804: previously possessed of these substances; much less is there any à
18805: priori law that could conduct us to such a conclusion, which experience
18806: alone can certify. On the other hand, we have seen in our discussion of
18807: transcendental logic, that, although we can never proceed immediately
18808: beyond the content of the conception which is given us, we can always
18809: cognize completely à priori—in relation, however, to a third term,
18810: namely, possible experience—the law of its connection with other
18811: things. For example, if I observe that a piece of wax melts, I can
18812: cognize à priori that there must have been something (the sun’s heat)
18813: preceding, which this law; although, without the aid of experience, I
18814: could not cognize à priori and in a determinate manner either the cause
18815: from the effect, or the effect from the cause. Hume was, therefore,
18816: wrong in inferring, from the contingency of the determination according
18817: to law, the contingency of the law itself; and the passing beyond the
18818: conception of a thing to possible experience (which is an à priori
18819: proceeding, constituting the objective reality of the conception), he
18820: confounded with our synthesis of objects in actual experience, which is
18821: always, of course, empirical. Thus, too, he regarded the principle of
18822: affinity, which has its seat in the understanding and indicates a
18823: necessary connection, as a mere rule of association, lying in the
18824: imitative faculty of imagination, which can present only contingent,
18825: and not objective connections.
18826: 
18827: The sceptical errors of this remarkably acute thinker arose principally
18828: from a defect, which was common to him with the dogmatists, namely,
18829: that he had never made a systematic review of all the different kinds
18830: of à priori synthesis performed by the understanding. Had he done so,
18831: he would have found, to take one example among many, that the principle
18832: of permanence was of this character, and that it, as well as the
18833: principle of causality, anticipates experience. In this way he might
18834: have been able to describe the determinate limits of the à priori
18835: operations of understanding and reason. But he merely declared the
18836: understanding to be limited, instead of showing what its limits were;
18837: he created a general mistrust in the power of our faculties, without
18838: giving us any determinate knowledge of the bounds of our necessary and
18839: unavoidable ignorance; he examined and condemned some of the principles
18840: of the understanding, without investigating all its powers with the
18841: completeness necessary to criticism. He denies, with truth, certain
18842: powers to the understanding, but he goes further, and declares it to be
