18843: utterly inadequate to the à priori extension of knowledge, although he
18844: has not fully examined all the powers which reside in the faculty; and
18845: thus the fate which always overtakes scepticism meets him too. That is
18846: to say, his own declarations are doubted, for his objections were based
18847: upon facta, which are contingent, and not upon principles, which can
18848: alone demonstrate the necessary invalidity of all dogmatical
18849: assertions.
18850: 
18851: As Hume makes no distinction between the well-grounded claims of the
18852: understanding and the dialectical pretensions of reason, against which,
18853: however, his attacks are mainly directed, reason does not feel itself
18854: shut out from all attempts at the extension of à priori cognition, and
18855: hence it refuses, in spite of a few checks in this or that quarter, to
18856: relinquish such efforts. For one naturally arms oneself to resist an
18857: attack, and becomes more obstinate in the resolve to establish the
18858: claims he has advanced. But a complete review of the powers of reason,
18859: and the conviction thence arising that we are in possession of a
18860: limited field of action, while we must admit the vanity of higher
18861: claims, puts an end to all doubt and dispute, and induces reason to
18862: rest satisfied with the undisturbed possession of its limited domain.
18863: 
18864: To the uncritical dogmatist, who has not surveyed the sphere of his
18865: understanding, nor determined, in accordance with principles, the
18866: limits of possible cognition, who, consequently, is ignorant of his own
18867: powers, and believes he will discover them by the attempts he makes in
18868: the field of cognition, these attacks of scepticism are not only
18869: dangerous, but destructive. For if there is one proposition in his
18870: chain of reasoning which he cannot prove, or the fallacy in which he
18871: cannot evolve in accordance with a principle, suspicion falls on all
18872: his statements, however plausible they may appear.
18873: 
18874: And thus scepticism, the bane of dogmatical philosophy, conducts us to
18875: a sound investigation into the understanding and the reason. When we
18876: are thus far advanced, we need fear no further attacks; for the limits
18877: of our domain are clearly marked out, and we can make no claims nor
18878: become involved in any disputes regarding the region that lies beyond
18879: these limits. Thus the sceptical procedure in philosophy does not
18880: present any solution of the problems of reason, but it forms an
18881: excellent exercise for its powers, awakening its circumspection, and
18882: indicating the means whereby it may most fully establish its claims to
18883: its legitimate possessions.
18884: 
18885: Section III. The Discipline of Pure Reason in Hypothesis
18886: 
18887: This critique of reason has now taught us that all its efforts to
18888: extend the bounds of knowledge, by means of pure speculation, are
18889: utterly fruitless. So much the wider field, it may appear, lies open to
18890: hypothesis; as, where we cannot know with certainty, we are at liberty
18891: to make guesses and to form suppositions.
18892: 
18893: Imagination may be allowed, under the strict surveillance of reason, to
18894: invent suppositions; but, these must be based on something that is
18895: perfectly certain—and that is the possibility of the object. If we are
18896: well assured upon this point, it is allowable to have recourse to
18897: supposition in regard to the reality of the object; but this
18898: supposition must, unless it is utterly groundless, be connected, as its
18899: ground of explanation, with that which is really given and absolutely
18900: certain. Such a supposition is termed a hypothesis.
18901: 
18902: It is beyond our power to form the least conception à priori of the
18903: possibility of dynamical connection in phenomena; and the category of
18904: the pure understanding will not enable us to excogitate any such
18905: connection, but merely helps us to understand it, when we meet with it
18906: in experience. For this reason we cannot, in accordance with the
18907: categories, imagine or invent any object or any property of an object
18908: not given, or that may not be given in experience, and employ it in a
18909: hypothesis; otherwise, we should be basing our chain of reasoning upon
18910: mere chimerical fancies, and not upon conceptions of things. Thus, we
18911: have no right to assume the existence of new powers, not existing in
18912: nature—for example, an understanding with a non-sensuous intuition, a
18913: force of attraction without contact, or some new kind of substances
18914: occupying space, and yet without the property of impenetrability—and,
18915: consequently, we cannot assume that there is any other kind of
18916: community among substances than that observable in experience, any kind
18917: of presence than that in space, or any kind of duration than that in
18918: time. In one word, the conditions of possible experience are for reason
18919: the only conditions of the possibility of things; reason cannot venture
18920: to form, independently of these conditions, any conceptions of things,
18921: because such conceptions, although not self-contradictory, are without
18922: object and without application.
18923: 
18924: The conceptions of reason are, as we have already shown, mere ideas,
18925: and do not relate to any object in any kind of experience. At the same
18926: time, they do not indicate imaginary or possible objects. They are
18927: purely problematical in their nature and, as aids to the heuristic
18928: exercise of the faculties, form the basis of the regulative principles
18929: for the systematic employment of the understanding in the field of
18930: experience. If we leave this ground of experience, they become mere
18931: fictions of thought, the possibility of which is quite indemonstrable;
18932: and they cannot, consequently, be employed as hypotheses in the
18933: explanation of real phenomena. It is quite admissible to cogitate the
18934: soul as simple, for the purpose of enabling ourselves to employ the
18935: idea of a perfect and necessary unity of all the faculties of the mind
18936: as the principle of all our inquiries into its internal phenomena,
18937: although we cannot cognize this unity in concreto. But to assume that
18938: the soul is a simple substance (a transcendental conception) would be
18939: enouncing a proposition which is not only indemonstrable—as many
18940: physical hypotheses are—but a proposition which is purely arbitrary,
18941: and in the highest degree rash. The simple is never presented in
18942: experience; and, if by substance is here meant the permanent object of
18943: sensuous intuition, the possibility of a simple phenomenon is perfectly
18944: inconceivable. Reason affords no good grounds for admitting the
18945: existence of intelligible beings, or of intelligible properties of
18946: sensuous things, although—as we have no conception either of their
18947: possibility or of their impossibility—it will always be out of our
18948: power to affirm dogmatically that they do not exist. In the explanation
18949: of given phenomena, no other things and no other grounds of explanation
18950: can be employed than those which stand in connection with the given
18951: phenomena according to the known laws of experience. A transcendental
18952: hypothesis, in which a mere idea of reason is employed to explain the
18953: phenomena of nature, would not give us any better insight into a
18954: phenomenon, as we should be trying to explain what we do not
18955: sufficiently understand from known empirical principles, by what we do
18956: not understand at all. The principles of such a hypothesis might
18957: conduce to the satisfaction of reason, but it would not assist the
18958: understanding in its application to objects. Order and conformity to
18959: aims in the sphere of nature must be themselves explained upon natural
18960: grounds and according to natural laws; and the wildest hypotheses, if
18961: they are only physical, are here more admissible than a hyperphysical
18962: hypothesis, such as that of a divine author. For such a hypothesis
18963: would introduce the principle of ignava ratio, which requires us to
18964: give up the search for causes that might be discovered in the course of
18965: experience and to rest satisfied with a mere idea. As regards the
18966: absolute totality of the grounds of explanation in the series of these
18967: causes, this can be no hindrance to the understanding in the case of
18968: phenomena; because, as they are to us nothing more than phenomena, we
18969: have no right to look for anything like completeness in the synthesis
18970: of the series of their conditions.
18971: 
18972: Transcendental hypotheses are therefore inadmissible; and we cannot use
18973: the liberty of employing, in the absence of physical, hyperphysical
18974: grounds of explanation. And this for two reasons; first, because such
18975: hypothesis do not advance reason, but rather stop it in its progress;
18976: secondly, because this licence would render fruitless all its exertions
18977: in its own proper sphere, which is that of experience. For, when the
18978: explanation of natural phenomena happens to be difficult, we have
18979: constantly at hand a transcendental ground of explanation, which lifts
18980: us above the necessity of investigating nature; and our inquiries are
18981: brought to a close, not because we have obtained all the requisite
18982: knowledge, but because we abut upon a principle which is
18983: incomprehensible and which, indeed, is so far back in the track of
18984: thought as to contain the conception of the absolutely primal being.
18985: 
18986: The next requisite for the admissibility of a hypothesis is its
18987: sufficiency. That is, it must determine à priori the consequences which
18988: are given in experience and which are supposed to follow from the
18989: hypothesis itself. If we require to employ auxiliary hypotheses, the
18990: suspicion naturally arises that they are mere fictions; because the
18991: necessity for each of them requires the same justification as in the
18992: case of the original hypothesis, and thus their testimony is invalid.
18993: If we suppose the existence of an infinitely perfect cause, we possess
18994: sufficient grounds for the explanation of the conformity to aims, the
18995: order and the greatness which we observe in the universe; but we find
18996: ourselves obliged, when we observe the evil in the world and the
18997: exceptions to these laws, to employ new hypothesis in support of the
18998: original one. We employ the idea of the simple nature of the human soul
18999: as the foundation of all the theories we may form of its phenomena; but
19000: when we meet with difficulties in our way, when we observe in the soul
19001: phenomena similar to the changes which take place in matter, we require
19002: to call in new auxiliary hypotheses. These may, indeed, not be false,
19003: but we do not know them to be true, because the only witness to their
19004: certitude is the hypothesis which they themselves have been called in
19005: to explain.
19006: 
19007: We are not discussing the above-mentioned assertions regarding the
19008: immaterial unity of the soul and the existence of a Supreme Being as
19009: dogmata, which certain philosophers profess to demonstrate à priori,
19010: but purely as hypotheses. In the former case, the dogmatist must take
19011: care that his arguments possess the apodeictic certainty of a
19012: demonstration. For the assertion that the reality of such ideas is
19013: probable is as absurd as a proof of the probability of a proposition in
19014: geometry. Pure abstract reason, apart from all experience, can either
19015: cognize nothing at all; and hence the judgements it enounces are never
19016: mere opinions, they are either apodeictic certainties, or declarations
19017: that nothing can be known on the subject. Opinions and probable
19018: judgements on the nature of things can only be employed to explain
19019: given phenomena, or they may relate to the effect, in accordance with
19020: empirical laws, of an actually existing cause. In other words, we must
19021: restrict the sphere of opinion to the world of experience and nature.
19022: Beyond this region opinion is mere invention; unless we are groping
19023: about for the truth on a path not yet fully known, and have some hopes
19024: of stumbling upon it by chance.
19025: 
19026: But, although hypotheses are inadmissible in answers to the questions
19027: of pure speculative reason, they may be employed in the defence of
19028: these answers. That is to say, hypotheses are admissible in polemic,
19029: but not in the sphere of dogmatism. By the defence of statements of
19030: this character, I do not mean an attempt at discovering new grounds for
19031: their support, but merely the refutation of the arguments of opponents.
19032: All à priori synthetical propositions possess the peculiarity that,
19033: although the philosopher who maintains the reality of the ideas
19034: contained in the proposition is not in possession of sufficient
19035: knowledge to establish the certainty of his statements, his opponent is
19036: as little able to prove the truth of the opposite. This equality of
19037: fortune does not allow the one party to be superior to the other in the
19038: sphere of speculative cognition; and it is this sphere, accordingly,
19039: that is the proper arena of these endless speculative conflicts. But we
19040: shall afterwards show that, in relation to its practical exercise,
19041: Reason has the right of admitting what, in the field of pure
19042: speculation, she would not be justified in supposing, except upon
19043: perfectly sufficient grounds; because all such suppositions destroy the
19044: necessary completeness of speculation—a condition which the practical
19045: reason, however, does not consider to be requisite. In this sphere,
19046: therefore, Reason is mistress of a possession, her title to which she
19047: does not require to prove—which, in fact, she could not do. The burden
19048: of proof accordingly rests upon the opponent. But as he has just as
19049: little knowledge regarding the subject discussed, and is as little able
19050: to prove the non-existence of the object of an idea, as the philosopher
19051: on the other side is to demonstrate its reality, it is evident that
19052: there is an advantage on the side of the philosopher who maintains his
19053: proposition as a practically necessary supposition (melior est conditio
19054: possidentis). For he is at liberty to employ, in self-defence, the same
19055: weapons as his opponent makes use of in attacking him; that is, he has
19056: a right to use hypotheses not for the purpose of supporting the
19057: arguments in favour of his own propositions, but to show that his
19058: opponent knows no more than himself regarding the subject under
19059: discussion and cannot boast of any speculative advantage.
19060: 
19061: Hypotheses are, therefore, admissible in the sphere of pure reason only
19062: as weapons for self-defence, and not as supports to dogmatical
19063: assertions. But the opposing party we must always seek for in
19064: ourselves. For speculative reason is, in the sphere of
19065: transcendentalism, dialectical in its own nature. The difficulties and
19066: objections we have to fear lie in ourselves. They are like old but
19067: never superannuated claims; and we must seek them out, and settle them
19068: once and for ever, if we are to expect a permanent peace. External
19069: tranquility is hollow and unreal. The root of these contradictions,
19070: which lies in the nature of human reason, must be destroyed; and this
19071: can only be done by giving it, in the first instance, freedom to grow,
19072: nay, by nourishing it, that it may send out shoots, and thus betray its
19073: own existence. It is our duty, therefore, to try to discover new
19074: objections, to put weapons in the bands of our opponent, and to grant
19075: him the most favourable position in the arena that he can wish. We have
19076: nothing to fear from these concessions; on the contrary, we may rather
19077: hope that we shall thus make ourselves master of a possession which no
19078: one will ever venture to dispute.
19079: 
19080: The thinker requires, to be fully equipped, the hypotheses of pure
19081: reason, which, although but leaden weapons (for they have not been
19082: steeled in the armoury of experience), are as useful as any that can be
19083: employed by his opponents. If, accordingly, we have assumed, from a
19084: non-speculative point of view, the immaterial nature of the soul, and
19085: are met by the objection that experience seems to prove that the growth
19086: and decay of our mental faculties are mere modifications of the
19087: sensuous organism—we can weaken the force of this objection by the
19088: assumption that the body is nothing but the fundamental phenomenon, to
19089: which, as a necessary condition, all sensibility, and consequently all
19090: thought, relates in the present state of our existence; and that the
19091: separation of soul and body forms the conclusion of the sensuous
19092: exercise of our power of cognition and the beginning of the
19093: intellectual. The body would, in this view of the question, be
19094: regarded, not as the cause of thought, but merely as its restrictive
19095: condition, as promotive of the sensuous and animal, but as a hindrance
19096: to the pure and spiritual life; and the dependence of the animal life
19097: on the constitution of the body, would not prove that the whole life of
19098: man was also dependent on the state of the organism. We might go still
19099: farther, and discover new objections, or carry out to their extreme
19100: consequences those which have already been adduced.
19101: 
19102: Generation, in the human race as well as among the irrational animals,
19103: depends on so many accidents—of occasion, of proper sustenance, of the
19104: laws enacted by the government of a country of vice even, that it is
19105: difficult to believe in the eternal existence of a being whose life has
19106: begun under circumstances so mean and trivial, and so entirely
19107: dependent upon our own control. As regards the continuance of the
19108: existence of the whole race, we need have no difficulties, for accident
19109: in single cases is subject to general laws; but, in the case of each
19110: individual, it would seem as if we could hardly expect so wonderful an
19111: effect from causes so insignificant. But, in answer to these
19112: objections, we may adduce the transcendental hypothesis that all life
19113: is properly intelligible, and not subject to changes of time, and that
19114: it neither began in birth, nor will end in death. We may assume that
19115: this life is nothing more than a sensuous representation of pure
19116: spiritual life; that the whole world of sense is but an image, hovering
19117: before the faculty of cognition which we exercise in this sphere, and
19118: with no more objective reality than a dream; and that if we could
19119: intuite ourselves and other things as they really are, we should see
19120: ourselves in a world of spiritual natures, our connection with which
19121: did not begin at our birth and will not cease with the destruction of
19122: the body. And so on.
19123: 
19124: We cannot be said to know what has been above asserted, nor do we
19125: seriously maintain the truth of these assertions; and the notions
19126: therein indicated are not even ideas of reason, they are purely
19127: fictitious conceptions. But this hypothetical procedure is in perfect
19128: conformity with the laws of reason. Our opponent mistakes the absence
19129: of empirical conditions for a proof of the complete impossibility of
19130: all that we have asserted; and we have to show him that he has not
19131: exhausted the whole sphere of possibility and that he can as little
19132: compass that sphere by the laws of experience and nature, as we can lay
19133: a secure foundation for the operations of reason beyond the region of
19134: experience. Such hypothetical defences against the pretensions of an
19135: opponent must not be regarded as declarations of opinion. The
19136: philosopher abandons them, so soon as the opposite party renounces its
19137: dogmatical conceit. To maintain a simply negative position in relation
19138: to propositions which rest on an insecure foundation, well befits the
19139: moderation of a true philosopher; but to uphold the objections urged
19140: against an opponent as proofs of the opposite statement is a proceeding
19141: just as unwarrantable and arrogant as it is to attack the position of a
19142: philosopher who advances affirmative propositions regarding such a
19143: subject.
19144: 
19145: It is evident, therefore, that hypotheses, in the speculative sphere,
19146: are valid, not as independent propositions, but only relatively to
19147: opposite transcendent assumptions. For, to make the principles of
19148: possible experience conditions of the possibility of things in general
19149: is just as transcendent a procedure as to maintain the objective
19150: reality of ideas which can be applied to no objects except such as lie
19151: without the limits of possible experience. The judgements enounced by
19152: pure reason must be necessary, or they must not be enounced at all.
19153: Reason cannot trouble herself with opinions. But the hypotheses we have
19154: been discussing are merely problematical judgements, which can neither
19155: be confuted nor proved; while, therefore, they are not personal
19156: opinions, they are indispensable as answers to objections which are
19157: liable to be raised. But we must take care to confine them to this
19158: function, and guard against any assumption on their part of absolute
19159: validity, a proceeding which would involve reason in inextricable
19160: difficulties and contradictions.
19161: 
19162: Section IV. The Discipline of Pure Reason in Relation to Proofs
19163: 
19164: It is a peculiarity, which distinguishes the proofs of transcendental
19165: synthetical propositions from those of all other à priori synthetical
19166: cognitions, that reason, in the case of the former, does not apply its
19167: conceptions directly to an object, but is first obliged to prove, à
19168: priori, the objective validity of these conceptions and the possibility
19169: of their syntheses. This is not merely a prudential rule, it is
19170: essential to the very possibility of the proof of a transcendental
19171: proposition. If I am required to pass, à priori, beyond the conception
19172: of an object, I find that it is utterly impossible without the guidance
19173: of something which is not contained in the conception. In mathematics,
19174: it is à priori intuition that guides my synthesis; and, in this case,
19175: all our conclusions may be drawn immediately from pure intuition. In
19176: transcendental cognition, so long as we are dealing only with
19177: conceptions of the understanding, we are guided by possible experience.
19178: That is to say, a proof in the sphere of transcendental cognition does
19179: not show that the given conception (that of an event, for example)
19180: leads directly to another conception (that of a cause)—for this would
19181: be a saltus which nothing can justify; but it shows that experience
19182: itself, and consequently the object of experience, is impossible
19183: without the connection indicated by these conceptions. It follows that
19184: such a proof must demonstrate the possibility of arriving,
19185: synthetically and à priori, at a certain knowledge of things, which was
19186: not contained in our conceptions of these things. Unless we pay
19187: particular attention to this requirement, our proofs, instead of
19188: pursuing the straight path indicated by reason, follow the tortuous
19189: road of mere subjective association. The illusory conviction, which
19190: rests upon subjective causes of association, and which is considered as
19191: resulting from the perception of a real and objective natural affinity,
19192: is always open to doubt and suspicion. For this reason, all the
19193: attempts which have been made to prove the principle of sufficient
19194: reason, have, according to the universal admission of philosophers,
19195: been quite unsuccessful; and, before the appearance of transcendental
19196: criticism, it was considered better, as this principle could not be
19197: abandoned, to appeal boldly to the common sense of mankind (a
19198: proceeding which always proves that the problem, which reason ought to
19199: solve, is one in which philosophers find great difficulties), rather
19200: than attempt to discover new dogmatical proofs.
19201: 
19202: But, if the proposition to be proved is a proposition of pure reason,
19203: and if I aim at passing beyond my empirical conceptions by the aid of
19204: mere ideas, it is necessary that the proof should first show that such
19205: a step in synthesis is possible (which it is not), before it proceeds
19206: to prove the truth of the proposition itself. The so-called proof of
19207: the simple nature of the soul from the unity of apperception, is a very
19208: plausible one. But it contains no answer to the objection, that, as the
19209: notion of absolute simplicity is not a conception which is directly
19210: applicable to a perception, but is an idea which must be inferred—if at
19211: all—from observation, it is by no means evident how the mere fact of
19212: consciousness, which is contained in all thought, although in so far a
19213: simple representation, can conduct me to the consciousness and
19214: cognition of a thing which is purely a thinking substance. When I
19215: represent to my mind the power of my body as in motion, my body in this
19216: thought is so far absolute unity, and my representation of it is a
19217: simple one; and hence I can indicate this representation by the motion
19218: of a point, because I have made abstraction of the size or volume of
19219: the body. But I cannot hence infer that, given merely the moving power
19220: of a body, the body may be cogitated as simple substance, merely
19221: because the representation in my mind takes no account of its content
19222: in space, and is consequently simple. The simple, in abstraction, is
19223: very different from the objectively simple; and hence the Ego, which is
19224: simple in the first sense, may, in the second sense, as indicating the
19225: soul itself, be a very complex conception, with a very various content.
19226: Thus it is evident that in all such arguments there lurks a paralogism.
19227: We guess (for without some such surmise our suspicion would not be
19228: excited in reference to a proof of this character) at the presence of
19229: the paralogism, by keeping ever before us a criterion of the
19230: possibility of those synthetical propositions which aim at proving more
19231: than experience can teach us. This criterion is obtained from the
19232: observation that such proofs do not lead us directly from the subject
19233: of the proposition to be proved to the required predicate, but find it
19234: necessary to presuppose the possibility of extending our cognition à
19235: priori by means of ideas. We must, accordingly, always use the greatest
19236: caution; we require, before attempting any proof, to consider how it is
19237: possible to extend the sphere of cognition by the operations of pure
19238: reason, and from what source we are to derive knowledge, which is not
19239: obtained from the analysis of conceptions, nor relates, by
19240: anticipation, to possible experience. We shall thus spare ourselves
19241: much severe and fruitless labour, by not expecting from reason what is
19242: beyond its power, or rather by subjecting it to discipline, and
19243: teaching it to moderate its vehement desires for the extension of the
19244: sphere of cognition.
19245: 
19246: The first rule for our guidance is, therefore, not to attempt a
19247: transcendental proof, before we have considered from what source we are
19248: to derive the principles upon which the proof is to be based, and what
19249: right we have to expect that our conclusions from these principles will
19250: be veracious. If they are principles of the understanding, it is vain
19251: to expect that we should attain by their means to ideas of pure reason;
19252: for these principles are valid only in regard to objects of possible
19253: experience. If they are principles of pure reason, our labour is alike
19254: in vain. For the principles of reason, if employed as objective, are
19255: without exception dialectical and possess no validity or truth, except
19256: as regulative principles of the systematic employment of reason in
19257: experience. But when such delusive proof are presented to us, it is our
19258: duty to meet them with the non liquet of a matured judgement; and,
19259: although we are unable to expose the particular sophism upon which the
19260: proof is based, we have a right to demand a deduction of the principles
19261: employed in it; and, if these principles have their origin in pure
19262: reason alone, such a deduction is absolutely impossible. And thus it is
19263: unnecessary that we should trouble ourselves with the exposure and
19264: confutation of every sophistical illusion; we may, at once, bring all
19265: dialectic, which is inexhaustible in the production of fallacies,
19266: before the bar of critical reason, which tests the principles upon
19267: which all dialectical procedure is based. The second peculiarity of
19268: transcendental proof is that a transcendental proposition cannot rest
19269: upon more than a single proof. If I am drawing conclusions, not from
19270: conceptions, but from intuition corresponding to a conception, be it
19271: pure intuition, as in mathematics, or empirical, as in natural science,
19272: the intuition which forms the basis of my inferences presents me with
19273: materials for many synthetical propositions, which I can connect in
19274: various modes, while, as it is allowable to proceed from different
19275: points in the intention, I can arrive by different paths at the same
19276: proposition.
19277: 
19278: But every transcendental proposition sets out from a conception, and
19279: posits the synthetical condition of the possibility of an object
19280: according to this conception. There must, therefore, be but one ground
19281: of proof, because it is the conception alone which determines the
19282: object; and thus the proof cannot contain anything more than the
19283: determination of the object according to the conception. In our
19284: Transcendental Analytic, for example, we inferred the principle: Every
19285: event has a cause, from the only condition of the objective possibility
19286: of our conception of an event. This is that an event cannot be
19287: determined in time, and consequently cannot form a part of experience,
19288: unless it stands under this dynamical law. This is the only possible
19289: ground of proof; for our conception of an event possesses objective
19290: validity, that is, is a true conception, only because the law of
19291: causality determines an object to which it can refer. Other arguments
19292: in support of this principle have been attempted—such as that from the
19293: contingent nature of a phenomenon; but when this argument is
19294: considered, we can discover no criterion of contingency, except the
19295: fact of an event—of something happening, that is to say, the existence
19296: which is preceded by the non-existence of an object, and thus we fall
19297: back on the very thing to be proved. If the proposition: “Every
19298: thinking being is simple,” is to be proved, we keep to the conception
19299: of the ego, which is simple, and to which all thought has a relation.
19300: The same is the case with the transcendental proof of the existence of
19301: a Deity, which is based solely upon the harmony and reciprocal fitness
19302: of the conceptions of an ens realissimum and a necessary being, and
19303: cannot be attempted in any other manner.
19304: 
19305: This caution serves to simplify very much the criticism of all
19306: propositions of reason. When reason employs conceptions alone, only one
19307: proof of its thesis is possible, if any. When, therefore, the dogmatist
19308: advances with ten arguments in favour of a proposition, we may be sure
19309: that not one of them is conclusive. For if he possessed one which
19310: proved the proposition he brings forward to demonstration—as must
19311: always be the case with the propositions of pure reason—what need is
19312: there for any more? His intention can only be similar to that of the
19313: advocate who had different arguments for different judges; this
19314: availing himself of the weakness of those who examine his arguments,
19315: who, without going into any profound investigation, adopt the view of
19316: the case which seems most probable at first sight and decide according
19317: to it.
19318: 
19319: The third rule for the guidance of pure reason in the conduct of a
19320: proof is that all transcendental proofs must never be apagogic or
19321: indirect, but always ostensive or direct. The direct or ostensive proof
19322: not only establishes the truth of the proposition to be proved, but
19323: exposes the grounds of its truth; the apagogic, on the other hand, may
19324: assure us of the truth of the proposition, but it cannot enable us to
19325: comprehend the grounds of its possibility. The latter is, accordingly,
19326: rather an auxiliary to an argument, than a strictly philosophical and
19327: rational mode of procedure. In one respect, however, they have an
19328: advantage over direct proofs, from the fact that the mode of arguing by
19329: contradiction, which they employ, renders our understanding of the
19330: question more clear, and approximates the proof to the certainty of an
19331: intuitional demonstration.
19332: 
19333: The true reason why indirect proofs are employed in different sciences
19334: is this. When the grounds upon which we seek to base a cognition are
19335: too various or too profound, we try whether or not we may not discover
19336: the truth of our cognition from its consequences. The modus ponens of
19337: reasoning from the truth of its inferences to the truth of a
19338: proposition would be admissible if all the inferences that can be drawn
19339: from it are known to be true; for in this case there can be only one
19340: possible ground for these inferences, and that is the true one. But
19341: this is a quite impracticable procedure, as it surpasses all our powers
19342: to discover all the possible inferences that can be drawn from a
19343: proposition. But this mode of reasoning is employed, under favour, when
19344: we wish to prove the truth of an hypothesis; in which case we admit the
19345: truth of the conclusion—which is supported by analogy—that, if all the
19346: inferences we have drawn and examined agree with the proposition
19347: assumed, all other possible inferences will also agree with it. But, in
19348: this way, an hypothesis can never be established as a demonstrated
19349: truth. The modus tollens of reasoning from known inferences to the
19350: unknown proposition, is not only a rigorous, but a very easy mode of
19351: proof. For, if it can be shown that but one inference from a
19352: proposition is false, then the proposition must itself be false.
19353: Instead, then, of examining, in an ostensive argument, the whole series
19354: of the grounds on which the truth of a proposition rests, we need only
19355: take the opposite of this proposition, and if one inference from it be
19356: false, then must the opposite be itself false; and, consequently, the
19357: proposition which we wished to prove must be true.
19358: 
19359: The apagogic method of proof is admissible only in those sciences where
19360: it is impossible to mistake a subjective representation for an
19361: objective cognition. Where this is possible, it is plain that the
19362: opposite of a given proposition may contradict merely the subjective
19363: conditions of thought, and not the objective cognition; or it may
19364: happen that both propositions contradict each other only under a
19365: subjective condition, which is incorrectly considered to be objective,
19366: and, as the condition is itself false, both propositions may be false,
19367: and it will, consequently, be impossible to conclude the truth of the
19368: one from the falseness of the other.
19369: 
19370: In mathematics such subreptions are impossible; and it is in this
19371: science, accordingly, that the indirect mode of proof has its true
19372: place. In the science of nature, where all assertion is based upon
19373: empirical intuition, such subreptions may be guarded against by the
19374: repeated comparison of observations; but this mode of proof is of
19375: little value in this sphere of knowledge. But the transcendental
19376: efforts of pure reason are all made in the sphere of the subjective,
19377: which is the real medium of all dialectical illusion; and thus reason
19378: endeavours, in its premisses, to impose upon us subjective
19379: representations for objective cognitions. In the transcendental sphere
19380: of pure reason, then, and in the case of synthetical propositions, it
19381: is inadmissible to support a statement by disproving the
19382: counter-statement. For only two cases are possible; either, the
19383: counter-statement is nothing but the enouncement of the inconsistency
19384: of the opposite opinion with the subjective conditions of reason, which
19385: does not affect the real case (for example, we cannot comprehend the
19386: unconditioned necessity of the existence of a being, and hence every
19387: speculative proof of the existence of such a being must be opposed on
19388: subjective grounds, while the possibility of this being in itself
19389: cannot with justice be denied); or, both propositions, being
19390: dialectical in their nature, are based upon an impossible conception.
19391: In this latter case the rule applies: non entis nulla sunt predicata;
19392: that is to say, what we affirm and what we deny, respecting such an
19393: object, are equally untrue, and the apagogic mode of arriving at the
19394: truth is in this case impossible. If, for example, we presuppose that
19395: the world of sense is given in itself in its totality, it is false,
19396: either that it is infinite, or that it is finite and limited in space.
19397: Both are false, because the hypothesis is false. For the notion of
19398: phenomena (as mere representations) which are given in themselves (as
19399: objects) is self-contradictory; and the infinitude of this imaginary
19400: whole would, indeed, be unconditioned, but would be inconsistent (as
19401: everything in the phenomenal world is conditioned) with the
19402: unconditioned determination and finitude of quantities which is
19403: presupposed in our conception.
19404: 
19405: The apagogic mode of proof is the true source of those illusions which
19406: have always had so strong an attraction for the admirers of dogmatical
19407: philosophy. It may be compared to a champion who maintains the honour
19408: and claims of the party he has adopted by offering battle to all who
19409: doubt the validity of these claims and the purity of that honour; while
19410: nothing can be proved in this way, except the respective strength of
19411: the combatants, and the advantage, in this respect, is always on the
19412: side of the attacking party. Spectators, observing that each party is
19413: alternately conqueror and conquered, are led to regard the subject of
19414: dispute as beyond the power of man to decide upon. But such an opinion
19415: cannot be justified; and it is sufficient to apply to these reasoners
19416: the remark:
19417: 
19418: _Non defensoribus istis
19419: Tempus eget._
19420: 
19421: 
19422: Each must try to establish his assertions by a transcendental deduction
19423: of the grounds of proof employed in his argument, and thus enable us to
19424: see in what way the claims of reason may be supported. If an opponent
19425: bases his assertions upon subjective grounds, he may be refuted with
19426: ease; not, however to the advantage of the dogmatist, who likewise
19427: depends upon subjective sources of cognition and is in like manner
19428: driven into a corner by his opponent. But, if parties employ the direct
19429: method of procedure, they will soon discover the difficulty, nay, the
19430: impossibility of proving their assertions, and will be forced to appeal
19431: to prescription and precedence; or they will, by the help of criticism,
19432: discover with ease the dogmatical illusions by which they had been
19433: mocked, and compel reason to renounce its exaggerated pretensions to
19434: speculative insight and to confine itself within the limits of its
19435: proper sphere—that of practical principles.
19436: 
19437: Chapter II. The Canon of Pure Reason
19438: 
19439: It is a humiliating consideration for human reason that it is
19440: incompetent to discover truth by means of pure speculation, but, on the
19441: contrary, stands in need of discipline to check its deviations from the
19442: straight path and to expose the illusions which it originates. But, on
19443: the other hand, this consideration ought to elevate and to give it
19444: confidence, for this discipline is exercised by itself alone, and it is
19445: subject to the censure of no other power. The bounds, moreover, which
19446: it is forced to set to its speculative exercise, form likewise a check
19447: upon the fallacious pretensions of opponents; and thus what remains of
19448: its possessions, after these exaggerated claims have been disallowed,
19449: is secure from attack or usurpation. The greatest, and perhaps the
19450: only, use of all philosophy of pure reason is, accordingly, of a purely
19451: negative character. It is not an organon for the extension, but a
19452: discipline for the determination, of the limits of its exercise; and
19453: without laying claim to the discovery of new truth, it has the modest
19454: merit of guarding against error.
19455: 
19456: At the same time, there must be some source of positive cognitions
19457: which belong to the domain of pure reason and which become the causes
19458: of error only from our mistaking their true character, while they form
19459: the goal towards which reason continually strives. How else can we
19460: account for the inextinguishable desire in the human mind to find a
19461: firm footing in some region beyond the limits of the world of
19462: experience? It hopes to attain to the possession of a knowledge in
19463: which it has the deepest interest. It enters upon the path of pure
19464: speculation; but in vain. We have some reason, however, to expect that,
19465: in the only other way that lies open to it—the path of practical
19466: reason—it may meet with better success.
19467: 
19468: I understand by a canon a list of the à priori principles of the proper
19469: employment of certain faculties of cognition. Thus general logic, in
19470: its analytical department, is a formal canon for the faculties of
19471: understanding and reason. In the same way, Transcendental Analytic was
19472: seen to be a canon of the pure understanding; for it alone is competent
19473: to enounce true à priori synthetical cognitions. But, when no proper
19474: employment of a faculty of cognition is possible, no canon can exist.
19475: But the synthetical cognition of pure speculative reason is, as has
19476: been shown, completely impossible. There cannot, therefore, exist any
19477: canon for the speculative exercise of this faculty—for its speculative
19478: exercise is entirely dialectical; and, consequently, transcendental
19479: logic, in this respect, is merely a discipline, and not a canon. If,
19480: then, there is any proper mode of employing the faculty of pure
19481: reason—in which case there must be a canon for this faculty—this canon
19482: will relate, not to the speculative, but to the practical use of
19483: reason. This canon we now proceed to investigate.
19484: 
19485: Section I. Of the Ultimate End of the Pure Use of Reason
19486: 
19487: There exists in the faculty of reason a natural desire to venture
19488: beyond the field of experience, to attempt to reach the utmost bounds
19489: of all cognition by the help of ideas alone, and not to rest satisfied
19490: until it has fulfilled its course and raised the sum of its cognitions
19491: into a self-subsistent systematic whole. Is the motive for this
19492: endeavour to be found in its speculative, or in its practical interests
19493: alone?
19494: 
19495: Setting aside, at present, the results of the labours of pure reason in
19496: its speculative exercise, I shall merely inquire regarding the problems
19497: the solution of which forms its ultimate aim, whether reached or not,
19498: and in relation to which all other aims are but partial and
19499: intermediate. These highest aims must, from the nature of reason,
19500: possess complete unity; otherwise the highest interest of humanity
19501: could not be successfully promoted.
19502: 
19503: The transcendental speculation of reason relates to three things: the
19504: freedom of the will, the immortality of the soul, and the existence of
19505: God. The speculative interest which reason has in those questions is
19506: very small; and, for its sake alone, we should not undertake the labour
19507: of transcendental investigation—a labour full of toil and ceaseless
19508: struggle. We should be loth to undertake this labour, because the
19509: discoveries we might make would not be of the smallest use in the
19510: sphere of concrete or physical investigation. We may find out that the
19511: will is free, but this knowledge only relates to the intelligible cause
19512: of our volition. As regards the phenomena or expressions of this will,
19513: that is, our actions, we are bound, in obedience to an inviolable
19514: maxim, without which reason cannot be employed in the sphere of
19515: experience, to explain these in the same way as we explain all the
19516: other phenomena of nature, that is to say, according to its
19517: unchangeable laws. We may have discovered the spirituality and
19518: immortality of the soul, but we cannot employ this knowledge to explain
19519: the phenomena of this life, nor the peculiar nature of the future,
19520: because our conception of an incorporeal nature is purely negative and
19521: does not add anything to our knowledge, and the only inferences to be
19522: drawn from it are purely fictitious. If, again, we prove the existence
19523: of a supreme intelligence, we should be able from it to make the
19524: conformity to aims existing in the arrangement of the world
19525: comprehensible; but we should not be justified in deducing from it any
19526: particular arrangement or disposition, or inferring any where it is not
19527: perceived. For it is a necessary rule of the speculative use of reason
19528: that we must not overlook natural causes, or refuse to listen to the
19529: teaching of experience, for the sake of deducing what we know and
19530: perceive from something that transcends all our knowledge. In one word,
19531: these three propositions are, for the speculative reason, always
19532: transcendent, and cannot be employed as immanent principles in relation
19533: to the objects of experience; they are, consequently, of no use to us
19534: in this sphere, being but the valueless results of the severe but
19535: unprofitable efforts of reason.
19536: 
19537: If, then, the actual cognition of these three cardinal propositions is
19538: perfectly useless, while Reason uses her utmost endeavours to induce us
19539: to admit them, it is plain that their real value and importance relate
19540: to our practical, and not to our speculative interest.
19541: 
19542: I term all that is possible through free will, practical. But if the
19543: conditions of the exercise of free volition are empirical, reason can
19544: have only a regulative, and not a constitutive, influence upon it, and
19545: is serviceable merely for the introduction of unity into its empirical
19546: laws. In the moral philosophy of prudence, for example, the sole
19547: business of reason is to bring about a union of all the ends, which are
19548: aimed at by our inclinations, into one ultimate end—that of
19549: happiness—and to show the agreement which should exist among the means
19550: of attaining that end. In this sphere, accordingly, reason cannot
19551: present to us any other than pragmatical laws of free action, for our
19552: guidance towards the aims set up by the senses, and is incompetent to
19553: give us laws which are pure and determined completely à priori. On the
19554: other hand, pure practical laws, the ends of which have been given by
19555: reason entirely à priori, and which are not empirically conditioned,
19556: but are, on the contrary, absolutely imperative in their nature, would
19557: be products of pure reason. Such are the moral laws; and these alone
19558: belong to the sphere of the practical exercise of reason, and admit of
19559: a canon.
19560: 
19561: All the powers of reason, in the sphere of what may be termed pure
19562: philosophy, are, in fact, directed to the three above-mentioned
19563: problems alone. These again have a still higher end—the answer to the
19564: question, what we ought to do, if the will is free, if there is a God
19565: and a future world. Now, as this problem relates to our in reference to
19566: the highest aim of humanity, it is evident that the ultimate intention
19567: of nature, in the constitution of our reason, has been directed to the
19568: moral alone.
19569: 
19570: We must take care, however, in turning our attention to an object which
19571: is foreign[78] to the sphere of transcendental philosophy, not to
19572: injure the unity of our system by digressions, nor, on the other hand,
19573: to fail in clearness, by saying too little on the new subject of
19574: discussion. I hope to avoid both extremes, by keeping as close as
19575: possible to the transcendental, and excluding all psychological, that
19576: is, empirical, elements.
19577: 
19578:  [78] All practical conceptions relate to objects of pleasure and pain,
19579:  and consequently—in an indirect manner, at least—to objects of
19580:  feeling. But as feeling is not a faculty of representation, but lies
19581:  out of the sphere of our powers of cognition, the elements of our
19582:  judgements, in so far as they relate to pleasure or pain, that is, the
19583:  elements of our practical judgements, do not belong to transcendental
19584:  philosophy, which has to do with pure à priori cognitions alone.
19585: 
19586: 
19587: I have to remark, in the first place, that at present I treat of the
19588: conception of freedom in the practical sense only, and set aside the
19589: corresponding transcendental conception, which cannot be employed as a
19590: ground of explanation in the phenomenal world, but is itself a problem
19591: for pure reason. A will is purely animal (arbitrium brutum) when it is
19592: determined by sensuous impulses or instincts only, that is, when it is
19593: determined in a pathological manner. A will, which can be determined
19594: independently of sensuous impulses, consequently by motives presented
19595: by reason alone, is called a free will (arbitrium liberum); and
19596: everything which is connected with this free will, either as principle
19597: or consequence, is termed practical. The existence of practical freedom
19598: can be proved from experience alone. For the human will is not
19599: determined by that alone which immediately affects the senses; on the
19600: contrary, we have the power, by calling up the notion of what is useful
19601: or hurtful in a more distant relation, of overcoming the immediate
19602: impressions on our sensuous faculty of desire. But these considerations
19603: of what is desirable in relation to our whole state, that is, is in the
19604: end good and useful, are based entirely upon reason. This faculty,
19605: accordingly, enounces laws, which are imperative or objective laws of
19606: freedom and which tell us what ought to take place, thus distinguishing
19607: themselves from the laws of nature, which relate to that which does
19608: take place. The laws of freedom or of free will are hence termed
19609: practical laws.
19610: 
19611: Whether reason is not itself, in the actual delivery of these laws,
19612: determined in its turn by other influences, and whether the action
19613: which, in relation to sensuous impulses, we call free, may not, in
19614: relation to higher and more remote operative causes, really form a part
19615: of nature—these are questions which do not here concern us. They are
19616: purely speculative questions; and all we have to do, in the practical
19617: sphere, is to inquire into the rule of conduct which reason has to
19618: present. Experience demonstrates to us the existence of practical
19619: freedom as one of the causes which exist in nature, that is, it shows
19620: the causal power of reason in the determination of the will. The idea
19621: of transcendental freedom, on the contrary, requires that reason—in
19622: relation to its causal power of commencing a series of phenomena—should
19623: be independent of all sensuous determining causes; and thus it seems to
19624: be in opposition to the law of nature and to all possible experience.
19625: It therefore remains a problem for the human mind. But this problem
19626: does not concern reason in its practical use; and we have, therefore,
19627: in a canon of pure reason, to do with only two questions, which relate
19628: to the practical interest of pure reason: Is there a God? and, Is there
19629: a future life? The question of transcendental freedom is purely
19630: speculative, and we may therefore set it entirely aside when we come to
19631: treat of practical reason. Besides, we have already discussed this
19632: subject in the antinomy of pure reason.
19633: 
19634: Section II. Of the Ideal of the Summum Bonum as a Determining Ground of
19635: the Ultimate End of Pure Reason
19636: 
19637: Reason conducted us, in its speculative use, through the field of
19638: experience and, as it can never find complete satisfaction in that
19639: sphere, from thence to speculative ideas—which, however, in the end
19640: brought us back again to experience, and thus fulfilled the purpose of
19641: reason, in a manner which, though useful, was not at all in accordance
19642: with our expectations. It now remains for us to consider whether pure
19643: reason can be employed in a practical sphere, and whether it will here
19644: conduct us to those ideas which attain the highest ends of pure reason,
19645: as we have just stated them. We shall thus ascertain whether, from the
19646: point of view of its practical interest, reason may not be able to
19647: supply us with that which, on the speculative side, it wholly denies
19648: us.
19649: 
19650: The whole interest of reason, speculative as well as practical, is
19651: centred in the three following questions:
19652: 
19653: 1. WHAT CAN I KNOW?
19654: 2. WHAT OUGHT I TO DO?
19655: 3. WHAT MAY I HOPE?
19656: 
19657: 
19658: The first question is purely speculative. We have, as I flatter myself,
19659: exhausted all the replies of which it is susceptible, and have at last
19660: found the reply with which reason must content itself, and with which
19661: it ought to be content, so long as it pays no regard to the practical.
19662: But from the two great ends to the attainment of which all these
19663: efforts of pure reason were in fact directed, we remain just as far
19664: removed as if we had consulted our ease and declined the task at the
19665: outset. So far, then, as knowledge is concerned, thus much, at least,
19666: is established, that, in regard to those two problems, it lies beyond
19667: our reach.
19668: 
19669: The second question is purely practical. As such it may indeed fall
19670: within the province of pure reason, but still it is not transcendental,
19671: but moral, and consequently cannot in itself form the subject of our
19672: criticism.
19673: 
19674: The third question: If I act as I ought to do, what may I then hope?—is
19675: at once practical and theoretical. The practical forms a clue to the
19676: answer of the theoretical, and—in its highest form—speculative
19677: question. For all hoping has happiness for its object and stands in
19678: precisely the same relation to the practical and the law of morality as
19679: knowing to the theoretical cognition of things and the law of nature.
19680: The former arrives finally at the conclusion that something is (which
19681: determines the ultimate end), because something ought to take place;
19682: the latter, that something is (which operates as the highest cause),
19683: because something does take place.
19684: 
19685: Happiness is the satisfaction of all our desires; extensive, in regard
19686: to their multiplicity; intensive, in regard to their degree; and
19687: protensive, in regard to their duration. The practical law based on the
19688: motive of happiness I term a pragmatical law (or prudential rule); but
19689: that law, assuming such to exist, which has no other motive than the
19690: worthiness of being happy, I term a moral or ethical law. The first
19691: tells us what we have to do, if we wish to become possessed of
19692: happiness; the second dictates how we ought to act, in order to deserve
19693: happiness. The first is based upon empirical principles; for it is only
19694: by experience that I can learn either what inclinations exist which
19695: desire satisfaction, or what are the natural means of satisfying them.
19696: The second takes no account of our desires or the means of satisfying
19697: them, and regards only the freedom of a rational being, and the
19698: necessary conditions under which alone this freedom can harmonize with
19699: the distribution of happiness according to principles. This second law
19700: may therefore rest upon mere ideas of pure reason, and may be cognized
19701: à priori.
19702: 
19703: I assume that there are pure moral laws which determine, entirely à
19704: priori (without regard to empirical motives, that is, to happiness),
19705: the conduct of a rational being, or in other words, to use which it
19706: makes of its freedom, and that these laws are absolutely imperative
19707: (not merely hypothetically, on the supposition of other empirical
19708: ends), and therefore in all respects necessary. I am warranted in
19709: assuming this, not only by the arguments of the most enlightened
19710: moralists, but by the moral judgement of every man who will make the
19711: attempt to form a distinct conception of such a law.
19712: 
19713: Pure reason, then, contains, not indeed in its speculative, but in its
19714: practical, or, more strictly, its moral use, principles of the
19715: possibility of experience, of such actions, namely, as, in accordance
19716: with ethical precepts, might be met with in the history of man. For
19717: since reason commands that such actions should take place, it must be
19718: possible for them to take place; and hence a particular kind of
19719: systematic unity—the moral—must be possible. We have found, it is true,
19720: that the systematic unity of nature could not be established according
19721: to speculative principles of reason, because, while reason possesses a
19722: causal power in relation to freedom, it has none in relation to the
19723: whole sphere of nature; and, while moral principles of reason can
19724: produce free actions, they cannot produce natural laws. It is, then, in
19725: its practical, but especially in its moral use, that the principles of
19726: pure reason possess objective reality.
19727: 
19728: I call the world a moral world, in so far as it may be in accordance
19729: with all the ethical laws—which, by virtue of the freedom of reasonable
19730: beings, it can be, and according to the necessary laws of morality it
19731: ought to be. But this world must be conceived only as an intelligible
19732: world, inasmuch as abstraction is therein made of all conditions
19733: (ends), and even of all impediments to morality (the weakness or
19734: pravity of human nature). So far, then, it is a mere idea—though still
19735: a practical idea—which may have, and ought to have, an influence on the
19736: world of sense, so as to bring it as far as possible into conformity
19737: with itself. The idea of a moral world has, therefore, objective
19738: reality, not as referring to an object of intelligible intuition—for of
19739: such an object we can form no conception whatever—but to the world of
19740: sense—conceived, however, as an object of pure reason in its practical
19741: use—and to a corpus mysticum of rational beings in it, in so far as the
19742: liberum arbitrium of the individual is placed, under and by virtue of
19743: moral laws, in complete systematic unity both with itself and with the
19744: freedom of all others.
19745: 
19746: That is the answer to the first of the two questions of pure reason
19747: which relate to its practical interest: Do that which will render thee
19748: worthy of happiness. The second question is this: If I conduct myself
19749: so as not to be unworthy of happiness, may I hope thereby to obtain
19750: happiness? In order to arrive at the solution of this question, we must
19751: inquire whether the principles of pure reason, which prescribe à priori
19752: the law, necessarily also connect this hope with it.
19753: 
19754: I say, then, that just as the moral principles are necessary according
19755: to reason in its practical use, so it is equally necessary according to
19756: reason in its theoretical use to assume that every one has ground to
19757: hope for happiness in the measure in which he has made himself worthy
19758: of it in his conduct, and that therefore the system of morality is
19759: inseparably (though only in the idea of pure reason) connected with
19760: that of happiness.
19761: 
19762: Now in an intelligible, that is, in the moral world, in the conception
19763: of which we make abstraction of all the impediments to morality
19764: (sensuous desires), such a system of happiness, connected with and
19765: proportioned to morality, may be conceived as necessary, because
19766: freedom of volition—partly incited, and partly restrained by moral
19767: laws—would be itself the cause of general happiness; and thus rational
19768: beings, under the guidance of such principles, would be themselves the
19769: authors both of their own enduring welfare and that of others. But such
19770: a system of self-rewarding morality is only an idea, the carrying out
19771: of which depends upon the condition that every one acts as he ought; in
19772: other words, that all actions of reasonable beings be such as they
19773: would be if they sprung from a Supreme Will, comprehending in, or
19774: under, itself all particular wills. But since the moral law is binding
19775: on each individual in the use of his freedom of volition, even if
19776: others should not act in conformity with this law, neither the nature
19777: of things, nor the causality of actions and their relation to morality,
19778: determine how the consequences of these actions will be related to
19779: happiness; and the necessary connection of the hope of happiness with
19780: the unceasing endeavour to become worthy of happiness, cannot be
19781: cognized by reason, if we take nature alone for our guide. This
19782: connection can be hoped for only on the assumption that the cause of
19783: nature is a supreme reason, which governs according to moral laws.
19784: 
19785: I term the idea of an intelligence in which the morally most perfect
19786: will, united with supreme blessedness, is the cause of all happiness in
19787: the world, so far as happiness stands in strict relation to morality
19788: (as the worthiness of being happy), the ideal of the supreme Good. It
19789: is only, then, in the ideal of the supreme original good, that pure
19790: reason can find the ground of the practically necessary connection of
19791: both elements of the highest derivative good, and accordingly of an
19792: intelligible, that is, moral world. Now since we are necessitated by
19793: reason to conceive ourselves as belonging to such a world, while the
19794: senses present to us nothing but a world of phenomena, we must assume
19795: the former as a consequence of our conduct in the world of sense (since
19796: the world of sense gives us no hint of it), and therefore as future in
19797: relation to us. Thus God and a future life are two hypotheses which,
19798: according to the principles of pure reason, are inseparable from the
19799: obligation which this reason imposes upon us.
19800: 
19801: Morality per se constitutes a system. But we can form no system of
19802: happiness, except in so far as it is dispensed in strict proportion to
19803: morality. But this is only possible in the intelligible world, under a
19804: wise author and ruler. Such a ruler, together with life in such a
19805: world, which we must look upon as future, reason finds itself compelled
19806: to assume; or it must regard the moral laws as idle dreams, since the
19807: necessary consequence which this same reason connects with them must,
19808: without this hypothesis, fall to the ground. Hence also the moral laws
19809: are universally regarded as commands, which they could not be did they
19810: not connect à priori adequate consequences with their dictates, and
19811: thus carry with them promises and threats. But this, again, they could
19812: not do, did they not reside in a necessary being, as the Supreme Good,
19813: which alone can render such a teleological unity possible.
19814: 
19815: Leibnitz termed the world, when viewed in relation to the rational
19816: beings which it contains, and the moral relations in which they stand
19817: to each other, under the government of the Supreme Good, the kingdom of
19818: Grace, and distinguished it from the kingdom of Nature, in which these
19819: rational beings live, under moral laws, indeed, but expect no other
19820: consequences from their actions than such as follow according to the
19821: course of nature in the world of sense. To view ourselves, therefore,
19822: as in the kingdom of grace, in which all happiness awaits us, except in
19823: so far as we ourselves limit our participation in it by actions which
19824: render us unworthy of happiness, is a practically necessary idea of
19825: reason.
19826: 
19827: Practical laws, in so far as they are subjective grounds of actions,
19828: that is, subjective principles, are termed maxims. The judgements of
19829: moral according to in its purity and ultimate results are framed
19830: according ideas; the observance of its laws, according to maxims.
19831: 
19832: The whole course of our life must be subject to moral maxims; but this
19833: is impossible, unless with the moral law, which is a mere idea, reason
19834: connects an efficient cause which ordains to all conduct which is in
19835: conformity with the moral law an issue either in this or in another
19836: life, which is in exact conformity with our highest aims. Thus, without
19837: a God and without a world, invisible to us now, but hoped for, the
19838: glorious ideas of morality are, indeed, objects of approbation and of
19839: admiration, but cannot be the springs of purpose and action. For they
19840: do not satisfy all the aims which are natural to every rational being,
19841: and which are determined à priori by pure reason itself, and necessary.
19842: 
19843: Happiness alone is, in the view of reason, far from being the complete
19844: good. Reason does not approve of it (however much inclination may
19845: desire it), except as united with desert. On the other hand, morality
19846: alone, and with it, mere desert, is likewise far from being the
19847: complete good. To make it complete, he who conducts himself in a manner
19848: not unworthy of happiness, must be able to hope for the possession of
19849: happiness. Even reason, unbiased by private ends, or interested
19850: considerations, cannot judge otherwise, if it puts itself in the place
19851: of a being whose business it is to dispense all happiness to others.
19852: For in the practical idea both points are essentially combined, though
19853: in such a way that participation in happiness is rendered possible by
19854: the moral disposition, as its condition, and not conversely, the moral
19855: disposition by the prospect of happiness. For a disposition which
19856: should require the prospect of happiness as its necessary condition
19857: would not be moral, and hence also would not be worthy of complete
19858: happiness—a happiness which, in the view of reason, recognizes no
19859: limitation but such as arises from our own immoral conduct.
19860: 
19861: Happiness, therefore, in exact proportion with the morality of rational
19862: beings (whereby they are made worthy of happiness), constitutes alone
19863: the supreme good of a world into which we absolutely must transport
19864: ourselves according to the commands of pure but practical reason. This
19865: world is, it is true, only an intelligible world; for of such a
19866: systematic unity of ends as it requires, the world of sense gives us no
19867: hint. Its reality can be based on nothing else but the hypothesis of a
19868: supreme original good. In it independent reason, equipped with all the
19869: sufficiency of a supreme cause, founds, maintains, and fulfils the
19870: universal order of things, with the most perfect teleological harmony,
19871: however much this order may be hidden from us in the world of sense.
19872: 
19873: This moral theology has the peculiar advantage, in contrast with
19874: speculative theology, of leading inevitably to the conception of a
19875: sole, perfect, and rational First Cause, whereof speculative theology
19876: does not give us any indication on objective grounds, far less any
19877: convincing evidence. For we find neither in transcendental nor in
19878: natural theology, however far reason may lead us in these, any ground
19879: to warrant us in assuming the existence of one only Being, which stands
19880: at the head of all natural causes, and on which these are entirely
19881: dependent. On the other hand, if we take our stand on moral unity as a
19882: necessary law of the universe, and from this point of view consider
19883: what is necessary to give this law adequate efficiency and, for us,
19884: obligatory force, we must come to the conclusion that there is one only
19885: supreme will, which comprehends all these laws in itself. For how,
19886: under different wills, should we find complete unity of ends? This will
19887: must be omnipotent, that all nature and its relation to morality in the
19888: world may be subject to it; omniscient, that it may have knowledge of
19889: the most secret feelings and their moral worth; omnipresent, that it
19890: may be at hand to supply every necessity to which the highest weal of
19891: the world may give rise; eternal, that this harmony of nature and
19892: liberty may never fail; and so on.
19893: 
19894: But this systematic unity of ends in this world of intelligences—which,
19895: as mere nature, is only a world of sense, but, as a system of freedom
19896: of volition, may be termed an intelligible, that is, moral world
19897: (regnum gratiae)—leads inevitably also to the teleological unity of all
19898: things which constitute this great whole, according to universal
19899: natural laws—just as the unity of the former is according to universal
19900: and necessary moral laws—and unites the practical with the speculative
19901: reason. The world must be represented as having originated from an
19902: idea, if it is to harmonize with that use of reason without which we
19903: cannot even consider ourselves as worthy of reason—namely, the moral
19904: use, which rests entirely on the idea of the supreme good. Hence the
19905: investigation of nature receives a teleological direction, and becomes,
19906: in its widest extension, physico-theology. But this, taking its rise in
19907: moral order as a unity founded on the essence of freedom, and not
19908: accidentally instituted by external commands, establishes the
19909: teleological view of nature on grounds which must be inseparably
19910: connected with the internal possibility of things. This gives rise to a
19911: transcendental theology, which takes the ideal of the highest
19912: ontological perfection as a principle of systematic unity; and this
19913: principle connects all things according to universal and necessary
19914: natural laws, because all things have their origin in the absolute
19915: necessity of the one only Primal Being.
19916: 
19917: What use can we make of our understanding, even in respect of
19918: experience, if we do not propose ends to ourselves? But the highest
19919: ends are those of morality, and it is only pure reason that can give us
19920: the knowledge of these. Though supplied with these, and putting
19921: ourselves under their guidance, we can make no teleological use of the
19922: knowledge of nature, as regards cognition, unless nature itself has
19923: established teleological unity. For without this unity we should not
19924: even possess reason, because we should have no school for reason, and
19925: no cultivation through objects which afford the materials for its
19926: conceptions. But teleological unity is a necessary unity, and founded
19927: on the essence of the individual will itself. Hence this will, which is
19928: the condition of the application of this unity in concreto, must be so
19929: likewise. In this way the transcendental enlargement of our rational
19930: cognition would be, not the cause, but merely the effect of the
19931: practical teleology which pure reason imposes upon us.
19932: 
19933: Hence, also, we find in the history of human reason that, before the
19934: moral conceptions were sufficiently purified and determined, and before
19935: men had attained to a perception of the systematic unity of ends
19936: according to these conceptions and from necessary principles, the
19937: knowledge of nature, and even a considerable amount of intellectual
19938: culture in many other sciences, could produce only rude and vague
19939: conceptions of the Deity, sometimes even admitting of an astonishing
19940: indifference with regard to this question altogether. But the more
19941: enlarged treatment of moral ideas, which was rendered necessary by the
19942: extreme pure moral law of our religion, awakened the interest, and
19943: thereby quickened the perceptions of reason in relation to this object.
19944: In this way, and without the help either of an extended acquaintance
19945: with nature, or of a reliable transcendental insight (for these have
19946: been wanting in all ages), a conception of the Divine Being was arrived
19947: at, which we now hold to be the correct one, not because speculative
19948: reason convinces us of its correctness, but because it accords with the
19949: moral principles of reason. Thus it is to pure reason, but only in its
19950: practical use, that we must ascribe the merit of having connected with
19951: our highest interest a cognition, of which mere speculation was able
19952: only to form a conjecture, but the validity of which it was unable to
19953: establish—and of having thereby rendered it, not indeed a demonstrated
19954: dogma, but a hypothesis absolutely necessary to the essential ends of
19955: reason.
19956: 
19957: But if practical reason has reached this elevation, and has attained to
19958: the conception of a sole Primal Being as the supreme good, it must not,
19959: therefore, imagine that it has transcended the empirical conditions of
19960: its application, and risen to the immediate cognition of new objects;
19961: it must not presume to start from the conception which it has gained,
19962: and to deduce from it the moral laws themselves. For it was these very
19963: laws, the internal practical necessity of which led us to the
19964: hypothesis of an independent cause, or of a wise ruler of the universe,
19965: who should give them effect. Hence we are not entitled to regard them
19966: as accidental and derived from the mere will of the ruler, especially
19967: as we have no conception of such a will, except as formed in accordance
19968: with these laws. So far, then, as practical reason has the right to
19969: conduct us, we shall not look upon actions as binding on us, because
19970: they are the commands of God, but we shall regard them as divine
19971: commands, because we are internally bound by them. We shall study
19972: freedom under the teleological unity which accords with principles of
19973: reason; we shall look upon ourselves as acting in conformity with the
19974: divine will only in so far as we hold sacred the moral law which reason
19975: teaches us from the nature of actions themselves, and we shall believe
19976: that we can obey that will only by promoting the weal of the universe
19977: in ourselves and in others. Moral theology is, therefore, only of
19978: immanent use. It teaches us to fulfil our destiny here in the world, by
19979: placing ourselves in harmony with the general system of ends, and warns
19980: us against the fanaticism, nay, the crime of depriving reason of its
