19981: legislative authority in the moral conduct of life, for the purpose of
19982: directly connecting this authority with the idea of the Supreme Being.
19983: For this would be, not an immanent, but a transcendent use of moral
19984: theology, and, like the transcendent use of mere speculation, would
19985: inevitably pervert and frustrate the ultimate ends of reason.
19986: 
19987: Section III. Of Opinion, Knowledge, and Belief
19988: 
19989: The holding of a thing to be true is a phenomenon in our understanding
19990: which may rest on objective grounds, but requires, also, subjective
19991: causes in the mind of the person judging. If a judgement is valid for
19992: every rational being, then its ground is objectively sufficient, and it
19993: is termed a conviction. If, on the other hand, it has its ground in the
19994: particular character of the subject, it is termed a persuasion.
19995: 
19996: Persuasion is a mere illusion, the ground of the judgement, which lies
19997: solely in the subject, being regarded as objective. Hence a judgement
19998: of this kind has only private validity—is only valid for the individual
19999: who judges, and the holding of a thing to be true in this way cannot be
20000: communicated. But truth depends upon agreement with the object, and
20001: consequently the judgements of all understandings, if true, must be in
20002: agreement with each other (consentientia uni tertio consentiunt inter
20003: se). Conviction may, therefore, be distinguished, from an external
20004: point of view, from persuasion, by the possibility of communicating it
20005: and by showing its validity for the reason of every man; for in this
20006: case the presumption, at least, arises that the agreement of all
20007: judgements with each other, in spite of the different characters of
20008: individuals, rests upon the common ground of the agreement of each with
20009: the object, and thus the correctness of the judgement is established.
20010: 
20011: Persuasion, accordingly, cannot be subjectively distinguished from
20012: conviction, that is, so long as the subject views its judgement simply
20013: as a phenomenon of its own mind. But if we inquire whether the grounds
20014: of our judgement, which are valid for us, produce the same effect on
20015: the reason of others as on our own, we have then the means, though only
20016: subjective means, not, indeed, of producing conviction, but of
20017: detecting the merely private validity of the judgement; in other words,
20018: of discovering that there is in it the element of mere persuasion.
20019: 
20020: If we can, in addition to this, develop the subjective causes of the
20021: judgement, which we have taken for its objective grounds, and thus
20022: explain the deceptive judgement as a phenomenon in our mind, apart
20023: altogether from the objective character of the object, we can then
20024: expose the illusion and need be no longer deceived by it, although, if
20025: its subjective cause lies in our nature, we cannot hope altogether to
20026: escape its influence.
20027: 
20028: I can only maintain, that is, affirm as necessarily valid for every
20029: one, that which produces conviction. Persuasion I may keep for myself,
20030: if it is agreeable to me; but I cannot, and ought not, to attempt to
20031: impose it as binding upon others.
20032: 
20033: Holding for true, or the subjective validity of a judgement in relation
20034: to conviction (which is, at the same time, objectively valid), has the
20035: three following degrees: opinion, belief, and knowledge. Opinion is a
20036: consciously insufficient judgement, subjectively as well as
20037: objectively. Belief is subjectively sufficient, but is recognized as
20038: being objectively insufficient. Knowledge is both subjectively and
20039: objectively sufficient. Subjective sufficiency is termed conviction
20040: (for myself); objective sufficiency is termed certainty (for all). I
20041: need not dwell longer on the explanation of such simple conceptions.
20042: 
20043: I must never venture to be of opinion, without knowing something, at
20044: least, by which my judgement, in itself merely problematical, is
20045: brought into connection with the truth—which connection, although not
20046: perfect, is still something more than an arbitrary fiction. Moreover,
20047: the law of such a connection must be certain. For if, in relation to
20048: this law, I have nothing more than opinion, my judgement is but a play
20049: of the imagination, without the least relation to truth. In the
20050: judgements of pure reason, opinion has no place. For, as they do not
20051: rest on empirical grounds and as the sphere of pure reason is that of
20052: necessary truth and à priori cognition, the principle of connection in
20053: it requires universality and necessity, and consequently perfect
20054: certainty—otherwise we should have no guide to the truth at all. Hence
20055: it is absurd to have an opinion in pure mathematics; we must know, or
20056: abstain from forming a judgement altogether. The case is the same with
20057: the maxims of morality. For we must not hazard an action on the mere
20058: opinion that it is allowed, but we must know it to be so. In the
20059: transcendental sphere of reason, on the other hand, the term opinion is
20060: too weak, while the word knowledge is too strong. From the merely
20061: speculative point of view, therefore, we cannot form a judgement at
20062: all. For the subjective grounds of a judgement, such as produce belief,
20063: cannot be admitted in speculative inquiries, inasmuch as they cannot
20064: stand without empirical support and are incapable of being communicated
20065: to others in equal measure.
20066: 
20067: But it is only from the practical point of view that a theoretically
20068: insufficient judgement can be termed belief. Now the practical
20069: reference is either to skill or to morality; to the former, when the
20070: end proposed is arbitrary and accidental, to the latter, when it is
20071: absolutely necessary.
20072: 
20073: If we propose to ourselves any end whatever, the conditions of its
20074: attainment are hypothetically necessary. The necessity is subjectively,
20075: but still only comparatively, sufficient, if I am acquainted with no
20076: other conditions under which the end can be attained. On the other
20077: hand, it is sufficient, absolutely and for every one, if I know for
20078: certain that no one can be acquainted with any other conditions under
20079: which the attainment of the proposed end would be possible. In the
20080: former case my supposition—my judgement with regard to certain
20081: conditions—is a merely accidental belief; in the latter it is a
20082: necessary belief. The physician must pursue some course in the case of
20083: a patient who is in danger, but is ignorant of the nature of the
20084: disease. He observes the symptoms, and concludes, according to the best
20085: of his judgement, that it is a case of phthisis. His belief is, even in
20086: his own judgement, only contingent: another man might, perhaps come
20087: nearer the truth. Such a belief, contingent indeed, but still forming
20088: the ground of the actual use of means for the attainment of certain
20089: ends, I term Pragmatical belief.
20090: 
20091: The usual test, whether that which any one maintains is merely his
20092: persuasion, or his subjective conviction at least, that is, his firm
20093: belief, is a bet. It frequently happens that a man delivers his
20094: opinions with so much boldness and assurance, that he appears to be
20095: under no apprehension as to the possibility of his being in error. The
20096: offer of a bet startles him, and makes him pause. Sometimes it turns
20097: out that his persuasion may be valued at a ducat, but not at ten. For
20098: he does not hesitate, perhaps, to venture a ducat, but if it is
20099: proposed to stake ten, he immediately becomes aware of the possibility
20100: of his being mistaken—a possibility which has hitherto escaped his
20101: observation. If we imagine to ourselves that we have to stake the
20102: happiness of our whole life on the truth of any proposition, our
20103: judgement drops its air of triumph, we take the alarm, and discover the
20104: actual strength of our belief. Thus pragmatical belief has degrees,
20105: varying in proportion to the interests at stake.
20106: 
20107: Now, in cases where we cannot enter upon any course of action in
20108: reference to some object, and where, accordingly, our judgement is
20109: purely theoretical, we can still represent to ourselves, in thought,
20110: the possibility of a course of action, for which we suppose that we
20111: have sufficient grounds, if any means existed of ascertaining the truth
20112: of the matter. Thus we find in purely theoretical judgements an
20113: analogon of practical judgements, to which the word belief may properly
20114: be applied, and which we may term doctrinal belief. I should not
20115: hesitate to stake my all on the truth of the proposition—if there were
20116: any possibility of bringing it to the test of experience—that, at
20117: least, some one of the planets, which we see, is inhabited. Hence I say
20118: that I have not merely the opinion, but the strong belief, on the
20119: correctness of which I would stake even many of the advantages of life,
20120: that there are inhabitants in other worlds.
20121: 
20122: Now we must admit that the doctrine of the existence of God belongs to
20123: doctrinal belief. For, although in respect to the theoretical cognition
20124: of the universe I do not require to form any theory which necessarily
20125: involves this idea, as the condition of my explanation of the phenomena
20126: which the universe presents, but, on the contrary, am rather bound so
20127: to use my reason as if everything were mere nature, still teleological
20128: unity is so important a condition of the application of my reason to
20129: nature, that it is impossible for me to ignore it—especially since, in
20130: addition to these considerations, abundant examples of it are supplied
20131: by experience. But the sole condition, so far as my knowledge extends,
20132: under which this unity can be my guide in the investigation of nature,
20133: is the assumption that a supreme intelligence has ordered all things
20134: according to the wisest ends. Consequently, the hypothesis of a wise
20135: author of the universe is necessary for my guidance in the
20136: investigation of nature—is the condition under which alone I can fulfil
20137: an end which is contingent indeed, but by no means unimportant.
20138: Moreover, since the result of my attempts so frequently confirms the
20139: utility of this assumption, and since nothing decisive can be adduced
20140: against it, it follows that it would be saying far too little to term
20141: my judgement, in this case, a mere opinion, and that, even in this
20142: theoretical connection, I may assert that I firmly believe in God.
20143: Still, if we use words strictly, this must not be called a practical,
20144: but a doctrinal belief, which the theology of nature (physico-theology)
20145: must also produce in my mind. In the wisdom of a Supreme Being, and in
20146: the shortness of life, so inadequate to the development of the glorious
20147: powers of human nature, we may find equally sufficient grounds for a
20148: doctrinal belief in the future life of the human soul.
20149: 
20150: The expression of belief is, in such cases, an expression of modesty
20151: from the objective point of view, but, at the same time, of firm
20152: confidence, from the subjective. If I should venture to term this
20153: merely theoretical judgement even so much as a hypothesis which I am
20154: entitled to assume; a more complete conception, with regard to another
20155: world and to the cause of the world, might then be justly required of
20156: me than I am, in reality, able to give. For, if I assume anything, even
20157: as a mere hypothesis, I must, at least, know so much of the properties
20158: of such a being as will enable me, not to form the conception, but to
20159: imagine the existence of it. But the word belief refers only to the
20160: guidance which an idea gives me, and to its subjective influence on the
20161: conduct of my reason, which forces me to hold it fast, though I may not
20162: be in a position to give a speculative account of it.
20163: 
20164: But mere doctrinal belief is, to some extent, wanting in stability. We
20165: often quit our hold of it, in consequence of the difficulties which
20166: occur in speculation, though in the end we inevitably return to it
20167: again.
20168: 
20169: It is quite otherwise with moral belief. For in this sphere action is
20170: absolutely necessary, that is, I must act in obedience to the moral law
20171: in all points. The end is here incontrovertibly established, and there
20172: is only one condition possible, according to the best of my perception,
20173: under which this end can harmonize with all other ends, and so have
20174: practical validity—namely, the existence of a God and of a future
20175: world. I know also, to a certainty, that no one can be acquainted with
20176: any other conditions which conduct to the same unity of ends under the
20177: moral law. But since the moral precept is, at the same time, my maxim
20178: (as reason requires that it should be), I am irresistibly constrained
20179: to believe in the existence of God and in a future life; and I am sure
20180: that nothing can make me waver in this belief, since I should thereby
20181: overthrow my moral maxims, the renunciation of which would render me
20182: hateful in my own eyes.
20183: 
20184: Thus, while all the ambitious attempts of reason to penetrate beyond
20185: the limits of experience end in disappointment, there is still enough
20186: left to satisfy us in a practical point of view. No one, it is true,
20187: will be able to boast that he knows that there is a God and a future
20188: life; for, if he knows this, he is just the man whom I have long wished
20189: to find. All knowledge, regarding an object of mere reason, can be
20190: communicated; and I should thus be enabled to hope that my own
20191: knowledge would receive this wonderful extension, through the
20192: instrumentality of his instruction. No, my conviction is not logical,
20193: but moral certainty; and since it rests on subjective grounds (of the
20194: moral sentiment), I must not even say: It is morally certain that there
20195: is a God, etc., but: I am morally certain, that is, my belief in God
20196: and in another world is so interwoven with my moral nature that I am
20197: under as little apprehension of having the former torn from me as of
20198: losing the latter.
20199: 
20200: The only point in this argument that may appear open to suspicion is
20201: that this rational belief presupposes the existence of moral
20202: sentiments. If we give up this assumption, and take a man who is
20203: entirely indifferent with regard to moral laws, the question which
20204: reason proposes, becomes then merely a problem for speculation and may,
20205: indeed, be supported by strong grounds from analogy, but not by such as
20206: will compel the most obstinate scepticism to give way.[79] But in these
20207: questions no man is free from all interest. For though the want of good
20208: sentiments may place him beyond the influence of moral interests, still
20209: even in this case enough may be left to make him fear the existence of
20210: God and a future life. For he cannot pretend to any certainty of the
20211: non-existence of God and of a future life, unless—since it could only
20212: be proved by mere reason, and therefore apodeictically—he is prepared
20213: to establish the impossibility of both, which certainly no reasonable
20214: man would undertake to do. This would be a negative belief, which could
20215: not, indeed, produce morality and good sentiments, but still could
20216: produce an analogon of these, by operating as a powerful restraint on
20217: the outbreak of evil dispositions.
20218: 
20219:  [79] The human mind (as, I believe, every rational being must of
20220:  necessity do) takes a natural interest in morality, although this
20221:  interest is not undivided, and may not be practically in
20222:  preponderance. If you strengthen and increase it, you will find the
20223:  reason become docile, more enlightened, and more capable of uniting
20224:  the speculative interest with the practical. But if you do not take
20225:  care at the outset, or at least midway, to make men good, you will
20226:  never force them into an honest belief.
20227: 
20228: 
20229: But, it will be said, is this all that pure reason can effect, in
20230: opening up prospects beyond the limits of experience? Nothing more than
20231: two articles of belief? Common sense could have done as much as this,
20232: without taking the philosophers to counsel in the matter!
20233: 
20234: I shall not here eulogize philosophy for the benefits which the
20235: laborious efforts of its criticism have conferred on human reason—even
20236: granting that its merit should turn out in the end to be only
20237: negative—for on this point something more will be said in the next
20238: section. But, I ask, do you require that that knowledge which concerns
20239: all men, should transcend the common understanding, and should only be
20240: revealed to you by philosophers? The very circumstance which has called
20241: forth your censure, is the best confirmation of the correctness of our
20242: previous assertions, since it discloses, what could not have been
20243: foreseen, that Nature is not chargeable with any partial distribution
20244: of her gifts in those matters which concern all men without distinction
20245: and that, in respect to the essential ends of human nature, we cannot
20246: advance further with the help of the highest philosophy, than under the
20247: guidance which nature has vouchsafed to the meanest understanding.
20248: 
20249: Chapter III. The Architectonic of Pure Reason
20250: 
20251: By the term architectonic I mean the art of constructing a system.
20252: Without systematic unity, our knowledge cannot become science; it will
20253: be an aggregate, and not a system. Thus architectonic is the doctrine
20254: of the scientific in cognition, and therefore necessarily forms part of
20255: our methodology.
20256: 
20257: Reason cannot permit our knowledge to remain in an unconnected and
20258: rhapsodistic state, but requires that the sum of our cognitions should
20259: constitute a system. It is thus alone that they can advance the ends of
20260: reason. By a system I mean the unity of various cognitions under one
20261: idea. This idea is the conception—given by reason—of the form of a
20262: whole, in so far as the conception determines à priori not only the
20263: limits of its content, but the place which each of its parts is to
20264: occupy. The scientific idea contains, therefore, the end and the form
20265: of the whole which is in accordance with that end. The unity of the
20266: end, to which all the parts of the system relate, and through which all
20267: have a relation to each other, communicates unity to the whole system,
20268: so that the absence of any part can be immediately detected from our
20269: knowledge of the rest; and it determines à priori the limits of the
20270: system, thus excluding all contingent or arbitrary additions. The whole
20271: is thus an organism (articulatio), and not an aggregate (coacervatio);
20272: it may grow from within (per intussusceptionem), but it cannot increase
20273: by external additions (per appositionem). It is, thus, like an animal
20274: body, the growth of which does not add any limb, but, without changing
20275: their proportions, makes each in its sphere stronger and more active.
20276: 
20277: We require, for the execution of the idea of a system, a schema, that
20278: is, a content and an arrangement of parts determined à priori by the
20279: principle which the aim of the system prescribes. A schema which is not
20280: projected in accordance with an idea, that is, from the standpoint of
20281: the highest aim of reason, but merely empirically, in accordance with
20282: accidental aims and purposes (the number of which cannot be
20283: predetermined), can give us nothing more than technical unity. But the
20284: schema which is originated from an idea (in which case reason presents
20285: us with aims à priori, and does not look for them to experience), forms
20286: the basis of architectonical unity. A science, in the proper
20287: acceptation of that term, cannot be formed technically, that is, from
20288: observation of the similarity existing between different objects, and
20289: the purely contingent use we make of our knowledge in concreto with
20290: reference to all kinds of arbitrary external aims; its constitution
20291: must be framed on architectonical principles, that is, its parts must
20292: be shown to possess an essential affinity, and be capable of being
20293: deduced from one supreme and internal aim or end, which forms the
20294: condition of the possibility of the scientific whole. The schema of a
20295: science must give à priori the plan of it (monogramma), and the
20296: division of the whole into parts, in conformity with the idea of the
20297: science; and it must also distinguish this whole from all others,
20298: according to certain understood principles.
20299: 
20300: No one will attempt to construct a science, unless he have some idea to
20301: rest on as a proper basis. But, in the elaboration of the science, he
20302: finds that the schema, nay, even the definition which he at first gave
20303: of the science, rarely corresponds with his idea; for this idea lies,
20304: like a germ, in our reason, its parts undeveloped and hid even from
20305: microscopical observation. For this reason, we ought to explain and
20306: define sciences, not according to the description which the originator
20307: gives of them, but according to the idea which we find based in reason
20308: itself, and which is suggested by the natural unity of the parts of the
20309: science already accumulated. For it will of ten be found that the
20310: originator of a science and even his latest successors remain attached
20311: to an erroneous idea, which they cannot render clear to themselves, and
20312: that they thus fail in determining the true content, the articulation
20313: or systematic unity, and the limits of their science.
20314: 
20315: It is unfortunate that, only after having occupied ourselves for a long
20316: time in the collection of materials, under the guidance of an idea
20317: which lies undeveloped in the mind, but not according to any definite
20318: plan of arrangement—nay, only after we have spent much time and labour
20319: in the technical disposition of our materials, does it become possible
20320: to view the idea of a science in a clear light, and to project,
20321: according to architectonical principles, a plan of the whole, in
20322: accordance with the aims of reason. Systems seem, like certain worms,
20323: to be formed by a kind of generatio aequivoca—by the mere confluence of
20324: conceptions, and to gain completeness only with the progress of time.
20325: But the schema or germ of all lies in reason; and thus is not only
20326: every system organized according to its own idea, but all are united
20327: into one grand system of human knowledge, of which they form members.
20328: For this reason, it is possible to frame an architectonic of all human
20329: cognition, the formation of which, at the present time, considering the
20330: immense materials collected or to be found in the ruins of old systems,
20331: would not indeed be very difficult. Our purpose at present is merely to
20332: sketch the plan of the architectonic of all cognition given by pure
20333: reason; and we begin from the point where the main root of human
20334: knowledge divides into two, one of which is reason. By reason I
20335: understand here the whole higher faculty of cognition, the rational
20336: being placed in contradistinction to the empirical.
20337: 
20338: If I make complete abstraction of the content of cognition, objectively
20339: considered, all cognition is, from a subjective point of view, either
20340: historical or rational. Historical cognition is cognitio ex datis,
20341: rational, cognitio ex principiis. Whatever may be the original source
20342: of a cognition, it is, in relation to the person who possesses it,
20343: merely historical, if he knows only what has been given him from
20344: another quarter, whether that knowledge was communicated by direct
20345: experience or by instruction. Thus the Person who has learned a system
20346: of philosophy—say the Wolfian—although he has a perfect knowledge of
20347: all the principles, definitions, and arguments in that philosophy, as
20348: well as of the divisions that have been made of the system, possesses
20349: really no more than an historical knowledge of the Wolfian system; he
20350: knows only what has been told him, his judgements are only those which
20351: he has received from his teachers. Dispute the validity of a
20352: definition, and he is completely at a loss to find another. He has
20353: formed his mind on another’s; but the imitative faculty is not the
20354: productive. His knowledge has not been drawn from reason; and although,
20355: objectively considered, it is rational knowledge, subjectively, it is
20356: merely historical. He has learned this or that philosophy and is merely
20357: a plaster cast of a living man. Rational cognitions which are
20358: objective, that is, which have their source in reason, can be so termed
20359: from a subjective point of view, only when they have been drawn by the
20360: individual himself from the sources of reason, that is, from
20361: principles; and it is in this way alone that criticism, or even the
20362: rejection of what has been already learned, can spring up in the mind.
20363: 
20364: All rational cognition is, again, based either on conceptions, or on
20365: the construction of conceptions. The former is termed philosophical,
20366: the latter mathematical. I have already shown the essential difference
20367: of these two methods of cognition in the first chapter. A cognition may
20368: be objectively philosophical and subjectively historical—as is the case
20369: with the majority of scholars and those who cannot look beyond the
20370: limits of their system, and who remain in a state of pupilage all their
20371: lives. But it is remarkable that mathematical knowledge, when committed
20372: to memory, is valid, from the subjective point of view, as rational
20373: knowledge also, and that the same distinction cannot be drawn here as
20374: in the case of philosophical cognition. The reason is that the only way
20375: of arriving at this knowledge is through the essential principles of
20376: reason, and thus it is always certain and indisputable; because reason
20377: is employed in concreto—but at the same time à priori—that is, in pure
20378: and, therefore, infallible intuition; and thus all causes of illusion
20379: and error are excluded. Of all the à priori sciences of reason,
20380: therefore, mathematics alone can be learned. Philosophy—unless it be in
20381: an historical manner—cannot be learned; we can at most learn to
20382: philosophize.
20383: 
20384: Philosophy is the system of all philosophical cognition. We must use
20385: this term in an objective sense, if we understand by it the archetype
20386: of all attempts at philosophizing, and the standard by which all
20387: subjective philosophies are to be judged. In this sense, philosophy is
20388: merely the idea of a possible science, which does not exist in
20389: concreto, but to which we endeavour in various ways to approximate,
20390: until we have discovered the right path to pursue—a path overgrown by
20391: the errors and illusions of sense—and the image we have hitherto tried
20392: in vain to shape has become a perfect copy of the great prototype.
20393: Until that time, we cannot learn philosophy—it does not exist; if it
20394: does, where is it, who possesses it, and how shall we know it? We can
20395: only learn to philosophize; in other words, we can only exercise our
20396: powers of reasoning in accordance with general principles, retaining at
20397: the same time, the right of investigating the sources of these
20398: principles, of testing, and even of rejecting them.
20399: 
20400: Until then, our conception of philosophy is only a scholastic
20401: conception—a conception, that is, of a system of cognition which we are
20402: trying to elaborate into a science; all that we at present know being
20403: the systematic unity of this cognition, and consequently the logical
20404: completeness of the cognition for the desired end. But there is also a
20405: cosmical conception (conceptus cosmicus) of philosophy, which has
20406: always formed the true basis of this term, especially when philosophy
20407: was personified and presented to us in the ideal of a philosopher. In
20408: this view philosophy is the science of the relation of all cognition to
20409: the ultimate and essential aims of human reason (teleologia rationis
20410: humanae), and the philosopher is not merely an artist—who occupies
20411: himself with conceptions—but a lawgiver, legislating for human reason.
20412: In this sense of the word, it would be in the highest degree arrogant
20413: to assume the title of philosopher, and to pretend that we had reached
20414: the perfection of the prototype which lies in the idea alone.
20415: 
20416: The mathematician, the natural philosopher, and the logician—how far
20417: soever the first may have advanced in rational, and the two latter in
20418: philosophical knowledge—are merely artists, engaged in the arrangement
20419: and formation of conceptions; they cannot be termed philosophers. Above
20420: them all, there is the ideal teacher, who employs them as instruments
20421: for the advancement of the essential aims of human reason. Him alone
20422: can we call philosopher; but he nowhere exists. But the idea of his
20423: legislative power resides in the mind of every man, and it alone
20424: teaches us what kind of systematic unity philosophy demands in view of
20425: the ultimate aims of reason. This idea is, therefore, a cosmical
20426: conception.[80]
20427: 
20428:  [80] By a cosmical conception, I mean one in which all men necessarily
20429:  take an interest; the aim of a science must accordingly be determined
20430:  according to scholastic conceptions, if it is regarded merely as a
20431:  means to certain arbitrarily proposed ends.
20432: 
20433: 
20434: In view of the complete systematic unity of reason, there can only be
20435: one ultimate end of all the operations of the mind. To this all other
20436: aims are subordinate, and nothing more than means for its attainment.
20437: This ultimate end is the destination of man, and the philosophy which
20438: relates to it is termed moral philosophy. The superior position
20439: occupied by moral philosophy, above all other spheres for the
20440: operations of reason, sufficiently indicates the reason why the
20441: ancients always included the idea—and in an especial manner—of moralist
20442: in that of philosopher. Even at the present day, we call a man who
20443: appears to have the power of self-government, even although his
20444: knowledge may be very limited, by the name of philosopher.
20445: 
20446: The legislation of human reason, or philosophy, has two objects—nature
20447: and freedom—and thus contains not only the laws of nature, but also
20448: those of ethics, at first in two separate systems, which, finally,
20449: merge into one grand philosophical system of cognition. The philosophy
20450: of nature relates to that which is, that of ethics to that which ought
20451: to be.
20452: 
20453: But all philosophy is either cognition on the basis of pure reason, or
20454: the cognition of reason on the basis of empirical principles. The
20455: former is termed pure, the latter empirical philosophy.
20456: 
20457: The philosophy of pure reason is either propædeutic, that is, an
20458: inquiry into the powers of reason in regard to pure à priori cognition,
20459: and is termed critical philosophy; or it is, secondly, the system of
20460: pure reason—a science containing the systematic presentation of the
20461: whole body of philosophical knowledge, true as well as illusory, given
20462: by pure reason—and is called metaphysic. This name may, however, be
20463: also given to the whole system of pure philosophy, critical philosophy
20464: included, and may designate the investigation into the sources or
20465: possibility of à priori cognition, as well as the presentation of the à
20466: priori cognitions which form a system of pure philosophy—excluding, at
20467: the same time, all empirical and mathematical elements.
20468: 
20469: Metaphysic is divided into that of the speculative and that of the
20470: practical use of pure reason, and is, accordingly, either the
20471: metaphysic of nature, or the metaphysic of ethics. The former contains
20472: all the pure rational principles—based upon conceptions alone (and thus
20473: excluding mathematics)—of all theoretical cognition; the latter, the
20474: principles which determine and necessitate à priori all action. Now
20475: moral philosophy alone contains a code of laws—for the regulation of
20476: our actions—which are deduced from principles entirely à priori. Hence
20477: the metaphysic of ethics is the only pure moral philosophy, as it is
20478: not based upon anthropological or other empirical considerations. The
20479: metaphysic of speculative reason is what is commonly called metaphysic
20480: in the more limited sense. But as pure moral philosophy properly forms
20481: a part of this system of cognition, we must allow it to retain the name
20482: of metaphysic, although it is not requisite that we should insist on so
20483: terming it in our present discussion.
20484: 
20485: It is of the highest importance to separate those cognitions which
20486: differ from others both in kind and in origin, and to take great care
20487: that they are not confounded with those with which they are generally
20488: found connected. What the chemist does in the analysis of substances,
20489: what the mathematician in pure mathematics, is, in a still higher
20490: degree, the duty of the philosopher, that the value of each different
20491: kind of cognition, and the part it takes in the operations of the mind,
20492: may be clearly defined. Human reason has never wanted a metaphysic of
20493: some kind, since it attained the power of thought, or rather of
20494: reflection; but it has never been able to keep this sphere of thought
20495: and cognition pure from all admixture of foreign elements. The idea of
20496: a science of this kind is as old as speculation itself; and what mind
20497: does not speculate—either in the scholastic or in the popular fashion?
20498: At the same time, it must be admitted that even thinkers by profession
20499: have been unable clearly to explain the distinction between the two
20500: elements of our cognition—the one completely à priori, the other à
20501: posteriori; and hence the proper definition of a peculiar kind of
20502: cognition, and with it the just idea of a science which has so long and
20503: so deeply engaged the attention of the human mind, has never been
20504: established. When it was said: “Metaphysic is the science of the first
20505: principles of human cognition,” this definition did not signalize a
20506: peculiarity in kind, but only a difference in degree; these first
20507: principles were thus declared to be more general than others, but no
20508: criterion of distinction from empirical principles was given. Of these
20509: some are more general, and therefore higher, than others; and—as we
20510: cannot distinguish what is completely à priori from that which is known
20511: to be à posteriori—where shall we draw the line which is to separate
20512: the higher and so-called first principles, from the lower and
20513: subordinate principles of cognition? What would be said if we were
20514: asked to be satisfied with a division of the epochs of the world into
20515: the earlier centuries and those following them? “Does the fifth, or the
20516: tenth century belong to the earlier centuries?” it would be asked. In
20517: the same way I ask: Does the conception of extension belong to
20518: metaphysics? You answer, “Yes.” Well, that of body too? “Yes.” And that
20519: of a fluid body? You stop, you are unprepared to admit this; for if you
20520: do, everything will belong to metaphysics. From this it is evident that
20521: the mere degree of subordination—of the particular to the
20522: general—cannot determine the limits of a science; and that, in the
20523: present case, we must expect to find a difference in the conceptions of
20524: metaphysics both in kind and in origin. The fundamental idea of
20525: metaphysics was obscured on another side by the fact that this kind of
20526: à priori cognition showed a certain similarity in character with the
20527: science of mathematics. Both have the property in common of possessing
20528: an à priori origin; but, in the one, our knowledge is based upon
20529: conceptions, in the other, on the construction of conceptions. Thus a
20530: decided dissimilarity between philosophical and mathematical cognition
20531: comes out—a dissimilarity which was always felt, but which could not be
20532: made distinct for want of an insight into the criteria of the
20533: difference. And thus it happened that, as philosophers themselves
20534: failed in the proper development of the idea of their science, the
20535: elaboration of the science could not proceed with a definite aim, or
20536: under trustworthy guidance. Thus, too, philosophers, ignorant of the
20537: path they ought to pursue and always disputing with each other
20538: regarding the discoveries which each asserted he had made, brought
20539: their science into disrepute with the rest of the world, and finally,
20540: even among themselves.
20541: 
20542: All pure à priori cognition forms, therefore, in view of the peculiar
20543: faculty which originates it, a peculiar and distinct unity; and
20544: metaphysic is the term applied to the philosophy which attempts to
20545: represent that cognition in this systematic unity. The speculative part
20546: of metaphysic, which has especially appropriated this appellation—that
20547: which we have called the metaphysic of nature—and which considers
20548: everything, as it is (not as it ought to be), by means of à priori
20549: conceptions, is divided in the following manner.
20550: 
20551: Metaphysic, in the more limited acceptation of the term, consists of
20552: two parts—transcendental philosophy and the physiology of pure reason.
20553: The former presents the system of all the conceptions and principles
20554: belonging to the understanding and the reason, and which relate to
20555: objects in general, but not to any particular given objects
20556: (Ontologia); the latter has nature for its subject-matter, that is, the
20557: sum of given objects—whether given to the senses, or, if we will, to
20558: some other kind of intuition—and is accordingly physiology, although
20559: only rationalis. But the use of the faculty of reason in this rational
20560: mode of regarding nature is either physical or hyperphysical, or, more
20561: properly speaking, immanent or transcendent. The former relates to
20562: nature, in so far as our knowledge regarding it may be applied in
20563: experience (in concreto); the latter to that connection of the objects
20564: of experience, which transcends all experience. Transcendent physiology
20565: has, again, an internal and an external connection with its object,
20566: both, however, transcending possible experience; the former is the
20567: physiology of nature as a whole, or transcendental cognition of the
20568: world, the latter of the connection of the whole of nature with a being
20569: above nature, or transcendental cognition of God.
20570: 
20571: Immanent physiology, on the contrary, considers nature as the sum of
20572: all sensuous objects, consequently, as it is presented to us—but still
20573: according to à priori conditions, for it is under these alone that
20574: nature can be presented to our minds at all. The objects of immanent
20575: physiology are of two kinds: 1. Those of the external senses, or
20576: corporeal nature; 2. The object of the internal sense, the soul, or, in
20577: accordance with our fundamental conceptions of it, thinking nature. The
20578: metaphysics of corporeal nature is called physics; but, as it must
20579: contain only the principles of an à priori cognition of nature, we must
20580: term it rational physics. The metaphysics of thinking nature is called
20581: psychology, and for the same reason is to be regarded as merely the
20582: rational cognition of the soul.
20583: 
20584: Thus the whole system of metaphysics consists of four principal parts:
20585: 1. Ontology; 2. Rational Physiology; 3. Rational cosmology; and 4.
20586: Rational theology. The second part—that of the rational doctrine of
20587: nature—may be subdivided into two, physica rationalis[81] and
20588: psychologia rationalis.
20589: 
20590:  [81] It must not be supposed that I mean by this appellation what is
20591:  generally called physica general is, and which is rather mathematics
20592:  than a philosophy of nature. For the metaphysic of nature is
20593:  completely different from mathematics, nor is it so rich in results,
20594:  although it is of great importance as a critical test of the
20595:  application of pure understanding—cognition to nature. For want of its
20596:  guidance, even mathematicians, adopting certain common notions—which
20597:  are, in fact, metaphysical—have unconsciously crowded their theories
20598:  of nature with hypotheses, the fallacy of which becomes evident upon
20599:  the application of the principles of this metaphysic, without
20600:  detriment, however, to the employment of mathematics in this sphere of
20601:  cognition.
20602: 
20603: 
20604: The fundamental idea of a philosophy of pure reason of necessity
20605: dictates this division; it is, therefore, architectonical—in accordance
20606: with the highest aims of reason, and not merely technical, or according
20607: to certain accidentally-observed similarities existing between the
20608: different parts of the whole science. For this reason, also, is the
20609: division immutable and of legislative authority. But the reader may
20610: observe in it a few points to which he ought to demur, and which may
20611: weaken his conviction of its truth and legitimacy.
20612: 
20613: In the first place, how can I desire an à priori cognition or
20614: metaphysic of objects, in so far as they are given à posteriori? and
20615: how is it possible to cognize the nature of things according to à
20616: priori principles, and to attain to a rational physiology? The answer
20617: is this. We take from experience nothing more than is requisite to
20618: present us with an object (in general) of the external or of the
20619: internal sense; in the former case, by the mere conception of matter
20620: (impenetrable and inanimate extension), in the latter, by the
20621: conception of a thinking being—given in the internal empirical
20622: representation, I think. As to the rest, we must not employ in our
20623: metaphysic of these objects any empirical principles (which add to the
20624: content of our conceptions by means of experience), for the purpose of
20625: forming by their help any judgements respecting these objects.
20626: 
20627: Secondly, what place shall we assign to empirical psychology, which has
20628: always been considered a part of metaphysics, and from which in our
20629: time such important philosophical results have been expected, after the
20630: hope of constructing an à priori system of knowledge had been
20631: abandoned? I answer: It must be placed by the side of empirical physics
20632: or physics proper; that is, must be regarded as forming a part of
20633: applied philosophy, the à priori principles of which are contained in
20634: pure philosophy, which is therefore connected, although it must not be
20635: confounded, with psychology. Empirical psychology must therefore be
20636: banished from the sphere of metaphysics, and is indeed excluded by the
20637: very idea of that science. In conformity, however, with scholastic
20638: usage, we must permit it to occupy a place in metaphysics—but only as
20639: an appendix to it. We adopt this course from motives of economy; as
20640: psychology is not as yet full enough to occupy our attention as an
20641: independent study, while it is, at the same time, of too great
20642: importance to be entirely excluded or placed where it has still less
20643: affinity than it has with the subject of metaphysics. It is a stranger
20644: who has been long a guest; and we make it welcome to stay, until it can
20645: take up a more suitable abode in a complete system of anthropology—the
20646: pendant to empirical physics.
20647: 
20648: The above is the general idea of metaphysics, which, as more was
20649: expected from it than could be looked for with justice, and as these
20650: pleasant expectations were unfortunately never realized, fell into
20651: general disrepute. Our Critique must have fully convinced the reader
20652: that, although metaphysics cannot form the foundation of religion, it
20653: must always be one of its most important bulwarks, and that human
20654: reason, which naturally pursues a dialectical course, cannot do without
20655: this science, which checks its tendencies towards dialectic and, by
20656: elevating reason to a scientific and clear self-knowledge, prevents the
20657: ravages which a lawless speculative reason would infallibly commit in
20658: the sphere of morals as well as in that of religion. We may be sure,
20659: therefore, whatever contempt may be thrown upon metaphysics by those
20660: who judge a science not by its own nature, but according to the
20661: accidental effects it may have produced, that it can never be
20662: completely abandoned, that we must always return to it as to a beloved
20663: one who has been for a time estranged, because the questions with which
20664: it is engaged relate to the highest aims of humanity, and reason must
20665: always labour either to attain to settled views in regard to these, or
20666: to destroy those which others have already established.
20667: 
20668: Metaphysic, therefore—that of nature, as well as that of ethics, but in
20669: an especial manner the criticism which forms the propædeutic to all
20670: the operations of reason—forms properly that department of knowledge
20671: which may be termed, in the truest sense of the word, philosophy. The
20672: path which it pursues is that of science, which, when it has once been
20673: discovered, is never lost, and never misleads. Mathematics, natural
20674: science, the common experience of men, have a high value as means, for
20675: the most part, to accidental ends—but at last also, to those which are
20676: necessary and essential to the existence of humanity. But to guide them
20677: to this high goal, they require the aid of rational cognition on the
20678: basis of pure conceptions, which, be it termed as it may, is properly
20679: nothing but metaphysics.
20680: 
20681: For the same reason, metaphysics forms likewise the completion of the
20682: culture of human reason. In this respect, it is indispensable, setting
20683: aside altogether the influence which it exerts as a science. For its
20684: subject-matter is the elements and highest maxims of reason, which form
20685: the basis of the possibility of some sciences and of the use of all.
20686: That, as a purely speculative science, it is more useful in preventing
20687: error than in the extension of knowledge, does not detract from its
20688: value; on the contrary, the supreme office of censor which it occupies
20689: assures to it the highest authority and importance. This office it
20690: administers for the purpose of securing order, harmony, and well-being
20691: to science, and of directing its noble and fruitful labours to the
20692: highest possible aim—the happiness of all mankind.
20693: 
20694: Chapter IV. The History of Pure Reason
20695: 
20696: This title is placed here merely for the purpose of designating a
20697: division of the system of pure reason of which I do not intend to treat
20698: at present. I shall content myself with casting a cursory glance, from
20699: a purely transcendental point of view—that of the nature of pure
20700: reason—on the labours of philosophers up to the present time. They have
20701: aimed at erecting an edifice of philosophy; but to my eye this edifice
20702: appears to be in a very ruinous condition.
20703: 
20704: It is very remarkable, although naturally it could not have been
20705: otherwise, that, in the infancy of philosophy, the study of the nature
20706: of God and the constitution of a future world formed the commencement,
20707: rather than the conclusion, as we should have it, of the speculative
20708: efforts of the human mind. However rude the religious conceptions
20709: generated by the remains of the old manners and customs of a less
20710: cultivated time, the intelligent classes were not thereby prevented
20711: from devoting themselves to free inquiry into the existence and nature
20712: of God; and they easily saw that there could be no surer way of
20713: pleasing the invisible ruler of the world, and of attaining to
20714: happiness in another world at least, than a good and honest course of
20715: life in this. Thus theology and morals formed the two chief motives, or
20716: rather the points of attraction in all abstract inquiries. But it was
20717: the former that especially occupied the attention of speculative
20718: reason, and which afterwards became so celebrated under the name of
20719: metaphysics.
20720: 
20721: I shall not at present indicate the periods of time at which the
20722: greatest changes in metaphysics took place, but shall merely give a
20723: hasty sketch of the different ideas which occasioned the most important
20724: revolutions in this sphere of thought. There are three different ends
20725: in relation to which these revolutions have taken place.
20726: 
20727: 1. In relation to the object of the cognition of reason, philosophers
20728: may be divided into sensualists and intellectualists. Epicurus may be
20729: regarded as the head of the former, Plato of the latter. The
20730: distinction here signalized, subtle as it is, dates from the earliest
20731: times, and was long maintained. The former asserted that reality
20732: resides in sensuous objects alone, and that everything else is merely
20733: imaginary; the latter, that the senses are the parents of illusion and
20734: that truth is to be found in the understanding alone. The former did
20735: not deny to the conceptions of the understanding a certain kind of
20736: reality; but with them it was merely logical, with the others it was
20737: mystical. The former admitted intellectual conceptions, but declared
20738: that sensuous objects alone possessed real existence. The latter
20739: maintained that all real objects were intelligible, and believed that
20740: the pure understanding possessed a faculty of intuition apart from
20741: sense, which, in their opinion, served only to confuse the ideas of the
20742: understanding.
20743: 
20744: 2. In relation to the origin of the pure cognitions of reason, we find
20745: one school maintaining that they are derived entirely from experience,
20746: and another that they have their origin in reason alone. Aristotle may
20747: be regarded as the head of the empiricists, and Plato of the
20748: noologists. Locke, the follower of Aristotle in modern times, and
20749: Leibnitz of Plato (although he cannot be said to have imitated him in
20750: his mysticism), have not been able to bring this question to a settled
20751: conclusion. The procedure of Epicurus in his sensual system, in which
20752: he always restricted his conclusions to the sphere of experience, was
20753: much more consequent than that of Aristotle and Locke. The latter
20754: especially, after having derived all the conceptions and principles of
20755: the mind from experience, goes so far, in the employment of these
20756: conceptions and principles, as to maintain that we can prove the
20757: existence of God and the existence of God and the immortality of them
20758: objects lying beyond the soul—both of them of possible experience—with
20759: the same force of demonstration as any mathematical proposition.
20760: 
20761: 3. In relation to method. Method is procedure according to principles.
20762: We may divide the methods at present employed in the field of inquiry
20763: into the naturalistic and the scientific. The naturalist of pure reason
20764: lays it down as his principle that common reason, without the aid of
20765: science—which he calls sound reason, or common sense—can give a more
20766: satisfactory answer to the most important questions of metaphysics than
20767: speculation is able to do. He must maintain, therefore, that we can
20768: determine the content and circumference of the moon more certainly by
20769: the naked eye, than by the aid of mathematical reasoning. But this
20770: system is mere misology reduced to principles; and, what is the most
20771: absurd thing in this doctrine, the neglect of all scientific means is
20772: paraded as a peculiar method of extending our cognition. As regards
20773: those who are naturalists because they know no better, they are
20774: certainly not to be blamed. They follow common sense, without parading
20775: their ignorance as a method which is to teach us the wonderful secret,
20776: how we are to find the truth which lies at the bottom of the well of
20777: Democritus.
20778: 
20779: Quod sapio satis est mihi, non ego curo Esse quod
20780: Arcesilas aerumnosiqueSolones. PERSIUS
20781: —Satirae, iii. 78-79.
20782: 
20783: 
20784:  is their motto, under which they may lead a pleasant and praiseworthy
20785:  life, without troubling themselves with science or troubling science
20786:  with them.
20787: 
20788: As regards those who wish to pursue a scientific method, they have now
20789: the choice of following either the dogmatical or the sceptical, while
20790: they are bound never to desert the systematic mode of procedure. When I
20791: mention, in relation to the former, the celebrated Wolf, and as regards
20792: the latter, David Hume, I may leave, in accordance with my present
20793: intention, all others unnamed. The critical path alone is still open.
20794: If my reader has been kind and patient enough to accompany me on this
20795: hitherto untravelled route, he can now judge whether, if he and others
20796: will contribute their exertions towards making this narrow footpath a
20797: high road of thought, that which many centuries have failed to
20798: accomplish may not be executed before the close of the present—namely,
20799: to bring Reason to perfect contentment in regard to that which has
20800: always, but without permanent results, occupied her powers and engaged
20801: her ardent desire for knowledge.
